Interesting performance to understand the Vietnamese folklore but the entire programme is in Vietnamese, no translation at all, so it is best you grab a copy of the programme list before the start of the show. The sequence of the performance as follows:1. Prelude by clown Teu2. Thang Long festival drumming3. Dragon's dance4. Buffalo-boy playing the flute5. Agricultural work (rice planting, soil ploughing, water scooping)6. Catching frogs7. Chasing teh fox that tries to catch the ducks8. Fishing9. Xa thuong 10. Phoenix's dance11. Le Lai returning the sword12. Unicorn's dance13. Eight fairies' dance14. Four sacred animals' dance (dragon, unicorn, tortoise, phoenix)You can catch the 620pm or 8pm performance if you are returning from Ha Long bay trip on the same day.The location of the theatre is above a cafe, do ask around. The shop keepers near the theatre are very helpful to direct you to the theatre location.

Freddie Mercury on a water buffalo, hilarious. No idea what was meant to be going on, but it was hilarious. If you go expecting a camp and rather strange Punch and Judy show, you will love it. The puppets are amazing, I loved the fire breathing dragons and laughed aloud at the Freddie Mercury doing strange things to a water buffalo. Kids will love it and a beer or two before is a good idea!

Fantastic. My better half wanted to go to this attraction. I was curious but was not expecting much. It was fascinating and worth the visit for much more money. There is a great cafe next door and check the scene of chaos on the road. I digress! The musicians and singers accompanying the puppets are true professionals. Enjoy!

some local culture. we really enjoyed the play. we got complimentary tickets from our hotel (Art Trendy). English information was on the program so you could understand what was happening.the theatre seating is designed for the people of Vietnam, so if you are taller than 5'-10" you are going to have trouble finding room for your legs when you sit down.

Just go with the flow. The simple stories reflect life and concerns of a thousand years ago and are skilfully done. Each of the 15 or so tableaux last two or three minutes and if you grab the English programme summary (other languages available) on the way in, you will know what is roughly going on. Ticket seats are individually numbered and cost between 60-100k each, depending on where you choose to sit. Far better to get the tickets at the theatre than pay package tour prices that will be many times that. Shows are roughly every 60-70 minutes from 3pm in the afternoon. When you come out of the theatre auditorium, turn left (don't go down the exit stairs) and walk around to the small attached cafe and have a drink and watch the world go by. When you do go downstairs to the little shop counter, look at buying the the puppet dolls as presents. At some £2.50 (US$4) each, they are a real and quirky reminder of old Vietnam Nam.

Charming. The Vietnamese water puppet show seems to divide opinions. We booked our own tickets for an afternoon performance (£7 for 2). Excellent value considering what tour companies try and charge. The theatre is air conditioned and the raked seating is comfortable. If you take children book early so that you can sit in the front so they will be able to see easily. We thought it was a charming show. I think that if you go with an open mind, like art and music and enjoy seeing things out of the ordinary then you too will appreciate it. The various ancient musical instruments look interesting, amongst them a bamboo flute and something that looks and sounds very much like a theremin (sort of electronic stringed instrument which was seemingly only "invented" in the west in the early part of the 20th century). The show is a sort of Vietnamese version of a Punch and Judy type show but using traditional wooden puppets in a water setting. The puppets being operated by unseen puppeteers behind a bamboo curtain. As you go in pick up a leaflet in English and you will have a better understanding of the 15 little scenes each lasting about 3 minutes. In fact we liked it so much we bought a couple of delightful jointed wooden puppets afterwards. Fantastic value and great souvenir of our holiday costing £5 for 2 (80,000 VND). Cheaper than 2 beers and a lasting reminder, what can be better than that?

good place to see traditional art performance of Vietnam. How could you imagine that wood puppets could move as real people. On the surface of water, wood puppets could climb the tree. All because of the very skillful control Technic of the artist. Very funny, very attractive. One you enter the performance room, you could be in a fairyland ...

A Kid Show.... look up videos and decide if its for you. can't believe the wide range of reviews, guess it depends on your background.For grown adults from the US, chances are you could care less for the 50 minute show. Nothing except the beginning in English so you have to guess on the story line.if you have small kids chances are they will enjoy it. Cost is very cheap and was included in our tour.Once is enough for me. Google videos before deciding if you want to go.

A must in Vietnam!. Water puppet shows are a cultural icon in Vietnam. It started in the north almost a thousand years ago but is struggling to survive in the modern age. The puppets are made of lacquered wood and are replaced every 8 months. They are controlled by puppeteers behind a screen on long poles. The show is less than an hour long and not in English but that doesn't matter. The show is a treat.

Great fun - unusual and dramatic puppet show. We managed to get tickets on the door for the next show - the seats were 'extra' and half price as they were temporary seats with a near perfect view of the stage. The show is a sequence of scenes of village life, some were very funny and some quite dramatic. The whole is accompanied by traditional music. It is good value and well worth seeing.

Not seeing a water puppet performance in Vietnam would be like traveling to Paris and not seeing the Eiffel Tower. Hope the following information might be of interest. Water puppets is a tradition that dates back to the 11th century, where it originated in the villages of the Red River Delta area of Northern Vietnam. Originally water puppet festivals were literally held inside a rice paddy. When the rice fields would flood, the villagers would entertain each other using this form of puppet play. And it was a popular way to celebrate the rice harvest.  A traditional Vietnamese orchestra provides background music during the show. Which includes vocals, drums, wooden bells, cymbals, horns, Đàn bầu (monochord), gongs, and bamboo flutes. The bamboo flute's clear, simple notes may accompany royalty while the drums and cymbals may loudly announce a fire-breathing dragon's entrance.The puppets are made out of wood and then lacquered. The shows are performed in a waist-deep pool. A large rod supports the puppet under the water and is used by the puppeteers, who are normally hidden behind a screen, to control them. Thus the puppets appear to be moving over the water.Tickets are in-expenses and performances only last about 45 minutes.

Unique water puppet show with live music. Our hotel booked the water puppet show in Hanoi, which is a unique form of entertainment in Vietnam. There is now an introduction in English, French and Vietnamese. There is also live music with traditional Vietnamese instruments. I'm glad the theater has now asked people to not video tape or take photographs, as in the past raised tablets and phones obscured the views of those in the back rows. Without this distraction, you are able to enjoy this unique form of entertainment. While it is in Vietnamese, you do not need to understand what they are saying. Much like "Tom and Jerry", the humor and intent comes from the action itself. My children enjoyed it very much as well. It is $5 well-spent and a nice respite from the heat and crowds of Hanoi.

The water puppets are one of the few genuinely Vietnamese treats. This is a real cultural experience, like going to the acrobatics in Beijing it is an important aspect of the Vietnamese culture and much more interesting than I was expecting. It was good to see this show and get an idea of what was entertainment back in the old days. the seats were uncomfortable and it started heating up. The tickets sell very quickly to the show.

Worst show we have ever seen. Avoid this.. This is a tourist trap....do not go unless you are under 10 years of age....and even then reconsider....We paid $6 to see this show and it was not worth it. The show takes place in a nice theater with good seating. The set is fine and there is a sextet which accompanies the activity on various different instruments, including a drum set, a half coconut shell and cymbals. The players are the best part of the show, by far. But if this were my job, I would be searching for another one. The show consists of eight people standing in water behind a bamboo curtain and using long wooden poles to manoeuvre various puppets around the water basin. They move left, then right, then left, then upstage, then downstage....all with amazing predictability and all to atonal Vietnamese music. There were 12 "different" pieces with different puppets in each but the only difference we saw was in the different plastic figures moving monotonously around the water. There was no explanation about the show....at one point I thought that that perhaps they were re-enacting children's fairy tales....but your guess would be as good as mine. It was very painful to watch and we would have left after 5 minutes if it were at all possible. We could not even make ourselves applaud. You would do well to skip this. This is now our benchmark against which we will measure other awful shows.

Brilliant little show. Don't be put off by the extremely tourist centric location, and the hordes of people trying to catch one of its 5-6 daily shows. Instead, get in there, and then let these guys sweep you off your feet. The show is touching and funny, and best of all, extremely skilfully performed. Less than an hour. Great event for the day -- highly recommended.

Breath taking water puppet show. Best and first water puppet show I've ever seen! The show starts with typically Vietnamese music which is something very special and breath taking. It's perfect for the first impression of Vietnam and introduces oneself very well into the country.Afterwards the water puppet show starts which is also accompanied by the music. This show is amazing and undiscradebly good. The atmosphere of the theater is like in an old big cinema and fits perfect to the whole concept.

A must see but not the greatest experience.. It was OK, it is probably on most tourists list of "must sees" in Hanoi, it was only 45 minutes in length and about £3 for top seats consequently worth doing. But in honesty, any more than the length of this show would have bored me. The orchestra were joking between each other and someone off stage which was distracting, after all if they are bored then not great for the audience.

Not very impressed . I went to this theatre full of enthusiasm as so many people recommended it but honestly I did not enjoy it too much. It is an average show, not particularly outstanding. It is still cheap and may be worth the money if you are interested in understanding the vietnamise culture
Fascinating. Very cleverly done. Could not understand the dialogue but the music was beautiful. Well worth watching because of its uniqueness.

Good, traditional Vietnamese fun. A completely unique Vietnamese experience. Yes all the dialogue is in Vietnamese and it is likely you won't understand everything that is happening (unless you speak Vietnamese of course) but that really doesn't matter. The puppets are beautiful and the way they are operated is incredibly clever and lovely to watch. We primarily went for our two children (aged 9 & 6) but actually we all loved it. Would be a shame to miss it if you are in Hanoi given that you can't see this in any other country.

Ok. It was ok.... It was included in our tour, we were tired when we got to the theatre and the show was 50 mins long.... 40 mins too long for us.. It was quite boring, but I've seen it.. That's all I can say. Its obviously for tourists as I can't imagine anybody going twice..

Strange little show. Tickets for this show are only 100000 and it entertained us for 40mins. The puppetry is cool, but the musicians were disinterested and talking onstage, which was heard over the traditional instruments. Good to see.

More for the kids.. Whilst I do appreciate history and creativity, without understanding the history and background of water puppets in Vietnam, I found the show to be a bit boring. So I would suggest reading up on the background history and the stories presented in the show before going to gain a greater appreciation. The kids in the audience seemed to enjoy it though. I wouldn't go again.

Wonderful. We really enjoyed this show. Very entertaining and the live music was just lovely. The seats are crammed in, but the show only lasts for an hour. Book early if you want good seats. Also make sure you ask to see the seating plan when you book, as they seemed to try and get rid of the seats right at the back (row P) to tourist who don't know any better.
An average experience . In our first day in Hanoi our tour guide organized a visit to the water puppet show. The live traditional music was interesting and the puppets were well designed.

I just didn't get it. I feel bad giving this show a bad review. Maybe it's just a lack of culture in me, but I'm going to be honest and say that this was one of the strangest and un entertaining shows I've ever gone to.In fairness, I didn't want to go in the first place. But it was really boring. It might have been a great show for Vietnamese kids, but for people who don't speak Vietnamese there isn't really any point.There were people around me who looked like they were enjoying it, but i think they were just faking it in order to look sophisticated. Both my eyes and ears hurt after the show and the woman at the ticket desk was a bit rude too

A pleasant evening diversion. The show was fascinating and well done, however, despite a brief summary of the story, it was hard to follow the story line throughout. Admittedly, I was really tired that night, and if my brain had been functioning on all its pistons I might have made more sense of it.

Nostalgia. We went here with my 80 year old father because when we were kids, he used to take us to the water puppet show in Saigon. it was crowded and warm inside the theater. it is as popular and well loved now as it was then. i think compared to other attractions, some people may be disappointed. but more than the art, there is the deep rooted tradition that makes it special. there are assigned seats so you don't need to line up early. but i suggest you buy your tickets ahead of time and then walk around the lake across the street/visit the temple on the lake/etc as it sells out.

Unique, fun experience in Hanoi. I had a great time watching this show. The musicians are amazing, and there's always something new to see with the puppets. It's really well put together, and a great way to spend time in Hanoi! I'd love to go back.

Very enjoyable show. The puppets appear from everywhere, very intriguing how the puppeteers are able to move them around without getting tangled up. Language was no barrier to enjoying and understanding.

Must do ONCE. This is such a unique art that is probably hard to keep alive in a fast paced world. And it tells important Vietnamese folklore. Interesting to see for foreigners, especially when the puppeteers reveal themselves at the end. The tales and music can be strange to foreigners and one hour, once is enough.

So much fun. This show was so much fun. The hour was the perfect amount of time and the nice cool theater was a great break from the heat. I had read a lot of reviews about it being over-rated, but if you understand it it an ancient puppet show then you can get a good laugh. The singers and musicians were amazing.

nice to see!!. It takes you only 1 hour of your time, costs vnd 100.000 and it is really worth going there. It is good fun and tells the story of the daily vietnamese life and some myths. We enjoyed it very much!!

Worth the money. This is worth the experience, being a middle aged couple without children we had a good time. Yes it is not in English, but I found myself laughing out loud a few times. You can use your imagination some and really get a great experience. I encourage everyone to see it, but take into consideration the negative points from others reviews about cameras flashing, no leg room, and babies crying, but even with all that it is only a 45 minute show and well worth the $5USD.

Very Clever. Very cheap, well put together show, all speaking is done in Vietnamese which is a shame , makes it hard too follow storyline. Live music is very good. If you pay the bit extra to film or photograph show make sure you have a seat in the first or second row because all puppets are quite low set and all you get is the tops of heads if not seating up front.A nice way to kill a hour or two..

A pleasant way to spend an hour. During a recent visit to Hanoi we managed to secure tickets to this light hearted Water Puppet Theatre. It lasted less than an hour with traditional Vietnamese music and skilful artists performing in a colourful setting and the charge was next to nothing. They entertained a full house on the day we were there and from the buses outside I imagine that would be the case each time they perform. It is not Punch and Judy but you don't need to understand art to enjoy this delightful production. My only beef was that we were crammed in and if you have long legs - good luck.
Wonderful story telling in a unique way. A wonderful show with 12 shorts stories told by music on historical instruments and the wonderful picturesque Water Puppets. Don't miss it!

Done in the water!. In a theatre in the centre of Hanoi you will find a most interesting performance with skillful artists working for hours totally unseen in the water. Stories, classical, are told through puppets in water and surrounded by vietnamese traditional music and instruments. Lovely! See it!

Great but can be difficult to see the stage. Unique to Vietnam (I think), interesting and amusing. It is held in a theatre and the show of music and puppetry lasts about 45 minutes. There is, however, a problem about seeing the stage. Although the seating is banked, anyone over 6feet tall sat one or two rows in front of you can be a major obstacle, especially when they then hold up an ipad to film the show! Tip - if you want a photo, take your smartphone rather than a camera (probably better in low light and avoids the 25000 VND camera fee), but please use it with consideration..

It's Not Punch and Judy. I have read some complaints about not understanding the content of the show, perhaps you should do a little investigation to what it is about before visiting, I had been in Hanoi less than one day when I learnt of the Legend of the Lake, which is what the show is about.For anyone who complains it was in Vietnamese, just remember where you are, you do not need to understand art to enjoy it, the music with the instruments and vocalists is to be absorbed and enjoyed, at such a reasonable price for almost an hours entertainment it should not be criticized.As regards the seating there are seats up either sides of the theatre for those with long legs, we had a most enjoyable and amusing time at this great little show, now think on, if a Vietnamese person came to a British resort and watched a Punch and Judy Show what do you think they would make of it?

Unique show . New sounds, instruments and colorful setting will attract your eyes. It is a unique show worth seeing even without kids who seem to have a great time in the show. Buy your tickets in advance because in high season shows sell out really quickly. Narrow seats can be quite uncomfortable yet it's a short show.

Good entertainment. We weren't really sure what to expect and were delighted with the water puppet show. Although its in Vietnamese, there wasn't a huge amount of dialogue so it was reasonably easy to follow the short sketches.The musicians were excellent and of course the puppeteers.The fact that its done in water is very unusual, and our two boys aged 5 and 3 enjoyed it.Be warned it gets very busy at the weekend so its advisable to book in advance.We bought our tickets at the theatre and were not charged for our 3 year old.

Good entertainment. I enjoyed the show which is very well done but unless you are in the front row do not pay to take pictures as it is impossible to get any decent ones. On exiting they do have some small puppets for sale but no postcards to buy and was unable to find any pictures of the water puppet show anywhere.

intriguing art. not quite sure what some of the stories meant. Would have been better to see at the end of our trip so we had an idea. Lovely live music and very skilled puppeteers. 60,000dong entry fee

Different Entertainment. I really loved the music and seeing instruments that you don't see and hear in the U.S. It is interesting how they do it. They speak in English. The stories are juvenile, but you are seeing how they were originally made. It is well worth seeing. It will be a lost art one day. The shows sell out quickly, but only in days not weeks.

Charming. This is something I have never seen anywhere else. It seems to be typically Vietnamese. Yes some of the music is hard on "western ears" but even tho it was all in Vietnamese, it was easy to understand. The show consists of 14 different "acts" or scenes, things like fishing or rice planting, or dragons. I found them all to be cute, charming and unique.The show is about an hour long and I think worth the time.We were with a group and seated right near the front which I think added to the enjoyment

Clever - But Storylines Hard to Follow. Very cleaver puppetry and visually stunning, but some brief commentary in English to describe each act would have really enhanced the experience for us. Pretty crammed seating. Tip - don't arrive late for the show as it is very dark and hard to get to seating.
Great piece of Vietnamese entertainment. Low price, something that I've never seen before, nice theatre and overall it was fun. Definitely recommend

Unique-See It. It's not everyday you see puppets splashing around in the water. The show is well done, sometimes humorous, and inexpensive ($5.00USD for the good seats). Book through your hotel. There are usually 5 performances a day. The show itself last about 45 minutes. You can take pictures (no charge). After the show we recommend a massage at SF Spa and dinner at the Gia Ngu restaurant. Both are near the Water Puppet Theater.

So different!. This one hour show in the Old Quarter is great fun for all. The musical accompaniment is played on unique instruments, unknown to western orchestras. The vocal music is an acquired taste, but not as screechy as Chinese opera :) Underwater sticks hold large puppets who enact brief skits, some funny, some sweet, some dramatic. It was a marvelous experience - especially for $5! There are many shows a day, and your hotel is happy to make arrangements for tickets. Do try to see it!

Worth a visit!! . Both of us weren't quite in the mood for anymore sightseeing or food so we decided to check out the 3pm water puppet show and I have to say it was a great afternoon out. It was quite unique and funny to watch! Definitely recommend going to see some traditional Vietnamese culture! Great show

Probably good for kids, just OK for adults. We went to the puppet show mostly because it was raining, and we had already gone to a couple museums that day. We just wanted to sit somewhere air conditioned and relax away from the rain. Given the circumstances, the puppet show was an OK way to spend an hour on a rainy afternoon. As others have mentioned, the seats have very little legroom - I am 5'8" and was feeling really cramped. The show itself is in Vietnamese and we did not have a program so it was a little hard to follow what was going on - but it was still entertaining and it was fun watching the puppets and trying to figure out how the puppeteers do it. I think this show would be very good for families with young children. For adults, it's OK, but there are probably better ways to spend an hour in Hanoi.

Should see the water puppet show if in Hanoi. Interesting cultural experience! Although difficult to follow along because the story is told in Vietnamese, it was still a really good show.When purchasing our ticket, the woman at the counter told us they were all sold out for the later show so we said we were leaving. Once we said that, she said she would sell us tickets for the show that started within the next 5 minutes. Strange as I think she just wanted us to buy tickets then and not for the later show. Anyways still worth seeing if in Hanoi!

The first water puppet show of our life.. The singers, the musitians were great. The various shows by the puppetiers were grand and unimaginable. We have seen the normal puppet shows with controls from the top but to imagine how were they controlling so many puppets at a time was fascinating. There were 8 puppetiers doing the show.

Average depends on your seat. The show is good, something that I never seen before but the problem was I was always distracted by mobiles, I pads and any kind of technology available in front of my seat. They should ban the use of tech devices. Like in cinemas.

Please visit if you have chance.. Cultural highlight of Hanoi.As the name suggests it is a puppet show in the water. Is reported as being based deep in Vietnamese historyWell worth watching and very good value. Even though we did not fully understand the story we still enjoyed watching with a few laughs in the show.Only lasts a hour so not a big event.
Great show!. Such a different slow and great tradition! All the performers seemed to love what they do! This was a funny and all-around amusing performance! Would definitely recommend for all ages!
A good experience. We went to this show whilst staying in Hanoi. We hadn't experienced this type of show before and thought it was good. Worth seeing once at least, just for the experience.
Boring. Don't waste your time. Every one around me after the show said how bored they were. Was not in English so couldn't follow the story line at all.

A Cultural Treat. We visited the Thang Long Water Puppet Theater in February, 2015. Our guide purchased tickets for us in the second row. The theater seating gave everyone a nice view of the stage. The show was accompanied by a folk music ensemble, performing with traditional Vietnamese musical instruments. The singers also provided narration for the 14 water puppet vignettes, such as "Catching Frogs," "Dragon's Dance," and "Fishing." The entire show was charming, colorful and interesting, with all of the vignettes having a humorous touch. No one was smoking in the theater. People were taking photos, but were not using flash. We thought the show was very engaging and would recommend it as a cultural experience and for its entertainment value. We thoroughly enjoyed it!

Spoiled by the Tourists!!. Do yourself a favour and get there early and book a show later on to get a seat as close to the front as possible. The theatre is very cramped for seating and there are many stupid tourists that record large parts of the show on iPads, iPhones and cameras by holding them high above their heads to get a view above the other idiots in front doing the same thing. Unfortunately if you are at the back you just get to watch it through somebody's iPad or other recording device - very frustrating!The show itself was worthy of a visit and very cleverly done. If the authorities can just tell people they can't record then it would assist greatly in everybody's enjoyment.

Only for child not for adult. This is one of must things to do in Hanoi so we went to buy ticket in the morning. We had to buy the first class ticket because the lady who sold the ticket told us there is no second class seat anymore. When the show started we realized there is no difference between first class and secone one. Just don't buy expensive ticktet. About the show, contents is just childish not interesting much. Traditional music was only thing that we could enjoy. If you have a child and can get a cheap ticket, it would be worth.
A good show for adults and children.. Good fun to watch. The program in English outlined each skit. As often occurs there were smokers in the audience and the air was irritating to my eyes.

I've seen several, this was best -of all the countries.. Front row seats are best for American girth. Fun evening - puppets glow, dance, some breathe fire and smoke, some spew water - all are playful and tell universal stories , Music is first rate! Singing voices are clear and beautiful. Drums, violin and lights are dramatic and background scenery is recognizable. Laughter is the best critic - and this show was. Success! WC on first floor, shop available upon exit, beautiful building, very popular place with locals .
Fun and colorful. Amazingly full performances and obviously a great highlight. We got the full 14 displays and would recommend this show.

Unique for sure but not very entertaining. I read the reviews before going and I knew not to expect a fun show, but just a unique one. And it definitely was a unique experience, seeing the puppets 'dance' in the water. They tried to add in a couple scenes of comical relief usually involving animals. The seats are tightly packed, and my legs had to be pushed pretty hard against the back of the seat in front of me.I found myself somewhat bored about halfway through, and maybe that's on me for failing to appreciate a different form of performing arts, but that was my personal experience. Some people - including the entire row behind me - left in the middle of the show, which I found rude and distracting. They really couldn't sit through a 40 minute show?Two types of tickets. The more expensive ones are in the front and the cheaper ones are toward the back, but the theater is very small and it really doesn't matter where you sit. Just hope you don't sit behind someone taking photos the entire performance.

The flooding history. This play tells the history of the rice farmers during the flooding times when most of the fields stay under water.It is a must see attraction while in Hanoi.I suggest to buy the tickets early if you want to watch the show on the same day since it gets oversold easily.

Spectacular........ As we settled down into our seats, the musicians took over. They played beautifully on traditional instruments. As they played and sang the puppets unfolded on the water stage.Water puppetry dates back to almost the 11thC and is well preserved and very popular even today. The puppets skim and dance on the water, maneuvered by puppeteers with bamboo rods and strings. They enact popular tales laden with humour. The show is just about an hour long. It's very colourful and entertaining. One doesn't need to know the language to enjoy it. The actions are elaborate enough to know what's going on. A must-see in Vietnam.

Amazing, Entertaining but Seating is Unbelievably Cramped.. Read up on the Story, the show is in Vietnamese only. The music from the ten piece live orchestra is also Vietnamese. What do you expect you are in a foreign country and many English speaking people think everyone should understand them and speak the language. That being said the show is highly entertaining and how the water puppets perform is totally amazing. The big and really big deterrent is the totally cramped seating. Anyone with long legs will be squeezed beyond belief. Luckily for me, the usher saw I could not even sit down and let me sit in a foldup chair on the aisle. Not a bad idea to ask for, so you can fully enjoy the show. There are ten puppeteers out of sight during the show. They do things with the puppets that are astounding. So except for the big, big problem of tight, tight seating the show is very special and just enjoy it without an English translation. I wasn't disappointed

Surprisingly entertaining and fun!. We went to the Puppet theatre because it has a long tradition in Vietnam and we'd never seen anything like it before. Going in we were up for a laugh and didn't think much of it. The tickets don't have seat numbers on them so we took up seats in the first row. Good choice! No splashing like they warn you in LP books. We were so surprised of how much we enjoyed it. You can follow the story kind of but not into too much detail. But you can see the puppet masters are skilled, there's fire and smoke and absolutely beautiful traditional music performed by the live band. It was funny and fun. Definitely recommend. It only takes up an hour of your time.

Great for kids and adults alike. The live music and performance as flawless. My only complaint was that without a program or english, I didn't really know what was going on. I like when there is an english program with an explanation of the scenes so I can kind of follow along. But aside from that it was still worth the money for the hour long show.

Puppets and water in a show (what more could you want)!. The water puppet show in held in a theatre by the lake - it's a traditional Vietnamese show, there is singing and puppets in water, you can sort of follow the story (there is talking in Vietnamese and live music / signing). The show lasts just under an hour (which is probably the amount of time you can sit in a seat with very limited leg room). Tickets are very reasonably priced and my tip would be to get a ticket on the front row with more leg room!The amount of money spent on the ticket represents the entertainment value of the show - if you are expecting something very sophisticated, then maybe not for you.
Worth a visit. we kind of stumbled upon the show, while walking around the lake and i am glad we found it, it costs 100'000 vdn per person for around an hours show.Really good fun.

Terrible. . Don't attend if you don't speak Vietnamese. Absolutely no translation is available throughout the show, props and actions of the puppets are limited. Overly hyped tourist attraction where tourists visit in the bus loads.

They stole an hour from me!. There were some good bits. I liked the fish and the dragons. Everything else was bad. The one-string harp must be a really hard instrument to play because it sounded awful. I don't regret going but I certainly wouldn't recommend it.

Come here if you lack sleep. My brother couldn't keep his eyes open for a minute, and half the theatre was asleep by the end of the show. There is no translation at all, the whole show was in Vietnamese so you wouldn't be able to understand what was going on. The programme flyer didn't provide much explanation too. The puppetry was okay, but it got boring and repetitive after a bit because I couldn't understand the stories being played out at all. Unless they start providing translations, this is another tourist trap not worth seeing.

Probably a must do but.... I suppose this is a case of when in Hanoi go and see however ... They also charge for you to use your camera. We paid however there were many who didn't and they still took photos with no issues. It is an attraction unique to the country however don't expect anything grand.

Excellent. We decided to go but were unsure what it would be like, it was excellent, a whole package of music, singing and superb puppetry, the whole experience we can definitely recommend, inexpensive and highly entertaining, if the others around Vietnam are as good take the chance and go!

A must go if you are into 'Touristy' things. As I was on a work trip, me and my group of mates decided that one of the days in our scheduled itinerary should include a 'touristy' place to spend our time. It was as expected. The whole theatre was full of tourists. The water puppet performance was quite easy to comprehend even though they were sung in a foreign language. I guess the actions of the puppets were quite universal. It was quite an amazement though how the puppeteers moved the puppets in synchronized movements. The singing of the folk music reminds me a lot of the Chinese traditional wayang that we have back here in Singapore.However, do take note that the theater is very, very warm especially when the theatre is packed to the brim and exiting the theater takes quite a long time as there is only a few exits and it creates a bottleneck at the end of the performance.

Can someone speak English?. I know, I know, I'm in a foreign country and I should learn the local language. However, people that speak English are paying and they should try and accommodate the tourists as most places do. Vietnam doesn't. I read the reviews and they said there wouldn't be any need for English because the themes are universal. We set out and immediately English was needed because the show starts out with dialogue! The dancing and puppeteer performance doesn't need English but in order to understand the story and make an enjoyable evening, English is needed or at least a ppt or something. Having said all that, we were in the front and the puppets seemed small so I can just imagine how people ij the back could see.I'm glad the show was only 45 minutes long because it was boring. I like doing cultural things but not when I have no idea what I'm watching. When I was buying seats, I demanded to see which seat I was buying. They had 60,000 and 100,000 Dong seats, I had tried to order the 60,000 dong seats but she said I could only buy the 100,000 dong seats. Surprise, surprise a Vietnamese trying to take extra money from a foreigner (get used to it in Vietnam!) I know it's not a tremendous amount of money and only 2 dollars but after many days of this treatment, it begins to become very tiresome and downright annoying.

Could have been excellent. I watched the water puppet show with my wife & 7 yrs old daughter. My wife and I find the show to be average. Perhaps we don't understand the local language. It could have been excellent if a narrator could introduce each section of the puppet show in English. But my daughter was facinated by the water puppets & enjoy it very much. If she will to rate the show, it will probably be excellent. So, I gave a good instead.

Get good seats. This is an inexpensive way to spend an hour in the area and take in a little cultural tradition. The show itself is not much (no explanation in English, no material available that explains what's happening), but the skill of the puppeteers are amazing. The puppeteers are underwater while manipulating the puppets, and they can hold their breaths for several minutes at a time.Very positive: keeping a cultural tradition aliveSomewhat positive: Figuring out how they do it and the skill behind the artSomewhat negative: The theater seats were meant for very short people (I'm only 5 feet 8 inches and my knees reach the back of the seat in front of me. Worse, the Caucasian guy seated in front of me was probably having the same problem and would lean back, making his seat back squeeze my knees even more. We were also seated at the very end of the theater (Row R) and would have enjoyed it more if we had better seats (the puppets look awfully small and unimpressive from this distance).Also, they charge an extra 20,000 Vietnamese Dong (actually only about one US dollar) to take photos of the performance (or 40,000 VND to take videos), but everyone seems to be doing it and I doubt that everyone paid for it since there was no way they could have checked and/or prevented anyone from taking photos/videos.Very negative:The staff member at the ticket booth and the manager (he had a name tag) were quite uncooperative when I tried to ask questions. While purchasing tickets, I even overheard an English guy (judging from his accent) complaining that he was very disappointed with the ticket seller because she refused to show him the seat chart (I also tried to ask for it but couldn't seem to make the staff understand what I wanted and I ended up purchasing tickets in the last row). The Englishman ended up not buying any ticket at all.

Not what we expected. The last time I went to a puppet show I fell asleep and missed it but I don't think anyone could do that at this show. Ok the seats are close together but the skill of the unseen puppeteers is amazing. Ducks, foxes, fish and people all chase each other around. You can't understand the dialogue but that doesn't matter the stories are universal. It only lasts 50 minutes and all the family would enjoy it.

Just awful conditions. you can check my profile I am not a moaner and can generally see the bright side of life. I really wanted to,experience this and my husband was not so keen. Once we went into the theatre we did not stay too long. The seats are awful I am not heavy but fairly tall and could not get my legs in any position other than jammed into the seat of front of me. The heat was unbelievable and it was cold outside and I felt like if there was any kind of emergency it would be awful. We lasted 10 minutes then left.

Entertaining puppets with pyrotechnics. Overall was entertaining, but disliked that I have no idea what they were singing about. Could be done better with accompanying subtitles in English, screened by the side or something.

Very entertaining show!. I had great time here! Even though I can't understand a bit from the language, but, the show was really entertaining. A very unique show I should say! Highly recommended for every tourist visiting Vietnam to watch this show!

How do they do it??. Great entertainment! We had never seen anything like it - puppets on sticks rushing around in water and controlled by operators behind a screen. No idea how the operators managed to make it look so easy especially when the puppets moved very quickly and cut backwards and forwards across each other. At one point there were dragons with tongues of fire - underwater! There were about a dozen traditional stories and the whole performance lasted just under an hour and we could have enjoyed much more. The musicians and singers provided very traditional music and looked as though they were enjoying it as much as the audience. A must do attraction.

Unique to Vietnam. This is a something to do in the evening. The show is not long and if you have kids they will love it. Be warned the theater was designed for children so the seats have zero leg room. You will be charged an extra $1 to take photos but don't bother because the puppets do not come out well.Delightful brief entertainment and world known. The coffee shop next door has bonza coffee.You will only see this in Vietnam, so brave it, go on.
Enchanting. This is such good fun. Traditional music in a quaint little theatre with Punch and Judy style puppets but in water. We really enjoyed it.

Something different. It is unlikely you will have seen anything like this before. The show is just the right length and fun to watch. The puppets are just a touch basic however their movements are very clever. There is a sense of fun that runs through the show. Well worth the visit.
intersting. Traditional entertainment visually very good. I think the performance lasted less than one hour so no time to be boring. The puppets even though naive are very colourful.Worth seeing.

Clever and well presented. We read a review of the Water Puppets and were no sure what to expect.It was an entertaining 45 minutes. The musicians and singers were top rate but the puppeteers were outstanding.They told a story without words and their skill was very evident.Everyone, mainly Europeans in the audience, left with a smile on their faces.

Would like to give this a better review!. The water puppets are an ancient art and really rather clever, so I would like to give this a much better review, but really we were disappointed in this show. The puppets looked tatty and in need of maintenance, the audience was very small. Not very exciting. We went as part of a tour, so don't know how much it cost us!

The length of the show is quite short. It is probably worthwhile going from the point of view of having the experience of seeing a traditional entertainment.However if you have seen a water puppet show once, you probably wouldn't want to go again as the entertainment value is quite limited.
naive yet charming. developed by farmers in the rice fields this is a very primitive and naive form of puppet theatre. colorful and visually nice.

An interesting cultural experience. From photos I've seen, I thought the puppets looked like the sort that would give you nightmare (like they came out of Chinese horror movies) and was apprehensive. Since the hotel took the trouble to go buy the tickets and given to us for free, we thought why not.It was absolutely fascinating and unlike anything I've seen before. The puppeteers stand in the water behind bamboo veils. The musicians were seated on the stage next to the pool of water. I was amazed by the movements of the puppets, such as doing backstroke and front crawl. It was an entertaining experience. Forget how hideous the puppets look, just go for it!

Its worth to give a try. Even i am a Vietnamese, there was sometime i have been seen a play like 4 times, everytime there are some friends visit me in Hanoi, i always willing to join them for the Water Puppet show no matter what.... always bring a good feelings of childhood time and memories. And its cheap for a show like that with live performace of traditional folk songs and music instruments, and specially for a short play like that needed many artist...just love it andim proud of it as how it is! Thats really how Vietnam daily life is under the eyes of Art!
Well that an hour of my life gone. The music was terrible the people playing wanted to be somewhere else and so did I don't waste your time and money ,if it was not so loud at lest you could sleep.

What a Wonderful Experience. This Water Puppet Show is one attraction not to be missed in the Old Quarter of Hanoi.The production and the story line was an experience not to be missed by young and old - one show certainly that can be enjoyed irrespective of one's age.With four shows daily, you can pick a show time to suit and not an expensive event.Do yourself and your family a favour to enjoy an unique production of world class.

Sneak Peek. I was looking forward to the famous water puppets. It is an enchanting art form and perfect for children--that is if they or anyone could see the stage. The musicians were visible and the music was played and sung with skill, if perhaps lacking in some enthusiasm. We paid extra to use our camera, bad idea, so had everyone else. My view was obscured by iPhones and cameras being held above their owner's heads as they tried to capture the show. The only seats from which one can get a a clear view are the front and back rows and the end seats of most rows. a very disappointing experience!

Interesting puppet show. Although I cannot vouch for the authenticity of this "traditional" Vietnamese water puppet show, it was interesting to see how the puppets were operated and hear music played on some very unusual instruments.Some of the scenes with dragons were particularly impressive. There is also a touching phoenix love story.

Interesting cultural show, but too hyped. Nice show, that takes a lot of talent from the staff (live singers, band and puppeteers). Would be nice to have it in English, so you could better understand the story.

Entertaining but once is enough. There are two Thang Long Water Puppet theaters, and the one we went to is the one near Hoan Kiem Lake. The show lasts about 45 minutes and tells stories from local life and Vietnamese legends. The puppets are unusual, and the performance was entertaining. I was impressed by the amount of work done by the puppeteers. The show may have been better if there had been English translations or a brief narrative in English. The guy next to me fell asleep for most of the show, but his kids took loads of pictures!

True Vietnamese culture in the heart of Hanoi. Entertaining and humorous performance of Vietnamese folk tales in a very unusual setting. Accompanied by live music on traditional instruments and vocals in the style of north Vietnamese opera. Multiple daily performances, but it may be wise to purchase tickets early in the day for the time you prefer, as they do sell out.

Flashlight photography was distracting.. I probably should have been quite impressed, but I wasn't. I found it rather repetitive and boring towards the finish. It appeared that every other person wanted to take photographs and the flash lights were a distraction (it costs a few dollars to use a camera). It took me sometime to work out how the puppets were controlled, and I did admire the work the puppeteers put into it.

Do not miss this show. This really is something that should not be missed. The spectacle is amazing. There is a great deal of talent and humour on view. Only complaint is that the show does not last long enough.
The seating in the theatre is very comfortable and the temperature well regulated.

A Step into Vietnamese Tradition and Culture. Delightful show. Don' miss it! A step into Vietnamese tradition and culture.
Beautiful dragons! Colorful cast of characters. Live music with traditional instruments and awesome vocals.

Unique and Interesting. If you have time, I would recommend watching a show (45 minutes and 100,000 VND per person with allocated seats). They show every hour which is convenient, and you can buy tickets at the front any time for any of the shows. We bought for a show at 17:20 when we arrived at 13:00, this was a good idea as we got great seats near the front but not the front row. (where occasionally you could get a bit splashed!)It was fascinating to watch the culture and listen to traditional music. Despite all being in Vietnamese, you could get the gist of the story line and the program tells you what each act is. The music is so unique! Although I certainly agree with another review - we were jet lagged and tired so my partner was nodding off a bit with the warm dark room haha...Lastly, take as many photos as you like (Everyone does) but don't ask an attendant as I was told to pay 15,000 to get a 'camera pass' which is nonsense - you can take photos regardless. Enjoy!

A Unique Exposure to Vietnamese Culture and Arts!. Lasting for 45 minutes, this show brings together various cultural elements from rural lifestyle and folklore legends. Throughout the show, on the side of the stage there are musicians and singers who are performing live Vietnamese music. I was amazed by this beautiful composition of puppet theatre, Vietnamese tunes and impressive folklore stories!

Nothing like you've seen before. Not to miss! The Water Puppets performance is really extraordinary: the music, the lights, the singing, the puppets acting on water - it is really like nothing I've seen before. And apart from being simply beautiful and entertaining, it is also very educational as the performance shows numerous moments from the history and everyday life of Vietnam.
Fantastic . A must when visiting Hanoi, entertaining and very cheap - the way they portrait their history is brilliant

Puppet magic!. I was captivated the whole of this 45 minute show. With fabulous Vietnamese musicians and singers at the left and wonderful water puppet vignettes, this could not help but delight. The show is sung in Vietnamese but you don't need to speak the language to understand what is going on. A wonderful Vietnamese tradition kept alive. The only question is, how do they do it?

A great event. We were in two minds about going as we had read the reviews (positive) but had met another traveler at the airport who told us don't bother going its very boring after the first 15 minutes. How wrong that person was. We went and loved every minute. The orchestra of traditional instruments was just fantastic and then there was the puppet performance. Wonderful and never boring. It just goes to show you just have to get out there and see and do stuff and make up your own mind.

Don´t do this too late in the evening. the room is warm and dark and the music makes you dozze off.. Nice if you need a power nap :)Actually it is a nice piece of Vietnamese history and I´ve done it twice now, but I fell a sleep both times, so don´t do it until you are past jetlag :)
puppets. the puppet theater is an experience very reasonably priced and entertaining even though all in Vietnamese, if you research prior to watching you will understand
Puppet show. I'm sure it was good but fell asleep!! It was certainly different to anything I have ever seen before

No language barriers!. This forty-five minute show was cultural immersion at its best! The show was a series of fast moving vignettes that were self explanatory and frequently charming and/or humorous. The puppets were accompanied by an orchestra using traditional instruments and singers. We enjoyed the music very much. The theater was clean, air conditioned and comfortable. We bought tickets through our hotel at a cost of USD 5/person.

A must see!. A unique experience into Vietnam's culture! The show is great and you will probably get surprised about what you are going to see.Tip: Save some time before the show to walk around the park accross the street and see the couples getting married.

Best traditional entertainment. Water pepper skits must be recommended as the best traditional entertainment in Vietnam.The Thang Long Water Pepper Theater is most famous and popular located close to down town in Hanoi. Have you ever been there? If never, you have to go there. You will fully enjoy with your family even if you cannot understand Vietnamese language.
You should see it!. Very interesting piece of Vietnamies history. Greatfull music which cooperate with puppets in water. All together was unforgetable.

Something different and funny. The water puppets are a novelty and fun to observe. We were trying to spot the strings and could hardly catch a few. The show is made of 12-15 small 2 minutes pieces and they were individually good but I could not understand the underlying theme or connect between the pieces. Nevertheless, worth the 5$ fee and they throw in some fireworks in some of the pieces.

Enjoyable traditional show!. We enjoyed the. Water puppet show even tho it s obviously in Vietnamese the music, colors and movements tell the stories. If you re taller book an end or aisle seat to be more comfortable.

Look no Strings!. The traditional Water Puppet show is well worth a visit and operates a highly efficient regular one hour session so if you just turn up during the day there's bound to be one happening shortly. Not everyone likes puppets but these are really different, they perform in a large pool of water and the show is fun and fast moving so you won't be bored even though the dialogue is in the local language. It could be in Welsh or Serbo Croat, as you don't need to know what the words mean!And yes, there are no strings and at times it's hard to work out how the various puppets actually work which is part of the enjoyment.

It's a puppet show . So, having read the complaint about it being only in Vietnamese I feel compelled to say that the Vietnamese people can perform a piece of their cultural heritage in their own language. Unless you are an entitled tourist playing out a subconscious fantasy of colonialism,you'll be fine. And if you are, you have been warned. It's a puppet show, but they're wet. The music was cool if you like that sort of thing. And I mean traditional Vietnamese music. Not the worst thing I ever spent $5 on. Nor the best.

Very traditional cultural experience-unique to Vietnam. Not to be missed, for a true Vietnamese experience by talented puppeteers, musicians and vocalists. The stories are simple folklore but easily understood by all nationalities despite the narrative being in Vietnamese. A pleasant afternoon interlude, in between all the foot slogging / shopping/ sightseeing and to get some respite from the hectic traffic and millions of motorbikes on the streets of Hanoi
Unique cultural experience.. Very artistic. This unique performance is very worthwhile attending and should be part of discovering Hanoi.
unique. Very interesting. Unique to this part of the world so worth the experience. In Vietnamese but easy to get the jest of stories.

A few chuckles, but no idea what was going on. Went and saw this when I had a spare day in Hanoi. Its all in Vietnamese, so you have no idea on what is going on. You get a few chuckles, and they are obviously skilled puppet masters, but I didn't think it was that great, and definitely not a must see.Would give 2.5 starts (but not an option), so went for 2.
HAHAHAAHAHA. Drink lots and lots of beer. You're going to need it to enjoy this show... Actually, down some whiskey if you can. Beer might not cut it.

Okay fun. I found that this was okay maybe only just slightly above average. Probably because everything was in Vietnamese. It was interesting for the most part although i did notice my attention to the running away from it every now and then. This was something like the Chinese show that i witnessed at the Lao She tea house in Beijing but that was way way way better. Still, this is okay.The thing that struck me the most is that the group of people who control the puppets from behind the curtains are actually half immersed in water from the waist down through out the whole show, which i felt was unnecessary and i actually came in Feb (winter), which just made it seem even more ridiculous that they were not wearing some sort of fishing wader.It was entertaining and you should go and catch a show if you happen to be around. It is one of the attractions in Hanoi that all tourist should get trapped to see :)

Worth a Watch for such a Short 45-min Vietnamese Cultural Show. Didn't watch this in Ho Chi Minh City so I told myself I shouldn't miss it again in Hanoi. This kind of show is unique in Vietnam and I think it's a must-see no matter one appreciates or not. I went to the counter in Saturday afternoon and was told full house for the next two sessions. Could understand it as I saw groups and groups of tourists sent to this place by coach. Finally I got a seat for 8pm. The seatings are cramped and I got a cigarette smoking smell in the middle of the show, didn't know where the disgusting guy smoked. The show is a bit fun. The price is reasonable and timing 45 mins is just good as I believe more than that will make me feel bored.

Glad we saw it, but don't expect too much. As a first-time visitor to Hanoi, we needed to see what these water puppets were all about. It was a somewhat entertaining performance. The live, traditional music was better than the puppets. Seating in the theatre was very tight. As a 5'7" woman, my knees were touching the seat in front of me. My 6'6" husband could not sit in his assigned seat. However, theatre staff moved him to an end spot where there was no seat in front of him.

Good show, bad audience. Interesting show marred by impossibly obnoxious people in audience constantly filming with bright screens and flashes. They should have special showings where filming and flash are prohibited. Seats are also cramped, but if you are under around 5'8" you should be ok. Recommend sitting in first row to minimize these significant annoyances.

Never seen a puppet show like it - a must whilst in Hanoi. I doubt it will be the best thing that you do whilst touring Vietnam but its something you must do in Hanoi. We paid 100,000 dong (top seats) just over £3.00 .... I cant think of anywhere in the UK where you get approx. 1 hour of culture entertainment for that price. If you can, spend a couple of minutes brushing up on the turtle in the lake with the sword fable, as the show seems to circle around that. The Puppeteers are amazing, you don't see them until they take a bow at the very end - waist deep in water. Over all, a very impressive show where language is not a barrier.

Fascinating performance.. Do not arrive late and pre-purchase your tickets! The performance is terrific. We were torn between watching the puppets and the singers/musicians, they were all so entertaining. We had no idea what most of the stories were about but thoroughly enjoyed it nonetheless.

Entertaining. It was great to get an insight into some local theatre forms from long ago. My children enjoyed the show and as there was no real talking it was a show that spoke to everyone in the audience regardless of language. I think it was $5 well spent on getting a bit of culture.

Entertaining. If you'd read a few local stories about the turtle in the lake for example then you'd get this but otherwise it was just colourful & clever so you could just marvel at how the puppeteers produced such gymnastics without accidents. There were giggles too: the sequence with the birds producing an egg then a baby bird was fun. Moreover, if you've watched Chinese film & wondered how that ethereal music was produced, you'll find out here. Just 6 musicians! Excellent interlude from seeing the sights on foot.
Well worth a visit . A taste of Hanoi culture at a small price. Music and show very entertaining and very cute!! Highly recommend as show only lasts less than one hour you won't be bored!!

For tourists but very traditional. If you are going then book earlier don't just turn up. Traditional Vietnamese music and traditional stories which don't appear to have been westernised for tourists. All the dialogue is in Vietnamese and the puppets play out traditional simple tales - it is not Disney.At 6'1" the seats were tight but ok for the length of performance and the view was ok but not easy with someone tall in front.

Wonderful!. This is so worth seeing if only to marvel at the cleverness of the puppeteers. Buy the most expensive seats but ask not to have A17, A18, B17 or B18 as part of the stage obstructs your view.

different experience. Nice puppet show, a bit different from other puppet shows.can get a bit monotonous as it lasts for about 50 min and everything is is Vietnamese.Overall nice but its ok if you give this a miss when in Hanoi.Is costs with 60,000 or 100,000 VND per person. There are plenty of shows in the day but they are usually full so book ahead of time.We booked on the day in the morning but evening shows were already sold out and thus had to go for an afternoon one.

Good summary of Vietnam's traditional agrarian culture. I enjoyed the Water Puppets pretty much. Most of the plays represented daily, common or traditional events and beliefs that took place on the rice paddies in Vietnam. You could see the buffalo plowing the soil, the people planting and harvesting the rice, and even traditional figures such as a dragon and Phoenix, all in puppet size moving in seamless coordination with the music. The music was played live with traditionally used Vietnamese and Chinese instruments. The atmosphere was good, although a little westernized (of course, it was made for foreigners...). On the other hand, the seating system was a little disorganized. We had to move and change seats several times before the program started, because the staff told us to move to make space for other people although we had pre-assigned seats (handwritten) on our tickets. But all this became irrelevant as the program started, and is nothing that takes you very far astray from transporting you to the rice fields and living the stories that the puppets attempt to tell you.

Interesting but ruined. We decided to go as it is a "must" when in Vietnam. I would recommend going, but it isn't the best thing we've done whilst in Vietnam.Firstly you have to contend with the crush of getting into the theater, people leaving are barely given time before other people are trying to get in. Second, leg room for someone of my height (6'4") is non-existent (sit on the end and you might be able to angle your legs). Some seats may not be sold so you also get the enjoyment of people bashing past to occupy "better" seats. Third, because camera's are allowed, you have to contend with the constant flashing of cameras or people holding them up in front of you with little to no regard of your view.The good things are that the music and singing is excellent and seemed authentic. The puppets themselves were interesting and comical in parts. For the price it is ok, can't help but think it would be better elsewhere.

Just go to say that you have been it will make you smile!. Well I managed to drag 2 boys along to this. At a cost of $4 roughly who can complain really! It is a cultural experience, with good traditional Vietnamese music. The puppets are quite funny to watch and the show is just long enough. It's very enjoyable, just go to say that you have been, it will make you smile regardless of what you think about it and It want break the bank. The whole process is about an hour. We bought our tickets about 2 hours before. I think some of the early shows are booked to tours.

One of a kind. An interesting experience and well worth am evening visit. I have seen puppet shows before but never something like this... the puppets seem to move by themselves in the water...various types of puppets and each act depicts some folklore. Set to traditional live music which is in itself quite pleasant.You need to book in advance as very popular and all shows are normally sold out.Close to the central part of Hanoi, so a visit here forms part of a nice evening dinner and a late night stroll through the markets.

Do it so you say you did. The puppets are beautiful and the performers very talented. However, this is made for tourists. Cameras are allowed in the theater and totally distract from the show. You are rushed in and out so the next show can start. All in all, it was worth doing, but I would not go back.

Dull. The Hoan Kiem Lake is the epicentre of the Old Quarter and here we watched the Water Puppet Show. The artists have performed internationally and my wife absolutely loved the music and puppets..unfortunately i would rather have stayed home!
It was a pretty dull show and i would not recommend this unless you absolutely have nothing to do....

A fantastic show. The performance was terrific and the puppeteering impressive (dragons breathing fire!). Printed programmes in several languages are available inside the foyer, so you can keep abreast of the different segments of the show.Problems can arise if you're particularly tall (over 180cm), as the leg room is far less impressive than the show. It only runs for around 45 minutes, so you're not cramped in there for too long.Note, too, that separate fees are charged if you want to take photographs or video of the performance.

A cheap and cheerful experience, well worth the $3. Next stop was the famous water puppets, marionette and stick puppets with local music, fire breathing dragons, lovely fairies dancing, singing and stories was a unique form of theatre and we both enjoyed it very much for a huge sum of $3 each. Have i mentioned how cheap Vietnam is!!! lol

Great show!. Being vietnamese, I had never seen a water puppet show and I was determined to see one. I'm glad I did. The show was great! Hearing the music and songs reminded me of my mother when she used to sing to me. Everyone involved in the production is expertly skilled and I can see why this show travels all over the world to perform. Very reasonably priced and the show was only about an hour. It's a great way to wind down after a chaotic day in Hanoi.

Awesome puppet show!. The puppet theatre was an excellent venue to experience Vietnamese culture with wonderful Vietnamese music and colourful puppets .... a great show overall even though it is done in Vietnamese. Anyone will be enchanted!

A must-visit attraction in Hanoi!. The theater consists of a pool of water as its "stage", with the backdrop of a traditional Vietnamese house and a team of musical performers at the side of the pool. Each show runs for 1 hour and comprises a total of 14 different themes, each lasting for several minutes and they depict the history or the lifestyle in Vietnam. The puppets emerge from inside the "house" and are controlled by performers behind the scenes. The performances are conducted entirely in Vietnamese, but you will still be able to appreciate and enjoy the performances even without understanding the language.This show is strongly recommended for all visitors to Hanoi, and is suitable for any type of audience.
Worth a visit . Good introduction into vietnamese culture. Amazing how they actually do the puppetry . 100 vnd entry

A must attraction in Hanoi. A exceptional traditional water puppet show, not to be missed. You can not find better puppet show anywhere in the world. One hour show , very reasonable price, only 5 $ US . They show 14 different Vietnam traditional theme based shows, like Thang Long festival, Dragon dance, Buffalo boy playing flute, rice planting, soil ploughing, catching frogs, fishing unicorn dance , Phoenix dance, Le Loi show etc. an excellent show to appreciate true Vietnamese culture. An excellent work of heart touching art of Nguyen Hoang Tuan. Highly recommended.

Delightful show with amazing, artistic performances. Just one word about the Thang Long Water Puppet show: WOW!!!!! Ok, more words are actually necessary, because just using 1 won't do, to describe this really remarkable, wonderful, cultural & traditional event :) The combination of amazing puppetry (how can the performers make them move in such fashion?!?!), delightful music (performed by talented artists), and humorous + historic themes, all make for a most enjoyable show (suitable for audiences young and old alike, of course).If you can, make reservations for seats in the first rows nearest the front, for the best views... those towards the rear are a bit far away to really see the puppets well... Also, in the upstairs lobby of the theater, you can purchase a book that has excellent information about the traditions of water puppet performances in Viet Nam (along with nice photos as well) -- which makes for a good keepsake, and is also a great way to share this marvelous experience with the folks back home too :)) Enjoy the Thang Long Water Puppet Theatre!

A spiritual masterpiece. i love it very much, those puppets are controlled but they act, dance and sing very well on water. they aren't just senseless puppets, they can touch my heart and convey emotion to every people in the theater. it is a special way to tell legend stories, fairy tales. it proves that vietnamese people are very creative

very good. i enjoyed it so much. I have to promote this show. come early if you want o hqve the best place it s full. a real good show to understand the vietnamese culture and to spend an evening in Hanoi

Worth going to!. Very unique experience and worth going to! The tickets were less than $5 US. The music is live. The etiquette was lacking... people taking photos and video by holding their camera up high.

a very popular show. The puppets are on display just outside the auditorium. The show was fully attended and quite interesting. It was enjoyable to see some of the unusual instruments being played. The theatre smelt a bit like a stagnant pond and the show was entertaining. I imagine that it would appeal to children more than adults

A show not to miss!. What a great experience! We lucky to get tickets to an early show. Good thing it was packed. There were many people that arrived late. I wish that they would not allow them in once the show starts, as this is a disruption to all. That aside it was truly a great show. The puppets are great to look at and the puppet masters are that, masters. Don't miss a chance to see this show!

On the tourist trail. Our visit was part of our tour of Hanoi - part of the Tourist Trail.The stage is a large pool and the puppets are controlled by eight puppeteers. The musicians sit on a raised platform to the side of the stage and sing the tales of harvesting, folk lore and the legend of the lake.Seating is cramped and if you have someone tall in front of you then you will not be see much of what is going on.Like the previous reviewer I was bored .
Interesting. A sweet and entertaining 1 hour show with some insight into traditions and culture. Go early and grab a coffee or ice-cream or linger after.

Ok. Not for us.. It is very original, inexpensive and gives you a taste of Vietnamese culture but I felt myself getting bored halfway through. That's not to say you might not enjoy it so my advice would be to go see it and judge for yourself.

Worth a look if you have time. The water puppet show was $80,000 dong, which run from 3:30 to around 21:00. We went to the 17:00 show which ran for about 45 minutes. Firstly, line up and getting in was comical. People getting in and out had to enter through a small narrow entry, and took a decent 10 minute to just get to the stairs. The seats were hard and the not the most comfortable to sit for prolonged periods of time. On top of that the seats are also packed in close together making it hard to see the stage in certain areas if you have people of average stature in front of your seats.Overall the show was good. The water puppets, and were skilfully operated. From start to finish it was an entertaining and worth while watch if you have some time in Hanoi.

Don't bother.. The reason for the score.. one point for the music and voice actors, both were brilliant. For non-Vietnamese speaking travelers the music and voice actors made it very easy to somewhat understand what was going on. But...Four things sucked the life out of the performance. Seating, cameras/smartphones, flash photography and the door.The seating was obviously made for those 5' or smaller. Anyone taller than 5' ruined the show for others as it was near impossible to see anything happening on stage (except the band, they were on a raised stage and in plain sight). Many people around me were complaining or leaning to see only half of the stage. Frustrated at the seating situation, I took in my own hands and opened a seat on the stairs to the left of the stage. This seat was great.Let's move on to cameras and smartphones... The light from these devices (not the flash, we'll get to that soon) is so terribly bright that not only are you breaking your neck to dodge another humans skull, but you're also fighting maximum brightness set on the LCD of someone's digital camera or smart phone. EVERY camera ad smart phone has a brightness setting. Lower it or keep it in your pocket.Now let's talk about flash photography... Do not. Use. At all. Ever. The f@!$ing flash. On your camera. When you're at a concert or theater performance. It's just a no brainer. Your flash is nowhere near enough as bright for the light to reflect off the surface you're trying to take a photo of so don't even bother. Most DLSR cameras have the MANUAL settings (and the ever so brilliant Auto-No Flash preset) to take a very decent low light photo. Set the ISO high and shutter speed long. Smart phones and point and shoot cameras will have little to no chance at getting a decent photo. Your flash does nothing but light up the heads in front of you and piss everyone off. I'd draw a diagram for you but it wouldn't be worth it. Just don't do it, you look like an idiot.Here's some advice. While you're looking through your lens or at your screen, you're missing the most important part of being there. The show. In real 3D world life. Take one photo, with no flash or a short video, then don't pick it up again. This will give you the chance to capture that oh so important moment and enjoy the actual show.And now for the grand finale. The door. I don't know who's job it is to be responsible for this but fix the door. All you need to do is spray the hinge with a little WD-40 and it will never make a single sound for at least 30,000 years. When the usher was taking people in and out (during the show) this bloody door would sound like a thousand men on fire. Lube it or replace it. Simple.Sadly, this theater will probably never change much at all.All that needs to be done is fix the seating, ban flash photography, enforce mandatory low screen brightness or no cameras/phones at all and most importantly... spray some WD-40 on that door.

Loved it-but get there on time. Only 1 hour long. SO dont turn up 15 minutes late. (Coz they will let you in and ruin it for a few seconds for evrryone else wjo has to move seats)
WELL worth watching for a few minutes of vietnamese music and theatre going.
Dancing fish are a highlight!

Unusual theater. The show would have been far more enjoyable if they would prevent people from taking pictures. The couple directly in front of us took photographs the entire show, therefore creating a huge distraction.

Excellent show - we thought the puppets did it on their own!. We went here after a long day touring all the main sites and were absolutely delighted we came here. Great show and fantastic artistry - really worth going to. Good varied programme of vignettes depicting pastoral themes and stories - watch out for the dragon, unicorn, turtle and phoenix finale!

Hard to see... The show was great for something different but there were quite a few down falls. Firstly the theatre itself is so tiny and cramped. I couldn't see as i am short and the heads in front of me blocked my view. The seats were squishy and cramped. There is also no English translation so you have to just try to follow along. There is also no order. Add one show finishes the next show starts going in by the same stair case. People were pushing and shoving. It wasn't the best experience.

5 stars except the uncomfortable seats . This is one of the most amazing puppet shows I've ever seen, and I work in the entertainment business. it's quite spectacular how it blends pageantry with the folk traditions of Vietnam. It will certainly amaze you. The only negative is that you have to spend the 45 minutes sitting in seats with no legroom and your knees jacked up against the seat in front of you. If you are under 5'6", you will love this show without reservations. If you are over 5'6" tall you will definitely be uncomfortable in the chairs. The taller you are, the more uncomfortable you will be. however, it's a small price to pay for what is one of the great experiences of Hanoi.

Puppet theater Hanoi. On 2015 by chance ,walking near the Haon Kiem Lake, I saw the Theater and attend a performance. Fantastic, wonderful, innocent , childish , creative and cheap. Don't miss it. In the time with so much, too much state of art technology, this show is the state of art in creativity and simplicity.

Such a lovely show. We have heard about the waterpuppet show from friends and went there in the evening.The musicians and puppet players are really good at there job. We enjoyed the nice music and the sweet little stories told by the puppets. The show is a nice lite piece of culture for kids and grow ups. It takes only 50 minutes and you can easily queeze it into a short stay in Hanoi.

Possible to prebook a session to your liking. Overall a pleasant afternoon & very talented performance. The music & puppeteers put on a great show.
