My only criticism of the show is the limited description, of the plot, in any other language. That being said it's not too hard to use your imagination.

Well worth doing!. Mixed reviews on Trip Advisor, but I think this was a great cultural experience and great skills in puppetry!There's a bit of a bad damp smell on entry to theatre but well worth getting front row seats and after 5-10 minutes you get used to the smell.

An interesting insight into Vietnamese Culture. This is conveniently located in the old quarter just next to the top corner of the lake so its really easy to find (the large queues outside will also give you a handy reminder). The show itself is good although the flyer you are given describing the scenes is very brief in its description (which could be improved upon but you could always take a Vietnamese guide as the tickets are cheap).The skill and versatility of the puppeteers is great to watch and the Vietnamese music quite enchanting, so you get a really good experience even if it would be much improved by having more translation material or a more lengthy description and explanation.Still well worth a visit.Additionally there is a really good cafe and coffee shop attached where you can wait for the performance to begin or just sit and watch the day go by.Overall a good package

A must see in Hanoi. This was a great little show to watch and it's done really well. The puppets are well crafted, the puppeteers are very skillful and the musicians that played alongside were really good. It is definitely worth putting time aside to watch the show I really recommend it. With photography, you have to pay extra but unless u have really good seats or a really good camera its not necessary to take pictures and pay the extra. Also make sure u check the date they stamp on the ticket as often the wrong date is stamped and you could miss out and they only give u 50% refund

Must see if in Hanoi. We booked tickets on the day with no problems. The singers and musicians were really talented and the water puppets were amazing. Very reasonable and a good hour of entertainment great value for money.
Very nice!. Beautiful show! Different to the other puppet shows. Nice music! The songs are in Vietnamese, but they are beautiful!

Of course it's totally weird, but glad I went!. This is at folk tradition from the 11th century and yes, it's totally different - aka, super strange! But that's the point.. It is a cultural experience. I can't understand why anyone would give this a bad review. If you don't understand what you are walking into- that is your own fault. It's 5 bucks & 50 minutes of your time, just swing in and have a laugh (while appreciating this ancient cultural entertainment). It's not something you need to see twice, and maybe you'll see some people napping- but whatever!! I'm really glad I went.

Well worth your time. It would have been lovely to have more description available of the plot and storyline than the scant description on the brochure. Most everything is in Vietnamese. One can guess on some of the theme, and it is enjoyable even without knowing what the story is. The puppets are beautifully made and the puppeteer quite skillful. Children love it. The performance is accompanied by singing and traditional instrumentation. I advise sitting toward the right side in order to get a better view of the instruments composing the orchestra.

Must See. We did this on our last day in Hanoi as a sort of afterthought, and were so glad we did. The tickets were really inexpensive, about $5 USD I think, and we were able to just walk right up to the theater box office and buy tickets about 25 minutes before the show (it was a wednesday, maybe it's more crowded on the weekends). We just had the regular seats and weren't in the front rows or anything, but could still see fine. The water puppetry in Hanoi is so unique, we were really impressed and the hour long show flew by. A definite must see for anyone traveling in Hanoi.

Very well presented cultural show. It is a popular show so, if possible, book in advance. We didn't but our guide obtained tickets for us in the morning before we went to the first afternoon show. It is worthwhile to pay for the better seats to get a good view of the performance.

Interesting experience. It is definitely worth a visit to get a better knowledge of the local culture. As a piece of warning though... make sure you are well rested before the performance. My visit was scheduled on the day of my arrival after a sleepless night on a plane, and the dark room with monotonous music didn't add to my stamina. In all fairness, I was far from being the only one napping during performance.
Interesting show. It's an interesting concept and was fun to see the performance in the water. However, the story was not clear as there is no subtitle.

Lovely!!!. We really enjoyed watching the water puppets and their wonderful musicians and singers. The show follows the traditional puppetry of the Vietnamese farmers and tells the folk stories of mythical creatures and culture.

A great experience. We enjoyed the performances. It lasted about an hour. The live music comprises traditional instruments. The singers were very professional. Even though the show is in Vietnamese, you could still follow as you get a copy of the titles and summary of the acts in English and a few other languages. It gives a good insight into the culture of Vietnam.

It's definitely worth an hour sitting. This show lasts about 50 minutes. It is quite interesting with different vignettes played out by a range of water puppets. The accompanying music is very 'cultural' but I didn't always find it easy to listen to. All the puppets are quite different and the stories are easy to understand. I

Pure Culture. Going to the Water Puppet Show is to experience the culture of Vietnam, to taste a part of the tradition of the villages.I was a bit ashamed that some of the foreign around me fall asleep during the show. Let me assure that its not boring at all. At some times the music tones can get you into a relaxed way but that doesn't mean is boring. The stage was amazing, and the live music and singing deserves a stand up applause. As westerners we need to open our mind and try to understand whats different to what we know.

Go and experience. The water puppet theatre was in our 'to do' list in Hanoi, having read reviews and guide books and we were glad to have experienced it. The show in in Vietnamese, you get a little summary of what the acts are about, so easy to follow. It is a good insight to Vietnamese culture, engaging and at times funny. Live music and singing add to the show.The theatre is located near the lake and there are 4 performances daily. Our hotel kindly booked the tickets for us. The tickets aren't expensive. Front rows have better view if you can get them.

Great insight into a treasured heritage. We really enjoyed the water puppet show. Our hotel (amazing Hanoi Merci Hotel) recommended and booked for us and while we had no idea what we were getting into, we had a great time! The show is only about an hour and very beautifully shares this age old tradition. The show is in Vietnamese but with the movements and music, the story is transmitted. It is a nice activity to add to your Hanoi itinerary.

Fun show, very entertaining. Went to see this show on our first day in Hanoi. Really enjoyed it, very clever, and entertaining for all ages. Very reasonably priced tickets and great view of stage. Recommended

A lot of fun. Chosen by our tour company, Cosiana Tours, for our first night in Hanoi. Enjoyed it. Not a clue what was being said, but puppets are very visual anyway and you can follow what was happening. You go to watch an ancient form of theatre, NOT something to rival The Muppets. It;'s old, but still very clever. Just go and enjoy it.

Great value for money. Do not miss this show. The show was in Vietnamese but that didn't alter the enjoyment of this fun show which is suitable for all ages. At times I was in stitches with the humour of the show and the puppets were very creative.

Musically insightful. Although only 45 minutes long, the show provides a glimpse of traditional vietnamese singing and music. Google the story line before you attend as you may not fully understand the performance.

Interesting show with a very reasonable price. In our view this is a most in Hanoi, especially if you want to have a whole experience of the Viet culture.The theater is well preserved and nicely located, and the show is really entertaining.The ratio value-for-money makes this attraction as indispensable.I went there with my wife during our Honeymoon trip and we had a really good time.

OK, just. The puppet show was OK, just. There is a series of scenes that are fairly basic, boys planting rice, girls dancing and so on, that are interesting for the technique and mechanics used but that's about it. The only part we could recognise was the emperor's sacred sword being taken by the golden turtle on the local lake. The small orchestra and singers were far more culturally interesting. The cost was VND100,000 pp, so about five dollars. Lonely Planet says to book ahead and probably right, our session was full of people who were equally unaware of what to expect. Applause at the end of each scene was lukewarm though applause for the orchestra at the end was strong. The music gave a better experience than the show. Worth going to but don't go out of your way.

Not a must see.... If you have time to kill and are not tired after a day of sightseeing then the show is an option. I won't say to avoid completely but this is not the Muppet Show so check your expectations at the door. The guide books say that it is an art form developed by rice farmers in Northern Vietnam over a 1000 years ago. Sounds cool in the guide book but very different when there is one puppet in a pool of water doing a monologue in Vietnamese. There were cool moments with fire breathing dragons and candle carrying puppets but those lasted a couple of minutes and the show went back to storytelling mode. If you are tall the seats are tight but they have separate chairs in the aisle. I am open to new cultural experiences but since the narrative is essential to understanding the story played out by the puppets, I found myself trying to learn more about the settings on my camera for the last half of the show.
Excellent puppet show in Hanoi. A show lasts 1 hour and consists of 14 performances. Highly authentic, accompanied by local music and singing

innovative. This is a cultural puppet show, to get the most out of it you should be well versed in vietnamese culture and had a graspof the vietnamese language. The puppets themselves are well controlled and the show is well presented. The show does fill up quickly soits important to book early, the charge is reasonable, the show lasts for an hour. As a Westerner i found the local music and singing was not what i enpjoy, and i found it hard to follow.

Great for kids. I took my two kids here and they loved it! My three year old cried at the end because he didn't want the show to finish! A really beautiful and atmospheric performance. 2nd class tickets are fine. 1st class gets you closer to the front.

"Ok" show. If you are trying to cut out other things to see this, don't. If you are trying to fill time, then go. We enjoyed the show but didn't love it. It's a unique experience but wouldn't do it again.

Not my cup of tea!!. I suppose this might be fun if you have children with you, or maybe if you understand Vietnamese; but we found it long and boring. Its basically a puppet show where the puppets are in water as opposed to being on a stage. There is a chorus of people singing off to the side. You are crammed in and the theater isnt all that nice. With so many truly magical places in Hanoi (my favorite city in Vietnam), I do not see why people go here.
Nice show. book your tickets early to avoid disappointment. The place is almost fully book at every slot - many tourists. a traditional vietnam cultural show that is not to be missed.
Well worth a visit. The seats are small but luckily I could stretch out on the aisle. The music and singing stayed with me on my Vietnam trip. The puppets and stories were amusing and original.

A must see. The show is the most popular among visitors to Vietnam. The theatre's central location is very easy to access no matter which part of the town you stay. There are from two ( low season during monsoon time) to five show a day ( high season), starting from 3pm to 10pm. Tickets can be purchased directly from the theatre's ticket counter. Two things you should notice before the show : 1. Using cameras/ video will initiate extra cost ( Professional video recording is not permitted). 2. The legroom is quite tight among rows of seats so if your seat is in the middle of the row, make sure to use the toilet before the show starts.

Interesting. A very unusual puppet show since everything is done in the water. Some of the individual acts in the performance are quite remarkable and others less so. still worth a couple of hours to see it.

Awful. Definite tourist trap.. I have no idea what show other people say through. The show I attended was not magical or fun. The theatre is crammed very tight, and additional chairs are added along the already narrow stairs. The orchestra members were very obviously bored and some of them spent time chatting throughout their performance. There is very little commentary so you have no idea what story is being told or the significance of each puppet.There might have been one or two moments where I said 'oh', but other than that I say watch a show on YouTube and spend your time and money experiencing something else.I really felt that this was a waste of time.

Don't miss this if you in Hanoi with kids !!!. My third time in ten years to see this water puppet show and this was the best experience due in no small part to having a seven year old who was totally engrossed in the show bouncing on my lap. So professional and some beautiful traditional singing and music accompanies the show. It's very bright , really colourful and has some amusing parts. The Cost is 100,000 dong (3.50€) for the most expensive seats . Its very popular and seems to be included in a lot of bus tours so If with kids book in advance and look for seats close to front. While waiting for the show you can stroll across to the lake and take some photos of the red wooden bridge and temple. if want to people watch there is a coffee shop and a fast food diner right next door. Well worth it. Only downside of puppet theatre was quality of toilets , they were filthy ....all due to patrons putting toilet paper down the toilets and not into the bins provided ( major issue in lots of public toilets) there was no paper at all so come prepared . the poor lady on cleaning really had her work cut out for her and was trying to unblock two toilets when I attended there tonight. Not to be missed in hanoi .
Wonderful. Well worth a visit. The show is magical and a lot of fun. We did this as a tour and it made things a lot easier
Not a must. Though saw it for the first time , it was an ordinary show.Did not enjoy much.Just ok for the first time.

Entertaining but not for everyone. It's an entertaining show, however it's all in vietnamese which makes it quite difficult to understand although the flyers they provide you with the titles of the performances give you some clue to what is happening.It's an entertaining show and I appreciate the effort put into this show (it was very nicely presented) however I noticed some people drifting off during the show (there was a young boy in front of me who fell asleep) and it's not hard to understand why as it was difficult to understand what was going on. It's a wonderful art form however and deserves your time if you have not seen it previously especially if you have about an hour to spare and are in the vicinity.
Went in skeptical but had a fun time. It is a bit touristy, but it's unique and fun and worth it. Show is creative and enjoyable!Helios cafe next door is good for a coffee before of after.

Great show. A lot of fun! Loved the music and the show. It is in Vietnamese but I don't think that's a deal breaker, you don't need to follow the story that much, it's just a great show to watch. We bought our tickets the day before the time slot we wanted and got great seats, I recommend doing that if you're thinking of going. Cheap and cheerful, I don't understand other reviews of people "almost falling asleep", at NO point during the show did I feel like that.

Must See. This is a top quality performance of water puppets with a live orchestra. The theatre has top quality seating, light and sound system and cast. This traditional Vietnam art form is entertaining, even if you do not understand the language. We have been told this is the most professional of all the performances in Vietnam.

A unique show - catch it if you're in Hanoi. The Water Puppet Theatre is located very close to the lake. The ticket price for the show we saw was 60,000 VND each (around £2 in UK money) - make sure your travel company doesn't overcharge for these! The theatre isn't designed for taller people i.e. there's not a lot of legroom; however the show is not that long. The stories are easy to understand, and the puppetry and music are brilliant. I don't believe there is anything like this outside of Vietnam. It's not a long show, it's inexpensive, so it's a "must see".If possible try to get a seat towards the right hand side of the auditorium (facing the stage/water) as this will give a better view of the excellent musicians.

Worth to see but... I wouldn't repeat it. I guess if you understand the story (meaning Vietnamese) you will get more out of it. We almost fell asleep. I am happy we went there but I will not repeat it.

Was ok. I suppose when you are in Hanoi and never experienced a water puppet show, then you should do it once. To be honest, it was interesting for about the first 15 mins, then I was fighting to stay awake. The show is not spoken in English, so you don't really get all the story lines, and frankly I find the Asian music grating after a short time. Check the times it is on, was not on in the morning at all, and does sell out quite quickly, normally 100,000 VND, because we were the back row was 60,000 VND. 45 min show.

Tourist trap - beware. The Thank Long Water Puppet Theater good great reviews so we decided to have a go ourselves. When you are buying the tickets the lines are long and you think it is something special. Unfortunately its not the case. Its a mass production tourist trap, the show is completely in Vietnamese language (no wonder our Vietnamese friends warned us), sitting is small and cramped. The puppets are cute and the singing is horrible...so unless you want to sleep for 45 mins, dont waste your time and money.

Worth a Visit but Not Impressive. Go, but don't expect to be blown away. This is one of those attractions you go to see but you don't walk away from feeling like you went to see something absolutely riveting and amazing. It's just the thing to do.

Must see in Hanoi. Right next to Hoan Kiem this place is a must. Very nice music and nice rendition of Vietnamese culture.All songs are in Vietnamese but they give you a pamphlet which has a synopsis of the stories. This is something that should not be missed.

Great fun!. Yeah we enjoyed paying a visit. Entrance fee is only 100.000B (4€) and you get a very nice chair and a funny show. Unique to Vietnam so a must see if you want to experience the Vietnamese culture. Unless you speak Vietnamese you will not be able to follow the story, but hey, who cares? Just sit back, relax and enjoy the 45 min show!

Family show. I suggest you buy tickets in advance, as there is a queue which moved very slowly. I was lucky that a tour guide wanted to sell a ticket at face value so I could skip the queue. The puppeteers are skilled, the musician seemed bored. The show tells stories of older times and village life. It is all in Vietnamese, but the stories are simple and easily understood. The show lasts an hour, costs around $6 and is a bit of fun. With so much technology attached to most entertainment it is refreshing to see something simple
Loved it!!!. What a laugh! Better than anticipated and well worth a look. Just sit back and relax and enjoy.I recommend paying for 100000 Dong seats, we did and we were very close to the stage.

I'm not sure this was worth it. I couldn't understand what was going on except that there were puppets frolicking around in a pool of water. There were some pretty impressive moments but most of the time you'll be thinking, "this is quaint" and looking at your watch.

Great performance, ruined by rude people. I found this performance enjoyable - the music and artistry was fantastic and well worth a visit. The performance was unfortunately somewhat ruined by 50% of the theatre arriving 10-20minutes late and constantly having people hold their cameras up in your view with continued flashes going off. I found this very inconsiderate to the artists and fellow patrons.

Entertaining, authentic and very enjoyable.. I didn't expect much from an hour long performance that cost a mere $5, so I was very pleasantly surprised. The puppeteers are very skilled and it was quite interesting to watch their performance. It's all in Vietnamese, but the skits are very straight forward. The music was wonderful, the singers were pretty fantastic and it was brilliant to get a taste of the traditional music. Would highly recommend! There are usually a lot of tickets available during the day, and you get the front seats if you come in a bit late.

Skilled puppetry. The show, of about an hour, recreates some folklore and stories from the country. Many different stories are enacted before your eyes and the skills of those working the dolls is evident. The musicians accompanying the performance have excellent timing and the music really adds to the show.Make sure you read the programme though, as it gives you clear listings of what each story is telling you.

Great performance and experience!. I was lucky to be seated at the 2nd row from the front (tickets cost 100,000vnd) and was captivated by the colorful and exciting 1-hour performance. The puppet show consisted of about 14 different folklore from dragons to phoenixes. The moving puppets were accompanied by an orchestra at the side of the stage where one can see them sing and play their instruments. It is a very popular tourist attraction and I would suggest buying the tickets one day earlier if possible. Their shows come in many different timeslots a day. It is definitely worth a visit! The only regret was that the whole show was in Vietnamese and while I enjoyed it, it would have been better if there were some form of explanation in English so that I could understand what they were singing about.

A different kind of theater in Hanoi. I´ve had never even heard of Water Puppet Theatre before my last visit to Hanoi this november. I had no expectations whatsoever and was positively surprised. The way they manouvered the puppets was extremely talented. The cost for the show was almost nothing. When in Hanoi, visit this local attraction.

Great cultural experience. This was definitely worth the time and expense. The show is an hour and has 14 different puppet skits throughout accompanied by live musicians that are visible to the side of the stage. Skits depict aspects of Vietnamese village life. The theater is comfortable enough for the hour long show. Sit at the front if possible!

A bit odd but memorable. In fairness, we went knowing it might not be for us but thought we should visit as lots of people had raved about it being Classic Vietnamese. For us, it didn't feel particularly authentic (no locals go) and other tourists were being a bit annoying by chatting through it. Tickets are cheap though, so if you've got time on your hands and no natural aversion to odd looking puppets, enjoy.

Interesting show. The show features puppets made out of wood and performed in a pool of water-a pool stage . It refers to Vietnamese folklore with different stories and musical . It would be really nice if some shows could be conducted in English language for the benefit of tourists . Even without understanding the language, its still worth a visit .

Good show. Fast moving with live singing, talking and music. $5 entry fee for a 1 hour show. Lots of different puppets with fire breathing and water squirting dragons. Probably saw 10 to 15 short stories in the hour long show. Busy with tourists but definitely worth going to see.

Important cultural event. We had front row seats for the show. The music on authentic southeast asian instruments was a wonderful experience. The puppetry was very clever and well coordinated with each other and the music. Very colorful and interesting and the show is not too long. As an American who is used to non smoking regulations, it was disturbing and unhealthy that people were actually smoking in the theatre during the performance.

Great cultural experience . The music was great and the show kept you captivated. It's great how it didn't last too long and the scenes were continually changing. The puppets were very fascinating and the puppeteers were very professional. However this theatre is very popular and busy and they double booked one of our seats but they figured it out in the end. Highly recommend this show for a cultural experience.
Amazing Show. It was an amazing display of chorography with music, singing, and puppets performing in water. The coordination of all with small pyrotechnics made for a very enjoyable experience.

mesmerizing performance. Certainly one of the most important attraction you should visit. This water puppet theater had preserved one of the oldest intangible cultural arts of Vietnam. The water puppets came in various sorts of figurines, ranging from humans, fairies to animals such as ox, pheasants and the mythical dragons. One interesting scene narrated the story of a Vietnamese King, a sword and a turtle. We guessed it had something to do with Hoan Kiem Lake (lake of the returning sword), which made the performance meaningful.The live singing of melodious ballads accompanied the movements of the puppets. Though the lyrics were incomprehensible to us, the good coordination of the rhythm and water puppets had made the visit a worthwhile experience.

Fun time. The puppet show is amazing, but different. If you want to go to something and understand the story...not the place for you. If you want to go and see great puppets in water ...do it! The show is a fun time!

Traditional Show. Enjoyed the average story through the puppet show with the information given by the tour guide.Very attractive and beautiful show. Worth money on it. However, it should be adjust something like in Thailand that will no allowed any cameras, smartphone taking a picture during the show in order to we can enjoy totally.A highlight in Hanoi Capital!

Great fun but........ TURN OFF you flash. . Great fun. Our 4 and 15 year old kids loved it (so did we).. For $8 au each it was great value and gave us a sit down for an hour. Only draw back was the fools that cannot take pictures without flash. It does take away from the experience.

Fascinating unique experience. The theater was small and they really cram you in there but I had never seen anything like it. You have to pay extra to take pictures and it's pretty dark so they didn't come out well, but I thought it was a cool experience overall.
Great experience . The water puppet of hanoi is a great and lovely experience. Absolutely deserves the money. The show is not too long and not too short and very enjoyable.

Water Puppets. Good cultural show The music is performed live, we didn't understand a word of it but it was very melodious the water puppets very interesting and depict stories and culture of ancient Vietnam
If you're over 6 foot tall don't go. The seating is tiny. I was in pain the entire time. If you're over 6 foot sit in the front row (requires prebooking way in advance)

Awesome water puppet theatre.. I've never actually seen water puppet theatry before, so I have nothing to compare it to. But I can say that it was a most enjoyable evening. And it was well designed for people not of vietnamese background. The puppetry was amazing, the fireworks and music were well suited to the audience, and it was a very lovely experience to have in Hanoi. Definitely a must do for any traveller to Hanoi.

Cartoonish. We saw this at the end of a long trip and slept through half of it. It's cute for the first few minutes, but we didn't know or understand the stories they were portraying, so not much entertainment. The seats didn't allow enough leg room and we were happy the show wasn't longer.

Nice experience . If you have not seen this show before then you should watch it once. We might not understand the whole story as it's songs and language is in Vietnamese but we should appreciate the people behind the puppets. They actually stand in the water for at least 1 hr for the duration of the show. This is more of appreciation of arts and crafts and the efforts by the people behind the scenes as well as the persons singing.

Interesting cultural experience. The good:The show was sold out at the desk, however you can ask about 60k dong cheap seats on the sides. We were unsure how good these seats would be but were very pleased as there weren't rows of people infront of us as these seats were separate from the main seating's. It is amazing what the puppeteers can do with the puppets, this was great!The show is authentic.The show was cheap, at 60k dong.The bad:The show is quite short.The show is in Vietnamese so it can be hard to follow.Overall: I would recommend seeing the puppet show in Hanoi. We choose to see this one over the one in Saigon/HCM because of the price and were pleased with the show.

Still Okay.. Is a traditional water puppet show with Vietnamese singing traditional song which you don't understand a word. Well is always up to you guys if you wanted to watch it because it sound like if you don't go, you don't look like you went to Hanoi. The show is about 1 hour long with few different stories to watch. Be sure to book early through online or with your hotel much in advance to get a good sit.

Maybe we didn't "get it"?. To be honest, we found this show a bit disappointing at best. The live musicians appeared bored (as one would after doing hourly shows day after day) and we really didn't "get" what the attraction was. Puppets on poles splashing in the water.....hmmmmm........The gentlemand sitting next to me fell asleep, as did the young boy with his mother sitting in front of us. I would have likely done the same, but the seats are so crammed in there was little room for my legs to move.I can think of lots of other ways to better spend your time in Hanoi.

Jennie and Elliot in Hanoi. Great show try to get a seat in the front two rows, where you can see how they work the puppets. Be aware this is a cultural show and imagine you are Vietnamese you will enjoy it more.

Glad I went, but wouldn't go back!. This is a traditional water puppet show, with very nice Virtnamese traditional music & song, played by talented musicians. The puppetry is a bit Punch & Judy at times, but is pretty entertaining.The whole show is obviously in Vietnamese, so it's hard to follow the plot (if indeed, there is a plot?), but I am glad I took the time to see the show.Lots of annoying tourists, insistent on videoing every moment or arriving 20 minutes after the show started, but in a way it addred to the whole experience.

Excellent entertainment, unexpected. The water puppets were mesmirizing. The theater had nice seating and all areas had good views. Entertaining for all ages. The musical accompaniment elevated our experience. The theater is well maintained. Must see

Innovative and Enjoyable. This was a bit of a surprise. The puppets were fun to watch and even the band providing the musical accompaniment was fun to watch. The show is comprised of about 15 or so short vignettes so things keep happening. Keep your cameras handy. They allow pictures and people take lots.
Interesting show- a bit long. This "must see" attraction in Hanoi is very interesting but would have been more enjoyable if there was English explanation of what's going on

Interesting experience. I don't know if I would recommend it, because I didn't quite understand what was going on on the stage, but the experience was extraordinary. Where else would you see the puppets on the water, accompanied with eerie music?

Vietnamese entertainment?. A bit hard to understand what is going on "on stage" since everything is in vietnamese. Many times it just seamed as the dolls were flying around splashing water on eachother.
But still interesting to get a bit culture and tradition.
And at times they make those dolls do incredible things.
Enjoyable. I really enjoyed the water puppet show. It was very different from anything that I have seen so it was an experience. The show was entertaining and the live orchestra was great!

Water great show. Bit of a cliche admittedly but no visit to Hanoi would be complete without seeing the water puppets. The box office and entrance are easy to miss in the hustle and bustle of the city. Once you find it there are regular performances throughout the day. The show is very professional and features live music to accompany the action in the pool. Based on traditional stories of Vietnam, it is a series of little playlets. There is plenty of action so there is no issues with following what is going on. The day I was there the audience comprised mainly adults. But the show is enjoyable whatever age you are. The theatre is comfortable and air conditioned. At the very least it is a welcome escape from the heat. Very enjoyable and entertaining. Worth taking the time to see before you leave Hanoi.
A little too long but enjoyable. There no longer is any English "sub-titles" so hard to follow what is happening. In addition, be forewarned, the seats are very cramped!

Unique puppet show. While you will not really understand what's going on given that most of the sings are in Vietnamese it is a must see in Hanoi as it gives an insight into traditions from the area. Also it is not expensive and the theatre is clean and well presented show overall.

Interesting show. I watched the show just after we landed from a flight into Hanoi and manage to catch it before we left for Sapa!I love the show BUT...Gosh the music are just so relaxing that it makes you really sleepy. Was struggling and forcing myself to keep awake cos I really don't want to miss anything. Fortunately I manage to see bits and pieces of the show in between dozing off. Hehe. The show was awesome. The amount if work put in to make a show like this... Priceless..Just make sure you try to stay awake at all cost!

Pretty boring . Went to see it today and felt like leaving early on. It is hard to follow the storyline as it is all in Vietnamese. Seats a pretty low so it can be hard to see if someone tall or has a big head is sitting in front of you. They people are talented and the music is okay but it is just boring.

Interesting but bad experience. I really love puppet shows and have been wanting to visit this for the longest time. The puppet show is interesting but the experience is really bad. Firstly, the seating, the person in front of me cover almost ⅓ of the stage, I have to keep moving left and right just to see the puppet. Secondly, they allow audience to actually take photos and videos during the performance which is really distracting, you can hear the shutter of the camera throughout and the flash is always on going. And people are talking loudly in groups. Other than that, its nice to catch the puppet shows. It is really interesting.

Interesting. We hesitated to see this thinking it would be too touristy (there were indeed a lot of tour groups there), and we dragged our feet, so to speak, by putting it off for the last of our four-night stay in Hanoi. But since the price of a ticket was only about US$5 and it got good reviews, we decided to give it a try.It was about a 45-minute show and we enjoyed ourselves.Seats were comfortable enough and the show was entertaining. I think 45 minutes is about the right length.

Skip It. The story line is hard to follow unless you understand Vietnamese. The puppets are interesting for about 10 mins and most of the audience is either talking loudly or sleeping. Unless you have nothing else to see in Hanoi you can skip this one.

How do they do it?. The 50 minute show is a perfect way to unwind after a hard day's sightseeing in Hanoi. The theatre is at the North Eastern corner of Hoan Kiem Lake. When we tried to get tickets on our first visit, it was sold out. So it may be advisable to book the day before. There are several performances a day. Entrance is a modest £3 for the top price seat. It is worth paying the additional £1 more than the cheapest seat as the puppets are quite small and will be harder to see from the back rows, although I am sure you'd have a reasonable view from whatever vantage point.The artistic form is almost a thousand years old. The music is very Vietnamese, and may be a little hard on the ear at times for western listeners. But the puppets are international and the stories easy to follow. The "sketches" are only a few minutes long and perfect for children (or adults) with a short attention span! There are three female singers and a band.From no where, the puppeteers (who remain out of sight until curtain call) conjure up scenes of village life, fishing, farming, courting. And there are also smoking dragons and jumping fish - amazing! It has to be seen to be enjoyed properly. Just go!

Quaint :). I actually liked this and yes it is a bit repetitive but it has charm and is not too long either. great for children and is funny in places too.My only complaint is that they let people in after the show had started. Not ideal but did not spoil the experience.

Weird but worthwhile experience. Attended out of curiosity with my family. Glad we did as it is clearly popular and there is history attached to the show. I have to say that we all found it a bit weird and would not revisit - puppets are not my thing. I would describe it as slightly bizarre, but something you should see if in Hanoi

Charming family entertainment. I'll be honest...when the show started I thought we'd made a big mistake. In an age of special effects and fantastic stage shows this got off to a creaky start.But then I looked at my children (aged 8 and 6) and they were captivated. They really connected with the show and story.It runs for 50 minutes and is a series of 'songs'. No one song goes on for too long. There's not a word of English but you get the gist from the imagery of the puppetry.We sat on the front row which was great.A really charming activity in Hanoi which we found delightful.

dancing history performed by puppets in the water. one of hanoi's traditions and only done here for centuries. the stories and dances performed by water puppets and accompanied by live vietnamese music is a special and rather unusual treat - even though for tourists only.

Interesting experience. Enjoyed the Thang Long Water Puppet Show (45 min show) which is opposite the Hoan Kiem Lake. The lead female singer's vocals was good. An interesting way of absorbing the musical culture of Vietnam, though we didn't understand the Vietnamese words. Perky Possum

A waste of time. Probably the worst attraction during our holiday in Asia.Entrance was 5$No translate during the show - it's on Vietnamise .There is no enough space for legs if you are tall - 1.90A ll the people that got in were disappointed - I really don't understand why they are asking for money for this kind of show.About an hour of wasting time

Good Entertainment. Good way to spend a very entertaining an hour at this historic Water Puppet show with music. An ancient traditional show with a few modern humorous twists. Very enjoyable but the seats are cramped if you're tall.
Very good a must see. I went to see this and was glad I did very cleverly done..around an hour so not to long .. Excited children can be nuisance if sat in front of you..

Snorkle or snore.. Not sure about this one. The place was packed out with tourists whose only reason for being there was that it was included in their holiday itinerary. Technically it is clever stuff and some of the routines leave you attempting to work out how they are done. That said you have to ask why some of the routines were done in the first place as their story lines are somewhat obscure or long winded. The performance would have benefited with an English translation though the tradition music was interesting. A problem for Europeans is the seating is designed for a Vietnamese audience and as the majority of Vietnamese are somewhat shorter than your average Brit, the legroom is budget airline. Anyone over 6ft needs to bag an isle seat. Looking round the audience on our visit many had dozed off while a number had their mobiles out - and not to take photos. I overheard someone near me "Oh God, there's still six stores to go before we can escape". It would be interesting to know what the audience levels would be like if the Vietnam & Cambodia tour companies dropped this venue from their tick list itineraries.

Would not go there second time. It was pretty nice to hear the traditional music and some songs. But apart from that the show is quite boring (probably due to the language barrier) and most of the crowd fell asleep while watching the performance. But when you are in Vietnam, I believe you have to see this cultural performance by dolls that dance on the water.

Unique puppet show. Clever show packing in the tourists. An explanation of the story in English would help. Seating is designed for short people. If you are over 6ft you will need Isle seat. I'm 6'5 and had to sit side on with my legs over my wife beside me.

Not so good. we went quite enthousiaste at first but we finish quite bored ,one of the spectateur start snooring.The music is nice but the puppets are stiff so they repeat and repeat the same mouvement over and over so it's start getting too long.

Fascinating Show. The water puppet show is definitely worth seeing if you visit Hanoi. I didn't know what to expect at all and was entranced by the show--the blending of live music and the puppetry. Although you start off a little skeptical you are soon drawn into the magic and fascinated by how it's done (although I never really figured it out). It's not something you'll likely see again but the experience is well worth it. And it's in a convenient location and hosts several shows daily--easy to fit into your travel schedule. If you travel with children, they will love it.

Suitable for children.. We found this show rather boring and tourist orientated.2 of our group liked it and 2 didn't so maybe my assessment is a bit critical.I dislike the shows that are put on especially for tourists in Asian countries and although this was quite nicely done it had no appeal for me and was not all that professional.I would rather have spent my time and money elsewhere in Hanoi.
Something unique. Its a must when visiting vietnam. Nothing fancing, but it would be more interesting if we know what they are talking about.
puppets insight into vietnam. it an esssential visit and must be done once to make your trip to Hanoi complete. Its a family affair and conveniently located at Hoan Kiem lake

Moderized, and less charming and authentic. The Thang Long Water Puppet Theater is a tourist staple and it is a venue that beckons when you are in Hanoi. It used to follow a very traditional set of narratives. Water puppetry is a rural practice intended to re-present to the countryside villagers their own Vietnamese history (march of the mandarins), their mythologies (dragons, turtles, and phoenix birds) and country life (fishing in boats, planting rice). The stories are ancient and repeated in water puppetry shows throughout the country.The Thang Long experience is one of the few water puppet performances conveniently available to the tourist Over the last few years, while the music has remained traditional, the performance has become modernized and concentrates on more spectacle than traditional scenarios. At this point, the best I can say is enjoy it for what it is -- a performance that speaks to the tourist, but one that would hardly be recognizable to the Vietnamese.

Surprisingly entertaining. After a few minutes of skwarky music and splashing i was dreading the next 40 minutes or so of the same. But then i found myself drawn in, charmed and intrigued as to how they did it. I then also realised that it provided a deep insight into Vietnamese culture, not just historical but contemporary thinking too. After a little longer the music seemed less annoying and melded into the overall experience, which was indeed charming. The litmus test was that i was accompanied by my early twenties children, both who are very fashion and modern cukture conscious. Uf anyone was going to resist it then it would be them. But they were laughing along with the rest of the audience, charmed and enchanted by this very ethinic piece of theatre.

Interesting new experience. The show showcase Vietnam folklore. It was nicely done and present a new way of telling stories. While it is interesting, after awhile it can become boring. Since this is my first experience in water puppet, I enjoyed it very much. Would I recommend it? Yes if you have not seen it before.

Magical experience. The kids (5yo and 3yo) were transfixed by the show and stayed glued to it till the end (about 50min). We bought some puppets at the gift shop afterwards and those have provided further entertainment. The show is in Vietnamese and while the exact detail of the story proved mysterious and elusive we followed the basic plot (only because we'd had a run-down on the history of Hoan Kiem lake that morning from the Hanoi Kids tour!!). The kids made use of the restrooms after the show and pleased to report they were clean.A great show with some humorous twists - highly recommend.

Relatively cheap and unique experience . It was a relatively cheap and unique experience at 100vietdong (about $5usd) for the premium tickets. My family has not seen such a show before. Although it was in Vietnamese, the show was quite easy to follow. And how they manouvere the puppets across the pool and even up a tree was pretty intriguing. Good and unique Vietnamese experience :)

Ancient Art. Thang Long water puppet theater is adjacent to hoan kiem lake. We took the tickets and spent some time along the lake as we had some time for show. Ticket costs VND 100K per pax.The puppet show was really good with traditional music in the background. Altogether it was a nice experience.

Entertaining local show. MUST SEE, ...Very entertaining show. Keep wondering how the players are managers those puppets over the water surface. Good to have live music too to make it even more authenticThe good thing it is not too short and not too long ... within 1 hour.

great cultural experience. I enjoyed this show. It actually took me a bit to figure out how the puppets were being moved, it is all very cleanly executed. The accompanying band is actually great, they provided all the atmosphere---I would buy their music if it was available. Downsides are that some scenes include dialogue in Vietnamese that foreigners wont be able to pick up easily, and in general the show is fairly slow-paced and the scenes are slow-developing; people expecting more 'action' are going to be disappointed. The tickets are very cheap though, so nobody is cheated.

Definitely a must see in Hanoi. We caught the puppet show on our first day. There are quite a number of performance each day so you can take a pick of which one you want to catch. The theatre is just across from the lake so do pop down to buy the tickets while you are enjoying the lake.Tickets are VND100K (around USD5) but best seats are in front so if possible do pick a performance where you can get better seats.The theatre is not that big but can probably accommodate around 100+ and certain performances could be sold out. We went around noon to see if we could get tickets for the 300pm screening but was told it may be sold out. The "may be" is due to previous agreements with certain travel agents etc and the booking staff said we can come by at 230pm to see if there are no shows and that's what we did and we got our tickets.Its a very interesting show and kids would love it but adults would enjoy the show as well especially that the puppet show is done in this pool of water - very different from other puppet shows.I wish they would have provided more colour into the background behind the stories but it makes it more interesting trying to figure out what is going on.The show itself is only around 45 mins so give it a shot.

Unique. I may be a big kid, but I loved this! The theatre is very old.rustic interior and small so booking is recommended. Didn't think much of the "music" , but the puppets are really interesting, funny and colourful. It is not a very long performance but it holds your interest the whole timeIt takes a wee while to work out how they are making the puppets move.- Quite a unique skill really.Suitable for all the family!
Excellent presentation. Loved the presentation and experience of this show. Singers and band was awesome too. We wish we could understand their language to appreciate their singing.
Charming. Reminded me of when I was young!! Packed for most performances and the thing to do in Hanoi! Last an hour and very cleaver, will say no more, but worth doing!

Fun and unusual. Be sure assigned seats are close up.. Never seen anything like it. Very enjoyable show. Amazing what the puppets can do. Seats are assigned. Be sure to get ones close to the front. Performance guide tells what specific acts will be put on - you will see about a dozen out of the 400 or so available. If you arrive early, go down a little bit and walk over the bridge to see the Temple (20K entry).
Nice experience. It was fun, different and a great way to know a little more about Vietnamese village life. The duration is perfect for 1 hour.

amusing. Visited the water puppet theater because it was one of the things to see but ended up really enjoying it Fun, full of colour and activity and you could really understand what was happening The music to accompany it was also excellent The tickets were extremely reasonable in price and the only quibble I might have is that the seating made it hard to see You had to keep moving your head from side to side I thought this was because I might have been too small to see it but others said the same

Get the Best Seats. If in Hanoi, then a visit here is a must.Try to get near the front for the best views, the puppets themselves are wonderful, but my attention was also directed to the musicians, seeing them creating all the wonderful sounds using the various unique instruments. Indeed it was a joy to seeing then having so much fun.The performance only lasts an hour, a great way to see some local culture.

Just wasn't for me. The show itself started out very slowly, with singing and music. Some of the puppets were very colorful, and I know there is an art here, but I was really bored here. I watched the reactions of others and it was mixed. An older group in front of me were literally on the edge of their seats, yet I also seen some people nodding off. It was too warm inside as well.

Good experience. This show is arranged evryday evening for 1 hour, showcase the village life of Vietnam. Fishing, farming & daily lives are portrayed by puppets in the water. Nice experience, you may not understand the language but can realize the story easily...good experience
Must do in Hanoi!. It was fun, different and a great way to know a little more about Vietnamese music and folklore. The duration is perfect. Not too long.

Different. Wasn't sure what to expect as we got tickets as part of our tour. The show was different but we enjoyed it although happy with the length (wouldn't want it to be longer). We enjoyed all of the different instruments used during the show. It would have been interesting to know how exactly the puppets worked. all in all, happy we went and got to see a bit of the Vietnamese culture.

Recommended. Worth going to see this. It's very clever, and good to see. It's not a WOW, but I really enjoyed it. I also enjoyed seeing the skill of the live band, playing unusual instruments. Try to purchase tickets well before the show - I got mine the day before - saves a long queue and gets good seats.

Good fun. Visited 12 years ago and saw the water puppet show and didn't really enjoy it, this time round thought it was great fun and really enjoyed it. Don't know if it has changed, but. I think the duration was a bit shorter this time. Well worth a visit, good fun for an afternoon show.

Once was enough. Taken to see water puppets as part of our tour of Hanoi. Something of a cultural experience which starts well, accompanied by pretty Vietnamese girl singers/costumes/ traditional musical instruments. After 30 minutes some of our group were beginning to nod off!
All part of flavour of Hanoi but once was enough.

Really very enjoyable. This is a lot of fun - it only goes for an hour but the individual segments are quite short and sometimes spectacular. The dragons and the fish are particularly good. The one problem really concerns European tourists sitting towards the front who hold their i-Pads up through most of the performance - presumably they either think that i-Pads are transparent or else (and I think more likely) they simply don't care that they are blocking the view of those sitting behind them Recommendation to the organizers - cameras are fine but ban i-Pads (and the sort of people who use them at this type of performance!).

Just go and enjoy. This show takes about an hour and it is really nice to see. The stories are quiet easy to follow and it is a good way to have a glimps of the culture of Vietnam. They simply love it. Just a note: The puppets don't last longer then a few months in the water, so the puppets making craft is still alive. There are some villages specialized in producing them.

Unique experience thoroughly enjoyed it. Had heard mixed reviews about this but was pleasantly surprised by how much I enjoyed it. I certainly didnt think it was too long and i can not understand how someone would get bored it was very unique and very colourful. It was lively and for us it did not matter that it was in Vietnamese after all we were in Vietnam seeing something uniquely Vienamese. there is a program that explains the show suggest that you read it beforehand. Try and get tickets close to the stage as further back it may be difficult to see the performance becasuse of heads in front of you. We went in the evening on a week night and had no problems getting tickets but it may be a good idea to book to ensure that you get good tickets. Overall we were both pleasantly surprised at how much we enjoyed the show.

Good to see once, but not again. This is not a bad cultural experience to do while in Vietnam, especially since it is so cheap and pretty neat. But that is pretty much the great thing about it - you see it once and that is good enough! The entire water puppet show is in Vietnamese and there is not much of an explanation on what is going on so you can just make up the story yourself.It's more one of those weird things and because it is so weird you can't take your eyes off of it even though you have no clue what the heck is going on.

Interesting, but little too long IMHO. Very interesting, but an hour is too long I think for many. I think children would get bored after a while unless they understand Vietnamese. I got drowsy in spite of the decibels and had I not been part of a small group, I would have slipped out after about the 3rd performance. Best part was when they pulled back the curtain and you got a glimpse of how the puppets are operated.

Unique experience. Water puppet show is a must do attraction in Hanoi. We went for the evening show. Do book the tickets in advance as the show was completely packed. The seating is not much comfortable whether first or second class tickets (We had taken first class).The experience was one of a kind. The only problem was that we could not connect with the story being told as it was in Vietnamese. Though you have a brochure with name of each act but that was it. You have to engulf yourself in the story being told and enjoy the experience

Okay experience . Thang Long water puppetInteresting experience the first time. The music was very enjoyable. As for the puppets, when the novelty wears off, it could get boring. There is a pool in place of the stage. The musicians are off the side. The puppeteers are behind the bamboo curtains.The show is divided into parts. Each features different puppets and conveys a story, sort of. The puppets basically do the same movements throughout that part, which generally last about 5 mins. I am sure it is fascinating for a 3 years old... If he wasn't given his iPad.
Superb. This is a must when you visit Hanoi. This is like no other theatre that you've ever seen. An hour show for 5 bucks? And the show is great? Sounds 'bout right to me...

Good Value for your money. . Entertaining for the money. This is no cirque du soleil, but what can you expect for 6 dollars. Biggest problem is that there is no control over the use of cameras and if you are unlucky like I was to sit behind someone who is constantly lifting his camera over his head and focusing and zooming in for shots it spoils your view of the show. Any camera shots will be useless anyway. I would rate this as good instead of average if they would ban camera's. Please ban cameras during the main part of the show please.

Worth watching at least once but a little bit boring & very touristy. For $3-5 USD this is a good cultural way to spend an hour of time in Hanoi. Even though the show is mainly in Vietnamese and I didn't understand what was being said in the songs or dialogue, I appreciated the colourful puppets and short skits and traditional live music. Go in with an open mind - this isn't a high-budget Hollywood production, but this type of entertainment has been around for centuries so approach from a cultural perspective.Oh and it was very touristy - do locals even go to this!?

Fun way to spend an hour in Hanoi. I had seen water puppet shows advertised throughout my travels in Vietnam. As I was walking around Hanoi, my last destination, I noticed a show was starting in a few minutes, so I decided to check it out. For only $5 you get to experience a small piece of Vietnam's cultural heritage while getting a break from the heat and traffic. I found it amusing, and thought the performers were very talented. Not necessarily a must-see, but fun if you have the time!

A good laugh at the Water Puppet Theater. It doesn't really matter if you don't understand the lingo because the Water Puppet show is funny and will give you a good laugh! You will wonder how the puppeteers do the show but at the end of the show we get to see them and give them a big round of applause. The show have lots of short "stories" and the puppets are terrific and the action is non-stop.The Water Puppet Show is great value for money and worth a visit.

Must visit!. I can't believe how little they charge for this given how amazing the show is! When in Hanoi, you must dedicate an hour to this show. Try and book ahead a day or so as the timeslots tend to book out fast. We picked up some puppets afterwards as a reminder of this memorable experience.

Something different. The place was a bit cramped for short blokes like myself making it harder to see, but the activity itself was very different and unexpected. I would recommend people to go and have a look at this at least once if they are near Hanoi.

Unique puppet show. Though it was the second last show of the night, the theatre was almost full of foreign tourists. The unique puppet show has quite amazing as the puppets were manipulated by puppeteers behind a bamboo curtain (or under the water?). Though I had seen a version of it in HCM City, it was still worth the while to see it in Hanoi as I understand where it first originated.

Very charming and very reasonably priced. I went to the 3:30 show. Something to do during the day in Hanoi that got me out of the sun. Very charming production, lasted almost one hour. Minimal commitment of time and money and it's a Vietnamese classic.

It's ok for the price,but wouldn't pay more.... Well, if you are planning to go, pay 100K dongs for the premium seats and ONLY(!!!) take the seats numbered A,B,C. Anything further and you will not see much as other heads will be blocking half of the stage. We were seating at J(that's still premium) and at my height of 6 feet, I still had hard time seeing some parts of the stage. A lot of people closer to the stage had the same problem and were constantly moving their heads in order to try to see anything. If you are over 5'10 you may have problem with the leg space.Show itself wasn't bad,but imho, it was about 15-20 minutes too long. We saw A LOT of people sleeping about 25-30 minutes through the show.

Only interesting for kids. We have seen the Water Puppet Theatre show in Hanoi in October 2014 in a group of 6 young adults and we were rather bored during the show. The puppet theatre tells stories of Vietnam's past through music and puppet sketches, but these are not really interesting for adults, supposing you already know the country's history and traditions. Do go there if you have kids, they will learn new stories about Vietnam in a fun way during the show. The puppet masters perform for more than one hour standing in a pool [that was interesting], do not expect a lake performance.

Exceeded my expectations. I loved it! I went with low expectations but the puppets were very imaginative and the music was peaceful and interesting. Definitely worth a visit! Very colourful and beautiful. It is so clever the way the puppets move in the water. Even though it was all in Vietnamese it was easy to understand and accessible. The only slight problem was the seats have very little leg room so for my 6'1" son it was difficult to sit with his legs so cramped up - try to get a seat by the stairs if you are tall and can hang your legs out!

Very interesting. It was a really interesting show, the staff were excellent in controlling their puppets and it was really lifelike. Nice 'special effects' too. The staff performing the songs and playing the musical instruments were really good as well. The only mildly annoying thing was that we arrived at the entrance at 5.20-ish and asked for the 6.30 show but was told there wasn't one and that we could still make it for the current show which had just started. There are two types of tickets (VIP and normal) and after we said okay she just charged us for the VIP tickets. Not too iffed about it since the price difference wasn't really big, about 20k or 40k VND maybe? I suspect they just want to fill up spaces as much as possible.

Very beautiful, but difficult to see. 45 min lasting show. Very nice concept and amazing how it is performed. However depending on your seat it is sometimes difficult to see the whole stage. Packed with people. If possible take a front row or a middle seat.
Must see in hanoi. Though in vietnamese language nice local programme to see in hanoi . Also definately visit roof top restaurent near by for after show dinner..ask your hotrl for suggestion
Not so kitch. At first it felt like going to a school show but was surprisingly pleasant and uplifting. One of the things to do while in Hanoi. Get a seat off-centre as they are less used.

Entertaining Evening. We went to see the show after our dinner. I enjoyed it and I wished we went earlier to buy tickets. Because we didn't, we were seated on the very last row. Although you could still see everything from there it would have been nicer if we were nearer. The seats were comfortable. A lot more comfortable than what I expected. This shouldn't be missed.

Touristy fun.. Again this features on all organised tours. It is a bit of fun showcasing a northern Vietnam tradition. An hour well spent but you do know it is for you only and is not somewhere the local Vietnamese attend regularly.

Exquisite insight into a fascinating art form.. Live performers and musicians tell the story and provide the dialogue for this highly theatrical piece of puppetry. Very colourful, fast-moving yet with a delicacy and deftness of touch that leave the audience wondering how on earth the performance is possible. My partner, who goes fishing, said that the movement of the fish in the water was breathtakingly accurate. All in all, a little gem not be missed in Ha Noi. P.S. All shows sell out, so book in advance if at all possible.

Quite different and very impressive. They play to full houses most of the time and no surprise - good entertainment with a high skill level. 14 separate acts all with a good local story and support music.
Fun and interesting. For 50 minutes and 100000 Dong it is worth going to see even if you can't understand it. Also understand there is a similar show in Saigon.

A fun look into old culture. The water puppet show is bad and great at the same time. Don't take it too seriously, just enjoy the cultural insight and the occasional ridiculousness. A (bearable because of the short duration) downside to the show is the small seats, if you're taller than 1,85m your knees will endure some pain.
Understand the People. The unique show gives you an insight into the Vietnamese culture by way of well narrated, enacted & intricately woven dozen odd folktales. Must see event.

A good way to spend one hour in the evening. Really different way of puppetering and some novel story telling. All the dialogue is in Vietnamese and was a bit loud, though you don't need to speak Vietnamese to enjoy their great show.
I would recommend to spend a hour in the evening to see this show.

Watery puppets. A bit overrated but still interesting.
Our seats cost 100,000Dong and there were seats of 60,000Dong.
I still cannot see the difference. Row K wasn't too good for filming or photos.

Good show. This was a nice way to spend an hour. It is all in Vietnamese and so it was difficult to follow. We bought the tickets at the boxoffice outside and there was no issue with needing to book in advance. The seating is small and there is not much leg space, I'm 5'7 and was slightly uncomfortable. I probably wouldn't go again but am glad I experienced it.

Nice show.. A traditional water puppet show in a small theatre. The show is in Vietnamese language accompanied by live music from an small orchestra. We had never seen something like this before and found it very nice and entertaining. Do not expect spectacular effects like in Holywood blockbuster movies but they do some impressive stuff during the show.Tip: try to book ahead and insist on seats on the first few rows (1 to 4 or maybe until 6). Although it is a small theatre, I can imagine that you will not see to much on the last rows. The show takes about 45 minutes.
wow!. I've never been to a theatre where all the puppetry takes place in water. very colourful and easy to follow.

Punch and Judy on water!. Really different way of puppetering and some novel story telling. All the dialogue is in Vietnamese so was a little hard to understand what was going on a times which did make the time drag. Overall though you don't need to speak Vietnamese to enjoy their great show
Interesting for first 5 mins . Interesting and one of a kind show BUT gets boring after first 5mins. It would be better if there was translation and we could understand the story.

really different for a tourist, worth seeing. I really enjoyed the show. The theatre is very comfortable. The story is sung in Vietnamese, but you have no trouble understanding the story from the antics of the puppets. The puppeteers who come out at the end of the show do a wonderful performance. Still wonder how they did some of the movements. Worth a trip

Do it if you have nothing else to do. It takes a lot of nativity some times to enjoy a show but this one for us it was a waste of time that we could have use to see the city. Nothing interesting here; it could be good for 5 years old kids, but I doubt.

Ummmm....what the hell just happened?????. I am not sure what I saw in that theater but it I am sure David Lynch directed it!
Not a waste of 45minutes.....but certainly something that will leave you bewildered for a long time.
Seats are tiny for westerners so leave your kneecaps at home.

A bit like Punch & Judy. Whilst on a walking tour of Hoan Kiem Lake earlier in the day, I'd passed the Water Puppet Theatre, and also the staff at my hotel - St Joseph's Hang Da, also gave good reviews.I booked my ticket and was seated in the front row. The show was a great spectacle and certainly something I'd recommend for those with children. It was also at this point I learnt about the Turtle, Phoenix, Unicorn and Dragon which helped me win a pub quiz later on this holiday.The great spectacle of all of this was that it's in water! The puppets are made of wood that will only last a short time as they start to get mouldy. All very interesting and something to see.

Really cool show. I went to see the show with 12 other friends of mine and we really enjoyed it. The music was amazing and the show was incredibly well put together. If you've got a spare evening in Hanoi I would definitely recommend seeing this show even though you can't really understand what's going on in the dialogue.

Interesting but....... The water puppets were very interesting but we could not see very well. I guess we were about 10 rows back and could hardly see the puppets through other peoples heads in the way. That was very disappointing. We even paid the higher price so we could see but may as well have paid the lower price.

Like nothing I have ever seen. I quite enjoyed this show. I think it got better and better as the show progressed and I marveled more and more at the skill of the puppeteers and the fact that they do this standing in water! It won't be everyone's cup of tea, and the music may not be to some "westerners" liking....but I love immersing myself in the local culture.

Underwhelmed. Not off to a good start. At 6 ft one inch tall, my knees were tight up against the row of seats in front of us. I thought some of the show was interesting from a technical standpoint, but being all in vietnamese it was difficult to follow. We would not return, nor would we recommend it.

Its a puppet show..... This was an experience.....one i'm not quite sure how to put into words.....it was as it says a water puppet show, it's hard to understand if there was any relevance or story other than the puppets dancing on the water.However despite saying that the musicians who were singing and playing instruments were fantastic and actually I would have rather paid to sit and watch them sing and play their instruments rather than puppets splashing around.Go but do not have any expectations other than puppets dancing on water, it does what it says on the tin, if you like puppets you're on to a winner.

Water puppet show. The water puppet show in hanoi is unique.no where in the world can you see this.very impressive.the puppets seem to enjoy swimming and doing stunts in the water.impressive puppeteers accompanied by a talented group of singers and accompanying instrumentalists.a must see event in hanoi.
It's ok, but not understand what's the story about. It is a traditional show in Vietnam, however the language and the story line is not understand-able for foreigners.
Facinating insight to Old Vietnam. Enjoyable show illustrating the traditional beliefs and ways of Viet Nam. Tickets need to be booked in advance to save disappointment.

Super experience. This one hour show was very entertaining with several short scenes accompanied by live music. It was nice to spend this time out of the hustle and bustle of the city,to relax and be entertained by these clever puppets and puppeteers.

Quick 45 minutes. we were told this was a show not the missed but I have to say we would not have missed anything if we did not go. The actual show is ok, it lasts about 45 minutes and is relatively interesting...luckily we had someone translating for us...otherwise it is all in Vietnamese and you could get very lost. The seats are tiny, with no leg room whatsoever...I was ready to leave after 20 mins as my legs were cramping up. Bus loads of tourists come to the show so if you do go and see it try and go in the middle of the day as should be quieter. Overall there are a ton more things to do and see in Hanoi, understanding that this is historical.

Something Different but go if you're wide awake. This water puppet show is unique in that the stage is on water and all the puppets are manipulated under the water, so you see puppets swimming and splashing around the entire program. Unfortunately, after the initial few minutes of exposure, it cools off pretty rapidly as the program is pretty lengthy and story told in Vietnamese. The orchestra has a unique one string zither-like instrument kept me interested as I've not seen such an instrument before and how it's played. Otherwise, I certainly would've dozed off during some part of the program. Go for the experience but be fresh or else, you will definitely nap during some parts of this program.
Not bad but a bit dull. After all its a traditional show in Vietnamese. It becomes a bit boring after 20-25 mins. Worth seeing but do not expect to much.

A Hanoi Must-See!. The Water puppet Show is typical and traditional only in Hanoi. While I almost cancelled my visit (thought it might be too touristy), I decided to try it and thoroughly enjoyed it! A must see, last 45 minutes, is very cute, great music, singing and performance (for only US5!) Kids and adults alike enjoy it.

Left too quickly!. Invented thousands of years ago by farmers in the Red River Delta region near Hanoi, the water puppets were a means to entertain the farmers when the rains flooded their paddy fields. The performers who entertained us with this lovely show were amazing with their skills, and the musical accompaniament was beautiful. You are allowed to take photographs, but they are a bit blurry unless you have an expensive camera - I got a couple of good shots, but found that a short video was a much better option, and it also captured the music. We were with a tour, and were rushed back to our bus for return to our hotel, which was a shame, as many would have loved to buy the toy puppets after the performance. We left too quickly! Bit of a shame, but the performance was well worth attending.

Fun way to spend 45 minutes. I had been advised by a couple of friends not to visit this show in Hanoi, as it wasn't worth the effort. However, I decided to go anyway as I wanted to experience some 'traditional culture'. I'm glad I did, as I thought the show was sweet and I actually enjoyed it. There is no English so you need to read the programme first to understand what is going on, but once you do this it all makes sense! That said I am glad it is only 45 minutes long as any longer and it may have become a little tedious. It also wouldn't hurt to clean the stale water once in a while.....it was certainly the smelliest show I've ever seen!!

A cultural must - and a little boring!. We went on our first night in Hanoi and had a pleasant if bland experience. Punch & Judy in water, Vietnamese music and singing and the 45 minute performance was appropriately short. (Very little legroom for tall Westeners.)

Nice, but hard to follow if you don't speak Vietnamese. Puppets, music, decoration, effects, all very nice, but if you don't speak the language it's hard to follow. Overall it is worth going, I'd go again if I had to do the trip over again.

Oh my god- too stupid-. First off 20.00 for 'premier' seating- hot, cramped, full (like 90%) of tour bus masses- several pulling out video recorders from the minute the show started- Honestly we only lasted 20 minutes of this mess- I felt it was a total rip the masses off experience.

A delightful and colourful spectacle. This is a wonderful theatrical experience as well as another insight into Vietnamese cultural life; it is worthy of its reputation especially because you don't get the sense that this is a fabricated tourist creation. It has lots of passion and energy and imagination.

OK show. so the show was ok, the music as well. My favourite part was the dragons and fish scene. Though worth seeing the seats are really tiny and they pack in as many people as possible (which is quite obvious). worth going to and seeing.

shiny fun puppet show. loved the authentic original music. Clarely this was for tourists, but nothing cheesy about it. Was fascinating to watch for about the first 1/2 hour, then became less about the puppets and more about the puppeteers.

Ticked the box of done/seen, but was not one for me. Ticked the box of done/seen, but was not one for me.
Plenty of people were dozing off during the performance.

This show is never good. I have seen this show three times over a 10 year period. The theater has the smallest seats of any theater I have been in and most uncomfortable. They jam as many people in to see this show of the puppets, that are just like your puppets back home dancing around. This art form has been performed for years however I find it just boring. I have hoped for years that they would put a good product out there but to no avail. It is really for the mainstream tourgroups who are trying to fill their peoples days. In a word, Bleeeeech.
Just don't miss it!. Whatever else you do in Hanoi, do this. But book or you probably won't get in. Lovely folk orchestra - sit on the right to see them well.

Very entertaining good value. We came across this theatre on a walk around the lake and booked on impulse. We are really glad we did. It was not expensive but very entertaining. The puppetry is good and the singers and musicians very talented. It was no wonder that the theatre was full. We really enjoyed this show and would recommend it to others .

Enjoyable Experience. I was quite shocked to see so many negative reviews for this show. At 50 minutes long, I found it to be an enjoyable length of time to experience this art form. The show is entirely in Vietnamese, and there is no english (or other) translation other than the titles of each segment on the program. I did not find not "knowing" what was going on to be a hinderance to my enjoyment. I understand that in a foreign country, the theater is going to be conducted in their native language. It is like that all over the world.The water puppets varied depending on the segment and were quite detailed. I enjoyed the flaming dragons and drum scenes the most. There was careful choreography as well as humor throughout the show. The puppeteers come out at the end of the show and it was interesting to see how few people operated so many puppets at once. The musicians did a wonderful job as well.The theater allows photography and videotaping for a $1 fee.
