If you are in the back rows, expect to see many phones and cameras lighting up the area in front of you. There was only one or two rude people who blatantly held their cameras above their heads. The rest of them were held in front of people and didn't block your view.The only thing that detracted from the experience for me were the small seats. I do not consider myself to be very tall at 5'9", but my knees were firmly against the seat in front of me from the moment I sat down. I do not know how the taller individuals in our group were able to fit comfortably in these seats other than sitting at the aisle with legs extended. If you are on the tall side, ask for an aisle or front row seat.

Lost in Translation. Interesting puppet show on water which I've not seen anywhere else in the world. The one page flyer had a short write-up and I think more details can be done to provided as I only recognised 1 of the story. Has not changed in improving the story telling since I visited 11 years ago.

Good for kids and seniors!. Its a very busy show with a mid sized hall full to the last seat ! Lots of seniors and tour groups make sure all the shows are sold out . Book a few hours or a day ahead to get your show time and seats that you want.Tickets are for 100.000 vnd for the front rows and 60.000 vnd for the rear seats. Just buy the 60.000 as the views all the same . Its not a very big hall. Make sure you pick up the leaflet brochure just before you enter the main hall which has a list of all the items being performed , so you know what's going on . To keep the purity of the show , all the dialogues are in the local language , so not much help on that front .  In my opinion , However i would prefer to watch a cultural song and dance over this show .Its a average show , watch if you are enthusiastic !

Great and exciting experience. The show is very enjoyable and fun. Before watching i think it must be a bit sleepy because of the traditional music, but I changed my mind immediately after it started. The singers are awesome, adorable, so are the artists behind the curtain. Puppets are beautiful and colourful. Fee is from 60k to 100k which is very reasonable. They also sell small puppets around 60k/each.
We thought is was great!. Very much a tourist attraction but immensely entertaining. Would definitely recommend a visit We are still wondering how it was done!

Wonderful puppets. The variety of the puppets was amazing. We enjoyed this show but would have liked to have read a little about the background to the various stories. It was interesting to watch the Vietnamese instruments being played as they were clearly visible at the side of the stage.

Very clever. This is an entertaining & clever puppet show. There were a lot of older (60+) people there and they seemed to really enjoying it. Our 12 & 14 year old sons thought it was a bit 'lame'. The skills of the musicians were unfortunately not appreciated by them - it's Vietnamese traditional singing & music. I thought it was very clever & worth the visit.

Punch and Judy on water. A good dose of slapstick humour, and interesting to see a traditional art form. I'd probably have enjoyed it as much for 30mins (rather than the full hour) but well worth dropping in.

Great Vietnamese cultural experience. We really enjoyed this show. It was very professional, with traditional music and singing, beautifully choreographed, colourful puppets. Lovely show with a little bit of humour, fun for the whole family
A must see and do!. This is unique and enchanting....they are so good at what they do! Provided as part of our tour, you will be mesmerised by all the different characters.

Much Better than Expected. I was walking along Dien Tien Hoang Street at 9:20 AM on a Sunday when I saw the theatre and its advertisement for a 9:30 AM performance. For 100000 VND ($5), I had a middle of the fourth row seat. A 10-person musical and vocal ensemble playing traditional music and songs accompanied the performance. The puppeteers operate the characters by using sticks and strings-all underwater. The puppets appear to be floating/swimming/moving along the surface of the stage-a 10 meter by 10 meter or so pool of murky, green water. What a great performance! I spent most of the time trying to figure out how they made it look so realistic and the other half of the time enjoying the spectacle: smoke, fire, colorful characters-and laughing children. The show lasted about an hour and 15 minutes and is really a unique, artistic treat. The only negative comment I have is not directed at the performers or the performance. Some of the adults in the audience felt it necessary to hold their camera and cell phones high in the air-blocking others' sight lines-while, obliviously, recording long videos to entertain future generations. Sit back a few rows to avoid them.

Total Waste. We tried repeatedly to get our tour agent to take this activity off our schedule, but he insisted we do it. We were right; he was wrong. Midway through the show, the Vietnamese man 3 seats from us started snoring so loudly we couldn't hear the singing. We should have applauded!

Fascinating Insight into Vietnamese Water Puppetry. Water puppetry is a fascinating art showcasing Vietnam's folklore and the means of entertainment for the native folks in centuries past. Let me note that people either "get" this attraction or not. If one goes in without any insight or idea of what is happening, one gets bored very very quickly, as evidenced by some of the other reviews on this site. I would equate this to walking into an Italian Opera with absolutely no knowledge of what is happening and attempting to make sense of it all. As such, first thing before you go in, grab the programme (it is available in multiple languages, English included) and have a quick read before the act starts, it will help you understand what is being portrayed. The complexity and skill of the puppet artists were evident in the motion of the puppets, swaying, undulating and even climbing a tree. Those from sinitic backgrounds may recognise some of the shared culture we have with the Vietnamese in terms of the Lion Dance, but on water, which was an eye opener to me. The show is accompanied by a traditional Vietnamese orchestra and singers, of which little would make sense to anyone but locals, I urge you to hear past the lyrics but enjoy the music with the show. Taller attendees may find the seats to be quite tight, I am 1.8m tall and found that my knees were pretty much wedged into the seat in front of me, those seats were evidently made for much shorter people. Enjoy the show for the art that it is, and do not expect special effects or whatsoever, and please, respect the audience and the artists by not leaving in the middle of the performance, which meant standing up and blocking everyone's view for 5 minutes.
absolutely lovely. beautiful musicians, touching music, sweet puppetstory, extraordinary technic to move the puppets. it is a must to go there, never I have seen something like this.

Good and interesting.... The music and the water puppetry was good. Easy to understand. There are parts that dragged a bit, but some parts were funny and interesting. Got a good glimpse of the culture and the marionettes were skilled. Imagine being in that water for a good hour?

Very entertaining. My husband and I really enjoyed this show. The performance & puppetry is fantastic & so very different. It's probably not something we would choose to see again, but is definitely worth a visit and is not expensive.

Boring. It is not expensice but not even worth it. Too boring, so many tourists were actually sleeping during the performance.
I wouldn't go again.

Puppets? Yes!. Those are puppets in the water. A very old way to entertain the royals. Try to be in the middle of the theatre. The stories are naive but are very well worthed... If you like after the show you can buy a puppet and outside the building there are many stores for local handicraft!

Funny and fulfulling experience. Myself and my friend went to this not really sure what to expect, but really did enjoy the show.The show we saw ran at about 50 minutes which is probably more than enough.The band were brilliant and we were both impressed with how they were playing their music from sight.The show is a fun experience, where audience members are welcomed to take pictures during the performance. But I did find myself having to check my Programme during the Performance to see what part of the show we were on. Maybe each new theme of performance they are moving onto could be made more clear to the audience. But, on the whole, great value for money at 100,000 VND a ticket which our Hotel was able to book us for on the day of the performance.

Horrible Service. i was looking forward to attending the Water puppet show, however having arrived at receiving terrible service towards simple basic question, decided not to go in. I'm sure the show was great though.......never got to see it!
Water Puppet. We had high expectations from the show, but it was a little bit disappointed. Old theater was nice but we expected more excitement.
Marvellous show. My first time to watch the water puppet show.The show was excellent. The music was lovely. Book a ticket in the morning which costs 100,000 VND to get a front seat.

Nice to see whilst in Vietnam. This was a nice 40 minute show and if you have the time you should go see it whilst in Vietnam.The seats are small so get quite uncomfortable.The introduction is spoken in English and there are leaflets outside in many languages so you can follow what is going on.It wasn't my favourite thing I've done whilst in Vietnam but if you've got a spare hour you should go.

Love the cute fans the theatre come with. MAN. This place is HOT. they give you free fans, if not you'll incinerate from the heat of the puppet show lights.
It is pretty cool, i haven't seen anything like it, but it also is exactly like what it says it is. A puppet show, with water.

Vietnamese water puppets. Definitely worth doing. The show lasts about an hour, and tickets are sold from the venue on the day of the performance (although our hotel was able to arrange tickets for us). Tickets are roughly £3 per person I think. The performers are really very good, and I found the music quite interesting also, as it includes several instruments which I had not seen before in western music. Sweet stories, would appeal to children and adults.
Delightful hours entertainment. Young and old alike should enjoy an hour at this venue.The puppeteers and musicians are first class and it's the first time we had experienced this art form.

different but fun. the music in Vietnam is very different from what we are used to. We might ask 'who is strangling the cat?', but when you really listen, you hear the subtle changes. It's really an art to be able to sing like that! The puppets are simple and are moved through the water on sticks. All in all quite some fun! The stories are short so even if you can't understand, you will not be bored!

Great experience. We would recommend this show if you want to get a sense of the Vietnamese tradition. The water puppet show involves puppets that tellfolk stories controlled from behind curtains by puppeteers. The show is accompanied by a small orchestra. The location of the theater is very good and you can have something to eat or drink at the last floor of the nearby City Cafe with an incredible view over the crowded Hanoi street.

Music is nicer than the puppets. The water puppet show is good. A nice art work and tipical. But it is a little repetitive and and you can only guess the story they are telling because it has no explanation in between performances. Musics are the highlights!

good to experience. glad we went to see the water puppets. The shows are under an hour, and was nice to see and hear some traditional music and culture. Would recommend booking ahead though if you can. when we turned up the evening show for the next 3 nights was fully booked so we had to go to day time show.

Simply magic.. The show contains basic scene of life so no need of subtitle.The puppet are really awesome and a lot of amazing effects help anyone falling for the show.Even if we are a photography lovers couple we dont think the paying photo option is worthing.The show is designed to be see with children.In our opinion it a must todo in hanoi.Have a good show.
Great one off. So glad we went. Fabulous cultural experience. Be warned ... If you are over 5 feet 4inches tall, it is virtually impossible to take your legs. Try and get an aisle seat!

Nice cultural experience. Very nice show but in Vietnamese. They provide a program in English though. The seats were a bit tight compared to Western standards and I ended up sitting on a foldable chair on the aisle. A definite recommend if you are in Hanoi.

Cultural experience. This is certainly worth going to if you're in Hanoi (we saw an advert for another one in Ho Chi Minh City so it's not unique to Hanoi as they claim). 50 minutes worth of folk stories told by puppets, controlled from behind the curtains by soggy puppeteers and accompanied by a 9 piece singing orchestra. Punch and Judy shows are the only thing that spring to mind as a comparator but this is so much more sophisticated.I'm glad I've been once but wouldn't queue to repeat the experience.

Funny show! Really traditional. ^^. The show was amazing. These talented artists stand behind the controls puppets. They have restated historical tales, folk tales Vietnam. It really means a lot, even those who foreign visitors understand its contents, although they speak Vietnamese.

The Puppeteers. This is certainly worth seeing, but really only because it's so different. The stories are a bit basic, and the sight of things popping out from behind a curtain and being dragged across an indoor pond while doing other things, all accompanied by music has a limited appeal!

Not to be Missed (if you like foreign cultures). Being able to witness a tradition that has been handed down from generation to generation, however muddled in modern nuances as long as its not excessive; is always and should be a joy and honor to witness.a throwback to the 11th century tradition,Múa rối nước, as its known in vietnamese, the THang Long theater gives an ornately aesthetic and pleasing performance that contains tons of vietnamese rural folklore and traditions.From farming to unicorns and dragons dancing, and other mundane activities of life in rural 11th century Vietnam are brought to life in the most vivid and entertaining manner.Particularly poignant is the band and the singers who as i understand, narrate, chant, and sing the narrative and plot of the performance.Do not miss this. And please turn off your camera flashes - its very irritating.

Different. Well, it certainly is different and I guess very reflective of local culture. All the signing that tells the story is in Vietnamese of course - so its difficult to follow whats going on, but very clever and good to say you've been there. Not sure it would be a regular destination for me though,

Beautiful theatre - fun show. Show was in a magnificent old theatre building on a street running up from the lake. The building is a colonial experience in itself. Delightful show with fire breathing dragons and leaping fish all in gorgeous irradescent colours. Live band on traditional instruments. Sweet traditional entertainment that has been performed this way for a long time. Must see.

Interesting amusing show. We didn't expect much as we entered the theater and we were a little skeptical at first ... But after 5 minutes of traditional music and songs, the show takes off and send you to an other world : it was fun and very well done. We spent a great time watching water puppets !
Great show. Very interesting show displaying the cultural side of Vietnam. It's brilliantly played and should certainly not be missed if you are in Hanoi.
Interesting. It was a short 50 minute show opposite the Lake. It was fun to watch and definitely entertaining. Perfect for in between the walking around and exploring.

Sweet show with traditional music. I think every visitor to Hanoi goes here once. The music is beautiful and the puppets are authentic. The show that we attended was sold out and lasted about 50 minutes. Unfortunately a tourist seated near us used flash photography all during the show, which was distracting. We paid for vip seats, but I think all the seats in the house are good.

Must see in Hanoi. I went to this show not knowing what to expect. As I used to work in the sound/lighting industry I had worked with a lot of different performers before so was looking forward to what they might do. The show certainly didn't disappoint me. Although the entire thing is in Vietnamese, if you have been given some history about Vietnam you'll "get it". The performers are very well rehearsed and the musicians are good. The production wasn't great considering the popularity of this show. It wasn't bad, although the PA system kept distorting and crackling.

Vietnamese Legends. We found the show delightful. A series of short stories told with puppets and traditional musicians. It was very good value for money, just the right length and the puppeteers are very skilled. We bought our tickets during the day for one evening performance. I believe it sells out.

cheap and fun. We bought the cheapest seats all the way in the back row, but we could see fine and even though we didn't understand the words, the music was great and it was very entertaining. We bought tickets the same day, but couldn't get the immediate show. Had to wait til a later one.

Colorful and melodious. So cute n colorful, loved the music. Goes for a out 45 minuts. Tickets get sold out early, especially for the evening shows but buy two tickets and get 1 free coffee (daytime) / beer (evening) at the bar! Great artists, really enjoyed the show after a day of visa hassle.

Interesting show. Saw the show recently during a vacation to Vietnam. The seats are not set up well for viewing. I could basically only see the middle of the stage as two tall people blocked my view of everything happening on the right or left side. It was an interesting show and gives tourists a good feel for the Vietnamese culture, altough the show could have been a little shorter. The scenes get a bit repetitive after a while.
Unreal. It was really good my daughter thought it was magical and was very entertain by it. It was very smart and well done we all enjoy it.
What just happened? . That was.... Different! Can't say it was good, can't say it was bad! Not really to sure what to say!!! If your into puppets then it's worth checking out
Nice place to admire the Vietnamese Culture. The show is Culturally spectacular. very well presented with colonial music and fashion. Another place not to miss.

Fun!. The water puppet show is indeed fun, carried out in Vietnamese language, no English narration but there are brochures about each act in many languages. It's amazing and fun if it's the first-time you're watching it.

Spoiled by the audience. Despite the interesting and enjoyable puppet production, accompanied by traditional Vietnamese musical instruments and vocals, the theatre's viewing policies let it down badly.My daughter and I sat down in our seats as the auditorium filled to capacity - we visited in late December '13 during peak tourist season - and prepared to be surprised and delighted by this quintessentially Vietnamese art form.As soon as the show started we were blinded by the blue glare of the phalanx of iPhones and tablets of two out of three members of the vast audience, some of whom preferred to let their devices do their viewing/listening while conducting conversations with each other.Frankly, the experience was spoiled by the desperate compulsion endemic amongst embarrassing western tourists to video every moment of the show and anything else they get up to on holiday. How do these clowns remember what they did on vacation before the advent of the smartphone???Until the management of the theatre introduce a ban on cameras and recording devices (like in any cinema) I recommend giving this place a miss.
Nice Traditional Show. The show was nice and enjoyable but sitting for the duration of the show was not comfortable at all, the space between the rows is very small and not enough for an adult.
Puppets aren't just for kids. The puppet vignettes were easy to understand and funny. A fun way to spend an hour or so. Shows are frequent so you can stop by when in the old quarter.

Theatre with a difference. I loved the production. The music was provided by a trio of 2 ladies and a gentleman on one side of the stage with a small band the other side. The story was based on a Vietnam tale and even if, like me you had no knowledge of the language the story was easy to follow. The puppets were excellent and the whole thing was so colourful and different. I thoroughly enjoyed it.

Thang Long Water Puppet Theatre is mesmerising. Thang Long Water Puppet Theatre is well worth the visit. Even my husband who came along grudgingly later admitted he enjoyed the show and that it was a cultural highlight of our trip.The mix of traditional puppetry, musical instruments and singing is really quite mesmerising. The artists are truly talented and you can’t help but admire their abilities long after the show has ended. My husband and I could figure out which way to look – at the puppets or at the musicians.The puppet show itself is quite dynamic and colourful. We were totally impressed by the dragon puppets who still breathed fire after emerging from the water several times. The love story of the water birds also was fascinating. A cute little baby bird pops up after the romantic dance of the parent birds. Despite the story being told in Vietnamese you soon get the idea of the story from the puppetry itself.The audience sits in a old theatre which despite being crowded and hot has an old world charm about it. Guests for the most part were friendly and polite so being crowded didn’t really bother us. It’s a good idea to take a fan with you though because the heat in a crowded old building soon seems to creep in on you. Probably not the best seating for someone really tall or large in build, butthat is to be expected in a Vietnamese environment.Be aware though that photography is not allowed during the puppet show unless you pay a small camera fee with your ticket. If you have a tour guide please make sure to tell them that you will be taking photographs so they can advise the ticket booth and pay accordingly.Even if you only have an hour to spare when in Hanoi this is a great attraction to visit.

Something a little different. We really enjoyed the water puppet show. It was something a little different and good fun. It lasted about an hour, which was perfect - not too long, not too short. Would recommend.

A Must See. Seeing the Water Puppets is a must see for anyone visiting Vietnam. The puppets portray scenes from traditional life acted out to live music in a comfortable theater setting with lots of splashing. It really was fun to watch.There are shows throughout the day, and tickets, which cost less than $5, can be purchased at the theater box office or through your hotel.

Not to be missed!. I had not expected to be enthralled by the performance but what a surprise. The dragon puppets spouting fire and sprays of water just tremendous. A cross between 'Punch and Judy' and synchronised swimming - if that makes sense. you just have to go.

Water Puppets.. Typical Far eastern organisation, chaotic both inside and outside the theatre but once seated the show was fantastic, music and voices even though in Vietnamise were brilliant. Well worth the hassle greeting in and out..

If you're tall, get an isle seat. This is a great show, the sound and puppet sync movements are very enjoyable to watch, however be mindful that the theater is small and the 40 mins show will strain your legs if you're tall as there is not enough legroom for you - so get an isle seat for your comfort and could enjoy the show to the fullest.

show. Great for kids too. A little pricey, era 100 000vnd but well worth it.Educational, cultural and historical.My 4 year old daughter made me take her back for the next two consecutive days!A 'gotta be', especially if you are by the lake.

A show worth seeing!!. A very interesting and traditional performance. The stage was devided in two parts: singers who were accompanied by instruments and the puppets in the water. The show was basically about vietnamese traditional myths/short stories. However, the whole show was in Vietnamese, so I couldn't understand much...but it is something different to common theater shows.
Worth seeing. Interesting insight into culture .Something worth seeing when in Hanoi.Make sure you get tickets the day before

Very Talented. What an amazing show from the start to the finish. I would certainly recommend it, a well worth visit. We didn't understand the language but that was fine you got the gist' of the little playlets.
good for children and adults. High class skillful entertainment that can be enjoyed by all age ranges.Good value for money. A must if you visit the area,
Traditional music and puppetry. We spent a lovely hour of live traditional music and storytelling through water puppets. Well worth a visit.

Great show!. I really did not know what to expect with this show, but left amazed at the creativity and entertainment. Some of the storyline was a bit difficult to understand since it was all in Vietnamese, but the beauty of the puppets made up for that. I have never seen anything like it and would recommend it to all visitors when in Hanoi.
Water Puppet. It's wonderful how they did it and even though you don't understand the language. The water puppet looks so real.

So much hype, so little fun. Everyone told us "the water puppets, the water puppets" and I guess it was our expectations that killed it for us. First, it was indoors - like why would you watch Water Puppets in doors? Second, it was kind of boring . . . puppets on long poles swishing around a pool of water (stage) acting out scenes. The authentic music and singing was nice and there was some real talent. But we would give it a pass.

Great show to watch with the whole family. I went to Thang Long Water Puppet Show in October and was not disappointed. The whole performance is great. The show is split into various folk tales and stories told using amazing puppets and traditional music. I would advise saving this show until after you have done some trips around Hanoi and the surrounds to learn about the history to better understand the stories as they are only narrated in Vietnamese.Overall though a very pleasant experience and worth a watch!

Lots of fun!. This show went for around 45 minutes and was excellent. The puppeteers were so good and, although the songs are in Vietnamese, it is explained in English first so you do know what is going on. Parts were very funny and was so enjoyable. Would definitely recommend this show.

Must see!. I usually don't spend money on attending shows while traveling because I usually travel on budget, but attending water puppet show at Thang Long was definitely worth it. The show has live orchestra, very comfortable theater and displays stories of tribals of vietnam. Do no miss it I would say!

Was there 6 years ago but it's not the same anymore. The puppet show is no longer with a good story line. There are disconnections on the understanding of the whole story. I fell asleep halfway. The coordination of the puppets shows that the puppeteers have no enthusiasm in the performance. Anyhow, this is a must-do thing when you are in Hanoi. The wooden puppets are still very charming. The lady singer sings well still.

We loved it!!. This was a highlight of our trip - our kids were looking forward to it and were not disappointed. Granted, it was a bit different than what they were expecting, but captivating nonetheless. Our children are adopted from VietNam, and have a vested interest in the culture and traditions, but Grandma thoroughly enjoyed herself as well. It is well worth the price. Be aware, though, that the music is very traditional and not easily acceptable to the inexperienced Western ear. The first time I went, I can't say that I completely enjoyed myself although I really liked watching the puppets perform. This time however, I've had a few more Asian experiences under my belt and the music differences did not bother me; in fact, I realized that I have grown to appreciate Asian-style music, language, and culture. So if you're open to new experiences, you'll love this show!

Something Vietnamese and Different. It was great to visit a part of Vietnamese culture that felt old and traditional, there is so much change in Hanoi in terms of development and increased exposure to tourism that it felt like something that could have been local to the country not invented to encourage spending. I mostly enjoyed the Vietnamese music as the string instruments were fascinating.

Great for families. This was a return trip for me to see the show and enjoyed it more this time around. I saw the show 11 years ago and remembered it as fair. This time around was with my teenagers who really enjoyed the musical talent and the variety and skill of the puppeteers. The puppets themselves are brighter and in good shape. We really enjoyed the musical talent the best!The chairs are not comfortable for Westerers as we have long legs. We did find it annoying that people prefer to video the majority of the show than to watch it. Dodging all the camera screens throughout the shows was distracting to us. A possible solution is to sell small programs with nice photos and details about the show. Also, a professionally filmed cd or usb for sale of the show may be another option.Nicely artistically designed tshirts with water puppets on them might sell as well.

Fun for all the family. Really enjoyed the show. It was entertaining and funny. Grab a leaflet on the way into the theatre as it gives you an idea of what each 'act' is but even though the dialogue is in vietnamese you still get what's happening. Worth a visit. Show is about 45 mins and you can get tickets for 60,000 or 100,000 dong.

A must-see for traditional culture seekers. We had never seen a water puppet show before and did not really know what to expect but this was a highlight of our trip. The basic premise is a stage filled with water on which puppets convey a story. You can not see how the puppets are moved, or see the puppeteers (except a brief glimpse of a hand at one point) during the show. Live music and singing is delivered by performers to one side of the stage who were clearly enjoying themselves, laughing and joking with each other inbetween the singing and playing. The puppets themselves are very varied and the actions are beautifully performed, from people and animals working the fields, to fishermen, to dancers, dragons, even the mating dances of birds. Some of the puppets carry flaming torches (was unable to tell if the flame was real or not but it looked like it) and the lights dimmed further for this night time dance scene. On other occasions fish swam, butterflies flapped around and a frog leapt back and forth across the water.My understanding is that there are in fact many different stories and which one you see will vary, but the troupe performing it have won awards around the world and the professionalism clearly showed.I could not follow the story and have no idea what was going on honestly but we enjoy that. We don't look for english speaking tourist events, but rather for the traditional culture and we found it here.You are allowed to take pictures and even film the event if you wish, though it would have been nice if they sold DVD's of it. We would certainly have bought a copy.The seats were comfortable although leg room was very tight. For a 50 minute show they were good enough. The price was very reasonable too and the building houses a waiting area and cafe downstairs and is fully air conditioned.All in all, absolutely wonderful. If you are interested in the culture, are not phased by non english performances and are in Hanoi, this is a must see show. I would point out though that this is NOT an english style puppet show. Do not expect Punch & Judy and be aware that this is not aimed at young children, who may well find it boring (as evidenced by the family with 3 youngsters sat directly behind us who did nothing but talk through the entire show). I cannot blame the show for inconsiderate audience members though so an easy 5 stars is well deserved.

Interesting folklore but difficult to appreciate. It's a unique experience: puppets dancing around in water, being manipulated by people who are out of sight. We were unable to follow the stories being acted out. By the end of the hour we had reached our limit of enjoyment. There is traditional music that's interesting enough although the singing parts are somewhat difficult for the western ear. The musicians try hard to appear enthusiastic even though they undoubtedly have been performing the same set hundreds of times, several times each night. The experience is unusual. However, its entertainment value and its educational value are both low because we couldn't appreciate it.

Traditional music and puppets. The Thang Long Water Puppet show was wonderful. I enjoyed the music and singing. It was perhaps a little long in duration but was speacial as it was something we had never seen before.

This gets fully booked so buy tickets early.. Very interesting way of introducing one's history or let's say legends of the past. I haven't figures out how the puppeteers do it, but it couldn't be easy. You must read the English story first to a precise what's going on. The singers are good but for you to get to know what's being said, you need to know the context first.The show is for 50 minutes. So for those who will enjoy it, it's long enough; for those who will find it boring, it's not too long!
Puppets and music. Just found this a little boring but really enjoyed the live dialogue and singing...however puppets didn't change movement too much at all...very repetitive.
Interesting concept with lot of potential application in children education. Really good and worth seeing. Proved language is not a barrier to understand the concept. Kids enjoyed thoroughly

OK, but Better Options Exist. While the water puppet show is a traditional activity, and perhaps kids enjoy it more, we didn't really enjoy it. After a long day of activities, most of our group fell asleep once the lights went down! We did not always know what was going on, despite the brief explanation they provide. It's interesting to see the puppets work. It's nice to see, but I would not put this on the "must do" list.
Viva Vietnam. Brilliant, the narration and the actual puppets are done in a superior manner - suitable to all young and old

Interesting but doesn't hold the attention. The show was interesting and different with some cool and clever moments however it failed to hold the attention of the audience. When I attended, approx. 50 people left before the end and people in my group fell asleep.The seats are very uncomfortable (no leg room) and at over 6 foot tall I ended up sitting on the floor in the aisle for some respite.If you haven't seen the show it is worth going but set your expectations before you go.
Water Puppet. A very hyped up review. It was interesting but not interesting enough to keep me awake as I fell asleep watching it. This was late afternoon.
Not worth it. Don't spoil your time to this show...Lots of people were sleeping during the show...Music annoying and the show was very boring...

thang long water puppet theatre. We went along to see this show thinking that it might get a bit monotonous after a while. We were wrong! This was a great and entertaining show. Great value for the 100,000 ($5) entrance fee.

Nice cultural experience!. The show itself was rather good, not mind-blowing but pretty nice. The mini orchestra played and sung well and it was funny in parts. The bad points were that first of all the row of people behind us would not stop talking! Everyone had there ipads out filming it so that was off putting and killed the atmosphere somewhat. There was also NO legroom. We are pretty tall and it was painful!! The show was short though so this wasn't as bad as it could have been. The show in general was quite amusing but some could say it went on a bit too long.

something different. comfortable setting, interesting activity. It lacks a bit of more explanation as to what the different dances represent, where the musical instruments are from (north, south of the country, etc). Overall a good 45 minutes activity

Interesting to visit once. For those who do not understand Vietnamese, remember to pick up the brochure upstairs, beside the theatre door. They provide brochures in different languages. The brochure helps you understand what is happening. The puppet show is worth a visit. I found the dragon dance most interesting. The music was played almost exactly like those in Singapore, Malaysia, Hongkong and a few other countries but the presentation was different. Near the theatre, there are many eateries, Vietnamese and otherwise. So dinner is not a problem.
Interesting. The show is not in English, however, it's very easy to understand with the animated performances. My favourite was the little firework show and all in the water.
An interesting show very cleverly performed. This show is worth a visit as it is musical and entertaining for all ages. The puppeteers are very good and the 50 minute show was very enjoyable.

A Surreal Experience. I was reluctantly dragged along to this event because it's regarded as a unique experience; on reflection I'm glad to have attended because it was an enjoyable spectacle with charming backing musicians and vocalists. As others have said, it's conducted in Vietnamese; as with operas not originally written in English I am happy to just drink in the sights, sounds and emotions rather than get the full script which is often quite inane. Overall, I'd say it was an hour well spent and something that I am unlikely to get the chance to see elsewhere.
Superb!!. A very unique presentation, the water puppet theatre is a must watch at Hanoi. Dont ever miss this 45 minute show which brings life to the people of the north!

Please no cameras. A unique experience. Like many others we enjoyed watching and listening to the musicians the most. Watching the puppets was spoilt for us by so many IPhones, IPods and cameras held aloft

Puppet theatre . This is worth a look. It goes for about 40 mins and its is well done. The only thing I could say is the story line is very hard to follow. It would have been great if they gave some context around the story they are trying to tell.
A bit of fun. It is very childish ,lots of people visiting I guess just because huge advertising,but if you have a choice go visit something else.I did like the sowing rice act.

Very unique show. To be able to maintain the uniqueness of traditional play is impressive and although I could not understand a single word they sang, it does not matter as the action speak louder than the word itself.
Watch the Orchestra!. The puppet show was good but just as interesting was to watch the live orchestra perform the musical accompaniment. This was a very enjoyable 50 minutes of entertainment.

Night Entertainment.. An interesting live show that runs for just 1 hour, it is suitable for adults and children. A string band play on the side and the show is based on the water. The only thing that spoils the show is people with cameras and the liking. They should be banned.
Great for children. Wish there was English speaking performance to understand more of Vietnamese culture. Otherwise, Google singing, music and performance.

Adored. Fun way to learn about the history and culture. The puppetry is awesome. Be sure to get tickets early as I had tried to go last minute on a few visits but didn't work until we got tickets through hotel.

Enjoy the Culture.. My husband wanted to see this and I am glad I went! While none of it is in English you get the basic story line and the music, voice overs and singing which is all live is fanstic. Show only goes for an hour and it is so cheap no more than $6 AUD each. You would never get show of this quality in Melbourne for that! Just beware not much leg room if tall!
Vietnamese culture at its best.. The water Puppet show was awesome, traditional music performed beautifully, the musicians and the singers were truly fabulous.

a wonderful experience with Vietnam's culture. This Water Puppet show has travelled the world sharing Vietnam's culture. Tho I didn't understand a word that was said or sung, you kinda get the gist of the play. Beautifully done and unique, my favorite part was the background music and storyline (done in Vietnamese) by a live group.

Kids loved it. We took the kids age 4&5 to see the Water Puppet show, they loved it, was good to see it and it also gave the kids a break from sight seeing. I Would recommend it if you have the time to go, its also super cheap approx 5USD for an hour.. If you have kids i would say add it to the list for sure as its only an hour anyway...

One of the tourist "must see's". For the price of admission (about US$4.50) you really can't complain and it can only be described as something that is very unique to this part of the world. A very nostalgic look at an art form that once meant a whole lot more to the locals than it does today. Kudos to the establishment for keeping the art form alive for the current generation to witness and enjoy.

Not really for me. In terms of culture, it's worth a watch as it was only an hour.... but not my sort of thing.. Others there did seem to enjoy it and there were a LOT of people recording the whole thing on their ipads which made it hard to see but all in all, was just average for me.

A genuine traditional performance. This is great if you want to see genuine cultural theatre telling native tales, but don't expect to be amazed, and perhaps better enjoyed with a vietnamese speaker or translator in attendance.
Bit boring but a way to kill an hour. Most impressed by the live band and singing, watching them perform was much more interesting than the puppet show itself

Entertaining Puppet show. Very entertaining and fun puppet show. The music is good, the stories are interesting and its a good peak into Vietnamese folk culture. Its a small theatre and the seats are very small, not made for westerners although that's all you will see in attendance. They allow cameras and recording which is a shame because everyone had their cameras out and it takes away from the great show but for only 100,000 VND it's well worth the 50 minutes.

A great show. No cameras please!. This was my first water puppet show experience and I loved it. What I did not like was interruptions by fellow audience trying to click photos (with flash) and do video recording.
Great entertainment. Thoroughly enjoyed the water puppets - the timing, the little stories the accompanying music made for an entertaining time.

Well Done. Something I think everyone should see while visiting here. Music is good. The puppets are well handled and all very clever. The only thing off cause it is not in English so you just have to guess whit the story is all about

Traditional water puppet show for tourists (don't miss). We just booked as time filling but it turned out to be much nicer as expected. It seems a Vietnam cultural heritage although you don’t understand the wording the over story is easy to understand.The show has live music and the puppeteer players are standing behind a curtain moving long sticks (under water) the figures. This is definitely quite skill to learn,. The actual theater is on the second floor and packed with only tourists, the seats are small, definitely not made for the typical longer Europeans. Yes is a touristic attraction but for $5 a ~50 min full water puppet show, what to say more, just go and enjoy.

Good experience. As others have said it is all in Vietnamese but there is a programme which gives some info about each scene, the stories aren't overly complex so you can sort of work out what's going on. It was funnier than I was expecting. I'd recommend this as something to do in Hanoi.

very original. Never seen anything like this. Worth a few dong to experience it. Would be worth even more if thry could offer some translation or subtitles. Lady on the ticket counter was very unpleasant. One and only experience with an unfriendly and uncourtious Vietnamese person. Everyone else so far has been great.

Unique puppet experience!. I had the unique opportunity to watch the water puppet play today, catching the 4.10pm show. The show lasted about 45 minutes with staged water puppet presentation about cultural folklore and stories, accompanied by traditional musical instrument band. However the play was all in Vietnamese language - if you do not understand Vietnamese you might just be there to enjoy the music, as well as, watching puppets move around in water. It is advisable to purchase tickets early in the day for an evening show as large groups of tourists flock that area and it gets very crowded. Overall I enjoyed the water puppet play (especially the Phoenix play) and would recommend it to anyone visiting Hanoi.

Go to the puppet show if you have children. Although the show is cute and clever, I feel it's more suited for those with children who will really appreciate what the show has to offer. Adults many not necessarily feel the same, unless they are open minded to anything.

Too long. We got the last seats so they put up seats in the aisle, which were horrible because there was a big box in the way so we could only see the things on the right side. i thought the puppets were quite cute but the "singing" was a bit like catawauling. I got bored quite quickly and actually fell asleep.
Absolutely Fantastic. Loved the puppets, the music, but grab a program before you go in. Almost the best thing in Hanoi, four shows a day and dirt cheap.

Part of the culture. How can you go wrong at a $5USD per person hour long performance. Water Puppet is a must see in Hanoi. Once is probably enough. Tickets can be purchased from the box office in front of the theater. The theater in on the second floor. We saw a person in a wheelchair being carried up the stairs. There is lots of leg room for seats in the first row. Plan ahead, because shows sell out.

A different type of entertainment. This was an interesting show in a large theatre. The water puppets were fascinating and it was very authentic with the live band playing traditional music. It only goes for about 45 minutes although some of us found ourselves nodding off listening to the music.

Neat - except for the audience. The water puppet show was actually very interesting. The only part I didn't like was all the rude tourists that talk the whole time of the show and the hundreds of cell phones that were constantly taking pictures and people texting, etc. I'm old school that way...put your phones away.

Good show. The adults and kids alike enjoyed this show. We were seated towards the front and that was a good way to see the detail. Even though in music and Vietnamese the story is easy for young and old to understand. The kids were entertained through out and is close to the markets for some night shopping afterwards or restaurants are close by.

I don't like puppet shows but this was special. I found this puppet show to be fascinating, and the stories interesting. What made it special was the musical accompaniment and singing. I would recommend it to anyone. And I do not like puppet shows.
Excellent!. Excellent show! Definitely worth it, and you would regret if you miss this! The show is interesting even you don't understand what they were singing and talking.

Impressive!. A lot of my friends who have been to the water puppet theatre told me not to bother going there as they all fell asleep halfway through since they didn't understand Vietnamese. Therefore, it took me some struggle with myself before I decided to watch it since I was already there. And I did not regret spending 45 minutes watching the show. Thought I was going to fall asleep like my friends, but I stayed wide awake for the 45 minutes show. It was really impressive to see how the puppeteers can make the puppets move so freely in the water. After all, it is in the Guinness Record for being the longest water puppet show. For a fee of VND100K, it is definitely worth a watch. The singing and music is all live so if you really like to experience a different culture and to understand the history of Hoan Kiem lake and some of the Vietnamese cultures, go for it!

So busy with tourists and cameras.. That should've been a good show with lots of musicians and plenty water puppets was spoiled by the tourists and the cameras. At one time I could barely see the water stage for the flashing of cameras. It seems for some visitors that it is more important to take photos back rather than experience the show.

Good show. We had never been to a water puppet show. Consequently, it was a new experience to see the puppets and puppeteers in action. I imagine that it takes quite a bit of skill to become an accomplished puppeteer. They do a lot of interesting moves with the puppets that make it seem easy but I am sure that the puppeteers are going through quite a bit of movement in the background. It is probably not for everyone but we were happy to see the show and experience it.

A very unique experience. This show happened very quickly - it's a good job we had the set list to keep track of where we were.Ask for the first class tickets 100,000 VND to get the best view, then sit back to enjoy one of the most random but intriguing things you'll have seen in a long time. The accompanying music and traditional singing are haunting in a beautiful way.Definite must do, even for those noto really interested in culture

Impressive and entertaining.. This show is a collection of 14 different traditional stories taken from a larger collection of 400. It uses traditional puppets, traditional instruments and songs. It's all in Vietnamese but it's fairly easy to follow if you have the free programme. The puppeteers are clearly talented and leave you wondering just how they control all the things happening at once. This show has dragons, fairies, unicorns, turtles, phoenix and a very cheeky fox.The theatre itself has comfortable seats and the show only costs about £3 which is cheap considering it lasts about an hour. We found it enjoyable and a good introduction to classic Vietnamese stories and beliefs.

Enjoyed it thoroughly. I had heard about the place, but I was not sure what the whole thing was all about. So I went in with not much of an expectation and came back absolutely satisfied. A must see for everyone who visits Hanoi.....worth every penny. A very good cultural experience. The only draw back was the fact that the whole show was in the local language so we had to try and understand everything based on the actions of the puppets.

A good culture stop off. The puppet theatre is a nice little cultural stop off point and deserving of its place in most guide books. The beginning of the show was probably best as it probably goes on a little long. Bring water as it can be quite warm inside.

Impression show. I have to say that's the unique puppet show I've watched. Despite the language barrier you still laugh quite a bit. interesting thing to do whilst in Ha Noi as it's only 45 minutes - artists are talented.
Splashing Puppets. Excessive noise,previously experienced puppets at HCMC,considered that performance much better,the children were enthral led,though,annoying flash lights from mobiles / cameras.
definition of a tourist trap. Tiny places, looking at flaslights. no vietnamese person besides the staff. pay, get in and get out and bye bye. I advise the bye bye.

Not worth it. This attraction is for parents and their children. My husband wanted to leave, but we were in the middle of an aisle and I didn't want to cause a disturbance. You can see a presentation of the same story at the ethnology museum and outdoors, rather than in a cramped, hot theater.

Best show i have ever seen.. Oh my goodness is this a good show! If you are in Chiang Mai I seriously recommend seeing this. The performers have clearly worked really hard making this and it´s very well put together and performed! So much fun! I must admit I was skeptic at first but then I could´t take my eyes of the stage and just wanted more :)

Cultural moment, but an hour is too long. Yes, definitely a cultural experience. But is it worth an hour of your time...? Suggest you sit by the door in case you need to make a quick exit when you have had enough! There were plenty of people leaving before the end of the show. If you have children, they will enjoy, but for us (2 adults), we were glad once it was over!

An enjoyable moment of culture. Five dollars. One hour. Make sure you get the program from the lobby so you know what you're looking at. Everything is in Vietnamese. It's a pleasant glimpse into an aspect of Vietnamese culture.

Boring?! Not at all.. I saw several reviews here saying that it was boring due to the amount of Vietnamese being spoken......which is just total nonsense. There is a series of 15 small "acts" - all of which are basically without speech (or at least of any significance). Most of the Vietnamese is actually part of the singing, which you do not need to understand to enjoy.Some of the acts were very funny, some less so. But the whole series gives you a great flavour of the puppetry, and you would be a fool to miss this if you are in Hanoi. I thought it was wonderful.
You can give it a miss!. For couple that do not speak the language and traveling with out kids it was quite boring. It will be nice for family with kids and local people.

Interesting, uniquely vietnam, a different experience. An experience to see another facet of vietnam. Set in a theatre, traditional vietnamese songs are rendered while the puppets are performing in the stage with water or pond as settings. Downside is we dont understand whats the story all about. No subtitles in english or show narratives.

Must visit if you are in Hanoi. This was the first time I was seeing a pupet show. This is a once in a life experience. we enjoyed the show very much.You should never miss this, if you are visiting Hanoi. My only suggestion is they must put a large screen tv and show the story ( scrolling ) on the screen.We could not understand the story or songs. But the show was colorful and enjoyable.

this is my second time, so the show was a bite borring compare to the first time many years ago.. I do not like the smell of someone smoking inside the theater. The musician and singers were very good, talent, and skillful.
traditional of musical. should be come and get ticket before the show. they had many so but defend on the season( winter or summer). in the afternoon very busy
Really worth seeing. Clever and amusing as well as culturally interesting. The only problem we had was the lack of leg room in the theater. I had to sit side on, which was pretty uncomfortable.
language barrier. need to translate to English the narration during the show otherwise those who dont know Vietnamese language will not understand what is happening

easy afternoon. we went for the 45 minute show and found it charming especially the orchestra which consisted of seven or eight musicians playing traditional instruments and vocalists who accompanied the puppets next time i will learn the story
Surprisingly enjoyable. I didn't know what to expect , I really enjoyed the show. The music was great , as were the puppets. The show was the right length , a cultural insight into Vietnam.

a good introduction to my first visit to Vietnam. Went to watch the puppet show on the first night in Vietnam and enjoyed it. On the following days as I visited more places, I saw things ( like the round boat) I saw during the show. I learned quite a few interesting things about the history and culture of Vietnam.

Interesting. it is not a place a preteen or teenager would enjoy-the music was good and sung by locals and the story was easy to follow-the seating was comfortable and all viewing was good with tier seating
Fascinating.....really loved the music. I loved the show itself but especially the traditional music played on Vietnamese instruments. I highly recommend this, easy location in the Old Quarter.

A piece of traditional Vietnamese culture. At 100k VND / 5 USD (rear is cheaper and also ok) the price is fair for a 50 min show. And while the songs are indeed Vietnamese without subtitles, the story in each of the 17 short narratives is quite clear. The puppets have been designed with an eye for detail, and with the tradition going back a few hundred years I would recommend you include this in your itinerary.Come and get the tickets early in the day e.g. for the 8pm show to get the best seats.

Entertaining even for non-Vietnamese speakers . The hour-long show was great for someone with short attention span like me. The music was upbeat and the water puppetry was a novelty to me. Very entertaining, definitely a must-go if you are visiting Hanoi. Do drop by in advance to buy your tickets. We were lucky to snap up 8pm tickets at about 4pm on the first day.

Kitschy show. Maybe it's ok since it is only an hour, but still... The show is sung in Vietnamese so unless you know the language, you can't follow the story. That leaves you to be entertained by the puppets. They are fine, but not really that interesting

Must-visit. What an amazing show! A true Vietnamese cultural experience. Try to book in advance (there are several shows a day) so you can get the front rows, as the seats are not tiered very well and people in front are constantly taking photos with their smartphones, blocking the views. Beautiful music and although the singing is in Vietnamese, like the opera, you don't need to understand the words to appreciate the 11 short stories. Very clever and fine entertainment. Don't miss it!

Go only if you speak Vietnamese. The show is in Vietnamese so I do not understand anything for the full one hour show. When entering the theatre, you will be asked to pay if you are seen with a camera, which you can easily avoid by putting it in your bag since there is no bag checks. When buying the tickets, they assigned us separate seats (foldable chairs along the staircase) because the theatre is full. Not that I would mind but the least they can do is to inform us before we buy. However, it turns out the view is better as it wasn't blocked by front rows. Still I would have been able to spend that additional hour on something else.

Entertaining Vietnam Culture. Loved this even though at first I was a bit reluctant. My hotel organised the ticket for $6US which was reasonable (can get it cheaper but we didn't mind). We were in the second row, centre. The puppets were amazing and it was great to hear the Vietnamese singing, music and history all in one! This is definately not to be missed!

Traditional show. Traditional show not to miss in Hanoi. Nice way to spend 45 minuts before having dinner... I liked the design of the Puppets, i even bought some reproductions to bring home for me and as gifts. The show is only 45 minuts long, so try it.

A must do. I have to admit I was not sure about the puppet theatre but afterwards I can safely say that it is a must do in Hanoi. The puppets in water are amazing and the show which only goes for 50 minutes keeps you entertained. While the speaking parts are in Vietanmese, you can follow the story which is made up 14 different smaller stories. The singing by the ladies in the band is extraordinary. Try and get front row tickets to really appreciate the show and its band.

watery experience. heard a lot about water puppet show.arrived early to get a seat. small hall overcrowded,poor air conditioning,extra chairs put in to accommodate guests.puppetry was astonishing technically-how was this done in the water ?language was vietnamese.not much impressed. may be kids will like.

Most unusual entertainment. Especially for western visitors this is a most unusual type of show. Looks like it could be for children only but there is a lot of skill required to manage the puppets. It takes about one hour , so an easy must do while in Hanoi. Easy location at the edge of the old city and Hoam Kiem lake.
Culture. Great show, seating a little to close together, surprised by the way the puppeteers operated the puppets.

Wonderful experience. Uniquely Vietnamese. Cheap entertainment and wonderful to see their cultural history. With the exception of the introduction it is all in Vietnamese, so interpretation is required!

OK - but long if you do not know the language. Probably more interesting if you know the language. Glad we went so we can say we have, but after about 20 minutes it was a "been there, done that" type experience.For the price it is actually worth it just to get out of the heat. Personally, do not think paying extra for the closer seats makes that much of a difference.

Unique Vietnam experience certainly worth an hour.. Lovely music and voices accompany this unique water puppet show just as fun for adults. This is an ancient form of Vietnamese entertainment that showcase various life pursuits. Highly recommend.

The best puppet theatre show we saw. Its authentic and in a nice setting. We enjoyed it, but bare I mind that most haylong bay trips will include a water puppet theatre show within the trip. This is however the better of the 3 we saw, considering the plays were identical. All part of the experience.

Great show, lovely puppets & fabulous music.. Thoroughly enjoyed seeing the water puppets. The show is spoken in Vietnamese and is accompanied by traditional music. There are programs available as you enter the theatre which give you the names of the acts you will see, this is helpful in keeping up with what's happening in the show.If you want to use your camera you will need to buy a separate ticket for this, I also recommend not using the flash setting - this is quite annoying to others in the theatre and I am sure your photos won't turn out as well as they could if you hadn't.They run several shows a day, you are able up buy tickets in advance.

Cultural hightight.. A very famous theater for Westerner who go to Hanoi. For me it was really a cultural highlight about a brand new arts: water puppetry, that was quite interesting but it's a pity that I can't understand anything about the script.
night out. thoroughly enjoyed the show,followed by a cyclo ride to the river for a dinner and entertainment on board a junk.good value

Great with adults and children alike. Ever seen a water puppet show? Know what it is? Now is your chance. Shows are cheap. It lasts 50min and it is fun for the whole family. Book ahead as tickets sell out fast

Charming, creative and inspiring. The team of musicians and puppeteers provide a lively introduction to Vietnamese folk culture. The music is strange to Western ears--five tones make for strange sounds, but the puppetry and sounds of the instruments are exciting and captivating.Worth the money.

Lovely music. I thought the puppets were impressive. Our teenage boys tired of them after 30 minutes of this hour long show. Solution? Close your eyes and listen to the lovely traditional music. NB worth buying tickets 24 hours in advance as big tours book up lots of tickets at popular times.

Beautiful Northern traditional music and distinctive puppet show. It's one of the best show I've seen showcasing a very interesting form of art from the North of Vietnam - the artists who play traditional musical instruments to the singers who have beautiful voices sing folklores, the puppets were skilfully controlled by the team. It's a must do on any package tour programs in Ha Noi so often filled with guests from these tours. If you are solo travellers, make sure you buy the tickets as soon as you plan to go and see it.
A must see performance... Quite a nice surprise! Didn't expect much from a puppet show but they did justice. It was truly a wonderful cultural experience.. :)

Interesting but.... The spectacle was actually good. You have to choose between the part 1 (in front of the theater) or part 2 backward. It doesn't worth to go to the part 1 (100k VND)... It is all in Vietnamese but it changes from European culture. I'm a student, so I'm not really into these kind of things, but I still think it is something to do in Hanoi!
Not to be missed. Traditional Water Puppets,costumes,music and instruments. Small theatre so performance seemed more intimate.A must for any visitor.
Entertaining. This isa classic style water puppet show based on what the farmers used to do in the flood times.It is very different and well worth visiting.

childhood memories. Used to see the puppet show in my childhood in Rajas-than,India,
but this is entirely different and unique. the entire show is in water with live music, songs etc. keeping an ancient art alive.

So so. This theatre must be a must visit in Hanoi but the reality is much below our expectation. The puppet performance is quite light and shortish. The attendant one of instruments and chant is, however, interesting and artistic. Usually, one should book at least a day before performance to get a convenient slot.

A traditional method of presenting folk stories. While it is interesting to see traditional Vietnamese theater, the entire show was in Vietnamese, resulting in non-Vietnamese speakers having to guess the meaning of the stories. Many of the stories were self-evident, but enjoyment would have been higher if there had been a translation.

Don't waste your money or TIME!. We were warned by a friend not to visit, but felt we needed to see it for ourselves. Our friend was right. The first five mins is sort of amusing, but you are stuck in there for nearly two hours and it is VERY BORING! It might be traditional, but ther are much more interactive enjoyable ways to spend your time by just walking the streets of Hanoi.
Amazing!. Unique art form that tells traditional stories with music, special effects and humour through clever puppetry. A must see!

The Puppet Show. The overall show was just ok.. not too badThe musician and vocalist are great..The overall plot of the show can be improvedNeed to have subtitlesThe staff are not friendly and not very welcomingOverall facility were fine.

Bizarrely entertaining. This was a very odd experience in a fairly normal theatre with a big banked pool at the back. The performance itself was pretty extraordinary - the puppeteers are clearly pretty talented - and replete with slapstick comedy moments. The music also seemed pretty authentic and I enjoyed it more as the performance went on. One downside was that the seats were not that steeply banked and I had a massive bloke in front of me which made it hard to see properly. If you're taking small children, be prepared (and maybe take a cushion?). At a little under an hour, it's an entertaining and peaceful diversion in a hectic city.

Well worth a visit!. We visited with some trepidation as we were told the show was delivered with traditional Vietnamese song and music. Our concerns were unfounded, the programme gave a short description of each act of the show and the spectacle itself was a unique and very enjoyable hour or so. The puppets are pretty basic (traditional) but the puppeteers who are immersed up to their waists (and out of sight) operate the puppets in a really lifelike way and reality is truly suspended for the length of the show. One item in particular with 'dragons' is absolutely amazing! You will find it a very educational and enjoyable experience.

Vietnamese traditional art. It is one of the most exciting Vietnamese traditional arts. In such a show, you can see the daily life of Vietnamese farmers, fishermen, etc. and their family.The most inconvenience thing for foreigners is all songs, lyrics, etc. in Vietnamese. Just the introduction at the beginning of the show is in English and French. It would make you more difficult to understand all the show, but it is still really exciting with a lot of wood puppets.At the end of the show, you can meet all the artists who control all the puppets under the water.

A cultural experience. Today we went to the water puppets. We had heard it was interesting and wanted to give it a try. For the 100,000 dong or $5 go for the more expensive ticket. The seats and very close with limited leg room but it is only a 1 hr show. Great insight into Vietnamese culture and a great experience for the cost.

Great reviews well deserved!. Got tickets for the highly praised Thang Long Water Puppet Theater as a treat for my 12 and 9 year old kids who indeed thoroughly enjoyed the show. What I had not expected was that I liked the show just as much as they did. Singing, music, songs and the actual puppetry worked together perfectly creating a wonderful expierence for the audience. There is love, drama, history and humour on offer and in particular when the lights are turned down spectacular fire effects on water. A performance of 45 minutes is just the right time to keep young and old engaged and the price for this wonderful performance is so affordable that you can even watch it a second time. $2 more for seats in the front are well spent. Superb! Definitely worth a visit!!!
Enjoyable Visit To Ancient Times. What a nice way to experience cultural stories through this medium.Despite the lack of translation, an enjoyable experience af an ancient art form.

Water Puppets!. It was really impressive and until you figure out how it is done, very mysterious. As far as water puppet shows go, this one is world class. The puppets are beautiful, the theater cute and the puppeteers super talented. The live music was great and matched the show perfectly. They frequently change their shows so I plan to return anytime I am in Hanoi. I would definitely recommend this place.
Local culture in the afternoon. This could be cliched but was amazing to see the artistry of the puppets and puppeteers. I will forever remember the scenes of fishermen and rice farmers enacted here.

Well worth a visit. It's all in Vietnamese and isn't quite spectacular however the water puppetry is a good time, even to listen to the wonderful traditional Vietnamese music being played. Possibly a tad overpriced for what it is but all the same an enjoyable and sometimes surprising experience.

Fun and different experience. We ware told that a water puppet theatre was an absolut must see. So we chose this one just beside the Hoam Kiem lake. It was funning singing and cool puppet movements on the the small fake lake. It is a must see.
Worth seeing. Nice theater with a nice performance with live music. The story was told in vietnamese but you'll get it anyways. But the seats were way too small for average western people.
It simple a must. The water puppet show is something that I couldn't imagine it was well worth the visit a trip to Hanoi with visiting would be a wasted trip
Good to watch. Good place for travel to visit . Value for money. Ít is cơlose to hoan kiem lake. Very near from our hotel . Much more fun forkid. We will see again next time

Must see. Show takes an hour - traditional music and singing supports the puppeteers, who do a remarkable job manipulating their puppets in the water tank - as they weave the stories - visually self explanatory. The puppeteers then emerge up to their knees in water.
Amazing. Wasn't quite sure what to expect but found the show quite fascinating - more appreciating how it's done and how it came about.
Best and cheapest entertainment in Hanoi😎. For $5 dollars you get 1 hour of authentic vietnamese show. Wished I could understand vietnamese to have more fun at the show😊
Entertaining. Unique way of puppet show staged on real water. Good stage lighting with a mini orchestra playing. All puppeteers have to stand in water behind curtains.

Good for culture knowledge. The hour long water puppet show was quite amazing at first but turn a bit draggy in the middle. The show is in Vietnamese but there atrocities different language brochure available outside the theatre for better understanding about the show.

Unique and traditional art of Vietnam.. A (supposed to be) most noticeable traditional art in Vietnam. It's interesting to see how the performers reeling the puppet around the show, but it's too bad that I couldn't understand the script.
And how come that a traditional Vietnamese art has only foreigner audience? I'm confusing ...

First, and probably only, water puppet theater experience.... I'm always a huge fan of new cultural activities, but this performance didn't really do very much for me or my colleagues, who are also big travelers. As other reviewers said, it is a cheap and air-conditioned break, but it wouldn't make my list of "must-see" activities when there are other interesting things to see and do.

Charming, Mesmerizing Puppet Show. Did not know what to expect when I got the tickets, but was surprised (pleasantly) with a good show that showcased traditional music and singers that had puppets dancing to the tunes and playing out stories of Vietnamese folklore.

Water Puppets. OK but the hour long show went to long in rather cramped seating. Impressive to see those who directed the puppets and realise they spent a considerably time up to their wait in water each day.

a must try. i was told "you havent been to hanoi if u dont watch the water pupet" so we decided to see them on our last night, the theatre was full and ticket price are cheap. The show was interesting and i think kids 7-12 will enjoy it. It has a music, culture and history presented during the show. We just wished that there was an english translation projected on the wall so atleast we can understand the story.

Enjoyable entertainment. My sister and I visited the water puppet theater on the first night in Hanoi. Located in the center of Hanoi and a few time slots to choose from each night, it is a great way to inject a bit of culture to your trip! We requested our hotel to organise our tickets for convenience but it looked easy to purchase the ticket from the front of the theater. For such an affordable entertainment we had fun! Everything is in Vietnamese so you don't really understand the storyline but you get the idea from the title of each piece. Great way to enjoy the traditional Vietnamese music and art!

Magic and Joyful fun. The cost is about $5 US, which is one of the best 5 bucks I have ever spent to help support culture. Really, live music and singers. Supporting a old cultural art form that would otherwise fade away. It is very enjoyable to watch even without understanding the language. It is about the right amount of time, just as you start to get a bit bored of the water puppets and their dances the show is over (about 45 minute run time). If you have kids, I am sure this would blow there mind and be a wonderful experience. Even with out kids it is just cute in a way that everyone should enjoy. Waking up the inner child to see the joy of the art and the stories.I was really happy we took the time to get tickets and put this on our schedule while in the city, between all the amazing meals we ate.

Great Vietnamese traditional music. Impressive Vietnamese traditional music show. It helps audience to understand more about rural life in the past of Vietnam. For foreigners, there's english translation on the screen during the show, so it doesnt matter much

Just Awesome !!!. What a show!!! We thoroughly enjoyed the show even my 6 years old boy liked the show a lot. The script and the songs were in local language, however they gave a booklet which has little descriptions of the act which provides the background of the act....and come on if you want to enjoy the local culture it need to be in local languageShow is absolutely amazing, what coordination, each and every act was done perfectly ....highly recommend this show to others Try to get the tickets in advance to get the front seats

Enjoyable and unique experience. The puppetry was well done and an ancient tradition here. Well worth seeing. The singing was pleasant and the music interesting, using old instruments. My only complaint is that the legroom is very limited if you're tall and the air conditioning I only working in the lobby. It was hot in the theatre

Very nice show. The Good:* Convenient location: Right across the street from the lake in Old Quarter.* Very good live singing and band. * Helps understand the Vietnamese people, their culture and traditions (if you are interested in it)The Bad:* The seating in the theater is very cramped. Tall people might have issues.

A good time. I've always been told you have to see a water puppet show when your Vietnam and I'm glad we did.It was a little silly and didn't understand any of the words or songs of course but it was very entertaining and a good way to spend a few hours. It is quite amazing all the puppets and the acts, I would recommend everyone to see it.

Good Fun. The theatre is found beside Hoan Kiem Lake and has a number of shows throughout the day. They appear to have stopped running the 21:15hrs show which you'll often find as being quoted in many travel guides. The last show is now 20:00hrs.Tickets can be purchased shortly before the show and cost 100.000VND for a front of house seat and 60.000VND for further back. The theatre is relatively small, however, for the 40.000 difference it was good to be close to the action.If you buy two tickets you get a free vietnamese iced coffee at the cafe/bar which is attached to the theatre.The show lasts for about 45 Minutes and has 14 short excerpts from traditional water puppetry. It was certainly something different and for the small amount that it costs is definitely something you should see whilst in Hanoi.
Awesome. This was excellent, a must for every traveller, the whole show was mesmerising and I could watch it over and over
A must see ... I guess. Well I suppose you got to go, its easy to get to and in a central location, and its quite fun and its quite short... once would be enough though!

the water puppet theater. We went as part of an all day tour. It was nice to sit and watch this hour long puppet show. It was an interesting look at part of the Vietnam experience.
However, if you miss it your trip will not have suffered. There are many other fine things to do.

Entertaining. Went in with low expectations and was completely blown away by the sheer effort put into the show as well as the variety of different acts. From the start to finish, I really enjoyed it and it was interesting to see different water puppets and how they brought everything to life. It would have been great if there was a brochure that described each scene in more detail though.

Nifty show that could be 15 minutes shorter. If down by the lake take the opportunity to catch the water puppet show. It's moderately priced and you do get what you pay for. Offers great ethnic music and exposure to legends and stories.
