If you have young children or you suddenly realized your meal isn't sitting too well you will find that the show goes on for about 15 minutes too long. Other than that, check it out.
Boring tourist trap!. Couldn't understand a word being said absolutely boring, there is no story line. Couldn't wait for the show to end!

Good place to see!. It was a good location and very convenion to get there when you was in the old quarter of Hanoi. It has many show for one day from the morning until late at night so you could going out for travel and see the suitable time!

Unexpectedly charming. I decided to go as it was a 'Hanoi bucket list' thing but enjoyed it immensely. While a lot of the symbolism is unclear to the uneducated like me, a lot of the scenes were obvious (and also amusing). Well worth a visit.

EVEN BETTER THAN EXPECTED. The show itself is fantastic - really expertly done with the water puppeteering. Also to note is the wonderful live musical accompliment and singing. It doesnt matter if you cant speak Vietnamese - the whole atmosphere and the content of the show (without giving too much away) 'tells' the story. Its suitable for all ages. A highlight of our trip and our stay in HCM city.I did have initial reservations having read some of the reviews that we might have our view impaired by people with ipads filming - occasionally someone would take a photo using one , but on a quick look around on 2-3 occasions, didnt see this happening so for us it wasnt a problem or it wasnt a problem on the night.It really is a must do - a very professional performance which is very engaging! 10/10 from me.

Surprisingly good. It is very different from anything I have ever seen and it was well worth seeing. The show was really neat and the music wonderful. The puppets and how they make them work is unbelievable.
Amazing Artistry and Folklore. Music, acting, puppetry, pyrotechnics, aquatechnics...I was blown away by this performance. You gotta see it!

Wonderfully weird experience. Having no experience of Vietnamese folklore I had no idea what was going on in the show itself and still managed to love it! The puppets are beautifully crafted and skilfully manipulated. The accompanying music is lively and fun. Warning to any tall travellers: the seats are designed for a Vietnamese audience, taller individuals may end up sitting rather awkwardly for a few hours.

Interesting Show. Although the show is in vietnamese language it is worth seeing this traditional show. We enjoyed the show and the skills of the person playing it on the water.The water puppet theater was fully packed with tourist. Everybody enjoyed the show. Worth to see the show. Fun.

Disappointment... The show was actually boring. They talk in vietnamese and we understand noting.
It a show for vietnamese kids and no more.

Distinctive but not amazing. It was worth seeing this, just because it's something different you're not going to see anywhere else. The act was clever and well executed, but got a little samey after the first few routines. Slightly disappointing, but at the same time still pretty cool.
Well done. Wasn't sure what to expect when we paid our $100,000 Dong to see this show. Turned out to be very entertaining and thoroughly enjoyed it.

Very clever. It was a really good show, even though it was all in Vietnamese, it is still worth seeing. It is original and very cleverly done. The theatre is incorporated into a cafe and they know how to charge, but it was still very busy. There was some good souvenir shops near by with good prices.

Interesting Performance. First time seeing a puppet show with water-stage!
The story of the show is depicted in an interesting and humorous way. But it will be better if subtitles are provided as the show is conducted in Vietnamese language, making me hard to understand some of the scenes.
Water puppets. A fascinating display of very clever puppeteers in water. The musicians showed their skill with music helping to tell story for puppets
Awesome. The show was extreemly entertaining and the live music was fantastic. Would highly recommend this attraction
Water Puppets Hanoi. A visit to the Water Puppet Theatre is a unique experience to see the "myths and legends" of Vietnam performed in a water environment. Well worth the visit

an interesting but funny alternative night. beautiful and so different from anything else you could see on a typical night out. The music was great! Even though everything is in vietnamese and you really cant follow the story at all it's still a good experience. It's cheap and cultural. We were a group of nine young backpackers and we had a good laugh (a couple of drinks before it at bier hoi is beneficial)

Interesting Puppet Show. Before today's RV and Internet world existed the entertainment and musical stories were told through shows like this and it should definitely be on your list of things to do in Hanoi. The puppets and in water and telling the stories with little people, dragons, fish and even using fireworks as part of the act.
Water puppet theater. This show was amazing my husband and I enjoyed it very much it was worth going to have a look.the lake around the show was lovely filled with flowers as it was Chinese New Year.
Boring. We really looked forward to see the show, but it is kind of tourist trap, and we were bored. I do not recommend it at all.

An experience!. The first time I saw a water puppet show and I was impressed. It was nicely done with most of the puppets were in the water. It was done in Vietnamese, luckily there was a handout in English telling us what was happening during the show. A must if you go to Hanoi!

Surprisingly entertaining. The show lasts about one hour (on the short side). It is composed of a series of brief sketches depicting the vietnamese rural life and its mythology and some music-only parts. There are two tiers of tickets, the cheap one goes for 60.000 dong and the expensive one for 100.000. I highly suggest buying the expensive one, because the difference is really small and the view from the front is much better. Attached to the theater, there is a very classy bar, which serves good snacks and drinks.
Not one to miss for adults and kids of all ages!!!. You hear about it, and then you see it and can't believe how clever these water puppeteers are. Not one to miss when in Ha Noi.

One of a kind show. Vietnamese Water Puppet Shows are one of a kind in the world and it is only here in Hanoi where you will be able to see the best Water Puppet Theatre. The cost of the tickets is only $5 per person and is really worthwhile to make some time to attend one of these shows during the evening. Before the show started, the narrator explained the background and story line in English so that the tourists, not speaking Vietnamese, would be able to understand the songs and dialogue. We booked seats for the last show of the evening at 8 o' clock.The duration of the show is only one hour, so you have still plenty of time afterwards to have somewhere a nice dinner. At the end of the show the puppeteers came forward so that the audience could see them. They actually stood in the water behind a curtain to do all these magic movements with the puppets. We as adults enjoyed the show as much as the children who were in the theatre. Highly recommended and a must see when visiting Hanoi.

Don't waste your time. This place is more for local tourists than any other thing. First of all, you will understand almost nothing. There is no subtitles at all (other Theatres around the world such as Gabriadze Puppet Theatre in Tbilisi have English subtitles) so imagine how boring it is that I noticed many people ended up having a siesta in the theatre... Therefore it is basically visual and music. As for the performance, it shows rural and medieval life in Vietnam...

Boring with mediocre activities.. Not worth spending your money to get in as the puppet shows are boring and way under my expectations. All you get to see are small puppets doing their thing along with the music that is not to everyone's liking. You can afford to give it a pass!

Great to see once. Good to see once but seating is not great and we sat behind some big guys and we struggled to see all the action. It is a small theatre and the perfomance lasts around 50 minutes. It is worth seeing once and we chose to see it in Hanoi rather than HCMC as the north is where this particular art form comes from.

My own personal version of torture. My wife would likely give it five stars so judge for yourself. Completely in Vietnamese, I tried to figure out a storyline strictly from the puppets but wasn't very successful. My wife loved how much the kids in the audience laughed and laughed. The musicians also seemed to be having much fun even though this must have been their thousandth performance. Highly recommended for local children, for everybody else... not so sure.

Surprisingly good!. Despite being a little apprehensive, we really enjoyed this show! Very different to anything I'd seen before and well worth the hour or so...It's very clever how they do it and the music and singing is fun too - all involved looked like they enjoyed it too, rather than just doing it for tourist benefit and $s :)
Awesome!. You need to take the time to go see this show. It was a wonderful display of traditional puppetry, with some cultural info included.

Quite boring.... The first people left after 5 mins. It might have been more enjoyable if most of the audience wouldn't have tried to film everything with their mobiles, the seats would meet European standards (I am 1,96m and I just had no space for my legs) or there would be some kind of English translation/description. It's all in Vietnamese and even with the theatre's desciptional flyer you don't understand more than the general idea what's going on. Skip this one and have a beer instead at the lake. Or at least watch a video on YouTube first :)

OK, probably just once. Maybe I was expecting more, after some buildup from (some) reviews. It was worth seeing as a cultural experience, and the dragon (with fireworks) was fun. Having said that, it's pretty much a one-time look-see.

How do they do it? Even more curious after I left. I took a last minute try to get tickets and we got them. Seated in the front row, at first I regretted as the opening piece was singing and singing. Then the first few puppets looked weird and wooden to me. Looks like some wooden puppets need some maintenance work as the paint was coming off. The performance was awesome as it's seemed to be a scene that scaled from one level of difficulty to another so that was hilarious. But overall, it was indeed a very unique piece of tradition. And am glad I watched it! Unbelievable good!

Worth doing once.. Because of the cultural significance of this art form, it is worth going once. Be warned, the theater will be packed and will be pretty hot, but in the end you will be glad you went.
Disappointing . The show was interesting for a few minutes and was only just ok. The dragons were the best then it went downhill and I had trouble keeping my eyes open.

Boring, tourist time-waste. Maybe there is cultural and artistic merit in some aspects of the show but one cannot escape feeling it is just there as yet another way to make tourists part with their hard currency. Disliked the music and the puppets.

Fun at the theatre!. A lovely evening had at the water puppet theatre, the puppets were quirky and the live music a real treat! Make sure you pick up a leaflet as this helps guide you through the sections. Also, the cheap seats are very good so don't worry about feeling you need 100,000dng ones, If you're long legged maybe go for end of aisle as seats are close together!

good for 5 min. This review is from Dec 2011, so things may have changed, but...The novelty of watching water puppets was fun for about 5 min, but it went on for longer than it was interesting. Perhaps the problem was I didn't know the story beforehand (they speak in Vietnamese), so I couldn't relate to it.The puppeteers are very skilled at moving the puppets around, but the show wasn't interesting to me.The seats are not very comfortable.I'm not sure i would recommend going to it. I went because everyone recommended it as the thing to do in Hanoi. Perhaps okay for kids, but I wasn't interested for very long. It's definitely not a must-see. Go if you have time, but don't make time for it.

Soul of Vietnam. very special show, staffs work very hard to make the show.Must see!!!!If you want to bring camera, you need to pay $1 more. There are 2 kinds of ticket : 60,000d~$3US and 100,000d ~ $5US which seat is closer to the stage

Well worth a visit for the atmosphere and live music. It's a tourist attraction, but still very nice to hear the live music and see the puppets in action. This is well worth a visit and the small entrance fee.

Aquatic puppets: a one-off. Went to this wondering to what extent it was just done for tourists. Of course it is, but nevertheless really good. The skill of the puppeteers is amazing; you could almost believe you were looking at real fish or fishermen. Interesting too to hear Vietnamese music. The nearest thing I've seen is Japanese bunraku, although this is much more lightweight. Performance is about 50 minutes in air-conditioned theatre and worth booking in advance.

Do it once, then no more. This is a traditional entertainment the vietnamese would put on when the fields were flooded in the rainy season. As such, it is one of those things that you have to see. Kids (teenage ones at least) will get easily bored and resort to their i-phones.The orchestra again is very skilled, as was the orchestra in the AO show in Ho Chi Minh.Before you go in, pick up a leaflet explaining the stories - a great help, but I only noticed these as I was leaving.
A little bit of culture. It was good to see something untainted by Western influence, however, anyone over 6'2" may have a problem with leg room.

This traditional art form got different responses from our group of 8 persons. Some were very impressed and others, well it was just ok for some entertainment. Maybe it is one of those things you either love or hate. Water puppet theatre has an existence for more than 1000 years. The puppets are mounted on bamboo sticks which are directed by the puppeteers behind the curtain standing in the water. It is fun watching the fish, the water buffalo, the man climbing the coconut tree and the dragon that flies. An entertaining part is the live music. Maybe a pamphlet in different languages would help the tourists to understand the story that is played to make some sense.

Extremely well presented.... What a wonderfully professional demonstration of the art of water puppetry. the singing was exquisite, the use of the theramin had me captivated (even if when i left i was imagining the star trek theme over and over), but the show itself was brilliant. Please get there on time, as it is incredibly annoying when you are all sitting watching and a large group of people stroll in and walk in front of the 'stage'!
Vietnamese Culture. These puppet shows are very well done, they may be a bit difficult to get your head around, worth it for the tradition alone

Is what it is. Took my mother to this show" i am always surprised when people bag this show. it is what it is, old culture. Not ipad and electro or anything resembling todays techno babble. It is a quaint authentic look at old style entertainment -and a delight worth at least a look
Excellent. Great show.. very talented puppeteers and show was very traditional. The venue offered good viewing throughout ... must book for show

Worth a visit. We chose to watch the show as it came highly recommended whilst in hanoi. The show is entirely in Vietnamese and is highly original and unique (for a westerner anyway). I'd say it's worth a visit and is something quirky and interesting to experience, but I wouldn't go back.

An interesting insight to Vietnamese Culture. You don't have to understand Vietnamese to enjoy the water puppet show. The puppets are very impressive and the musicians on the side of the stage are just as good. Would definitely recommend seeing this show as it is great value and a nice break from the hectic streets of Hanoi.

Very Interesting. My wife and I took the 3 kids (11,10 and 8). All enjoyed it and it kept them occupied learning about some good quality Vietnamese cultural performance for the best part of an hour. Very inexpensive at only VND100,000 per person. Buy tickets at the box office. Ask from seats as close to the front as possible to see all the puppets in detail.

A bit stinky and humid and was just okay. Just another traditional puppet show. It was a bit stinky and hard to breathe, not recommended for people with asthma. Seat was narrow and small. I was okay with the seat but tourists with bigger body will find it uncomfortable to sit for such a looong time. If you one of those person that needs to go to restroom a lot, make sure get the aisle seat as it was really difficult to even move your leg from you seat.

Interesting art with no locals interested.. Havent seen this kind of amusing performance anywhere else except Vietnam. Good traditional music, skillfull acting and very attracting overall even not being able to understand the script. Just wondering where all the locals went to cause just foreigners everywhere.

Local culture. Was told it is a must whilst in Vietnam to see a puppet show so we went to the one in Hanoi. There is no doubt that the show is very professional and polished yet not always easy to follow. The colours and charm of the puppets are really impressive as is the singing and the small band of instrument players but i felt that it was a little long at 45 mins. 30 mins would have sufficed.

Not for everyone. I've been here twice and really that's probably once too often. Enjoyed it the first time although it's a fairly slow process and you need to be a bit patient. It's interesting although a slow process and if you dislike sitting on a VERY hard seat you will be in trouble. All in all think once is enough.

Interesting and fun.. This was an amazing performance of several amusing sketches depicting country life. The stage is a pool and the puppets seem to be able to move about the whole area. Sometimes there are so many moving objects that it is hard to understand why they don't get tangled up. The puppets were colourful and it was a great spectacle. I particularly enjoyed the fishing scene and the synchronised swimming. I wish I had paid more attention to the programme before the lights went out. There was musical accompaniment. I liked the instrumental playing but need more exposure to be able to enjoy the singing.

Interesting but wouldn't go again. You have to admire the enthusiasm and the history behind the show. I am glad I went but also glad it only lasted 50 mins. The whole show was quaint and professional. Worth visiting but be open minded.

Amazing. An amazing spectacle - we all loved it! The attention to detail was great. Our kids absolutely loved it.
100% recommended

Not for teenagers!. We took our 13 year old daughter and 15 year old son to the show apprehensive that they may not enjoy it but we wanted to say we had experienced another part of Vietnam culture! The show is in Vietnamese with very little English spoken. I enjoyed the music particularly listening to musical instruments that I hadn't heard before.It would've been useful to have known the folk tales to appreciate the puppetry!

wet magic. How on earth, or rather, how in water, can they do that?Incredible show of puppetry, so inventive and explicit, and technically brilliant. Hard to believe how the artists can remain so hidden during the complicated activities of the various puppets and their antics.Don't miss it.

A fun way to spend an hour. They often put on an extra showing at 3pm in addition to the published times outside their door, so if you're suffering from the heat, check it out. Tickets are 100k VND (August 2014) and for this you'll get just around an hour of entertainment, which is about long enough to get a reasonable understanding of water puppets. If you sit in the front row, you may get wet, but you'll also see a lot more than sitting further back.We got row C (three back), which is close enough to see, but not get wet. If you want to take photo's or video, then there's an extra cost (20k VND for photos), and while we were there, we saw folks warned that if they took photos (on taking out their camera) they'd have to pay. Not sure if this continued throughout the performance though.Its an interesting look at entertainment and I spent a lot of the time working out how they might actually perform some of the movements. You'll laugh out loud at some of the skits, and while the printed material that you can collect on your way in is supposed to guide you through what's actually happening and what is being sung, you can't actually see it once the performance begins, so its worth scanning it beforehand.Interesting, and a good way to sit out some of the summer heat for an hour.

The Shortest Way To Learn the Hanoian Culture and History. I was already excited to see this water puppet show, by the time we arrived at Hanoi. It is located near the Hoan Kiem Lake. There is an entrance fee for this show and also fees for bringing camera/video camera.You may want to pay a bit more to enjoy the front seats, however even if you're sitting at the back, you will still enjoy the show.If you're a near-sighted person, it would be advisable if you buy the one for the front seats.

A lot of legends but hard to grasp the stories. We wanted to check out this local form of entertainment - as apparently a large crowd did as well. The old theater was packed and a bit warm but the performance is under 1 hour so no one minded too much. Your tickets are for assigned seats so don't worry if you find yourself at the end of the line - you will still have seats together. The puppets are accompanied by local musicians playing a variety of folk songs. The music was enjoyable for us but most of them looked bored -no doubt they perform many times per day so I can excuse them for that. The puppets were interesting and it took my sons a few skits into the performance before they figured out how they were being operated which was added fun for them. I would have liked a more detailed explanation of the various folk stories being enacted as the stories were lost on those of us who did not understand Vietnamese. The brochure did provide some info in a variety of languages but was pretty brief. As our tour guide we had the next day talked to us about the history and legends as we visited various sites, we were able to related back to many of the skits in the show.

Interesting. The show lasts about an hour. I can't remember the price now but I certainly don't remember thinking it was over-priced. The experience is unique. The dialogue is in Vietnamese however it is easy to follow along. The puppets are well made although there are some routines which seem to be very similar to previous ones. You are able to take photos throughout which can be a little annoying, especially when people are using their flash. I would suggest it's better suited for children to enjoy but as it's part of Vietnamese culture, it is definitely something you should experience although I would doubt you'd want to experience it any more than once!
Just amazing. One of the most impressive traditional shows I have seen around the world. An absolute must in Hanoi

Mixed feelings. The water puppet show has left me with mixed feelings. On one hand it's interesting how they perform the show and make the puppets move in the water. However, it was not very entertaining the different parts of the show had not a clear story and as it was dark you could not see on the program what they were trying to show. For example, there was a 'unicorn dance' which more looked like two dragons or dogs (they didn't look like unicorns anyway) playing with a ball than anything else. If you are really interested go have a look, if you are not completely sure spend your 60000 dong on something else.

my visit February 2014. Very interesting way to give you an idea of some of the local customs in the Hanoi area, nice music and professional and pleasant musicians, unique set up, a must for every visitor.
Hmmm. In the centre of town, but very touristy and quite expensive. If folk culture is your big thing there are other free shows at various museums. Ask your hotel.

BRILLIANT. This is absolutely on of the best spectacles from Vietnam.
How they do it, who knows, but the performers and singers are brilliant.
The best part is a fox running up a tree.

A bit of fun for young and old. Everyone that comes to Hanoi generally ends up at the Puppet Theater, the theater is air conditioned so it's a relief from the heat, the show isn't that long and has some funny moments, you also get a taste of Vietnamese music and song.

Nice and old fashion (no special effect here :-)). If you are in for the local culture, then it is a place to visit. Songs are in Vietnamese, but you can follow the story (almost). It takes about 1 hour and costs VND 100.000/DKK 30/USD 5 for a better seat. Remember mosquito repellent (we were there in July 2014) and a fan (it was hot).

Water puppets with cramped seats. Good way to get a taste for traditional Vietnamese water puppet theatre. Very touristy. I am not that tall (approx 5ft. 8 in.), yet the seats had very little leg room. I had been warned about this, so had chosen an aisle seat. Highly recommend asking for an aisle seat! The woman at the window tried to dissuade me and originally even gave me a center seat even after I asked for an aisle. When I persevered, she reluctantly provided one. If you are at all tall, persevere... Overall, fun show and worth the experience.

Five minutes is enough. This could be really good if you had a written script so you could understand the story that is been portrayed. However the puppeteers do an excellent job and the special effects are good.

Long show and not entertaining. Even though this show is really cheap, I'd save your dollars... The staff front of house are rude - actually they were the only unfriendly people we came across in our trip to Vietnam! The show was really boring, the first 5 minutes summed up the whole show so the rest of the 40minutes dragged on. Heaps of tourists but no effort was made to have translations so all the jokes and stories were lost on us. Would recommend you spend your money enjoying a nice Hanoi beer on the Hanoi Elegance Diamond Hotel rooftop bar.

Entertaining. While I enjoyed the 50-minute show, my husband did not! Conducted entirely in Vietnamese, the audience are left to infer what's going on (the programme in English is helpful). While the puppeteers are skillful, we were more fascinated and intrigued by the musicians and their interesting musical instruments. Bring your own drinks eg. water, to avoid being overcharged at the restaurant/coffeeshop downstairs. There are several shows a day, but they are usually full so don't expect to walk in.

Good to see but a bit long. This is good to see if you want to experience what these are like. Its lasts about 50 minutes which is about 20 minutes too long as its all in Vietnamese. Its authentic so good but you may be better seeing a puppet show in the Museum of Ethnology which is included in the price of the entrance.
Good. I really did enjoy this show but wouldn't be rushing back. Seating was cramped and my husband found the show went for too long. Otherwise good show, very talented people!!

Interesting, worth a watch. The 30-45min show is entirely in Vietnamese, but many tourist go to watch it. It is quite funny hearing them sing and speak in their melodious voices, and though the dialogue is lost, one can vaguely gauge the meaning and folklore they are trying to portray. It is cheap, get the 60k VND tickets and find yourself adequately entertained for the next hr. It is usually full so you need to book for a few shows in advance (they have a few shows per day), so book it early then go about exploring the old quarter then get back for your show.

Cultural disconnect. An hour performance was included as part of our tour in Hanoi.Although the theatre was packed with mainly western tourists it was obvious that the jangly music and high pitched Vietnamese singing did not resonate with most of the audience.It was an interesting insight into a local artistic performance and the movement of the water puppets was quite intriguing.Not understanding the language or the cultural significance of the stories made it difficult to appreciate the show as much as the local Vietnamese audience.10 minutes is more than enough unless you are an experienced water puppet aficionado

Totally different!. I have to say, I have never seen anything like this anywhere else! One criticism, the seats are almost on top of each other, but the puppets in the water are just amazing ! Highly recommended if you visit Hanoi !

Brilliant show. Excellent show enjoyed the music and the puppets. We paid extra for seats at the front and I would say it is definately worth it as you can see alot more. Think it may not be as interesting at the back where you cannot see so well. Would definately recommend we loved it.
Like nothing I've ever seen. This was a great show. I is rich in its history, and tells the folklore of the people. I would recommend it to anyone wanting to take in a unique cultural experience.
Living Theatre. The water puppets are like nothing I've ever seen. The lighting effects and puppet mastery were mesmerizing. A taste of culture you should not miss.

Very good experience. I really enjoyed the puppet show! It was very different from anything I have seen before. Even though it was presented in Vietnamese it was easy to follow the stories. Everyone should pay a visit here :)

A nice treat to learn the historical culture. It was a very low cost way to start the day and see some amazing artistry with the local puppeteers. The location and equipment is getting a little old, but if you put that aside, it is a nice 30 minute treat to get a local show and understand the culture a little better.

Puppet Show. A must see because this part of Vietnam is famous for this. However we had already seen a show on our return from Ha Long Bay and this show was very similar. That said, it only lasts about 30 minutes. One can admire the puppeteers' skills but it's not my cup of tea.

Special Vietnam traditional art. Around 1 hour, the show express Vietnam history, daily life with effect of lights, music and artist .This is suitable for all people from child to old to understand more about Vietnamese culture.Should try it if you come to Vietnam

Just ok. Nice to see but not a must. There are many other things to do and see in Hanoi. It reflects well life in Vietnam before and the way they do it is interesting but you will not die stupid if you haven't seen it ;-)

Part of the culture, but not that exciting. The show in late afternoon was packed (3000 people?). The show looked authentic enough and they did their best. Worth a visit as it is part of Vietnamese culture, but it was not too exciting: if I had missed it for whatever reason, I still would have had a great time in Hanoi....

Great bit of Vietnamese culture only 1hour long so easy to fit into your day. We had seen Water Puppets advertised in other cities in Vietnam but wanted to wait until Hanoi for the most authentic show. The tickets were easy to purchase and we got them just a couple of hours before. We opted for the higher price tickets which was worth it as we were just four rows from the front and due to the size of the puppets I think at the back if would be difficult to see. The puppeteers were very talented and they made an effort to make the production entertaining for adults. All of the language was in Vietnamese except at the beginning so at times it was difficult to understand what was going on and I would have been lost without the leaflet I picked up before going in which explained the title of each of the sections.
A joy to visit. Our night out was arranged by Buffalo tours in Hanoi. The puppet show exceeded our expectations and we recommend this show for all age groups.

A must see. The whole family enjoyed the show. It was in quite a small theatre with a stage of water. It was very exciting seeing the puppets do various acrobatics in the water. It was very soothing and mesmerizing! My daughter described the puppets as smiley and made her laugh. We all enjoyed the experience, took lots of photos and purchased two puppets

A one hour cultural show which could be a bit shorter.. The show is well presented with skillful puppeteers. The auditorium is comfortable with good air-conditioning. Good for families with young kids but adults may find it a bit too long.

Good fun. I wasn't sure what to expect - my 14 year old wasn't amused, but my 7 year old and husband loved it. Lovely storytelling and fantastic puppetry, the Vietnamese version of a good Punch and Judy! Would defy it let recommend as you won't see this elsewhere.

Bored musicians and underwhelmed audience. I had been really looking forward to this. I am a Drama Teacher an enjoy experiencing new art forms around the world. I'm not sure what I was expecting, but the puppets didn't quite match up. It didn't help that I am short (5'3") and was unlucky enough to be sat near the back behind some tall people, so couldn't see everything.I could see the musicians though, who appeared to be quite bored and not that into it. The singer checked her nails and brushed down her skirt while singing! Some of the scenes were fun and funny and the firebreathing and water squirting dragons were cool. However the audience didn't seem to care, and My automatic clapping after each vignette was sometimes the only to be heard. I really felt for the puppeteers who were working so hard, and can't blame the musicians if that's the reception they normally get! Worth going to see for a cultural experience and was cheap at about $5/3GBP each (this key board doesn't have a pound sign!)

unique....amazing and unbelievable!!!..puppets in a frenzy!!. ...am tottalllly in awe,how this puppets are handled...the just appear out of nowhere and they move and glide and create a total ruckus in the water...we paid thru the hotel USD5 each for this show at the far end of the lake...till now am trying to figure how the mechanism is controlled so as they stay afloat and glide and dive and jump around in a frenzy..almost alive!!..the whole show lasts for a good 1 hours with some singing,wish they cud translate whats going on as some are legends or either folklore..anyhow its good fun and amazing to simply watch it.....go for it and enjoy it,its simply one of a kind!!

Charming traditional fare. The puppets were very unusual and portrayed various tales from Vietnamese folklore, Costumes and special effects were good , particularly liked the jumping fish routine. The accompanying music my be a little harsh for Western ears, but overall a different experience and well worth taking in.

A taste of Vietnamese culture and story telling.... Beautiful live traditional music and singing. I really enjoyed it!The show is unique, and the puppets tell interesting Vietnamese stories and legends (all in Vietnamese) which I really liked. I don't think you need to understand Vietnamese to enjoy the show. It's a lovely way to experience some beautiful traditions of Vietnam!It cost only about $5-$6 AUD, and the show runs for about 50 mins. If your interested, try and get your tickets at the box office at least a day or two early to get good seats near the front.

Not very exciting. We went here as it was recommended by various people. We actually found it pretty boring. Its all spoken in Vietnamese so you dont understand what is going on. We visited on our 2nd day in Vietnam and due to jet lag, it was hard to keep out eyes open in the squashed theater room.

Charming show. Brilliant show that had lots of charm. Was really annoying the amount of people using flash photography, I'm not sure if this is a regular occurrence. If you are over 6 ft don't get there too early as you will be uncomfortable sitting down for so long!

Entertaining. I am traveling solo and decided to take in the show. Although there is no English translation, I enjoyed the performance. If you are bringing children, I'm sure they will enjoy it as the children(foreign) in the audience were laughing hysterically. The only downside is that there was some major double booking and the staff was a bit rude when it came to seating.

I have appreciated it very much. At the begining of the story it was raining and I was just e few meters from this theater. I know about it but Puppets are not my favorite. I decided to pay for this attraction. It was really nice, interesting. I spent a very good time inside this little theater. there were tourists of course, but also locals. The signers are very nice in their traditional clothes. Nice place.

Really Different. I had no idea what we were in for with this show. It was really terrific and also only 1/2 hour - which was a great length to enjoy the show. This is an amazing art and I am really glad I went to see it.

Iconic Vietnam. Worth the 100,000vnb and a must do Vietnamese experience but little explaination what the whole show was about, not that the scenarios need a story. Do some reading about cultural history prior to the show. Musical accompaniment worked well with the show. Suitable for whole family. Theatre is a little small and the seating not designed for taller or larger westerners.

Hilarious crossing language barrier. Very impressive and worth every dong spent. Skill of puppeteers and band provide a wonderful entertains experience that is for all ages. Witty and comedic the tails told through the art of puppetry breaks the language barrier and you find yourself involved and laughing along to most acts even you have not one clue as to what is actually being spoken. The pamphlet is informative and gives you an idea of what is about to take place. Very skilful with water and fire work effects. If you don't go you have missed out on a wonderful experience. The shows occur late in the arvo nearly every hour so go in and book in advance to get closer seats. Even up the back it was worth it. Front row I do believe you pay extra. The seat leg space is tiny be prepared to be uncomfortable if you are tall ( really by this stage you are already aware of this being in Vietnam) don't bother paying for cameras everyone is doing it and they don't seem to have control on who does take pictures. Exiting the building going away from stage there is a back entrance where old puppets are stored. Can go have a look at these close up.EnjoyNote if you can't stand Vietnamese music/ singing try to sit through the first stage it's totally worth it
WOW! I enjoyed so much. Me and my family had a great fun hereThe show is sooooo niceFor kids and for adults!We will back here again

A bit tacky but fun. I went in with a open mind and was not disappointed. It was a bit too long, and I couldnt follow the story quite because of the language (no english). Still it was fun to watch and quite different from what we see in the west. Should not be first on your list, but maby second or third :D

A unique experience!. A must-do if your in Hanoi for a day or two - although booking in advance is highly recommended for good seats. We were in Row E, right in the middle so it made for comfortable viewing. Make sure you collect the guide (available in English, French, Japanese and a few other languages) in advance before you enter the theatre as apart from a two-minute intro, the rest is in Vietnamese. However, with chapter headers, one appreciates that art and humour does not have a language barrier - so for less than an hour it is worth keeping your mind alert and responsive for the show! It is different, clever and quite entertaining ..and so uniquely Vietnamese that I strongly recommend it to fellow-travellers to Vietnam!
A different experience. This show was great and in a beautiful setting. I would recommend it as a must for any traveller visiting Hanoi

Book in advance to get good seats. This is a must see place for any type of tourist to hanoi. It is totally different and very interesting not just the play, but seeing the different musical instruments been played etc.

Keep you amused for an hour. Go because it is different, traditional and probably unlike anything you have seen before. The guy next to me fell asleep, kids in the audience loved it. Seats designed for people under 5' 10 , so be warned!

evening show. this is worth the experience and even if you don't understand Vietnamese you will pick up on the stories being told, some very amusing. even though the audience is 99% non Vietnamese, i think we all had a good time.
awsum. tis is such a cool show. its very clever how the do a puppet show on water, the music works really well too. we got a cyclo (tuktuk) there...a great experience cause scooters are crazy!!
Boring. I realise this is culturally significant but with no English explanations and repetitive actions it was very boring
Interesting. Interesting though the costumes & puppets look a little worn-out. Tickets can be bought via your hotel.

A must see in Hanoi!. You must see the water puppets in Hanoi, we were left wondering how they do it! Short, sharp, entertaining and a good laugh. Ask your hotel to book tickets for you in the first 5 rows. Anywhere further back and you won't see much.

Worth a visit. This is something unique and worth a visit. Tickets can be bought at the box office in front of the Theatre located just off the North part of the Hoan Kiem Lake. The better seats in the front usually get sold out earlier so try and buy them asap or get your hotel to book, should cost abt 1,20,000 Dong. The ones in the back go for abt 60,000 Dong. Tall people beware there is little leg room between the rows so be prepared ! Also those visiting should carry mosquito repellant as there are quite a few resident mosquitos which perhaps are attracted to the stagnant water. The program is abt 55 minutes and has small performances centered around local tales including the story of the lake and turtle.The one downer is that all the commentary is in Vietnamese and the theatre should try and do an English version also. Over all the Water puppets and their puppeteers put on quite a show with several surprise elements!
Nice but not great. We read about this Theater in our guide and wanted to check it out. It is worth a watch but nothing more. It was nice watching and the actors with their puppets were good.

Neat Experience. Neat show if you've never seen it. Other than an quick into in English though, the entire show is done in traditional Vietnamese music and song, so some might find is a little boring to not be able to understand the stories. Also a bit warm in the summer with no air conditioning, just a fan.

2011 first visit. This is the place where all the tourists go and to be honest I much preferred the puppet theatre which I went to in Ba Vi on an open lake. It depends on how much time you have in Vietnam, if you have the time opt for an alternative to this theatre.

Pleasant enough. I found the musicians more interesting than the puppets - too bad they were set back in the wings. The puppet performances didn't really capture my attention. Colorful and pleasant enough and no real complaints at $5 each but not really a highlight of our visit to Vietnam.

A gift of history and culture. Vietnamese friends gave me tickets to this show, sharing the music and puppetry of their country. A lot of the "legends" portrayed will be new to Western visitors, but the live music will keep your toes tapping as the water puppets do their thing. The only annoyance was audience members constantly holding up their phones and tablets, blocking the view for those who just wanted to enjoy an evening of local history and culture. Oh well.

Interesting thing to experience. We were told to see a water puppet show when we visited Vietnam. We went to this one as it was closest to our hotel. For the $5 price it is worth seeing. It does go on a bit too long and is a bit difficult to follow (are just a series of very short stories) but still an interesting experience if you haven't seen a water puppet show before. I had wished they would have made the actual show a bit shorter and then had a demonstration of how they manipulate the puppets...at the end they have the puppeteers come out and take a bow but no explanation of how they do it. Unless you have a great camera and a good view, don't bother taking photos or getting a photo pass...I had a point and shoot and most of my photos were blurry...just too dark and we were too far away for a flash to be useful. Best if you get your tickets a day or two before the performance...then you don't have to stand in line very long to get your seat.
Beautiful must see folklor!. The show is short but intense, the musicians and singers are just incredible and the puppets are beautiful to see. This is a MUST if you visit Hanoi.

One of those thing u just go see. We came out of this show a bit confused whether we liked it or not... its just one of those things you shud just see once in your life. dont get the expensive tickets causethe theatre is pretty small

water puppets. Very interesting with the way the puppets are maneuvered, and the special effects used, including funny moments of cats running up a tree. Being charged to use own camera was a bit much

Fantastic!!. We had no idea what to expect - but the show started on time, the live (band) musical accompaniment was delightful and the puppets!! Wow!! we had no English translation but just by watching the puppets you got the general idea. Beautiful puppets, gorgeous colours and fun!!Then when the puppeteers waded out even more impressed.

A uniquely Vietnamese experience. I was advised to see the famous Vietnamese water puppets by a friend at home, but was rather put off by some of the reviews I read on Trip Advisor. My fears were raised when I found myself queueing, ticket in hand, in a long line of tourists waiting to enter the auditorium. I had been allocated a good seat, central and three rows from the front, so I had a good view of whatever was to come. As soon as the Vietnamese musicians started to play their traditional instruments, and the first puppets appeared in the water, I was entranced! Fabulous entertainment, and the hour sped by as one colourful scene flowed into the other. The Music was a real treat, as I had thought I wouldn't have time to attend a concert of Vietnamese music. So, two for the price of one, in my book! There were well carved puppets to buy in the lobby on the way out. I usually avoid such things, but left the theatre grasping a nicely carved wooden puppet fisherman in one hand. I go as far as saying that the water puppets are a unique experience, and a visit to Hanoi wouldn't be complete without seeing them!

Thoroughly unexpected delight. We had no idea what in the world we were getting into but it turned out to be just delightful.While the puppets are traditional, as is the music, there was a simultaneous English translation that was very helpful. The puppets appear in a large pool and at the end of the performance the puppeteers came wading through the water to take their bows. I had this "aha" moment...oh, that's how they did it!

Cheap, but spend your time somewhere else. I do not agree with the most here.. It seems that they didn't change anything in the 20 years they play this show. The show is simple, there was no real story and in the theater was hardly any space to put your legs. We were glad that the show only takes one hour. Completely overrated!

Well worth it. Surprisingly entertaining cultural experience. For a city that can be a bit short on entertainment, the water puppet show proved great value and entertainment.Not sure wether the flash photography should be allowed.

Glad we discovered this. As we hadn't prepared our trip on beforehand, this water puppet show wasn't on our program. But I'm glad we were able to buy tickets just some hours on beforehand. In the morning for that day there weren't much options left though: only for one certain time and one price category. In July there were about 4 performances a day. (e.g. 16.20, 17.30, 18.30, 21.00). On sunday there is a performance in the morning. There are 2 price categories: 60.000 and 100.000 VND per person. We had the cheapest category and seats in the last row in the back, but we still had a very good view of the scene. The duration of the show is 1 hour. Really fantastic traditional form of art and amusement, showing important elements of Vietnamese culture, e.g. ploughing the fields, harvesting of the rice, the 4 important animals in vietnamese culture (Phoenix, dragon, turtle and unicorn). It's as amusing for adults as it is for children. If you have children and you're visiting Hanoi I think this is definitely a stop you should make!

Very Entertaining. The water puppet theater was very interesting and I many times I couldn't decide whether to watch the water puppets or the musicians playing the traditional instruments.As an English speaking person I did find it some what difficult to follow the story line in parts but the enjoyable nature of the show more than made up for that.

Worth the trip. I had read varying reviews on trip advisor and wasn't sure if we were going to get value for our money with this one, but am really glad we went. There is really nothing else like it and it is such a unique Vietnamese art form that you just have to see it. Even bought the souvenir puppets as we left. Our daughters are aged 9 and 11 and loved it. It got a little bit repetitive a few times, but you have to see it to believe it and to appreciate the skill involved in this ancient art form.
Great!. We had front row seats! The music and puppetry was very impressive. A fun 60 minute show! It was definitely something that we had never seen before!

A great showcase for traditional Theatre. We had to go to the theatre to get our tickets no pre booking system is available. We arrived at 9.00 am and could only get seats for the 6.30pm or 8.30pm sessions. The tickets are only us$5 so it is a cheap event. The theatre is air conditioned and all the seating has good views. There were lots of kids when we were there and young and old enjoyed the performance. The show is around an hour in length. The music is traditional and the puppetry amazing.

Second visit and still entertaining. Even though I'd seen the show before, I knew my partner and our friends couldn't miss it so I signed up for another show. I was prepared to be a little bored, just as I'd seen it all before, but I found it as enjoyable as the first time. And I'm sure they'd changed an act or two that I couldn't remember.A joy to watch, definitely make sure you catch a show.

Ok way to spend an hour. Wouldn't go again, others in our group enjoyed it more than I did (and there were others who didn't enjoy it at all). Paid extra for the best seats and we were half way back in the theatre - so it wasn't worth paying the extra, although it was still only 100000 (about $5). Was in Vietnamese, so it was hard to figure out what was happening and they need to enforce a no cameras/flashes rule. I ended up sitting behind a couple of different groups who popped up their cameras and phones every minute or so trying to take a photo. Very annoying and detracted from the show a lot.

A fun evening out. Thang Long Water Puppet Theater is worth the money spent. Amazing use of water and puppetry that we don't have in Thailand. Suggestion is to try not to sit in the front two rows in order to get a better view. We didn't take photos since you need to pay to do so. Wish I had.

Very good, didn't get the unicorns though!. It was fun watching old vietnams trends like this water puppets! It was very fun although the story line is in Vietnamese but you can see the storyline! It's a must see!!!

Unique cultural experience. This is the preeminent water puppet theater in Vietnam. Very reasonably priced with an excellent show lasting a little bit over an hour. You should definitely not miss a visit here. We were able to get same day tickets but were in Vietnam outside of peak season. Apparently during peak season plans must be made well in advance. The show involved some beautiful live music and puppetry that is unique to Vietnam covering fables and stories about farming life.

Pretty good!. Not something I knew about before I went, we stumbled upon the Water Puppet Theater after a walk around Hoan Kiem Lake. It was actually pretty cool! The live musicians are amazing and the instruments they play are so cool and haunting - and the vocalists are soooo good! The water puppet theatre itself is very clever and entertaining too - what an amazing age-old tradition and a fantastic way to tell stories through the generations.Would I have made a special trip for it? Funnily enough - for the musicians, yes - but that's just more interesting to me. Was it worth the money we paid (maybe a few AUD) and an interesting way to pass an hour or so? Absolutely. If you happen to be nearby, drop in.Just something to note - if you have very young children (up to possibly 2 years), forget it. It scared the bejezus out of at least two little kids near us, and one parent of each couple duly took frightened child outside to entertain them whilst partner-left-behind tried to manage other children. No fun for parents, just hard work. But hey, sometimes that's parenting, huh??! :)

A paper show where the stage is water and live music and singers.. The puppet show has large puppets that appear to wade through water to show a story about the culture of northern Vietnam. The music is live on the side stage with instruments and singers. The dragon's dance was one of my favorite parts.

amazing. You do not have to be a kid to enjoy this, it is so wonderful, and the artist are faboulous! you should really book in advance, but if you are lucky there can be left over tickets, but do not expect good seats. A must do!!!

Surprising performance. A cultural tale told with puppets. The show lasted for approximately an hour. Often these shows can be a bit tedious. However, there was enough variation to keep you interested. It was good to see the traditional puppets in use.
Great show with a difference.. So special to see that old traditional type of puppet show. Excellent costumes and such fun watching, Comfortable seats.
cute. It is good. More like cute, bit interesting. Not like awesome or mind blowing. Try to get a seat on the first rows as it can a bit difficult to see further on if you a short.

Worth a visit. This is about a 50 minute show and quite cheap. There is traditional music and and the story is very old time Vietnam. Don't have to get dressed up or anything, just fit it into your day if you are nearby.
Well worth a look if you have the time. Wasn't sure what to expect, but this was very well played, we were lucky and front row seat, great show and very clever how its done,

Good views everywhere - buy the cheaper ticket. There are good views everywhere in the theater. You don't need to buy the higher-priced ticket for better seating. There are also signs saying not to take pictures, but it seemed like 1/4 of the people in the theater with us were taking pictures practically the whole time and I didn't see anyone get in trouble. This part was a little bit annoying since we were sitting towards the back and there were fluorescent phone lights popping up here and there. There are plenty of shows everyday, don't worry about having to reserve ahead of time. My husband and I showed up 5 mins before the late show (8p) started and there was still plenty of seating space.Be forewarned - the entire show is in Vietnamese! It is a short show at 1hr. The show comes off a little bit cheesy (like a college production), but it IS cultural. Show up with an open mind and appreciation for this ancient art form.

Its not as great as advertised. My hosts in Hanoi insisted that it was an essential tourist experience, both times I visited the city. Although Hanoi does not have a huge selection of places to go, this one is not high on my list. If you have limited funds, have an excellent meal instead. If you have limited time, go to the Ho Chi Minh museum instead. If you go, get there early, or get your tickets booked by a tour company, usually hotels can do this. Seating here matters and tour companies have the best seats already bought up. And, if you are above 5'8", prepare to have your knees just under your chin.
Well worth seeing. The music alone is fantastic and the singing. I really didn't think I would enjoy this but I was SO glad I went.

Must see while in Vietnam. The1969 established Thang Long Water Puppet Theatreis located at 57B, Dinh Tien Hoang street, has water puppet shows daily.Photography as well as video shoot is allowed. But do book in advance as there is heavy demand for the shows.

Good way to spent your time. Just a few minutes walk from our hotel, we can find out this place easy and had a great show of water pupetry. We loved everything about this. World class performance in so many ways. From the reviews on Trip Advisor, we happy to say they have succeeded. Take time out of your travels to experience this show. Well worth a visit.

A must see in Hanoi. Be prepared to be totally blown away. At first I did not know what to expect. All animations are coloured timber figurines dancing around in the water,controlled from behind the scene. Voice over's and music is a pleasure to watch sitting both left & right of the stage singing local Vietnamese story lines and playing local musical instruments. All you need is one hour to spare.

much better than expected. As this is a major tourist experience, it could have been all hype so though it was hokey, it was enjoyable. Skillful, synchronized, clever use of fire and underwater work. It was perfect length - one hour, The musicians were BRILLIANT, enhancing the action with true musicianship. You can buy some of the instruments after the show.

Book in advance!. We saw the show on a Saturday afternoon and it was sold out so make sure you buy tickets before the show time. We had no idea what to expect and were pleasantly surprised by the show. The puppetry was so skilful and quite entertaining. The view wasn't brilliant. We had bought the 'expensive' tickets (100,000D) but couldn't see how our seats were any better than any of the others. The rows are tightly packed together so there were lots of heads in the way when the show began. Try to get seats as close to the front as possible. It's not something I would rush to see again but I'm glad that we went and would recommend it to others.
Popular venue for a fun hour. You have to go once....always amusing, this is a 'must visit once' venue. See traditional water puppet performances on the side of Hoan Kiem Lake.
A good show. The water puppet show is worth seeing. The theatre can get crowded and the seats are are uncomfortable as there is not enough leg room especially for tall people.
Kind of kooky, but a must do in Hanoi. We took our family and enjoyed the show. Just a shame it was all in Vietnamese as we didn't understand a thing!

Something to do. Live music is well done but not something that most folks would be familiar with. The show was sort of predictable and not all that entertaining. It was unusual but probably worth the $ 5 ticket price

Interesting water puppets. It was a good showcase of Vietnamese culture and we enjoyed the show. The live music adds to the performance but the theatre is not well maintained. The acoustics and sound quality could have been better. Although there was an English pamphlet with write up about the performances, live translation could have made it more interesting. My kids bet age of 7 and 9 definitely enjoyed it. Ticket price was value for money. Front seats are more expensive.

Even exciting for a 10 year old boy. Was wondering what the kids would think of this but water sprouting dragon puppets had them on the edge of their seats. Some of the singing lost them a little but overall it was a great thing to do here.
Great. We really enjoyed the water puppets. I was very impressed with the way the puppeteers worked their magic. The theatre was full. We had seats in the middle and could see easily.

Good!!! Interesting!!!. Well, i went to Thang Long water puppet theater with my Australian friend on 4th July. Strengths:-Have AC (Hanoi is hot in this month). -Have nice coffee shop and restaurant nearby. -Have great souvenir shop selling puppet toys (Interesting functions, Small and convenient to bring, Reasonable price)-Costing 4$/toy. -Have waiting seats. -Have a cozy welcoming by receptionists. -Be easy to buy tickets and the price is fixed and published. -Be quite spacious.-Having beautiful decorations to take photos. -Be easy to get a taxi or cyclo (Should bargain, avoiding cheating).-Have an ideal position (Near Hoan Kiem lake on Dinh Tien Hoang street).-Be an amazing performance related to Vietnamese culture, history and lifestyle with skillful artists, professtional stage, good light and sound quality. -Perform traditional live music well. Weaknesses:-Have small seats (Suitable with small Asean people) Sadly enough, my friend who is 195cm high and 120kg weight, found sitting uncomfortable, so he chose the outside seat. I hope the theatre should be change and upgrade new big seats that are suitable with Western people. -Only perform by Vietnamese version. Its challenging to understand well for the international tourists. Should have billigual Vietnamese and English. -Some people are late, making annoyance and distraction. Please remind audiences to be on time. -Some people take a lot and take many photos with flashes. In short, this is a fantastic show which tourists should enjoy.

Nice and worth to watch. Is a good experience to watch this Water Puppet show. Ticket may vary due to the seat / view. Of course front seat is the most expensive, suggest to check and order ticket with hotel staff.Camera and Video recorder is allow.

It was well done. It won't be to every bodies liking but it was well done. It would have been better with an explanation or narration about the story. I read the other review that mentioned subtitles we did not see any.

Surprisingly fun. Wasn't sure what to expect. Was worried it would be juvenile.
Had time during the evening before dinner so went up to the ticket counter and was able to get a ticket for the immediate performance.
I found it delightful. Occasionally some of the skits start slow but overall it's a fun time.

unique experience. It's one o a kind experience. If you like art and ready for something you'd never see in western culture, it's great enjoyment. It's a theatre and musical performance with unique traditional musical instruments. We loved it! They tell a story (subtitles are available through the performance), that is related to the history of Vietnam. The only bad thing, that some of the spectators are not very respectful and make a lot of noise with their snacks, being late and walking in front of other people (performance lasts for only 40min, so those small disturbances are not nice at all). Otherwise, a great attraction and as said unique experience!p.s. we visited it in july 2013.

WTF. Well, that's 55 minutes of my life I'll never get back.Tedious, indecipherable, cramped seating.Novelty factor wore off after the first five minutes.Give it a miss, much better things to see and do.

Great experience especially with kids. I went with 3 kids between 9 and 4 and everyone really enjoyed it. It was an entertaining experience and the kids loved it. My 4 year old wanted to go back the next day. Make sure you get the English pamphlet that gives you a bit of an idea what each piece is about. There were 14 short pieces about rice farming, fishing, catching foxes, fairies and dragons. It gave the kids a taste of traditional Vietnamese culture including music singing and puppetry. Sitting near the front is good.

Interesting show. This show was ok with some interesting parts. The problem for me was it was in Vietnamese and hard to follow, maybe I'm just getting old. Not really my thing but a bit of fun with some culture thrown in. Probably better for the young. Not expensive and cool in the heat.
Fascinating cultural art or fever dream?. Could go either way… definitely a unique art form and the performers are talented. It may haunt your dreams however...

Interesting once nothing spectacular. Something nice to do on a hot evening. Ok for first timer but I will not go for a return visit. They spoke in Vietnamese and I could not understand a word. Would be nice if there are some English words in between to make it a lighter session and some laughs.

Better than expected. We had fairly low expectations, but were pleasantly surprised with the variety and spectacle of the show. The puppets are beautifully made and cleverly manipulated, and there are some surprising special effects. It's great to see a bit of culture and tradition in a country that doesn't seem to make the most of these things.Good to book as far in advance as possible so you're seated close to the front.There is a sheet available that describes the different parts of the show.
An Unique Art. We buy the ticket in front gate and get in the Thang Long theater to watching the show at 7pm, that was really unique art of Vietnam

Charm and entertain. Very entertaining, something new. Even though you miss the words, it is not impossible to understand. The show is based in 14 different songs/stories/musical numbers and they don't have any connection to each other as far as I understood from both the program and the show. I travel with a 15 year old daughter and my husband, all of us enjoyed a lot. It has a lot of humor and charm! BUT: I really don't understand why tourists have to take pictures with flash the whole way trough the show! They talk loud as well, as if they never knew how to behave in a theater. That was a minus, really! Leg room is a bit on the short side for tall (european :>) people. Anyway, really nice experience!

Good show. Really enjoyed the show overall but no English! That made it hard to follow so just go to watch and relax in the cool. We saw one in a museum in HCMC that was not as good a show but was in English so that balanced it. This is worth going though as it's cheap and again cool in summer! My kids enjoyed it too (11, 8 and older ones).
It was cute!. Very nice show! Worth seeing! I recommend it to everybody, especially families! It is also not too expensive.

Worth a watch. You won't understand much as it is in Vietnamese, but probably worth a watch. Two ticket prices, 10000 dong for closer to the stage seats, 60000 dong for the further away ones. 5 shows a day, every hour from 4:30 to 9:30 pm

A Fun Show - Great for all ages. Don't delay organising your tickets for this show. It sells out very quickly. There are plenty of places to eat nearby (either before or after the show).It is very entertaining. There is a handout which you receive prior to the show. Make sure you read it before the show commences so that you can understand what the story line is about.This is great value and a highlight of a stay in Hanoi. I highly recommend it.

For something completely different. Water puppets are a lot of fun. This show is only an hour long but you will wish it was longer. If possible sit in the front row so no heads will block your view. I really enjoyed myself at this performance. Great for kids too.

Hanoi - Thang Long Water Puppet Theatre - Very enjoyable yet confusing. As soon as we got into Hanoi we headed off to the Thang Long Water Puppet Theatre so we could see the show that day. They have various performances during the evening and they are pretty much booked up fairly quickly. We managed to get one of the later shows allowing us to have a meal before entering the theatre. It's a pretty good sized seating area and the views are good. The show lasts about forty to forty five minutes and consists of the water puppet presentation and the orchestra to one side and two ladies singing. The music and the singing were great, as was the puppet show itself but I just couldn't follow the story. I got parts of it but was unsure what was really going on meaning it was less appealing and enjoyable. If I ignored any story then seeing how the puppeteers perform and listening to the music and singing was great but I left thinking I saw a great performance but not necessarily a great show. Perhaps the theatre could offer some form of understandable dialogue or explanation leaflet for foreign visitors in the future. I would certainly have benefitted from some assistance with understanding what was going on. Still, the show is relatively inexpensive and the theatre very attractive with a number of puppets on show in the area outside the performance hall. If you are to visit this place see if you can get some form of understanding as to what the story is telling you before you go in and perhaps this will make it better for us western Europeans.
Good musical. Good price for relax, you should chose this theater to get knowleged about musical Vietnam. It's near by old quater. That's recomendation.

water puppet theatre. It was a wonderful experience. Sober, bewitching and very rich in culture. They gave us an introduction in French & English that enabled us to follow the story.Your trip to Hanoi is incomplete if if you have not seen this

water puppet-extraordinary difference!!. A must see- unique experience...good music. narration in vietnamese. will help if they do it in english but we can sort of understand it because of the actions shown by the puppets.Read the brochure first so that you can get a glimpse of the show..It makes it more enjoyable!Buy a puppet home as a souvenir. Available after the show.

Thang Long Water Puppet Show. Thoroughly enjoyed this show. Very cleverly done using water as the stage. Loved the variety of puppets used and their props. The music and singing added to the experience. Could have gone a second time but ran out of time.

novelty show. Part of an arranged tour. Would not do it again.Although the puppeteers were very talented at what they did there was very little information about the history of the story behind the show.
Unique and Entertaining. A colourful, funny and lively show - pity we couldn't understand the words! It would be very interesting to go backstage and see exactly how its done.
Water Puppet Show. Good performance by the crew members. All moves were well coordinated. Good songs with live band on stage.

hmm. thought there was guide handbooks provided with different languages, which is very considerate.but i did not have a clue about how they connected plot to plot. i had to read handbook and watch the show at the same time to understand what is going on there.overall, it was a special puppy show performed above water, and the ticket price is pretty acceptable. visitors could try and experience unique Vietnamese way of show.

Amusing. My friends and I thought this was best enjoyed when you are watching it more as 'funny' than as a 'serious show'. We laughed and laughed at it. Others in the audience were not as impressed as us.
Fun. Very different to other puppet shows I have seen. Very skilful and great fun to watch. Language was no barrier to enjoying and understanding
Water puppets in Hanoi. Very enjoyable show. The puppets appear from everywhere, very intriguing how the puppeteersare able to move them around without getting tangled up
Yawn. It was not what we expected. There was no background info on the cultural significance. It went for too long.
Great performance. A fun thing to go and see in Hanoi. They sing in Vietnamese, but you understand the story easily. Very talented puppeteers.

Water puppet theater. Who would go all the way to Hanoi and not see this? It is a real slice of culture. Sit somewhere close enough to photograph and be fully engaged but not in the front two rows unless you don't mind a little splashing. I've seen it about 10 times now and will again

amazing. A very interesting and amazing performance. The scenes were very colourful and attractive. It's one attraction which shouldn't be missed in Hanoi. Have to get the tickets early though cos they get sold out fast. The theatre can be can warm cos the air-conditioning is not cold enough.

Must visit. It is the traditional art which must watch when visit to Hanoi.
There are a few legends/ stories presented thru this water puppet art.
It's fun!

Worth a look. It's worth visiting if you have some free time, but not something I would specifically make time for. It's very reasonable and you can buy tickets on the day, about $2. It only lasts about 50 minutes and the seats don't really give much leg room. It was full the day I went and several people left in the middle, disappointed or bored I don't know, it seemed a bit disrespectful to me, just my opinion. The location is very convenient right across from the lake. The times have changed slightly, 1st show started at 5.20pm.

Remarkable show once you realize what you've seen. I thought it was a little slow at times and i did not understand it initially. Live music, puppets and a pool and no clue what i was going to see. Enjoyed it and would go again just to try and figure out how they make this happen.

Wonderful experience. We enjoyed the water puppets immensely. It was something very different to experience and the puppeteers were very clever craftsmen indeed. The music and singing that went with the show was excellent. Great value for money.

Kids will love it, parents could fall asleep. Kids will love this Thang Long Water Puppet Theater because of the effects and the unusual puppetry in water. Problem is it's quite long for something you can't understand what they're singing and talking about, there's a possibility that you'll get bored like what happened to me, worse I fell asleep.

Better than expected. I must admit that I did not have high expectations of a puppet theater. Though having seen the show I can say I have changed my mind and would highly recommend this attraction to any traveler. Why? you will understand after you see the show!

Must-Stop in Hanoi. The Water Puppet Theater in Hanoi is something that you should set aside an hour to see and enjoy. It is deeply routed in the Vietnam culture, and is well worth your time and money. Enjoy the story telling the water & fire, the music, and the local color.

Water Puppet Show. Very nicely done and rather unique. We thoroughly enjoyed this show. We did this with a tour Group Gate 1 tours and it was well organized. I would highly recommend this.Jim & Marina D'Costa
Absolutely unique. This is really a unique art form and is worth visiting. Your mileage may vary regarding whether the stories are enjoyable, but the dramatic presentation is captivating.
Water Puppet Show in Hanoi. Not really my cup of tea but fun after the ride through old Hanoi and the traffic in a rickshaw...what else can I say!

Good performance to show legend about Vietnam. I and my friend from USA decided to see Water Puppet Show because it's one kind of traditional music and performance in Vietnam. we really enjoyed the show, I was excited to hear woman voice, melody of music instruments, nice puppets. The story of show is a legend about history of Vietnam. The only minus point is that they sang in Vietnamese, so my friend didn't understand any thing and they just have screen to display the story in English, my friend couldn't catch full meaning of legend because he had to see the show and listen to music too. General, we still like performance

A must see in Hanoi. These water puppet plays originated in the rice fields of the Mekong delta, at the puppet theatre here in Hanoi, the shows are really interesting, with singers and instruments, gongs, flutes and drums, the puppets are made from papier mache and appear out of the water. Most of the plays are based on folk tales.
A must do whilst in Hanoi. 🐸👺. It is interesting with some good effects, but just long enough went to see this as it is part of vietnamese culture. Fire spitting dragons are good fun!

just okay.. it's was nice to know about history but it's in vietnamese.. so we can only enjoy the music since we dont really understand the stories. And the guidebook they gave not really helpful. entrance fee about 5 usd/person.

Cute. It was fun to see. I highly recommend taking a pamphlet outside the theater before the show because the show is entirely in Vietnamese. The pamphlet helps describe each scene. It was fun to watch, but I wouldn't say it was a top highlight.
Wonderful performance. Amazing show with incredibly talented musicians and puppeteers. Surreal and fantastic stories, you forget you're looking at puppets!

It's a must do in Hanoi and it's only 45 minute of your time. With 3 shows starting from early evening it is easy to fit this in, probably before going to dinner. There is no point rushing dinner to see a 45 minute show, so go first, then you have time to have dinner or go to the night markets on a Sunday. Sure this type of theatre is not every-ones idea of fun, but with it's cultural significance about Vietnam and Hanoi it is worth the visit just because you are in Hanoi. It is well done, It didn't seem to matter where in the theatre you sat (pre seated ticket sales), so if you are buying the cheaper seats, they still have a good view. There is not a great deal of leg room, so if you are very tall ask for an isle seat or front row (if still available).The programme is quick and each part of the show doesn't last very long so keeps your interest. As I mentioned it is only a 45 minute show. And it is very well done with live music and live singers as well as the Puppets controlled by the team of puppeteers.

Interesting insight into local culture. The theatre is situated beside the lake and the show runs for about 1 hour. It's is quite amusing and consists of a series of scenes all wonderfully controlled by expert puppeteers and accompanied by traditional song and music. Worth seeing if your looking for something different

Something to do on a rainy day. the first half of the show was ok. Puppets moving around on water, manipulated by people standing behind the scenes but the second half got a little boring. There was no translation and yes you could make out the story line but i would not do it again.Sorry.
Puppet show - traditional Vietnamese show. We took our child here and he loved it even i am sure he did not understand about this show. A little bit long. We had to leave after 40 minutes
special. Absolutely fascinating spectacle. So clever and appeals to all ages. Loved the music and the puppets. Not to be missed.

Fun and daft and interesting all in one. The Water puppet show is great for $4. It is slightly dragged out but it doesn't take away from the whimsy of the whole thing. Definitely worth a visit. Don't go early- be bang on time.
