Seems very authentic and traditional with the water stage front and center and the live band and singers on the left. The only down side is the seats are very small, so tall people will have to squeeze in, however it is only about an hour long performance.

Fun. I think you have to experience a visit to the Water Puppet Show whilst in Vietnam, very entertaining and clever work, and worth every penny. The only downside would be they should ban photography in there, nothing more annoying than people in front constantly waving ipads in the air to take pictures.The amazing singing voices and unusual musical instruments used is incredible.

The show itself is great. I would've given 5 stars, certainly for the show, but inside the theatre, it was rather warm and smelt of cigarette smoke. As we are non smokers, we ended up with a sore throat.
Interesting show. Good show - interesting but not fantasticSeats are tiny so be warned - it also gets crazy busyworth a visit once at least
A must see. Once in Hanoi one should definitely take some time to see this show. It takes around one hour, the coreography is unique and easy to follow.
A good hours entertainment.. This is totally different to anything else I have seen. Ideal for families and people who like traditional entertainment. Don't expect and 21st century CGI
Amazing. Not what we were expecting. Absolutely brilliant show, from the live music and amazing puppetry. Well worth a visit. You can take your camera in but they do charge extra for it

Could be better. An excellent set up and display. But I found the lack of English as an alternative language lacking. Yes, the traditional songs have to be the same, but maybe the content of the dialogue could have an english version to allow the tourists to understand the humour that was on display...
Good experience. It is a must when you visit Vietnam. A cultural show that will remind you how simple life there and exciting with the way they can control the puppet.

Step back into time, ancient theater. while you may not understand the traditional music, this is a must do to make your Hanoi experience complete. While most of my colleagues would not want to go a second time, they are very glad they saw this unique art form - blending traditional Vietnamese music with puppets attached to long rods beneath the water. From a boy and his dog to harvesting rice, to a royal processional, and a dragon or two thrown in for good measure - this folks is entertaining.

Can't go wrong for $3. Nice cultural experience. Interesting to see different things from around Vietnam represented in the puppet show. Worth sitting in the front to be able to see more. Can't go wrong to pop in on the way to dinner and it's only $3!

water puppet theater. were not able to get tickets the first time we were in hanoi, so were thrilled to finally get a pair when we went this time. sit in one of first few rows if possible if want to take some photos--otherwise, have to hold your camera over the heads of those in front of you and you cannot see what you are taking a picture of. 45 minute show--just right.

A good experience. I liked the show I went to, it was a good experience. I wasn't too long (I think more than 90 minutes of anything in a foreign language would be pushing it) but this is funny - the jokes work, the story is easily followed - the puppeteers are insanely talented. And the music is very well played. If you're not a theatre fan obviously not for you, but anyone who doesn't mind theatre and likes culture will enjoy.

Delightful. So charming and delightful. This is a nice break from dodging motorbikes in Hanoi. The show includes 12-13 mini segments of old stories they used to enact during the rainy system. It was a highlight of Hanoi!

Could have been better presented.. There was so much hype because this puppet show went international many years ago.The performance started interesting but unfortunately became repetitious and monotonous.Biggest problem was the lack of subtitles for foreign audiences. All dialogue and singing was in Vietnamese. While many in the audience may guess the storyline, it would be more enjoyable if a synopsis (in English) was given before each act. Towards the end many of us were getting restive.However, I did enjoy the traditional music and singing.Perhaps when the show was performed at foreign art festivals, explanation was given in the languages of the host countries. Hence its world wide popularity. The theatre itself was small but right for the type of show. However the seats could be steeper because tall viewers, as many Caucasians are, tend to block the view of the audience in the row immediately behind.

its a must. This was a fabulous show. A great experience.... it's only about 45-50 minutes and costs 100k but if you want to take photos it's an additional 20k (which we paid, but most people walked past without paying and nobody seemed to check!)We loved the puppets and the singing, would definitely recommend you see this.

A good and different experience. A beautifully conceptualized, created and choreographed show. With melodious vietnamese music and beautiful story telling, the puppets come to lfe and keep your eyes glued on them. Better to sit in front. So be on time.

Enjoyed it.. The water puppet show was not really on my list of things to do since it sounded very touristy but since it was so close to the hotel I was staying in, I could just walk across so I bought myself a ticket (100,000 Vietnamese Dong..approx 5 USD). They have seat numbers so if you need to sit in front you have to book early. My seat was midway down the hall, but it was gallery style and I could see very well.Once having gone there, I really liked their music and enjoyed the water puppet show very much. The puppetteers are very skilled and since the brochure gives a synopsis of each of the playlets, it is quite easy to follow. I thought the show was designed very cleverly with sudden appearance of dragons from under the water, puppets climbing up trees, etc which seemed very skilled. It was very colourful and also made me laugh at parts. The show lasts for less than an hour. I am glad I did go, and also bought a little keepsake puppet from the lobby outside since they impressed me so much!

A part of Vietnamese Heritage. If you are in Hanoi, I would recommend you visit a water puppet show. The traditional music is beautiful and the stories are interesting. If you visit this puppet theatre however, please be advised that there is very little leg room and kids will not see the water if they sit too far up. My son had to sit on top of the folded seat in order to view the puppets in the water.Go to take part in their cultural heritage and know that the show is less than an hour long.

An experience not to miss. It was a nice way to experience Vietnamese culture. Although the stories are told in Vietnamese language, it wasnt hard to understand. Some of it are even funny (well for me and this other guy anyway). We paid 100,000dong and an additional dong for the camera use. Other people suggest not to pay for the camera.

Curious!. Different, intriguing and fun. The shows last less than one hour but it's worth to go.
Great musicians. Beautiful puppets

Visual Spectacle. My family and I saw this show on a Wednesday at 3pm. The line wasn't long. We paid at the entrance right before the staircase to use our camera during the show. Get a front row seat or nearer to the front. It is clearer and when you want to take pictures, less heads to obstruct your picture-taking view. The show was visually entrancing. We wondered how they managed it because the cast came out at the end to receive their ovations. And they were not wet at all! It was colorful and energetic. The singers too, showed enthusiasm, even though, they must have done this thousands of times. Enjoyed the show.

Enjoyed the show. On a bleak.cold,grey day in Hanoi we decided to see this puppet show. It's a good way to spend some free time in this busy city. Coffee and French cakes in the café are very good and the toilets were clean. The show has a traditional Vietnamese band playing on the side of the "stage" which is a square pool of water with a bamboo curtain at the back where the puppets enter and leave the pool. Fire works,smoke and splashing dragons,turtles swimmers,fishermen create an enjoyable show. I would guess the show lasted 45 mins-which was long enough with shopping bags piled on our laps and very squashy seats.

Not a long show so try it. The talent to do these water puppets is great. It's not the most amazing show I've seen but for the $5 and the short performance time, you should probably go to it. It's something they are known for and it's interesting to watch the little puppets flipping and flopping around in the water.

Has a charm all of its own. Whilst I loved this theatre my husband fell asleep - but that could be due to the fact we had been touring for almost four weeks and it was the end of another busy day! The audience could follow the story from the programme provided, it was colourful, clever and certainly different from any other puppet show you're likely to see. Dragons breathing fire, cats running up tree trunks, birds, soldiers, boats, dancers - every type of puppet appeared from behind the screens and the puppeteers took a bow at the end of the performance. The two lady singers and the musicians add to the atmosphere and should have kept my husband awake!

Sweet tradition. I wasn't initially that interested in seeing this show but I'm glad I did. It 's not too long & not being able to speak Vietnamese isn't an issue if you're familiar with story telling. It's something quit unique. I loved the musical instruments & even the singing.There were several kids watching & they loved it as well.

Just wonderful. This old form of puppetry is so unique and all done in water with great band. Get the cheap seats so you sit with the Vietnamese as they just love it and it greatly adds to the enjoyment.

Great show and music, cramped seating. The music and water puppet show was wonderful. Yes, the water does smell dreadful. No English subtitles, but you get the idea from the feeling of the music and what the puppets are doing. The seating was the worst part of the show--I felt cramped, but my husband's legs couldn't even fit in the seat! They really pack you in like sardines, and if you have someone tall sitting in front of you, you'll only see about half of the show.

Fun. You just have to go and see this, it is part of the Hanoi experience. The water when I went smelt a bit so I immediately felt sorry for those working the puppets. The show was well put together with short scenes and the usual (awful) singing but nice music. Some of the scenes were really funny such as the chicken with the egg. Suitable for children too if you explain that this is a different type of puppet theatre.

Great show. Loved the puppet theatre. Don't miss it. I was amazed to see how many people attended the show. The theatre was completely full and when we left a crowd was descending for the next show. Don't be put off by the crowd. The tickets are seat numbered and the turnaround is so fast. Loved it
Interesting show... Interesting show.. Too bad the show was done in Vietnamese though. Otherwise, we would've enjoyed it more.

Very nice show!. I always like to visit the touristic and the local sites, restaurants and activities. If you are in Hanoi for the first time, visit the Water Puppets. Read about them before you go, so you understand the significance of the representation. it is a very nice activity to do in the late afternoon!

Loved it! So impressive!!!. This show was fantastic! We were often on the edge of our seats trying to see how they were moving the puppets! Very impressive what they have the puppets doing, totally recommend going. You are given seat numbers so perhaps book ahead for your show so you can be front and centre.....you have to pay a fee to take photos but nobody looks to monitor this, however it's quite dark and you don't want to be rude to others by taking photos.....

World famous Puppets. The talented puppeteers make for an interesting show, which last for about 45 minutes. Much loved by the Vietnamese, but the show a little hard for tourists to understand. However, a fun thing to do while in Hanoi.

A relaxing show. One of the activities in Hanoi to attend .Seating is very comfortable , price is 5$ for a 45minutes show,full of creativity and talent. Nice music, it puts you in the atmosphere of old tales and songs.The impression we had it sounded more Chinese than Vietnamese .A recommended activity.

Well worth a visit. Have never seen anything like this before so it's worth a visit. It's about an hour long and that's perfect. Traditional stories and music. A pleasant was to relax and spend an evening

Fun Excursion for Kids. We went with a family that included a 75-year-old, a 19-year-old, a 5-year-old, and a 1.5-year-old, and everyone had fun. Admittedly, the music -- which is like Chinese opera -- is not for everyone. Perhaps it is because I am Asian, but I like listening to traditional music every now and then. Our 1.5-year-old, who loves music generally, started dancing in my lap as soon as the music and show started, and was riveted. She did not fuss at all. Our 5-year-old likewise was fascinated and talked about it in detail when we got home. She even remembered details that my wife and I did not remember/see. Even my 19-year-old nephew found it interesting how they could operate the puppets in water. Again, because we have small kids, a 50 minute show was probably just the right amount of time. The chairs are a little cramped, and perhaps one could say that the ticket price (100,000 VND) is a little expensive. But given that water puppetry does not really exist outside of Vietnam, I think it is worth the experience. One final tip -- get tickets early (your hotel should be able to help with that).
Dissapointing. It was very amateurish and not so interesting. Maybe if we understood folk Vietnamese songs it would have been worth to see...

A very pleasant experience. I enjoyed the performance. Seating is comfortable and everyone seemed to have a good view. The music was beautifully presented and lyrical.The puppetry was most skilfully performed in short scenes. It didn't matter that I didn't always understand the stories, the puppets were charming and there was great activity and extraordinary explosive movement. An hour was just about right.
Worth the visit. An experience to be sampled although with all the audience taking photos/videos with mobile phones etc make sure you get a good seat at the front

Not recommended the way it is now. While the show may have been wonderful the audience kept taking pictures and videos of the whole production. With people taking videos with an ipad, its very hard to see the show. I think that the management should limit the use of audience cameras during performances especially non-stop videos.

lots of fun,. The puppet show was a lot of fun, many thoughts of "how do they do that"...............don't know why it's not been brought to
the states. good show.

Amazing. How do they operate the puppets in the water? This is quite spectacular and at 100000dong good value. For an extra 60000 you can video the show. Small puppets can be purchased for 80000dong after the show. The musicians are also good. Try to get a seat at the front if possible.The show lasts nearly an hour and includes fish, dragons, warriors and water buffalo.

Interestintg despite language barrier. The tickets soldout like a hotcake!! The staffs from the hotel we stayed help us to purchase the tickets in advance. The show consists of different story line - more like a little musical using water puppet. I have to say they were very good and did amazingly well. The only unfortunate part of the show was the language - it's in Vietnamese language and I'm sure it will be even better if we are able to understand the story line.The condition of the theater can be improved. A tip for those with long legs, you will have a challenge sitting on the theater seats as it's pretty small and squeezy. But they do have option to allow you to sit by the side of the stair so you have more leg room!!!Must go for a visit!!

Vietnamese culture through puppets. We had a fun time watching the water puppetry in Hanoi. In the beginning I thought it would be soooo touristy and a little boring (because we had watched the Barong Dance back in Bali and that seemed a tourist trap to us), but it turned out to be only very touristy and not boring at all. It takes only 40 minutes, and it has a good rithm, with 12 or 13 acts. Its rather very interesting because we could see aspects of Vietnamese culture through the spectacle.Be prepared though because it's very cramped, so if you're tall you will struggle with the absence of leg room.
Different. We went to the show not knowing what to expect, it was an enjoyable 50 mins, very clever how it's done,

Very clever use of design of puppets, music,lights. Well choreographed,good talent in design, making and using puppets. Entertaining show, included some history and we enjoyed the musical segments too. Seating is crammed and a bit hard. We will see it again on our next visit!!
Not to be missed. Brilliant fun and the skill of the puppeteers is extraordinary. Interesting music but authentic ! Small theatre with good views of the stage from wherever you sat.

OK on a wet Hanoi day. At 100k VND each (+20k for camera-30k for video) it is ok for a wet day in Hanoi. 45 mins of water puppetry with Vietnamese soundtrack and music. Photos are almost impossible as it is dark and the puppets are fairly small. We sat on E11/E12 and could see ok - I am 6'1" and could sit ok too. At this price worth a look?
Water Puppets. A very interesting concept. I enjoyed it at the beginning but the dragons and the fish section went for too long.
All songs are in Vietnamese. If you haven't seen a show of similar sort then I would strongly recommend this show. Bizarrely entertaining and clever how they operate the puppets.

Brilliant. This was a truly unique experience.
We weren't sure what to expect. The show is only 45 minutes long and although it is in vietnamese you can get the gist of the story.
This is typical to the North of Vietnam so a must see it if you visit Hanoi.

An Hour of my Life I Can Never Get Back. First, my wife loved the show. Unfortunately, I went to it. The smell of the theater reeked of some unknown rancid odor. The "music" was a cacophony of noise that could make one appreciate the subtleties of Bartok. Unless you're in the first two to three rows, forget about seeing the water. The puppets were cute, but the overall effect, with the unrelenting noise, was awful.Worst part of the performance - the idiots in the audience who took videos or flash photos the whole night! I know why it's not allowed at home. It's just not civilized

Lame. It might be a typical thing to Hanoi, but it is not for me!They perform 5 shows a day to all of the tourists visiting the area and it shows as well: bored stiff and uninterested performers.Theatre is not comfy at all: I am of average height and even i could not sit comfortably. Imagine my friend who is almost 2 meters!Nope watch it on youtube and you have seen it as you can ff it all

A novel experience which provies a sense of the culture. This show is well performed with a clear program explaining each scene and it's tradition. The theatre has a good rake so that one can see from any seat. It is a different art form and very professionally done. Well worth the visit to this unusual performance.

Excellent show, but only in Vietnamese and small sits available. We really enjoyed this 45 minutes show that projected us in the Vietnamese culture. Unfortunately the show is in Vietnamese only and being it based on songs that tell the story represented by the water puppets, we could not completely appreciate the meaning of it. Please note that the sits are for 'vietnamese' people and therefore if you are more than 170 cm you could have some problems in sit comfortably (I am 193 cm and had serious difficulties in accommodating my knees in the small sit provided). If you are tall you might prefer to ask your guide to provide you sits in the first line.
A bit disappointing.... Perhaps if we had gone with a young child, it would have been worthwhile to see the Water Puppet show. For us, it was amateurish and not very interesting.
Lively Puppet. Is my 2nd time and they have new puppets and interesting stories which I really admire the artist behind the show. Lots of tourist from over the world, Japan,Korea, US, Europe

Fascinating 45 minutes. Even when the Chinese Opera-like caterwauling commenced, I remained charmed by this traditional puppet show. Puppets splashing water, the most realistic fish water ballet I've ever seen, and fire breathing dragons that emerge from the water are sights not to be missed.

A facinating experience not to be missed. The show was well worth seeing with the music and singing performed by various players. The show itself was cleverly performed and lasted just under one hour.The was a rooftop restaurant nearby with great views of the lake and the food was ok. Can't remember the name but can't miss it as a you lady was touting for business just outside.

A nice spectacle. The whole performance is in Vietnamese so we didn't have a clue what was going on, but the puppets were skillfully worked and the live music gave an authentic feel to the performance. We purchased some puppets after the show and these were much appreciated by our grandchildren.

Different form of entertainment. It takes a lot of skill to manoeuvre the puppets in the water that quickly and adeptly, using bamboo sticks and ropes, while standing in the water. Although I admire these skills, I found the show to be boring as it is not my type of entertainment. A few people left the show midway, while a few others fell asleep. I kept awake and watched the entire program and there are parts that are spectacular to watch.There is an extra fee to pay for a permit to take photos, which I paid. There is no enforcement and I suspect a few people took photos without paying the fee, but that is for the theatre to sort out.

Something to see maybe once??. I went to a showing at the Water Puppet Theater a few weeks back. It was for the most part packed and I understand that it is a big tourist attraction here. As another reviewer noted, seating quarters etc. are somewhat tight. I have no idea if they have an elevator. If they do not, you need to be able to navigate stairs for sure. The water puppet theatrics were somewhat interesting to me but what I liked more was the traditional Vietnamese music that accompanied the show. I thought that was quite entertaining being somewhat of a music kind of guy. This is one of those attractions to Hanoi that is worth doing once in my opinion but I also am objective enough to understand if others would want to go more often. The cost is reasonable by all means. Now I can say "Been there done that."
Amazing experience. This was a truly amazing experience. We did not know what to expect and we were so surprised how professional and unique the show was. You really must see it if you visit Hanoi.
Brilliant 'must see'. Colour, humour and music brilliantly presented. However, it is booked very quickly so on the first day of your arrival make sure you book a slot for your stay.

Thang Long Water Puppet Theater-Hanoi. We visited this theater during TET but the crowd were mostly tourists. We were Lucky to have a seat on the first row ( reserved by our guide of Indochina Odyssey Tours ) On the left of the water-basin, on an elevated podium, a Vietnamese band is accompanying the puppet-performance which content is a mixture of Vietnamese legends such as the Magical Sword given by the Gods to the emperor to defeat the Chinese invaders . After the war the emperor was rowing on the Hoa Kiem Lake when a turle appeared and took the sword back to the Gods.This legend and scenes of the daily life in the countryside of the North are the main topics of this show which is a real feast for the eyes. The puppets are controlled ( by puppeteers ) through a rod dancing on the greenish water of the basin.Dragons glide over the water, phoenixes mate , ducks play with balls sending sprays of water all around, fish are jumping and frogs make happy leaps . The 8 musicians play their instruments while 2 ladies sing and give narratives. Really a fantastic and magical performance very much appreciated by the audience.
Very cute. Very cute original type show. Easy to see, even with a crowded theater. The seats are very very close together, so if you are tall request an aisle seat or a side seat.

Different but wouldn't go again. Unless you have really good seats at the front it is not worth going. We found it interesting to begin with but then got a bit bored with the same thing. Live music which again was nice to hear in the beginning but then grated a bit. Obviously everyone has different tastes and some people would love it but unfortunately was not our thing.

Unique - so worth a visit. I reflected for some time whether this had been worth seeing. It was. It's only an hour and it is truly unique. Yes, it is boring in parts but some of the puppets are very amusing and the music makes it interesting.

alright. Nice show to watch.. sometimes a little too much for my opinion. my friend fell asleep during the show but all in all it was intersting to watch it to get to know that side of vietnamese culture..

Not to be missed!. Firstly, i recommend to book your tickets in advance. When i went to ticket office, they were already fully booked for that same day and the next one - for luck i spent few days in Hanoi so was not a problem. The show lasts about 1 hour and i do not think is too much tourist's thing as i saw the 30% of guests were vietnamese (maybe not from Hanoi city...) This water puppies show based its roots in the ancient traditions of common people, so it acts the everyday activities plus mithes of pleasants. Chorus was great, absolutely...I found it very interesting and i went out excited at end of show! Is more than an attraction.. It's a work of art!Not to be missed!If taking seats in first lines you will be very close, but can happen you get wet ;-) just few drops not a thing to worry about! Anyway they advise about this on their brochure.

What a fantastic and interesting show!. We had never attended a water puppet show, and for the first 20 minutes We could not figure out how the puppets were moving about in the water. The singers and musicians were excellent. After a while we gave up on trying to figure out how things were done and just enjoyed the show. This show is for kids of all ages and captivates your attention and interest right to the end of the performance. This is a MUST when visiting Hanoi.

A bit crowed, but such fun!. Watch the musicians and singers as much as the puppets!! They sing and say all the words of the puppets and their expressions are priceless. The musicians use instruments that we westerners have never seen or heard. All wonderful!!
A different sort of theatre.. Worth a visit . My group members found it be worth the effort to come back to visit the the Water Pupper theatre.

You have to take an hour out to see this. The Water Puppets are a little kitsch gem half way along the west side of the Northern Lake in Hanoi. Akin to a very wet Punch and Judy presentation though telling the stories of Vietnam with some excellent backing music and voice. For 100 VMD (around 3GBP) you can have a smile and see traditional puppetry though all done in water.Best advice is not to sit in the front row.
Didn't know what to expect but it was great. very entertaining, it will make you think , "how did they do that". Worth the trip since you will not see anything quite like it elsewhere

Water Puppet Show. A water puppet show where the audience is nearly all adults and tickets are difficult to get. At the change between two shows you see a crowd going out and another coming in. This would tell you of the popularity of the show.A good show enjoyable to see puppets performing on water moved around with bamboo rods under water.

Booooooring. Ok, it was interesting to see puppets in the water but very boring- 40 minutes seemed a lifetime for a show. However, you will listen to typical folk musicI (around 14 original items) and see some special effects (poor ones though). Honestly I almost fell asleep in the theater. Seats were very tight. I had the impression that at the end everyone was dying to leave the theater.
Really touristic and boring . We went to the show at 4pm and really though it was bad. We felt like in a tourist factory and the show itself lacked any interest.

Enjoyable and hilarious!. Hilarious water puppet show, I had such a good laugh on my last night in Hanoi! Do purchase your tickets hours in advance in order to secure the better seats in front. Duration of the show is approx 60mins.

Unique and enjoyable. We loved the water puppet performance here! It was totally different to anything we'd seen before. The singing and music were exceptional and the performance lots of fun! Highly recommended while you are in Hanoi! That said, it is a VERY popular tourist attraction, so be prepared for lots of people, both while buying tickets and in the theatre.

Very entertaining and unique show.. We had good seats for an afternoon show and were thoroughly entertained by the puppetry. Even though we don't understand Vietnamese, we could appreciate the skills of the puppeteers and the stories conveyed through the actions of the puppets. We found the show very entertaining and certainly worth viewing.

You have to be open to a cultural experience. Please don't get me wrong by the title of this review; but you have to be open to enjoying Vietnamese traditional singing which to me sounded like the worst entry off a talent show TV programme.The water puppet operators are very skilful and extremely patient doing this show 4 or 5 times a day, and the music is good. Unfortunately the singing wasn't for me after a day in the heat and being tired.
It's so fun. The show is really fun. It's amazing how the pupetters can handle the puppets. As is a musical anyone can understand the show.Sure you will laugh with the liveliness. Do not miss
Hanoi puppet theater. The Thang Long Water Puppet Theater is well worth a visit it is the only one in the world and quite unique

Unique once in a life time experience. Have never seen such a production and certainly worth seeing more than once. Make reservations as early as possible as it is very popular and closer that you are to the front is best.For singles, couples, families, children and grandparents...

good show, don't miss it!. we enjoyed a very good puppet show, with live music and a story about vietnamese legends and traditions, with the giant turtle receiving the sword from the king and giving it back to the gods, the phoenix, dragons and fishers catching jumping fishes. Water puppet theater is a must in Hanoi and the entrance is not expensive at all. They have about 4 or 5 shows a day.

Something different. very colourful, interesting show. they give you a program in your language so you can understand whats going on. Definitely worth seeing as its very unusual and fun. have to pay extra if you want to take pictures but it doesn't seem to be enforced once you're in there, and unless you have a really good camera the pictures don't turn out great, so don't think its worth paying it.
Touristy, but interesting. Its definitely a place for tourists, but was still really beautiful and worth a visit if you have time.

Pure exquisite fun. Hanoi was cold so decided to go in doors to see puppet show on a whim. Hotel walked across and got us tickets and we just pottered in and where absolutely delighted. It was just 45 mins but so clever and funny puppet show of life on the river.

Charming - brought out my inner child!. I'd rate this a 'must see'. The puppeteers are skilled, many of the stories (there are 14 items) will make you smile, so just sit back and indulge your inner child. Performances last about 45 minutes and probably worth booking tickets in advance. My only complaint was the number of tourists taking photographs throughout the performance. There is supposed to be a charge but doubt whether any of the iPhone flashers had paid it. Shame on you. Put your phones and cameras away, please!

Good!!. This is first time I have visited Hanoi. My first choice was Water Puppet, I was really surprised by the show. It's very attractive and different. However, I think it's too long, no leg space if you r tall and it made me tired. Anyway, I hope there will be something special in the next timeThanks.p/s sorry if my E is bad :D

Good but there are space for improvement. The puppet show experience is a good experience for us but the company definitely need more management for their show. We bought a seated ticket for the show, somehow when the show start they let more and more people into the room and we are forced to switch our seat just to fit in those people. Another thing that i notice when watching the show, when you walk through the door there will be people actually getting payment from you for the purpose of taking photos or video during the shows. I did not pay for it but still able to use the camera freely in the show (without flash) which make me feel like it might be a scam for those people to get payment from us.overall it is still a pretty good experience and the show is fantastic!
A must if you visit Hanoi. Real entertainment Vietnamese style, excellent puppetry and well worth the money-buy tickets ahead for performances to make sure you get a seat.

Yawn! Save your money!. This was really boring sad to say. Children might enjoy it, but I didn't feel it was entertaining enough for adults. The first two minutes is just repeated for the next 20 minutes with different puppets.

Good (but english translation will help). Presentation of show is superb....Kids will enjoy for sure. An english script will help people to understand exactly what is happening, apart from the visual assumption.
Worth seeing if you have time. The show was entertaining, but I'm glad it was only 45 mins and not longer! Beware- no leg space if your a tall Westerner!
Kids Love It!. My kids really enjoyed the water puppet show. It is a fun family outing…not expensive and not too long. Get seats as close to the front as possible!

Professional Band. For $3, this is pretty good entertainment. The show is about 45 minutes long and I had seen enough after about 15 minutes, but my husband enjoyed the whole thing. It is a nice cultural experience and the band, singers, and puppeteers were good at what they do. It would be nice to understand the language, but the stories are easy to follow. We were a little late getting into the show. It was dark, crowded and there was very little leg room.

Unusual Vietnamese theatre tradition but a little goes a long way.... Fascinating technique, almost absurd, and the live musicians are probably the best part of this experience, but the story lines are...simple, to say the least.

average, yet go-nice folklore. The artists are very very professional. The show is typical to Viet Nam, so it is interesting, but an English translation is really necessary. The show is a bit too childish. In spite of this, go. Cute experience in a very fair price.

Sorta required.... It's something you really just do do while in Vietnam, but this show was actually really cool, and a really interesting insight into this unique artform. I really appreciated that it didn't just feel totally constructed for the tourist experience, channeling 'ancient' 'traditional' 'authentic' Vietnam: the show, which is explained as you go along, actually features contemporary compositions and choreography, and is about more contemporary subject matter. So, in other words, it's a living breathing representation of a living breathing artform. I like that!

Fascinating, colourful and fun.. I was a bit dubious about going to see the water puppets as I find Asian music discordant to my ears but this was fabulous. There is a small orchestra and a large pool of water where all the action takes place. It is very clever and some if the stories are quite funny.Only warning is for tall people - not much leg room.
Well worth it. This is about an hour of great entertainment. The music and singing are really haunting and authentic, and the puppetry very clever. Several shows a day, and very inexpensive.

I was bored after about 10 minutes. The novelty of seeing puppets glide backwards and forwards on water wore thin for me very quickly, but it is very cheap and only lasts an hour. Might be good for kids

Good show, great band.. This is a great show in a very modern western style theatre. It involves colourful puppets being manipulated from underneath the water, very well done. Best part in my opinion - there's a 9 piece live band supplying the oriental style music, very authentic! The show's worth it just to see the band!
Must see. Had to book. 45minutes was about right but something you have to see! Puppets were interesting and music was good.

Great fun!. We thoroughly enjoyed this attraction. It is very cheap (only VND100,000 each - about £3 or $5) and the whole thing is so clever. The puppetry is magical and the musicians are excellent. The one down side is nothing directly to do with the theatre. There were a whole load of people who arrived over 10 minutes late (for a 40 minute show!). That meant lots of people bobbing up and down in their seats to let the latecomers in. Very distracting. What is the matter with people? Don't they have watches?

Wonderful introduction to Vietnam Culture. The water puppet show is an expereince in itself. One would have seen puppet shows on the ground but this one is in water and showcases the culture, tradition and life of Vietnam

Definitely a Vietnamese thing. In my opinion there are good and bad things about the show. it is something I have only seen in Vietnam. It is pretty amazing how the people in the back work the puppets. The show length does get a bit boring but 45 minutes is really not that long. Probably the worst thing is the very, very cramped seating. It is obviously designed for small Asians. To avoid the problem, grab a chair on the far side of the room against the wall. This is the only way to be comfortable if you are a tall or large person. This time was my second show in 5 years and I won't go back. But I think everyone should go once as a part of the Vietnamese experience.

A pretty good night out. We decided to visit the water puppet theatre on our last night in Hanoi. The theatre is easy to find and we paid 200.000 dong for two tickets. We saw a similar show in Ho Chi Minh city but felt that the Hanoi counterpart was far more touristy and less impressive. However if you haven't seen a water puppet performance yet you definitely should take the opportunity to!

Would have better if I had sat on the front. The show was very good what I saw. The seats are granulated a little but it only take the people in front to take photos all the time and then show each other them to block your view.My husband was luckier and so I watched his video. It is very clever and you can follow the story quite easily. Ask for a front seat when booking or one at the back where you could stand up. All tickets have seat numbers on and do occasionally get mixed up.There is a notice that says you need to pay for a ticket to take photos but nobody seemed to take any notice.
Vietnam experience. A very good cultural show. A historical story told with puppets, something different and enjoyable. It goes for just the right amount of time.

Boring. I found this water puppet theatre so boring.If I had any advise it would be not to go.If you decide to go get a seat at the edge of the aisle so you can escape when you feel like it .Trapped in the middle of the rows makes it impossible to exit.
Sadly disappointed. The Water Puppets have a world-wide reputation, but unfortunately we found the show rather amateurish and we were rather disappointed.

Worth going at least once. My children who are 3 and 5 years old enjoyed the show. They even laughed at the slapstick acts and talked about them afterwards. As for me, I thought the singing and the music to be culturally rich. Though I probably wont make repeated visits but I think it was a worthwhile experience.

Worth the visit - touristy. The Water Puppet Theatre is entertaining no matter your age.It gets busy with tour buses so buy your tickets in advance. Seats are assigned. There are two prices - close to the stage and not so close. Don't waste money on the higher priced tickets. We paid the higher price and were about 3/4 of the way back. It seems they just keep selling until the two categories meet.

Weird but really enjoyed it!. Some of the performances etc were a little different but the way the puppeteers control the movement of these puppets is pretty impressive. It's all in Vietnamese so read the list of scenes first (they don't really flow into one another, it's more 'acts' than a story) so you have a clue what is going on. There's fireworks and action (cat catching a duck from the duck boy and quite a chase ensues and a fishing trip (or two) that gets dicey!) - you might not understand it but it's worth the trip. The cheap tickets are right at the back - if you want to take photos (you do need to pay about USD1 for this), get a tickets closer to the front as its quite dark so its hard to get a clear shot from the back.

Authentic Vietnamese Culture. Having read many poor reviews we were concerned it might be boring and whilst it wasn't the most exciting show(compared to Disney), it was definitely traditional fare.Suggest not to do with jet lag as this might be a tad difficult to stay awake but if relaxed and open minded then you should enjoy, and for 5$ not much to lose!!Tip -don't bother with taking pictures unless you are confident they'll come out as it's quite dark.Overall worth a visit.

I really loathed this.. Sorry everyone, but I knew when our travel agent booked us into the water puppet show in Hanoi that I would struggle with it. Perhaps I am culturally bereft in this area. You are jammed into a theatre and can't get out even if you want to. To keep myself amused I spent the hour trying to figure out where the people were for each puppet. Just not our thing I am afraid. They also charged you to use your camera as you went in.

Go to this, you won't regret it!. This was something I could not imagine. Live music along with the performance. And someone to give a summary of the story. I liked at the end when you can see the "puppeteers". Don't miss this one!
Superb show. Don't normally go for puppets and folk tales but this show is rivetting. Pity some clown was allowed to film in front of us

No Spinal Tap, Just Puppet Show. Interesting ancient art, great little theatre and you can buy a puppet to take home. The only drawback was the water was a bit stagnant and so the theatre smelled a bit dank. Show was 45 minutes which was just enough time.

Fun performance. The whole family enjoyed it.. Arrange tickets a day or so beforehand if possible. The evening performances filled up when we were there but the afternoon one was good. We didn't realized that we were buying a more expensive ticket as the lady just told us a price and we paid it. (Apparently, they are different options closer and farther from the stage.) We were close to the front and it was great. The stories were fun and you were able to follow along based on the titles in the program. All four of us loved it and would recommend it to anyone. A fun escape too from the hustle and bustle of Hanoi.

Unmissable if you're in Hanoi !. A truly magical show, not to be missed ! We'd been twice on a previous visit to Hanoi and had to take friends to see the show. They were blown away! Lots of " camera action ", but people do want to record the experience, and it's not too distracting . We found the best seats are about half- way from the front.
Another first. A brilliant entertainment very cleverly presented. The music and singing was enchanting, and although we could not understand the language the story was clearly visible.

Hard to describe. If you haven't seen a water puppet show, this is a must see. If you have seen them before, even if it was in a different country, then you probably don't need to go unless you really like them because they are all pretty similar according to other tourists that I've talked to.
Unique - beautiful music. Beautiful music! Make sure you go look at times early, because it fills up fast. We ended up getting end seats, not together.

Bordering on a "tourist trap". I will be honest and tell you we fell asleep 2/3rds through the show! I just had the impression coach loads of people were being herded in and out for each performance. The music was excellent, the puppetry very clever and I'm sure hard work, but it just didn't do it for us. Perhaps some more detailed explanation rather than "3. Dragon's Dance" would have stirred our souls to greater heights!

Great show, but annoying audience. The show is great, funny, skilful, entertaining. If only the place would not let people come in late - they let people come in even though the show been going on for 15 minutes. So when somebody sitting in the middle of a row arrived late the row stood up and blocked the view for those sitting behind. Rude foe the artists in my opinion. Would definitely go again if I knew that latecomers would not be allowed in and there were a no photographing policy (the flashlights disturb a lot)

fantastic. I had never heard of water puppetry before going to Hanoi, I read about it in the lonely plant and was intrigued enough to be talked into in by a ticket salesman. And I'm very glad I was! The show is magical and perfect for kids, also traditional vietnamese music which was excellently played.

Unique and Awsome performance. I think this show must be one of its kind in the field of puppetry.Very captivating in every respect.The costume of musicians,poise ,musical instruments and ofcourse the vocal as wellas instrumental music is amazing and topnautch.Not knowing the language is no bar to enjoy the music.The 14 acts presented are all very interesting,colorful and at times hilarious.The puppets are played in flawless manner and one wonders how are they being played.A value for money and time show indeed and must do when in Hanoi.

Interesting Experience. Great way to experience vietnamese history. The effort that goes into these shows are incredible. 45 minutes was a little long as we are westerners and the entire show is in vietnamese but would still recommend having a look.
Very entertaining. We were surprised by the way they handled the puppets and you do not have to know the language to appreciate the show.
Really Brilliant. Although I had wanted to see the show my wife was very reluctant. However she was totally entranced at what was totally unique experience. Really is a must see.

Not very interesting if you aren't into theater.. While I think the music was very good and the puppetry was good I didn't care much for this attraction. Even though many people say it is a must do I wouldn't recommend it unless you are into theater or shows.

Nice way to spend a night. It's not in English but I don't think that matters the show was still well done. The only thing that was annoying was the people using iPads to record and take photos in front of me blocking the view book as mans days in advance as to get a better seat for 100 dong well worth it
A children's show. Great if you have kids. But it doesn't merit going without them. An amateur puppet show in Vietnamese.

Traditional Vietnamese Show. This water puppet show is very close to the lake in old quarter. The show is about 45 minutes and the ticket is 60,000 VND. It's a must visit place when you visit Hanoi. Good experience for you. I didn't buy ticket in advance, I just bought ticket on the spot before the show time.

It's an experience. Even tho, I dont quite understand the show, due to the language barrier
But its an experience that you dont want to miss.

Colorful and full of history. Really, some people should just stay at home.(previous reviews). These people train for up to three years to master these 15kg puppets. It is rich with history and the music speaks of many fables and stories. Although I didn't fully understand the story it was very easy to appreciate the wonderful atmosphere it created. The players certainly enjoyed their presentation.Highly recommended.

Amatuerish. Oh dear, oh dear. What a dreary boring show with lots of banging and thumping from the 'orchestra' at the side of the stage. I've seen better at Blackpool and that's saying something. BUT it's only £3 (and they're the expensive seats) so if your backside is aching from all that walking round in Hanoi, it's a cheap 45 minute rest. And trust me, you'll keep checking your watch til the lights go up when you can escape.

A witty, colourful and highly entertaining folk show.. It's easy to be a bit cynical about the folk/culture shows one comes across as a tourist, but this one really is a bit special. As we understand it, the water puppet shows were started centuries ago by the farming communities of Vietnam to provide some entertainment for the locals. This tradition has continued into modern times and is now offered for visitors at the Thang Long Puppet Theatre.The theatre has comfortable seating and everbody has a good view of the watery "stage" . The musicians are seated on a (dry!) platform to the left of the stage, providing accompaniment to the puppets on a range of traditional musical instruments. The show consists of a series of short performances from a wide range of puppet characters, playing out a selection of traditional water puppet performances. We had, for example, fire breathing dragons, rice planters, dancing fairies and Unicorns. Each performance was colourful, witty and brilliantly executed. The whole show is a little masterpiece of folk entertainment. I would thoroughly recommend paying the theatre a visit if your time in Hanoi allows it.

Very charming!. This was my first time watching any water puppet show, and I enjoyed watching this charming performance at the Thang Long Water Puppet Theater. It amazed me to watch the water puppets gliding seamlessly through the waters with such lifelike actions, and the English translations helped a lot in my understanding of what was going on as everything is, of course, narrated in the Vietnamese language.If you have the time, I recommend going to see this traditional form of Vietnamese entertainment (and it's definitely not just for children!).The price was 100,000 dong per person for a Type 1 ticket (I imagine this was for better seat tickets, and I did get to sit in the first ten rows from the stage) and 60,000 dong per person for a Type 2 ticket. If you want to take photos during the performance, it costs around 15,000 dong and more for recording a video.

A fun national art form. We were dubious about going to this show, but when we learned that the tradition migrated from the 16th century courts to performances in village rice paddies, we decide to go and were glad we did. It was quite entertaining and more than worth the $5 ticket. The music was played on traditional instruments and the singing was also very much in a traditional folk style, so that was all interesting. But the skill of the puppeteers was the best part.

Show is awesome. 45 min show is really nice !but, disturbed a lot by the theatre allowing FLASH photography, very disturbing, just like Tripadvisors ads, always bullying their ways in my ways to see hotels, etc, really HATE tripadvisor for this !Know your place Tripadvisor !!!Anyhow , this is a great little show, stop allowing people to come in late, stop allowing pictures to be taken !!!

This will blow your MIND!. You MUST see this show. It is probably one of the most interesting things I have ever seen. The way the pupputs move and the way the puppet masters manipulate everything from snakes to dragons will impress the heck out of you! -
Time Waster. Boring folklore puppet theatrical show in vietnamese songs and dialogueNothing spectacular or fancifulPer title, a time waster. Go for it if you just want to pass time, 45 mins iirc.

Highly novel show. We loved it! It's amazing! Really unusual way of displaying traditional rural life. Highly skilled puppeteers keep you delighted and amused throughout and after, you can wonder round the display of puppets.

Touristy but fun. Inexpensive and family friendly. I didn't know what was going on in the story in each scene but the puppets were visually entertaining.
I would recommend this to those that have never seen a water puppet show which was in my case.

Something different. A very clever theatre that will appeal mostly to children, and the kid in all of us. The stories are easily followed but it is the way the characters are controlled that is very interesting

An Absolute "Must See". A truly beautiful presentation of the mythological origins of the Vietnamese people. The technology of the water puppets is brilliantly simple and effective. Visually beautiful. Book at least a day ahead as most performances are fully booked.

Really well done, and surprisingly charming. Small seats (think economy on a discount carrier), tiered so no problem seeing. Show was less than an hour and comprised of 14 brief water puppet shows depicting traditional folk stories. The puppets were great, easy to see (in spite of being puppets). Some of the stories were funny and all were charming. They were accompanied by Vietnamese (duh) singing and traditional instruments - not my favorite music, but what else for a Vietnamese traditional puppet show?? (Lonely Planet has a boxed page explaining more about the water puppet performance and tradition. We found it very helpful)About mid way I noticed that the only two doors to the (upstairs) theatre are next to one another. If there were a fire it would be.... Still, I'd go back - it was great!

If in Hanoi do not miss this!. This is an extremely popular attraction for foreigners and Vietnamese alike.Located in the heart of the tourist district of Hanoi by the lake.The theatre is not large therefore either go with a tour group of book as far ahead as possible to ensure entry at your desired time.It can be a bit chaotic around the entry doors at showtime as the previous show empties out and the next audience prepares to enter. Seats are designated so inside its not to bad whilst everyone gets seated.The water puupet show is performed by a group of puppeteers wearing waders and hidden behind screens. To the left there is an traditional Vietnamese Orchestra and singers. The puppets peform on an artificial lake in front of a traditional Vietnames building.The show is spellbinding. Do not miss.

Puppet show. Booked to go to puppets not knowing what to expect it turned to be a great show ,it was a inexpensive and lasted about 50 min it was colourful and funny in places all round a great show . Book and pay before the session for good seats ,enjoy a coffee after in the coffee shop next door .

Unique cultural show & great for kids. We included the Water Puppet theatre show in our itinerary as we were travelling with our 5 year old son. He really enjoyed the show. The live music and various water puppets retelling Vietnam's history was very interesting. Personally I found it a bit long but that could also be because i just travelled 18 hours and then started my tour right away.I recommend if you want to experience something unique to Vietnam.

Tourist snapshot of traditional theatre. A brief 45 minute show giving an insight into the traditions of Vietnamese puppetry. Aimed at tourists. Small theatre, always full. Need to book tickets a few days in advance. Inexpensive but try to get seats near the front as can be difficult to see.

Not everyone's cup of tea but definitely worth doing. Water puppets are an important part of the folk heritage and this is reportedly the best place to see them. Other reviews can give the logistical basics...note it sells out, so grab tickets early in your stay. I loved it, and it was one of the few places to hear traditional music -- both singing and instrumentation. The music stays with you and the skill is way higher here than the other places I caught snippets. It's only an hour -- a very worthwhile investment of time to get closer to the culture.
Traditional Entertainment. We enjoyed the show - water puppets were cool. Great entertainment and not expensive. A very nice theatre located in the Old Quarter.

fun for adults. I went as part of a group tour. I am not sure I would have went on my own, but I am so glad I did. The seats are small but luckily I could stretch out on the aisle. The music and singing stayed with me on my Vietnam trip. The puppets and stories were amusing and original

Very good show. The show took place in a small, tiered theatre. We sat towards the back and could still see perfectly. The seats were not designed for 'westerners' so there was not much leg room, but this did not impact the show at all. Although all of the singing was Vietnamese, the puppetry allowed us to get the gist of the story line. The show we watched covered all of Vietnamese culture. Overall this show was excellent, a must see in Hanoi!
I didn't want the show to end. Get your tickets early as it sometimes sell out. This is a fabulous fun show and a must see in Hanoi

Interesting. It's is an inexpensive way ($5) to spend about an hour and get a taste of traditional Vietnamese puppet theater. A live band made up of traditional instruments accompanied the puppet show where all the action takes place in/ on a lake. The puppeteers are all waist deep in water behind the scenery working their magic. It's a cool thing to see but didn't blow me away.

Worth seeing once. It's not riveting or cutting edge, but it is one of those cultural things that are worth doing while in Hanoi. It's about $5 and lasts less than an hour, so it's worth catching a show if you have time. The music is very traditional and the puppets are old-fashioned, but I suppose you get to see something that was popular over the years and specific to Vietnam.

Go if you want a cultural experience. Like others, a visit to this Water Puppet Theater formed part of our tour of Vietnam. It's basically one of those far east cultural experiences that you get offered if you travel this way. It seems to be very popular. Personally, it was not to my taste and I found myself nodding off on several occasions. However, some members of the party found aspects of it highly hilarious and I do appreciate that such shows rely on visitor support to keep the art-form alive.

A strange and interesting experience. Water puppets are at least unusual and are probably unique to Vietnam. The puppets in this show are traditional in form. They are operated from behind a screen, as one would expect, and the show takes place in a large pool within the theatre, accompanied by a small orchestra playing traditional Vietnamese instruments, which they do with skill and accomplishment. Two of the girls attached to or in the orchestra also provide songs and other accompaniments to the scenes. The show itself consists of a sequence of short sketches dealing with aspects of Vietnamese country life, history and mythology. It would have been nice to have had, or to have been able to buy, explanations of the backgrounds to the scenes, even though a few were obvious. The show is well choreographed, and puppet handling, accompaniments, etc, are all done to high standards and seem to have been rehearsed/practiced thoroughly. This type of show is probably not something that one wants to see more than a couple of times but, equally, it is certainly well worth visiting.

Worth checking out. The show was really nice to watch and it was intriguing so see the way the puppets move around the pond. The show is not in English however so it is hard to follow at some points what is actually going on.
dont miss it. amazing spectacle, and very Vietnamese. We went to see the water puppets in other places in Vietnam too -

Puppets in water - why?. The puppet theatre was part of our Hanoi tour, and frankly I have to ask "why"?I'm sure it's really clever operating puppets when partially submerged in a metre of water, but if it wasn't for the amazingly disinterested girl playing the one-stringed fiddle, and the commissioners on all exits, I would have walked out even sooner.

Interesting experience. If you like cultural shows in general, you'll probably appreciate all that goes into pulling off this show. The precise coordination, the well-rehearsed cues, the music, the singing etc. But what makes this special and different are the water puppets. That's not something you see everyday, and is easily worth your 5 bucks. The theater is located just next to the Hoan Kiem lake, and if you're in Hanoi you're somewhere around this area anyway. They have shows starting every hour or so, hence you can easily catch one if you're around.Now to the problematic bits...there should be a ban on recording in the theater, or people can pay extra to get a DVD of the show. Because what happens is there are always a bunch of people holding handicams above their head in the seat in front of you recording. Or taking big flash photos on their iphones. It can easily ruin the experience if you have someone like that near you. I would also have liked more details about what's going on somehow. Maybe a detailed transcript of the show for non-locals. Or headphones where you can hear the english translation. This is not hugely concerning since without this, you can still make out the overall structure roughly but it would be a great value addition. Lastly, for the seat allotment. I clearly asked the lady at the ticket counter to give me seats as close to the stage as possible and I booked very early relative to the show I wanted to go. But I still got seats 10 rows back! Overall, this still should be a part of your Hanoi tour and you shouldn't miss it.

A Delightful and unique show.. We were intrigued by the history of water puppets when we came across the concept in the ethnographic museum - there is quite a history behind this unique folk art-form. The show is well worth visiting. Apart from the technical wizardry of the puppeteers, I was also interested in and impressed by the virtuoso live band performing on indigenous instruments, and singing. The flautist in particular was a real star, amazing technique.
Just go, nothing to lose. I thought this was an interesting and entertaining show. At 45 mins and the $5 or $10 (I forget) price no reason not to go while you're in Hanoi.

Cultural experience. The show was a cultural experience with traditional music. It was nothing that will blow your socks off but for 5 dollars it was well worth the 50 minute show. During the show there was some talking in Vietnamese but I had no idea what was going on. There is a guide for you to follow the acts, so you can make things up as you want. Its a part of Vietnamese culture and to witness at such a cheap cost was well worth it. I would recommend this while in Hanoi. Don't be alarmed after you buy your ticket and enter the theatre that they charge 1 dollar for you to use your camera during the show.

Honed performance to meet the demands of most visitors?. It's certainly quirky but reflective of Vietnamese culture and without doubt brilliant in terms of technical puppetry. There are six live musicians to observe if the cameo scenes get a bit "samey".Good fun at a sensible price but of quite adequate duration for all but water puppet specialists or aficionados.
Good Day Filler.. Just saw this 45 minute show. We all really enjoyed it. It was very entertaining and a good price. It was great to witness some of the local culture.

Good break from museums.... Very typically Vietnamese and a great experience. Be realistic about your expectations though as it is all in Vietnamese so I just appreciated the live accompanying music, singing and humour conveyed by the puppet. Some of the scenes are dialogue so were less understandable. The show is only 45 mins which is long enough to appreciate it. There are 2 price levels: 60,000vnd ad 100,000vnd. The lady at the ticket booth was totally uninterested in answering any questions and just put us in the front row (which we didn't really want as we'd heard that its the splash zone) and seemed ticked off when we asked to be further back. We ended up in the centre of row 9, which is still in the upper price range, and the seats were great. It's only a small theatre so shouldn't be too many bad seats.People book well in advance, as you can see as the lady flicks through the reservation book, but the 2 of us turned up 2 hours before the show and found some seats.

Sorta Cheesy,. The music was interesting and so was the show. Security is crazy, with a couple of cameras moving on the audience during the show. Its worth the cheap admittance, but its pretty cheesy.
Wonderful. A great treat, especially if you have a small child or you yourself enjoy to see a piece of culture and something unique. It was a great experience.

Do Not Miss. This is my second trip to Hanoi, 15 years later, and this is one thing that I had to see again. I remembered it vividly , and is amazing to see puppets in water. I have never seen anything like this any where else in the world. It is my understanding that this is this show is only performed in Hanoi. The show is about 45 minutes, and there are numerous performances a day

I wouldn't go again. Went to see the 18:30 show and paid 100,000 for first class seats. The main reason I went was that it was recommended and I felt I should see a water puppet show before leaving the country.The musicians/singers were good, the puppeteers were also good but I felt the price was excessive for a 50min show. I also didn't appreciate being video taped for the majority of the performance.There were 14 parts to the show, each lasting <5 mins.It just didn't really appeal to me I suppose.2nd class seats are 60,000, a bit further back and apparently smaller, I'm a slim Westerner so I could probably have sat comfortably in them but I can't be sure.
Not to be missed!. Only the equivalent of $5 for a ticket and well worth it! We booked through our hotel and had no trouble - hour long show so perfect for pre or post dinner entertainment

A bit overrated. I'm not sure this was worth it. Being a foreigner, obviously I couldn't understand what was going on except that there were puppets frolicking around in a pool of water. There were some pretty impressive moments (I remember some fire-shooting dragons) but most of the time you'll be thinking, "this is quaint" and looking at your watch.

The kids liked it.... And so did the Japanese tourist behind me who thought it was ok to lean over me while doing continuous shooting on his SLR. To be honest, if the show had a theme or an overall storyline it would have been a lot better. Vignettes are ok, but not for an hour long show. The six and eleven years olds enjoyed it, the rest of us ended up napping.

An experience like no other. There is nothing else to compare this to, it is a slice of Vietnamese culture not to be missed. You spend much of the time trying to work out exactly how they manage to do many of the movements whilst the puppets are in water. Buy tickets in advance if you want seats near the front.

Entertaining . This is a must see whilst in Vietnam as it really is part of the ongoing history and culture of the country.Cleverly done, (took me a while to figure it out) lots of bright colours and lovely music tooYes it's touristy but so are a lot of west end shows in London!

Unique and fun. The water puppets are a must for every visitor to Hanoi. The puppeteers are hidden behind curtains standing in a pool of water which forms the stage. The intricate puppets take many forms and come alive as they tell folk stories and fairy tales. The traditional music is a bonus. Book through your hotel.
Enjoyed. Nice to see local culture. Very enjoyable and short (1 hour) entertainment. Would recommend visiting. Get tickets ahead of time so you don't get shut out!

Grossly overrated tourist trap. I've had the misfortune to see this show twice and the supremely good fortune to miss out when there weren't enough tickets for sale... If at all, the Water Puppets is a once only experience. Preferably, it's an experience to be avoided at all costs.Almost every single organised tour includes it on the itinerary. My advice - skip it. Really, skip it. Go for a walk, go shopping, go and have a coffee in a cafe on the street and watch the world slip by. The Water Puppets are simply a chunk of time in a tourist trap that you will never get back.You've been warned :-)

Interesting entertainment. Though not suited to us, many local Vietnamese people just loved the show and howled with laughter. This traditional water puppet show is accompanied by local folk music and the story depicts a humorous slant on country life (I think!). Hard to follow for Westerners but the puppetery is amazing.

Cultural experience worth seeing. This type of puppetry is a fascinating artform that has been studied and perfected for generations. That in itself makes it a cultural experience worth seeing.Set to live music, puppeteers work behind a screen to manipulate the movement of puppets through water and they do a great job. If I was traveling with family this would be a perfect activity.Tickets are either 100,000 or 60,000 for further back. Its not a big theatre so distance isnt an issue, the main problem is all the cameras that will be held up in front of you to block your view. You may get wet by accidental splashing but sitting in the first few rows would be my recommendation if you pay 100 anyways.Be prepared to have a camera in YOUR face. Not sure if its common or just a one time thing, but at the 630 show a man with a camera films the audience in a very bright light annoying way and also blocks the view of the band for a brief period. The show lasts for 45 minutes roughly. There is very little distance between rows, so if you are tall like myself be prepared for a little discomfort or sit sideways.

It is a must to feel Vietnam. These are dolls dancing in the water and few musicians playing instruments on the sides. Kind of touristy and not real. However does its job to portray and feel some old culture. It lasts for an hour but it is all the same. So you see the first fifteen minutes ant it is enough.

A Cultural Delight. This was our final attraction to visit on our journey through Vietnam before saying farewell and it didn't disappoint. The colour and creativity was special. We didn't understand the language or singing but they complemented the performance which had us waiting to see what the curtains would reveal next.The puppeteers delivered a wonderful play that left us all smiling as we left.

Splash and funny. Extremly funny and a good idea about the vietnames humor.We saw some of it free in different places in Hanoi and HCMC and enjoied it a lot.Dont miss it, try to get it cheaper without the meal.

A welcome change. My husband & I were thankful that this was included in our 14 day tour of Vietnam & Cambodia; it was truly beautifully done. The puppets and backdrops were colourful and there was a touch of humour in the show. Definitely a show for people of all age groups but especially children. I think they'd be enthralled.

What did I just witness. I had no expectations when arriving at the water puppets, which was a good thing because it was really odd, some parts made me laugh and some of it was well done but by the middle of the show I was bored and wanted to leave but not wanting to be rude I stayed. I guess it's the done thing for tourists but don't expect anything magnificent. The bathrooms were awful and not well looked after, be sure to bring your own toilet paper.

Interesting show. After walking around the lake in downtown Hanoi, we went to the Thang Long theater to watch the water puppet show. The program lasts for about 1 hour. The show itself was pretty basic, but the more interesting aspect of it was how the puppeteers manage to orchestrate all the puppets at the same time. Very good show worth the cost of admission.

Brilliant snapshot of rural Vietnam. This was booked for us by the travel agent, and we were so pleased to have seen it; in fact we are considering another show tonight! The music and puppetry were first class, but what was interesting was how it depicted scenes of rural life and legends of Vietnam, which made it even more appealing. Do not leave Vietnam without a visit!
Worth a splash. Was going to give it a miss but for a few dollars it was worth it. Suit all ages, maybe research the story line in English and I think you would get a lot more out of it.

Very different style of theatre. I didn't know quite what to expect and some of our fellow travellers didn't sound completely keen to see it, but I thought it was charming and completely different than anything we could see at home. The traditional stories were easily followed and I enjoyed seeing the performers come out at the end of the performance.

Kitschy, Cute, But Hard to Follow the Storyline. Hanoi is known for water puppetry, so it's worth going to at least one show. They are an hour long, performed throughout the day, and you can get a second-class seat for only 60,000 dong (about $3). Some of the puppets are beautiful crafts, and I was amazed at how they all appear from beneath the water, without the puppeteer anywhere in sight. I still don't understand the mechanics. It's all in Vietnamese, so don't expect to understand the story, but it's colorful and stimulation to watch.

You don't need to understand Vietnamese. The puppets do all the work for you. It was a good experience in a lot of ways. We saw, and heard, instruments that we did not even know existed played. The singers, musical narrators, were excellent with wonderful voices. The puppeteers were amazing. The show took just the right amount of time as far as our family was concerned.
Unique experience - enjoyable. This was a stop on the way back from a boat trip to Halong Bay. It is fun - very unique and quaint. A nice break from the long ride.

Great show. We saw the water puppet show on our visit to Hanoi. At first I thought I was going to sit through 50 minutes of a show dreading every minute. But we loved it, after it got going it was very entertaining. My 22 month old son was even entertained, he sat through the whole show without fussing.

Very entertaining theatre. Really unique theatre experience. Never seen anything like it before and enjoyed it immensely. My lack of Vietnamese language skills no impediment at all. Was glad we had pre purchased tickets though as queues very long!

Excellent show. I compared this show to the Lotus Theatre, close by on the lakeside , and this one comes out well ahead. Try to get close down to the front rows as once the performance starts there is a crowd of camera being held up on the air potentially blocking your view of the stage. Do not be put off by the box office suggestion that you will get "splashed " at the front, it will not happen. Also the box office just want to give you the seat they decide on with no discussion so be prepared to slow the process down and pick your own seats. Great show from a great tradition. A must to see if in Hanoi.
Wonderful Show of Vietnamese Culture. The music and puppet show are both amazing. I have never seen anything like this before. This is a must see in Hanoi.

Educational and fun. At first it looked like a terrible rip-off, but once seated each scene gets more complex and before long I began to wonder how it was operated. Only downfall was probably the brochure - if it explained the instruments used too it would be good.

Skilled puppetry. This is a unique cultural experience and not to be missed. The show is only about 45 minutes, and inexpensive. There is a rather good traditional orchestra with singing to accompany the short pantomime stories. A brief introduction was given in English, but little explanation is needed. It is fun, ingenious and interesting. I was amazed at the skill of the puppeteers (who stand in water, behind screens) e.g. the handing of a sword from one puppet to another took some dexterity. Thoroughly enjoyable. Just don't expect popcorn and usherettes, plus the seats are styled for Vietnamese-sized bodies!

Never seen before. Traditional Vietnamese show, colorful and visually amazing! Usually included in organized daily city tour, but you can buy a ticket on your own and enjoy the show any time in the afternoon (multiple performances).
Unique. Of course, it's not some phenomenal show. But with the price of US$5, it's worth to spend an hour to experience some national art that isn't offered anywhere else in the world.
good but confusing. I enjoyed the show, but note it is all in Vietnamese so i had to guess what was going on! still an interesting cultural experience
Worth the visit. It was just OK but pleased we visited it. It is on the edge of the lake and the Old quarter so plenty to see and do before and after the short show.

unique. We paid 60,000 dong each for the show. The theater is in front of Hoan Kiem lake. The show lasted for one hour. It would have been better if they had a show with english translations. Some of the puppets need repair. The seats assignment were not followed. The ushers were the ones assigning the seats. They also allow people to come in even if the show already started. The show was okay but the novelty wears off after 20 minutes.
Something different and cute. We anjoy the show, it was something different and new to us.Won't do it again.But nice the first time.

Great activity for kids!. Highly recommend this activity, especially if you have kids, and even if you don't. A very traditional Vietnamese art form (1000+ years). Shows last about 45 minutes - which is a good amount of time. Get your tickets in advance as shows do sell out.
Fun for young and old. Wonderful way to spend an hour in Hanoi. A well organized event. The players show amazing talents in handling the puppets and the life musik adds a good background to the show.

worth a visit!. fun and colourful 50min. busy - so buys tickets as early as possible. my tall partner could not fit in the seat (he is very tall), but they arranged for a chair for him and for other 'larger' visitors. all well in the end. would recommend!

Interesting performance. We took the performance in 45 minutes which cost 5 USd for the first row and it was well worth for that price. It is a very entertaining show - the fish are realistic, I loved the water buffalo, chicken fighting, and the man climbing the coconut tree, - oh and the dragon that flies away! The puppeteers work from behind a screen in waders, standing in the water. Some of the puppets are up to 15kgs and keep several villages outside of Hanoi in work, as they have to be replaced frequently. Live music.
