Get your tickets early!. We were impressed by the live performance and singing. It's quite worth a visit though it gets a little boring in the middle of the show. One important note is that you need to get your tickets early! Try to sit close to the stage for the best view and experience!

show okay, but the singing is beautiful. This would have been more enjoyable experience if they stopped letting people in after the show started. We had seats a couple of rows from the front but were also near the door. It was so frustrating to try and watch the show, when people kept coming in and then walking in front of you to get to their seats. They ended up making people sit in the front rows, which probably is one of the best spots to sit. The door was constantly left open, so light and noise would come in, hubby got up and closed it a few times. The lady in front of me had a big camera and was videotaping the show, but she was holding her camera up high, making it hard for me to see. I ended up asking her to put it down so that I could see the show myself. The show itself was okay, but we are not really into puppets. But the singing was beautiful. The puppets are part of the culture here, it was okay, but one we could have missed and not been worried about it. Reading the programme, made it easier to understand what was happening.

A taste of authentic Vietnamese theatre. The puppet theatre was a classic taste of traditional culture and special effects. The puppetry was complimented by traditional live music played by gifted musicians. The theme of the show was a collection of folk stories and both young and old could easily follow the magic of the story. I would recommend visitor's to Hanoi take the opportunity to view this show as it is an authentic taste of local culture.

Worth a Visit. This is a lot of entertainment for $5. Live music and singing plus the water puppet skits. You can buy tickets in advance (even several days ahead) at their box office. Seats are assigned and your seat number will be hand written on your ticket. The show starts promptly, so be on time.

Brilliant. We managed to get tickets just 5 minutes before the show started and boy am I glad we did. There was an amazing amount of skill shown by the 9 water puppet operators, as well as the 6 musicians who played a range of instruments to complement the performance. I would strongly suggest that you grab a brochue detailing what happens in the show as this would have helped us greatly had we seen in before entering.

Interesting. The puppets are a bit worn out but thats what makes it interesting, one of the puppets keep hitting his eye out every time he beats the drum, it got a black eye on it. It was hilarious. Aside from that, the singing was good, the story shows some history and culture of vietnam and overall it was an ok show that you shouldnt miss.
Really surprised. I went with friends and was expecting a typical tourist show. To my very happy surprise I experienced an authentic treasure of Viet Nam...an entertaining and unusual show.
Cultural Show. A must do to experience Vietnam culture. We had an enjoyable time even though we did not understand the language.

Great cultural experience. Have never seen a water puppet show before. Love the way they manipulate and move the puppets - would have liked an English translation of the stories being performed, but it is fairly simple to follow anyway. Show is inexpensive and around an hour long. Loved the show so much that I went to another one in Saigon.Recommendation - if you want to get good photos book your tickets in advance so you can get seating in the front.
Very good . I when to see the water puppets after my dad said we should go and I really enjoyed the water puppets. I had never seen anything like it before and it is well worth a visit to see

A lovely experience. Here is a bit of culture that would be a shame to miss. For 5 dollars, a beautiful performance in a nice theatre with lots of different stories done by water puppets. The amount of time, about an hour was perfect, and the location is right at the market so you just wander after soaking up sights and sounds, or walk around the lake.

Not just for children. This is very interesting and unique theater. I believe it is only done in Vietnam. The puppets are awesome and the puppeteers put the figures through their paces in a way I've never seen before. All ages will enjoy this.

Watch it if you have not seen it before. What can you expect in this days of computer wizardry and gizmos, this is just a cultural experience. Well, that was what i told myself when the curtain lifted and the show began. And indeed, the water puppet show tried to infuse excitement using lighting effects and pyrotechnics to woo the new generation of audience like me. When you factor these in your expectation, the show comes away as rather entertaining and worthy of watching.Perhaps the show organizer could have a translation in English to deepen the appreciation of the water puppet show.

Different and entertaining. Definitely a must do, since this is a specialty of Vietnam. While the show was done in vietnamese, you do get a program in english and it's mostly visual so you don't necessarily need to understand what is being said.

Exciting!. I usually avoid shows for tourists, but I'm really glad we attended this one. Seeing water puppets in action on such a large body of water is very entertaining. The show is great! My wife liked them so much she bought a water puppet the next day and carried it all the way back to the US!
Entertaining and novel. Despite being in a different language this was a great show which we really enjoyed. The puppets and music were amazing.

You probably haven't ever seen anything like this before. It doesn't seem to be clear how the water puppet tradition developed in North Vietnam, but it involves relatively large puppets being manipulated so they appear to be either walking on or just below the water without the viewers being able to discern the means of manipulation. Worth seeing (once).

A must watch when in Vietnam, but.... We went to watch the show in one of the evenings when we were in Hanoi. Thought it was one of the must do's when in Vietnam. theatre was a bit old and cramped, seats were too small and close together. We enjoyed the live singing and band, but the puppet show got a bit boring as it went on, partly because we couldn't understand the language. Fortunately our ten year daughter enjoyed the show. Overall we thought it was worth watching the show. A definite must see for first timers to Vietnam.

Not just for children. The water puppet show is an old peasant cultural activity for rice farmers. The tales retell folk tales and legends in a fascinating way. The art work of the puppet characters and the extraordinary skills of the puppeteer are outstanding. Sitting in a theater with a pool of water in front of a stage screen, you get a better view down front.

not absolutely spectacular. I do not advise "the famous water puppet theatre - boring, boring, not absolutely spectacular! My husband fell asleep ten minutes after the start of the show.I long tolerated trying to find in this view anything interesting.But finally gave up and I - we left and not waiting for the end of the show.Do not waste your time!
Entertaining. Amazing puppetry! Great entertainment for young and old alike in a huge theatre. Thoroughly enjoyed the drama

Great entertainment for kids. It is a must to see the water puppet show if you are in Hanoi - I saw it 12 years ago and again this year, and both times have been memorable. Most Vietnamese watch a traditional full show in relation to the Tet, but the theater puts together a show with "samples" for tourists. It's 45 minutes and our kids (4, 6 and 10) sat glued to the seats.
Good show. Love the show! It preserved the tradition very well... it would be better if there was subtitling or translation for the words the performers said/sang.

Entertaining. During our recent Asia trip we saw the water puppet show at Thang Long theater. It was well-organized, athough it looked chaotic with several tour bus coming and going. The live band that accompanied the water puppet show performed beautiful and soulful folklore songs. The water puppet show was colorful and my daughter enjoyed it a great deal. There were some quite rude people from the tour in the audience just in front of us, making fun and laughing at the show and it was a good thing when they walked out (but extremely rude in the middle of a performance). Do make sure to check for the time that there are no tours buses. Around dinner time that the audience are there of their own volition, instead of it being part of prepaid tour.

Cute and worth five bucks. The traditional music alone is worth a visit, and the water puppets are cute and better than I expected after reading many of the reviews on this site. Don't waste your money on the photo fee, as I found it unnecessary and took many pictures regardless.

Waste of time puppet show.... Very crowded theatre, all in Vietnamese so we had no idea what the story line was of course. Puppets bounced up and down and all around the water for about 45 minutes. Price was cheap and included in our day tour so we did it. Next door to very good coffee house and across from the lake.
Beautiful. The music is exceptional, seems to be specially written contemporary music and the show was nicely presented in bite sizes so there was always something new happening.
Good Traditional Fun Show. Well worth a visit to this traditional water puppet show, with Vietnamese music and performances - very entertaining

How do they do it?!?. Simply incredible! This is an amazing 45 minute show where puppets in the water enact various Vietnamese stories and leave you wondering how do they do it? Yes, the singing is in Vietnamese but with the wonderful music and the show being very visual, it does not matter. The comedy of some of the stories also translates well for this reason.Having read the reviews re the lack of leg room, when we bought our tickets I explained I was 6 feet tall and asked for appropriate seats. We got the front row which had ample room, and a great view, although looking back it did not seem too bad (I have been in more cramped theatres in the UK!). Wherever you sit the view will be fine anyway. The tickets were 100VND (about £3), there are three or four performances every day (we went at 8pm) and this was my highlight of Hanoi - would definitely recommend and would be good for kids too. Enjoy!

Good for a snooze !. SInce the whole programme was in Vietnamese language we had to guess what was going on...a lot of the audience were nodding off to sleep since it bacame boring after a while...Should be shorter if there is no translation!

Emtertaining. This was a great show. The view from almost every seat was great making the venue good for groups.We chose this venue at the bottom of the lake as it was less crowded and you could head inside and look at the seats before booking.
A Must!. WOW! Naive, childhood entertainment...but soooo enjoyable! I don't believe that there is another show like this one. Don't miss it!

Interesting novel experience. I have always wanted to watch one and it is definitely something that is culturally novel. I mean its puppets on water! It can be quite comical at first but as the show runs over half an hour, it can get quite repetitive after a while. Great novel experience though!

the best puppet show I have ever seen!. If you are going to Hanoi, please don't miss this. It is a little expensive (compared to local prices) but it is so much worth it. the show is really unique. everyone comes out of the show wondering how they did it. What was so pleasant to see is that all the performers (singers not the puppets :-)) looked like they took pride in what they were doing. They were also so good. the show is in Vietnamese - all songs or exchanges but the story is so simple that you can easily follow along.The seats are assigned so try to get one in the front & center a few days in advance. we tried to get for the same day and it was sold out (its not uncommon for shows being sold out so please book early). Also you have to pay extra money (US$1) for the camera. We did it and have no regrets.

Impressive Singing. Love the show. Hate the audience especially kids making silly noise and can't stop talking with the parents. Kids like that shouldn't be allowed at the last show of the day. should be in bed.

Loved it!. The show is awesome. I loved the music and often found myself watching the musicians rather than the puppets! All of the musicians seemed to be really enjoying themselves, they were captivating. The puppet show is great fun, so entertaining. It is a dirt cheap, entertaining and fun experience that I highly recommend. I agree with other reviews that front row seats are the best, however we were in row G and still thoroughly enjoyed ourselves.
Interesting!. I wish I spoke the language so I could have been able to understand but the theatrics were adorable! Good show

Well worth the visit, you gotta see one.. I would've given 5 stars, certainly for the show, but inside the theatre, it was rather warm and smelt of cigarette smoke. As we are non smokers, we ended up with a sore throat. The show itself is great.

Fun show. The show itself was very interesting and well done, the puppetry was relatively flawless. The live traditional music was very enjoyable. The tickets themselves were very reasonable, however you do have to pay extra if you would like to take photos.The seats in the theatre are not designed for westerners, so people with long legs may be a little cramped for space. The theatre was also small enough that you could get a good view wherever you sat.Overall a very enjoyable experience, a definite must when visiting Hanoi.

Well worth seeing. This is a great show. Its colourful and amusing and very clever. Even if you're hard to please the show is only 45 minutes. Yes the rows are a bit cramped but again its only 45 minutes. Its useful to grab a leaflet that outlines each of the scenes so what you're seeing makes more sense. These leaflets are just outside the door as you go in. The location of the puppet theatre is at the top corner of hien kiem lake so easy to find. Ticket prices are ridiculously cheap ($5 for a front row seat). The night shows seem to book out but if you're exploring the old quarter its easy enough to pop in for the 1:15 or 3:00pm shows. Adjoining the theatre there is a good cafe.

Weird. I found this show a little strange but it was entertaining enough and worth a visit if you are in Hanoi for a few days. It's located right beside the lake so is well located. Beware if you have long legs the seats and spacing between the rows is made for people with very short legs. Buy your tickets in advance and get the front row seats if you can.

Not as impressive as expected. After all the positive reviews, we were expecting to see something more authentic and captivating. My son (aged 15) felt asleep and I was glad when the show ended. It was ok but I am wondering if there is a way to attend a more traditional show attended by vietnamese in a village.
Certainly worthwile for young children.

Mixed reaction. All four of us nodded off at some point in the show, it did get a bit repetitive (dragons splashing round and round... fish splashing round and round... boats splashing round and round... then dragons again?) but some of the segments were gorgeous, the water fairies were cute and there was a nice sequence where rice was planted then grew and was harvested. I enjoyed the traditional singing and musical instruments but the seats were small and uncomfortable and at 45 minutes with repetition the show was just that little bit longer than the kids could bear. Maybe if you go early in the day and take some snacks, and make sure you read the pamphlet that comes with the tickets before the show so you know what each sequence is supposed to be about (it would be even better with more translation or someone providing more detailed explanations).

An Old Tradition Well Worth Seeing.. The water puppet theatre was recommended to us by friends. It's a beautiful performance and although it's in Vietnamese we still enjoyed it. A small orchestra sets the mood and we recommend it to anyone who enjoys culture and traditions.

SO GOOD!. This show was amazing! I'm not sure what I was expecting prior but I was blown away by the talent and quality of the show. No matter what language you speak, the show is easy to follow. It was funny, sad, exciting, and captivating. Definitely worth seeing.
A great show. My advice to you, if you choose to watch this show, get front row ticket. This show is fantastic, and as every detail counts, removing any obstacles from your way will be well advised.
Amazing show, you will love it. Quite a surprise a water puppet show...awesome, nice puppets, very professional presentation! Nice theater. Live music band!

different kind of puppet show. Seating was really cramped resulting in you being uncomfortable for the duration of the 45min show. The show itself was not bad with the different puppets and the musical accompaniment.

Beyond expectation. This show was included in our itinerary,and we were arranged to sit in front of with first class ticket each cost 100.000 vnd. We all so excited on the show. The show was really cleverly done, artists were brilliant. A very good show performance
Glad we went. There were four of us and 2 fell asleep but I enjoyed it! It would be wonderful to take small children to see it, but for adults it hit and miss.

Water Puppets - worth a visit. If you're in Hanoi definitely put this on your agenda. Make sure you go early to get tickets otherwise you may be disappointed. We arrived about midday and got the last four tickets for the 8 pm show that night and there were only tickets available for one show the following day.

A different experience. I somehow enjoyed this performance, although initially I was in doubt as my friend did not have a good experience previously.The show is in vietnamese but it is fairly easy to grasp the story told. I like the stage and how they presented each story with live music and puppet dance.Go and experience it, it is worth seeing at least once.

Very cute but English translation missing. The water puppet show was a treat to watch. I haven't seen anything similar earlier. However, we could not make out the meaning of many of the stories or scenes enacted as the songs and narration was in vietnamese. Simple subtitles on an LCD screen will make the entire performance so much more engaging to the international tourists. Despite this shortcoming, I would still highly recommend this to everyone as it is fun, colourful and cute. If you have small children, then this is definitely a must-see.

Sweet, Old Fashioned Entertainment. My young children and I all loved this show. It was colorful, energetic, and the lack of English was fine as the basic story lines were easy enough to follow. My five year old (as I was!) was disappointment when the show was over and asked if we could come back the following day. A very affordable way to see a unique Vietnamese entertainment while also getting off your feet for an hour! Buy tickets early in the day or the day before if very particular about what time you will see the show. We were the first at the ticket booth once it opened but had to go with our fourth choice showtime!

Pleasantly surprised. Our family of three primary school daughters attended without much in the way of preconceptions, and were pleasantly surprised. Although there was limited context given in English, each piece was fairly short and readily apparent, even to our 9 yo. The live music was fascinating, especially given the unusual (to western eyes) instruments used.Seats are a little cramped, but the performance is only an hour. Best to book a few days out, as all shows were fully booked on the first day we visited.Kind of nice in today's age of electronic devices and smart phones to see children's faces light up watching live puppetry.

Amazingly cute. The puppet show is a must. It is very novel and sweet folklore. The artists are brilliant and the stage is very well created. Thought the show is in vietnamese but it does not at all interfere with the fun! The fee is 100.000 VND.

This is different> Worth seeing once. Unless you are tall, sit near the front.. A unique way of presenting history, culture and music. This is worth seeing once. I have seen it 7 times since 1995. The price is right, the presentation is very good.
Water Puppet. Very Unique ShowSmall stage - viewers sit infront of a pond. The puppeteers work from behind a curtain with poles and puppets attached to the other end.

Good music and show. The music was excellent. I've been twice. You are packed in like sardines and the space between seats will leave those with long legs uncomfortable. The first time I went I was near the front and could see fine. The second time, I was nearer the back and could hardly see anything. Would be nice to have a translator between items as had no idea what each item was about and struggled to understand. Visually entertaining though. If you wish to use the bathroom.. take own paper!

Sweet if childlike. This was part of my Hanoi day tour and it was clever and sweet but I felt it was more for children. Most people who went said the same. However it was only about an hour long and it was enjoyable but I would not go again through choice.
Better than expected. This was included in our itinerary and we were not expecting much - but it was so much better than expected and really cleverly done

Thang Long Water puppet. It was an interesting experience. Sadly lacking was explanation/written guide on the scenes in English as not everyone understands each scene without some form of introduction.

OK for kids, otherwise give it a pass. An hour of Steve Zodiac spinning in the water. If I walked by this show in a park at home I would just keep going. The history and cultural significance don't come across in the performance. Good musical accompaniment, though.

The baby likes it. For you crazies who travel with young children, make sure you check out the water puppets. The live music, colorful puppets and constant action kept our 16-month old entertained for 30 minutes. The show goes for 45 mins, sorry to the person sitting in front of us. Really cool cultural experience. Watch out for the gruff lady at the ticket counter, she doesnt have time for nonsense. Seats are assigned so no need to arrive early. Aisles are very narrow so dont plan on escaping during the show.

Seating makes viewing difficult. Indoor water puppetry. Didnt really get why it was done on water. Good music using traditional instruments. Spoiled somewhat by groups of people being seated during the show.

I enjoyed it.. I enjoyed this show very much. The puppets and scenery are beautiful. The technique with the puppeteers in the water is fascinating. The music us very pleasant. I wished I was more familiar with Vietnamese music. The show is only an hour and the tickets are inexpensive. I think it's a good experience for children and adults alike.I had a problem with the seating: tourists packed like sardines in undersized seats. I am small and my knees were hitting the seat in front of me. The other is with the public itself. Video cameras and cell phones filming galore! It takes away from other's enjoyment. It should not be allowed.
indescribable. the music and puppetry was out of this world. it was spectacular and so worth the ticket price. would definitely go again.
Water puppet show. I was this water puppet show twice and was amazed that the puppet show was done in the water.I love the baby dragons play. The story is rich in its culture.

Lovely Water puppet show at Hanoi. We went to the Water Puppet show at Hanoi. It was quite unique to see the puppets being controlled from beneath the water. Nice props and music though the commentary is in Vietnamese. Introductions are in English & Vietnamese.The cost per ticket is inexpensive $3-5! Kids and adults will love to see it once. Book in advance.Most all shows run full...Ramky Bangkok, Thailand

Beautiful! A must!. My husband and I went to see this show because it is highly recommended on trip advisor. It is fantastic and very creative! The music is lovely and the puppets are awesome! It would be nice to have a little more background about the tales, because they are myths of Vietnamese culture, but still most of the stories are pretty easy to follow.We recommend going early to buy the tickets for that day so you can sit as close to the front row as possible.

A visit to Thang Long water puppet show.. Thang Long water puppet theatre is situated at Hoan Kiem lake in Central Hanoi. Their shows are considered the best in Vietnam and advance booking is essential.I had booked a ticket in advance for the last show of the evening.At 2100 hrs entered the "Thang Long water puppet theatre" and was lucky to get a good centre seat, close to the stage. The play was in Vietnamese language with a live orchestra performing folk songs next to the "Water Stage" while the puppets enacted their stories. Excellent and perfect harmony making the viewer feel that the puppets are actual humans , nothing artificial, brilliant. Now realize the reasons for this show being a huge success.It was a one hour show and at approx 2230 hrs was back in my hostel, a short walk from the theatre.

Interesting show. Althought we didn't understand Vietnamese, we found the show interesting to watch. The performance lasted about 45 mins and looked a bit like the Canton Opera. The artists and together with the muscians were so skillful to make the water puppets come to live!

Worth one visit. This show came highly recommended by the travel books and websites so we decided to give it a try. We were also told getting tickets were a little tricky, but we were pleasantly surprised to see there were indeed tickets ( non premium ones cannot recall what they were called but they were around 3$). The show lasted around 45 minutes. Pretty entertaining with the use of the water,songs, fireworks and traditional Vietnamese puppets. Be prepared though- the whole show is in Vietnamese with no English translation! Just have an open mind and enjoy the show!

worth a visit (if you have never seen a puppet show). music was relaxing and entertaining, worth a visit if you have never seen a water puppet show, the story is told in Vietnamese through music so it could seem boring (some people had a snooze in our Group but we had a long day and it was wet & cold) hence it was relaxing, puppeteers/musicians and the singers are very talented..... thank you for a very good evening

Should do once. A Hanoi tourist staple - a must do just the once. The 45 minute show is visually interesting and the technique is admirable. The theatre seating is really cramped and uncomfortable with the knees jammed up against the seat in front.
Better than expected. The show was a lot better than expected - live music, colourful and the right length. Keep in mind - it is all in Vietnamese, so just smile and laugh when everybody does it.

Interesting show, better with English translation. It is interesting to see how the water puppets come to life and sets one thinking how it is being done.It is a bit long when there is no English translation to follow the story.

Cultural. Show was very well done with singers and musicians. Well maintained theatre and puppets. An interesting insight into another cultures entertainment form. Unfortunately is was also a good time for many to take a nap after a long busy day.
Very Unique. This is the most unique entertainment. There is live music and singing to puppets in the water with a story

Lovely, relaxing spectacle of culture. This was recommended by a friend who’d been and as a novel experience didn’t disappoint. There is a little speech in Vietnamese, which obviously the mostly foreign audience can’t appreciate but you can get the gist of what’s going on in the series of short skits performed by the puppets. There are a few fun pyrotechnics but also some strobe lighting which you aren’t warned about if you’re prone to seizures, so do be aware. The performance is only 50 minutes and accompanied by a live band and singers who are lovely to listen to on their own. The entry price is only 60,000 VND but you must ask specifically for the lower price tickets if that’s what you want – visibility is not bad from anywhere in the theatre. At high season, be prepared to book a few days in advance. The couple in front of me in the ticket queue where told they were all booked out of seats together for the next few days – I got in because I only needed one seat. Well worth a look.

Wonderful show. Very traditional music accompanying a wonderfully executed waterballet of puppets. Of course it has a high 'tourist attraction level' but that does not take away anything of the performance. The only minor: the size of the seats is clearly not meant for western tourists. And make sure to book tickets in the first rows, to enjoy most of the spectacle.

Interesting but long. Ok so the show opened with some amazing traditional instruments such as bamboo flutes, bronze drums, gongs, xylophones being played, then there were dragons and monkeys and the whole show started off very nicely.After a while the show became slightly monotonous and I felt really sleepy from all the travelling.

good for 1st timers. If you had a busy day, try doing this some other time as it can put you to sleep.
The novelty of watching a water puppet show wears off after a few songs. I wished they shortened it to heighten audience impact. a 40 minute show would have been more than enough.

A Unique Experience. We thorougly enjoyed the water puppet show at Thang Long. This was our first trip to Vietnam and we did not really know what to expect, but the visual beauty and beautiful music provided by the live band and singers makes this an unforgettable experience.

Love it. There is not a lot of English which was nice
Loved the puppets
100,000dong 12/2013 plus I think you pay extra to take pics or more if you take a video.
It was a nice way to spend Christmas Day 3013

Interesting. Its all in Vietnamese. It would have been good if there was a little translation, or if there was an introduction to explain the significance of the story/performance.
The puppets were beautiful and they moved flawlessly across the water.

Unique Vietnamese Art. Artistic puppetry, unique that performers and puppets are in water. Almost a must do in Vietnam. The shows are very popular so it is recommended to buy tickets early and wander around Old Quarters until the show. Seats are small and children are easily blocked by adults in front.
Excellent. Fun hour watching puppets telling a story. Different atmosphere as the entire production is on water, the puppets being manipulated completely under water.

Must be seen to be believed. The Thang Long water puppet theatre show is something of an institution and forms part of the itinerary for most visitors to Hanoi. Shows are about an hour long, it's not overly expensive, and it really must be seen to be believed. A phantasmagoric romp through Vietnamese folk history and stories, brought to life through the unique medium of puppets on water, all set to a Vietnamese musical soundtrack provided by a live band. Slightly bizarre but absolutely recommended!

Beyond my expectations! Fun and enjoyable!. Arrived in Hanoi and immediately tried to book for their 9 pm show to be told that their is no 9pm show which meant we had to make the 4:10pm show with about 10 mins to go from our hotel the Sofitel Metropole. So we booked with the concierge, he rang the theatre and when we arrived were shown to the first row!! Good job concierge!The show was very funny, we had bellyful of laughs from the audience and as we are always interested in theatre anywhere we travel to, this was something different. It was very well executed and the synchronisation was amazing. One of the main character puppet broke her arm - poor thing! For $5, it was worth every cent. Try and get front seats.We love it!The show times currently is 4:10, 5:20 and 8pm.

The music is excellent. Started off slow. It wasn't until midway through that you start to appreciate the artistry in the puppeteering. Very cool. I was particularly very impressed with the singers and musicians. If you get bored by the puppets (which I did), then just imagine it is a concert abd watch the singers. Very cool.I suppose it's valuable to see in a cultural sense, but I wasn't too excited by it overall.

great value for money. we were lucky to get tickets and were a bit unsure of watching puppets in water. However we thoroughly enjoyed it even although the seats are built for smaller vietnamese people. We left with big smiles on our faces - and all for £3 each

A Gentle Distraction. We went for an early evening performance and were delighted by the display of traditional water puppets accompanied by some fabulous musicians - it is an opportunity to lose yourself in a lovely distraction for an hour or so. The humour and pathos transcend all cultures.

Essential Hanoi Puppet visit. Wonderful performance. We saw one in HCMC as well, but the one in Hanoi is better. Try to read up on water puppetry first as a lot of reviews posted on TripAdvisors seem to be by folks who have no understanding of what they are seeing.There's an excellent bookstore at 46 Tran Hung Dao that carries all sorts of books on Vietnamese culture by the Tre Gioi Publishing house. Even without script, sub/sur titles, the music and the vitality of the puppets is wonderful. Get your tickets several days ahead so that you can be up close, and potentially have some leg room. The seating is for Asian body, not the ones we possess. The seating is assigned, so no need to show up very early to the actual show.

Better than expected. We were visiting Hanoi with some friends who had read about this and wanted to go; we had our reservations! It was actually pretty good. The puppetry was well done, the traditional music and singing lively and the special effects good. All in all, a surprisingly professional and un-childish show which I think most adults would enjoy. The entry fee of 100,000 dong (£3, $5) isn't unreasonable.

Not too exciting!. This show is not that great, and at times can be quite boring if you can't understand Vietnamese. There are a few interesting and bit funny parts, but it could be helpful to tell the audience what every scene is about (instead of giving them those flyers that can;t be read at the dark).As I said, it was not that interesting, and I even fell asleep for a few minutes during the show. However, it can be interesting for you to see the puppets, how the puppet operators control them over the water (for example, it was nice to see the puppets hitting the drums in sync with the music). And, the price is quite cheap.
Avoid. Although it is popular culture, the spectacle is very repetitive and entedioso. An hour is plenty of time for that attraction.

I expected better. From all the reviews I had much high expectations but I was rather disappointed. I'm not sure if they were just having an off day but half the puppets were halfway submerged the whole time and the voiceovers weren't in time. Overall for the price I paid I wouldn't recommend seeing it if you have limited time in Hanoi
Excellent Show. Was a bit apprehensive as not sure what to expect but the show was great. You had a leaflet to help follow show and very different as performed on water. A must see if you go to Hanoi

Water Puppetry Vietnamese Style. Not an easy feat for the background performers to be in water & balance the puppets above water level. The vocals are in Vietnamese, so couldn't understand a damn thing what the entire story is all about. Needs lot of patience & imagination watching this show or u will get sleepy in due time......boring......

Interesting. Unique form of cultural arts. Interesting to see how the puppets were operated. It's an hour long with 8 different stories, all narrated in Vietnamese so a prior knowledge of the country's history would be good. It can get draggy sometimes. It can get annoying when the people in front of you starts whipping out their cameras and blocks your view. Probably they should assign seats to those taking photos to the back of the theatre. One of those tourist attraction that should be visited but probably not revisited again.

Authentic show repackaged for mass tourism. In the old times this show could be seen at a small theater a bit away from the city centre. The art form itself is fun to watch: colorful puppets rising from a pool of water, manipulated by players hidden behind blinds. Live traditional music accompanies old mythical tales. The songs are all in Vietnamese, however, so if you don't master the language don't expect to be able to make much of what it's about. When the show ends, you've probably seen enough.Today, a brand new theater is right at Hoan Kiem lake and every day many bus loads of tourists are moved through the building quite efficiently for a series of shows. For Caucasian legs, seats are extremely tight, and the view may be partly blocked by dozens of fellow-tourists taking pictures or movies. Traditional art, in other words, in a not-so-very-traditional setting.,
Delightful. A unique show.. And charming.. Not expensive and not long at all.. If you have children with you, they will enjoy it a lot.. Recommend

Excellent show. I'd never seen a water puppet show, but this one was not only performed with expertise but also elicited shouts of approval from the spectators. I was pleasantly surprised at how enjoyable and funny I found the performance. Basic folklore tails were told with music and water puppets. Although not in English, you will still laugh and smile at the show. My kids loved the show very much and I hope to bring them back to Hanoi again next year.Definitely worth a visit.

delightful--a surprise. This was a lovely little adventure. I really liked the live music. The puppet show was also charming. Understanding the language is not an issue. I also recommend a walking through the park around the lake (across the street from the theatre) in the early morning. Life is all around, the usual exercise activities go on and ballroom dancing--I kid you not--at 6:30 am. I always love to walk vigorously in the early am but this was especially rewarding.

Great show...Pleasantly surprised. Very cool if you've never seen a water puppet show...We caught the 6:30pm show which is very popular so we had to deal with about 3 Chinese tour groups who can be a bit overwhelming. Other than that, the band and puppeteers were on point and I would recommend catching a show. Very cool how they do all the puppeteering from behind a curtain and the puppets (as you can imagine from the name) seem to just dance on the water.

Watch your knees!. If you are an average sized person, get a seat in the front row otherwise your knees will hate you when you are done. There is ZERO leg room for anyone over 100cm tall in those seats.Ok show, but all in Vietnamese, so the story was a bit lost on me. Annoying that everyone holds up their cameras, blocking what poor view I had. Were it not part of a tour, I'd not have paid to see this show.

Unique and worth a visit. The live theater interprets the traditional stories of Vietnam through some very well managed water puppets.Don't mind that you cannot understand Vietnamese, just enjoy the show!

Great fun!. It's a great little show to go see if you have an hour to spare.You'll never see anything quite like it again. The fire breathing dragons and the carp were the highlight of the show for me.
water puppets- a must do. we heard this was a must do, so did!Short and entertaining, tho seats in the theatre are tiny!Very uncomfy hour for Mr 190cm!!

Wonderful unique attraction. The water puppets combine humour, with artistry and a wonderful collection of puppets. It is performed in Vietnamese but is very visual so it doesn't matter much. This is a chance to enjoy something a bit different which kids and adults alike will enjoy. The price is very cheap and we had a great evening here. Thanks to all the puppeteers and the orchestra. The orchestra itself was quite special all playing traditional instruments which we had never seen before. Highly recommended

Good evening entertainment. All songs are in Vietnamese otherwise there isn't much narrative anyway. If you haven't seen a show of similar sort then I would strongly recommend this show. Bizarrely entertaining and clever how they operate the puppets.

Great show. The water puppet show is something that they say you have to see in Hanoi, and they're right. It's impressive to watch a performance using a fluid stage, and it's a very unique performance. The show is a series of short scenes, each one important in Vietnamese culture, but there is a pamphlet you can pick up which describes the scene. As a bonus, after the show, when everyone else is busy trying to file out of the theater, you can go down to the "stage" and check out the pool and get an idea of how they're making it all work.
Well done, great local performance. A great way to spend an hour watching the local culture/art. Price is equivalent to $5. Clean and comfortable facility.

Just do it!. Ok, so we were worried it would be a big old tourist trap, but it was really fun. The show is short and it's really a cultural thing. The whole thing is in Vietnamese, so read the little booklet ahead so you know what the stories are. There are worse ways to spend an hour of your life, we really liked it!

Ha ha ha. You should attend just to see what it's like. We enjoyed the show. I'm sure there are people who might not enjoy it, but if you have a good sense of humor blended with a great admiration for live theater this show is worth the ticket.

Its everything Vietnam is. A must.. Took our two teenagers to this show, thought they might pretend to be un-impressed but I was wrong. They loved it. Whats not to like. Hanoi was our 2nd last stop north bound. We had travelled from the Mekong delta upward, everything in the show was visually interpreted by what we had experienced along the way in Vietnam. I was sceptical, I had read some bad reviews from people, but they obviously just dont get it. Money well spent, a nice rest stop for an hour or so after wandering old qtrs all day. The music is outstanding, you really dont need to understand Vietnamese to understand the story. Its all done so brilliantly. I have never seen anything like it in my life. Just go, its truly unique. Enjoy.

Unique puppet show. Attended a show as part of a tour.While we have seen puppet shows in different parts of the world, we had not seen one like this. The stage is water, there is a lovely band and singers to expand on the show. It is difficult to see how the puppets are controlled while they do flips, jump out of the water, have dragons spray water, fishermen catch fish which are then eaten by a snake. Action packed 45 minutes.

Disappointing. We were told that Water Puppets were an artform in Vietnam and not to be missed. OK we were not enthalled but glad we had at least been. The puppetry was very skilled a\nd all credit to them but not really our cup of tea

At least now I can say I've been there.... Honestly, we didn't have a bad time, it was actually interesting to see something different and a quintessential feature of Hanoi. But it did feel a little like one of those iconic places you go to when traveling, not because it will be the the of your life but rather so can say "yes!" when someone asks "you went to Hanoi, did you see the water puppets?". Overall, I'm definitely glad I did it but I wouldn't really want to see it twice.
Book early as it fills up very fast. You can do this on a tour ir by yourself. Book at least one day ahead.good value for an hours entertainment

Bummed . Just went to the theatre to buy tickets. We paid for two, looked down at the tickets, (while still at the window) and realized the lady gave us the wrong time for the show we wanted to see. She gave us new tickets and then asked for us to pay again when we literally just gave her money! When we told her we had paid for the original wrong time tickets she yelled at us telling us we didn't pay. One moment we were tickets-in-hand ready to walk away but apparently the return policy here is you just don't get the original tickets or money back. We opted to go drink our next 200,000 Dong at the bar rather than double down. Lesson: check the time stamp then pay to avoid this confusion.

Good to see different thing Jet Privilage No. 149773993. I was on bussines trip but worth to spend time to see different things. Water puppet is quite popular in Hanoi, thet have daily 4-5 show each of one hour....the whole shows is in vietnamese but you will enjoy if you like different thing....i saw people were sleeping and enjoying as well during the show...
Go , you will love it. I was really undecided whether to go to Water puppet show. So glad I did . Was much better that expected and had a great evening. Beautiful costumes, puppets and music.
Skillful and not too long. Cheap, intriguing cultural experience. Short enough that you don't nod off more than once and you feel like you learned something. Tight on the knees if your somewhat tall.

Puppets so fun. Great experience. Water puppet stories were humorous and so talently told. Fun to see. Music was wonderful and watching the woman on the main instrument was mesmerizing. Loved seeing puppet stories of stories I'd heard before.

Interesting. Unique form of cultural arts. Interesting to see how the puppets were operated. It's an hour long with 8 different stories, all narrated in Vietnamese so a prior knowledge of the country's history would be good. It can get draggy sometimes. It can get annoying when the people in front of you starts whipping out their cameras and blocks your view. Probably they should assign seats to those taking photos to the back of the theatre. One of those tourist attraction that should be visited but probably not revisited again.

Lovely authentic show. The theatre is very nice,and the show was easy to follow using the programme you get with the tickets. We enjoyed the music and the puppets, and the show started promptly, with an introduction to the people behind the puppets and the band at the end of the show. Recommend visiting this show.

Excellent performance by puppeteers and musicians. A place not only for the kids but also for the adults to enjoy traditional Vietnamese culture. A pity there's no English translation for the folklore that was portrayed. If there's a programme information sheet on the play, it will help the audience appreciate the story better.

Thang Long Water Puppet Theater. While the show is in Vietnamese language we found the theme of the show easy to follow. The work of the puppeteers was amazing. The music & vocals had a soothing effect.Booking as essential if you plan to go as it is very popular

One of those "check this off the list" experiences. Classic Ha Noi. I fell asleep, but it was a nice hour break from the heat and humidity of the streets of Ha Noi. Nice to experience something that is somewhat unique to Ha Noi. It is not a venue one would want to revisit.

A brilliant night out. This was such a fun, enjoyable experience. It lasted about an hour and during each scene the puppeteers illustrated a small story. It was totally charming and we felt it was well worth a visit. The theatre is quite small, but is air conditioned and fully seated. It was full for the performance we went to - we got tickets the same morning, but only just managed to get into the last show of the day that evening.

Unique and entertaining. My daughter loved it. I thought she was going to fall asleep. We paid with usd and it was $5 each. The shows get soldout on weekdays. They give multiple showings. I wish they provide more contexts to each song.

Boring after the first song and seats are extremely close together. This does not cost a lot to go to, but I found this extremely boring. The show goes for 14 different songs but to me the first one appeared to just repeat over and over. I am 5'3 and had a hard time sitting in the chairs with my knee's being squeezed into the chair in front of me. But on the plus side it doesn't go for too long and the price is cheap - but this is not something I would recommend unless you really have nothing else better to do while in Hanoi.

Unique show - worth seeing. This is a great 1hr show, very unique and different. You spend the first 30mins trying to figure out how they are controlling the puppets - it is that unique. The price is great, the seating and theater are nice, and even though everything is sung in Vietnamese, you can still understand what is happening.

Show is good, seating is dreadful. This is a great piece of theatre, cleverly done. Colourful, lots of movement and good live musical backing. On the down side there is very little in the way of explanation of the stories unless you understand Vietnamese and the seating is the most uncomfortable I have ever experienced in an entertainment venue, designed for petite locals. I'm 190 cm tall and simply could not fit into the seat, even though I had an aisle seat.

A clever novelty of Vietnamese history. To be honest, I was expecting pretty little going in. However, I was very impressed by the performance. The traditional folk music and the demonstration of daily life by the puppets as they danced through the water was great. If you are tall (like I am), then you may want to pay for a better ticket and possibly even ask for the front row. They were kind enough to place us in the front row and we had a wonderful experience.Make sure you go about an hour early to grab a ticket just in case.Basic ticket - 60,000 DongPremium ticket - 100,000 Dong

How on earth do they do it?. Well, it´s typical and you get a feel for vietnamese music, and the stories they tell about life in the village and the themes they pick give you an inkling as to the rural life that has pervaded in Vietnam almost until now. The way they move the puppets very clever…couldn´t figure out how they do it though. And yes…the musicians seemed bored out of their wits…my husband remarked on that...
Clever. Very fun and cleverly done. Very little English, but it doesn't matter. You get the gist of the stories, no problem. Best to get tickets in the first 3-4 rows if possible.

Worth a watch!. The water puppet show is a very unique show that's been around for many years. Its very different from most plays and shows I've watched in my life. The show is broken into many sections, each section is with different characters and story's, all water puppets though. The show starts very well cause its unlike anything you've seen before, puppets dancing around in the water with very traditional music being played in a dimly lit background. Personally for me the novelty of this show was wearing off during the middle section of the play, but it picked up towards the last sections as they were some complicated puppet movements and multiple characters, with the tempo of the music changing. Overall it was worth a watch! and kudos to the team to have kept this show going on for several decades!
Well worth a vist. Really different to anything else I've seen before and well worth seeing.it does get a bit same same but not really that different at the end but is still entertaining.

I liked it, my husband fell asleep!. It's definitely different and you'll probably never see anything like this outside of Vietnam.
The best bit were the musicians. Unusual music and instruments. I spend most of my time watching them.
My husband thought it was terrible, but I thought it was interesting to see something unique.

Brilliant!. Saw a brilliant show. The work of the puppeteers was clever. How did they do all those complicated movements? Agree with comment about the musicians, two kept on chatting throughout the performance. If they find it boring and repetitive, then perhaps they should get a different job!
Different. In all our travels, this is the first time we have seen anything like this. The live band was great!

Magnificent. This is the heart of Vietnamese culture. It starts with scenes from the village life and goes to the ancient myths. The beauty of simplicity & popular malice. Also one of the rare places to hear un-edulcorated traditional music in Hanoi.

Puppets and muppets. The show was really well done and sort of gives you an overview of some Vietnamese traditions and the like. The problem I had was I saw more of the people's cameras in front and the back of their heads which kind of detracted from the experience for me. I also thought it was funny because of the musicians was just chatting with her mate for almost the whole show stopping only to play her bit, I think she was saying something about what Miley Cirus had been up to ;)

Average attraction. The water puppet theatre was a good way to see a performance that is a cultral tradtion of vietnam. The show itself is a bit repetitive and boring after awhile but the concept is unique and the music by live performers is good. The show is conducted in vietnamese language with no english translation. Worth going to for the cultural experience.

Cute and Lively. The orchestration for this water puppet show is simply amazing. The singers are very good and even though I could not understand the language it was evident that they were really well trained musicians. The co-ordination of the singers and the people who actually work the puppets is amazing. The show itself is cute, some sections of the show especially the dance of the fairies and with the lamps is visually captivating. Some parts seem a little repetitive and gets dull. But overall it is a good way to spend an hour getting acquainted with an age-old cultural tradition.

Only with kids. I would recommend it only if you have kids. One hour show, repetitive. Good music and live performance but no translation. The 60.000 entrance is enough. Don't pay to take pictures and just get a small camera.

Amateur performance, amateur audience. I assume that many people who go to see these performances don't attend much theatre elsewhere. Cameras were flashing constantly and the woman in front of me actually had a spotlight glaring from her video camera on the assumption it was going to somehow enhance her 12th row pictures. (She did turn it off when I gently asked her.)The show was worth seeing just because it's a traditional art form but it's not an inspiring or particularly interesting show. Don't go if you are tall because the leg room is nonexistent. At least it was not expensive.Glad I went but wouldn't recommend it.
Puppets. A unique experience. Although there are several performances each evening it is necessary to book in advance. The Little Hanoi Hotel did this for us.

Really worth a visit. Went last week whist in Hanoi. Great entertainment for all ages and really worth a visit, its very well done. The show was an hour long. It was very last minute for us and we only decided to go on our last day. My wife went to the box office and was told there were no tickets. I went up as well to try and was also told no tickets. I went back five minutes later in the hope the a few thousand more Vietnamese dong may help. This time she managed to find some tickets without my offer of extra money. The odd thing was that although it was very busy it wasn't full in there anyway. Good entertainment for adults and I would think kids would love it as it isn't too long.

Hour show....capacity audience. I was really looking forward to seeing this performance and commented to my friend that I had hoped it would have been longer than an hour, however an hour was too long. The choreography of the puppets was great, just repetitive. There was a live group of performers who played instruments and sang in Vietnamese. They were great and without them the performance would have been bland.It's a shame that there was no pamphlet handed out or any translations given...the audience were mainly European...it was left to our own interpretations.Looking around the audience many were asleep...I have to admit I was bored. Thank God for the live band performers they certainly love their job :)

Touristic but enjoyable. I'm reviewing this as a local. Been here once. The place has been renovated so it has canteen (pricey but ok) at the front with very nice lake view from the entrance. The show is mostly about the life of Vietnamese in the old time with farming, fishing and showing the close-to-nature, simple, hardworking happy life of Vietnamese farmers. The songs praised the beauty of nature and people and the enthusiasm of working. Highly recommended for kids. This kind of puppet used to be the entertainment in some village in the north of Vietnam for Tet (new year) or other special occasions before we have TV and imported shows :D. I wish they could have made the show more various so people would have want to comeback, but now it's mostly for tourist :(

Traditional Theatre. We went to the Water Puppet Show as part of an organised excursion which included a rickshaw ride from our hotel to the theatre. Being cycled through Hanoi's late afternoon motor cycle traffic was an eye opener. The entrance to the theatre was crowded but we were shepherded through to our seats quite easily. The puppet stories were interesting to watch for a while but did get a little repetitive. I assumed the instruments, music and vocals were traditional and were excellent. I would recommend a visit to experience Vietnamese traditional theatre

A MUST visit. Visitors to Hanoi should visit this place for a performance, but booking is essential. It is part of Vietnamese culture and tells many of the traditional stories. It lasts for an enjoyable hour, is colourful and funny and the stories easily understood, plus if you pay $1 you can take photographs!

A Fun Night Out. If you find yourself in Hanoi and have an hour to spend check this out. The music is wonderful, the puppetry is unique, and the entertainment is priceless, all for $5. It's worth your time.
This is a "must do" when in Hanoi. The Water Puppet show is great entertainment for all ages. Very well presented and gives everyone lots of laughs. This show is suitable for all ages.
Water puppet theatre. Just ok not all that's it's cracked up to be. The puppeteers are good in what they do but it was no big deal

We all really enjoyed it. It was a great performance, bit hard to get tickets, the kids loved it but our youngest fell asleep as we had to settle for a later performance. The length is around 45 minutes which is good for kids, it has music, humour and atmosphere.

Touristy but probably worth seeing. This is a typical tourist attraction but I didn't want to miss it on account of the fact that it was so rooted in the history of these people - it was the way they entertained themselves in the rice paddies long ago. It was only an hour long and quite tame but I was still glad that I had gone. A simple pleasure!

Fascinating traditional music. I actually paid less attention to the theatre part, but music (live) was superbly performed (both vocal and instrumental) and really fascinating. I'm not qualified to tell how originally traditional it was (are percussion cymbals traditional Vietnamese instrument...?), but it sounded fantastic.
It's a pity they don't have CDs on sale.
Worth an hour of your time to see this Vietnam Tradition. Amazing how they do the Water Puppets. Well worth the $10 cost of a ticket to see the art they have created thru the water puppets

Different but not exciting.. The music played by the vietnamese traditional band was as interesting as the puppet stories. Was pleased I went because I had never seen a puppet show performed in a very large "tank" of water before. The stories performed were traditional but a lack of english translation meant the subtleties of the stories and characters were not clearly understood. Interesting but not a mind blowing experience.

I enjoyed it. Caveat: I had a rice wine taster and an egg with beer before the show, which may have biased me in a positive direction :-)I read the somewhat mixed reviews but decided to go anyway, as I heard that water puppetry is unique to Vietnam and it was only a one hour show that wasn't super-expensive. I bought my ticket for the latest show at 9:15pm just a few minutes before it started. I thought the show was charming and unusual. I liked how the water was not just a means to an end, i.e., a way to move the puppets, but also an important character in the shows. There were scenes of people cutting rice in the water and fishing. There were fish puppets and water dragon puppets, spraying water through their nostrils instead of fire.The live band playing Vietnamese traditional music was also a plus.The only thing I wasn't too crazy about was the seating, While the seats were arranged on an incline, the incline was so slight that it was hard not to have your view blocked, especially if there were tall people sitting 1 or 2 rows in front of you.

Excellent...!. I had looked back through reviews before booking and was 50/50 about whether I visit. After several recommendations from friends that had visited Vietnam, we decided to give it go.What a fantastic show! I am 25 and my boyfriend 31, and we thought it was delightful. Vietnamese band were great and a joy to listen to and be water puppets were comical and played a out a nice little story. Lovely little theatre.I believe it went on for 45 minutes which went quite quickly (about 13 scenes altogether). I would definitely say give it a whirl. If theatres are not your cup of tea, I would still say give it a whirl. Price for a ticket is 100,000 dong which is about £3 - so nothing wasted if you want to talk out after 30 minutes.

Something different. This show was entertaining in the first 10 min as it is something different, that you more than likely have never seen before. However after while it becomes boring and repetitive, I have noticed that many others were feeling the same as there was some sleeping going on around me. I believe it has been set before, and I agree that considered there are no Vietnamese in the public it would be good if there is some more English translation on the leaflet or some kind of English introduction at the start of each play, so we have q notion of what is going on.

no different to Ho Chi Minh City. Last year i visited the water puppet show in Ho chi Minh City and was not too impressed, the same goes for here. I had not planned to go again but this was part of the hanoi city tour. I am sure it is quite clever but i did find it very childish and as the vocals were in vietnamese it didn't help either.

Unusual art form, worth the time. After 2 weeks in Vietnam, Hanoi being at the end of our trip, we could easily understand where the water puppet theater idea came from with all the water around :)It was in interesting experience, worth the hour we spent there. The artists are very skilful and the singing that explains the stories sounds nice even if you do not understand it. You do not really need a script or translation of what the ladies are singing, the stories are short and some of them really entertaining. I would recommend going in order to experience an unusual form of art.

Not my thing. Went with open mind but frankly I was bored silly. Two men in front of me nodded off to sleep straight away and my husband joined them ten minutes later. Was seated infront of air-conditioning that blew on me the whole time, so hence I ended up with a cold a day later. Clever but boring.

Water Puppet Show. The show is excellent. You have to buy tickets in advance, The theater was packed to capacity when we went to see the show in the afternoon.The puppeteers are very talented. The show is made up of different typical Vietnamese scenes, such as fishing, rice planting and harvesting. It is a great show to go and see, Don't miss it !

Supposedly a must do in Hanoi?. Interesting at first and then a bit overlong and boring. I don't see what all the fuss is about. I was more interested in watching the beautiful live female singers and band. I guess we can say we been there done that. As most of the audience was European, North Americans and Aussies it could have benefited from some English translation.
Different. In all our travels, this is the first time we have seen anything like this. The live band was great!

Interesting. Still not quite sure what the play was about,however the puppets and music were really lovely to watch. There was a lot of effort put into making the show and I enjoyed it. They sold puppets after the show which made great souvenirs.

Little boring. This a traditional art of the Vietnamese so we made sure we did go for the experience.It is very clever but can be a little boring at times. It does not go for too long, which is probably just as well as the kids were starting to get restless.Worth a visit - is colourful and funny at times

Interesting show !. Despite the mixed reviews, we attended the show one evening, and it was good. It is part of the local culture, so worth spending one hour and a few $ (5) to see it. It feels sometimes like a show for children, but the music was good and i did not got bored.Only problem is that if you are too far away from the scene, a part of it may be hidden by the heads of the people sitting in front of you. So try to get a seat on the lowest rows.
An interesting show.. This is one of the attractions we had wanted to visit during our trip and we weren't disappointed. For us once was enough and this theatre did it justice.

We ticked it off the list.. We had heard good reviews about the Water Puppets, and the hotel said it was a "must" so we went. It cost about $4AU and unfortunately was extremely average. The whole thing was in Vietnamese and when you consider that most Europeans can speak english and we Australians almost speak english, why on earth it would be in a foreign language, especially when the "locals" don't go. The puppetting was clever, but got boring quick. The best thing was the live band and the singing, and if it was just THEM on stage it would have been a whole lot better.

We had higher expectations. We chose to see this attraction because it was the number 1 rated attraction on Trip Advisor and also recommended to us by our hotel...but we didn't think it really lived up to the hype.The puppets are an interesting novelty initially, but after 20 minutes or so it seems to drag on a bit. If you've got nothing else to do, this is worth a look, but it wouldn't be at the top of my list.

An Unexpected Gift. Our guide encouraged us to go to the theater and we were glad he did. We had no idea what to expect--and to me that was part of the fun. This is a very old traditional theatrical presentation with live musicians and performers. Don't want to spoil the experience so I'll just tag this as a must-see in Hanoi!

Nor woth the rating. The show is 45 minutes long. I didn't understand most of what's going on as there was no English captions. The music and the puppet movement were monotonous after 10 minutes. Kind of boring actually. However, for $3 USD, one cannot complain too much.

Been there done that. Interesting show. Not in English but can kind of follow whats going on. Amazing how it works, perhaps a little expensive for less than 1 hour (100dong). Would only see it once, not again

Pay extra to get a front seat. I spent the first 30 minutes with a smile on my face.
Went under duress as my wife wanted to go after reading the reviews on trip advisor. I was glad I did as it was much better than I expected. The singing and instrumentation were also enjoyable

Definitely an experience. Siting on the back row our view was still really good even if the seats were cramped. The show was interesting but in Vietnamese with an English program giving you a brief description of each event such as man with water buffalo. The music was amazing too

Unique cultural tradition. The water puppet theater is really a must-see when visiting Hanoi. The theater and the puppets are very unique, and the music and stories they tell are quintessentially Vietnamese. It's affordable and not difficult to get to, near the Old Quarter. If you can avoid attending a show with a busload of tourists, do it! It can be hard to see over all the iPads and phones being held up to record the show..... only reason I didn't give it 5 stars.

A must see in Hanoi. The Water puppet theatre is very interesting and good entertainment. The time passes all too quickly.The accompanying music adds considerably to what is a very well presented cultural show providing some insights into rural life. It is a popular show so, if possible, book in advance. We didn't but our guide obtained tickets for us in the morning before we went to the first afternoon show. It is worthwhile to pay for the better seats to get a good view of the performance.

An evening experience. We managed to get the last show at 915pm. It was difficult to get tickets for the show. We paid VND100,000 per person and got the 3rd row. Alternatively, you can pay VND60,000 per person and sit further back. The show lasts 45 minutes and we liked it.

Water Puppet. The live band is awesome. It is all in Vietnamese and hard to understand, but it is very good. People were a little obnoxious when they took pictures with flash. The way they control the puppets is very cool.

Different. This is a must see - albeit touristic - thing to see right in the centre of the town. The only problem I had was that I'd seen 90% of it on TV previously, so little was new. However if you've not seen the TV publicity, go to the show. Expect a smell of damp, but in fairness, it is all done in water.

Must see cultural item. The quintesentially Hanoi cultural show. Very reasonably priced at about $5 per ticket, charged in VND. Reserved numbered seats, the shows are very popular so make sure you book well in advance. Entertaining water puppet show comprised of about 20 short vignettes, so it doesn't get boring. Impressive what they can do; these are some of Vietnam's best puppeteers. The musical accompaniment gives you a flavour of Vietnamese music and singing.

Entertainment & Artistry. Very enjoyable show and was amazed by the artistry of the puppeteers. But you should book early as they tickets sell out days in advance (possibly because of block bookings by the tour groups) We couldn't get tickets at the days/times we wanted, and had to rearrange our plans. And agree with the other reviewers -- the seats are uncomfortable. Very little legroom, and I was starting to squirm a little towards the end of the show.
Boring. This was the most boring experience that we had in the whole time in Vietnam. Maybe it was just me and my friend but we couldn't wait to get out.
Enjoyable moment. Many tour company take tourist to visit, need to check time and book ticket a bit in advance. Simple story of Vietnam and culture shown. Interesting how performance show off.

Entertaining show but a bit long. This was a fun show but maybe went on a little too long. We arrived just as the show was starting and had front row seats, so a great view! There were 14 separate scenes, each showing a traditional Vietnamese scene or tradition. They were all accompanied by a large group of live singers and players. Although it was all in Vietnamese, you are given a card with a brief description on English you you now what is going on, although it is pretty much self explanatory. There were 14 different scenes which was maybe a few too many but still an entertaining way of spending 45 minutes.

Enchanting. The water puppet show was enchanting and you have the added bonus of live Vietnamese music and singing making it a very special 45 minutes. We just turned up for an early evening performance on a Saturday and had no problem buying 2 tickets. I felt very privileged to see something that I don't think can be seen in any other country.

Fell asleep!. Maybe not to our taste. We had front row seats and we both struggled to stay awake! Can understand that this could be considered quite charming but just not for us and no advantage to front row seats.

It's a very long 45 minutes. 45 minutes of my life I will never get back! The show was so long and I didn't find it entertaining at all. Once you get over the first couple of minutes of the puppets in the water being mildly interesting, it just drags on. I wouldn't go again and wouldn't recommend it to others.It might've been good if there was some translation but beyond the introduction which was in English as well as Vietnamese, there was none. The woman next to me fell asleep and I struggled to stay awake.

a wonderful performance. Not sure why others said they were bored! This was a great little performance. Yes it isn't in English but you get the idea. The music accompanying the perforance is beautiful. Something a little different. for approx $5 I would recommend for all ages

It was a mazing. Spent an hour for watching the show. We were impressed straight away, It made us understand more about history of Vietnam. It was quite hard to get a ticket because it was booked out by groups many days. If you would like to see, check it first.

Definitely worth it. I wasnt sure what to expect and after a couple of minutes of the show i was thinking oooo this is going to be a longggg hour. However the show is actually very amusing and very clever and in the end I really enjoyed it. It is definitely worth spending an hour of your time taking in this traditional form of entertainment
Very entertaining. I was surprised how light hearted and entertaining this was! I was amused the whole time and was incredibly impressed! Must go!

Entertaining view of Vietnamese culture. A very entertaining show. The cast worked extremely hard to ensure the show was enjoyed by all - even if some obviously preferred to stay hidden behind the puppets. The puppets themselves aren't in their best condition having done multiple shows everyday for weeks, but don't let that spoil things. Also, the translation screens aren't very well positioned - which left you unsure of whether to watch the show or read the translation. Overall, an enjoyable show that's well worth the ticket price.

The water puppet show Hanoi. Don't be put off if puppets are not your thing as you won't have seen anything like this before. The show is always popular but there is very little waiting time in the queue though pre booking is essential . The show takes place in a traditional theatre and even children have a good view due to the tiered seating. The stage is a mini lake and all the action takes place either on or under it. Different folk tales are enacted by wonderful large and very colourful puppets skilfully manipulated by a hidden cast. The best thing about this show is the traditional music played on traditional instruments by highly skilled musicians accompanied by haunting singing, all perfectly synchronising with the puppetry. The entrance fee was 100000 dong approx £3 each for good seats and lasts about an hour. Could probably have done with more explanation of the story as I gather it tells the story of the sword in the lake in Hanoi centre

Too loud. We did not enjoy the show. I know that tastes can differ, but is was extremely loud music (seated at 3th row) and would suggest to take earplugs. (And no we are not 60+ who find everything to noisy ;) )Maybe if you have kids it might be worth the sacrifice to go.

Good Show. Nice show we caught lucky and got in just as it was starting so didn't have to wait! Very clever puppetry and good music but I would have liked to understand a bit more about about what was going on. Maybe should have tried to find an English performance or narration.
Really good. Clever puppeteers and good music. A bit jet lagged to it was a bit same-y after the 5th or 6th item. But a must-see in Hanoi.

Definitely worth a look.... It's true that this is a major tourist draw - the day we went they had six shows scheduled. So I was a little skeptical - but it was thoroughly worth it. I loved the traditional music - that alone was worth it - and having been a puppeteer many years ago for a brief period I was fascinated to see how this was done - but like the last reviewer I'm still not sure! The show is barely an hour so even without knowing what the stories are about, the music and the visuals keep your attention.

a fantastic evening!. I had no idea what to expect - puppets, right? hand puppets..marionettes, ..but water puppets???This is puppet theatre from a rural base. Their performance space would be the village pond. the scenes were funny, ingenious and needed no translation - some things are just universally human! The music and singing were professional and enjoyable. The interaction between musicians and puppets brought a delightful aside to the performance.The puppeteer's skill and ability made this performance believable on all levels.These shows are booked out early, so get your tickets from the theatre when you arrive in Hanoi.
Charming!. We saw this performance about 10 years... but still have nice impressions!It was something special for me!

talented musicians and intriquing performance. Since visiting this performance I have heard from several people that it was somewhat amusing but they didn't really appreciate it. when I suggested that it told the story of the sword that united Vietnam several hundred years ago it made a bit more sense to them. This is a very popular venue for tourists so the lineups are long and the expectations ore high.I suggest that it would make it more enjoyable if one delves into the past history a bit before attending.My wife and I enjoyed the traditional instruments and the vocals although we couldn't understand the language. The puppet movement was engrossing for me. I like to figure out how things work and although I have a couple of theories, I'm really still puzzled and suitably impressed with the abilities of the puppet masters.All in all, it was a fun interlude.

Good Fun and Worth Seeing. Suitable for kids and adults alike. The show goes for about 50 minutes and shows a number of different representations of Vietnamese life. The puppets are bright and the show is well done. It is primarily in Vietnamese but that doesn't detract from the visual feast for your eyes. The seats cost 60,000- 100,000 dong. (around $3.00- $5.00 Australian) If you want to take pictures or video you have to pay an extra fee on top. Overall its worth the money you pay for something you just wont see anywhere else. Try getting your tickets early in the morning of the day you want to go because they do sell out some sessions quite early.

Very unique!. Thoroughly enjoyed the marvelous puppet performance and particularly thebeautiful traditional musical accompaniment. If you have long legs, try to sit on the end of the row or an aisle chair. The seats are extremely close together and was very uncomfortable for me.

Cute show. Bigger than it looks from the outside with comfortable seating and AC. The show was entertaining and filled with Vietnamese culture and history. We really enjoyed it and the live music us lovely.
