Loved it. We were centre front row for this performance and honestly did not know what to expect. It was a live performance from singers and musicians. The timing from the puppeteers was almost faultless. The entire performance is done in the water. Puppets performing were people, animals, dragons and boats. The performance lasted approximately 50 minutes. For a small charge you were allowed to film or take pictures of the performance. Looking at the brochure it states that there are 14 original items performed. There is a shop where you can purchase a souvenir or even buy a puppet - take it home and perform your own puppet show!!! The attraction is right in the centre of the Hanoi district, so, after the show you can enjoy a meal or even hit the markets and contribute to the Vietnam economy ....

Water Puppet Show Hanoi. It is here to get a glimpse of real Vietnam, its people and culture through this unique Vietnamese traditional art. Tham Long Water Puppet Theater is Located at 57B, Dinh Tien Hoang street in Hanoi, nearby Hoan Kiem Lake, Water Puppet shows are popular among foreigners and Vietnamese alike. It exhibits the daily life of Vietnamese peasants, farming, cultivation and fishing, dancing and folk music. Several shows are performed during the day. Entrance ticket is 3-5$ that can be bought right on the entrance.

mixed experience. You have to see water puppets in Vietnam as they are so unusual and good fun, and this is the easy place to go. But it is indoors and they allow flash photos and video filming, so that watching the performance is hard, especially when people hold up their cameras in front of them. They should do one item for the cameras and then ban their use for the rest of the show. We were lucky to get another opportunity in the village of Yen Duc outside Hanoi, which was during the day and delightful.

Charming. This is a charming piece of music/art/puppetry. Is it a little hokey. Maybe, but you are on vacation. I don't usually use these forums to preach but I missed out enjoying this performance in its truest presentation due to an obnoxious group of tourists who video taped the performance. While it is permitted for a fee, if you are shooting above your head you are shooting directly in front of another patron's face. From what I could see of the video's screen he missed half his shots. There are over 7,000 hits for this performance on youtube. Just sit back and enjoy the show!

Water puppet show. We got there late and they let us in anyway so we missed the first part of the show. The music and singers were live and that part was good but we didn't understand what was going on until we saw a different water puppet show later in our trip that was narrated. Do not go in if the show has already started when you get there.

Not for me but worth a visit. I couldn't really enjoy the show as I am a tall man (6ft 4) and the seats were very small and the leg room just wasn't enough so I was constantly trying to get comfortable. Not there fault, mine for being tall. Maybe if there was greater leg room I would have been able to get comfortable and enjoy the show more. They tell a series of fairytales about the Vietnam culture with the water puppets. The visual display is really good and the skill it takes to work the puppets is admirable. Definitely worth a visit but beware if you are tall, then you might not be able to get comfortable.

Cultural and traditional. Despite the fact that I'm now an adult and I don't speak a word of Vietnamese, I really enjoyed the show. It's traditional and gives a great insight in the Vietnamese culture. The performances tell the story of Vietnam and its people and it's as valid as reading a book or visiting a museum, in order to understand this beautiful people.

Highlight of my trip in Hanoi. There's a lot of things that I don't like about Hanoi and this little gem was the highlight of my trip. No idea why previous visitors were either complaining that it is boring, it's only for kids or that they don't understand the language.Look, you are given a card of the rundown of the performances in ENGLISH. For eg: Frog catching. Do you need translation for the song or what was being performed? It's very straight forward segment about some farmers trying to catch frogs. Even a 2 year old can understand that without the need to translate the songs into various languages. As for boring - I spent time trying to figure out how they control the puppet and other tricks and wondered how it was done. Won't give it away to you guys who have yet to watch it.Lastly though, I wished they ban all these wannabe photographers who kept on using flash. There was this woman who was next to me, photographed the show non stop, rotating between her digital compact camera, DLSR and phone and the flash lights were irritating. Instead of looking back via pictures, people should learn to respect others and also try and live for the moment.

A good way to waste an hour. If you are under the age of 8, you will find the puppets, color and movement entrancing. You will have ample room in the seats, and not fear death in the event of an emergency. I attended with a friend and we paid extra for the seats with more room. I am not tall, but my knees had to be on an angle, and I still tipped the seat in front forward 10 degrees. We were about 15 rows back, which is a long way when the puppets are maybe 60 cm tall. The exit is more or less locked and concealed behind a black curtain during the performance, and extra chairs are placed in the access stairs, for that added degree of obstruction to exit. . The walls are timber coated in a gloss material, so this theatre meets my definition of a fire trap. The music and musicians were very good. There was no sur-titles or anything else in English, so I have no idea what the show was about, other than water dragons and water buffalos. In general it was a long way away, incomprehensible, and in theme reminded me of Postman Pat. We left after 15 minutes. A complete waste of time, do not under any circumstances attend a water puppet performance.

Fantastic Show!. I'd never seen a water puppet show, but this one was not only performed with expertise but also elicited shouts of approval from the spectators. The puppets are manipulated above the water from below, and the best scenes are ones showing a farmer battling a snake for a water rat--typical of what actual farmers did to survive when growing their rice plants. This puppet show depicts how one can live literally "under water."

enjoyed by parents and teenagers!. unique, entertaining, ice cream and coffee downstairs in aircon! reasonable price. comfortable.Book/buy ticket several hours early to ensure that you get the performance time that you want.

Water Puppet Theater. All in Vietnamese but still interesting. It helps to know some of the more famous fairy tales and myths for the region and if you google that in advance the shows will make more sense. Still, an entertaining night out. The seats are assigned so no need to queue and push with others. Go in last, go out last (and linger over the water puppets that are for sale - they sell the used ones here).

ok, but not worth going out of the way for. The show was OK, the puppets, colours and musicians were good, but I wouldn't go out of my way to see it. There is no explanation of the acts, so is quite hard to follow. End up spending 45 minutes sitting there not having a clue what's going on.

Weird but worth it. This is a must do in Hanoi, just to see what all the hype is about - but be prepared for a packed theatre, with little leg room (if you're tall, they might give you an aisle seat). Book early and avoid the rude crowds that bank up outside before each show.

WATER PUPPET PERFECTION. An important art form from this part of the country, this is the oldest continuing theatre for the performance - and without equal. Charming, beguiling, orchestra is breathtaking - a compelling hour of entertainment.

Good for the kid. This was pleasant for my 9 year old daughter & my hubby liked it to a degree too - but for me I couldn't have been more bored. It would help if I could understand the Vietnamese language. Many foreigners appeared to like it though... I left about 40 minutes into the show - it goes for an hour. Would rather take in the sights. I wouldn't go again - maybe if I was paid say $50 I would go & just try to sleep my way through it. I prefer the dentist chair to this...!
"a must see". Brilliant. a must see while in Hanoi. Very cleaver and entertaining.It pays to book your tickets in the morning or the day before as they sell out quickly.

This is something that you are not likely to see outside of Vietnam. This particular theatre is indoors and very popular so you will need to book. Basic folklore tails are told with music and water puppets. It helps if you know the background to the story, and these are not well explained but visually it is very interesting and colourful. We later saw and outside water puppet show, but this was better explained so we ended up with a greater understanding of what was happening in the show.

Worth seeing as a one off experience when in Hanoi. Peculiar but interesting. I was pleasantly surprised at how enjoyable and funny I found the performance. I would definitely recommend spending 45 minutes of your time in Hanoi to visit a performance, you are not going to see or experience anything like it anywhere else on your travels! Book your tickets as far as possible on advance as shows can be sold out if you just arrive shortly before performance times. Tip would be to get seats on the front few rows as seats are very cramped with leg room further back, less legroom than a ryanair flight!

Worth seeing!. This show is a bit weird - and probably a little long - but it's worth seeing. It's cute and interesting. You get a sense of what's important culturally to the Vietnamese people. If you're tall, try to get the front row. The seats have about 5 inches less leg room than an airplane!
great. nice and funny show, you can go there to buy ticket and for 1 hours for one show. If you come to hanoi you should to see it

Quite strange but charming. Shows cost 100k VND and last 50 minutes. There are about 12 scenes each taking a few minutes accompanied by live music. Although not in English, you will still laugh and smile at the show.Puppets will smoke, spray water and generally chase each other round. Very unique and very charming!

Good fun, but glad it was short. I thought this was a good little experience for the price. You don't need to pay extra to sit near the front. It was entertaining, but any longer than 45 minutes and I would have been looking at my watch a bit. The band are the best bit.

among the best experiences in Hanoi. After reading around a bit, and just the thought of puppetry didn’t give us any sense of excitement, however my wife and I decided to give it a try. We were shocked at how hilarious it was. Also, the show had a certain line of though which anyone could follow easily. The show is cleverly done and exotic, among the best we experienced in Hanoi! They have really managed to get into a lot of history in these 45 minutes, the parts are small stories with classical Vietnamese music. The chairs were not very comfortable but they definitely good enough for how long the show is.

Book in advance seats in the first rows. Don't get me wrong. The show is very interesting and the music artists simply amazing!Is the location which doesn't allows you to enjoy the performance. If you are not in first three rows, is almost impossible to see what's goin'on and understand in full the story.

Great show!. Tickets are relatively cheap at 50000 Dong. Show is spectacularly done with visual effects and fire, with the puppets floating on top of the water. Really something different from what one normally sees in a theater.

amazing. I was unsure about this when I booked the tickets but once the show started it was amazing. I enjoyed every minute of this event though you can't understand what is being said. Job well done to everyone who puts the show together.

Great Entertainment. I thought this was just swell. Musicians were very good and the puppetry gave a kind of slapstick view of traditional Vietnamese life and legend. Highlights were a Quagmire type character wearing a gold thong chasing a cheeky fox who was after his ducks. A fisherman choking on his pipe and a woman smacking a dude over the head with a fish net.The musicians sat to the side of the puppets and really brought the show to life, not only with their playing but also with their laughter as they genuinely appeared to enjoy the comedy moments of the show, despite no doubt having to do it 5 times a day for the whole of their living memory :)

Water .Theatre . You must see. Greeting from denmark. A place you just have to experience and a must when I am in Hanoi. I have been there 5 times and all was a great experience seering. It is experiences both children and adults. You see : Dragon dance , Buffalo fighting , buffoon teu..horse race .I have been in different places in the room and all seating provides good experiences.So do not leave Hanoi before you have seen this very special theatre.Water theatre was me totally unknown. Here in Denmark is no like this. So it was great and I carry it deep inside me. I`am back January next year.
Family entertainment in Hanoi. This was a fun place to have a rest in air conditioned environment after walking around the city.. Interesting experience, all in Vietnamese.
Not a must see. We booked in to see water puppets after others raved about it. Very disappointing show except for brilliant musicians. Your time would be better spent walking around the lake.

A tradition not to be missed. It doesn't matter that you don't understand the narration, this is a must see. The traditional puppets are a window on life in a rural society. It can be hard to get tickets, so plan ahead.

A different thing to do. A friend and I watched the show back in May and loved it! Nice stories telling you about the culture. Everything is said in vietnamese and English aswell. Definitely worth a visit.

Loved it!. The show was simply nice and interesting. It represents in a simple and spectacular way the Vietnamese lifestyle. The show includes Vietnamese music and songs. You cannot miss it if you go to Hanoi!!
Great show and price!. The show was great and the kids really enjoyed it too. We were all very impressed. I was surprised that some people left early as the show wasn't too long.
ok, if you have done every thing else first. Don't make it your must see, good to full in some time, very cleaver puppetry but glad it was only a short session. wouldn't do it again though.

An hour of my life that I'll never get back. Unfortunately I was convince to go along and see the Water Puppets. Colourful and clever (I guess), but mindnumbingly boring. Trapped mid theatre, I couldn't extricate myself without being obviously disrespectful. I sat and suffered for the entire performance. I can appreciate culture, but definitely in much smaller doses. In summary, .. there are a thousand and one things I would rather do in wondeful Hanoi.

Worth going for the Vietnamese experience. I am glad I went to get the experience of Vietnamese culture but once is enough. I got lost through the show as it is in vietnamese but I was in Vietnam. Leg room for a 6'3'' was cramped but acceptable.

Interesting for the first 3 minutes. The first 3 minutes were moderately interesting and amusing, but after that, it was literally the same thing over and over again for 45 minutes. The musicians were good, but in all honesty if you left after 5 minutes you would not be missing out on anything. Numerous people around me had fallen asleep during the performance. The seats are also uncomfortable for anyone over 5'10". It is, however, very cheap in comparison to shows in the UK.
Water Puppet show in Hanoi. Captivating story told using water puppets. Be sure to go early to book tickets - they sell out about 1/2 hour before the show starts.

Interesting theater experience. It was an interesting experiece as this was the first time that I had seen a water puppet show. The theater is located at teh very heart of the tourist district, just by the lake. The show is about an hour, but need to be there a little bit early as there is quite a que for the performances. We found the show to be relaxing and entertianing. Enjoyed the songs and music too.

afternoon seeing the water puppets. Not to be missed. After reading so much history about the water puppets it was great to finally see the show.Little cost to see show, seating comfortable.The performers top class
Hanoi Water Puppets. One of the best shows we have seen while on holiday in a foreign country, magnificent puppetry, great story told in a brilliant setting,absolutely loved it!

Well worth a visit...if you buy anything from the gift stand, make sure you get change!. Great experience- fun to watch and well worth the small admission fee. The lady at the gift stand after the show pocketed our change, but aside from (or partially because of)that it was a good evening's entertainment.

Water puppet theater Hanoi. Both my wife and myself found this a little boring and it seemed to drag on a little bit to long for us, the seating is not very comfortable and rather cramped, I am six feet four and my knees were pressed firmly against the seat in front and the seats are quite low also, I wouldn't say don't go but it wasn't for us.

Thang Long Water Puppet Theatre. The Water Puppet Theatre is a bit cheesy but it is a). unique and b). somewhere cool to sit and relax away from the oppressive heat experienced outside. Admission is by pre-booked ticket, not too expensive.

Unique and charming....an insight into Vietnamese culture and history!. Well worth it! This lively show will charm all ages. The music was terrific and having English translations on the screens above the stage was genius, making it all the more enjoyable.
Amazing.... Very creative in skill playing the puppets. Entertaining and will keeps u laughing. However the best sitting are the front few rows. If sit too far, very hard to see it clearly.

Quite different. We went to an early evening performance at the Water Puppet Theater and we were among many forign tourists which was a sign. I think it was a show more for the tourist market. I enjoyed the show but it was a little hard to follow I am not sure what I expected and I am not sure what we got either. It was a plesant hour and quite different experiance.

The art and craft of puppetry. Loved this show. I expected it to be pretty ordinary but it was mesmerising. There is something special about inanimate objects coming to life. You know they are not real but the people behind the scenes are skillful and dedicated to the craft (working all day in water no less) and make it all seem magical. I felt like I had gone back in time - small old theatre, wooden seats, crowds of people.
Appreciate this with an Open mind.. An appreciation of an Old Art Form. Low in entertainment value but a peek into traditional art-forms. Do appreciate the creativity that stems from the environment.

experience that you have to see once in your lifetime. sit back , relax and enjoy the show. yes you can pay extra to take photos or else you can just watch the whole show unfurl before your eyes. the singing and instrument playing are unique. Not sure if it was opera or folk singing but definitely unique. The seats are not posh, but you are only there for a reasonably short time so it does not matter.The skill of the people manning the puppets has to be seen to be believed, and soon you will be captured by the stories and the themes they are acting out - in water - up to their waist - with the puppets about a meter plus in front of them. yes it might seem commercial, but when you go home it is something that will come back to you again and again. go and see the show, it is an art form that will not last forever.

Interesting and amusing. I was looking forward to seeing this but was a little disappointed. Our seats were well up the back so unfortunately were not able to see the puppets as I would have liked. It would be wise to try and sit where you can get a better view of the puppets.

rewarding Cultural expereince. The puppet were great with interesting backdrops. Purchase ticket early and go for close to the stage. the venue is close to the West lake and it is enjoyable to stroll from the Old Quarter and the lake to the Venue. A must for any visitor that is interested in understanding the culture and history of this amazing country.
good fun. entertaining and amazed at how they work the puppets. Especially liked the water dragons spouting water, singing was good too

Must see. Have attended performances here twice and thoroughly enjoyed both of them. Plenty of showtimes to chose from so you can plan around them. The english translation may not always be good but who cares. Good price and value for money and you will be entertained.

So Glad We Went. Read about this on trip advisor before we left and put it on our places to visit list. So glad I did. A wonderfully entertaining show visually and mentally. Came out with a better understanding of the culture of Vietnam and its people.Would highly recommend this to all travellers

Water puppets. Great show, interesting scenery, translation in english is provided. Our daughter enjoyed also. A must see in Hanoi. Buy tickets early , and request front seats. It is crowded at the back of the theatre.

Way of knowing Vietnam's culture. The theater is conveniently located near the Old Quarter and Hoan Kiem Lake. It would be best if you buy tickets early in the day. The hall was big enough, however the chairs were clearly not built for tall people. The show was not that amazing, but, nevertheless, it was a good way of knowing the history of Vietnam. Note: additional charge for those who wants to take photos and videos during the performance.

Excellent and unique show! You must go for it!. During our honeymoon, in Vietnam, we visited this amazing country from south to north.On our first stop, in Ho Chi Minh City we tried to attend to the Water Puppet Show, but on dates that we will be staying on the city, the show wouldn't take place.So, on our last day in Vietnam, more specifically in Hanói, we didn't want to loose the show!We bought tickets early, yet in the afternoon, and then we returned, at night to attend the show.This is a show who reflects the story of Vietnam, its culture and arts, the richness of vietnamese people and the uniqueness of this country.It's a very different show, that, undoubtly deserves your attention.We absolutly loved The Water Puppet Show!This is our last memory from Vietnam, and it's a great one!
Really surprising. Very entertaining. It is best described as watching a magic show in the water. Great fun and cheap, makes for something very different to see.

Unique puppet show. We were told this was the original puppet theatre in Vietnam. It was conveniently located near the Old Quarter and the show was only 45 minutes, but well worth it. There are TV screens that provide an English translation of the story that is portrayed by the puppets and that made it more enjoyable and interesting.

Suprisingly good fun. This is a great potted history of the mythology and culture of Vietnam. Think Thunderbirds meets synchronised swimming.(lol) Really great to hear such good live music supporting the puppets. The main singer was enjoyed by whole party.

Buy tickets early. I incidentally bought my ticket quite early, so was right up the front. It was great being so close to see the details of the puppets and the puppetry. Glad it was only 45 minutes, as I can imagine it could get a bit boring. Overall, very cultural and interesting. I'm glad I went. Value for money.

Must see for tourists. I've been in Hanoi a few times and finaly planned a trip to waterpuppet theater. It was a wonderful experience, especially suitable for kids but nice for adults anyway. They sing live in Vietnamese, but you'll understand the meaning by watching only.Be sure to buy your tickets early (e.g. 2h before show and spend the time in Old Quarter) because there are also big tourist-groups coming by bus.One star less because seats are very small for people with long legs and show is quite short (50~60min).

Don't Miss It, despite your skepticism. The water puppets have universal appeal. The theatre is lovely and the shows continuous, and well organized. The puppets are lovely, the antics fluid and jaw dropping beautiful. Despite the language barrier, these tales are universal and very, very funny. It is a must see...no matter what your level of sophistication.

Water Puppets Rock. This place makes each performance of this ancient art lively and impressive. That is quite a trick, since they must run shows every hour and yet never get stale. The color, folk drama, and earthy humor make it come alive and transcend language. It is a real treat and I came away excited, although I entered with skepticism.

What a waste of time. It was so boring. I almost slept through all the performance. The English translation is also not good as I didn't understand almost all of it. It's a better idea to watch Water puppet in Japan. And I fell like the show don't respect the guest att all @@

Tourist trap but good fun. A tourist conveyor belt, but culturally significant. Theatre is right opposite the lake. Many shows run through the afternoon/evening but book early if you only have limited time in Hanoi. It's cheap and runs for about 45 minutes. Great music and singing from the orchestra. Would love to see the theatre spruced up a bit. Looks a bit tatty. It's a complete scrum once the performance is over so watch your possessions and try to avoid taxi drivers/cyclo drivers/souvenir sellers and traffic on leaving!

Fun for the Whole Family. A lovely little theatre with a great show. If you haven't seen water puppets before this a good place to see them. The puppeteers do a great job telling the stories with the help of the orchestra and singers.

Excellent show - terrible seats for tall people. Great example of Vietnamise water puppet theatre that captivated the audience. Spectacular and unique event that should nt be missed.The seating has been designed for locals and was terrible for tall people. Despite this I would recommend the show.

was good to watch the show. It was good to watch the performance at first. Everything seemed to be new. They were narrating about some history about Vietnam with a touch of some sort of love story. It was amazing to actually see how they did it. It was my first time to see that kind of performance in the water, but on the middle of the show, it was kinda boring for me. Some parts were just the same. To top it all, it was okay, a good way to kill some time. It's worth the price though.

Worth a look. I read some reviews before I went here, and I think some whilst harsh, are fair. The show in itself is great, I like the culture behind it, the work that goes in to it, the skill of the people controlling the puppets. I would highly recommend going to see it, here is what I'd warn you of though. People with cameras don't care who is around them, they will block your view and blind you in there efforts to take photos. One extremely rude lady and her husband blocked my view at every opportunity, for me, cameras should be banned, watch the show and leave the cameras in the bag.

like being at the circus .... Have never experienced such a performance and we really enjoyed it. It only cost 5 dollars u.s. and such a good way to spend an hour. Live music performed superbly with commentary (in Vietnamese) and the water puppet show itself . It's a must see if your visiting Hanoi....

Don't miss it!. We loved the water puppet show, it was so cute. It was only about 50 minutes long but so worth the price. The music was great, it was in Vietnamese but you can figure out what is going on, it was done in short skits. So worth the $5 entry fee.

Interesting cultural experience. I went to the water puppet theatre in September while travelling in Vietnam, and I must say it is worth a visit. I mean there is nothing extraordinary, but apparently water puppet shows are "very vietnamese", and even though you don't understand what they sing, it is nice to see the performance of all those puppets dancing and fighting over the water... the colours, fire, songs, it makes it an interesting experience. They give out leaflets, so you know what's going on in each performance, e.g. a puppet returning a sword to the turtle god... it's cute and I bet children would love it. It's amazing how they control those puppets, it looks like they are doing everything on their own!

A good way to kill some time or catch a nap.. Performance is in local language. The seats are very tight. Cost wise, does it really matter, not that expensive in the first place. Had to get tickets two days in advance for what we wanted.If you have some time, check it out, i enjoyed this for 20-30 minutes before it got a tad boring.

Water Puppet Show. We went to see the International Water Puppet Show. The theatre was full and the show is about 45min. The music and the show was great. Couldn't always understand what they was saying, but was a great experience. Money well spend.

amazing. a 50 minute show with incredible performance, the team is able to do "miracles" with the puppets.
it worth the visit, by far the best part of our first day in Ha Noi.
the cost is around USD 5.

Amazing water puppet show. I like it all, the performance, the singing & the music. There are lots of skills involved.
It will be better if there is a briefing in English before the start of the show.

Definitely worth going.. What an interesting show. Very funny in some spots. Haven't seen anything like this before and it was very well done. This was our second trip to Vietnam and we did the puppet show both times.

Very good cultural show. If you want to a quick insight into the Vietnamese culture, this is the show for you. They have a traditional instrument orchestra that opens the show on their own and then provides the music for the show. The idea of puppets in water was new to me and I really enjoyed it. The puppeteers told the story of how Vietnam was made by the dragon and then acted out the traditions of the tribes and villagers. You can also buy copies of the puppets. The seats are cheap and they perform 4 shows a day (afternoon and night). I'm not usually a puppet type of person however I enjoyed this show.

Great but we were cheated on the ticket office. Water Puppet show were so nice and we enjoyed very much, but the goal of this review is give an advise to people who are going to buy the tickets.We tried to buy tickets on september the 22nd to go the 24th, but the staff told us that we would have to buy the same day. We came back on 24th morning and the girl told us that they had run off cheap tickets (60000 VND) and they offered without asking a 100000 VND ones.. So we were aware of that, we insisted in buy 60000 ones and with a very bad mood she gave it us.It is a very common trick tall customers that they have not 60000 VND tickets, so be aware!
puppets. what a great show, the music and song and spectacle were great. well worth the 100000 dong a ticket ($5-00) AUD.

Worth every penny!. We had the most amazing time at this show today, would thoroughly recommend for anyone visiting Hanoi! We arrived at the ticket office an hour before a show and were able to get second row tickets (we did opt for the more expensive ticket to be closer to the front 100VMD instead of the standard 60VMD) for the next show which we had not expected, so just sat in the neighbouring cafe and enjoyed a traditional Vietnamese coffee to pass the time until the start of the show. It would be even better if there had been a little more English to explain what was going on, but even not understanding the language you understood what was going on. The live musicians were fantastic and the puppeteers true masters! :-) Both me and my boyfriend are quiet tall, but surprisingly found the seats comfortable with enough leg room. I would definitely say, just enjoy the show and don't bother with cameras, or if you must then be courteous to others. We were very lucky in our showing but I heard from other people that flashes were going off all the time and they could not see the show for cameras.Best money we have spent so far in Vietnam! :-)

Some Grand Music indeed!. We had a great time listening to the wonderful concert. It was indeed a unique experience to hear the poems being narrated in the form of songs and performers dancing in tune to the same. Everything was in perfect melody! It was fun to learn how to beat the drums; we had a gala time doing the same. The water puppets were so beautifully presented that I wish that show continued for more time. Surely a great place to visit for any cultural enthusiast!

A spectacle to behold. The water puppet show was a spectacle to behold with its live accompaniment, colors, and lights. The performers really put their heart and soul into giving a good show to the audience. The puppets were attached to long wooden sticks and were maneuvered by people hidden behind the wooden curtains. The puppets can only do so much though. Although I can’t say that it is the most amazing thing I’ve seen, I love how they tried to show their culture and beliefs through the music and the movements of the puppets. The performance still merits an applause for their creativity and showmanship.

A unique performance. Enjoyed the performance and the music. The English translation of the various stories and songs really helped to understand what the performers standing in the water and handling the puppets were doing.
Worth doing. Really enjoyed this. Very different and worth an hour. Try and get seats at the front if you can. Very colourful, good music, great costumes.

Absolute waste of time!! People falling asleep.. Don't even bother with this. We only went as it was one of the "top" attractions to do. Became extremely boring after the first 3mins. Saw alot of people asleep not even half way through.
People in the theatre were continuously taking photos with flash on which was extremely annoying as well.

OK, I've been here about 10 times now!. For 80.000 for the "cheap seat" or 100.000 for premium seating ($4 and $5 US), you can spend another 20.000 for the privilege to take photos or movies.I first came here in May, 2012 and almost half of the time that I came to Ha Noi from Thai Binh Provence, 120 KM from Ha Noi (where I lived). The first show fascinated me. The music, very traditional, was mesmerizing. Watching the puppets in the water, well choreographed, presented aspects and stories of Vietnamese folklore, mythology and culture. Various regions and ethnic groups (there are, I think, 56 ethnic groups in Viet Nam) were represented.Where this art form originated was in the field where water-grown rice is worked. The water is usually only about a couple of feet deep at the most. Somewhere, someone put up lanterns , put puppets on long sticks and had a cast of water marionettes to move them around in the water. Certainly, the first puppets were quite primitive with no moving parts. As time went on, different small animations were added: arm and tail movement, turning heads, all rather repetitive, but which could be done in rhythm to the music.There are actually three shows (an hour or so each) in their repertoire that are rotated every two yeRs. So far, I have had the privilege to see two of them. In another 16 months, I will get to see the third!This is very enjoyable. They sell CDs of the music . I don't remember the price, but the price for each is about $10 US (200.000 VND or less).You can't miss,but you should get reservations ahead of time during the tourist high season (not in September or during the cold months from late December to mid-February). You may ant to arrange with your agent and hotel to get you tickets at the times you would like, from the afternoon until late evening. If you are backpacking or going it alone, you will need to go to the ticket office on your first day and get tickets when convenient for you. The theater, if looking at a map, is off of the NW corner of Hoan Kien Lake at the Old Quarter.

entertainment. Brilliant!!! very very clever the way they handled the marionettes. If we had known what the story was about it would have helped to understand it more, it is all narrated in Vietnamese.

Tourism at it's worst. 100's of tourists packed like sardines in undersized seats taking flash photos and talking throughout a lackluster, repetative and tedious presentation of this ancient art. It could have been good. But it wasn't. Shame on the organizers for exploiting the artists.
So different!!!. Great show-very different with a story-just a touch too long at about 45 mins although the air conditioned theatre was a lovely relief!!!
Interesting Entertainment, must see.. If you are in Vietnam, you should see a show of Water Puppet. It's about one hour long, cost about $4 to $5, and it's their culture. Highly recommended!

Nice Relaxing Puppet Show. Water Puppet show with Live Music and Singing - TV's show English Subtitles. This is a good way to spend an hour in Hanoi and you can read the subtitles so that you can understand what's being said. We paid the extra to sit in the front rows but that didn't help me too much as I had a tall camera happy man sitting in front of me not taking any notice of anyone else. My only criticism is the seating could be better so you can easily see over peoples heads in front. Other than that the puppets and music are good.

Slightly dissapointed. I was slightly disappointed at this performance. It was okay, but not great. First 10 minutes are impressive, but then it becomes bit too much of the same, over and over. And turists using flash cameras are bit annoying element (people - please turn off flash!!!). On the other hand, while 5 USD/person is a hefty price for Vietnam, in most countries, it would be considered a bargain I guess. I'm not regretting going there, but I wouldn't go for a second show

Good performance. The show was a pleasent way to spend an hour in the early afternoon. English intro, with the performance and singing in Vietnamese. The puppetry was very clever, and we got a few good laughs out of it. The theater is air conditioned and comfortable, if a little cramped. The downside would have to be the 100,000d entry price ($5), most other tourist attractions in Hanoi were 10,000/20,000d and the sense that you were being herded through the experience like cattle. Souvenirs were available in the lobby with the expected inflated prices. Worth it if your in the area, but not one i would go out of my way for.

If you have the time.... It's a tradition, the show is only 45 minutes, and the price is less than $5 US, so if you're in the area and have the time, you should check it out. Probably more fun if you have kids. Definitely the most interesting part for me was watching the musicians playing traditional instruments.

good for pre dinner entertainment. went to this show after reading tour brochure. Only 45 mins long, but really enjoyed the music and the clever puppeteers - you have to pay extra to take photo's which you don't have to do in Saigon, but many people paid for the privilege, which I felt spoilt it a little as there was constant flashing of cameras. Good cultural experience

Worth a visit. This is certainly an experience and whilst interesting and very clever, I would not visit again. The theatre is nice, the show is very cleverly done. The music and narration are entertaining. However, the highlight of the show is the young lady who plays the traditional Vietnamese instrument. I am sure there are more than one but on the day we went the young lady was one of the most beautiful women I have ever seen with an amazing smile. All four of our party could not take our eyes off her and her amazing smile - we all thought that she was singing and playing to us as individuals, especially the only male member of our party - my husband! She is stunning!

Just OK. If you're in Hanoi and want some culture, I think the Puppet Show is a good idea. I wouldn't go out of my way to see it, but at ~$5 USD, you can't go wrong. Get drinks beforehand and it'll be really funny. It's also very short, which is good because I don't think I could have stayed for much longer.

Boring! Show did not meet expectation. The show was recommended in our travel guide so we decided to go there before dinner. The tickets were very affordable but one has to pay extra to take pictures. Our guide book showed pictures with a nice stage design (temple, palm, ...) but it turned out to be just a grey curtain, nothing more. The puppetiers behind the curtain did a good job, although I would not describe them as very skilled or extraordinary. I think everybody can do this job with some practice. Not comparable with real artists or dancers on stage or other puppetiers (e.g. Augsbuger Puppenkiste, Germany).Overall the show was quite boring and both my wife and I almost fell asleep. We suggest to skip this part of Hanoi and better spend the money in a bar at the corner watching the Vietnamese street life. Much more interesting and you won't get bored even after 5+ hours...:)

A must see so clever. This is so clever how they operate the puppets. They tell the story of Vietnam and there is a screen at the side with translation in english. I went to the 3:15 showing and got an excellent seat. The two children aged about 3, sitting near me were mesmerised. A small band plays live music for the performance. Theatre very easy to find very close to the lake.

OK but not a must do. We were full of good intentions for this show and the first few minutes were entertaining. However, the local music and language is not particularily made for western ears. When we got to the third sketch, it started to always look alike from one number to the other. Almost everyone in our party fell asleep.I will tell my friends that if they need to miss an activity in Hanoi, this is it.

Enjoyable. This was a show I really enjoyed! It wasn't dull even for a moment. We had excellent seats in the second row. Kept wondering how they managed the puppets so well in water! Really worth a visit

Interesting but do not understand the story line. We went for the puppet show. It was interesting how the puppeteers made the puppets come alive but as the whole show was in local language, as a tourist, I have no idea what the story is about. Only able to make out some of it from the brochure taken from outside the theater.Overall, it is a good experience. Recommend to get VIP seats at USD$10 per person. You will get better view since you will be seated in front and you just need to arrive 10mins before any of the 5 showtimes to purchase your tickets from the ticket booth. You can also find lots of eateries and the night market near the theater. Have fun!
Good experience. The whole family enjoyed the puppet show, although there was the obvious language barrier as the majority of the show was in Vietnamese. Well worth the experience.Recommend a visit.

Water Puppet Theater. Really enjoyed the water puppet performance in Hanoi. Puppeteers are fantastic in what they do and puppets are colourful and tell their story well. I would like to take my nieces and nephews as I think they would also love it. I also enjoyed learning how water puppet theatre came about. The singers and music accompanying the puppets was also fantastic.

Unique and quite entertaining. This theater is located near the lake and easily reached on foot from the Old Town.The show is about 45 minutes. There are several show timings every day. You can go to the theater and purchase the ticket in advance for a particular time of your choice if the seats are available. I do not remember its cost but I think it was around US $3. The show is accompanied by the music in the local language. I found it quite enjoyable even though I did not understand the language.The stage is actually a water pool. The far end of the pool has a vertical curtain. The puppeteers maneuver the actions of the puppets from behind the curtain.Various characters in the puppet form are shown doing different things. All of them floating on the surface of pool water.At the end of the show, all performers maneuvering the puppets come to the pool with colorful lamps.The show is good for all age.Try to book a seat on the first raw so you can take pictures.
Touristy thing to do. No regrets!. Our group ranged in age from 4 to 68 and everyone was entertained. Traditional music and a neat puppet show. It was a nice way to cool off on a hot day!

Nice to see but not essential. Dont have great expectations and you will enjoy it. It is quite cute and interesting enough for 45mins, and really very cheap. Do it if you can but don't worry if you miss it.

Water Puppet Show. The theater was clean.. I never seen a pool on the stage. Every seat can see the stage. The seats are soft enough for you but if you are tall you will have a hard time with your knees hitting the front chair. Good thing no one sat in front of me.The show was very nice. I never seen this before. It is very inexpensive you must go see it. It is about 45 mins. The music and songs are very ancient and help bring you into time. a must see.

So Unique!. While on tour in Hanoi, we had the pleasure of going to the Thang Long Water Puppet Theater. It was a real treat to see the mastery of the puppeteers! The music was really nice, too. The puppet show was remarkable. The only drawback was the theater staff allowed guests to use their cell phones to snap pictures. People were even taking videos which was a real distraction from the artistry of the puppet show members.

Great cultural experience.. Traveling to any destination one wants to sample something full of local flavor and connected with the history and culture of the visited area. Thang Long Water Puppet Theater is exactly that - part of history and culture of Vietnam. The tradition comes from the villages of the Red River Delta area and goes back to 11th century.The show is fairly interesting and our performance was translated to English so we were able to follow the story lines. The puppets are in a sense art objects themselves. A traditional Vietnamese orchestra provides background music for the show. The puppeteers appear in the end of the show.The theater itself is a nice building with a bar/restaurant area in the foyer - a busy, bustling place prior to the show.Tickets are very inexpensive and can be purchased before the show, but do it earlier if you want the best seats of front rows.

Good way to spend a rainy afternoon.. It was raining in Hanoi and we decided to see the water puppet show to stay dry for an hour. The music was very good and I liked the way the girls tell you about the history in Vietnamese and there are English subtitles. The puppets are not as good as I was hoping but nonetheless are a 1000 year old tradition. It's worth a visit but don't miss out on something else in order to do this, go on a rainy afternoon like we did and have an open mind. Incidentally we were not charged to take photos.
Quaint. A visit to see the water puppets is almost compulsory isn't it. It is a good experience. I liked the connection of music, culture and theatre.

A boring "must" thing to see. The show was something I've never seen before. It's kind of a must thing you should experience but I have to tell you that, It was boring. I fell asleep about 15 mins after the show starts. LOL sorry..

Bizarre but part of Hanoi charm. The water puppet theatre is strongly marketed in Hanoi - to the extent that you feel obliged to go. Why it is done in water remains a mystery but it tells quite an interesting story of the ancient history of Vietnam. HAlf way through you may wonder why you bothered!!

Very beautiful - talented performers. This was a lovely experience, despite having to pay an extra few dollars to take photos (as well as ticket price!), it's stunning to see talent of the puppeteers!
Water puppets. Very entertaining although was very hot and stuffy inside. Would go again. Very popular with the locals.

Well worth the visit. Our hotel got use great first row center seats that only cost $4! Very well performed with live orchestra and singers, English translation and explanation is shown on large flat screens on the sides so there is no problem in understanding the story being portrayed. Colorful puppets and interesting musical accompaniment.
Cute and entertaining!. We loved the Water Puppets! The show is very interesting and unique. It certainly tells a story, and is worth the visit! Especially great for kids!!!
Tedious although clever!. First show in the town so jet lag may have affected judgement but personally found this show excruciating.

Very different and interesting. This show runs 5 times a day, 7 times a week. So you will undoubtedly be able to get a ticket. When we went it cost 100,000 dong for the 'good' seats which are close to the front. The puppeteers are obviously well practised, but the puppets looked like they'd seen a lot of wear and tear. It's a very well orchestrated affair and lasts about an hour. Explanations of what's happening in each scene is shown on a projector screen. It's all accompanied by traditional vietnamese music. My partner is very tall (6'4"), and so couldn't fit in the seats. But the usher kindly gave him a chair in the aisle to sit on.
Nice show. Its a nice show, a must watch show in Hanoi.A traditional water puppet show, with interesting story line.Ticket priced at 60,000 Vietnam Dong. Duration about 45mins - 1hour

Good fun.. The famous water puppet show, very popular with tourists and locals alike, but unfortanety we went the day of ARRIVAL in Hanoi after a 14 hour flight and were jet lagged.Unfortunately 3 out of 4 of us nodded off half way through. What I saw looked good though.
Unique!. I wanted to see this because I saw a special about it on TV. I think kids would like it & it was interesting. We added it to our Walking Food Tour & highly recommend that tour!
Interesting show. I was impressed how they can control the puppet and make it a wonderful performance. One way to know the culture and history of Vietnam.

Wonderful show. The Thang Long Water Puppet night show was an interesting experience in Hanoi.
If you have the time, get there earlier, or leave a little bit later to check the puppet museum with a lot of pieces at display.
The music and the overall show was very interesting and a relaxing experience after an exciting day.

If you want a cheeky nap or shelter from the heat go otherwise don't bother. My partner and I went here on recommendations of TA. This show is a joke...During the show 7 people on the our row alone were asleep snoring and about ten people get up and left. The show was dull and at most laughable in places at how bad it was. We had more fun trying to spot the sleeper. The staff were not helpful or friendly especially in the booking office. We felt is was a waste of money and time. The puppets weren't in sync with each other and the music was repetitive. For a show which is performed three times a day you'd think they would be able to manage to be organized. Well thought we would be able to learn more about Vietnam culture but no which was a shame as we were looking forward to this. Oh well... perhaps in HCMH

Good experience and story. Don't get fooled into buying expensive tickets (the lady will try to convince you that the view is terrible, etc.), just pick some from the cheaper rows, it's small enough that the extra 5 meters won't do much difference, plus, once the show starts everyone shuffles down to the free seats at the lower levels. The show was great, with live music and narration, the story was great as well as it gave me a bit more insight regarding the history of Vietnam! It was also a great "resting" place in air conditioning from the heat outside as well!

Problems. Quite a lot has changed since I first saw this institution 17 years ago. The venue is a new air-conditioned theatre, complete with screens for sur-titles and high quality lighting, sound and even effects like dry ice. The puppets themselves are the same quaint, wooden marionettes controlled via underwater strings and rigs, but the show's content seems to have changed too; instead of tales from the rice paddies we get a Vietnamese creation myth and episodes incorporating the country's ethnic minorities. It feels as though some government ministry has swept through and insisted on tweaking the content to make it even more wholesome and nationalistic, as if that had been necessary.But my biggest problem was the behaviour of the audience. People not only chatted through the performance as if they were at the pub, many used the iPads and DSLRs indiscrimately, and with flashes, as if watching the performance was immaterial - all that mattered was creating a record of the fact that they came. No matter if holding their screens up and using bright flashes in the dark auditorium affected others' enjoyment of the performance. Worse, they were doing this with the approval of the venue, who charge a fee for the right.
Not for me. I wouldn't go back, in fact I nearly fell asleep. Would be good for children. Orchestra were very talented.

Weird but wonderful in its own way.. A strange evening's entertainment by western standards but you should go anyway - it's a classic part of Vietnamese history and culture, and ties in with the outdoor water puppet theatre seen at the Museum of Ethnology. Extraordinary and colourful, with (like it says on the tin) carved wooden puppets in a massive pool in a theatre, illustrating tales from vietnamese history. Go on, you know you want to.
So so!. Very nice design but very small to see. I though just only near distance but the stage is quite small.

A must when in Hanoi. Although you are maybe not immediately attracted to go seeing a “puppet” show this ancient performance is a must when in Hanoi. The performance is perfectly done in various languages and attractive for young and old. So why write more ….. you have to witness it yourself.

You need to visit. I got dragged along to this show kicking and screaming by my friend, and I grudgingly admit that I enjoyed it more than I expected. The puppetry is well done. The story is explained with an English translation as it depicts parts of Vietnamese life. I enjoyed the puppets, with all their flaws and would recommend that when in Hanoi you visit this theatre. The show is only 45 minutes, but you will get a laugh. Enjoy!

When in 'Nam.... This is a real cultural experience, like going to the acrobatics in Beijing it is an important aspect of the Vietnamese culture and much more interesting than I was expecting.The photography is not very well regulated, costing $1 for the opportunity to take photos on top of the ticket price...but not enforced, I was able to take photos without any members of staff being in the theatre to stop me. This did occasionally detract from the experience; clearly people who have paid their dollar use the flash throughout. Perhaps a ban on flash photography would be better?The programme and commentary on the tv screens is useful, but they need a better translator into plain English!
Very impressive puppetry. Great way to take some relief from the heat and enjoy a great show. The kids loved it, and provides great background on the history of Vietnam.

Ancient entertainment. It was good to see this show and get an idea of what was entertainment back in the old days. the seats were uncomfortable and it started heating up. The tickets sell very quickly to the show. We paid a little bit more for the A grade tickets and really dont see what the difference there was.

This was excellent... Really!. Despite all the horrible reviews, we went (half drunk) for a laugh at a minimum and were surprised. Really clever, ive never seen anything like it before and definitely worth the $5 to get in.. Only downside is the seats are tiny and i mean tiny. No seriously, tiny. But its for 50 mins so you can suck it up. Oh and they allow photography etc inside which is nice until you get stupid tourists and their GIANT camera with the flash on FULL. Some b***ch behind me totes ruined it. I hope she got food poisoning. Other than that a nice way to spend an afternoon in Hanoi... (Lets face it, theres not much else to do)

Hokey but delightful. The water puppets are one of the few genuinely Vietnamese treats; the current version tends to concentrate on folklore and dances while the music is performed live, fronted by three Vietnamese ladies. It's as well to try not to sit behind a row of youngsters waving their cellphones around to get pictures.....

Entertaining and educational!. The water puppet show was one of the more cultural things our group saw in Hanoi, and I think it's fair to say we all enjoyed it! The seats are designed for tiny Vietnamese people so stick to the aisles if you're taller than 5'8. The show lasts about an hour and it's demonstrative of Vietnamese culture and everyday life so it's really interesting. Pretty cheap too so why not!

"Worth Watching". Its all about Vietnam's culture and everyday life.. The show last about 1 hour. There are about 5 different stories which they will sung in Vietnamese with an english translation on a nearby screen.The classical orchestra played their part very well, including the person whom are handling the puppets on water.Perfect place to spend your time..Worth watching it. We loved it so much since this is our 1st time watching puppet show play in the water.

Water Puppets. Seeing the water puppets is a nice and interesting but not extraordinary experience. The 'show' lasts about an hour and tells five different stories of vietnam's every day life like fishing, dancing, myths etc. The music is life by a classical orchestra, little texts explain the scene in english and french.
Great experience. I really enjoyed this show, the people are very skilled and the music and show itself were beautiful.Great evening well spent, everyone should see it at least once!

It's worth seeing it once. I went at the last minute to the first show of the day and it was an interesting show. I was able to get a ticket quite easily and I actually got a good seat. The seats are quite small so it can be a bit uncomfortable. Also when you try to enter the theater is a bit chaotic, there is a huge line to the restroom and I was a bit lost at first. The show was cute, I thought that the puppets would be bigger but the show was good. I wouldn't come back and see a show but it was fun to see it once.

Hmm... is OK for once in life. It's more like children's shows theatre, well... the Spanish tourist next to me is fall to sleep during the show ! 100.000dong for the entrance fee, I appreciate the AC but the chair are far too small... no place to put your legs in front

A joke! Give it a wide berth. The only upside to this show was the respite it offered from the hot and humid late afternoon sun! Not to be disrespectful to the ancient art of water puppetry but this really left me wondering what's the point. Artistically the presentation is average, the mini sketches are a bit corny and overall there is limited reason to applause as you never get to the point of excitement or hit a WOW factor. In fact my husband nearly fell asleep! That being said we enjoyed the aftermath and chatting about it with our kids several evenings on our holiday and it always produced some laughs. Sorry but I wouldn't recommend

WATER PUPPETS!. There's no more to say. It's Vietnam. It's Water Puppets. Of course you're going. The stories are sung in Vietnamese, but helpfully translated on a nearby screen into English. Some stories are amazing (Dragon & Phoenix) and others just so so (courtship). But Vietnam is the only place with water puppets, so it's a must see. I loved it.

Breathtaking and spell-bindingly exquisite entertainment. 45 minutes of breathtaking and spell-bindingly exquisite entertainment marred by too many selfish (Western) theatre-goers using blinding flash photography, chatting amongst themselves or holding-up tablet computers to video proceedings obscuring the view for people sitting behind. Tip - you need to book in 1-2 days advance unless you're happy with the less popular 9.15pm performance.
very clever. absolute skill displayed by the operators must have taken years to learn was just right amount of time to sit in those little seats

Try to book seats in advance if possible. The puppet show lasts about one hour and it is broken down into a number of small camios which are explained on screens at each side of the 'stage'. If you can it is best to get a seat as close to the front as possible because there are lots of insensitive people who don't seem to care about obstructing your view. Consequently try to book seats in advance if possible.

Get a ticket it's not like anything else. Not having prepared for this visit we were not really sure what to expect, the music is local and super, the puppets all in water tell a wonderful story and the air conditioned theatre is comfortable, worth getting the more expensive ticket to get closer to the water. If you want to take photos or video you can but need to pay a supplement only a dollar or so.

Worth much more than 100,000VD. it was a different show altogether, its not your normal puppet show, the live music that accompanies it is great. and the effort that the people put into it are incredible. i have no idea why people would walk out on the show, its not like it was expensive, and there is live music and a culture of the people. it was fun to watch. in my opinion they could have asked for more.... :P

A 'must see'. Very enjoyable show, very cleverly done & extremely well performed. There is air conditioning inside which made watching the show more comfortable & a welcome relief from the temperature outside. You are allowed to video the performance, but have to pay a fee of 90,000 VND. However, this does not appear to be enforced. There are performances throughout the day.

Unique and entertaining. The building is not big but can be seen from distance. The tickets cost 60k (back rows) and 100k dong (front rows).I enjoyed the show but I can tell that some of the other audiences didn't enjoy as much as I did, especially those who are tall. There wasn't enough space for leg between the seats.

Amateur and boring. Obviously when you go to a show in Hanoi, you don't expect a top quality production like you'd get in London or on Broadway, but amateurish way this was put together made it, for me, a complete waste of time. The music can be charming from time to time, but on the whole is quite mundane, but I think it would probably be quite hard to put passion into music that the performers play 4 times a day every single day.Others I've spoken to who attended a performance say they've either slept or just found it hilariously bad. I wouldn't go that far, but I would advise you save both the time and money and find something else.

Good show - not too long. If you are in Vietnam you have to do a water puppet show. It was good to see and the music was probably the best part. It goes for around 30 minutes which is long enough. Would recommend trying to get a seat close to the front as we were up the back and found it a little difficult to see.It's not mind blowing, but was good to see. Ps. Thought it was a bit cheeky asking you to buy a camera/photo ticket so you can take photos!
Water puppet show. Colorful puppetry on water, tells a story about how the different tribes were born. Good performance with traditional musical instruments and classical singing.

Good but as short as the leg room. Well this is most interesting to go and watch and unlike anything that I have seen before. The music that accompanies the performance is also lovely and I enjoyed that equally. Tickets are 60k Dong for the cheap seats at the back and 100k dong for the front rows. Personally unless you are short sighted there is no real need to pay the 100k. The performance is only 45 minutes so very short. There is also more leg room in Easyjet cargo! I am 6 foot 2 and I couldnt put my legs together but had to sit either 'side saddle' or with me legs spread! So in the end I was quite happy it was only 45 minutes!
Puppet show. Excellent show, very clever. Glad it wasnt too long. Learnt about Vietnam. ood for families. Located near the Lake. It was a good price.

Boring. We went to the water puppet show because it came highly recommended on tripadvisor. Although the performers are highly skilled we found it extremely boring. The musicians are amazing in their craft but can be monotonous. There was also a man seated in front of me, blocking my view from the show. Luckily it is only a half an hour show. I would not recommend this to everyone.

Family Attraction. A unique family and all-age attraction. It's a must when you are in Hanoi. The large screen and translation help the audience members understand what is going on throughout the scenes. Our family learned a lot about Vietnamese culture, life and history from the show. Seating arrangement is a little cramped. Don't forget to book your tickets ahead of time.
loud. Entertaining but oh so loud and the Vietnamese people really enjoy it. The gardens where wonderful and the monument in the garden was amazing.

Unique, entertaining and highly skilled. The water pupet theatre was very entertaining, and easy to follow with the accompanying slide show on screem, combined with some english commetary. The excellent singing and orchestra complemented a unique experience.Well worth taking the time to see.

Not for me. I arrived in Vietnam the day before my visit to the Water Puppet Theatre and therefore was enthusiastic and fully refreshed for this visit. The show commenced at 5pm with the Theatre itself resembling that of a normal Picture Theatre. Upon arrival, I found out that if you wanted to take photos,it would cost a fee. Although only $1, I was a little taken aback.In fact, I think I only took 3 photos as sitting up towards the back of the Theatre, I was to far away to get good shots,plus I felt using a flash would be distracting to those around me. Once the show got under way,I settled back to enjoy the entertainment. Although interesting for the first 15 minutes or so, I soon lost interest as it became rather repetitive. Sitting up towards the back probably didn't help,as it seemed you needed binoculars to see the finer art of the puppetry.Anyway,the show finished just under an hour which to my way of thinking was about 30 minutes too long. I have no doubt the costumes,carpentry,skills of the performers/operators was first class but it just wasn't my scene.Maybe it was the 65 year old male in me coming out! I was with a tour group which comprised about 25-30 people of mixed sexes, and I believe the consensus of quite a number,particularly the males that they shared my views,and perhaps we could have spent our time elsewhere. By the way,the Theatre was air conditioned.

Unique but needs a complete facelift. Definitely a unique show but disappointing as it could do with work on its choreography and is in need of new puppets. The music, musicians and musical instruments were unique and fabulous. I had a 2nd row seat and was trying very hard not to fall asleep after the first 15 minutes. The story lines (translated onto a TV screen during the show) were vague and all the performances blended into each other. The hour long show seemed never ending! Costs only $6, so was worth the visit for its uniqueness, though I wish I could have sneaked out after the first 15 minutes without appearing rude! This show would probably be most enjoyed by very young children. I felt badly for the water puppeteers as the enthusiasm in the audience was low.

Great show - horrible audience. Eventhough we have seen another water puppet show in a village on our Vietnam trip, I really loved the water puppet theatre in Thang Long theatre. The musicians where great, the puppets where more colourful than on the other show we have seen. And at the end, it is a part of authentic vietnamese culture. Unfortunately it is also a part of each and every Hanoi city tour what leads to the problem, I had with it. The theatre was full but the audience was so ungreatful, loud, nobody applauded when the orchestra showed up, they barely applauded at the end of the show. A lot of smartphones and even tablets were hold overheads and interrupted the sight for those who said behind. I guess, many of those people did not really see the value in this play, they only took it as another (boring) part of a standard citytour. I bet, lot´s of them have never been to a theatre before and had no idea, how to behave. The show lasts about 50 minutes, I will never understand, why it is so hard for adult people just to sit down, shut up and listen for 50 minutes.That is really a pity and it made me said for the musicians and artists that are really doing a great job.

A unique experience. The water puppet theatre was an inexpensive, totally "different" event. There were also musicians playing traditional instruments. It was a colourful and fun show, climaxing in the puppeteers coming from behind the screens in the waist-deep water with their puppets.It was quite a short show,but the length was appropriate for the content. We had excellent seats in the centre of the second row. Something to be aware of - if you want to take photos, you need a separate ticket to be able to do that, although I'm not so sure that anyone would know if you had it or not. When I was taking photos I wasn't asked about it. Also, know your camera - it's dark,so you need to be able to operate it in the dark, and how to take low light photos.

Something different. Stopped here after a hot day site seeing. Not sure what to expect, but really enjoyed the music and the puppets were very clever. Never seen anything like it before. Would recommended going early in the day and buying your tickets if you're passing. We were at the back and probably missed a bit of the atmosphere.

Once in a lifetime experience ! Just once, trust me. It's a thing to do whilst in Hanoi, almost compulsory tourist "must do"Nice comfortable seats and a unique show. Make sure you you get your tickets !!

Entertainment you cannot miss!!. This is just an amazing experience. Suitable for all ages...mesmerising in that every face on every puppet differs..Amazing musicians accompany these talented performers...An absolute must see if you are in Hanoi.

It was ok.. It was an interesting show. The water puppets are an important part of Vietnamese history but our children had no idea what was going on most of the time. I enjoyed it but with the modern age of pyrotechnics and digital enhancements I think the rest of my family was expecting more flair. I enjoyed the historical simplicity of it but my children were not impressed. I still feel it's important to go see it.
Interesting puppetry. Well worth seeing but 40 minutes was more than enough. Visit here if you have a spare hour but there are more interesting things to see in Hanoi.

Different and entertaining. The show was just 45 minutes and that was enough. The artists (musicians, singers and puppeteers) are very talented. It was certainly different and something your whole family will enjoy.

A Good Cultural Experience. I really loved the water puppets, but the tourists clicking flash photos and holding up their iPads to film the whole show without regard for other viewers was annoying. Also the seats are very small with little leg room, so if you are six foot plus expect to be physically uncomfortable.The performance dramatizes Vietnamese folklore that explains the myth of origin and why the diverse ethnic groups are all Vietnamese among other stories. This would be a great place to bring kids.Get your tickets early in the day and come back later because it does sell out. The price is reasonable.

Excellent performance!. A highlight of our visit to Hanoi.
Very entertaining and instructive.
A glimpse in the folklore of Vietnam.
Great singing and beautiful puppet show.
Really original.
The evening shows sell fast.
Must reserve in advance or through your hotel.

A decent place to kill some time. Overall the experience here was ok. The show itself is not overly impressive but you I think is still worth seeing.From what I could hear, only the bass guitar and drums were live. Everything else was tracked, which was quite disappointing as I was hoping to hear some proper live Vietnamese music here. Also if you have longish legs, the rows of seats are very close together!Overall, worth checking out if you have some spare time but I wouldn't go out of my way to see it.

Interesting but expected slightly more. Located opp the Ho Kiem Lake at the Old Quarters, it is difficult to miss this place. Advisable to go early in the day to book the tickets for the evening show to avoid disappointment as the tickets are sold out fast (Tried to book for the 8 pm show at 5+pm but the tickets are sold out).It's a 45mins show with traditional music, singing and of course the water puppet. Interesting to watch how each puppet has its uses and "special skill" but was not really "wow" by them as well.

Vietnamese puppet. To be honest, this is not a fun place to go to. But if you want to know more about Vietnamese culture or their tradition, you should try this place. They sing and tell a story by using the puppet on the water. I have never seen this before so for me, it is very interesting. I don't know why but there are a lot of foreigners or travelers during the show. Good to give a try!

Unless you have a toddler don't bother.. Our 18 month old had an absolute ball!! We on the other hand were bored stiff!!There is culture and then there is this.....Sometimes things are popular and survive in spite of themselves? This is one such anomaly. Save your money. Tourist trap

Unexpectedly good. Having read about the water puppets I had envisaged an outdoor performance on the lake but the theater is actually indoors. We managed to get seats near the edge which was nice as there are wall mounted fans along the walls of the theatre. The stage has been removed and replaced with an in-ground swimming pool on which the small puppets perform. Local ladies sing and play the music accompanying each performance and there is a description of each performance translated into English on the LCD TV screen either side of the stage at the star of each performance. It reminded me of the puppet scene in the sound of music but sung in Vietnamese and performed on water instead of a stage. Well worth a visit as the performances are quite short (about 30-45min) in total.

Waste of time!!. Don't go!!!its ridiculous !!boring!we left after ten minutes of the show( if you can tell such a thing for this)! On our way out there were some marionettes for sale ....and we ask a very rude woman who was in charge the price ....and she gave us a price to knock us down....300 € !!!!so we left the soonest!!!some times I feel ungry with some sort of people who think that as we are tourists we are the fooliest persons on earth!!!never mind they lose profits!!!

My toddler had a gala time. The theatre is like an auditorium like hall, with the stage. aircond. clean and well organaised. Its a terrific way to showcase their culture.. it was musical, vibrant and colorful.. better than all of us, my 2 year old was having a good time.. with the chime and bang of the drum and the swift movements.. it was really very entertaining. its was a pleasant expirience. I would rate it as a must do as its pretty rare in other countries,.

The show is charmingly presented. The show is charmingly presented, lots of colourful puppets performing historical Vietnamese stories and legends to live traditional music and all operated by means of rods and wires underwater. It is often booked up for days in advance so make sure you allow enough time for it during your stay in Hanoi.
Water puppets. The water puppet show allows you to see an interesting art form indigenous to the region while also learning more about the lore (through the stories told).

Worth Checking Out. The water puppet theater is a great experience - a good combination of music and visuals. It was short enough, and gave a glimpse into the Hanoi past. I would recommend if you're nearby, and would like a quick introduction to Hanoi.

Please, leave your cameras at home. This was an interesting insight into the art of water puppetry, not too expensive, long enough to have multiple stories but short enough to be captivating. However, the show is completely ruined by the tourists who insist on watching it from behind their camera lenses. They are charged extra (this is not enforced) to annoy other people with their flashes, only to end up with some second rate videos and photos. The girls next to me had their views completely blocked by a woman holding her video camera above her head for 80% of the performance. The picture quality that I could see was terrible - are her friends and relatives really going to watch it anyway? You can see other peoples' low quality films on youtube. The puppets are only about a foot high and so it can be hard to see above the people in front. A good thing to see, but put your cameras away!
Best for kids. Maybe better for kids but it wasn't as impressive as it had been hyped up to be. Don't sit in E15 or you will get dripped on by the air conditioning.

folkloric performance. way to go! continue sharing genuine vietname culture to the world. what a show! a showcase of talent, patience and creativity, what was annoying though were the other tourists who already stood up and left immediately even if the show was not over. there is a show every hour. make sure to book a show at least two hours before. buy the ticket direct at the cashier. don't entertain touters!!!!

Excellent show. Colorful puppets well managed by the puppeteers accompanied by excellent musical. Well worth the money spent. The manipulation of the puppets on the water was so good that it makes the entire show comes to live and the vietnamese music accompanying the show was something new and compliment the show well.

Great fun. My husband and I went to the 5pm show. It was booked out and our hotel had booked us with front row seats. Very colourful and the storyline was easy to understand. Very cleverly done and would recommnd for all age groups to try and visit this theatre

Cultural? If you say so. I must be a simpleton, because I didn't really know what was going on here. Poorly choreographed fugures on poles splashing about in a rather off smelling pool. But hey, perhaps I just didnt get it so I will leave the performance to one side. What I really couldnt stand was the theatre itself, and the criticism here is universal. Firstly, the seats where haggard and the leg room was nonexistent. Im a tall fellow and I have to say my knee caps were feeling it by the end. Obviously built with the slight physiques of the Vietnamese in mindSecondly, the audience. Behind and infront of me I had some inconsiderate oaths with hulking great slrs blinding me temporarily throughout. Perhaps not such a bad thing.
