Finally, the incline of the rows are not steep enough. Half of the water stage was blocked by the back of peoples heads. So all in all id give this one a miss, save your money.
This is a must - Water Puppets. The performance was amazing. It is not necessary to choose front row seat like we did. Better to be back a couple of rows for better photography.

Cheap & Cheerful!. Really enjoyed it. Good price, and just the right length. The live music/singing was great - probably more entertaining than the puppets! The puppet show had good variety, with some really good bits. The surprise ending was great!
nice performance. all people play the water pappet show are excellent,this is in the heart of the city,near hoan kiem lake,near the hotel,just 1 munite walking.
Fun!. Very fun, nice 45 minute show! Tells a nice historical story of Vietnamese history and past. Very different and unique
A must do fun cultural performance for all the family.. We really enjoyed the puppets. The show was well done with live Vietnamese music. The length at 45 minutes is about right and all for $5.

Entertaining show. The water puppet show is very enjoyable, it is a wonderful way to see/hear about some of the culture of the Vietnamese people. The artists are very clever, the music and story sweet. It is something a bit unexpected but definitely enjoyable. The area near the theatre is lovely, there a some touristy type shops, a lovely lake area and downstairs from the theatre is a nice little coffee shop. I am not sure of the cost as this was included on our tour of Vietnam but given the cost of most things in Vietnam I do not think it would be very expensive.

Water Puppet in Ha Noi Vietnam. Form you hotel you can get a public bus to 57B Dinh Tien Hoang Street in Ha Noi City to see water puppet. It is so great. You will see more Vietnam in the past time, cultural life styles....

OK glad I did it. Wasn't what I was expecting, the craftsmanship is great although I had a bratty kid sitting behind me which took the shine off it. I didn't think we would be in a 'cinema' type situation, I was expecting an outdoor performance. You have to go, just so you can say you've done it

Enjoyed it. I bought the first class for 100,000 VND (~5 USD) for the show for one hour watching the Water puppet show. All shows very meaningful, very Vietnam cultural, vividly reflected in the lives of people Vietnam,...We both was really enjoyed it.

Different cultural expperience. Forget high tech productions - this is a really special cultural experience which does have you wondering how it is done! It may be a bit repetitious but worth a visit.
It s a great show for kids and well done. The show is great for kids and well done. It is quite clever how it is done and the men and woman show their faces at the end . Very colourful show

A Bit of Culture. I missed out on seeing this the last time I travelled to Vietnam so was super keen to ensure I saw the water puppets this time. I didn't really know what to expect, but it was a little bit of light entertainment. Perhaps a little cheesy, and some of the puppets could do with a lick of paint, but for the sake of an hour, it wasn't bad. The theatre is comfortable and nicely air-conditioned, and it was nice to listen to live musicians.

water puppets fun. get your tickets early since I think its is first come, first serve for the closer seats. It is less than a hour show with 9 different story lines. It is a fun event. Photography is not allowed during the show but you can take photos of the puppets in the lobby and exitway after the show.
A lovely cultural performance. The performance is attractive, along with all the stories behind each round of play. However, it takes about 1 hour and more, which could be quite long for certain ppl.
Excellent show. We took our children here and they loved the showed. It is closed to Jasmine Hotel. Only 2 minutes away

A must but not thrilled. Something you have to see but sadly enough there is not a lot of competition in this sector. At least I am not aware of many other puppet theaters in Hanoi or elsewhere. That's a pitty as that could increase the quality of performance. It was not bad but it felt like it all had to go quickly,etc...

Interesting piece of culture. The show is an interesting presentation of Vietnamese folk culture in a comfortable environment for tourists. The show seems to be on most package tours and most visitors seem to enjoy it. The music is nice and traditional played by a live group. The show is a series of skits and lasts about one hour. The theatre is clean and comfortable and the presentation has been upgraded over the years. It is a relaxing and interesting break from shopping in the old quarter.

Over rated. I was expecting more from this to he honest. But apparently the puppets are all made from a local community, so I suppose its good to support tohose guys. Ad far as the performace goes, I was expecting more to be honest, perhaps some more sound and lighting. Overall not bad for the price. Wouldbt go again though.

A must see in Hanoi. Seeing the water puppet show is a great experience. The puppetry, music and colours are beautiful. If you're hoping to take photos, you might want to try to get a seat near the front (if possible) or on the end of a row.

There are better things to do in Vietnam then go here. When in Hanoi we thought lets see everything we can, unfortunatley we decided to go and see the water puppet show. After 10 minutes it just became mundane and quite boring. the idea sounded great buit it just did not live up to its expectations
Thang long water puppet theatre. I wasn't over impressed with the puppets,whilst it is very cleverly done once you're been there 10mins you've had enough

Original and interesting. Definitely worth to see, you need to be there 0,5 h before in order to get the ticket (as many touristics groups are coming and they buy 10-20 tickets at once).Music and the how is something original, calm and relaxing, to be honest we did it after the lobg flight and we got almost asleep in the middle of the show:)).

water puppet show. Well worth the visit while in Hanoi. if you want to take photo,s sit down in front so as to avoid the back of tourists heads in your picture. you also have to pay a small extra fee to take the photo,s. to avoid standing in queue,s buy you tickets the day before. Very fun way to spend an hour

Top of the List. As a Hanoi resident for two years, this was my favorite attraction. It is colorful, professional, highly entertaining, and very representative of Vietnamese music and culture. Don't miss it, but arrange for tickets well ahead of time, as this is such a popular activity.

Hanoi must-see. As a Hanoian myself, I wasn't thrilled about this program because it seems to be too touristy. But once I accompany some foreign colleagues there, I was surprised. It was interesting and cool. It s very good to have a quick overview of Vietnamese culture. But the most touching moment for me was the end of the show when you saw all the artists who literally emerge from the water to greet you. So I strongly recommend this although it might look quite "turn off" when you see all the tourists there.

Water Puppets !!. The name is enough to make you want to see it . the old school art of water puppets is a must to see on your trip to Hanoi . It is said that if you do not go to a water puppet show then you have not been to Hanoi .

Wet puppets. If you like puppet theaters, you will love this one, because it is quirky and authentically Vietnamese, especially, the musical accompaniment. The seats in the auditorium are exceedingly uncomfortable for tall people and so is the lack of fresh air for everybody. Nonetheless, it's fun.

Decent Place to Spend Time. While not a “must see” if you have an hour to spare this is a good place to spend it. The show is easy to follow with the accompanying captions on the large television screen and I especially enjoyed the music. The show was just long enough (about 45 minutes) any longer and it would have dragged. It is a quick way to learn about the history of Hanoi. Also don’t send the extra money for the camera fee, it is too dark for good pictures.

Nice performance & special effects. Likes:The performance is great. The opening was quite spectacular and there was a slide in English that explains what the performance is about in each scene. The duration of the show is just perfect, longer than that people will start to get bored and fall asleep.Dislikes:  The long face on ticket counter. As this is a tourism spot I expected a bit smile and positive energy.
Ok on a rainy day. I know everyone talks about this, but to tell you the truth, I was not overwhelmed by it, it some part I had a hard time to stay awake, and this was the afternoon show !!!!

Must do!. Our 6 & 7 year old children LOVED this show. Cheap and cheerful entertainment. Great to see at the start of our Vietnam adventure as cultural themes are repeated freqently throughout travels within Vietnam. Don't miss it. You get issued a seat number so no need to get there early. I found the seats a bit tight as per other posts... my husband had to sit on the aisle to be able to accommodate him and his dodgy hip! It is not too long which suited the children too. Fabulous.

Showcases culture, but this place is not for everyone!. Caught this show after a flight from Singapore. The puppeteers are very talented and you can see that the performers are talented. The show's format is roughly one explanation of life in Vietnam, and a scene after that to illustrate it. My friends and I found it rather tedious(we are 21) but I suspect children and anyone looking to learn more about the Vietnamese way of life will enjoy it more than we did Also it is only 45 mins long so no harm taking a peek.

Great cultural experience. This puppet show set in water gave a lovely short show through song and dance of the history and development of the vietnamese culture, it is all through vietnamese but with english subtitles, but that didnt take away from it at all, cheap with tickets costing only 100,000 dong, would definitly recommend.

Entertaining puppets, should interest most. This is a great way to see and experience some Vietnamese art culture. They have a live music to accompany the show where they use traditional instruments. As I am someone that is not particularly into arts, dance etc. One bad thing, if you get a seat up the back like we did you might find it hard to see, especially if you are elderly. I did get a little bored towards the end of it, but I still think it's a good idea to go and see this.

Puppets!. The puppet show was good as it depicted Vietnamese folklore and daily life. The puppets looked great and the traditional music was good as well. For 100k Dong (5 USD) it was a fair price to pay for a good 45 minutes of simple entertainment. But it is definitely not for everyone. Kids and adults alike will enjoy this show.

Shouldn't be missed!. It's hard to pass this one while staying in Hanoi. If you ever wander around the old quarter, you'll definitely see endlessly crowded place filled with tour buses and tourists. The show is worth the money because it tells you what typical countryside of Vietnam is like through the puppets. It's also art and very very hard work. Highly recommended!

It is Entertaining, but not for everyone.. We came here as this is one of the main attractions of Hanoi.I really liked the show as it is really original and entertaining to see the puppets in a totally different way. The stories that are telled during the show are based on Vietnamese rich culture and folklore. However, one of my friends did not enjoy it as he said it was too slow for him and did not understand the story between each scene. This is also valid as it is his opinion.TIP: if you like cultural activities like theater you will really like the show. If not, it is possible that you will get bored but you will miss a really original show. So, take a look.

Well worth seeing. The water puppet tradition originated in the rice paddies and it is great to see the skills being carried on. We saw a show in which cultural legends were represented, but at other times I understand they work on up to date issues.The show is not very long so is good for smaller children.......and adults !! ;)The music was lovely and the instruments were interesting too......
Super boring. I can appreciate the history behind everything, and the talent of all the presenters and puppeteers - but unless you are a child this can be pretty long and tedious.

Delightful cultural interlude away from the Old Quarter action. This popular and very professional theatre show is situated at the end of Hoan Kiem Lake closest to the Old Quarter. Be warned - you will generally need to purchase your tickets days beforehand to secure your preferred date and performance time. Large tour buses bring dozens of people and on the night of the performance I recommend you arrive early to have time to visit the bathroom and take a look at the interesting display of character puppets on the first floor.The ticket office advertises that if you want to take photographs you will have to pay more but I found that no one checked anyway. In fact, half of the theatre goers hold up their ipads for long periods of time, taking video footage, which thoughtlessly blocks or distracts the view of those sitting behind. VERY annoying.The show itself is charming and the puppet masters work their craft hidden behind bamboo screens, with the brightly coloured puppets skipping and dipping across the water stage, accompanied by a traditional instrumental group and a couple of very impressive vocalists. The whole performance includes nine different small pieces which tell various stories of life in the countryside, courting, food production, the significance of fans, and the culture of different ethnic groups. There are plenty of cafes and street stalls nearby so it's easy to quickly grab something to eat before or after the show. Try a coconut ice cream if you can.

Fun puppets. I enjoyed the show very much. More than the puppets I loved the music. Eventhough I have no idea of what they are singing, I enjoyed the music and the voice of singer is mesmerizing. I suggest not to miss it.
Awesome!. Definitely make the effort to see this show, it's cheap short, but of high quality (though I didn't see the Saigon shows). I don't want to tell about the show and spoil it, but just go.:)
An enjoyable show. The Thang Long Water Puppet Theater was awesome. The puppeteers were very professional and put on a great show. A delight indeed.

Interesting but not too entertaining painfully close rows of seats. We went to this as part of our tour. I think quite a few of us fell asleep. Conceptually interesting but too long. And if you are taller than 5'6" you will be uncomfortable as the rows are closer then any the airlines would dare. I'm 6'2" and couldn't move a micron. One plus good AC.

A sweet and fun way to spend an hour. I don't imagine this would appeal to everyone but I thought it was sweet and fun. There were still tickets free 30 min before the show about 6.30 but we did end up having to sit further back so if you are keen on front row or close to the stage I suggest you buy earlier but its not a problem to turn up and buy on the door. My photos did not turn out so great from the back row! There are 5 or so stories set to live traditional music with a tv screen translating the story told at the start into english. The adjoining cafe was nice and you can wait in the air con there with your drink before going in and we took our drinks in from there too.

Dull & overrated. This was heralded in my guidebook as one of the main things to do in Hanoi. Went on my first day, perhaps expectations were a bit high. For Vietnamese standards, my ticket was expensive (100k VND, 5$). I fell asleep a couple of times. The live & authentic Vietnamese music is much more intriguing than the actual waterpuppets.
Simple but worthwhile. Well worth the visit but a little bit more basic than I expected. Music was lovely and it was all done very well. The puppets reminded me of Punch and Judy!!

Worth a Visit. We took our 6 year old son, he enjoyed the show. 45 mins is long enough. It was a bit of fun, we had seats up the front which were good. Entry is not expensive and we felt it was worth a visit as part of our trip to Hanoi.

Creative and entertaining. I was amazed by how creative the water puppet show was. The live music was beautiful and the show was very entertaining. We bought the "photo pass" that allows you to take pictures during the show, but it is so dark and they are moving so quickly I'm not sure it was worth it.
Average show. Please dont expect an extravagant show. This is a very simple show of puppets,So what ever inside, you can guess what will you see.Good attraction if you have 1hour spare time.

different...not really a "must do". While the show is entertaining, it's very twee. I was expecting to be wowed but frankly the appearance snd movement of the puppets is quite amateur - I was reminded of Punch & Judy, which may not be so bad.A fun thing to do if you've got kids, and worth a look if you have an afternoon to kill, but don't stress yourself out to get tickets. We had read it was a highlight or "must do" of Hanoi but I disagree!

Charming set piece - 45 mins is long enough!. I took my teenagers to this and we all enjoyed it - it's sweet and charming and goes on for just about the right amount of time! I'd say it was just becoming less interesting when it stopped....The music is very lovely and the puppets are fun to watch - some comedy moments both intentional and otherwise! The story is simple and you can understand what it happening - helped by the translations on the large TVs in either side of the stage.Do book the day before (or first thing in the morning). You'll also need to pay extra for the camera fee.

A bit of fun. This experience is like going back to the simple childhood of puppetry. It's not digitally enhanced its just raw old fashioned entertainment. There was a tv telling the story in English and it was the story of Vietnam, from romancing to work life. Just go and relax. The music is pure and beautiful, even though I didn't understand a word, it was memorising.

Average.... I only think this show is worthwhile if you start your travels/Vietnam experience in Hanoi, as it gives a little history via a theatrical, dramatic and drawn-out fashion, however, it's not worthwhile if you already have some experience/spent time in Vietnam.

Fantastic. The only problem with this show is it dont go long enough. A thoroughly entertaining evening. I was a bit worried when our tour guide took us here to see this but i came out wanting more it was great. The singers even though i did not understand a word it as beautiful. .

well..... if you don't have anything else to do.... Okay, so i'd heard the Puppet Show was campy and all - and it's sort of true. The people in the audience are only tourists, the show is like a hula show in Waikiki, bu tif you're curious, the puppets are cute for the first 30 minutes, and imagining the chaos behind the curtain is fun. It doesn't hurt to go. You can get a little bit of sleep if you find it boring!

Water Puppets. Was on the must see list so we did and although it was good, it was not one of my favorite things. I enjoyed the music which was live but I found the performance of the puppets stilted and just not my favorite thing.

Worthwhile. We enjoyed our visit and feel that that it captured an important element of the cultural side of a trip to Hanoi. The tickets were only 100,000VND, the show was short but very well presented. Theatre was comfortable, performers professional, the show lasts for 45 minutes which is just right. English language monitors provide enough information as do the leaflets in various language which are free. Glad we went along.
well done. very interesting, the artist men doing well. So many audiences like it. Theatre located next to the Hoan Kiem Lake so feel cool.

Traditional, cultural water puppet show. This was a quaint, professionally run puppet show detailing cultural and historical aspects about Vietnam and its people. The puppets are controlled by puppeteers holding poles which travel under water. The show is accompanied by polished performers singing and playing traditional instruments. It is a big deal for tourists in Hanoi, employing a decent cast and obviously highly regarded by the locals. My family thought it was ok.
Cultural. Literally puppets on the water. The story of Vietnamese origin told with puppets and traditional songs. The entrance fees is 30,000 VND. It is located at Hoan Kiem District at the lake.
Do it, once!. There isnt any excuse not to go once. The music wasnt appealing to me but to share in the culture and know I dont have to do it ever again was great!
Water Puppet Theatre. Bright ,colourful and entertaining. This is a must see if you are visiting Hanoi. It was very popular so make sure you book your tickets.
Amazing. All the puppeteers are behind a screen manipulating the puppets. I liked the display of puppets that were in the foyer because you could see how the puppets worked.
Must do for kids. We took our pre teens to the show and they loved it. Adults also enjoyed it. Was very interesting and just the right length, 45 mins. Cheap too. Try for front row seats.

Magic!. This was a really fun show, we got quite good tickets even though we bought them on the same day. Sit near the front for a better look. The puppets were amazing, as were the three ladies who sang and played traditional instruments to the side. Only complaint is that it was too short!!! My nearly-two-year-old was completely mesmerised by it for the entire time, she was totally transfixed! Highly recommend to all families.

TURN OFF YOUR PHONES. Just went to the show tonight. I'll abstain from comment on the performance ad it's pretty well covered. What I can say, from the back of the theatre, my experience was mostly that of watching other peoples iphone and camera LCDs as they held their arms over their head videoing and photographing the experience - which completely ruined mine. PLEASE PLEASE do not be that person. It is so unbelievable rude and obnoxious to other guests.

The entire play was narrated in Vietnamese. The water puppet theater highlighted the rich culture of Vietnam and their Chinese heritage as well. Though the puppet movements were in rhythm with the rich musical background from the orchestra of traditional instruments, the entire play was narrated in Vietnamese that made the story line hard to follow and thus bland and repetitive.

great experience. As a Vietnamese, I haven't been here until my husband told me to come with him. He said it's such a great show that he has never ever seen anywhere else. And I do enjoyed it too. Next time we will bring my little daughter with us. I'm sure children all love this show

Really good fun and great value. For something different and that will be enjoyed by all ages, go! The puppets are clever and well synchronised with the music. All ages will enjoy it and is great value. Highly recommended

I dunno what the big fuss was all about. It's a show about the culture of Vietnam, which I could have more pleasantly learned while in the comfort of my own room. The theater was full and I understand it is always that way because tourists are always brought there. Kids couldn't even enjoy the show for longer than 3 minutes. It was boring and very ordinary.
Something different!. This is one of the must dos when in Hanoi, water puppets tell the story of how the Vietnamese people believe they came to be. Hour long show which our kids and us both enjoyed!

Fun, if you're a kid a heart!. This puppet show is really meant for younger audiences. That being said, those of us over 20 can still enjoy it! the music and lights are great. Many puppets need to be fixed though. One of the most entertaining parts of the show was the grammar mistakes on the video screen that translated the stories of the Vietnamese genesis.

Entertaining. I was quite fascinated that the puppeteers could control the puppets so well. I started looking for wires then realized the puppeteers were standing in the water behind the screen and used metal rods. It was definitely worth the entry cost to see the clever puppetry. It was a nice slice of culture while in Hanoi. It's well located near the lake and Old Quarter.

Very entertaining. The music, singing and puppets were very entertaining. It was also a great way to learn a bit about Vietnamese culture and legends. Whenever I looked over I saw our two 10-year olds totally captured by the show.

Very entertaining. This was a real revelation and a very entertaining evening outing. The ladies who gave the commentary and explanations were lovely and very professional and brought an extra dimension to the show. Thoroughly enjoying

Fun and funny. We enjoyed the water puppets, and think that it's worth stopping in for. The first few numbers were beautiful- especially the ones involving dragons and fish swimming in the river. Some of the later ones were a little less exciting to watch- but the music and singing was still lovely. A great way to learn a few of the folktales of the region and relax for an hour. The marionettes are simple, but beautiful. Don't expect a high tech performance and you'll enjoy it. The100,000 VND for a better seat in the front was worth it, try to get front row if you can.

Well worth doing. We went with low expectations thinking it would be just another tourist trap. But the show was lovely, the stories genuinely interesting and the music was great. Not at all what I expected.Seating is fine for tall people despite earlier reviews. Harden up people. Tickets are inexpensive, maybe VND 100K? Book early to get good seats. Show runs for around 40 minutes so dinner before or after is easy.  It's a shame they allow late arrivals and flash photography. We had a few bus loads arrive 10 - 15 minutes late. They didn't enter quickly or quietly, and then proceeded to take flash photos. Has no-one ever explained to them how utterly pointless (and annoying) is to use flash from so far back. After the show stay in your seats for five minutes and allow the pushy tour groups to empty - if you stand between them and their buses parked outside you risk being trampled. Relax and enjoy.

Interesting but story not dynamic. Apparently, this is a new production fairly recently revamped to focus on ethnic minorities in Vietnam and some of their cultural practices (e.g. hunting fish, playing pan pipes & holding umbrellas for courtship, etc). The Vietnam legend part was just at the start with the dragon & phoenix and the egg that produced 100 sons who became the Vietnamese people. The stage and music were great/unique and the puppets charming but without a dramatic storyline to tie all the segments together, it was not a particularly dynamic show, apart from some interesting puppetry (e.g. puppets spinning umbrellas). It's worth a visit for the novelty of seeing a live water puppet set/show, the live ancient instruments & singing. A few of my students nodded off (to be fair, we had just arrived in Hanoi a few hours earlier from 13 hours of travel from San Francisco, CA).

Brilliant evening out. Book a few days in advance or you could be disappointed. We went to 8pm show. Fun and informative. Local music and tales. Explanation in English on VT. a must go to when in Hanoi
Historical puppetry.. This is a must do event in Hanoi.Quite cheap and very entertaining,folk legend relative with good traditional music.

Worth turning off your hand phone for an hour. An interesting but brief run through a remaining cultural tradition. Great to see that this bit of local culture is still popular among tourists. The show was short and to-the-point and featured local music on Vietnamese instruments (although I could hear an electric bass in the background!). Managed to keep the audience's full attention throughout and was over before it could get tedious. Recommended.

Enjoyable and different. Definitely something to put on the agenda to do when in Hanoi. If you can, then book a seat near the front. We were lucky enough to book on the day through our hotel and got great seats in the second row. The show is fairly short but having seen the 6.30pm show it was easy to go for dinner afterwards. The puppets are long a bit scruffy but their movements are fantastic. The highlight for me though was the music and the musicians.

A must to See. Real authentic entertainment. You will not be disappointed. Ensure you get a front seat to enjoy, it's all set over water don't really know how they do it, music rather tinny but then again that's the part of being in Vietnam. Make time to see something that you will not see anywhere else.

Water Puppetry is a tradition. Water Puppetry is a tradition that dates back as far as the 11th century. If you go to the Museum of Ethnology you can also see some old wooden water puppets on display.

Pleasant Experience. Very interesting to see the Puppetiers come out at the end. As much as it was interesting for our short stay in Hanoi, I'm sure there are other water puppet shows that are not as touristy if one has the time to find them. Downside..a tall person sitting in front of you! Enjoyed the live traditional music and signing.

Entertaining cultural show. My husband and I found the show entertaining and unique. The puppetry and associated art form were interesting. The music was lively and the folk tales enthralling. We felt that the show really gave us a great Vietnamese cultural experience. We booked tickets 10 minutes before the show could start and were allowed to take our camera in for a small fee. The show was about 40 minutes long and was packed to capacity.

Puppetry at it's best.. Absolutely amazing. Hearing the story then seeing it come to life via the puppets,accompanied by singing & music played on traditional instruments was mesmerising. at the end the puppet masters wade out into the water with their puppets. Well worth a visit.

Mercifully Short. Worth going to for the experience but after 10 minutes you'll be pleased to know you only have to endure another half hour or so. The musicians are excellent but the puppetry is both boring and amateurish. Like a primary school show, would be quite good if done by 10 year olds but this is not professional entertainment. If you're tall (over 6ft), you won't be able to sit remotely comfortably. I was moved to the aisle where there are a few seats where you can sit without feeling cramped. At the end of the show though, I was almost crushed in a stampede of mindless Chinese tourists who didn't have the patience to let me move my chair before their rush for the exit. An experience for sure but not one you'll want to repeat. Kudos to the musicians though.

Fun entertainment. Very popular show, so book early if you want to go. It was a tad pricey at 100,000 but it was a well produced show and informative and amusing. It caters for English speaking. Some of the puppets are looking a bit rough around the edges but in general they look the part in the water. 45 mins maybe a bit long but a tiger before hand makes it lighthearted entertainment.

Puppetry is not our thing, but loved the music. Great show for kids, enjoyed the music. We went not knowing what to expect but found it OK. It is very popular and there weren't many seats left in our session. The concept is quite interesting and reminded me of seeing the Tintookies in Australia when I was a child.

Unique and entertaining. We went to this show without any plans and bought the tickets there. It is interesting show using water and puppets made of wood with lacquer. it is entertaining and funny also show vietnamese way of life, music and instruments and operatic folk songs. This is a must do when in Hanoi.

Very well performed show.. The puppet show was fun to watch, if not a little kitch. However, the musicians and puppeteers performed very well and the show was based on cultural beliefs which was very interesting.

Bit of a laugh. We went to this as we felt as though if you were going to be in Hanoi, this was something that you HAD to do. The seats were too small for my 5'9" frame and my travel partner's 6'0" frame. There were some poor souls who were a lot taller than us who also had a rough time. Photography is permitted, which is weird. Usually performances (especially in SEA) prohibit photography.The first three items were good but it was pretty repetitive after that. If we weren't trapped in the middle of the row, we would have walked out.We booked our tickets at 5.30pm for a 6.30pm start no problems. When we got in, however, it was packed to the eyeballs.This is a really great insight into traditional Vietnamese music and instruments, and Vietnamese history.

INTERESTING SHOW. It was the first time you saw this kind of show. The puppets dance beautifully on the face of water and the special effects are fantastic. Just little tired when queuing up to buy tickets. An advice: buy ticket from morning in the weekdays and from the previous day if you intend to see the show on the next day. And consider booking a seat on the aisle :DYou really have to put this on your 'TO DO' list when visit Viet Nam.

A muss see. This show was very well done with fantastic music, story telling and puppets. The theatre seems designed for smaller Asian sized people, so if you are 6 ft expect to be stuck like sardine, unless you ensure you book a front row seat. Need 2 times to booked two tickets on 8 hrs after dinner.Should be book it early if you would have a show.

Superb. Really worth the time spend there. The tickets price was very very reasonable too. Well choreograph show. Visually appealing and stunning. Most of the person in the theatre gave a standing ovation to the performers too.
Unique. The water puppet is unique and one of it's kind i guess....the story is not make us boring, the music is good too

Fantastic.. Although the show went on for a little too long - 40 mins to an hour, the folklore story behind the puppetry was fascinating. The music is live and breathtaking. This show itself is novel, atmospheric, lively, and very entertaining. You really have to put this on your 'not to miss' list.
comical. not something I would go to but i read mixed reviews so decided to go, very boring the ladies playing the music and singing however where fantastic

Bit of fun for the kids. We purcahsed our tickets from the theatre and managed to get tickets for that night. The kids thought it was ok, you get a run down of the show in English or your desired language before you go in so we gave them more of an idea of what the show was about. Best to be in the first 10 rows i think, we were in the 5th row and the kids could see okay. Definetly worth visiting if you have kids with you, is only about 40 minutes which is more than enough.
Tourist Trap. The performance is good and value at $5 a ticket, but it is overhyped. The theatre is rundown, seats are allocated to tour groups and it is over far too quickly.
Lot's of fun. I have never seen anything like it. It is not super exciting but to a westerner it is very unique and a lot of fun. A "must see" in Hanoi.

Unique Experience. Something very different from the usual puppet show for their stage is filled with water and I was really amazed by how the puppeteers control the wooden puppets in the water. The show is in Vietnamese but luckily there is a small screen on the left side of the stage with English subtitles. There are a few scenes and the lifestyle of the Vietnamese is portrayed in the show. The seats are very hard and uncomfortable and there wasn't any leg space.

Don't miss this!. It might seem a little strange, but you have to experience it! From the beginning it surprises you. The puppets are very well done and the special effects are fantastic. The water really adds that bit of magic and the whole scenery makes you have a wonderful time. Before each scene, they tell you with an off voice what the next scene will be about and also you can read it on a screen. I really recommend you going there and getting as close to the stage as you can, because it's even better!

Family fun.... Didn't know what to expect at first, the show was awesome. It was great entertainment for families, they did a fabulous job with the puppets in the water. It was nice to see the people behind the puppets at the end of the show, brilliant. Large crowds for this.

wonderful and intriguing. Totally different from anything we'd seen before. Very clever presentation and the intricate actions of the puppets made them appear so real. Lasted one hour. Anyone who is taller than a Vietnamese, consider booking a seat on the aisle.

Must see in Hanoi. If you spend some days in Hanoi, you should not miss this show.It is a tradizional puppet show with colored scenes, local music and a wonderful atmophere.Even if you are not a fan of vietnamese popular art, still you should try this experience

Tourist trap. If you have nothing else to do, it is poring down rain, and you just want to sit in air con and escape the traffic then go. But seriously, this show is a waste of time and even the actors and musicians know it. Broken puppets, repetitive coreography, and the feeling like the whole operation is about to fall apart just add up to a waste.Maybe if you have kids or lots of drugs it would be worth it.

Really enjoyed this performance. Despite being a bit touristy we really enjoyed the water puppet theater. It was amazing how the artists controlled the puppets as accompanied by singers and traditional Vietnamese instruments. Highly recommend attending, but make sure to buy your ticket in advance because it fills up and has assigned seating.

An interesting evening.. We heard this was worth a watch so we decided to give it a go. At £3 each for first class tickets it was a steal.The puppets are dancing in the water while the puppeteers stand behind the curtain wearing waders.We couldn't understand a word of the Vietnamese narration but we enjoyed the music and the show.Definitely worth a look if you're in Hanoi. The theater is on the north east side of Hoam Kien Lake. It would be best to buy your tickets the day before as they sell out pretty quickly on show day. The show is about 45 minutes long.

Like nothing else we have seen.. To think that this theatre emerged from the rice fields is amazing : to have come so far with surprising dexterity and reality. A unique experience and well worth the wait.Go to the booking office itself to see when the sessions will run as not all the sessions run. You can be dissapointed.

not a special show but must see during hanoi stay. I was not willing to visit when i found that this show cannot book in advance, must buy at counter. but when the show started, i changed my mind. i cannot say it was a superb & spectacle show but i enjoyed with vietnamese music instrumental. there was a screen to displayed english translation, thus we could understand every scenes.

Local thing, surreal and cheesy but not bad. We knew it would be super-cheesy, but decided to go anyway. Our expectations were exactly met. The show is a little staid and it seemed to us that some of the puppets might be in need of a little mechanical repair. But what saved the show was the translations on television as the show went on and the delightful live quintet playing some of the music and singing. Glad we went, but we may have been disappointed if we'd been expecting something mind-blowing.

Slow. It is a must see as it is a traditional show of Vietnam. However it was a bit slow and the puppets had paint dropped out. Some even had hands and legs missing. They could do with some maintenance of the puppets. Overall it was a bit disappointing.

Do watch it if it's your first trip in Hanoi. Its quite different from the usual puppet shows we usually see....as it takes place on a stage filled with water. It's not exactly mesmerising but a good experience to learn a bit about the Vietnamese culture.
Boring. it was no doubt a must see, considering it was prize-winning puppet show. but 10 minutes into the show, my boyfriend almost feel asleep. nothing much to shout about.....

Water Puppets Hanoi. Well worth it!Don't know why people were complaining about the seats. Comfortable enough for length of show. Unless your extremely tall!I just walked up and got tickets before show, however the show was full so might be an idea to get them early. Ticket office closed between the 1800 and 2000 show.Show details the origins and traditions of Vietnam.

Kids and adults love this, a must-see!. The show is entertaining and one of a kind, i did not imagine a puppet show can be done in a pool of water. Each puppet theme is created uniquely and artistically which matched the Vietnamese music. I love the sound of the harp (i hope i got the name of the instrument right) and the sweet voice of the lady singer and narrator. The english translation of the narration on the screen is such a great help for the foreigners. The show is also priced reasonably and started and ended as scheduled. The kids really enjoyed the show.

My daughter asked if we could leave...15 mins in.... It was only my respect for other people and the musicians that I refrained from getting up and walking out.Yes, we had front row seats, so I can't argue and it was 100,000 dong per person, so only £6 overall...HOWEVER...The whole thing seemed to be one giant tourist trap, stated by agents and tour guide and travel books as something cultural, ageing back centuries, but it was awful.The first 10 minutes were good, but once you've seen one dance, you've seen them all!The puppets were in a shocking state and I realise that they only last one average 3 months due to, obviously, water damage, but surely they can afford to given their faces a coat of paint with the amount of mugs like myself packing out the auditorium 4 times a day. They (the puppets) all appeared to have severe facial disfigurements.The music was fabulous and I wish I could give the musicians 5 stars for their performance, because they were wonderful, and if the show had just been them on the stage performing for 45 minutes I would have come away a lot happier!!!Don't bother!
unique show and interesting experience. nowhere else have i ever heard of or seen such a performance which is native yet in nice theater setting.

A bit sleepy show. May be the music was not my type thus i was falling asleep during half of the show. But for people who loves cultural show im sure you will like it. The actors was very talented ( from what i remembered from the beginning of the show), they somehow making the pupet moving....

A thousand year old tradition. Great to see the history of Vietnam acted out in this thousand year old tradition. It was nice to imagine this show being performed for a thousand years; what it must have been like without college-aged white people in audience texting, laughing, talking, getting up, taking pics with flashes. Buy your tickets as soon as you arrive to Hanoi. Better to sit in front row if you are tall as the seats are cramped.

Disappointing. The production was supposed to have won many awards and is recognized nationally. Yet the show itself was so poorly run, from the stage to costumes to everything else. The audience is crammed inside a small auditorium and everyone is fanning themselves for lack of A/C. Uncomfortable and disappointing.

A must see, but book early...... We had seen a couple of other "water puppet" shows in Saigon and surrounds but this was without a doubt the most professional and well put together show we saw. Worth paying the few extra $.Tickets to all performances sell quickly and with full houses for every performance if you are not part of a tour group go early and buy your tickets in advance or risk missing out.

Great show!. For anybody who hasn’t got this show in the travel itinerary then I think you should add it in immediately. The show is great in both music and performance. The content of the show is about the Vietnamese and it is very easy to get the meaning of each scene as they also show it in a big screen in English. Generally, it is a quick way of understanding Vietnam.
Water Puppets. Just loved this show & could have sat through a repeat, so well done, so beautiful. Recommend all travellers to at least see this show.... worth the money.

Interesting but strange. This was a very interesting cultural experience and I'm glad I made it to see them as I'd heard a lot about the water puppets. However it was a bit too long for my liking and was quite a strange experience. Definitely worth the 60.000 dong but don't go expecting too much. Also - way busier than we expected... we only just got seats!

Fascinating. The seats are small but comfortable enough for the 1 hour show. The show was interesting and entertaining and the music very melodic. I was fascinated with the the danbau. Its amazing what can be done with a single string!

Amazing performance!!!. It is Vietnamese traditional and cultural performance taken place in a waist-deep pool. There are many puppets controlled by the large rod under the water. I found that puppeteers - who stand behind the screen - control these puppets skillfully and flexibly. Also the content of performance reflects Vietnam life and if you have a chance to go to Vietnam, spend your little time enjoying this art.

Nice, traditional show. This theater provided good evening entertainment and showed us the traditional water puppet show. The show wasn't too long so it did not become boring. The seating rows are a little tight. Luckily one of the ushers noticed that my long legs were compressed against the seat in front of me, so thankfully she moved me to an end seat so I could stretch my legs.

A cultural experience. This is unique experience that is not for everyone.Would be great for kids and people with an open mind to learning a little culture. Best to get a seat near front if possible. Music can be loud but loud at front and back due to speaker. If you want to take photos you are supposed to pay extra 20 000 dong at entrance and get a photo taking ticket. People behind me did not purchase ticket but said they did not know they had to. I did not see anyone getting chucked out.

Fun experience. OK, so yes the show is hugely touristy, but it was fun and our kids (5 and 7) liked it. Plus the show is not so long and only $5 - hard to complain! I liked that the puppeteers came out at the end - it was interesting to see how they worked the puppets, plus nice to give them credit for their performance.

A must for any visitor. The show is a little over an hour and is cultural but with the enormous difference of so many puppets appearing in the water to tell the story. A mini orchestra sits on one side. At the end, when the puppeteers come out, it is astonishing how many there are. Photos allowed.

Hilarious!. Man, I loved this show. It was utterly incomprehensible (apart from the rather graphic opening episode with the dragon and 'fairy' mating!). But you know what? That only made it more amusing! By the time the 'back-flipping babies' came on, I was struggling to control hysterical laughter! The puppetry scenes are interspersed with explanations shown on TV screens beside the pool/stage, often with great examples of Engrish - the local people being 'attacked by the Evil Beats' being one of my favourites!All in all, this is a fairly inexpensive hour of amusement. But book early if you want to go - all the evening shows were full when I went, but luckily I could just squeeze into the lunch performance. Oh, and I'll second the chair-size thing - ridiculously small - but it's only an hour long, so not likely to be fatal!

Fun time and new experience. Very cool show, like nothing I've ever seen. As it takes place in water and in a dark theatre, not many of my pictures turned out, but that's OK, because it's better to experience in person than through photographs.

Interesting Show. It was an interesting show and it is a good thing that they added the sub-titles which enabled us to understand the show. Our hotel managed to get tickets for us and the seats were at the second row at the front so we had pretty good views.
Worth, even without kids. The show is great and last for about 1 hour (just leaves little legroom for people over 1.65m). However, highly recommendable.

Worth seeing for the culture, but not the worlds best puppetry. A fairly unique puppet show, with pretty wooden puppets floating on and splashing on a pool of water.The theatre seems designed for smaller Asian sized people, so if you are 6 ft expect to be stuck like sardine, unless you ensure you book a front row seat.The puppets are showing quite a bit of wear and tear, but the music, singing and story make it worth the cash.
Interesting. Interesting way of how they do a puppet show. Most of the time you wont understand whats going on but its nice to see how the stage setting is done and how they control the puppets.
Fun hour. It's a different way to spend an hour of your time, I hadn't seen anything like it before so for 100K VND it was good value.Don't go expecting too much, just enjoy the show!
Interesting. Wasnt sure what to expect but the show is really interesting and the puppets beautifully done. Also really enjoyed the music.
Water puppets. Interesting, but missable. Singing and music good, live, high point. Puppets mixed condition, looking tired and not working well. Ok if you have nothing better to do

Not bad - but still worth doing. This is obviously done over and over, but we enjoyed it (especially my 10 yr old). It went for about an hour and you need to go early and book your seats or you'll miss out. The show was very interesting and tells the history of Vietnam through the use of water puppets and lighting. worth doing.
Nothing special. tis is only a few dollars and take only 45 mins so is worth a visit - the show describes pieces of their life/ beliefs - puppetry ok but show is a bit boring

Interesting and entertaining. Very nice show, very affordable. Don't bother paying more for up front seats, same view regardless and you see more from the mid to upper rows. The seats are very tight for any one 5'6 or taller, you'll have your knees at your chin. The announcer is hard to understand, but read the phamplet and the monitor during the show and it will all make sense. A/C unlikely, bring a fan and water in, as it's very hot and always jammed packed. Also buy your tickets at least 2 hours in advance, as they sell out all the time (think big tour groups).

Very clever. It was a bit touristy but fascinating. It also gives a good overview of some Vietnamese history and culture. Great for kids to see - very crowded however. Loved how ingenious the puppets were - I won't spoil the surprise here.

visit if you have nothing else to do. visited the theater as we didnt have any other interesting options to see around. didnt get the seats on sunday evening but got them on tuesday for the 18:30 show (u can get them directly at the counter for VND100000). paid another 1USD for camera but not everyone seems to be paying this additional amount. interesting concept and performance but not all can appreciate it. the entire performance last 30 mins which was too long for many people around.

My watch stopped..... ...and said that I had only been suffering for 45 minutes - it seemed like hours. After the musical intro and first number it could have finished and we would have walked away amused. Not so, we got more and more of the same. Each chapter may have a different intro but it was the same moves and same music. Then we have the audience - taking photos and videos, yelling at each other and standing up to get a better view. Refuge from the heat? - leave me in the direct sun as an alternative.

Strange but fun!. Although the setas are small for tall people it is comfortable for the 45 minute show. The english translations are sometimes wrong but amusing. The puppets are a bit battered but overall the show is fun and enjoyable.
Interesting show. Very good. Lasts about an hour. Nice to move indoors away from the heat and the heavy thunderstorms. Kids will love it too.

Tourist trap, pretty odd. Towards the end I started rocking back and forth uncontrollably chanting "make it go away, make it go away". My 7yo daughter spent most of the 45 minutes picking her feet she was so enthralled with it. I feel like a bad parent after torturing my children with this. At least it was cheap! Why everyone seems to speak about these water puppets of Vietnam in whispers is beyond me. I'm sure some will find it all very exotic and enchanting. I just thought it was B grade - particularly after having recently seen Siam Niramit in Thailand - talk about chalk and cheese!

Interesting display. We went to the water puppets in Hanoi after reading about how they were the best, I did enjoy them however I believe the ones we saw in Ho Chi Minh were more authentic and a better display,I was a little disappointed when they showed you at the end how they worked, I liked the mystery !! Overall not bad, however I have seen better !

Lovely 45 minutes. I wasn't sure what to expect but was pleasantly surprised.The show is about 45 minutes - just long enough. The "story" of each set is shown in English on a monitor on the side of the stage and that makes it easier to follow.If you want to take pictures you need to pay an additional amount of $1. The seats are tiny - I am 1.68m (average) tall and had to move to the isle as my knees were touching the chair in front.The audience is an experience - coming late, talking, kids playing on mobiles ........Overall a good way to cool down and be entertained.

Highly Recommended. Book early to see this wonderful display. The combination of puppetry skills, traditional music and story made this spellbinding. Without giving too much away it starts with the creation of Vietnam and progresses through various traditional screens. Only disappointment - No CD available

Disappointing. We were looking forward to this performance having a great interest in folklore & culture, however we did not think it was as impressive as the performance we saw at the museum on Ethnicity. All seats gave a good view, but were not particularly comfortable!
Great Show. Went here with a group of 6 people and everyone enjoyed it. The show is only about 45 minutes long which is actually perfect. Loved how passionate all of the puppeteers are.
Nice traditional music and fun. I was there with my little daughter and we loved it. The music was very nice and the show was really fun for my girl. Valuable for 45 minutes show.

Neat. Wanted to see what it's all about. Was a neat show. Great music and puppeteers. I got a kick out of watching how bored the featured musician was. Found it didn't hold my attention long and was disappointed so many of the puppet's paint was chipped so badly :(
Enchanting!. Very interesting theatre with beautiful music and puppets. Quite a magical experience. Children will like it very much

Great way to understand Vietnamese culture and history. Show lasted for 45 minutes and it worth the money to watch this artistically arranged cultural show. Complimented with live musical instruments and narration in local vietnamese language with translation projected on 2 large TV screen. Shows starts in the afternoon and runs until 9pm. Advisable to get tickets early as many tour buses will stop in front of this place and tickets runs out fast. There is a good coffee shop called Helio right beside this theatre where you can get a drink while waiting for your show time.

Cheap but waste of time unless you are taking a toddler. Many shows per day and the place was packed. Seems to be part of any tour. The vocalists and musicians were very good but the puppets movements and condition were bad....laughable!
Entertaining cultural show. The music and the skill of the puppeteers is excellent. I think it is probably good to be seated near the front if possible (we were int he front row).

Not just for children,,,,,. Well worth a visit! Its not just for children my boyfriend and I are both in our 30s and we had a great time, value for money and a nice way to see something a little different,

cute way to learn the local history. colourful and musical way to learn about the local ethin groups. It was quite crowded when we were there, but it was a long weekend.
Certainly worth visiting.

Worth a watch. Good show, kind of weird at the same time but entertaining nonetheless. Costs around $6US and lasts around 45 minutes. it does pay to get in early and buy your tickets early morning for the afternoon show. Enjoy!

Interesting but not a "must see". The concept of puppets being perform on water is quite unique. However the reason why i gave it only two stars is because its boring..! I was hoping to see a story play but what was shown is actually more like a documentary about Vietnam and its cultures based on their legends and beliefs. If you're lucky you could catch (a more genuine) show at the Museum of Ethnology.
Fantastic experience!!. This show was very well done with fantastic music, story telling and puppets. Very interesting and entertaining at the same time.

Must do!!!. We ran into the theatre by accident and bought a ticket. We are 30 and 57 years old.We both had a great time. It was an hour of live music...live singing and many background stories about Vietnam. It was very professional and amazing to see how all the puppet actors were in the water themselves.It was well worth the time and money!Try to sit in the middle...one of the first rows!

well synchronized puppet show inspired by the culture of the land. a lot of foreign tourists are lining up to buy entrance tickets. it is advised to buy your ticket in advance. the theater is located near the shopping area. a good coffee shop is found at the lobby which is full most of the time. the show is highy recommended

it's art.... this theater costs approx. 6 dollars for an approximately 45 minute show. Value for money is a guarantee, as something like this in the West would probably run over 30 dollars per person. The theater room titself is a bit crowded and the chairs really close together. The puppet show is really informative with background information written in English on a large screen to explain the difference scenes of the show. The live music is really nice. The puppets themselves are very well crafted and the puppeteers are very skilled. My 2 year old loved it as well!

Terryc. Just an average puppet show in the water. It was inexpensive and all seating was good. The narrators ans singers made the shoe dressed in traditional gear. Good way to cool off and rest a spell after walking through Hanoi traffic.
Worth a visit. Inexpensive, and an introduction to Vietnamese cultural life through water puppets, local musical instruments and signing.

Amazing!. it was entertaining,if you are really into music and performance,then this would be great for you,youll see the puppets performance and the music that goes along with it,i dont know what the hell is wrong with people who finds it boring,i guess you should have visited halong bay and went to cat ba island and do some trekking,i respect your opinion but maybe this is just not for you as music and performing arts might not be your thing.so pls just say you did not enjoy the show for your self instead of saying its boring.get some idea of what the place has to offer before going to save your self some time.
Boring. The story was very slow, had trouble staying awake, the amazing thing was how many people appeared at the end that were working the puppets
Boring show. The show was quite boring. Not worth the time and money. If there are other places to visit, you may skip this one.
a popular venue. It is interesting.puppets in the water telling stories from ancient history. Some puppets are a little old but we'll worth a visit.

Must see Vietnam's traditional culture. Water puppet has been Vietnamese traditional culture which dates back as far as the 11th century. So it's best to go and watch it. This is a live performing art where puppeteers hide behind a screen and move the wooden puppets using bamboo stick. The puppeteers usually perform in a waist-deep pool. Live music is also played together during these performances. We manage to catch the 3pm show which lasted for 45 minutes. The entrance ticket cost us USD10 for 2. There are 2 type of tickets. The expensive one which you get to sit near the front and the less expensive which sit at the back. I would recommend to go early and purchase your tickets early because this is a very popular show. Tickets sells out very very fast!! Faster than hot cakes.

Brilliant!. We weren't quite sure whether to go to this or not, however we were very pleased that we did.We caught the 5 o'clock show, it lasts foe one hour & costs a little over £3 each to get in.It's a proper theatre with a very large water pool as the stage setting, from which the puppets emerge to do various dances & enact stories, from Vietnamese history, on top of the water. There is a live orchestra, playing traditional music on traditional instruments, which is absolutelty lovely & the ladies that sing are wonderful, quite enchanting to watch them play & at the same time haunting to listen to.We couldn't help but think that if The Beatles had heard the sounds, then they would have been influenced by them, just as they were by the sitar & other ethnic music!Well worth a visit for those that are sceptcical, as we were!
Book early. This is understandably popular and right next to Hoan Kiem Lake so advisable to get your tickets early.

Very good. I would recommend visitor to see this show as it was very unique and interesting. The content was good and funny. Music was good as well. It would help us to know about Viet Nam's culture, Viet Nam contryside life (agricultural civilization)
Must see!. Great eye opener! A must watch when you are in Hanoi. The most expensive ticket only cost 100,000 Dong. :)
Great!!. The creativity and storyline of the water puppet show told a story which was very unique. An A+ for creativity on the part of the producers

Entertaining indeed!. Entertaining! The music was live and loud, stories very local and movements deft.. I caught the last show of the evening and thought the show did dragged on a tad too long but overall, fun entertainment. Go for it!

hmmm.... average. i fell asleep in the middle. but still, i gave a big clap for their effort. although i have to admit the performers did look a bit bored.. well, why shouldn't they since they perform 3 times a day everyday.. the hall was packed with people, nonetheless. but once is enough. i figured it's a must since it's my first time in Hanoi.

Interesting At Best. It's probably one of those things which must be included in a trip to Hanoi but it certainly wasn't the highlight. I probably enjoyed listening to and watching the 3 musicians more than the puppetary. Certainly the theatre was full and there was no shortage of camera flashes but in the end I came away feeling a little underwhelmed by the experience and puzzled as to why "water puppets?".

It's so exciting. I visited Ha Noi and my friend took me to this theater. I love so much the water puppet. It's very exciting and unique. The music was good as well. I help me understand Viet Nam culture that is a rice agriculture civilizationI would recommend people to watch water puppet when come to Ha Noi

Original idea but shaky execution. You would think that by now, with three daily performances, the puppeteers would score perfect presentations. Unfortunately it is not the case. The puppets are not synchronized- they move spastically-- the water is filthy (yikes! how can the puppeteers soak in that stew up to their torso for hours without catching something). The orchestra is there for show, as the music is recorded. Since your investment is limited to US$5 and 50 minutes of your time and the theater is air conditioned, if you are curious you might as well go.

A Charming Experience. I'm not usually a fan of bog standard tourist activities but I was persuaded to go with a friend who was very eager to see the show.Be warned it is definitely aimed at tourists and it felt unusual being surrounded by so many "foreigners" in such a concentrated area as the last few months had been spent largely with local people.The show is fascinating from a musical perspective as all the music is perfomred live as are all the songs and some of the instruments, the sounds they make and the way they are played is, in itself, very entertaining.Coupled with music and the puppets is a commentary before each section of the show which provides you with information about each performance which is about the folklore, the ethnic groupings of Vietnam and/or the history of the country, which provides for some useful context not just for the show but also for the country.Finally, the puppets - really the word that comes to mind is charming - its something the like of which I have never seen and may never again so I am glad I went. I would suggest putting any cyniscm aside, not expect anything overly sophisticated and go learn about some Vietnamese culture and history while being entertained by some wonderful artists, at approximately USD5, and one hour, you don't have much to lose if you do make the investment!

Could have been better. This show could have been really good, but the puppets are in bad shape, paint is chipping off. One of the baby puppets leg came flying off in one of the songs... I think it needs a bit of a revamp. It was a boring hour.

Novel insight into Vietnamese culture and history. Using the unusual medium of water puppetary the program covered an array of legends, mythology, music, historical events in a charming and entertaining manner.

Interesting entertainment but not a must-do. The puppet show was interesting but not overly entertaining. The live music was a nice touch. The best thing to me was the information on Vietnamese history and culture that was shared during the show. If you have spare time, do it, but don't go out of your way.

Out Standing Show. The water puppet show was highly professional with its movements and accompanying music. The ladies presenters on the stage did a good job. Visiting Hanoi without watching the water puppet is incomplete.

Tourist Mania. Surprisingly underwhelming and completely ruined by the multitude of ignorant tourists that spend the entire performance taking photos with bright flashes and holding cameras, mobile phones and video recorders up in the air. Exceptionally frustrating. Would advise booking day in advance minimum if you really want to go and get a seat up the front so youre not being blinded by the flashes.

The new programme is much better for western visitors. My second visit; the new programme made it much more accessible for overseas visitors. It is a little bit shorter - and the English subtitle screens were much easier than trying to read the programme in the dark. A special little taste of Hanoi!
Charming. Very charming, with monitors with English translations, nicely situated on the edge of the Old Quarter so easy to go on to some of the restaurants or try street food in the evening.

Interesting show. The show is interesting with traditional music, good techniques of the performers. However, it is pity when u cannot understand Vietnamese because the show includes some short Vietnamese conversations. The thing i disliked is the chairs, it is rather small and inconvenient. Take photos with flash off, do not annoy other audiences. Should buy the ticket at least 2 hours in advance. Their website: http://www.thanglongwaterpuppet.org/?/en/Home/

Great show!. The show only goes for just under an hour, great length of time really as anymore than that and it could be too much. Great music, singing and the puppets are engaging. The puppeteers come out at the end, waist deep in water. Good cultural experience and only costs about $5.
Water Puppets. Entertaining hour at a reasonable price. The play tells a somewhat legendary tale of Vietnam, all involving the water puppets and backed with live music.
Disappointing. Possibly because we were jet lagged we did not really get into this show. To be fair there were a lot of people but the applause was somewhat half hearted. We would not go again.

A Total Surprise. Worth every Dong. We were initially sceptical about the water puppets but they were very entertaining and fascinating to watch. The only downside, which we have discovered many times over, is that the seating is made for short locals and not tall foreigners.

Water Puppets - Performers Like No Other. Please see the show @ Thang Long Theater - the performers work long and hard and are waist deep in water for a couple of performances a day. Its charming and this Art originated in Vietnam. See it! Great Fun for Families!
Water Puppets. Well worth a visit, but if you want to take photos, get as close to the front as possible!!The performance has musical accompaniment and the story is told in English and Vietnamese.

Interesting local cultural show. Good location next to Hoan Kiem Lake (walkable distance from Old Quarters). Consists of about 8-10 mini stories (approximately 5 minutes each) depicting Vietnamese legends and culture. The show is in Vietnamese language however the story line will be flash out in English via LCD TVs. You can also secure a copy of the story line pamphlet outside the theater (in English, Chinese, Japanese, French, etc) to ensure you understand the play. Get your ticket earlier (from Hotel or tour agents) to secure the best seats.

Short but not expensive. This show lasts a little over 45 minutes. A bit short but it was cheap in any case. Interesting concept. You need to have an idea of what this is about. Essentially it is the legend of Vietnam's birth.

easy to reach with nice try. Once you arrived there, let's try.You will know and can learn the vietnam culture from this place.But the ticket price show 60.000 VND and 100.000 VND on the board, but actully the ticket officer told that only 100.000 VND. per person.

Definitely worth a visit once!. I would definitely recommend checking out the Water Puppets as where else in the world can you see this creative arts performance?! The puppetry was combined with wonderful, traditional live music you would watch at the same time as the puppet show. Highly recommend getting tickets (though hotel or direct) in advance at least a couple of days to get in the first few rows (A-Z). If you're closer to the front not only can you see the puppets better, but also the narration of what is taking place (in English). It's a wonderful explanation of the Vietnamese people and their history. It's a dying part of their culture so see it while you can! No food/drink for purchase, bathrooms not so great, but it's only 40-45 minutes long. Really enjoyed the colorful puppets, entertaining movements, beautiful music and learning more about the Vietnamese culture.

Interesting. This show is interesting to know a traditional art of Vietnam. Story is simple, so is the performance, but I liked very much the delicate movements of the puppets and the live band, that was very good. It's very touristic and the theather is a bit run down, with old bathrooms and not very comfortable chairs. If you like puppets, go for it! I'm assessing it average because it's not something wow. But worth, especially because it's cheap.

Worth a visit. The puppets are quiet clever and if you are travelling with children they will love it. (I would rate it as average for adults). The show itself isn't very long and we found it an easy "extra" while out for dinner.
Lovely show. A really lovely show that tells the history of Vietnam and is part of Vietnamese culture. The puppeteers do a great job with their movements, it's interesting to watch

Long standing tradition. If you want to see a water puppet show in Vietnam, Thang Long Theater is the place to go. It's the most famous show in the country. It's done in the traditional style (which was invented centuries ago) so don't expect 21st century lighting and visual effects. While it wasn't the highlight of my trip, it is worth seeing if you have the time and budget. Find out more about what you can expect from the performance at: http://backpacktress.blogspot.com/2013/04/vietnam-water-puppet-show.html

a waste of time. Came to Hanoi as the last stop to our 20-day South East Asia trip, what a disappointment. We ran out of things to do the first day, a friend of mine suggested we go see the water puppet show, boy what a waste of time we had too much of.The theater was stuffy and cramped, the show was not exciting at all, I mean some of the puppets weren't even working properly and out of sync. The best part of the show was probably the first 5 minutes when a dragon came out to breed with a phoenix and eggs were hatched, the rest was just redundant and boring. Honestly, some kids were even falling asleep. I will never return to Hanoi again, and most definitely don't recommend the show, although perhaps it's worth just to see how bad it is.

Better things on offer. Whilst it has some cultural appeal, the show is quite long, seat cramped and uncomfortable and the auditorium stuffy. The show itself is interesting but does not offer enough variety to keep you interested beyond two of the ten acts

Excellent. A really lovely show that tells the history of Vietnam and is part of Vietnamese culture. The music is absolutely lovely and the puppets charming. Photos can be taken, but you have to pay 20,000 Dong for the privilege.

Something different and enjoyable.. There are a lot of mixed reviews about this show, but I quite enjoyed it. The music was cool, the puppets were fun (although they could do with a paint job). The puppeteers do a great job with their movements, it's interesting to watch. Even if you don't like it, it only costs about AU$5 and goes for 40 minutes - not like you have wasted a whole day. I'd recommend getting the 100,000dong ticket as you are closer to the stage and can therefore read the narration better.

Good show. This is an old theatre providing 45 minute performances with puppets moving around in water - tales from the rice paddies. Musicians play authentic vietnamise instruments and behind the scenes the puppeteers move the characters around via poles under the water.Our group were all very tired after travelling 28 hours or so, but the music will keep you awake!

Didn't know what to expect. Just could not decide how it worked. Kept looking for strings! A good show and the musicians added so much. Picture taking was allowed which was very distracting, especially the iPads.

I've seen it.... We went to a 6pm show and the theatre was packed. I wasn't sure what to expect as we had heard mixed reviews, but you don't know unless you see it for yourself. I did like the music, I like the idea behind it (explaining Vietnams history) and I really liked the fact it only went for 50 minutes. Of course every tourist in there uses flash photography so it looks like a disco at times which was annoying. The seating is tight and cramped but like I said, it goes for less than an hour. On a positive note my 2 year old daughter absolutely loved it. I'm glad I saw the puppets, not sure I'd go again though.

Worth it for the music!. The live Vietnamese music played on interesting instruments and singing was well worth the visit- very moving and atmospheric. I really appreciated the free program to explain the scenes we would see beforehand available in a number of languages. However, personally I found the puppet show itself a little boring and repetitive at times. But perhaps I'm just a little uncultured because many people around me were moved to tears!!
Entertaining and Unique. Although it seems that the show is mainly for tourists, it is interesting and unique. It is worth seeing this Vietnamese traditonal entertainment.

Would be better if it was shorter. This is a very interesting show, but it's a tad too long. Also, it would be nice if the musicians were visible because the live music is beautiful. I did see some people sleeping in the 8pm show, but our four-year-old made it through, so I guess it was interesting enough!

Interesting, immersive experience. Second time watching the show. The troupe does update the program as I remember it being quite different. Enjoyed it immensely both times! The powerful singing, rich instrumentation and skillful puppet manipulation captivated me throughout the entire show. A very immersive experience. An hour gone by in a flash!

this is a must see. on my trip to Vietnam this month we went to the water puppet theatre in Hanoi i have never seen a show like this anywhere in the world ot was fantastic highly recommend to all visitors to Hanoi

Disappointing show this time.... On the one hand, it's nice that the puppet troupe dream up new shows regularly, but on the other, this one was a little disappointing. The water puppet art is still well worth seeing, but the show was a little lacklustre this time (I've seen shows previously in Hanoi and HCMC), and lacked the humour of the ones I've seen before. Still a fascinating art form and the puppeteers and musicians are very skilled.

Hanoi Water Puppet Theater. It is interesting to listen to Vietnam's traditional music. Other than that, Personally feel that this show is slightly boring. There were many repetitive moments although the puppets wore different costumes. The puppets are also quite worn out. If you have time to spare, you may consider watching this show. Otherwise, I think exploring the street food, walking by the lake would be of a better option.
Truly unique. Weirdest thing I ever saw in my life. People waist deep in water behind a screen, playing with puppets. Absolutely wonderful and unique. Very enjoyable!

Very Unusual. You will probably not see a theater like this in other places. This is a traditional type of art developed in the country, usually performed after harvest. The puppets are manipulated by performers hidden by a curtain. Puppets and puppeteers are standing in water. Very interesting.

Good to see. Worthwhile the $5US to see the 50 minute show. Seats are very close together and if you are tall, very cramped ( I am 174cm and knees very bent). Well put together show, but 50 minutes long enough. Need to book, preferably day before to get the show you want. 4 shows a day. All in afternoon/evening.

An hour I'm not getting back. We went to the 9pm showing and although I had low expectations I was surprised just how poor this was. The theatre itself smelled of damp, the seats were small and the film explaining what was happening was written in tiny letters that were almost impossible to read. An hour of our trip we could have spent doing something else!

I never knew such a unique thing existed!. It was a show describing the history of evolution of Vietnam in decades; it also demonstrated the different culture of different parts of Vietnam. At the left corner of the dias, the singers and the orchestra were sitting playing instruments and singing and describing the puppet dance; vis-a-vis at the right corner a TV monitor was giving brief in english as to what will be displayed next. In the centre of dias was the big pool of water upon which the puppet show took place.
