The puppets were placed on a bamboo and their parts were moving with threads fixed with the bamboo; whole time the bamboo was being moved from the back behind a curtained area by some expert puppeteers. They were saying this type of water puppet show is only one of its kind in the world! I don't know how far that is true but it was definitely a new and unique experience for me!

Fun and entertaining show. Our tour of Hanoi included the water puppet show and we had a great time! It was fun and informative to learn about the stories of Vietnam. The puppets are really cute too! It was amazing to see all the puppeteers come out at the end of the show. They must have some good arm muscles to maneuver the long stick back and forth for the puppet movements. If you have the opportunity to see this show, then do it! If you use the bathroom, just remember to bring your own toilet paper.

The most bizarre thing I've seen on holiday. We took the 1945hrs show, well organised, shown to our seats...The band seem to really enjoy themselves but I had no idea what was going on, the programme explained what the scene was but really all I could deduce was lots of splashing and whirling puppets around in the water.I'm sure if I'd have understood Vietnamese it would have all made sense... Saying that, it was very clever how each of the puppets were controlledbewitch out the audience seeing the puppeteers. Whilst it wasn't my cup of tea, my wife really enjoyed it and says I'm miserable. I guess it's a 'must do' for an insight into Vietnamese entertainment, but I wouldn't rush back. Sorry guys.

Interesting Puppets - but Too Much Politics. If you have not seen a water puppet theatre before, you should definitely see this show. It is a colourful, skillful performance. Book ahead if you want good seats, as the best seats tend to go to groups.Plus points: You can see as well as hear the musicians on either side of the stage, and the music is excellent. Lighting and stage effects are also very good.The performance is fast-paced, and is all over in about 45 minutes - so it is not over-long for children.Less positive: The program packs in a great deal about Vietnamese cultural history and cultural diversity. The content was interesting in itself, but one feels the heavy hand of the Party and of political correctness: the message is clearly that VietNam is ONE nation and always has been. By contrast, I found the performances in the smaller water puppet theatre in Saigon much fresher and more creative,

Great piece of cultural entertainment. My family and our travelling friends attended for a Tues night performance. I had previously seen this troop when they visited Adelaide for a Festival of Arts some years ago. On their home ground the performers occupy a purpose built theatre with great accoustics and every seat offers a good view. Very tight for legroom though. The show itself is a series of 10 or so vignettes, drawing on stories from myth and religion as well as Vietnamese rural life. The performance is accompanied by traditional instruments, played with polish and flair by the resident musicians and singers. Photos are allowed, and there is no need to pay the extra money asked. Just go ahead. Overall, a great way to spend an hour with the kids.

Very very interesting. The puppet show is like no other. Very very enjoyable and very different. Enjoyed the colorful performance and the music. It's a story about Vietnam. A worthwhile show to watch and should not miss.

Novel show. We visited this how as part of the food walking tour with Vietnam Awesome Tours and this allowed us front row seats so we had a great view of the show.It was a very novel ( and historic) way of giving a puppet show.The show included demonstrations of various parts of Vietnamese culture and so this added to the appeal of the show. A wide range of local musical instruments were used too which added to the show.

Water puppets - not for me. What a disappointment this was. We were all crowded into the theatre at the end of a long day to watch this. It seems to be on the itinerary of all the groups. I had trouble keeping my eyes open - one to miss i think

Delightful but professionalized folk art. This show was a lot of fun and very interesting. The live music and instruments were an important tpart of the show, but, of course, the water puppets were the star attraction--especially the water-spouting dragons! As is often the case with institutionalized folk art, there's a professional sheen that doesn't quite fit the medium. As others have noted, the seats were installed for the petite Vietnamese and larger visitors will find them quite confining.

Very interesting. This is considered a cultural highlight of a trip to Hanoi and the theatre was full of both tourists and local people. We enjoyed the 40 minute performance which was deftly performed and accompanied by Vietnamese instruments and songs, and were fascinated by the mechanics which were revealed at the end. I would have enjoyed it far more if the screaming baby behind me had been taken out of the theatre but as far as the production, it was very nice--and I can see that children would really enjoy it. I would not do it a second time, but it was worth one visit.

Entertaining. Very entertaining but very busy and if you are either a very tall or large person the seats are designed for small people. I am just over 6' and had trouble fitting into the seats and my legs cramped up by the end of the 40 minute show

Better than expected. A very enjoyable hour watching something very different.Easy to find on a corner opposite the lake, we were easily able to book for the next day as the Saturday time didn't suit us.The show started on time and ran for 50 minutes, I think it cost 100,000 dong p.p. (about $5.00 )The seating was very comfortable and the music wasn't too loud ( unlike many places in Australia )A pamphlet was provided that told the story of each dance, this helped us enjoy it as we were able to understand what was happening.The movement and colour of the puppets and the beautiful singing and music all added up to a very good show.

Water puppets. Don't book the water puppet show until you arrive,in Hanio Get your tickets either in the morning or day before they have quite a few shows each day. The price is only 100,00.00 dong $5.00 Australian dollars. It is a great show very colourful, with beautiful singing. It goes for about 1 hour. Worth seeing. We were going to book back home but I'm glad we didn't as its so cheap.

Wonderful show. I enjoyed it although I usually am not so into these kind of things. There are several shows a day. I bought my my ticket in the morning.Theatre is easy to find, near the lake. There were still seats available for every evening show. However, I didn't know the seats were numbered. Luckily I sat in the middle, but i would have enjoyed the show even more if I sat closer to the stage. So better check where your seat is when buying the tickets.

Nice experience. As a Vietnamese, I am familiar with this art. But I didn't help feeling surprised of how the show went. The music is amazing and the content is well-demonstrated. They speak cute Vietnamese accent and have the subtitle showed behind.If you are interested in seeing the culture of Vietnam, especially that of various ethnic groups, it is highly recommended. An excellent way to preserve this precious art of VietnamOne thing you should take into consideration is that the content is repeated through different shows. So first time would be nice experience. The second time, like watching a film, is not worth.

A fun experience. As part of our tour we had this trip experience pre-booked. It was a fun hour and was an interesting art form to watch. For those who are mechanically minded its interesting to see how all of the equipment operates, and it keep me entertained trying to identify the mechanics. I wouldn't rush back though, but glad that I saw it.

Great for the whole family. We loved this show. However, if you've seen one puppet show you've seen them all. The puppeteers did an excellent job of telling the story. The wooden puppets were beautifully designed. The music was good. Kids were entertained the entire 45 minutes. Seats were fine, but if you are a tall person you may have to get a folding isle chair. We would highly recommend this show in Hanoi!! Get your tickets early to get the best seats.

Wasn't sure I would enjoy it but I did. Visited the puppet show as part of our tour and as the heading says I wasn't sure if I would enjoy it. However it was a very enjoyable 45 minutes, any longer and I might have got a bit restless. The story is well explained albeit some of the translation needs a bit of imagination. The seats were quite comfortable although my husband struggled with the leg room but he survived! The show is well planned and some of the puppets were very colourful, the music and singing were also enjoyable. Give it a go it is a traditional form of entertainment and it does only last 45 minutes.

An absolute must-see. In the centre of town, and lasting just 50 minutes, it's an absolute must if you're visiting Hanoi. It's 60,000 or 100,000 VND per ticket (about GBP3). Do try and book e day before. There's 5/6 shows a day but they get booked up quickly. Amazing live traditional music and singing accompany the magnificent puppet show. We absolutely loved it.

Must see!. We were impressed by the Puppet Theater.The artists are just amazingly good, the music is live and very pleasant. The show is only 45-50 minutes long so there is no time to even think about getting bored.And the tickets are very cheap - $4.Go to the ticket office and book in advance as the tickets 9especially for the 9pm show) run out quickly.

An interesting take on a puppet show. This is one of the old favourites for travellers to Hanoi. It was an interesting show accompanied by a live band. The show goes for about 45 minutes. Which is more than enough. I started to feel like I had seen enough by the 20 minute mark. I would highly recommend getting a seat close to the front. I sat in the front row and had a clean view of the puppets and was able to get some decent photos. The puppets arent all that big and I would imagine sitting at the back of the auditorium it would be very hard to see much of the detail.

Fun!. Brilliant stuff. Traditional stories told with wooden puppets on a small pool accompanied by live musicians. There is an English translation of the commentary via a couple of screens and a printed programme. The skill of the puppeteers is amazing and it is a great experience. We got front row seats for $5 each. Highly recommended.
Puppet mastery. Original with brilliant manipulation with enchanting music. Book as soon as you can as it is very popular. Show is about1 hour.

Uncomfortable but skillful. The seats in this theatre are very uncomfortable - if you are tall as in taller than 160cm you are in trouble fitting into the seats, equally if you are overweight - think narrower than a normal plane seat. They cater for tall people by having foldable chairs on the walkway. the presentation is something else- beautiful live music, the narrator's voice is very peasant, the puppets are very lively and colourful.

wonderful. a different experience as I thought it was open air however in a theatre. Music and show was magical. A story easy to follow. the ending was great as the puppeteers came out waist deep in water wearing waders, and smiling.

Delightful Aquatic. The show is charmingly presented, lots of colourful puppets performing historical Vietnamese stories and legends to live traditional music and all operated by means of rods and wires underwater. It is often booked up for days in advance so make sure you allow enough time for it during your stay in Hanoi.
A must. Worth a visit to see the traditional puppet theatre- 45 minute show which is just the right length, and cheap

Worth seeing - a different art form. We've seen a lot, but this 45-minute show was something else, imaginative, artistic, good entertainment. Amazing what the master of the water puppets can do with their wooden friends!

Amazing puppets. I have always been fascinated by the water puppets ever since I was a little kid. Water puppet show is Vietnamese traditional puppet show that you can find nowhere else in the world. It is amusing how the puppets look like they are walking on the water all by themselves without any strings. As kid I thought that the puppeteers had to hold their breath and stay underwater the whole time. Really worth a try.

Great way to fill 45 minutes. I really enjoyed this show. Along with the advertised shows starting from 3.30pm, they were also running a show at 2.15pm on the days we were in Hanoi. I am not sure if this is typical.The show was informative and fun. Just the right length at 45 minutes. Unfortunately, the constant use of flash photography was a little annoying at times. Also, if you are booking, ask for a seat in the front row (row A). We were in row C and seeing some parts of the performance was difficult even from only the third row back.
Interesting. Interesting thing to see if you have never seen a water puppet show, but a bit long. Live music was pretty and a nice touch.
Socialist propaganda. Not the most exciting show in town! "All the tribes coming from one egg" seems to gloss over the ethnic tensions in Vietnam.

So bad it was funny. This was a "must see" in the guide book, but it came across as very amateurish and rather silly. It was actually amusing because it was so weird. The puppeteers had trouble controlling the puppets and a couple times a piece of a puppet would fall off and float off to the side. I wouldn't call it a "cultural" experience, but it was mildly amusing, so don't take it off the list. You may find it amusing as well.

Definitely worth a visit!. It was great to see some traditional Vietnamese culture, among all the motorbikes and madness. We are a young couple, and we really enjoyed this, though we didn't see too many other people our age there. I think you;d have to be quite narrow minded not to appreciate the skill and beauty of the water puppet show! It's not something we've ever seen before, and it was a little slice of tranquillity in busy Hanoi. Plus, it's only about 5 quid. You can't loose!

Interesting cultural event. We were fascinated by this very authentic expression of ancient Vietnamese culture. The showmanship was excellent as were the traditional orchestra & hand made puppets. We had expected to be bored after reading the reviews on Tripadvisor but we thoroughly enjoyed the 45 minute long show. Seats near the front afforded great photographic opportunities.
Water puppets. Fun, beautifully presented, good value. Our children were a bit restless by the end (6 and 8), but we all enjoyed it. Sunday morning children get in for cheaper.

Bright, colourful and interesting!. This show was wonderfully executed. The colours of the puppets, the lighting, the music, the water - it all made for quite a magical show! Our 9 year old daughter loved it and we took some lovely photos.Even though the narrative is in Vietnamese - the English version is posted on screens which we found easy to see and read.Definitely a must see as its unique to Vietnam.The souvenir shop outside is quite small and we found better and cheaper water puppets in markets elsewhere.

Mmmmm cheap and worth a visit for the sake of 45mins. I attended the show we 3 x friends at the 9.15pm show, it lasted around 45 minutes (any longer and i would have been asleep like most of the theatre).Almost all of the row in front of us had fallen asleep, it was sooooo funny and was te ony thing keeping us awake by giggling! I would question the skill and amount of "training" it takes to be able to work the puppets - I used to do something similar in the bath as a child ha!It's 45 mins of your life and for that reason ony I would say go along it's cheap and if you do get bored just place bets on how many people will end up dropping off during the show!

So much better 4 years ago.... I went to Hanoi 3 times in late 2008 and early 2009, and went to the Thang Long Water Puppet Theatre each time. It was the same show but I thoroughly enjoyed it (why would I go 3 times in 7 months if I didn't!). The acts were varied, interesting, and incredibly humorous--Kids swimming, lots of parades, funny animals -- I don't recall any story based on legends, no real linkage between the acts. Just good fun, with background music that I remember to this day. I enjoyed it so much that after my third visit, I actually purchased one of the puppets that they sell in the lobby -- And I don't tend to purchase souvenirs, ever!I was in Hanoi last week for another work-related trip, and looked forward to paying another visit to the puppet theatre -- I heard that the program had changed: But was I ever disappointed. The dragon and swan duo at the beginning was cute, but the remainder of the program was stifling: The various acts were supposedly based on the day-to-day lives of people in the different provinces, but the puppetry essentially consisted of figures bobbing up and down in the water swinging their arms. Like so many others, I dozed off intermittently throughout, I found it so boring. It was like the puppeteers behind the curtains were putting in the least effort they could (again, compared with the past). I found the whole performance to be Incredibly uncreative, and I felt sad, as the various acts used to be so varied and sparkling.Bring back the old! Or if that's not possible, I hope they re-tool the acts significantly. Next time I'm in Hanoi, I'll be visiting the puppet theatre at the Ethnographic Museum, which I've heard is more "authentic".

What a boring show !. I was with a tour... That day, our last stop was the famous " Water Puppet Theatre "... Honestly, more than half of the show, I was just sleeping... It was so boring !!! But, I have to say that the starting of the show was colorful...

Unique show good for the kids!. The theater was very near the hotel where we stayed in the Hoan Kiem district. The 45 minutes show is good for kids up to 10 years old. Almost all of the adults in our group of 24 either slept halfway thru the show or had difficulty staying awake and only the kids were enjoying the show. But it was a unique experience!

Something a bit different, decent value, but have some respect for others and take your seats in good time for the start. We went to a 5pm showing the other day and were entertained enough for the 45 minutes or so of the show. Just about worth a $3 seat to see it for its unique cultural experience, but not much more since the novelty of seeing water puppets wears off quite quickly and not all the puppets seem to work (or the puppeteers are being lazy behind those curtains). There is a Vietnamese commentary with English language screens narrating the show, although there are so many tourists and so few locals that it should probably be the other way around.However the start, which was probably the best bit from what we saw (the bit with the dragon) and should have been the novelty part being something we've never seen before, was completely ruined because two or three coachloads of tourists took their seats in the four rows in front of us after the performance had begun (filing in from the door noisily and disturbing more than just the back rows I'm sure). There's a cafe downstairs so no doubt the theatre or their tour guides were encouraging coffee consumption, but there's no excuse for missing the start. They didn't even rush to their seats but noisily talked their way in, despite there being music. Maybe these tourists were just complete morons, maybe it was their tour guides fault, maybe it was the fault of the theatre. No excuse for it happening though. Grumble grumble grumble.

it's in vietnamese language. Quite a unique show, puppets on the water. It would be more interesting if it is not in vietnames language for tourist who watch this. Because later on, you will get bored of not knowing or understand the story of it.

Different and interesting. Of course is a show for tourists although is spoken in Vietnamese. But it is realy well done and presented. Live music, translation in big screens, around 40 minutes show. First a musical prelude and then 8 pieces showing the rural daily life of the people. The performers hide behind a curtain with waist deep in water and maneuver their puppets from there. The performance is done in a water tank. You may choose to pay US$ 3 or 5 depending on the place you want to sit. In the way out you can take pictures of the old puppets on display at the foyer.We bought our tickets in the same day of the performance.

Tourist trap. This was a total tourist trap, snoozer. My husband and kids were sound asleep in 20 minutes. This was recommended by our guide, I'm guessing the tour companies get a cut of ticket sales.

unique performance. puppets in water. very unique. very colourful. shows only found in vietnam. must watch. not expensive. however, audio in english wld be good instead of vietnamese language coz there are more foreign tourists than locals in the theater. although english is written on screens, the writings are too small for older folks.

very unique performance. puppets in water. very unique. very colourful. show only found in vietnam. must watch. however, wld be good if audio in english is used instead of vietnamese language. although english is written on screen, the words are too small for old folks.

Professional and unique to understand vietnamese culture. I was following a tour and they got us thr ticket.
It is an intetesting and unique tour. The sound system, the lighting are professionally done.
You would have an memorable experience for it.

Water Puppets, what is that?. Puppet theatre, with puppets in water!
Narrated in Vietnamese but translation shown on large screens meant we could follow the plot
Live music accompanied the show
Excellent theatre, could see the stage well
Book a day or more in advance, it is often full.
Too long. Novelty value for the first 10 minutes made it different, unusual and interesting. The other 35 minutes went by way too slowly.

Good for the first five minutes, then boring..... I'm sure its not easy to do, and I know that its a tradition, but five minutes would have been plenty. Not very impressed... It goes on for way too long.
Great show. Wasn't sure what to think before we went. We mainly went as we though my 4yo son would enjoy the show. We all thought it was great and my son loved it. Better than I expected!

A Show not be missed. We had our hotel book tickets for us to see this show and I am so glad we did. Water Puppetry is a tradition that dates back as far as the 11th century. If you go to the Museum of Ethnology you can also see some old wooden water puppets on display. A large rod supports the puppets under the water and is used by the puppeteers who are hidden behind a screen. Seeing the puppets tell the story really was amusing. The cost is reasonable and only takes less than an hour. If you travel all the way to Hanoi and do not go to this puppet play than you are missing out understanding their culture.
good show. suitable for all ages from tiny tots to pensioners. The skill of the people working the puppets us amazing. my 3 year old granddaughter sat spellbound through the whole performance.

boring.... Not what I was expecting. Just a tourist trap. The show was quite boring and the translation into English was pretty bad. I felt like a sheep going into the theater: hundreds of middle ages tourists got out of buses 10 min before the show and when the show ended they all jumped straight back into the around 10 buses waiting in front of the theater to go quickly to the next attraction. I feel bad that I fell for that trap too...

Normal puppet show in water.... Liked: This shows the different culture of Vietnam. Disliked: Entrance fee is expensive. They even ask you to pay additional fee if you would like to take photos/videos. Seats are for small people.

Something a little different. Love the water puppets! The show goes for an hour. I think that I watched the orchestra as much as I watched the puppets. It was interesting to see the different instruments being played.Don't miss this

Amazing performance. The show lasts about one hour and is unique since it is performed by puppets on a small lake. It is accompanied by traditional music and there is a program in English explaining what the story is about.It is skillfully done and fascinating to watch the operation of the puppets.

Surprisingly good. We really went because you just cannot go to Vietnam without seeing a water puppet show - but we were actually very pleasantly surprised! The music was good - the puppets amazing - and very amusing. The one downside - we sat near the back - it was impossible to see the writing for the subtittles on the screen!
Fantastic. Fantastic show! We loved the water puppet theatre, it is such an original show. And we loved that there was an explanation of the stories being told.

Glad I went. Went to the 9.15 performance, not sure if it was going to be a tick in the box. I am really glad I went, its a 45minute performance including live music and it was well worth it. Very clever production and I really enjoyed it. If you want to take pictures you have to pay a small fee.

unique entertainment. If you have a couple of hours and are looking for entertainment, this is a good way to spend the evening. The theatre is in a nice part of Hanoi. Understand this style of puppetry evolved from ride paddies; that makes it interesting from a historical angle.

A national treasure but the luck of the draw. The Thang Long Water Puppet Theater is a highly revered by the Vietnamese, and the art form is considered a national treasure. I greatly enjoyed the performance with the highly intricate puppets and can only imagine the skill it takes. The music and singing is also high quality and completes the entire experience. If you go to Vietnam, you really need to see this. The show is relatively quick and it's easy to work into a day touring around Hanoi. That said, the seats leave much to be desired. If you are more than 6'2', you will not be physically able to put the seat down! I'm taller than that, so I had to move to one of the folding chairs along the side stairs. It was awkward, but in the end, a superior seat as I had much more room. This is also the kind of thing that attracts the worst kind of package tourists unfortunately. There was a group in the front few rows that held up their cameras and video recorders for almost the entire performance I cannot imagine what it was like for the people directly behind them. Given the amount of international tourist traffic going through Vietnam, it would be worth the effort for this theater to remodel the seats to be slightly larger and with more viewing pitch. My recommendation. If you can see water puppet theater somewhere else in Vietnam in a more pleasant environment, go for it, even if it's an inferior troop. But if you're in Hanoi and this works into your schedule, just go into it knowing what to expect. It's a worthy yet highly touristic tick the box experience.

Good for children. Colourful puppets with singers and musicians - It's always good to see local culture but the performance was an hour long which is about 30 minutes too long. There was a lot of fidgeting and the theatre was very humid - don't go if you are claustrophobic. There is an English translation of what the narrator is saying on a screen to the side of the stage which was helpful.

Thang Long Water Puppet Theater: Beautifully Done. The Water Puppet Theater's auditorium was completely packed. The show displayed a high degree of artistry and professionalism and was beautifiully choreographed. You could not tell that the puppets were being operated by human beings. Fortunately, the puppeteers took their curtain calls along with the puppets. A marvelous theatrical experience!

Bit boring.... I understand this is traditional performance art but it for me it was boring. Was also very uncomfortable in the tiny seats with a big guy in front of me blocking my view. The kids seemed to enjoy the first half but they got restless after 20 minutes asking "how long does this go for"? It just seems something you do as a tourist in Hanoi, however if you miss out on tickets (they tend to sell out) don't be too worried!!

Puppet show with a difference, a must for all age groups. Vsiiting the Vietnamese Water Puppet show which dates back about 1000 years, should be on everyone's itinerary when visiting Hanoi.Be sure to buy an extra ticket ("Tickets of Camera") so that you can take pictures of an exquisite water Puppet show. Set your ISO at the highest possible speed rating (mine was set at 6400) turn off the flash and shoot!

An Art True to Its Originality. While many of the shows that we have visited have evolved to include state-of-the-art lighting & AV equipment, water puppet has stay true to its originality. Besides some spot lights and a elevated podium for the musicians dressed in pretty white aoi an, it is very much still an old art form. For USD5 (VIP seating per pax), I believed it is still worth to keep this traditional art of entertainment going.

45 minutes fun, tiny seats, worth to do it. hiwe booked on same day, was not a problemlike in a cinema with subtitles , but seats are a bit critical for tall/strong people (just OK for 45 minutes)we were somewhere in the middle, perhaps is the first row the best ??!! its a kind of "to do" in hanoi, and after you can join all the conversations "how was the puppet theater" ;-))cheers
Interesting water puppets. If you are over jet lagged like we were, I recommend an earlier show, we were nodding out, unfortunately!
Fun with the kids. Something you are not going to find elsewhere for sure. The music is very fun and the puppets were unlike other shows we had seen. The kids definitely enjoyed it.

Not a water puppet fan.... We went with a tour group. It was after lunch, which may not be the best time to go. Long story short: I fell asleep. Others around me seemed to be ok with the show, so it gets 3 stars.
A true pleasure to see. This was very enjoyable and at $5 well worth going. Interesting to see this old art form. The way the artists moved the puppets in the water was amazing.
Great Fun!. Better than I was expecting it to be. Really clever. Seating was a bit cramped but it was still very enjoyable.

Working Magic With Water. We saw the water puppet theater performance one day. There were roughly eight or nine different scenes, accompanied by musicians playing traditional instruments, in a darkened theater. The puppets are manipulated by people and provide memorable entertainment, set within a large pool of water, for both local people and tourists. Scenes may have had both historic and legendary backgrounds, as I recollect. Are there many other puppet theaters in Vietnam? I don't know. This one certainly is famous and the water-based entertainment is unique and satisfying. The instruments and sounds are a special treat, for western tourists, as the sounds and melodies are unique. At the end of the performance, the puppeteers appear. A big round of applause from this visitor!

surpassed expectations. We went here as part of a Wendy Wu tour group. My husband specially was not looking forward to it, but we were entranced. The music is exceptianally, seems to be specially written contemporary music and the show was nicely presented in bite sizes so there was always something new happening. Beautiful.
Water Puppets. I am sure they are very clever but they didn't "wow" me. Interesting, a good place to enjoy the aircon when it is getting hot but ... puppets

Water Puppets. What a fantastic and unique experience. The show was done very well with authentic music and narration with English interpretation. It lasts about an hour. The puppeteers and the puppets are great. An experience not to be missed.

Great spectacle-loved the show. Wow, I really enjoyed this.--The theatre, music and water layout.And the English explanations on the side screens to explain the themes, background and meanings before each segment.The show was full of colour, characters and a real example of a story with great teamwork, timing and co-ordination.Well worth the time.

OK but you've seen it all in five minutes.. I saw the water puppets earlier this month and they were OK.First up - it is very popular so book early for the show that you want, and ask for the front row if you are above 5'6" tall. Leg room is virtually non existent - I'm 6'5" and I felt like a sardine. Each ticket sold has a row and seat number handwritten on it which you aren't made aware of when you buy so always ask for the front row if you can. The puppets aren't huge so closer to the front also benefits your enjoyment.Secondly - now you know that you have a booked seat you don't have to take part in the awful scrum to get in. We were split, jostled, pulled and pushed on the way in and there really is no need once everyone realises that they have allocated seats.The show itself lasts about 40 minutes and is fine. There is a subtitled narrative and the puppets act out what has just been said accompanied by some good local music. Ok, the puppets are cleverly put together and skilfully operated but I was over that in five minutes, after which I got back to concentrating on how to sit more comfortably in my small seat. I don't want to belittle the puppeteers as it's obviously skilful just not really my cup of tea.The show tickets were pretty cheap but I've seen it now and don't feel the need to return.
Loved it. Really good show. Entertaining, clever & humourous. Really nice that puppeteers all came out to take abow at the end. Good coffee in coffee shop below as well!

Beautiful Music and awesome performance. I watched both water puppets from Golden Dragon Theater in Saigon and Thang Long in Hanoi. Both are really good. Although this show was less comical than Golden Dragon, it gave me a sense of awe throughout the whole performance. I loved the opera and I really admire the ladies' elegance as they play the musical instruments, sing and speak. The show also allowed me to appreciate Vietnam history and lifestyle. I felt so tempted to retire in Vietnam! I liked the adorable puppets and I was really tempted to buy one. All in all, I had a good night sleep after the show

Don't miss out. Ignore those that say it is too kitsch listen to the songs and stories and be in the story, then it all makes sense. The art form is ancient so enjoy it for what it is not the reviews, sit close to the action...get wet and be a part of it
Slightly disappointed. We were slightly disappointed in the production however, we really enjoyed the musicians and the narrative.
Great fun. I loved the puppets, there were some great characters,the musicians accompanying the show were excellent. I would really recommend a visit, great for adults and children.

Tick on the list... But so unusual.. It is so hard to explain this show. I'm not sure how something can be so interesting and yet so boring at the same time. The show is about an hour though so at least it doesn't go on for too long. I kept thinking it may get better... but it stayed at about the same pace throughout. It's not expensive so go do it... but don't expect too much.

Super interesting and an insight to the culture. I suggest that everyone see this show. It only takes 45 minutes and if you are curious like I was...check it out. I think this water puppet performance must be unique in SE Asia so it gives some cultural insight. It is only 100 dong if you buy tickets at the theatre...many show times available throughout the day. The live music makes it lively and fun!

10 minutes and....Zzzzzzzzzzz. We missed out chance to watch Water Puppet show when we visited Ho Chi Min, so this time we have to do it! So excited to wee it but it just last 10 min for me.... hahahhahaa!!! Not so sure either the show really bored me or i'm just too tired after perfume pagoda day trips. But that's the fact, just 10 minutes ok.... Not really a fan of the puppet but the music very pleasant to my ears. I like the music more than the puppet. Try to open my eyes but with the air-cond, the music and the darkness it just a perfect time to zzzzzzzzzzzz.....

Greatly enjoyed but a little bit random !. The skill of the puppeteers has to be admired, even more so when all is revealed at the end of the show.There is a running commentary through out the performance which at times confused us...but I guess without it we would have been even more confused.Try to sit in the front two rows of seats if possible as so many people are filming or photographing the events, that often all you can see is someones arms, elbows or back of their head as they bob & weave about.An experience not to be forgotten.

Been there and done it!. This is talked up as place to go managed to get tickets as get booked up days in advance. Show lasts an hour but had some I considerate people in front so kept having to change to see. Different sciences depicting different aspect of life lasts 1 hour

Worth seeing.. We heard mainly good reviews about this so thought it was worth checking out. The show is clever and you also learn information about Vietnam from the narrators. Be warned though I am only 5" 6 and I struggled to sit comfortably! Also make sure you boo early as sells out in advance.
Interesting. Cleverly done, but best if seated near the front. Use of screen to translate into English what is being said makes it more interesting.

Not to be missed. The puppet show lasts about one hour and it is broken down into a number of small camios which are explained on screens at each side of the 'stage'. If you can it is best to get a seat as close to the front as possible because there are lots of insensitive people who don't seem to care about obstructing your view. Consequently try to book seats in advance if possible.

Vietnamese Love This, Americans ???. From my chats with Vietnamese living in Hanoi, I conclude that Water Puppet Theatres, especially this one, are held in considerable esteem. I think it is a cultural phenomena. I found it okay, more entertaining that I expected, but I would not go again.

Clueless!. It is incredible how clueless most visitors to Hanoi are about how to find the best water puppet show in town. This one is not it. Put on for masses of tourists each day, this is but a watered down version of the real thing. It is not bad -- but far from excellent, but everyone goes down to the lakeside theatre without knowing this is not in fact the Vietnamese national water puppet company, an organization of excellence to be found a few miles away.I've been to both shows, and the one from the national company is far more skillful and fun too. You get dragons that snort real fire and an authentic full-sized traditional orchestra as well. There is great subtlety in puppet manipulation too. The setting -- outdoors in the middle of buildings -- is more attractive also.The audience at the national theatre is mixed Vietnamese and foreign -- far fewer foreign tourists come here than to the other show, and they seem to be on high-end packages whose guides know where to find the real thing for their clients. The show is in Vietnamese whereas the Thang Long has an English commentary -- however, understanding the words is not essential to experiencing the drama or enjoying the sheer sorcery of a puppet running its fingers over a flute while a real one is played offstage...The Nha Hat Mua Roi Viet Nam is at 361 Truong Chann in Hanoi and has daily shows at 5 and 6:30 pm. I recommend the 6:30 pm as there is particular magic after it starts getting dark. Traffic is bad, so allow plenty of time to get to the show from central Hanoi.

Interesting show. Probably most tourist would have been bought here. But I guess it is really not a bad show, yes it is might have too much meaning or story line but overall it is a good watch and English subtitle for tourist to understand what is going on.
Puppets after all???. The show is pretty good. Enjoyed an unique 'puppet show'. The performers definitely had to put in every bit to make each show a success. Good to watch once.
Fascinating. I've never seen anything quite like it. It lasts a good half hour and is accompanied by music and singing. It's hard to describe really: you need to see it! Get a front seat as I did.
Music and performance worth it. Never seen anything like it. get there early to get tickets for the times you want. Music was wonderful. every seat seemed to be a good seat.

Clever. This was very cleverly done.There are leaflets re the stories told on the way in,also screens telling the story of each scene.Book or get tickets well beforehand to avoid disappointment.You can get them for days in advance.Interesting how puppets are worked. All becomes clear at the end

Highlight of Hanoi. This was the highlight of Hanoi for me. A unique experience, and interesting cultural experience. There are screens explaining in English what the theme of each episode is, and when the puppeteers appear at the end it is a revelation. Some people say it is uncomfortable, but I was fine, and it only lasts 45 minutes. I confess to being a bit horrified that some suggest not paying for the photography license - it is only $1 and contributes to the local economy, so despite the fact that they don't check I think it should be paid.

Interesting. The concept of a water puppet show was interesting and the puppeteers obviously worked very hard and did a good job with their craft. Unfortunately it was a very hot evening, the theater was packed and our tall frames were squished like sardines into small seats for too long.

Worth a look but had had enough by the end!. Great to see - especially as it was just getting dark. Colourful although story is all in Vietnamese it is still a joy. Puppeters appear very skilful and singing was great! Go see it!

A bit disappoited with new program launched by the theater. The management just lauched a new program which they got international gold medal. But in my point of view it is not suitable for foreign visitors as it is very artistic and it focuses on the the origin of vietnamese and dances around the country while the original play focused on the daily activites of the farmers in the North of Vietnam where water puppets were founded. The original program was way more fun and easy to understand for everyone.Anyway it is a good chance to enjoy the unique art and music of Vietnam
Well worth a visit .... ... for the cultural insights the weater theatre gives. The music and singing were very good and the puppeteers were great.
Fun. Nice way to spend part of an evening in Hanoi, only be there at least 1/2 hour before the show, it's usually busy.
Don't miss this!. This unique show is, from what I could discern, unique to Vietnam and should not be missed. Totally enjoyed the music and show.

Interesting art form. We booked our show through our hotel and got our first choice of times. We enjoyed this, particularly the music, although we were glad it was only 45 minutes long. No problem with the seats or the English translation (we are Americans). It was interesting to see something new to our Western eyes. Go for it!

What I saw through the cameras was good.. The Water Puppet show was good and well done. If you go I recommend getting a seat as close as possible to the stage to avoid your view being blocked by cameras. I am unsure why they allow cameras in the theater.

Best show ever!. It;s hard to put into words as it was one of the most fabulous under and above water puppet shows I've ever seen. Very beautiful and professionally done. Puppets are such a work of art.

Diverting. Worth going to. The show is 45 minutes long and the puppets are amusing. I was curious as to how the puppet movements were done, and at the end of the performance, the puppeteers step out from behind the curtains to show themselves.

Not everyones cup of tea. The show was ok. The music and the types of insruments used was different and the sound were very Vietnamese. Be sure if you have long legs your in for an uncomfortable hour or so. I guess the puppets were clever and colourful

Charming. Really enjoyed the water puppets, it was on my list of must see's when we visited Hanoi. It is very popular so book early. We went to buy our tickets and where told that all the shows for the day where sold out. Had a coffee at the place attached and went back in 20 minutes to ask again luckily for us they had just had two tickets returned for the 6.30 show. We loved it, found it charming and enchanting. A must see when visiting Vietnam

it's a bit expensive, but worth going. good traditional music and nice colours. but when we wannted to buy the ticket the woman told us that it was sold out until the show at 8 pm. we decided last minute to got there and left hanoi that night so we said ok we wouldn't go. Suddenly the woman changed her mind and said that there were still tickets left. When we attented the show it was full, but there were still a lot of seats empty.

A very old age art form that stills survives -- Thang Long Water Puppets. The theater is not that large and the seats were uncomfortable. However the Water Puppet Show was amazing as were the colorful traditional costumes of the very talented performers.
Not to be missed!

Very colourful and surprising show / one of the coolest thing in town !. Do not miss/ the show is brief cheap and features the best of Vietnam's flamboyant culture , diversity and richeness! On top of that its cheap and lasts for only 60 min.

Fantastic and unusual experience. The show is just long enough and short enough. Where else is the stage a pool of water?
Plenty of souvenir shops bustling with goods when the show lets out.

Like a creepy dream. The theater seats were uncomfortable, the screen was too small, the puppets stiff, the scenes were boring,the music hurt the ears after a while. It was like having a creepy dream where you wake up with a nasty headache.

Classical Theatre. Really enjoyed the puppetry and the musical presentations. The musicians are dressed in traditional costumes and look so peaceful whilst playing. It is quite amazing how the puppets perform. Well worth a visit. Keep in mind it's very popular so need to book early.

Interesting singing and music. The show was 45 minutes long and was reasonable entertainment, would not form a queue to go again. I enjoyed the 3 ladies singing and playing a range of musical instruments.

Not impressed.. Though the concept is quite unique, I think the water puppet show is abit oversold or over hyped. Not very interesting, too long and too much ado about water puppets. Personally I would have preferred to watch a live ( people ) show...

Awful. If you fall asleep your lucky. The show itself is just plain boring. Reading the synopsis on the screen there is no way it could be related to the random and repetitive movements of the puppets. At the start a dragon had coitus with a swan and they had a steaming egg. Then I was lost. The seats are so small that comfort is a distant memory. It is also stifling save for the fans down the wall. We had a whinging Chinese lady in our row who wanted the fan off because she was cold. I could see sweat running down others faces so I bribed the usher to leave it on (20k VND). The other bad thing (no fault of the theatre), was all the people in the 40-60 age bracket holding up iPads trying to record the whole show. So unless you are in the front few rows you will only be taking photos of middle aged iPads

lovely show and great skills. Beautiful singing, live music using traditional instruments. Really lovely show, good length not too long or short. Great narration.Amazing how they operate the puppets in the water. Worth a visit
Loved it. The water puppets were a unique look into Vietnamese culture.The music was wonderful.Make sure you take some water in with you as it gets a bit humid in the theater

Interesting Art Form. Given the importance of this art form it is probably a must see. We were really excited before we went, but in our minds the actual event did not live up to the advertising. The music was average and the scenes tended to be a bit repetitive.

Probably a must see, once. Too long, best for kids but an unusual concept unless you have seen it before.
It is very Vietnamese. The music is often loud, This is kind of a thing to do and one really should.
I liked this. although the man in my life fell asleep! I found the music and singing captivating,,its not long so your partner can endure if its not their thing.

Up to you!. If you like puppets, or are at a loose end in Hanoi, go and see the water puppets. They are, after all, one of the things for which Hanoi is renowned. However, do not build up your expectations too much as the show only lasts about 50 minutes (5 or more shows per day) and you may find it rather tame. It is a novelty after all. Also, if you are tall, you may want to sit on the end of a row because the leg room is very restricted.
A bit boring.... The puppets were interesting for the first 2 songs- after seven got a bit repetitive. The seating was very cramped and the toilet facitilies bleak

If you have time you should see it.. It is a theatre about Vietnamese culture. Wooden puppets are played by people inside and the puppets dance on the pool. It is worth to see because it tells about village life, other native people living in Vietnam.
Puppets. Good cultural experience, not too long, Very reasonable ticket price, Very talented performers. The Band and singers were very good and at times I watched them more than the Puppets

Even the performers were bored!. Bought our tickets 45 mins before the 2:15pm performance, first class seats, not sure where the second class ones were so I'd recommend just paying for the cheaper ones. Don't pay the dollar requested if you want to take photos, just take them no-one checks. The performance was supported with a "handy" ppt presentation to follow each theme but alas this wasn't enough to hold our interest. My husband fell asleep, the singers chatted through the non singing pieces, the puppeteers sounded like they were having a heated row between their pieces, sorry to say I'm not sure anyone really wanted to be there. Disappointing despite the supposed eminence of the production team!

Dent live up to my expectation. Given its high ranking and photos in travel magazines, I expected larger puppets and a better performance. The plus is this a unique show which I've never seen before. The minus is if you're 6 feet tall or taller, your knees will be pressing into the seat in front. Also, depending on where you're seats are, the puppets will be quite small. Another plus is seats are reserved. If staying for a few days, book tickets early in your stay, as these shows sell out. Also they asked $1 for photo, gave me a slip of paper, but there was no organised photo session at the end.

very good to see. That is wonderful show about Vietnamese agriculture with puppet... only 100,000 VND you can join the show and the show times are very comfortable time for you, The shows performe in each one hour star from 2:15PM and last show at 9:30PM.

Clever puppets. Book ahead, as there are bus loads of people that flock to this show. We turned up in the morn to book later that day but could only get the next day. The show it self is good, and puppets clever, as I had no idea how it would work. Show goes for 45 min. Unfortunately some parts were a little boring, where the puppets danced a little too long.

Lovely and puppet show. This puppet show was over our expectation. The music, color and performance was so entertaining. This puppet show is always fully book so you should buy the ticket 1 or 2 days earlier.

bring you relaxed time. I read this nice show since I was on airplane to Vietnam from U.S. and actually, it was so interesting seeing the wonderful little things controled by some masters. a bit difficult to follow the story but you can get it. worth a visit.
puppets. Very good show. Only 100000 VNB. Live music and commentary with English translation. Very popular. A must see

Worth the visit. A great way to spend an hour. Best you prebook tickets. We did so on the day of our performance from our hotel and were limited to a choice of 2 performance. It is very popular. AUD 5.

Zzzzzzzz..... People to my left AND right both fell asleep during this 'show' ... I couldn't believe what I was seeing!Just some puppets being flinged around in the water in no sequence - just randomly flipping about in the water! Storyline was difficult to follow as the script has been poorly translated into English

Worth a visit. We were not going to bother with this attraction but finding ourselves with an hour to spare after lunch and because it is so conveniently positioned we decided to attend and we are glad that we did.The perfomance is relatively short but very skilfully and professionally carried out. The cost is very little and it really is well worth a visit

AMAZINGLY ENTERTAINING. even though I had no idea what the narration was talking about, I was riveted to the display of water puppetry that went on before me. The musicians play music on authentic instruments that create a most wonderful atmosphere, the music is part of the show and dictates the mood with great success!!Highly highly recommended, Would see it again and thats a rare endorsement, I never see stuff twice unless its GOOD.
Water Puppets - a good cultural experience. interesting and entertaining - once. In a great location for restaurants, sightseeing, and people watching
nice. Nice to see. A must do when you are in Vietnam.Live music and a nice show.Tickets are sold out very fast
very different. An entire puppet show which is water based. well worth seeing. last for 1.5 hours. shows the origin and culture of the people of vietnam.

A very different theatre experience, but definitely not one to miss. Amazing cultural expereince!. DON'T miss it! The performance is an absolute MUST!!! Music, costumes and the puppets themselves are amazing. You are kept guessing as to how the puppets actually work......wait until the end and then all is revealed. I would definitely go again....and .....again!
Not worth it. This is appropriate for the young, not anyone who has traveled a lot. I would rather spend my time walking the streets and taking in the real Hanoi.

fun diversion for kids but tickets way in advance. A fun little treat, in an area that you probably end up in anyway. anti climatic for a typical adult or experienced traveler but fun treat for kids. Mostly tour groups

Tourist Trap but its a laugh. Paid for best seats but on entering the auditorium we were shown to any old seats without our tickets being checked! The coffee shop next to the theater is the most expensive place in Hanoi so beware! As for the show the best description would be odd! I know its traditional and "had to be seen" but the forty five minute show was thirty minutes too long. After a couple of "acts" you get the idea and the rest of it becomes slightly boring and repetitive, it is however most amusing for all the wrong reasons.You have to go and see it, you have however also been warned.
warm and humid. This was very interesting but as you are in a closed theatre style room the humidity gets a little too much and we found that everybody in our party felt sleepy half way through
A new type of theatre. Other reviews describe this unique form of theatre. Anyone who enjoys theatre will find this quite fascinating and the skills of they puppeteers amazing.

Fun Show, would go again. Everyone in our group (my wife, two boys ages 3 and 17 months, and my parents) really enjoyed the show.It was something new and different and we were all entertained.If you're in Ha Noi I would check this out!

Great spectacle. All the actors were preforming in the water. I found it extremely diffcult.There were a small group of musicians playing local musical instruments and a narrator telling the story of the country.Also there was a screen where the naration was written in different language.The theater was structured in such a way so one could see the entire stage from every seat.The audience consisted from many different tourist groups many of them made such a noise and didn't respect the other spectators especially the actors.Very sad!!!!!

Worth the effort (especially if you've never seen water puppetry) BUT you will be uncomfortable..... The show is well done with broad explanation given in the program and on tv screens of each act. However it is clearly predominantly targeted for the tourist audience which is all the more surprising that the seats are uncomfortable. Anyone more than aporox 1.80 or 5ft 11 will have their knees up against the seat in front. I assume this is one reason some find the show too long winded as clearly it is more difficult to enjoy when in building pain! Nevertheless the show is entertaining, professionally produced and worth the pain! The only seats without constraints are the first row (Row A) although I suspect these are snapped up by the tour groups. When I went all shows were fully booked for the next 48 hrs so if you are passing through Hanoi eg en route Halong Bay, make it a priority to book your tickets first. I was told (but can't confirm) that last minute tickets can be got at the door as some tour companies return their unused tickets. Certainly the day I attended there were quite a few empty seats in the first 3 rows ..... As an alternative you could consider visiting the Ethnology museum. It is worth the effort (see separate review) and has the bonus of putting on its own water puppet shows at 10,1130, 230 & 4 when I was there. These are in daylight, certainly more comfortable to watch (you pull up a plastic chair to watch) and more authentic in the sense that the majority of the audience is Vietnamese and clearly love it. Either way a water puppet show is worth seeing!
Nicely done. with live music to boot, if you can't get to the museum in Saigon, then go see this one. I was a great show. Little kids love it.

Well worth it. This show was the best water puppet show we saw in Vietnam. It was a wonderful and a seemingly authentic traditonal water puppet theatre. The music, the puppets and the stroy were all brillant.
A curiosity but a little long. Worth a visit because it is part of the Vietnamese culture and very popular with the locals judging by the audience, but a bit too long and repetitive.

Really different. I have never seen a show like this - learned about Vietnam's history - nice to see but after awhile the puppets keep doing the same thing - I expected more after reading all the reviews...

Great show. This show is well organised, some seating is difficult to view the show. Being on the shorter side I needed to move to the sides of the theatre to see. I found the whole show mesmerising. How the heck do they do it . Thoroughly entertaining and nothing like anything I have ever seen before. Well worth the visit.

Quite boring. We queued up to buy tickets to this show after reading reviews on trip advisor.
Being an expat in Vietnam I love learning about their culture but I found this show to be repetitive and boring.
The venue is not child friendly at all, I would not recommend taking children.

Once in a lifetime thing. It's definitely a very touristy thing. The performance was good but unless you have a very strong liking towards such a thing, it's really a place to visit just because you're already in Hanoi. I personally became sleepy halfway through the show.
Interesting. Got a last minute ticket to see the show and happy I did as it is quite interesting. Cheap seats are good enough and as it is beside sword lake easy to get to

A fun filled time. We found the puppet show in Hanoi to be higher quality of venue, costumes and location than its counterpart in HCMC. However, we found the storyline of the puppet show in HCMC more interesting, entertaining and playful.

A wonderful cultural experience. We recently took in the show and thoroughly enjoyed the one hour long performance. The puppet masters are brilliant and it is easy to appreciate their international reknown. It is probably necessary to book several days in advance to ensure a seat reasonably close to the pool
Doug and Ulai Kirwin
Thailand

Colourful and entertaining. We enjoyed the water puppet show very much and I would say it is a must-watch. The show was around 45 minutes. We bought our tickets three hours before the show and we managed to get the second row in front. It was 100,000 dong per ticket for the front rows. Choose the front row so, you will get very good view. The show was not projected on the screen so you may not see properly if you are sitting behind.I just loved the colourful stage and the musicians and narrators in traditional costumes. Although the narration was in Vietnamese, we could refer to the translation at the two screens by the side of the stage. Or we just referred to the brochure in English/Chinese that we took outside the hall. So, understanding the show was not a problem for us.Till the end of the show, we were presented the puppeteers behind the show. They were all dipped in water (till waist height) throughout the show. Kudos to them!
Water puppets are impressive. Overall worht seeing it because there is nothing like it - however it is not the highest production value as far as puppet theater goes.
Another must... Seeing the Water puppet Theater is a must for every traveler. Incredible coordination and creative minds create a special spectaular show
Ok show, NO LEG ROOM. Show somewhat interesting but if only a few days in Hanoi you may want to skip. If over 6 foot the lack of leg room is painful!!!

Thoroughly enjoyed ourselves!. It was an enchanting introduction to the origins of the Vietnamese people (in their myths and legends anyway).The music was superb, while the water puppets could have been a little more lively (just a little), it was a great performance.Highly recommended that you book your seats in advance as we found out that the shows were sold out on the day that we wished to see it.

thoroughly enjoyable. We purchased tickets with a little apprehension thinking the experience would be fairly lame. I was totally mesmerised for the entire show and really enjoyed the whole experience. The narrators, musicians and puppeteers were all super talented and the show was short enough to not get boring but at the same time offered an insight into Vietnams heritage. A must do whilst in Hanoi.

Check your change and check your tickets. The show itself was enchanting and definitely worth seeing but the experience was somewhat soured by yet another Hanoian scam attempt. We quite clearly asked for two 100,000 VND tickets and paid with a 200,000 VND note; the box office employee tore out two 100,000 VND tickets in front of us, moved them out of sight to arrange them neatly or whatever and then placed 2 tickets face-down on the counter. In our sleep-deprived, jet-lagged state we naively didn't check the face-value until we were being seated in the back row - not the best view as some of the puppets are quite small - and then it turned out we'd been sold 60,000 VND tickets (and offered no change in case, like us, you're trying to find the honest mistake). When we explained what happened the usher insisted we go back to the box office where the same employee sulkily swapped the tickets. 100,000 VND tickets are green, 60,000 VND ones are red.

Lovely Valentines night. Had a lovely night at the puppet theatre. The tickets are so cheap and it's great to see something a bit different and hear some vietnamese music, no visit to Hanoi is complete without it!

A charming & interesting show. I went to see the Water Puppet show with low expectations after reading the recent reviews on Trip Advisor. I however found it it to be a charming and interesting show & really enjoyed the experience. There are set show times each day & I recommend booking in advance (our hotel did this for us). I found the theatre to be comfortable (am 5ft 8 so not tiny) & noticed that very tall people were offered seats on the side aisle where they could have more leg room. The show moves through ten stories/scenes at a good pace - each are explained in Vietnamese beforehand with an English translation on a screen - and takes 45 mins in total. It was nice to do something different. There is a small charge (20,000 dong) to take photos.

Great show. This show makes for a great afternoon. The puppets are amazing and the musicians are absolutely wonderful. There is a screen translating, but only in English.This is a little hard to find unless you follow the tour buses! But I saw the show and then caught a cyclo for a tour and it was great.

Worth seeing once. The show is more of a novelty than anything else so worth a trip once if the ticket is cheap enough for your budget.
If you are over about 5'8" it could be a long hour as the seats are very close together so don't expect comfort.

Boring. It was just plain boring for me! The theatre doesn't have well organized rows, so you might be unlucky to watch someone's back in front of you. Anyways, the show was repetitive and I couldn't wait to finish.

good only for kids. Though well presented, the water puppet theater seems good to take kids to... don't expect adults to be thoroughly entertained.
We left half way through the show and enjoyed a walk around the lake instead.

Can be skipped.... Firstly I have to say that the water theater is quite fascinating. The way they move the puppets through the water via long bamboo poles behind a black veil certainly requires a lot of skills.The problem is the whole show is done in Vietnamese. I totally do not understand a single word and in fact, like one of the reviewers here, I dozed off for quite awhile being bored out of my skin.Yes, it's world-renowned as a Vietnamese tradition but really, I don't see any point going thru the whole performance without understanding a single word about the stories!By the way, all the best seats are reserved... I suspect by the local travel agencies.

Century Old Dances and Stories. What to expect at a puppet show? A few visible muscians opened the show by playing on old instruments as the "puppets"appeared in the water stage.There were a number of different stories presented from the legend of the marriage of the Dragon King and the Fairy to the "National Festival Dance". We were fortunate to have front row seats for the afternoon show. It was a fasinating show and amazing to see the behind the scenes at the end. It lasted about an hour and was appropriate for all age groups. One should not visit Vietnam without seeing a water puppet show

This made the top 25?. Seating is comfortable......if you are the size of a water puppet!If you are over 5 feet tall, get an aisle seat. After the first two scenes, catch up on your sleep, the rear of the show is the same. What a waste of 100,000 of my hard earned Dongs.

Worth seeing. Worth seeing just for a feel of the Vietnamese culture. Live music. Vietnamese commentary with English translation on screen. Only 45 minutes and cost 60,000 - 100,000 VND. Don't be surprised though that you do not get the seat as stated in your ticket as the ushers will try to fill seats from the back rows. Think the tickets do get overbooked at times.

Unusual. Our visit was part of a tour of the city. I was not looking forward to a puppet show. However I was delighted with the show. It was a little bit repetitive but there was still plenty of variety and the live performers good. The revalation of how it was done at the end was a real surprise.

Everybody goes, you should too... Saw more tourists here that anywhere else in Hanoi. A good performance, includes singing, puppetry is quite unique and cleverly done, whilst telling a good story, get tickets early (day before) to avoid missing out. Seemed to go on a long time but maybe I was just tired on the day..
Lovely show. I love this show, the music very nice, and very Vietnamese style. It is really worth to spend time and money.
Baffled ....... The water puppet show is worth a visit to see some authentic Vietnamese entertainment, just don't expect to understand what is going on!

Didn't meet expectations. There was a lot of hype concerning this attraction in Hanoi. Tickets are sold out well in advance. There are 6 shows a day and two ticket prices, 100,000 and 60,000VND. You can also purchase an extra cheap ticket to take pictures. But I would advise against it, they don't check when you're taking a photo. The show tells of Vietnamese culture in the form of scenes depicted using puppets in water. Hence the name of the theater. However after several of these scenes, the performance becomes rather repetitive. It is roughly 45 minutes long and is a good opportunity to escape the weather outside. Worth a visit if not just for the novelty factor.

Interesting- glad 1 hour. The live music was the highlight for me and that they do this in water. Do they artists wear wetsuits and does it get cold doing many performances a day? How does one get into water puppetry? These are the things I wondered while watching it.Having been to many cultural performances in Asia I think they are just not my thing. I would like the theme park 20 minute performance glad it is only 1 hour. They do work hard.

Frustrating tourist trap. I work in the arts, and as such am used to finding a range of slightly abstract shows as entertaining as possible; I found it particularly difficult with the water puppets. As a demonstration of an ancient art, it's just about sufficient - but the show's too long, really dull, and doesn't show a great deal of variation. Of the 12 vignettes we were shown, I found 2 or 3 of them really interesting - but the rest were pretty mundane, on both a narrative and artistic level. Not the best demonstration of what is a thriving artistic culture.

Unique Experience. Ws not expecting much but at the end of the 45 min performance, I have a different opinion. The puppets are performed in the water throughout. My respect to the puppeteers and interesting puppets. Well depicts the lifestyle, culture and history of the Vietnamese people

Fun Introduction to Vietnamese Culture. This is a fun show to go to. It gives you a quick glimpse into Vietnamese culture.A few tips:Go early in the morning to get your tickets. Have the ticket seller show you what seats are left for the times you're interested in (it's assigned seating). Pick a show that you can sit near the front of the theater. Everybody takes pictures and the fewer flashes and iPads you have in front of you, the more you;ll enjoy the show.
Wow!!. This was a fascinating experience, beautifically performed by gorgeous puppets The action is explained by actors to the side but a translation is provided on a screen next to them.
Cool cultural thing to see. Everyone in the audience was a tourist. But that being said, it was still cool to see this Vietnamese art form performed right in front of you.

Very clever and worth a look. For the misely ticket price and for 45 mins out of ur life it's definitely worth a look.Quite creative and clever. Wouldn't say scintillating entertainment but tells an interesting enough story. Seating quite cramped - worse than Tiger Airways or RyanAir!!Give it a go ...

Still enjoying it after third time.. While it is targeting at the tourists, the performers are serious about the art. In an hour, you get to experience about 8 items. The backup musicians are equally impressive. Suitable for all ages. Book tickets in advance as a lot of tickets are taken up by tour groups. Some inconsiderate audience, in order to get good pictures, may stand up and block your view. Pity.Review and photos:http://clumsycompass.blogspot.sg/2012/06/vietnam-water-puppets-again-and-again.html

very intriguing, very unsusual. Thie North Vietnamese art form is unlike anything you have seen before. The artists manipulate puppets on long poles in the water. It's pretty fascinating. 45 minutes was plenty.

Charming and Undemanding. Good value for £4 this 45 minute show is unusual and skilful. There is a narrative in English before each short scene and musicians perform live. The water puppets are colourful and the show tells Vietnamese folk stories.It just about the right length because the numbered seats, although comfortable, have insufficient legroom for Europeans - who make up most of the audience
Unique experience. A true Vietnamese art form. Not to be missed! Tickets are usually available and can be gotten through your hotel if you don't have time to go to the theater.

Tradition and culture unusually presented. Vietnamese legends presented as a water puppet show; it sounds silly, but it works. Great musical accpompanyment too. At about an hour it is long enough and not too taxing. Charming and educative

One of the weirdest things I have ever seen...must see!. I know what this is supposed to be, and it's really something that you have to see to believe. It was super strange, in a good way, but also very very strange. It really can't be described...you just have to go...and you should. For the price, you can't not go see it. Traditional, and about an hour so not something you need to spend all day doing. Not a very helpful review, but I think a lot of people would agree with me. Enjoy! And get tickets early!

A charming little show. This was a colourful little dance display but I would have preferred a stronger narrative. the puppet masters were skilled. We went backstage afterwards. T he space there was very small!
Don't miss it!. It is a very unique performance and very enjoyable. It is not expensive and it is short. Highly suggest putting it on your list of things to do in Hanoi

Crazy puppets and well worth being splashed .. The water puppets of Hanoi are legendary and rightfully so.The life size puppets are worked by their masterful puppeteers with joy and great ability.Think Punch and Judy in the rice paddys, and be prepared to laugh.

Worth a Visit. We were glad we popped in to see this show. It lasted just about the right amount of time (45 minutes), only cost £3 each and when you consider the live musicians and the puppeteers that was excellent value for money.We attended a 6.30 showing and the theatre was nearly full.
Split decision !. She liked it - I didn`t !! ( but probably worth a visit ...) Depicting Vietnamese social history and customs.

You have to see this. The water puppet theatre was really interesting and definitely worth the entrance fee. We were staying in the Old Quarter and we first walked around the lake and then to the theatre close by. You have to pay extra to bring a camera in ($1) but it's worth it.

Over rated. Water puppets have a long history in Vietnam so that is a good reason to go to the show. But the seats in the theater are not made for long western legs. The music was terrific, but there is only so much motion you can get from a water puppet. Many people found this to be a highlight of their trip but I was less impressed.

Puppets on sticks - in water. Went with the family (ages 41,40,12 and 8). The adults found that it taught us quite a lot about the country's history in a "compact" way. The 12 year old fell asleep a couple of times. The youngest looked up a few times when new dolls were introduced, but generally fiddled with everything else and shifted her feet.Some dolls where very nice. Some were not.

Cool. Must see when you visit Hanoi, you could not find better for $5...great introduction to the Vietnamese water puppet. Seats at the front section are of benefit to ensure the best view. Be ware of tourists with cameras and video's.
A boring experience. Great playing on the one string musical instrument, yet boring performance. Characters are old fashiond and little atractive. Nothing much goes on.

Fortunately also Vietnamese visitors.. Before entering the theatre our expectations were not very high as this performance receives rather mixed criticism. It was good to see was that among the audience also a few Asian, most likely Vietnamese, visitors were present. However, probably over 95% were tourists from abroad. After all we enjoyed the show, not in the last place the music and songs, which added greatly to the overall experience of witnessing a piece of genuine Vietnamese culture. When in doubt, the price of only about Euro 3.50 is probably no major financial obstacle for anyone to attend this performance. Also the duration of 1 hour is just perfect.

really worth seeing. You need to get your tickets a show or two in advance but worth the wait.not gonna say to much as surprise isis the char, lets just say it is unique and you won't get the chance again.
Wonderful. An absolute must to see. it is amazing how talented these performers are. I loved it from beginning to end and would consider going to a show if they would visit here.

Average. The water puppet show was one of the famous tourist attractions but the whole show was a little draggy and on the average. Nothing really interesting after the few stories and as much as there was no smoking sign, people did smoke in the theater and nobody stopped them.

Marvelous. This show exceeded my expectations. I had never seen anything like it. Maybe thee is nothing like it. We have another few days in Hanoi and are going back to see it a second time. The first time we were so busy taking pix that I didn't let myself get lost in the show. The music, narration, English translation, performance...all superb. You don't need to speak a word of Vietnamese to enjoy this cultural, historical, ethnic, humorous show.

A decent show with good music. I kept hearing that this was a must-see while in Vietnam, but we were left a little dissappointed with our experience. The performers were really great, and the puppet masters were pretty good. The seats were really crammed and it was annoying that the show started on time yet people were still coming in and trying to find their seats in the dark so it obstructed everyone's view. So many people were snapping pictures with flashes that it was distracting. It was only $5 for the 45min show, so I guess it was still worth going, but it wasn't my favourite experience in Vietnam.

Interesting insight into Vietnamese culture. We were raced into the theatre after being delayed by flights and traffic, not sure what to expect. The show was OK, but we were pleased that it didn't go on any longer. The theatre is very cramped. Not sure how anyone with long legs would manage. The puppets and music were good, but not the 'must see' that other reviewers have raved about. Equally interesting just to sit and people watch around the old quarter.

Entertaining and Beautiful. This is a great experience. The blend of live music and storytellers with the puppets and lighting is really impressive. the show is just long enough to keep your attention without losing focus. It's well organized and very comfortable - go if you can!
Entertainment. It was a high energy performance. Lots of visuals and sounds. Very entertaining. Recommended as a must see. Not expensive and eay to find.

Utter disappointment. We rushed to this tourist mecca as everyone said this was one to see and left feeling cold, frustrated and disappointed.
