The organisers allow flash photography which when you factor in an auditorium of 400 a dark space and 100 people using flash photography means any atmosphere created by the performers is utterly crushed. People enjoy the moment experiencing things through your camera lens not only diminishes the experience for you but is exceptionally annoying for everyone else!!There is so much that could be done to improve this experience and show case this amazing bit of culture and it is such a shame that that is not the priority.

Bizarre, but in a good way. I wasn't sure quite what to expect but ended up enjoying the experience. The presentation is about 8 short scenes showing the mythological evolution and life of the peoples of Vietnam through the mating of a dragon and a fairy complete with legions of happy babies hatching from the resulting egg (the best bit!) through scenes of everyday life of the various ethnic groups that make up the nation. The message of inter-ethnic solidarity is laid on with a trowel, but the short scenes are charming.

Interesting different. It is a very different way of telling a story, worth a visit. At the beginning of every act you can read a translation of the story on a screen in English. I really liked that the secreat on how it's done is lifted at the end of the show.If you are sensitive to draft bring a jacket or scarf since it is very drafty from the AC.The best way to do it, is probably combining the visit of the show with visiting the old quarters since the puppet theater is right there. Buy the tickets upon arrival there and plan accordingly. If you want to use your camera equipment during the show there are fees. Small cameras/phones for pictures and filming seem to be free if used.

Best $5 event. Got a lot more for my $5 than I expected. I've seen a lot of puppetry all around the world and water puppetry certainly is unique. The seats are assigned so if you want to be towards the front get your tickets in advance. We were in the last row and was still pretty decent views. The theater is not that big. I really enjoyed the live music and bought a CD of it after the show for $3.
Brilliant and unique. Really unusual form of entertainment and mesmorising. Well worth seeing but you need to plan ahead as many tour groups snap up all the peak time tickets.
Magic. Excellent experience but book early as they fill up fast. Leg room in seats is very cramped. Try to get seats on the end.

A very different highlight of Hanoi. I think the water puppets are unique. They tell the story of the Vietnamese people through puppetry and music. It's very clever and you spend time wondering how it is all done. All is revealed at the very end. A definite must see when in Hanoi.
Fabulous!. This is wonderful to see. Do yourself a favour and go see this veyr professional show. Well worth the time and energy and it's not expensive.

Entertaining for 3 USD. Bought tickets last minute for the last aisle but the view was still good. Show lasts about 45 minutes with approximately 8 acts. The puppets are on long bamboo poles and controlled by puppeteers in waist deep water (they come out at the end). We paid extra to take photos but it was too dark for any of them to show up well even with a good SLR camera and we paid extra for a camera ticket which was never checked. Try to exit from the top right (instead of bottom left, where you entered) as you pass by a little display of the puppets where you can get good photos. If you can only exit left, make a left at the door to see the display. Both exits meet at the top of the cafe stairs.

Ok if you have the time. Although I appreciate the work that would have gone into making this production, I found it a little boring. Maybe it just wasn't my thing, but I think if you only have a short time in Hanoi the time is best spent elsewhere. Also for 100 000 dong, it's pretty expensive. Don't think I could have sat through more than an hr of it.

Love the Traditional Music and Vocals. The cultural show was about 50 minutes long, with fantastic traditional music and vocals which I enjoyed more that the puppets dancing on the water. They was a brief introduction with subtitles before the beginning of each play, and then you will be treated to the great traditional music and the puppets dancing on the water. There may be a risk of getting bored with the dancing puppets after a while. I would think this will be a great attraction for children especially and as for adult, the music and vocals are simply amazing and will keep you glued on to your seats.We went to purchase our tickets at around 2pm, for the 8pm show. There were two types of seatings, 100k and 60k VND. We got the more expensive ones, and got the second row seat which was very good. The show was almost fullhouse except the front row only. Altogether there are 5 shows daily.
For the comrades. The puppets are a cultural experience that is meant to show their socialist idealogies. Go to the earliest show possible or you may fall asleep.

Great little theatre. Fun way to spend an hour.. If you are in Hanoi taking in a water puppet show is a must. It is a great way to learn about traditional Vietnam, hear some traditional Vietnamese music and have a good chuckle.

Breathtakingly good. Never seen anything quite like it. Completely "other" experience - fabulous puppets, great skill by the puppeteers, amazing music - my wife and I loved it and our 2 year old was transfixed!
For me just ok. Not a bad way to pass away 45min and £3 won't break the bank but not quite for me as thought it boring at times but know others enjoyed it.

Great Theater & Wonderful Music & Performance. Go to this show. It's super. You'll want to take fotos or videos so be sure to try for a Front Row Seat at only $5. Seats 8,9, 10 are center & best for photography!
A Must See. A must see when in Hanoi Vietnam, Tradition Song and dance with puppets in water, dosent give you the WOW factor but totaly entertaining

Culturally interesting. A bit difficult to find as it appears to be on the lake but it is tucked away on the opposite side of the street.
A great way to get an hour long presentation of their cultural beliefs and symbolism. Thoroughly enjoyed.

If you have time - go.. I didn't go on my first visit to Hanoi, but this time had spare moments so with a friend went. And yes, it is unusual but you know what, you do come out thinking "How do they actually do that? Why do they do that? That was actually kind of clever?" When you see the puppets afterwards they are intricately made and you realise that they must deteriorate over time in the water so the care of them must be on going. The play itself is cute, the musicians are talented and add to the overall appeal. Yes it is all set up for tourists but if you step back a bit you can imagine what it was like when this was a form of entertainment for "the people". I'm glad I finally went.

Packed but fun!. Absolutely crammed full of tourists, but still worth the cultural experience! It would be fun to see if you could follow the story without the little hints displayed on the screens.Live music and live puppets = a cultural must!
A must. A fantastic way to learn about Vietnamese traditions. It would be a good idea to read up about the performance before you go, just so you enjoy the story line better.
If you like traditional music. This theater is good if you like traditional music. It is impressive to see how they handle the puppets.
Nice show. It's one the things you do in Hanoi, so go, as it's worth checking out. Don't expect anything grand, it's a puppet show with live music which gives a glimpse of Vietnamese popular culture.

Suppose you have to see water puppets somewhere. Water puppets are a unique art form in Vietnam so I suppose it's good to see it. I didn't see it in Saigon, so I can't compare. It was interesting to see the puppets and hear the music although the movements were cruder than I expected. The design of the theatre is flawed – the gradient of the seating is not steep enough and it's hard to see the tiny puppets over people's heads. It's only 5 USD, so if you have time, by all means.
Water puppets at their best. A colourful spectacle giving a "history" lesson in the mythology of ancient Hanoi. Very cheap and worth a visit.

Interesting but .... I thought the show was interesting, how they did the puppets and everything. The show lasts less than an hour, so it is not too time-consuming. Was easy to purchase the tickets on the spot (we got front row seats too!), we had arrived about an hour before the show. I have to confess that I nodded off during the show (I'll blame it on my lunch and the dark, comfy atmosphere). Felt that they could have added some sort of a story to the show to make it better.

The Puppetry of Propaganda. One afternoon, my wife and I went to a performance at the nationally-renowned Water Puppet Theatre. As the title suggests, the strings are pulled by underwater operators while a dazzling light display adds a colorful background; a chorus and small orchestra provide musical companionship, and a narrator tells the story. The latter was generally naïve communist propaganda --------- grasping landowners and heroic peasants; the son of a shoemaker getting the better of a wealthy young aristocrat; the lazy member of the commune who is banned from the Annual Outing, left behind, and single-handedly saves the precious crops when a vicious tornado suddenly strikes. Or simple fairy stories about good versus evil that make Hans Andersen and the Brothers Grimm seem ultra-sophisticated. If I were a censor, I would have given the show a special rating: Persons Over the Age of 15 Prohibited. Yet the theatre was packed, mostly with adults of which only a minority had brought their children along. It struck me that there is a lot of cultural naivete in this part of the world.

Thang Long Water Puppet Theater -- Fun Shows All the Day. Your search of Vietnamese culture would not be complete without visiting the Thang Long Water Puppet Theater located in Hoam Kiem district. The theater hosts shows thrice daily at 5.15 PM, 6.30 PM, and 8 PM. Highly skilled puppet shows not only attract children but their elderly counterparts as well. Depicting the country life in Vietnam and re-living numerous ancient tales leading with the legend of the Hoan Kiem Lake, it will give visitor a glimpse into the inner side of the Vietnamese culture and tradition. Viewers will be mesmerized at the use of simple tools like bamboo poles for extending the puppets from the backside of proscenium and the expertise with which the performers handle the puppets. Unique feature of the theater is that the viewing could be better from the middle or back rows instead of the front rows in the theater hall.

Interesting experience. The show is very interesting. Lots of lights, beautiful singers with fantastic voices, nice music and the puppet show in water itself is beautiful. Its amazing to see and a must see in Hanoi

Fun show. Read about it in a guide book. It's a small theather with 45 minute shows with at least 4 every night. Tickets cost either 100,000 VND or 60,000 VND. The cheaper option means sitting up the back and it should have no impact on the show.The performance itself was a lot of fun. A live score complimented the action which was lively.The narrative is very simplistic telling folklore and demonstrating parks of Vietnamese culture. A short synopsis accompanies each act so you know what it's meant to be about but really, it's just nice to watch.For $3 at it's cheapest there isn't anything to loose by giving it a go. The tone is very lighthearted so don't go in expecting a masterpiece of an intricate work of critical acclaim and you will have a good time.
Fun for kids, even toddlers. Puppets are after are for kids, right? Our kids loved the water puppets and I found them worth the time and ticket price myself. Would highly recommend.

A bit touristy.. Not as good as I'd hoped but still glad we went. The puppetry was really clever. Not sure why it's all set in water? The girls narrating and singing the story ( in Vietnamese) were the highlight. They pack in the tourists and it's hard to see over the person in front of you. If you have limited time give it a miss.

Cultural experience. Revisit inner child.. I enjoyed this probably more than is expected for adults. Children would love it. Very unique form of puppetry. $5 to get in. Don't believe them if your hotel calls them for availability and they said booked out. They weren't.

Boring. At the end of a long cold day of visiting museums etc with our guide we ended up here on our own. All 4 of us found it quite boring and not all that easy to understand what it was all about. The accompanying music was of greater interest to us.

waste of time and money. Nothing special to talk about. Waste of time. I would not have gone if I knew it was going to be that bad. Not an artistic performance. Even the seats were not high enough to see the show. I dont think there is any good reason to recommend this show.

a must see experience. a really quaint experience with real live singers and musicians. The actual puppets were a bit naff to be honest and i couldn't for the life of me see why some of the scenes they played out would be set in the water. That said, it is worth a look, even if just to say you did it.
a terrible tourist trap. this is a waste of time and money, not interesting in anyway and it felt like a tourist trap. I would not recommend it.

Bit odd but you've got to do it!. Beautifully crafted puppets, charming performance all very traditional, a bit iver my head to be honest but like nothing else you'll see. The puppets don't actually do much- come on stage move around a bit and go again but the package of music atmosphere and visuals was compulsive, top tip- get a seat on the end of the row if you are over 5'9"z they are made for midgets, and small midgets at that. Else there are some plastic chairs you could snaffle.

Great family activity. Our boys (12 and 9) really enjoyed this unique performance. We had never seen a water puppet show before and it was very cleverly done. It was easy to follow with narration in Vietnamese and English (printed on LCD screens) and told the story of the history of the Vietnamese culture. Seats didn't have much in the way of leg room however, as the performance lasted approximately 45 minutes, it wasn't too uncomfortable.

A must see, although we are very tall for seating. It was an experience which cannot be missed. Music was brilliant and a great storyline even though we did not understand a word . Very long and the seats are made for Vietnamese which of course makes sense. Very well priced and sells out quickly so get tix a day before or so
Great Cultural Experience!. Our kids really enjoyed the show, which lasted about an hour. They learned a little about the culture of Vietnam and enjoyed the puppetry.

Interesting and entertaining. At first I thought it was going to be another tourist show when I saw the crowds flocking in. The ticket prices are very reasonable but so I thought it was worth a punt. The show itself is obviously aimed at tourists but its really well done and tells a cute Vietnamese folk story. For 60 000 Dong it's worth a look and only takes an hour. No need to book the premium seats which are 100 000 Dong - the theatre is small enough to get a good view from the back!

Incredible Puppet Show. I can honestly say I have never seen, nor do I believe I am likely to see, a puppet show as delicate, intricate or elaborate. Definitely a must see in Hanoi, keeping in mind the large crowds, crowded theatre and very tight seating arrangements.

Very Cute. This theatre is quaint and small!The show is about $5USD for about 50 mins and the show has great live traditional music accompanying the water puppetry. The story is explained in many languages on screen and in the guide but is presented in Vietnamese which is fine and how it should be.Great little place and cultural experience.

Must do in Hanoi. Any puppetry is mystifying for me, but ones that can do somersaults in water defy belief! There are little tales of Vietnam life all interpreted by the puppets, which are controlled by poles by artists who are waist deep in water (behind the scenes). It is usually a sell out and you can see why.

Well worth a visit. GIven the mix of comment on this site, we were pleasantly surprised by the show. The puppets and skill of the puppeteers were very good, the show well thought out and choreographed, the right length and with interesting music. We had kids (14/12/9) who all enjoyed it.

The ingenuity of artists continues to amaze me. This show tells some of the Vietnamese stories via the medium of water puppets. Considering the difficulty of controlling the puppets in the water without too obvious contols, this was a choreographic masterpiece.
We enjoyed the show and were glad we attended. Children would certainly enjoy the show.

Unusual, Clever and Enjoyable!. The theatre was comfortable and seating was good - it was easy to see the 'stage' whatever row you were in.I loved the 'stories' and link to Vietnamese culture. It's difficult to say what specifically I enjoyed other than I liked the atmosphere, it was fun and it was very professionally performed ... it all looked easy and relaxed but the verbal and powerpoint introductions, together with the performance of the puppets must have taken a good deal of organising.

Well done on the water. This was done well on the water, the 30 minutes or so it runs for is more than enough. The music is nice and you learn a bit about Vietnam along the way with the story line.The seats are built for kids, so if you are tall i suggest hang back till the doors are almost closing and see if you can nab a spare end of isle seat to hang your legs out.There's a little cafe at the front you can eat/drink if you arrive too early, they make a lovely ham and cheese baguette.The theatre is across the road from the red bridge on the lake near the big round about, quite easy to find.On the second floor i think it was, there are some of the puppets on display.
entertaining and unique. enjoyed the 45-minute show. it was worth the time and effort. I just wish they had translations on headsets or something so that narration could be understood.
Interesting but maybe a bit overrated. To understand some of the Vietnamese folklore, an interesting show to see, but do not expect too much. A bit amateurish.

Nice traditional show. The show is fun, creative and entertaining but the seating is WAY to short for my long American legs. I'm 6'2" and unless you are in the mid 5ft range I think you will be uncomfortable. Fortunately its not too long of a show so it is tolerable for its length.

Tourist Trap. All shuffled into a theatrette, smelly musky and mouldy. The puppetry is well done given the difficulty of performing in water. If it had not been included in our travel package, we would not have been "eager" to attend. It was an opportunity to have a little "zone out" to some music and dull lighting. Sorry it is what it is.
Fun. Loved the water puppets it was fun and unique. Don't seat to close to the front will get wet. It was great to watch.

So bad it's good!. You really can't miss this because of the novelty factor. However, the novelty might wear off after a few minutes and then you become aware that you're stuck in seating far worse than the economy cabin in an aircraft, watching a puppet show! I actually found the music and singing quite soothing so I made the best of it and had a nap. According to my partner, who suffered through the whole show, it was a good choice.
Fun!. Though this was a bit silly, you shouldn't miss the performance. The stories presented provide you with a brief history of this amazing country.

You'll laugh! You'll cry! You'll eye off the emergency exit!. We saw the 9.15pm presentation of the Water Puppets. Here's the deal: it's pretty cheap ($3 for 'B' seats, $5 for 'A' seats), and it goes for about 45 minutes. You'll hear traditional music, see the traditional water puppets, and bruise your knees on the chair in front of you. For 5 minutes, it's an interesting cultural experience. At 10 minutes, you realize they spent the entire special effects budget in the first 5 minutes, and that the remainder of the show is made up of puppets of people doing traditional dances/activities/ceremonies of various Vietnamese people.The issue here is sadly not with the product - these guys sell out multiple performances a day and have a great reputation. The issue is that this medium is frankly not that interesting, that the puppets are traditional and therefore incredibly limited in their range of movement, and consequently, most segments of the performance are frustratingly repetitive.My girlfriend paid $3 for a good snooze. Next time I see a puppet, I'ma punch it in the face.
Great experience. We thoroughly enjoyed this - especially compared with other folk performances elsewhere. It was lively and fun.

Interesting experience. Whilst the novelty ran out very quickly, you have to admire the skills of the performers. Several performances throughout the day and tickets are cheap. Use of cameras were supposedly prohibited unless a fee is paid upfront but many people took photos regardless.

Definitely worth it. It does not take much of time, neither money nor effort. For this you get a travel experience, which you can hardly get elsewhere. Apart from the puppets, I was amazed by the musicians and the main singer. I wonder how long she learned to command her voice like that. The only thing I regret now is that I didn’t buy the soundtrack CD upon leaving the theatre. It must be so good for relaxation and/or Tai Chi or else stretching exercise.
Definitely a Must. This is really good. Something that i never seen before, the puppets and the musics are good. I enjoyed it very much.

Telling about Vietnamese ancient history. Many tour groups go to this Water Puppet theatre, so at times it might be necessary to book tickets in advance. I was lucky to get one right away through my concierge. There are several performances from 3:30pm on at about $5 entrance (cash).I enjoyed the show because it's traditional Vietnamese character and it's certainly an hour well spent on a grey and cold January afternoon.

Good fun. Make sure you buy a ticket in advance and be prepared to get knee capped by the seat in front. Other than that this show is a bit of fun and quite clever in its presentation. Since we first saw it 3 years ago it has improved in that in now has an English translation of what is happening which makes it all a lot more meaningful. Certainly worth going to.

Interesting bit of local culture.. Enjoyable for the duration. If it was longer it might have been a little more uncomfortable. The seats are a little small for taller people or those with leg problems. I would suggest this to others looking for evening activities in Ha Noi.

Interesting, but a bit too repetitive. We had some time to kill before catching our flight, so we went to the puppet theatre. They charge about $3 for B seats and $5 for A, not much difference in seating location, but cheap anyway. The puppets were smaller than we imagined. Being on the water they are different and the musicians and singers were good. It was only 45minutes, but still felt a little long.

If you've got the time .... I expected a higher calibre of puppeteering and music that was more traditional. (Despite the live musicians sitting alongside the stage, half the music seemed to be canned.) Be ready for the tight quarters, too: the lack of knee room had me wondering if there were economy-plus seats available.

A little cheesy view into a classical VN art form. The one hour show is worth viewing but is a bit repetitive. The art form is unusual and that is the reason to go. The seats are worse than economy on a long flight, but it does not matter where you sit in the theater.

Music players were talking through the whole show. We wanted to go to a puppet show, because that is a typical Vietnamese tradition that we never saw before. We decided to go in Hanoi, because the puppet shows originated in the north (In Saigon you can also go).The show itself was nice and sometimes funny, just how it's supposed to be. But throughout the whole show the music players were talking to each other. Very distracting! Other than that: nice experience.
NOT A MUST SEE.......,. Worth a visit if you have time. Basic puppet show on water with nice traditional singers and music .Good show for kids ,reasonably priced.

why this is a must see is a mystery to my family. it was long, hot, boring and the seats were not built to handle a 6' frame. The musicians looked like they had (and I'm sure they had) played the same music a thousand times before.We asked our kids (10 and 8) what they thought of it and they used the words 'it sucked'.

Very entertaining. The puppet theatre is well worth a visit and the 45 minute show is charming. The puppeteers are excellent and there is an English translation of the stories told in Vietnamese. There are several performances from lunchtime onwards but we recommend you book as early as possible for peak times as these can get blocked out by tour companies.

a bit boring. I was really looking forward to seeing this but it was a bit of a yawn. Several vignettes of vietnamese life but really, after the first 10 minutes, was a bit repetitious. I really wanted to like this but it was really boring.

Fun show, very interesting.. Large screen TV had translation of story which made it easy to understand. Worth seeing & to those in the audience who so very rudely left part way through the show....your loss!All visitors to Hanoi should go to this show & make your own minds up but if you do go to the show, you will be giving support to some very proud performers!
Probably more fun if you've been drinking. But worth seeing since you're there. A bit weird and anti climatic. They won awards so maybe I am missing something?

Puppet show. My teenage son said that he would rather endure a prison sentence than have to sit through another water puppet show! It wasn't that bad but it really is not that interesting. Only go if you have time to kill.
A unique kind of entertainment. I like that it tells a lot of story of Vietnam's past from romance, comedy and tragedy. However, I think it's not as entertaining the second time around.
Must watch. Never watched such a performance before, very creative and it's definately worth a visit. It helps you have a better understanding of the vietnamese culture
Stunning. A fantastic show with plenty of artists and puppets with traditional music. A must for every visitor to Hanoi!

ok.... a bit boring... but at the same time worth it. a few suggestions: go before dinner if possible. we went after dinner and a few beers, as it's not very entertaining, i was struggling to stay awake. also if you are over 6ft 1, be prepared to be vary uncomfortable... the seats are made for shorter people

It's OK. It was interesting to watch with my kids, ages 7 and 9. After about 30 minutes they were bored. Thankfully this was only a 45 minute show, so the timing was good. I think it was worth seeing it because its part of the cultural tradition. However, it is not thrilling.

fun for all ages. i only went here as i was getting a little stuck for things to do in Hanoi on an afternoon ...apart from the excellent food and drinks of course ! But was spellbound by this excellent little theatrical novelty .Very cleverey perfomed and a magical spectacle for all ages
Interesting. Interesting and worth seeing but only if one has nothing better to do. tends to be repetitive and unimaginative.

Adults and children - you'll love this!. We thoroughly enjoyed this performance of 45 minutes. The story line was clear without words and the puppeteers were wonderful especially the school of fishes which turned into a dragon. Go early to get a good seat. It is very crowded.

Good show, spoilt by some inconsiderate people. Good show, spoilt by some inconsiderate package chinese tourists taking photos in a dark cinema with flashes. Also people holding there iPhones in the air above their heads trying to video the performance while blocking the view for everyone behind them.BE CONSIDERATE AND DON'T TAKE PHOTOS.Otherwise you may find people behind you kicking your chair extremely hard like we had to do until you get the message!!!!!

A definite 'must-see' of Hanoi. This was a strange but wonderful experience which typifies Hanoi. Our show lasted 45 minutes which was a perfect time. The cafe downstairs also looks lovely. Wish I'd spent more time there!

Great night, but it was a little over-hyped. A group of us went after we had heard so much about it and there was a real split in our opinion. Its half an hour long, which I think is just long enough. We tried to book the VIP but they didn't have enough seats for us, so we were 2 rows from back, it would have better maybe to be closer to really see the puppets. The music and the singers were amazing.Some of our group fell asleep during it. i think its worth a look, even if its to figure out how they move.

Entertaining escape from the frantic streets of Hanoi. A fantastic experience. A great way to learn about various ethnic groups whilst being entertained by skilled puppeteers. Definitely a must see!!
Make sure you buy your tickets in advance i.e. a day or two earlier so you don't get stuck up the back of the theatre as this show sells out for most time slots.

Interesting Show. It wasn't what we expected. However, the hour long show was interesting. The theater gets hot during the performance. Seats are squeezed too close together and the aisles between rows are the same as they are on an economy class airplane - hardly any room, especially for tall folks. The theater fast food service restaurant is overpriced, especially for soft drinks, coffee and tea and it gets very crowded before a performance.

Unusual. I had heard about the show from friends who had visited Vietnam and it lived up to expectations. It was very well "choreographed" with simple folklore themes. However, the seating and accoustics left a bit to be desired. I had to keep dodging between heads right through the show to get a clear view!

Great night out. We really enjoyed our night out at the Puppet Theatre. We have never seen anything like it before. The music was played live and the singers were fantastic. The puppeters were very talented and it was a great night out.

Never again. There is one hour that I will never get back! What a waste of time and money. The puppets are in poor condition, the music is frightfully loud. I hAve never seen a whole audience rush out as quickly as they could at the end of the show! I advise to bypass this!
Interesting and different. Was a really nice show. Very different from anything else you can find. Just book in advance otherwise the times you want will be booked out.

excellent. You must to booked the show one day before to have the place. The experience is very very nice! The show is high recommended and the actors are very professional. I think you have to pay also for the camera, but nobody checked...so maybe you don't have to pay. You must go! Don't go to the cafe inside the Theater, one coffe 3 or 4 dollar! toooo much!
Unique and interesting. An hour of water puppets performance - very unique and an insight into the vietnamese culture. Need to book tickets in advance as its always sold out.

Charming. Our family thoroughly enjoyed this unique water puppet show, hard to describe, you just have to experience it. We had tickets in advance and it was sold out on a Thursday night. Charming ethnic folk stories in a creative medium. Go.

So sleepy. At one point half of our large group was asleep simultaneously. "A class" seats were within five rows of the rear in a 20-ish row theatre. Highlight of the show was listening to the people behind me squabble constantly about whether they should leave. No breathing fire or fireworks (despite what was said in the lonely planet). Group of 25 year-old males might not enjoy this particular form of entertainment.

The tourists are the ones getting soaked. Uncomfortable seats, poor sound system with tinny canned music, and live performers who looked bored to years. The live music was fine. The puppetry was mediocre. In one scene where the water buffalo was the main puppet, the operator could not keep its head out of the water and all we saw was backside. A waste of an hour. At least it was a warm respite after a long day touring Hanoi on an unusually cold day.
Amazing!. Surprised tickets sold out very quickly! Luckily, we obtained some tickets through a tour guide with some extra tickets from his group! Aircon vents are very dusty!

I loved this show!. This was a wonderful experience. Was it my favourite kind of music? No, far from it. Am I a huge fan of puppets? Not really. Was this a fascinating insight into Vietnamese culture? Yes, absolutely. Was this good entertainment? Definitely.If you're interested in culture and/or you like the fine arts, you should enjoy this show. It's a bit like watching Vietnamese fairy tales or folk stories acted out, and even if you can't follow the story it's fascinating looking at the way the puppeteers make their little characters move. Sometimes it's even quite emotional. The Vietnamese orchestra and singing is masterful and interesting. The puppets are sweet, and the puppeteers very skilled. Considering they were wading about in utterly freezing water -- I popped my hand in after the show, and it was really cold -- it's incredible how perfectly choreographed and delicate the puppets' movements were. It was great theatre.I wanted to take photos, which is OK so long as you buy an extra 'photo' ticket. The hotel concierge bought the ticket for me and I begged him to get me a front row seat. He couldn't manage that, but he did organise an 'extra chair' seat at the bottom of the aisle on the right of the theatre. This was great. Better still, someone in the front row got up and left, so I ended up with a front row seat after all. I got amazing pix!I really recommend this if you're wanting to understand local culture and a bit of real Vietnamese tradition.

Skip if your time in Hanoi is limited. This was scheduled as part of our tour. The theater was very warm, even with AC. The seats are very close and cramped. I am petite and felt uncomfortable. The show provided a history of Vietnam which was interesting. However, I would have enjoyed more time exploring Old Quarter and the lake as opposed to sitting through the puppet show.
Good Show for Kids. We took our two kids (ages 5 and 3) for an afternoon show. Anyone would enjoy it and it is only 45 minutes to one hour, which is a perfect amount of time.

Tired, but still interesting!. We booked through our hotel; though they told us it might be difficult because it was high season, we got in for the 8:00 show that night. It's walking distance from the opera district and the old quarter, and just around the corner from the night market, which is open on Friday, Saturday, and Sunday, from 7:00 - 10:00. The show's just under and hour, and that's enough. The puppets are charming, and there's an informative narrative introducing each of the 10 short scenes. It's in Vietnamese, but there are screens on either side of the stage which have the English translation. The narrator and musicians seem to be stifling yawns and wishing they could check their cell phones throughout the show, so keep your attention on the puppets themselves and you'll enjoy yourself more!

Great water puppet theater in Hanoi. I know a lot of people said they fell asleep or found the puppet show boring but my family (all adults) thoroughly enjoyed it. They explain the short stories in English, the puppets are masterfully handled and the the accompanying music very good. The hour goes by fast and the price is good ($5/person). However, if you're tall, try to get an aisle seat so you can stretch your legs out. The seats are meant for short Vietnamese people :-)

You do it because you have to have done it.. I thought the theatre was more weird than the puppet show. It's all a bit tame and twee. Ten minutes in and you're clapping politely thinking about gin and tonic. There's one thing wrong with this and that is the puppets should get bigger and bigger and build to a finale, there's none of that, just little moral tales with small puppets. If I owned this I'd be doing Jaws with a Xanadu finale. I don't know what the water had to do with the stories thinking about it. But, it has to be done just so you can say to people "And we went to the Vietnamese Water Puppet Theatre."And they say "Oh wow, what was that like?"And that moment before you reply, there is a little bit of wide-eyed hope you are about to reveal something special.

There are TWO water shows - tread cautiously. We were told that the one near the lake (where we were staying) was less traditional. We were taken to the other theatre a loooooong way away in traffic that needs to be experienced to be believed. It took over 45 minutes to get to the show. Traffic to get there for the 5pm show was HORRIFIC but we embraced the experience chatting as best we could to our Buffalo Tour 'guide' who was very well informed and helpful with university English. We arrived for the last 1/3 of the puppet show but 3 out of 4 of us were relieved at the brevity of our puppet experience. Perhaps we missed out on the 'flow' of the full experience but I doubt it. We have since been informed (not sure how valid) that the theatre we went to is the second of the same 'company' for when the other is booked out. We booked at least two months in advance!?

Vietnam folk art. We enjoyed the music and the stories as well as the puppetry. There was a program with the stories printed in English as well as a screen with explanations of the plays. The puppets were cool.

Meh. Judging from the lineups I thought this was a must see while in Hanoi. It was cute but not that interesting. Skipping it will not make your trip any less exciting, go around the corner to a coffee shop and people-watch overlooking the lake instead

Charming Slice of Vietnam Culture. Well, I guess they are not for everybody, but we found the water puppet show charming, a lovely way to spend a quiet hour in busy Hanoi. If you've spent any time in Vietnam at all before seeing this show, you will find it ilustrative (if simple) of some of the sights you have been seeing during your travels. Absolutely worth the admission and the time it takes.

Fantastic Water Puppet show. We were hesitant to go to puppet show but so glad we did, just when you think you have it all figured out how they do it they come out and show you and you do not believe, Fastest hour in a theater, go see it

Lacks a little in organisation. We were a bit miffed to find people in our seats and so ended up on the side which I guess was OK but there weere two empty rows behind us. The show was fine, nothing exceptional but clearly traditional.

See this last--very good. If you see this your first night in Hanoi, it will be disorienting since many of the references will be new. However, after seeing the Ethnology Museum, the performance is very good. Also a great chance to see the Dan Bau instrument played.

"Could do" not a "must do"!. I guess it is a must do if you are in Hanoi. It was interesting but I wouldn't worry if you didn't have time to go. We also saw the puppets in Saigon and I think there the 'show' had a bit more humour to it which made it more interesting.

Worth the time!. Sure glad we bought our tickets in Hanoi instead of on line. We had flexibility in our choice of times as there were 8 of us. The music and drama was very good and more than worth the low cost! We had people from age 7 to late 50's and I would have to say all of us enjoyed it.

After a long flight ..... Go to see it!!!. With All thé publicity that I heard about this I imagined it was going to be spectaculaire! It's ok & maybe for young kids who still have lots of imagination it's worth the visit

Absolutely worth the $5 it costs. How could you go wrong for a cultural experience for $5!!Great little show, something I have never experienced before. As if you can complain for $5??Heaps of fun and I'm very appreciated to have been able to have the experience! Make sure you book early though it sells out!

Great show. I thought this puppet show was fantastic and captured Vietnamese culture very well. The puppets were really cute and I am suprised to see negative reviews on here, after all the show only costs 2 GBP for cheap seats and 3 GBP for more expensive seats. We bought the expensive ones but not sure if these seats were better than the cheaper ones.The ony negative is disrepectful people in the audience- people arriving late and disrupting entire rows to get to their seats (and leaving early!), talking throughout, allowing kids to behave badly, and taking photos and holding the cameras in a place that obviously disrupts people's views. I thought this was a big shame and disrepectful and distracting. Apart from that I enjoyed this show very much and would even go again.As for the comments about tall people, I am not one but I could imagine having your legs a bit crampt for 45mins so you get a view over the top of people's heads is worth it. Tall people after all have the best view.For the money a really enjoyable 45 mins and in my opinion a must see. Make sure you get your tickets in advance as it gets really busy.

Water puppet magic. Fascinating puppet show. It's amazing how they can operate so many puppets without them getting tangled up. The seats are not friendly if you are over 180 cm tall. There is an additional charge if you want to use your camera.

Different. I wasn't sure what to expect when heading here at my gf's request. Certainly haven't seen anything like it before. Opening is quite good and last scene is good also. In between - bit repetitive but each to their own.

A Hanoi must see. Very very busy is make sure you get in early to get your tickets! May seem a little slow but is all about the Vietnamese heritage and way of life and is one of them tourist things you must do!

Excruciatingly necessary experience. Massively underwhelming. The novelty of puppets in water is, well, a novelty, but after that's worn off there's not a lot to commend it. In between the 6 or 7 scenes there are screens which translate the introduction to the following scene, so you know what is about to happen. And the place is full of people with zero theatre manners - talking and flashing all the way through. To be fair, the fact people are encouraged to buy camera passes for D20,000 does encourage this. I'm glad I went because I've seen it, but am glad it was only 45 minutes long.
Great Show, Cramped Seats. The seats in this theatre are quite cramped for a tallish westener. Once my knee cramped up I was counting the seconds to escape. I think it was a very creative production.
Lovely gentle 45 minutes of entertainment. Music was wonderful, and the puppetry fantastic. Only cost 100,000 Dong. Well worth a visit. And we were a bunch of adults.

Worthwhile. Need to book tickets if your time is limited as generally it is a 3 day wait. Better than I expected with live music and traditional puppets. The night scenes were especially spectacular. My only complaint would be about the mainly chinese audience who talked through the whole show, viewed it through the lens of a camera and finally took flash photos the whole way through, even the "night" scenes...... This should be banned.

A good way to know Vietnamese culture.. A must see place if you want to know about Vietnamese culture in short time.Lighting and sound arrangement was very synchronized with puppet performance.My wife and i enjoy it very much. Few performance was dullThere is extra charge if you carry camera.

Certain Sameness. The water puppets are an inventive and interesting form of theatre. The range of stores to be told is obviously extensive and the puppetry at times is very ingenious. The evening we went however, there was a certain sameness about the scenes played out. They were mostly showcasing regional dance styles which was a bit boring. I was hoping for more like the opening scene where a phoenix and a water dragon mated during a thunderstorm (complete with rain and lightening).

artisitc and creative. arriving to vietnam at Hanoi it was great to see this early in our trip; the artistic and clever puppetry was a colourful experience but also the story and representaton of Vietnam, creation and sgnificant figures eg. dragon, phoenix, turtle and unicorn came in helpful for my understanding on a few occasions later on.

Interesting representation of Vietnamese folklore!. Mixed reviews from our family. Children found it boring but adults found it interesting. The show depicts the Vietnamese folklore with puppets and story telling with singing and music.

Uniquely Vietnamese show like no other!. Heard this shows when I am in Saigon. But Hanoi's is feels more authenatic. The show i had is about Vietnam, the people and their history. The different musical instruments and songs does make it uniquely Vietnamese. The only setback I had coming from a largely non-smoking country does make it hard to enjoy the show without avoiding the smoke. Overall great show to catch.
not the best. not that interesting but a fun way to learn a bit about the vietnamese culture. first 20-30 minutes were fun but then it got a little boring and we were ready to leave.
Typical and Funny. Very typical and funny as well, worth to be seen once in a time. easy to understand thanks to the English translation on the LCD screens
Exciting. I am a Vietnamese so I understand all the stories, but for foreigners, should have a screen with words translation!

Could be better. When in Vietnam, water puppet is a must see. This is more like a musical type of show. My wife said that ahe has watched a better water puppet show near Halong bay (part of the itinerary of star cruises).You have to pay 20,000 VND to use slr. Well, a lot didnt pay but i paid to make sure cozi wanted to video record it. I will upload a video of it in my blog cheftonio.com when I get home.
Uninspiring water experience. I didn't enjoy this one - the one in HCM City is much better and more colourful and exciting, my wife who's seen both said.

great example of vietnamese culture. We had heard differing reviews of the theater, but we figured, since we are here, why not? We went to the 9:30 showing and absolutely enjoyed it. The show is narrated with subtitles in English. It's a really enjoyable display of the art of puppetry. I think it's definitely something to see to appreciate Hanoi.

Having a good dream. The place is near to other tourist attractions in Hanoi (turtle temple, red bridge, old town). Felt asleep during the show since it was so boring...perhaps not really my kind of thing....guess what? i thought I was the only one, but spotted about 5 other people visited were caugth by my eyes felt asleep as well.....PS: they dont allowed you to take pictures while you are inside..you have to buy additional tickets if you want to be able to take pictures...
Interesting Show. First time watching something which we have never seen before. The show reflects on Vietnamese culture and the children loved it.

Charming. Very charming theather show with local music and some very skilled puppeteers.
Certainly to be recommended on your trip to Hanoi

Entertaining show. I'm surprised at some of the unfavourable reviews as I thought the show was delightful. It was only 100,00 VND for a seat in the first few rows and the show lasted for about 50minutes. The theatre was quite small so nice and personal. There are singers and a live orchestra and there is a small introduction to each scene in Vietnamese with English subtitles on the screen which is great. The water puppets are an old art so yes they won't be doing super whizzy but it is rather enchanting and visually appealing to watch. The show is very touristy but so what - do it once to see what it's all about. If you like musicals and shows then you will enjoy this. I will probably go again in HCM.

Water puppets Hanoi. We arranged this tour via Luxury Tours. It included a dinner after the show at a colonial restaurant.We were picked up at our Hotel Lobby by our guide and driver. They drove us to the busy market area of Hanoi where the theatre is located. We went in early and watched the people come in. They have a variety of preformance guides in many languages just as you go in to your seats. We grabbed two to have some idea of what was going on.Our seats were smack in the middle of the back row. The only problem for me was, I am 6ft tall and the seats are made for little people. The seating was awkward and uncomfortable but i managed. Nothing like having your knees under your chin. Fortunately nobody sat in front of us, so we my legs were not squashed even more.The water puppet show was great. Very well done and entertaining. We thouroughly enjoyed itI had paid a camera fee as we went in. With my long lens I was able to get some great shots of the performance. If you get the chance, go to the show for somthing different.

Too touristy,. The prelude sounded like pop-music we almost couldn't contain our laughter. Singing was great but I can't say the same for the puppets. Due to the puppet design, movement was stiff,restricted which made the dance boringly repetitive. It was the same with other character puppets in the show as well.I will not visit it again.

Not impressed. Our guide book told us there would be fireworks and it was amazing... I was left rather disappointed. It felt a bit tired and to be honest my husband slept through over half of it and I dont think he missed much at all! It is one of those things though you feel you should see... its only 45 mins!

Interesting (once). Bit of an odd one this - they apparently were in training for 3 years to be able to put on this show. Yes, it's worth seeing as it's specific to the area, but the orchestra and ladies singing steal the show. The puppet element was, in our opinion, a bit dull. We expected more movement (than bobbing them up and down) for 3 years worth of training!

Puppet Theater. Pretty cheap to get into. Unfriendly ticket seller. If you are tall watch out for the seats! Looks like there might be leg room but once you sit down the leg room disappears. I had to move to the side where they have some folding seats set aside for vertically challenged punters. The show itself was clever and the music is good but not my cup of tea I'm afraid. The best bit was when the the people came out out into the water at the end and you realise how small the puppets are...a great optical illusion. It's probably worth checking out as something different to do in Hanoi but if you're tall be careful when you sit down! The people that insist on videoing the show are annoying because they block the view of the people behind them. it must also be irritating for the musicians and the puppeteers to look out and see mobile phones, video recorders etc. Why anybody would want to watch the show a second time on their video player is beyond me. Now I know why they ban video recorders in live performances (not just about protecting copyright)...it is very distracting.

Overrated. I am completely disappointed at the quality and presentation of the show. It was repetitive with many mistakes. Beyond the differences in the make and design of the puppets (that were quite nice in its own right), there was little to stay for. The 45 mins the show ran for felt like they were trying to draw out the show to make it seem 'acceptable'.Disappointing.
Beautiful singing; puppet ok. The puppet show was good but didn't wow us. We did enjoy very much the singing and the atmosphere. I would recommend it as a must-do activity in Hanoi.

Puppet mastery!. Great show full of cultural stories. At 45 minutes long with 6 sections, the music and different puppets the show was never dull. Would recommend the first couple of rows. We booked a couple if shows in advance to guarantee this, but with 6 or so showings a day, there is room for flexibility! Inexpensive at around £3.
Something to watch in Vietnam. short enjoyable show. Never seen anything like this before, but the puppets and the theatre could use a little more maintenance.
Boring Show. Cannot understand what they are singing, only show subtitle on the introduction but not the song and almost half of audience fall asleep, sound system is no good,

Delightful experience. We really didn't know what to expect and were pleasantly surprised. Echoes of a bygone age, myth and legend, accompanied by great lighting and atmospheric music. Although the show is presented in Vietnamese, an English translation is displayed on two large TV screens. Do go - you will not regret this quintessentially Vietnamese cultural experience.

Not like western theaters!. The show itself was pretty neat, but the family with the three children all under 5 sitting behind us talking the entire time was quite annoying. My death stares didn't stop them from talking either!

A must see. A continuing heritage.. It feels good that in this day and age, old traditions and art-forms are kept alive. For that reason alone, the show is a must see.The show is all about Vietnam, how Vietnam was born, their people, their culture using water puppets that were first used in the rice paddies of Vietnam. There are large screens with English translations to explain the upcoming scenes. Then the scenes are played out by the puppets and live ethnic music.I was intrigued with how the puppets were made to move and the first scene was pretty cool, seeing a puppet dragon 'swim' across the theater. But about half in the show, it can lose its initial appeal and the scenes become similar to the previous ones and end up becoming a bit boring. It ran for almost an hour, I think it was enough.Be ready for the tiny seats. There's not much leg room and it can be uncomfortable. Be sure to visit the john before taking a seat. It will be cumbersome to take a leak especially when you are seated in the middle.Have a later dinner at Cha Ca La Vong or do some shopping after as the theater is in the Old Quarters.
The show to see. Very good show. The music and the puppet are great. We spent a real nice evening. It is a very fairy show. Beautiful colors.
Nice to see it ones!. Nice show. I personaly would not go again but it is definetely good experience!! Seeds are very small, for larger person not really comfy.

Kitsch but fun!!!. We weren't sure we would like this - we saw good reviews but the photos looked like a child's show, where as we are couple with no kids. When it started we thought our fears had been realised! But before long we changed our minds, it's good fun! Even my husband hated to admit it but really enjoyed it!! It's only about 40 minutes long, basic but with a few simple special effects. Really skillfully done by the behind the scenes puppeteers. Definitely worth a visit.
Must See. worth the price you pay for, it's like watching a movie but this is more real (lively) and more musical, also get to know more about the people of Vietnam

Watch it at least once - something different. The show was about an hour. Everything was in Vietnamese, so I did not understand it at all, but the skill of the puppeteers was good. Although the cost of the ticket in both theatres is the same, 100,000 dong, the show in Golden Dragon, Saigon was better.
great show. enjoyed the puppet show very much ,especially the singing and music.As a bonus it is across the road from Hoan Kiem lake and there are many restaurants and shops close by.

Quick, inexpensive way to get slide of Vietnamese culture. Sure the Water Puppet Theater is a tourist activity and the place is a little tired, but that doesn't make it an interesting insight into a Vietnamese cultural craft. The stories depicted in the show are interesting vignettes from different aspects if Vietnamese life, and there are TV monitors that explain the story in English so you can keep up. The music was very pretty. The show lasts about 45 mintues and cost approx $3 USD (this is for the 'premium seats' in the first few rows, worth the additional $1. The night we went (to the 9:15 pm show) the theater was about half full and some visitors were kind of rude, not clapping for the performers which was disappointing.

Unique experience. Good for passing time in Hanoi. It's a reasonably priced 45 min show- 100000Vnd if I'm not mistaken. But again, to even try to price the performance and base your decision to watch it or not would be a mistake. I hadn't seem water puppetry performance anywhere else in the world so it was a unique experience for me. The puppet movements became repetitive after a while but I enjoyed the music tremendously and the snippets of cultural knowledge narrated. A minor point - Seats are very narrow with little leg room (much worse than airplane). Be prepared for a cramped 45min. Still, overall it's worth it to catch it if you've never seen it.

Good experience with the kids.. once enough. It is one of the listed things to do in NAM and also on Hoan keim later so afterward you can take a walk to the pagoda and learn about the famous Turtle that takes a round on the lake. THe play is not long and definitely not expensive but you must reserve your tickets at least 24 hours.. minimum.. it is a very busy place.
It is something different. It is a must see for all tourist. Kids will love it. It is an old form of art and as such it is great to watch.

Taste of culture!. The water puppet theatre is a wonderful hour long experience. Beautifully presented, and very atmospheric. Only spoiled by the incessant flashing of cameras, which sort of ruined the ambience.

Skillful puppeteers - dull plots. The show was mesmerizing as a demonstration of the skill of the puppeteers - very good indeed - however the plot of the show was dull and seemed almost as if it felt it had to be "Politically Correct".Interesting experience, but don't expect entertainment!

Fantastic. The puppets are very exquisite and it's really interesting. This is the first time I see puppets in the water. The show is about 45 mins and the song is in vietnamese. But the puppets are very nice and you wonder how it's being controlled. At the end, the staff actually came out from behind the screen and you can see how they control the puppets. This was very nice.However, for my girl, 7 years old, she only enjoyed the first 15 mins. She was bored after that as it's repetitive. However, i would recommend it to anyone bringing children as it's an eye opener.

Enjoyable $3 afternoon activity. For 60,000 dong per person we got a lovely afternoon activity including some cultural history of Vietnam. Having seen the theatre, I'd suggest against the 100,000 dong price as it's literally going to move you a few rows closer to the stage.

What's the fuss all about?. Fairly naff puppet show that didn't take advantage of the fact that it's in water. A short puppet piece in Sichuan was more innovative. Puppets here in need of some repair. I liked the snippets of cultural knowledge you get before each peice though. Great if you're stuck for time (or drunk).

A step back in time. This was a rather unique entertainment. Rather pleasant and unsophisticated in these modern times of big productions and explosions on the big screen. The music was quiet and the productions were gentle and endearing

Enchanting. We had no idea of what to expect when our tour guide arranged for the group to go to The Water Puppet Theater. We were mesmerized. My only complaint: the boors who kept on taking photos, the light from the camera spoiling the magic. Then there was the man behind me who leaned forward to take photos until I said something.

Authentic Vietnam art form, what's not to enjoy?. The 45 minute show is divided into short story segments, which are both printed onto a programme and flashed on screen prior to each act.The stories are genuinely quite interesting and give you an insight into the lives of the Vietnamese people. The water puppet show CAN get a little tedious after awhile however it is fascinating to observe the intricate puppets when they first appear.It is definitely worth it forking out the extra 40,000 vnd for the front few rows.

Lots of fun, loved the live music. We thought this was fascinating and unusual. Tickets were being sold with allocated seats on the day we were there, (so I don't understand all the other reviewers advising to sit in the front row). Anyway, I thought the show went on for just the right amount of time. 45 minutes was interesting but too much longer would have been too much longer. Definitely worth paying attention to the live music which was really beautiful.
Disappointing. Billed as the greatest spectacle on earth, the water puppets are just plain disappointing. 40 minutes of my life I will never get back!

Unique puppet show with NO STRINGS ATTACHED.. This is one unique puppet show, it is performed on a stage with a pool of water.The puppets are on the water or partly submerged in the water.They don't seem to be controlled by strings, probably by levers underwater.The show is presented in several sketches, mostly comedy and based on the rural communal life of Vietnam - such as fishing, tending to water buffaloes, a village wedding ceremony etc.A small traditional Vietnamese orchestra provide music to support the performances. But book your ticket early so as to get seating nearer the stage.For more read :http://jotarofootsteps.blogspot.com/2012/12/vietnam-hanoi-day-1.html

Saw both and liked Saigon's better. We thought we should see this in Hanoi since it is where the puppetry originated however we had seen it in Saigon first. While the theater setting was larger and looked better care for it was not as complicated or interesing a set up as the Saigon one. The Saigon one actually had better puppeteers and more interesting puppets. You can also see the musicians better in Saigon. Only drawback is that the Saigon theater did not provide explanation of the skits...I hope they change that...even as someone who understands Vietnamese I had a hard time understanding the stories.....as a Vietkieu.

Great for adults also.. On previous visits I have never bothered to visit, because I mistakenly thought it was "just for kids".This time with my 11 year old grandson,off we went.Believe me it was "Great" We bought the 100,000 dong tickets, and ended up in the front row.The way the story was related via the screens in English,plus the skills of the pupeeters was something you need to see to fully appreciate.Really a spectacle not to miss.
Innovative Puppetry. Enchanting puppets, soulful local music. But after 45 minutes felt a little too much the same. But a bargain at US$5

Great Viet Nam cultural show. Sit in the front row. The seats are very close together and you will have no leg room. The music is riveting and the live band brigs the whole self into the production. Get your seatts early.

A must place. Although touristy, the Water Puppet Theatre remains a must in Hanoi. It takes only 1.5 hours or less for the show and you will see Vietnamese culture is artistically expressed by the exciting music and moving puppet all on water.

nice cultural place. This seems to be the place to go for everyone - Vietnamese or vistitor. Go early to book a spot. The theatre is small and intimate so all seats are good. The show is short - about 45 minutes. It is the classic puppet show that is part of the ancient culture so a good show from that perspective. Well presented.
a strange experience - words cannot describe. Definitely worth an hour of your time one evening. A brief history of Vietnam is told by 'water puppets'Band and singers are fantastic.
Completely agree that this is fantastic!. Thanks for all the helpful reviews on this. We loved it. Go early to get your tickets. It's great for the kids and adults too.
What a disappointment!. Highly overrated! None of our group found the puppet theater entertaining. The program is repetitive and tedious. Perhaps those that are held outside are more appealing.

Water Puppet Show which was supposed to be cool is oven hot & humid. & stink!. I was at the 9:30pm Thang Long Water Puppet Theater on 21 Nov 2012. The outside weather was cool but the temperature inside the theater was oven hot, humid & stinky due to the exceptionally poor ventilation and non-functional air-conditioner. I wanted to leave immediately but couldn't do so as there was hardly any gap for me to squeeze out along the row of seats. The seats were designed for people less than 50Kg with no spare leg room. Those who are above 50Kg will definitely be squeezed by the front seat. I landed with a serious migrain after the show. Should there be a fire, I am sure all will die of a stampede!The show was just so-so. I would strongly recommend to you not to waste your time and money and above all to suffer for 60 minutes which seems like 100 years.
Good for an hour. Almost of an hour for this show was remarkble although it was busy and crowded.the female ticket needed to be more friendly

A must if you haven't seen it.. This is different from the normal puppet show we see elsewhere. It is water puppet. Puppets moving about on water ! With local traditional music, light fireworks and some gimmicks, the show is something special and can only be seen in Vietnam ( only in HCM and Hanoi I guess ).The tickets are always sold out during tourist peak seasons. So go early to avoid disappointment. Or you can buy the tickets for the next show in advance.Those who love arts will surely enjoy it. Get the best front seats !

Have a laugh and visit this tourist trap!. My oh my!The Thang Long water Puppet Theater seems to be one of the must-see attractions of Hanoi. Almost all tourists will visit it during their stay in Vietnams capital. Supposedly water puppetry is a treasured (folk) art form with a rich and varied repertoire performed by skilled musicians and puppeteers. Yeah, supposedly.In reality it's only 'performed' (to flattering a word) for an audience of foreign tourists (no Vietnamese will turn up there!) most of which are to bored, drunk or uncultured to recognize the tired, spurious and abysmally bad pageantry for what it is: a nasty first grade tourist trap. It's difficult to say what is worst. So many things are competing for the bottom rung! Is it the rundown ramshackle theater itself with its threadbare dirty carpet and fatigued tip-up chairs? Is it the fact that the 'singers' lip sync the whole thing? Is it the sad special effects (stroboscope light and smoke machine)? Is it the ONE creepily cheerful and maniacally enthusiastic puppeteer (who really believes in what he does!) at the end of the show while the rest of the performers seem to be embarrassed to the bone about what they've just done? No, it must be the 'story' itself: an endless string of tired clichés and hyper-nationalistic anal-cramp-inducing bog wash produced by the propaganda division of the Vietnamese Communist Party. Is it really THAT bad? I assure you: it really is!But that doesn't mean you shouldn't go there. In fact I urge you to go. Happily Vietnam is changing. And it's changing quickly. This might just be your last change to see this kind of propaganda anywhere in the world. So go and have a laugh!
A very pleasant evening. music and musicians were a high light, we sat at the front and enjoyed watching the process. Didn;t matter that the story line is vague

Must see. We weren't at all sure what to expect when we booked our tickets to this but we were pleasantly surprised. It was a charming performance and a nice insight into a traditional Vietnamese performance art. Would definitely recommend this to anyone travelling to Hanoi.

Best attraction in Hanoi. I'm not a fan of puppet shows. The only reason we went was because everyone said you have to see it - well we were very pleasantly surprised. The show tells the story of the history of Vietnam to include the myths and legends about it's beginning. For the best view of the show get seats in row A or B.

New show. Have seen this show twice before some hears ago.I was pleasantly surprised to see a whole new show this time. More emphasis on the ethnic groups that makeup modern Vietnam with contemporary music and special effects. A unique experience

Disappointing but very clever. Not sure what I was expecting as the show is very cleverly acted out and suorising at the end to see the operators -- wont say anymore as it would spoil it but was left a bit underwelmed by it all. Probably my over expectations
Fun for the kids. Great show for kids. My 9 year old son enjoyed it, as did myself and my husband. There is a great live band and the show is very interesting.

Interesting. Nice way to kill and hour. The show is interesting. But the music was the best part for me! would of been nice to see the band play instead of them hiding behind a curtain thats a little see through

Excellency. Something absolutly compulsory to see. The outrage spectacle justify by itself one visit to Hanoi. Beautifuly done. Beautiful musical and singers. And the experts of the puppets movements are absolutly incredible.

A must for a first time Vietnam traveler.. The theater is located near the north end of Hoam Kiem Lake. This was a first for my son and I and we enjoyed it so much we went again 3 months later in Ho Chi Minh City. It was the same show there as in Hanoi. With or without kids I would see a water puppet show.
Don't miss it.. This is a place that I avoided while living in Ha Noi. I thought it too "touristy" and just not worth it. I finally went with some students on a field trip. I was wonderful!

Worth a visit.. My hotel got us front row seats which is always nice--and at $5 it's a great value. They allow photography, but bring your zoom lens (and turn off your flash). The puppets are not very large, so they do not fill the stage. Keep in mind that this is a 1,000 year old art form--so it's no Hollywood visual effects extravaganza, and the story lines are simple. Puppets themselves are sort of clumsy as they are specialized for a simple type of motion vs a whole range of expression, but sort of cool at too. The music made it worth going. The finale is worth staying for, though I acknowledge some folks may be tempted to leave early.

You must go and see this. OK, what's so good about water puppets, you may well ask? Well, the music can be irritating and the puppets are odd...but you find yourself thinking the whole time...how do they do this? Where are the strings? Are the puppeteers underwater? All is revealed at the end and that makes it all worthwhile. Go and see what I mean when you are next in Hanoi.

magnificent. This sight is very beautiful! It is very instructive and the audience is struck by the high skill of the puppet-masters who appear at the end of the sight. The enthousiasm of the puppet-masters is a very moving event. We can just regret that the sight is not a bit longer...

Nothing to rave about. It is interesting I guess but a little boring near the end. The musicians are excellent and I enjoyed the music better than the show. Go early if you go as I could not see very well from my seat.

Really enjoy it.. I really enjoy the show at Water Puppet Theater. But it can be much better if they find out the way to translate lyrics into English for foreigner to understand what's the show about.
A tad boring. A bit long, and a tad boring (45 minutes). Not something that should be on top of your to do list. Seats very close together, I am small and even felt uncomfortable.
Wonderful theatrical experience. Well set up seating and such talented puppeteers made this performance well worth attending. The singers and musicians were very talented too.

Don't miss it.. If you've taken the time to visit Vietnam then you should take the time (only 45 mins) to see this cultural rarity. Go early to buy your tickets, $3 or $6, and get the best seats. Dress lightly as it's quite stuffy and keep your wallets safe upon exit as it can be crammed. Well worth it!

Waste of time. Well what can I say, maybe it was the fact that the theatre was filled with what are obviously large tourist groups to the last seat, or maybe that the seating had less space than the seat's on Ryan Air. It was certainly 30 or so minutes of my life that I will not get back, while I appreciate the time and effort that went in from all the performers I can not help but feel that I would have been better of, to sit on the other side of the street and watch the traffic pass by, would have been more entertaining in my opinion. I am not saying don't go, just remember my post when the show is over..!

Must see. The water puppet theatres are very much part of the culture of Vietnam and have to be seen. Very adept puppeteers and suitable accompaniment, both musical and vocal. May seem somewhat twee to westerners but if you don't want to get into the culture of somewhere like Vietnam, why come?

Underwhelming unless you're 5. Only go if you have small children.As an adult, this was disappointing. It's just a puppet show in water. The addition of water is intriguing for a few minutes and then its novelty wears off.

Interesting show. When I arrived at the theatre I were ushered in by a kind, gentle Vietnamese woman and I eagerly took our seats. The “stage” is a backdrop put in the water, and the puppets are controlled by amazingly talented puppeteers.It is really interesting show. You must see the Water Puppet Show when you travel to Hanoi.Highly recommend to everyone.

An entertaining way to rest your feet.. I went with a group and at least half dozed off. I think the hot room and some residual jetlag were mostly to blame, but the show is a bit too long and becomes repetitive.Having said that, I really enjoyed it and am glad i went. Go after youve exhausted yourself in the old quarter and our feet will be grateful too.

Interesting for kids. This was a nice way to spend a little time off the busy streets with children. I cant say our pre-teens were mesmerized but it was worth doing. One comment, a lot of children were struggling to see around adults leaning forward, filming and photographing the show. A reminder to please be considerate of others in the theaters...!

Can I have a written translation of the story?. Theater was crowded and we got a seat in the back. The story was told in Vietnamese and there was an English translation in a small screen next to the narrator which was impossible to read. The show would've been more interesting if I knew what the story was about.

Great fun. Informative and entertaining for kids from 1 - 100yrs!!. We travelled with two children ages 6 & 9. We all thoroughly enjoyed the show. The music is beautiful. Very colourful and entertaining. The kids loved it. Translation was a bit hard to follow at times. Well worth it and good value for money. Cafe downstairs serves great coffee too!!

Our children (4 and 6) were entranced for most of the show. The show is perhaps a little long - the first half hour was fascinating. After that, my son started asking how much longer, luckily only 10-15 minutes. There are little explanations between acts with English text flashed up on a screen.

Interesting Art Form. It was interesting to see how the 'actors' performed their craft. But, the 45 minutes show was slow at times and difficult to follow. As well, the seating arrangement was poor -- not enough incline -- heads were in the way. I say skip this one. Fly down to Macau and see "House of Dancing Water" instead. Then again, it was only $5. But, I wouldn't make any special effort to see this one.

Was good to see. This was a good show to see and experience however the biggest problem me and my 2 much taller friends had here was that the seating was VERY cramped. So cramped in fact that their knees were red and dented from the seats in front. It was a real shame as if it were more comfortable it would have been more enjoyable...

Very very nice and relaxing....watch out for pick pockets... I have been 4 times over the last year, the show rarely changes but it is part of Hanoi and very nice , live music and singing ...the translation is poor, but you will understand the stories of the puppets...and after you see the show and go shopping the puppets are in every store.

45 minutes of culture but seats uncomfortable. Loved the music. Length of show just right. Little boring at times but all would have been right if sears were six inches more apart. Don't go unless you can get the front row unless you are under 5'5". Very unique and as stated the music and signing superb. They use English subtitles to explain the action.

Can afford not to watch the show. Personally, I did not enjoy the show. Maybe I was too tired after long day.. But I did notice, most of them in crowd are the older ones.. So, maybe those in the older age group would enjoy it.
Mwah. I guess this is a must see when you're here, but I just wasn't impressed. It is definitely a unique show, but I just didn't find it very interesting. Can be difficult to get tickets
Very professional Show for all ages.. Live music with fascinating water activity. get front seats. Take photos is ok. Movie theatre like seating.

Great experience!. We were intrigued by the concept of water puppets and wanted to check them out. The theater is located across the street from Hoan Kiem lake in the Old Quarter and tickets cost about 60,000 dong (~$2.25). The theater seats are pretty cramped (my knees were against the seat in front of me; I'm 5'10") but the show is only an hour, so it's bearable. There are video screens that translate the Vietnamese narrative into English and the accompanying music was great; however, I would have enjoyed seeing the instruments and musicians play rather than them being behind a curtain. My one criticism during the show is that there appeared to be a lot of inconsistencies between the abilities or functionality of the water puppets. Some puppets were very physically agile and in-sync with the music, while others seemed lethargic and off-beat. We couldn't identify whether it was the fault of the puppeteer or the puppets needing some work; either way, it seems as though professionals would find it unacceptable and want it corrected.Overall, I would definitely recommend checking out the show; however, I would also recommend the company looking into correcting some of the performance inconsistencies.

Traditional show. A bit of a crush to enter and exit the theatre but worth it. I paid extra to take pictures but got some abuse from the people in the row behind for doing so. I could understand it if I had stood up to take them.Overral a fun show, especially if you have good seats.

"If you have time". The water puppet show was quite good. As mentioned, full of tourists, but still worth a look - only goes for about an hour and is quite cheap. Make sure you try and book at least a day in advance as tickets sell out quite fast.

Worth a look.... While I appreciated the talent of the puppeteers, it was a slightly strange experience - more like reading the outlines for a story than reading the story itself. But it is a 'should do' thing in Hanoi
