Sounds corny but well worth it. Wasnt sure about this one but our guide from Hanoi Free Tours said it was worth it. Nothing like having a local to arrange the front row seats. Very well done, not just another puppet show, a big cast skillfully done that also provided a history about the country
Water puppets. While the traditional music was fun to hear the overall experience was a cattle herd. I would not recommend this unless you have plenty if time in Hanoi.

I thought it was fun. Husband bored.. I really enjoyed the live music. The puppets were cute and kept me entertained, but my husband was bored after the second act. It's not expensive on Western standards and only 45 minutes long, so definitely worth going.
45 mins was too long. Very well done, colourful puppets and live background music however 20mins would have been long enough without being too reptitive.

A must see in Hanoi. The water puppet show should definitely be on your list of things to see in Hanoi. The level of artistry and music is high. This is not just another tourist attraction but a way to view the Vietnamese culture.

Maybe we were just tired..... Apparently this is as good as water puppetry gets and the show we saw had won awards... let's just say that a warm dark theatre after a long flight didn't work for us. We snoozed on and off and were glad it was only an hour! That said the music is good and all live plus they have subtitles to help you understand what is happening.If you want to take photos of the puppets you need to be front row - we were row 5 and nothing came out.
Incredibly boring. Music too loud - poor show with muppets on water if you have ever seen a muppets show in your life. This one is really boring. Even my daughter of 3 years old was bored

Must see. We booked at the box office and immidiately got out tickets at a very low price! The show was about Vietnamese history and very interesting! The puppets were beautiful and the show was great! If you have time please go and see this as this type of art are unique to Vietnam! For old and young
Book early. This ismvery popular and we tried to bookm but it was booked three days in advance, so book as soon as youmarrive.

An interesting cultural experience.. You kind of have to do it when you visit Hanoi and why not - it's cheap, enjoyable and a nice cultural experience. It's very cheesy and probably like most tourists, I had no idea about anything that was sung but it's quite a fun evening out! Visit the theater the day before you want to watch the show to book your tickets as immediate entry tickets are normally sold out.
Fascinating. There is nothing like it. A MUST see if you are visiting Hanoi -- great for all ages. We were unable to get tickets for the time we wanted so be sure to reserve in advance.

Very touristy but fun. the historical legends surrounding Vietnams history are explained in traditional song and puppet dance which is interesting for the hour or so that the show lasts which about the extent it will hold most peoples attention before becoming a little repetitive. This is not Disneyland or high tech entertainment but for 100,000 Dong or £3 its great value and there is a very good coffee shop next door. The ticket office is also very low tech, closed for lunch between 12-1pm and had a sign up saying sold out Friday, Saturday and only one show left on Monday morning but we wiated around anyway and when they opened up they took down that sign and sold us tickets for the very next show less than 1 hour later.

Excellent show. An excellent show which you may drop your tear when you watch their performance. The play of music with the explanation of the story, plus the effort they invested, it definitely attracted me. Seriously, a lot of people dropping their tears after watching the performance. I love it. USD5 for VIP seat.
nice to see. if you have the time, you should go and visit it. its quite cheap but gives you some impressions of the rural life in vietnam
Don t miss it!. The show is unique. Touching and moving. Most of all I appreciated Vietnamese music and songs, played and seng alive by wonderful professionists.
Water Puppets show?. Very unusual, our first experience and this was in Hanoi-Very interesting and unsual and it was done very well-smart way of relating a story !
Puppetry Review. Sorry but the theater presentation was a bit long, mind you my husband & I were extremely tired so could not appreciate properly

Clever and different. Only Aus$5 to see this lovely show. With live music and talented performers, this show tells an interesting story during the hour long performance. Situated next to the main lake, it is close to most tourist hotels around the old quarter.

Take time one evening to see a show. The show is a series of cultural and historic stories represented by the puppets. I have traveled all over the world and have never seen anything exactly like it. Puppets controlled with underwater devices from people behind the back screen. The show also incorporates traditional musically instruments and voices. Show runs 45 minutes. Buy tickets at the theatre the day before to get a time that works. Often full just prior to show time.
Very sweet. An ancient art of water puppetry. The singers have heavenly voices and the live music fills the air. Sold out most days--plan ahead.

Pre book if you want to choose the seats and session.. 60,000 Dong for the hour show is truly worth it. We were very lucky to get tickets, it was our last night in Hanoi and went to book for the 6.30pm or 8pm session, however the only session with seats left was the 5pm. There is a choice of 100,000 or 60,000 seats however only the 60,000 were left, It is only a small theatre and we were 3/4 way back and could still see with no problems. The seats are not made for westerners and I was glad my legs are relatively short!! Definitely make the effort to visit this theatre whilst in Hanoi.
Definitely worth a visit. We made reservations through our hotel. So enjoyed the performance -- unusual, and so we understand, authentic. Easy to attend, lasts about an hour. Definitely recommend.
a must. Worth visiting. Seconf time i have been there and each time it has been a different show telling a traditional story. The music played adds to the atmosphere. .
Interesting cultural experience. But the novelty wore off pretty quickly...was trying not the fall asleep by the end. Try to get the tickets a day before as they are hard to come by for same day!

Water Puppets worth the effort to see it. This is worth seeing, lasting appox 45 minutes the Puppets, music and Instruments really do get you into Vietnamese culture / story telling. Inexpensive about 3 GBP each I am so glad we made the effort. The theatre is not out of the way either as it is near the lake and busy shopping area. Having said that all Hanoi is busy!

Fun little show. If you have never seen water puppets before it is really worth the time to go to this short one hour show. Its a nice theater in the middle of the old section of Hanoi and the show is very well done. Recommend getting seats closer to the front (reserved seating available).
interesting. worth seeing, not just a puppet show for kidsentrance is 100K dong (around 5 dollars), the show is about an hour

Interesting experience. I like the story of the water puppet show. It helped me understand the culture of the country. The puppetry was interesting and I still don't really know how they did it. It was worth the 100,000 dong.

Fascinating!. This is really very beautiful. Puppets on the water: diving, fighting, dancing, playing with fire,... With a live band singing and playing traditional music. If you have a chair on the right side of the theatre–watching the scene- you ‘ll have the best view on orchestra and puppets. It is a must not only for tourists. You can buy the tickets simply at the boxofffice of the theatre.

Loved it. This was my two year old's first "theater" experience. He LOVED it. It was touristy, yet totally held my attention and was totally worth going even as an adult. It's not expensive and short, so I definitely recommend it.

Loved it. Had a great seat at the front and thoroughly enjoyed this experience, sure it is for the tourists, but the I was a tourist. Appreciated the artistry, with the commentary that had English translation on screen. Very colourful and relating some of the legends of the Vietnamese people.

A delight but somewhat pointless. It's is a traditional puppet show performed in water! Apparently it was invented by a rice farmer who performed it in the paddy fields. Whilst the whole effect is very clever and skilfully done the whole point of performing it in a water filled stage is strange to say the least. not my cup of tea but many others really enjoy it. Also the theatre seats are not designed form the larger western audience.

Not worth it. It was very OK. It gets crowded. We were in the front rows. It does not cost much but the performance is not much different from one item to another. They tried to give you some ideas about Vietnam culture. But it was not that good.

Who are the puppets?. This art form is rejected by the locals, and is kept alive solely by tourists. Not a single Vietnamese in the audience. Most people there, like me, were conned by tour companies to be there. Very few appeared pleased they'd spent their time here. Avoid it. Have a coffee on a bustling street instead and watch the people!

Charming and interesting. A few comments:I do not get all the fuss about the seating. It is not crucial to,be in the first rows, for it is easy to see from anywhere. We were in the tenth row, and it was fine. Also, the seats are a little smaller than Western standards, but they are comfortable, and anyway, the whole show is about 45 minutes, so what is the big deal. The most annoying thing is not the seats, but the patrons, some of whom insist on holding up cameras for long periods to,take movies--how boorish and distracting! The show itself is charming and interesting. Of course, it is almost all tourists who attend, but it is an authentic presentation, and well,worth your time.

Let gentle children make your day!. I visited the Bo De Pagoda orphanage with 2 Hanoikids volunteers (young ladies) and was able to share a delightful show about Vietnam's traditional history with 4 precious children. If I could settle down, I would want to spend a few hours with this team every week!

Interesting. It's an hour performance with a 3-member musical group. The people behind the curtain will be pushing the puppets on the water with dance and action. Very interesting and the story is mystical. Very funny. The row of seats are narrow with little leg room. It's worth the money (slightly more than US$5) for the front rows. It's cheaper if you choose the rows further away from the water stage. The evening shows are very popular and easily full. I've to book 2 days in advance for the afternoon performance.

Distracting audience. This puppet theater is actually very interesting attraction and worthwhile watching. The performance is superb. There are english translated explanations on screens on each side.But it is really distracting when you sit in a dark theater watching a stageperformance and the audience in front of you are filming it on their digital cameras where the back screen of their cameras are so bright that your sight of the show actually is blurred.I tried twice to make the tourists in front of me stop filming with no result.And to my surprice I saw on signs outside the theater afterwards that it is possible to buy permission to film and take flash pictures. That is not a good idea and it spoils the show
A tourist oriented show. It is nice and different, but mainly catered to tourists. Am not sure if it is really part of the culture or more for tourists.
Nice Theater. This is a very special water theater presented by the local people behind the scene! I really enjoyed it

good place to rest. after roaming the old quarter, we went for a quick bite; tuna sandwich and chocolate au pain. they were OK. the place could get too crowded sometimes, normally before or after the puppoet show.but otherwise, it is in good location.
Waterpuppet Theatre. Show was very clever but rather repetitive ..... finale makes it worhwhile.They charge for use of cameras, but waive this if you have coffee while waiting for entrance to show.

need to be in the front row. it is a nice way to discover the vietnamese traditions but it depends were is your seat. Select the front row especially with children because everything is on the water and the puppet are small.
A must see. World famous water puppets are not to be missed. We just walked up and got tickets for the next performance. Seats closer to the front are better--try even the front row.

Amazing. I remember watching "Punch and Judy" as a child however nothing will compare to this. The music and the show was fantastic. Remarkable how the artists move the puppets round the water stage while hiding behind curtains. A must do when visiting Hanoi. We will go back. We were there in May 2011
important cultural reflection. It gave an insight into the culture of Vietnam and it is absolutely amazing to see what they can do with the water puppets - the degree of coordination and precision

Very nice. Our family bought 6 tickets in Here, the price so cheap. 60.000vnd for economy. one hour for show, Its really Vietnamese Artist We like very much. Our Son barker out "Mummy watched...watched" He face brightening Happy.

fun, beautiful, interesting and unique. See a unique art form while learning a bit about Vietnamese rural customs and history. This is a beautiful performance with live music and narration in both English and Vietnamese.
A must while in Hanoi. So pleased we visited this. Quite magical both in music and puppetry. Visual story line on screen helpful in understanding the stories. Nice to see the puppeteers at the end.

good but not great. Puppets dancing and retelling of some aspects of vietnamese culture. The good- live orchestra/musicA new concept of puppets in water for meVery folky and long establishedThe bad - repetitive routinesNot enough wow factor. I thought the show was good overall And appreciate the effort and cultural heritage. As a young person it just wasn't my cup of tea. My wife thought the same and was quite bored. We paid for cheapo tickets and were seated in the back row. The auditorium is the size of a small lecture theatre so no biggieElderly and very young would enjoy it. For our age group I suggest giving it a miss.

When in Rome. I have to say our found the Water Puppet Theatre a little disappointing. Tried hard to like this but really the theatre was too hot the seats are squashy. I'm glad we went but I wouldn't need to to it again. Very clever but you need to put it in prospective and appreciate the cultural attraction.

Just entertaining. Nothing much to applaud except for the difficult livelihood for those hands behind the puppet, having to stay in the waters for numerous shows a day. Some of the stories were too long and actions of the puppets repetitive. The stories were flashed on the projector but some of their English were incorrect. Even though we paid for 1st class ticket at US$5, we can hardly see the sunken water stage as we Asians are blocked by the taller Caucasians. Maybe 2nd class ticket at US$3 seats will give you a better view as it is higher behind.

An unusual show to see. Interesting to see. The music and singing was enjoyable. Amazing as the puppeteers stand in the water to move the puppets. There is no problem taking photographs but you pay a small charge for the privilege. If you want a front row seat, book in advance - there are quite a few shows each day.

Mercifully short.. In all the guide books and extremely popular. Probably worth a go just to tick it off the list. Little kids would like it best I'd imagine but at the end of the day it was only 45 minutes out of my day.

Interesting animation of Vietnamese arts. One of the must-do's when going to Hanoi, Vietnam is to watch a water puppet show. It's musical and fun to watch eventhough you do not understand what the song is all about as it is done in Vietnamese which brings out the authenticity of it. There will be a stage with a pool of water where the handmade wooden puppets, coated with waterproof paint, dance with the music and song serenaded by a group of musicians at the left hand side of the stage. The stories and dances depict the cultures and history of Vietnam. The movements and gestures protrayed by the puppets in the water look lively and funny. There are several preludes in the programme. Each prelude has its distinctiveness. Believe me, even you don't get what the song is all about, somehow, the figurines will give you a sense of the storyline. Enjoy!

interesting show. One of the better attractions in Hanoi, which isn't saying much. The show was presented very well but it could have been a bit better if they had explained before or after about how the puppeteers worked. It was very enjoyable but I was curious to know more about the process. Don't expect to get good pictures unless you are in the first few rows.

So worth it. Either purchase tickets (100,000 or 60,000 Dong) at your hotel or in person at the box office of the theatre (same day okay). It's fascinating to see the stage: a pool of water. It's a colorful show and features so many different puppets! Bonus is getting to see the puppeteers at the end of the show. Great cultural experience while in Hanoi.

Unique style of theatre. A great way to see a bit of the culture of Viet Nam without having to go out to the country-side (but you really must go for a trek to Sapa or Mai Chau or similar). I've been to the Water Puppets maybe 6 times, whenever I visit Ha Noi with friends. It has evolved over the last four years and is much more glitzy. It gives a romanticised view into the life of the land outside the big city, and is worth seeing.

Cultural Information. If you know little of the Vietnamese culture, this quaint little show will give you some insight into some the history of Vietnam. The front row seats give the very best view and be sure to book your tickets early - especially in high season because there are only 100 tickets per show and they usually sell out fast!

Amazing!. One of the most go place in hanoi! Kids will love it! Love these cultural show. But Remember to grab their brouchure before the show. You need these brouchure to guide you through the show so that you can understand it better!

Great cultural experience. Water puppets are an ancient Red River delta tradition that you can view for just a few dollars here in Hanoi. You will learn a bit about Vietnamese myth and culture and the show is entertaining.

book your tickets early. had went to the theatre at 6pm to get the tickets for the night. however, even though there are many time slots for the night, all tickets are sold. (even it is just a monday night). And the next earliest slot available for tuesday 8pm.so if you want to catch this fantastic show, do get them early.

Seems to be the thing to do but a little dissapointed.. We paid the higher rate of 100.000VDN but our seats were pretty far back, the puppets were much smaller than i expected so quite hard to see. Also paid an extra 20.000VND about $1 to take photos and seems anyone can take photos!I wouldn't go again however if your here in Hanoi and have the time it's ok.

Unique and attractive. I've heard a lot about the art of water puppetry in Vietnam. The puppets are flexible and lively. We do not understand the contents of the play much but the music and puppets brought many new feelings. It supplements our knowledge of Vietnamese culture... unique and attractive.

Fun experience. I was skeptical going in and thought this would be a cheesy, touristy production and waste of money. And it was a bit cheesy and a bit touristy but it was a fun performance and very cute. It also was not too long so it did not lose my interest. I actually think this is a must do when in Hanoi.

Disappointing. Unfortunately this experience was poor due to terrible seating, the chairs were very small and the theater was overcrowded - i could feel the person behind me bumping the chair constantly-this was very distracting and ruined it. Also you can pay extra to take photos which was also not so good as everyone was snapping away constantly with flashes, and cameras were in the way of the performance view-this was also very distracting. The story was told in Vietnamese but had the subtitles in English but was too small to read from our seats. I would recommend this only if you have front row seating otherwise don't bother. The music was nice-if you can block out the distractions.
Water puppets galore!. A great activity for the kids and grownups alike. Everyone thoroughly enjoyed it. Need to book tickets early as they are very popular.

A very nice surprise!. I sat at the end of the row in case I got bored and wanted to leave before the end...but I truly enjoyed the whole time. I smiled, I laughed... incredible music, lights, colours and great artists! This I would repeat againfor sure!

Fantastical!. So this is one of "the things to do", and in this case, the phrase really does apply. Be sure to go a bit early in order to get a good seat if you're not buying in advance (15 minutes should be more than enough), and please take your seat on time, or else you'll miss some of the best music in addition to annoying everyone who's there on time. Traditional instruments work together to make a beautiful musical score, the narrator is dressed in period costume, the puppets are enchanting, the stories entertaining, combined with water and lighting special effects that hold one's interest... and comfy seats to boot! On top of it all, you'll actually learn something from/about this art form. The whole production takes close to an hour, and the good seats cost about 5 USD. Shows run every day in the afternoons and evenings.
our cambodia and vietnam trip. Very realistic. You really believe that the puppets are real people. The strories are told well. At the end the puppeteers appear and wade through the water

Water Puppet Theater. A very interesting and enjoyable cultural experience. We have also seen the one in Ho Chi Min City and found the one in Hanoi not to be quite as good, in our opinion, but still very much worth seeing. The puppet action is enjoyable, but the music and sound effects by the musicians are really great.

traditional performance. is quite nice to listen to the traditional song & the story of Vietnam. However, I took the late show, a bit tired thus can't stand but fall asleep at the last 15 minutes :P Besides, 150,000VND ticket is not much different with 60,000VND ticket as they are just one row beside me.
Its only a puppet. We had to go and see the water puppets. Its one of THE sights to see, but to be honest it was a bit lame.Expensive and a bit boring

Excited but show might be too long. Excited to visit the show as water puppet is famous in vietnam, and 'I think' it originated from Hanoi. Get excited when the show started as never saw this sort of show before, but after a while, it start getting bored probably because I dont know what it is talking about. Still worth a visit as it is just in the old quarter area anyway.

Entertaining and unique show. First time for me watching a water puppet show. It kept my interest. They have a tv screen in English so you can follow the story line. Something here for everybody. Worth checking out.
Interesting!. A must not miss if you are in Hanoi. Very interesting show where you get to learn about Vietnam culture. Remember to book early to secure front seating.
Fun to watch but slightly silly. It was quite cramped inside but something you really have to do if in Hanoi for the experience. Slightly silly but quite enjoyable.
Charming and beautiful. The puppets are new and slightly dfferent to those I saw four years ago, but the show is as charming as ever. One should not miss it.

I'm glad I went. It's not the most amazing show i've ever seen, but it was definately the only one of its kind and I'm glad i went. It was interesting to learn a bit about Vietnamese culture and history, and as we went on the first night of our trip it was a good introduction to Vietnam. If you have long legs be prepared to be uncomfortable for an hour though.
Better than I thought.. Not what we're used to but you have to admire the skills of the puppeteers. It was still very enjoyable and was made interesting with the help of the narrators.
very unusual. we enjoyed the show..the music and singers were also excelleny.We had never seen such a show and discovererd this technic with lot of pleasure.Please, go and see1

A great night. We went on recommendation of the trip advisor and we enjoyed it. The entry was cheap at $10AUD each and the theater was packed. It only went for about an hour which is long enough. There is a narrative in English all the way thru. Music is abit loud and the seats extremly narrow for us widder Australians but a fun night out.
A must see. A very good show with lots happening and very informative story of their beliefs. Well staged, comfortable theatre not a long show but well worth seeing.

Fabulous Cultural Show. This was great fun - a small orchestra accompanied the water puppets, very cleverly operated by puppeteers who actually stand in the water behind the stage. The water surface is the stage. A narrator tells the story of the mythical history of Vietnam, as well as the daily life of the people.
Fun theatre. good to see how it all works at the end but we had a real mover in front of us and hard to concentrate on show

crazily underwhelming.. this was crazily underwhelming. beautiful set, great lighting, but very lousy choreography. The show goes on for about 40 mins, with about 6-7 acts, with each act lasting for 5-7 minutes. Painfully boring, the puppets just do the same thing over and over again. If you just stay awake for the just first 30 secs of every act and fall asleep right after, I would say you wouldn't have missed a second of the performance.there were a couple of times i had stop pinch my thighs to stop myself from bursting out in laughter because some of the actions were just plain ridiculous (sorry if offend anyone but i'm just being brutally honest here).for USD5 per ticket I would very much rather have spent it on a good authentic Vietnamese meal or maybe even go on an overpriced Cyclo ride.Don't waste your time.
funny. it was funny and interessting to see but not big entertainment. Puppets are showing different culture traditions from hundreds years ago.
Water Puppets. Truly unique, very cleverly presented and some comical elements make this suitable for all ages. Accompanied by traditional live musical ensemble. Volume too loud during some singing.
Amazing. Good location, opposite Hoan Kiem lake and very easy to access, each show is only 45minutes. The Show is amazing with puppet on water and traditional folksong. please do not miss this show
A 'must do'.. Maybe not a very spectacular show, but very interesting to learn about the Vietnamese culture and traditions.

Uniquely Vietnamese. Have been there several times and just like everything they had here. An awesome visit with so much love for the music. It is though a bit crowded, try to get the first class ticket of 100,000vnd (5usd)

An exhilarating performance. We left the theatre smiling and all talking about the experience. The performance is as polished and professional as you'd expect of such a long standing draw-card. Everything about it is enjoyable. What more can I say?

Tradidtional art. We booked 4 tickets at the gate,(2 for 4 usd and 2 for 5usd per ticket), staff said sometimes all seats are not available because many people coming here to see. The wooden human who controlled by "REal" human inside was great action. Maybe it was a nice & traditional art.A coffee shop next to the gate was a good place for a next show, it was fabulous

Very nice. This show exceeded our expectations - it was really cute. Nice to rest in the airconditioning. If you are tall you will have to fold yourself into the seats! It was only about $3, or $4 for the closer seats.

A good presentation on Vietnamese culture. We booked to see the show ahead the day we arrived and had front row seats. The show takes you along a journey from traditional Vietnamese beginnings to more traditional tales of Vietnamese life. It certainly helps understand the culture more and is well worth the visit. The show needs to be put in context as one showing traditional crafts with the simply made puppets used during the rainy season times. The show runs for just under an hour. The traditional music accompanying the show adds considerably. At the end the puppeteers come out and show how they manipulate the puppets. There are English translations shown on screens so the story lines are easy to follow. It is worth a visit to better help understand the people and their traditional way of life.

Poorer performance !. In Oct 20, 2012, It was my forth times come back to Hanoi. Back to 1996, 2001, and 2009, the water puppet show was continued it's high quality, the show itself told the story and culture of people in wet land, very attractive, and charming. This time in 2012 it is a real disappointed. The opening dragon and swan laying eggs scene is great, but the rest is poor and a real boring. Only 5-10 puppets come out to dance with a song, that's all indeed. I realize changing is normal, but should be in a positive way !

Worth a shot. Bit of fun, gave a little of the history and was entertaining. Well worth a visit. It is only an hour long with a show every 60 mins most days in the afternoon/evenings and at $5 a ticket you cant go wrong.

Great for kids. The water puppet show is great for kids and grown-ups, a nice glimpse into this very skilled ancient Vietnamese art.There were two prices displayed but we were told that only the higher one was available, not sure how true this was. Either way we had a second row seat so it was worth it!
Puppet Theatre. I'm sure some people love this - just not my thing. Good to see but 10 minutes would have been enough for me.

So much fun. My husband and I really enjoyed the water puppet show. The musicians and singers were enjoyable and all of the puppets were cute. We had a good time and would definitely recommend to other travelers.

A Great Experience. The water puppets were a very enjoyable experience which encompassed many elements of Vietnamese culture. The puppeteers were very clever and together with the musicians, singers and story tellers they added to a very enjoyable show. The storytelling was translated into English on a screen so the storylines were easy to follow. The show only goes for an hour which was a good amount of time. It was great to see Vietnamese culture being supported by appreciative audiences. It was good to see the puppeteers at the end.
Had to do it. Everyone says its a must see, but we found it a bit boring. Good if you like the cultural aspect of the vietnamese

funny and happy. i was very happy and funny. i think every childrent will happy when see this show. they have show at 6h30PM,7h30,8h30,9h15. i like to booked at 6h30 they said fully book every show 6h30,7h30,8h30 then i take 2 tickets ( second class)

Much better than the water puppet show in Saigon. It is definitely worthwhile going to the water puppet performance in Hanoi. I had previously seen the water puppet show in Saigon, and the Hanoi show was much better. I don’t recall the price (perhaps about $7 per adult), but I remember thinking how cheap it was to see a culturally significant experience while in Vietnam. It is also in the heart of the touristy area at the top of the Hoan Kiem Lake. I also liked the fact that it wasn’t too long (about an hour). There were many show time options, so you can fit it into your schedule. Despite the many show-times, and the fact that we picked an earlier show on a weekday, it was a packed theater. We sat towards the back, and it was still a great view. And flash photography was allowed during the show.

Funny and interesting. Nice show and very well performed. There is also an orchestra and singers (ladies in traditional Vietnamese dress). Funny to see the puppets move. Cleverly done. The seating is a bit tiny for the average (long) Westerners.

Water Puppets. This was amazing! cheap as chips (about $5). The puppeteers(?) are in the water behind screens and make dozens of puppets go in sync. Only negative was that the seats were a bit cramped for gangly westerners it was hot as in the building as the aircon was inadequate. This kind of added to it though. A cosy watering hole cafe with good beer next door. Great place for people watching as there are amaizing sights to be seen in Hanoi!!

Great show at a low cost. We secured front row tickets to the 8pm show for around $20 each. Show only went for around an hour, but that was sufficient. Was a good show and I would recommend it. Great for children. Our energy-filled three year old was entranced for the whole hour! Singing was lovely, music was beautiful, and the show was interesting. Be sure to grab an English version of the guide on your way in so that you can read what each scene is in reference to.

Worth the visit. Water Puppets are an interesting piece of Vietnamese culture and this Theatre is well worth the visit. The performers are very well trained and provide a faultless performance. The audience seemed to appreciate it. I certainly did.

Great cultural experience. We all enjoyed the 45 minute show. The puppets, music and story were all very professionally presented. Seating is quite cramped so not for those who will need to fold themselves up.

Worth it. Chocka full of tourists, but worth a visit. The synopses on the TV screens helped a lot. The afternoon show does provide a respite from the heat; the evening shows a respite from the traffic -- take your pick.
must go in Hanoi. a must see if you are in Hanoi, just one hour show where they tell the story of Vietnam, amazing puppets.

Very cool!. It is traditional, it is very well-done, it is funny and it is cheap.Make sure you get there early to get a seat in the front rows, otherwise you will be annoyed by tourists raising their cameras to take pictures every 5 seconds...
Entertaining but a bit difficult to see. Very good art form..structure of the theatre did not allow for good views unless you are in the very first few rows -

Interestingly different. My girlfriend told me this show had over 800 positive reviews so we decided to take a look. I'm glad we did but we wouldn't be doing it again. Positives; 1. It's cheap, we paid US$6 for two tickets in the middle of the theatre. 2. It's short, 45 minutes so it's easy to fit into a packed day. 3. You will laugh because you don't know what the heck is going on. 4. You will learn a small amount of Vietnamese culture. Negatives; 1. Even thow there are some English subtitles at the begining of each act everything else is in Vietnamese so you really don't have any idea about what's going on.2. Super small seats, I'm 6ft and could not fit into the seat comfterablely. I was lucky no one was sitting in front of me so I could pop my legs over into the spare seat, still wasn't that comfy.

should've walked out in the middle. for a show that gets sold out all the time i would expect a whole different level.no maintenance - some puppets were broken (no hand), not working (umbrella not moving, hands not moving)aweful choreography - puppets moving totally not in synch or with the musicif this was something run by a kindergarten and not by a troop that states they went on shows worldwide i would understand but there's no excuse here except that they'd much prefer just taking your money.only good thing was seeing some vietnamese musical instrumens in work, but even most of these were behind a curtain...
Entertaining. Entertaining hour filled with historical stories from Vietnams people and culture. The puppeteers operate the puppets in waist high water from behind a wooden curtain, talented!

Great Show. The puppet theater should be on any traveler's list. The tickets are cheap and the experience is amazing. You'll get a nice flavor of Vietnamese culture plus have some laughs. I detest theater in general but really liked this. The performers are fantastic at their craft, particularly the musicians. You probably won't see anything like this in any other place in the world so I'd definitely put it on your travel itinerary.
Traditional Vietnamese culture. 45 minute show, celebrating the ethnic diversity of Vietnam, with local music and singing. Lots of interesting puppets and atmospheric lighting

Delightful to see. Very popular attraction with very good Vietnamese narration. We were all packed into this theatre. Very unusual but very well executed. The programme certainly introduced us to culture and history of the Vietnamese people.
A must see. A must see if in Hanoi....a little bit of local history as well as an incredible show. Plan this little gem into your itinerary.
Wacky. I think you have to go just to say you have seen it. A pretty odd experience- there is undoubted skill in tn controlling the puppets but I must say I was nodding off a bit.

Not my thing.. The Water Puppets were on the itinerary of the Indochina Pioneer guided tour and although it was nice to be in air-conditioning unfortunately the performance was not really my thing. The music was beautiful and it was interesting to watch the puppeteers make the characters come to life, I still could have spent my time better doing something with the Vietnamese people.
Great sound effect but not much. Average attraction. Mainly for the tour groups to bring the tourists there. Can skip if there is no time.
Must see. Exceptional performance. Must see when you're in Hanoi. Personally I liked it better than the one in HCMC. Pay for better seats nearer to the stage, worth it.
Not sure how they do it!. Yes the water is dirty, but it has to be to hide the pupeteers! It was very entertaining and the music and singing was lovely

Definately a. Must see. We were not so keen to go but it was included in a city tour and we were so pleased we did see the show. The puppets were amazing and the live music and singers that accompany the perform were unbelievably good. Loved and came away really pleased we hadn't missed this on our trip through Vietnam
Thang Long Water Puppet Theatre Review. Very clever puppeteers. Most enjoyable show. A little long perhaps but still a unique offering not seen anywhere else in the world

Good fun and a little crazy. The puppets went from making absolutely no sense to making all the sense in the world, and often did both at once. The singing and the musicians that accompany the puppets were really good and some of the puppets themselves (the flying fish and fishermen in particular) were hilarious - in a good way. Other scenes didn't really work. But I'm glad we went.

Entertaining for all ages. I very much enjoyed this show, the music, the puppetry and the splashing around is good entertainment for all ages! It's something quite unique and the puppeteers are very talented - the puppets themselves can be picked up in stores all over the city and make really nice souvenirs.

Not worth the visit. Perhaps our expectations were unrealistic but this was a disappointing experience. The music was good and the predominantly Asia audience were really into it. It was enough for me after 5 minutes.

Beautiful performance. No visit to Hanoi is complete without a visit to the Water Puppet Theater. They usually have three performances in the evening. They have a small restaurant selling drinks and food. Great place to go to while waiting before the performance. Best to buy your tickets early as the first two shows are usually sold out. We got the cheap seats at the back, the seats are close together so anyone with long legs will have their knees pressed up against the seats infront.The music, singing and puppetry is excellent. At the end of the performance, those who worked the puppets come out from behind the screen. Outside the theater room are a huge variety of puppets they use that can been seen up close. Great opportunity to take beautiful photographs.

traditional entertainment. In the first time it is a wonderful experience. There are english subtitles, sou you can understand what about the story is. but after all day on foot there is big danger that you will fall asleep :)

Get you hotel to book the tickets!. On our first trip to Hanoi we tried to get tickets but were told everytime that it was sold out, so I would recommend getting your hotel receptionist to book them for you. The water puppets are a thing you would only go to once. The show is good, the way they put the show on is great with all the music, singing, colours etc. The show is quite funny in parts, if you have a spare night definatly go check it out.

Even my 21 m baby enjoyed it!. I didn't think I would stay through the whole 45-min show as I was with my 21 m and 4-yr-od boys. But then it was USD5 per ticket so I thought even if it was for 15 mins it would still be worth it. To my surprise my 21 m baby really enjoyed the show and stayed the whole 45 mins. He kept on asking where the fish and the puppets were. I was glad that we went.

Fun show to go see.. Our family really enjoyed the performance and the length of the show is about right. If you are tall try to get tickets on the isle or in the front as the seats don't have much leg room.
Good. The puppet show detail the lives of the Viet Nam people. It was interesting to hear the music and amazing how the water puppets work. It was worth seeing.

Definitely Not a Waste of Time and Money. This is an example of a minor piece of the history of Vietnam and is well worth the small amount of money and time to learn something about another culture. Before you leave the theatre make sure to view all the old versions of the puppets to see how intricate the carving work is and how the puppets have evolved. People who write reviews and do nothing but whine and moan should not waste their time or their money using this site.

Water puppet theater. we came by it by mistake and managed to get tickets to a show about to start. It was funny to watch - they give you a brief history of how the locals live in Vietnam. If you have an hour to spare it is worth it. the music was very good

interesting. worth seeing,colorful and the stories to each part are interesting,children and adults alike will like this show. the screens on each side are a great idea with english on one and other language on other. girls on side have lovely singing voices,

Waste of time and money. I would not normally go to this type of event but after reading such good reviews in lonely planet I decided to give it a bash. Even booked early!! Well seating cramped. Puppets uninspiring and story a "cultural" trip through Vietnam was pathetic. Only saving grace was the musicians. Don't ware your time even if it seems inexpensive.
Fun but not enough. It's really traditional and unique puppet of Vietnam. The show is good but hard to say it excellent. Sometimes I dont understand at all

Professional and entertaining. More than just for kids! We saw the traditional water puppet performance and got to see and listen to traditional Vietnamese music played on traditional instruments with great skill. Clearly it is a tourist attraction but many local families were there to enjoy the show too. Well worth a visit and very handy, just off the lake area - which is a great place to wander around anyway and enjoy the colour and movement (and be gobsmacked by the antics of the traffic).
Boring night for adults. This is o.k for little kids but we found it boring as not interested in the history. Not worth the money.

Water Puppets good. This is a well known place, but sessions are too long and become bit boring, needs updating , kids like it for 20 minutes, I suggest you leave early before finish as it is all the same.

second visit - still funny. We visited the theater the second time and saw different shows.
It was still funny.
Negativ: the music could be a little quieter.

A unique water puppet show, a cultural experience. The water puppet show is a great 1.5 hour show that show cases the music, the acting the stories of traditional Vietnam.You get a taste of how stories were told in the past, and how important their culture is.The problem is that the seats are filled fast, so it would be best to purchase tickets today for tomorrow's show and get seats closer to the front.The show and music are purely in Vietnamese, so there are parts that seem to drag as you can't understand whats going on.Not sure if small kids could sit through the whole show without getting bored.The puppets and acting are amazing, and is worth the trip.

It's a must. This form of entertainment has been going on throughout Vietnam for hundreds of years, you will find it in many places but the one in Hanoi is the most authentic and best produced, you can also find a version of this at the museum of ethnology. Certainly worth a visit

Water Puppets. One of those cultural shows that you probably need to tick off. 50 min show of puppets dancing in water. Very few non-foreigners in the audience. Moderately entertaining. VND100,000 is okay value for money.

Water puppetry in Hanoi. It's a unique art of Vietnam culture and everyone who comes to Hanoi must see it. It's very easy to book the ticket from the hotel or you could buy it in front of the theater. Book it in advance to get a better seat.

A unique art form. This was a second visit, and it was an improvement over the first visit. The Water Puppet is an art form unique to Vietnam and its skill is worth watching (for an affordable ticket price of US$5 only).The puppets are brightly coloured and their movements do make you wonder how they are executed. The music is very nice. Two LED Screens with English explanations help the understanding.Recommmened to watch. Several performances a day.
a great show for children and parents alike!. I ummmed about seeing this a second time, but I had my 9 year old daughter this year... a new show... and my daughter was enraptured!

Touristy, but fun. Of course most tourists in Hanoi end up here some time, but the show is still good fun. Get you own tickets early and in the good caterogry, the tickets included in tours are usually more towards the back.

Very cute. The presentation is a mix between the muppets in water and Chinese mythology. The story is cute and enjoyable. The work and labor to put of the performance is amazing and inspiring. The voices in song, and instrumental music is excellent. Inexpensive - if they asked 5x the price, it would still be well worth it! Excellent show - thank you!
water puppets. What an amazing art form. Not only the puppets & the story telling but the singing & music were fantastic. The only let down was the toilets!!

Interesting. Go there, its worth it. Reviews are mixed. But I think its nice to see once. (its not too expensive). Sometimes necessary to book way in advance if you are with a group or you want a specific time. Many shows every day (also many different entree prices). You have to pay extra (1 usd) if you want to take your camera and take photo's

Quite cute. An interesting side trip if you would like to see something truly local. Some entertaining music and song. Not quite what we expected but for the few dollars it cost it was worth it. Must buy your tickets the morning or afternoon of an evening performance..it sells out quickly.

Entertaining show. We were a bit skeptical at first to catch the water puppet show after friends poor reviews of the water puppet show in Ho Chi Minh City. However we bought our tickets directly from our hotel concierge (Metropole Hotel) and enjoyed the show. The show is culturally entertaining.Each ticket has a seat number and the seats are tiered so you can watch the show without someone blocking your view. The show has English narration at the beginning and has English translation via the tv monitor.
Quirky !. This was an odd experience. Not puppets as we would know them but a clever show - although we did not understand half of what was going on !Beautiful singers tooNot really for kids

A different theatre experience. For less than $4 each you can admire some unusual puppertry, some live music and superb singers accompanying the action in the pool. English translation of story line on TV screens on each side of stage. Not world shattering, but enjoyable & intriguing.

Amazing programe. I took my kids there, amazing water artist in here not only for kids but adult also. Lovely ,high moving skill under/on the water. I and my daughter like and she did not want to come back home. she want to watch one more time again but we have no more time I think next time we come back .
Water Puppet Theater. The water puppet theater was very good in presentation and Puppet play. They also have a story to tell and the singers werevery good.

Hmmmm.... Difficult one, this? I mean, it's someone else's cultural heritage, so you wouldn't want to denigrate it just because it's not to your own taste. And it's cheap as chips. And something of a sightseeing 'must do' in Hanoi. But in the final analysis, it's also an hour of watching 'unseen' puppeteers recreating incomprehensible traditional Vietnamese folk stories, in Vietnamese, thrashing around in water to the accompaniment of a cacophanous migraine-inducing band. I guess if you're really really short of something to do, or you're a culture-vulture, this could be a great way to while away an hour. But we're philistines, and the pubs were open so we lasted maybe 15 minutes...

I dont want to rate this low as I wasn't able to watch this.. Not so long queues at the theater maybe because they have at least 8 shows a day(hourly). I can only tell you it's located across Hoan Kiem lake and the Temple with the red bridge.

Very interesting. Very interesting..for the hour. I really enjoyed going to this traditional performance. The crowd was mostly westerners but was performed all in Vietnamese with a traditional band accompanied them. Great for an hour but glad wasn't too, the have really good skills.

Quite fun if you can get a ticket.. An enjoyable way to spend an hour and quite cheap too. 100,000 dong each plus 20,000 for a permit to take pictures (probably could get away without paying this though). I thought it was quaint and I enjoyed the music at the beginning. My husband was plagued by a tall man in front of him who used his camera constantly so he couldn’t see properly. He didn’t really enjoy it. I thought it was a good way to get a little feel for old Vietnamese stories. It is quite impressive what they can do with these puppets and was a good way to spend an hour in the evening. Do book ahead, at least a few hours in advance or more as some other people in our hotel couldn’t get tickets for the night, booking early evening. I also know of others who couldn’t get tickets the whole time they were in Hanoi. It is a good evening but not essential to your Hanoi trip.

Superb cultural experience. The orchestra and singing was unexpected and helped make the experience. Buy the best tickets you can and you will have a great time. You may however wish to deposit any uncultured partners at the local bar before you go!

beware long legged persons. one of the best attractions in hanoi , pamplets at the door explain what the scenes are about as they are all sung in vietnamese but easy to follow beautiful production. a word of caution the seating is numbered and is designed for vietnamese height,had a good laugh when my husband at 6ft 3in tried to fit in as the seat in front was way too close .after some tossing and turning managed to sit with his legs tucked under the seat.also noticed other westerners sitting in the aisle.

No trip is complete without seeing this. Absolutely amazing you really can't miss this if your in Hanoi. The puppeteers go to university to study for this and when you see it you'll know why it is such a sort after job. The story is in Vietnamese but that's not a reason to miss it
Fun evening activity. I thought the puppet theater was going to be cheesy and boring but it was actually pretty fun! It only lasted about 45 minutes, which i think was the perfect length of time

A cultural experience of Hanoi.. The exremely cramped rows of seats with inadequate leg room and seats poorly pitched so constant " head wobbles" to see the performance was required by patrons was very disappointing. The brochures in various languages located at the the theatre entrance were essential to understand each puppetry performance. The musicians were enjoyable. I am pleased to have had the experience but would not say it s a " must do". If you are tall, ask for an end or front seat for comfort as 45 mins crammed saw many uncomfortable people. Respectfully, the venue was built inthe 1950's I was told, for local people. It was a joy to watch these children really enjoying the performance with their extended families.

Treat your eyes and ears to some true Vietnamese culture. This was incredible to witness. Knowing that there is a long history surrounding the Water Puppet show, it was an absolute treat to be able to witness it for myself. The visual display accompanied by the traditional music, is something that must be experienced by any visitor to Ha Noi wanting to embrace some of Vietnam's wonderful culture. As the theater is not crammed full of people, a special feeling of intimacy is provided. I must admit that I was very lucky to have my Vietnamese girlfriend sitting with me and interpreting the story. I was then able to share this with my friends after the show. A very special experience!

Should be seen for the experience. The hotel got us great tickets very close to the front for only about USD 4.50 each. The show is in Vietnamese but there were 2 smallish screens in the front which translated what was happening into English. Music is provided by a live orchestra playing Vietnamese instruments and there were a number of different cultural items performed. They started with how the Vietnamese people originated from the union of a dragon and a heavenly being (although it looked more like a bird) and then went on to showcase life in the rural areas, some of the different ethnic tribes and the effect of Indian influence on Vietnam. Since it is unique to Vietnam and so inexpensive, it is worth seeing once. It does get monotonous at times and the people next to us left halfway through. However the last part is possibly the most interesting so you should stay till the end.
New Production. The new production was very interesting which now also includes TV screens with an English translations of the VN narrative. Enjoyable...

Great Entertainment. This was an entrancing performance. We thought it would have been great for our grandchildren, so definitely one for the kids as well. I doubt you would see this type of theatre anywhere else in the world. Well worth the ticket (very cheap)!!

Enjoyed by all. I loved being exposed to this bit of Vietnames culture. The crowd was made up of mostly locals and a few tourists. While I do wish the program would have more of an explanation for foreignors, I did like the energy of the show and it was helpful having a friend there to translate and explain things to me.Worth the experience if you want to explore the culture.

Not worth the time. Every travel brochure tells you to go. It's just not worth the time. I feel sorry for those people who are herded off a tour bus to the theater. Skip it. Walk around the lake. Go off in either direction to explore shops and restaurants.

Unique and cute.. This is a very pleasant and cheap way to enjoy an hour of an evening in Hanoi.The water puppet theater is quite unique.Tickets for front row seats cost pennies, literally and the show is about 50 minutes long.There's a live band playing and singing on stage and the puppetiers are quite talented, as they make the puppets move in complex ways.Forget about the storyline - nobody cares about it, and sit back to enjoy this lovely unique show in Hanoi.Make sure to book tickets weeks in advance if you want first row seats.
Amusing half hour. Very amusing half hour out of the busy streets of Hanoi. The music is nice and puppets are adorable and they move in ways you can´t really understand. Very nice.

as Authentic as you can get!. As a traveller, I always seek to gain a better understanding of the local culture and history. This was good entertainment, good cultural showcase, good insight into their history - all rolled into one! The show lasts for 1 hour but you won't feel like it dragged too long, which goes to show the entertainment value of it (if you know what I mean). Pay for the premium seats so you get a better and closer view of the puppets, musical performers and figure out how they manipulate the puppets from underwater. It's worth it! (not a lot more expensive for the premium seats anyway)

Just good enough. For me, I find it little boring watching the puppets. At first, we were really excited. The show began by group of people playing instruments. It is first ok, but it takes too much long, that you may fall asleep waiting the puppets to come out. When the puppets come out, I was first happy and giggly but the narrator speaks on Vietnamese language that makes me feel confused although, the actions of the puppets are really obvious and you can easily understand the story. The movement of the puppets are really good and amazing, there are exhibitions that are awesome. You can take pictures of the show with no additional cost. And because it is cold inside the theater, I felt sleepy because we came from a  hot whole day city tour. Will recommend but don't expect too much.

Entertaining but a little boring at times. For A$5 it was good value, show went for what felt like about 40 mins, was a nice air conditioned theater. The difference between the 'premium' $5 tickets and the cheaper ones were the $5 filled the theater from the front back whereas the cheaper ones filled from the back first. It was a pretty small room so it didnt make that much difference, but for the sake of about $2 go for the better seats.Was pretty amazing at the end to see just how many people were involved. The storyline also proved helpful in understanding other tours around Vietnam.
Worth to watch. The show is around 1 hour. Vietnamese culture is shown and quite interesting on how they manuover the puppets. There is a lot of people working behind the scene.

Entertaining show!. The Water Puppet Theatre show is a good show, albeit none of it in English they do provide you with a booklet in several languages at the entrance so you know roughly what is going on. There are several showings per day and you need to check the notice board outside for when as it varies during the week. The ticket office could have been more helpful as they were telling people who wanted more than one ticket that they were sold out, but if you don't mind not sitting together then you can usually get a seat despite this. Go early if you want to get tickets as this is a popular attraction for both tourists and locals alike. Theatre is easy to find, right on the corner of the lake with a bi neon sign!

Worst show ever watch. With very exciting mode entering the theater for the show. Bearing in mind should be great show, as most of the ticket sold out for certain timing. After missed few show schedule, finally get the ticket. But I could not understand the performance... and fall asleep during the show. What a boring show!

An impressive puppet. I like very much. The show is impressive and retake traditional songs and life scenes of rural vietnam. the music is great. they do 5 shows at day, you have to take tickets before. If u have first places is better. you have to pay to take a pic (sigh!) but nobody takes care on.

Nothing special. This was listed as a "must see" in our guide ... but wasn't really anything special.
The puppet shows would probably mean more if you could understand Vietnamese, but the music and singing was excellent.
It was an OK way to spend an hour or so ... but wouldn't go out of my way to see it.
Silly & great fun. It's all a bit daft but great harmless fun and very cheap (about €2 per head).. Worth an hour out of your day to see.

Great Piece of Local Entertainment. You certainly get your moneys worth here, well over an hour of puppetry and music with a decent sized orchestra playing along with the puppets.It is so colourful and so unique to the region that it is definitely worth doing. The first ten minutes of so I was scratching my head a bit as the puppets were nowhere to be seen and the music did drag on a bit. But once they start, they are quite magnificent.Well worth your time.
Nice to kill an hour. Funny theater, with a lot of vietnamees music, the performance however is funny and ends at the right time. legg space is limited so take the otside seats

Amazing puppet show, even for adults. This seems to be the standard end to the City tour, by the time we got there I was not looking forward to it if I am honest. Best way to describe the front of house is chaos. The show is fantastic and can be enjoyed by children of all ages (I am 59). Only down side was when the lights went down all you could see we're dozens of IPads and tablets glowing in the dark! Getting a good picture is difficult if not impossible because of the constant flashes from cameras in the audience. You can't go the Hanoi and not see this.
Can be missed. Culturally interesting. Small theatre uncomfortable. Crowded hot but still good for culture vultures

Fun entertainment in the cool. This show provided a cool and quiet place to escape the madness outside. It was interesting to see and hear the traditional musical instruments. The puppet show was easy to follow with the help of the guide written in English ( and a few other languages are available). The puppets were cute and the puppet show is cleverly done.
Lots of fun and interesting. The stories and puppets are charming and worth spending the hour to see the show and learn about the music, instruments and culture. A bargain for $5.
Very enjoyable. I don't know what I was expecting when I read about the water puppet shows, but this show was really fun for us
Go. Go even if you don't want to. Is fun and charming.the best is the gorgeous live musicians. Also great air on .....sorry.
Must see, or maybe not.. It is considered to be a must see performance. The price of a ticket does not have to stop you. To be honest we were not that impressed.
its fun. its fun to watch, but i think it needs more of something, i dont know ?? to make it more better...dont get me wrong...go see it, you will like it too

Interesting to see if you have time. The water puppet show is interesting to see if you have time to kill in Hanoi. Make sure you walk out the rear door so that you can see what the puupets are made off and how heavy they are.

Music yes; light-hearted fun; artistry not so much. A generally pleasant experience at a modest price in a nice location for launching a pleasant evening by or near the lake or French Quarter.Loved the music; some of the performance was fun. Seats very tight; views not great due to both distance from stage and audience members raising their cameras to get shots they will never look at again.
Water Puppets. Fun time for children and adults. Reasonably priced and a great way to hear the music and singing of Vietnam. Easy to find and you can buy tickets at the door.

Learning about their culture. Good cultural experience in Hanoi. I had read the reviews and felt I did not want to miss this performance. It was well orchestrated with a tv screen in English which depicted what each performance was about. This helped to understand the meaning of each section. Colourful and interesting.
puppets great. wow this was great puppets were very good would recommend to every one to visit this show we liked the music and the puppets
Loved it!. Had read a few negative reviews about the show before i went, so I wasnt expecting a lot. Got there & loved it! I would definitely recommend it as something to see while in Hanoi.

godd night out. I wasn't really looking forward to it at first because it sounded boring but i actually really enjoyed it. The production value/quality isn't great and there's no translation so it's vietnamese but i thought it as good fun for a night out.
Tourist Trap. I personally did not enjoy this show, for the money you pay, its not worth it. The water was dirty. I think it is something nice for children.
good. It was a nice visit buy the tickets in advance iff at all possible as it saves queueing in the street.

What an amazing surprise!!!. I didn't have great expectations on this show, it was included in my tour itinerary but what a nice surprise!!! the show is less than an hour and it's totally worthy, the singers have an amazing voice and the music is awesome First time I see water puppets! and it's so different!!. The only downside is that everything is in Vietnamese so you need to guess what's happening which is kind of intuitive. Oh, it's also annoying all the tourists taking pictures and video... (you need to pay for permit) they raise their phones and disrupt the show, you need to be moving to see the show. Otherwise, the show is AWESOME, you MUST go !!!

Cool puppet show. It's a must if you visit Hanoi, not to be missed so you got to buy in advance especially if for the weekend. Please read the guide before the show starts cause it gets dark. Nice music and the way the puppets are chronograph is very interesting, being full of Vietnamese culture

Fond Memories. We saw the water puppets a few years ago and really enjoyed the performance. It may not be the same now, But I still have my puppet that I purchased and it always brings back fond memories of Hanoi.

So bad its funny!. So its 100,000 for the front half of the theatre and 60,000 for the back half. There's only 16 rows and the seats have zero leg room so the view from the back is perfectly fine. It's an extra 20,000 to use a camera and 60,000 for video but as others have said- this isn't policed. The show is a collection of 10 or so sets with Vietnamese narration. There are 2 large screens with English translation so unless you can't read, there is no way you can't follow the 'story'. The music is truly terrible so earplugs may be advisable. The 1st set is by far the best so if you don't get on with that I advise you to walk out because it gets very boring! The puppets are shockingly bad and the movements repetitive, hence the boredom. Some parts are so terrible we could barely contain our laughter! Who ever wrote that you would die if you used the toilets needs their head checked- they are perfectly fine. The theatre is nicely air conditioned which provides a nice 45 min break from the heat of hanoi. I can't say I enjoyed the whole experience but I'm glad I went to see what all the fuss is about. It's only 3 bucks and will take less than an hour so make up your own mind- you don't wanna leave hanoi thinking you've missed out!
Puppets!. I liked it a lot! I am a puppeteer and I really liked it because it was something different. The only problem is the language barrier, but still I liked it!
Brilliant. Loved it! I didn't have a clue what was going on but it was brilliant none the less. The puppets are really good and the puppeteers very talented.
Lost Soul!. It is different from the last time (2001) when we saw it. It had a theme for the entire show. Now it is a combination of small presentations rather than a linked stories.
Water Puppets. A little over rated. The singing and the musical instruments were much more interesting than the puppets

Make sure you book. the experience is wonderful if you've never seen water puppets but when I returned a second time the process was hackneyed. Very very popular so make sure you have your ticket in advance

Unique Theater Experience. I never thought water and puppet were two words that could be used side by side. It was enlightening to know that such an act existed. The water puppet theater highlighted the rich culture of Vietnam and their Chinese heritage as well. Though the puppet movements were in rhythm with the rich musical background from the orchestra of traditional instruments, the entire play was narrated in Vietnamese that made the story line hard to follow and thus bland and repetitive. Some of the water puppets also need some repairs or replacements due to noticeable dents and deformities.
Language barrier. We couldn't understand the Viet, and as such throughout the show can only guess what the show was about
nice for children. The water puppettheater is very nice to see but we think it is more for children. After a half an our you have seen enough.

Great value but maybe not everyones cup of tea. If you don't take too much notice of the content but think about the technique and history attached to this form of ancient art its thoroughly enjoyable. The actual puppets are not very big which was a surprise to me. The dragon finale was the best.
AC and 100% Vietnamese.... A nice way to spend a few hours in the air conditioning and see some of the culture of Viet Nam. Suitable for kids of all ages. Very colorful. 1ID/67-68.

good, little hard to follow the story though. very small cramped seats - only there 40minutes though,tickets sell out fast - hard to get them if you're only there a few days. Programme had the outline of the story on, but even then it was hard to understand.Beautifully made puppets - very large. music ok - only two girl singers which were annoying after a while. Good value - only a couple of pounds

Fun show!. This was one of the highlights of our trip to Hanoi. It was a fun show. Though the show is performed in Vietnamese, we could understand what was happening. The show is comprised of about 10 (maybe less) very short stories. It is worth it to get a closer seat. Though the puppetry wasn't perfect and the stories were simple, we had fun watching this show. It would be great for kids, too. The seats are not made for western bodies, but sitting in the front row is more comfortable. I agree that it's not worth it to pay for the camera pass, as the photos don't turn out. Get the tickets ahead if you can and you'll be there during a busy time (such as August). The show was about 45-50 minutes long. This show is much better than the free one offered at the Museum of Ethnology on weekends.

Different but nice!. Not too cheap and sometimes a bit weird with Asian singing but definitely a must. Tall people (my boyfriend is 194cm) might have problems with the seats, ask for aisle or the first row. Don't bring a sweater, it's warm in there.
Fun and kooky. we enjoyed this but it is a little kooky and kitsch! however, worth checking out. don't pay the extra $ to take photos as the photos don't turn out and they don't check anyway.

Well Worth the Time and Money. Attended the last show of the day (2115 hrs) and sat in the 100,000 dong ($5) seats four rows up from the front. As others have stated, seats are not for westerners but then neither are most economy seats on airplanes, but I digress. The show is about 45 minutes which is the right amount of time. There is an English and French introduction but the rest of the show is in Vietnamese. The do have printed programs in several languages so you will have a general idea of what is happening. The music is good, better than I expected without the usual twang of a one string instrument in other cultures. I had some hesitation in going to this based on some reviews and almost skipped it because of a rain storm but glad I didn't. Pay for the 100,000 dong vs the 60,000 dong seats if you have a choice. Also, there is a camera charge collected at the entrance but not enforced inside from what I could see.

Good on a rainy afternoon. The music is a bit much, a little annoying. But, the puppetry was great, I loved that part. I can't imagine what a physically challenging job it is for the puppeteers to stand in that water all day. It was really lovely, definitely go see this.

Interesting. We went to the Water Puppet Show because it seems to be one of the things tourists do while in Hanoi. I had read up on the background of water puppets, which in my opinion gave the whole thing more substance.It was OK and entertaining for the 45 minutes or so it lasted. The concept has more potential as a folcloric event, but then in a different setting with maybe some more background to the concept, why, where, when and how it originated.For now, this is it and what you get. The venue is centrally located, so it will not eat up much pf you time.

A splendid performance of live music and theatre. We took our family of 5 to an evening show, during our first night in Hanoi. At first, we thought it would be boring as we already seen "water puppets". As it turned out, this show is as much about the live music, and their excellent singers, as it is about some old story with puppets. The theatre is comfortable and frankly, its a great show. Highly recommended.
A lot of fun. Really lovely funny puppets. Loved the music and singing too. Amazing how they get the puppets to work. Audience was full.

Excellent music, puppetry needs work. The music was excellent, the water puppet performance itself needs a little work. Two people on my right, I think a mother and daughter both fell asleep. We would like to have seen the musicians playing their instruments. Besides the water puppets, the only thing you see are the three singers onstage. A thin green curtain separates them from the musicians. For the 6:30pm showing, we bought our tickets around 3:30ish. We got second row seats. It wouldn't hurt to buy your tickets in advanced though.

Quirky and weird. This show is interesting for it randomness and good for a laugh. I'm not entirely sure that it's culturally relevant these days but for an evenings entertainment, it's not bad. You don't have to understand Vietnamese to enjoy it either but I found the dialogue quite funny as well.

Fun for a few minutes. We went to see the puppets for my 4 year old daughter who proceeded to fall asleep after a couple of minutes. My 19 month old spent the entire performance with his hands over his ears shaking his head. Enough said!We enjoyed it but once was enough.

Good for a bit of fun, loved the traditional music. Recommend.. A bit of easy humor and a unique look at the world of Vietnamese water puppetry. The venue was comfortable and clean and though there was a few of you in there it never felt cramped. Had good ventilation and movie theatre style seating so you get a decent view of what's going on.What fascinated me was the traditional instruments being played in view to the left of the stage. Obviously by very good musicians as the sound and how they were played was great.The show lasts for only a short time in which there are traditional stories played out via wooden puppets in the water. I didn't understand any of it being in Vietnamese but got the gist in the end and found it enjoyable and humorously quirky.Would definitely recommend.

Nice show. There are two types of tickets available: 60.000d for the back and 100.000d for the front seats. Except that the frontseats have a slightly better view, (from the backseat I could see everything perfectly clear) I didn't noticed any other differences. The seats are pretty small, so if you are tall you may have an uncomfortable seating during the show.The introduction is in English but the rest of the show is in Vietnamese and takes around 45 minutes. For me it was a nice experience to see all kind of puppets dancing on the water combined with some traditional Vietnamese singing. Tip: When you buy a ticket at the cashier you often find there are only tickets left for the 21.15 show. So if you wish to watch the earlier shows it is wise to book in advance.
A Vietnamese speciality with good humour. Something different and great to take kids too! Yu need to book a couple of days n advance if you want the front seats which are worth it

funny and excellent. Very funny ad excellent. You surely will have great time to see the water puppet show, the artists control the puppet under the water and you could only see them when the show ends. A must-visit place when you come to Vietnam. This kind of art is unique to Vietnam and you should never miss it.

Maybe over-rated. Water puppet show may have been over-rated; seem that only foreigners attend the show.Eventhough useful written synopsis provided, but I fail to appreciate the presentation which was in Vietnamese.
Loved it!. I didn't expect much from this very popular tourist attraction but it was quite fun and the live music was the best!

Experience this part of Vietnamese culture. It was a nice and fascinating experience to see how they manipulate the Puppet. I'm sure kids would absolutely love it but not for all adults. Traditional music but is local language should be somewhat difficult for usto understanding of the puppet. Still, I found it's valuable to experience this part of Vietnamese culture.

A good cultural show.. If you are tall then you need to sit in the front row or an aisle seat as my hubby is 6ft 2 he had a very uncomfortable time. It can be a little hard for small children to see. We enjoyed it although once was definitely enough.

Where else can you see water puppets?. Our tour guide for the whole of Vietnam wasn't all that forthcoming with suggestions for Hanoi, but he did suggest booking tickets for this show. I think it's because he knew we were all tired from travelling and were in need of air conditioning. His words were more along the lines of "where else can you see water puppets" and I suppose, that is the best way to describe the show. It's a little bit cultural, all in Vietnamese, there are some clearly talented musicians and puppeteers, but it's really just a tourist show. But for $3.00, why not go and see it? What have you got to lose? There's a great cafe at the bottom of the theatre stairs for a coffee afterwards, and I must say there is great skills on behalf of the puppeteers. No, it's not the most interesting thing around, and if you're short on time, then skip it. But it is a bit of corny, tourist fun, and sometimes it's exactly what you need.

Bad Theater, Pretty Puppets. If you are a connisuer of theater, don't expect much. Tickets are cheap for a reason. The puppets pretty much just bounce from side to side, and the music pretty bad (often not together and out of tune). That said, the puppets are very well crafted, and the theater is probably the best you will see in town considering it is a third world country. The tickets are cheap enough, that it is worth going just to say you did.
its cheap enough. You need to book ur tickets a few days in advance to grt seats. i guess its worth seeing if u hve nothing else todo but i wasnt a huge fan

Very entertaining !. The show is about 45 minutes long. It is great entertainment for all ages. I have never seen a water puppet show like this before. Since the lighting can be bad when taking photos, I would highly recommend videotaping parts of the performance.
Traditional Arts. If you have time do it. Try to get seats #1 or #19 if you have long legs. Seats are really made for fairly short people ;-0
