dissapointed in the information given about the show. i liked the show but it was very had to follow as it was all in Vietnamese (i expected this). i received a pamphlet at the door to read about the show but it is very very vague and you cant really gauge whats going on from reading it and watching the show. in addition to this the leg room is ridiculous for westerners. i am only 5'4 and my legs were completly squashed against the seat in front of me so much so that i had to sit with tippy toes or legs fully apart to be comfortable at all. the poor girl i went with who is 5'11 was in much worse a position than me. it also means that your legs are digging into the back of the person in front of you. not good at all. i wouldnt recommend going. on a positive note the show looks really good and the singers are wonderful.
Interesting. I found this very interesting and unusual, would I go again ? No I dont think so but it was worth it for a one time experience at a very cheap price.
Clever use of puppets. A very popular theatrical experience. The seats are rather cramped but the show provides plenty of surprises

Nice but not wow. The water puppet theatre is apparently a must see in Hanoi, so we went to see the 17h30 show. It's certainly charming and it probably depicts a real folk tradition, but I found it somewhat disappointing. Not a real tourist trap, but a bit too commercial.

Insight into Vietnamese culture. Make sure you book 1st class tickets to be near the front.Show is 45 mins, which is long enough to give an insight, but not to long for the kids to get bored.Photographers are a bit annoying though, which is why it's better to get to the front.

Weird!. Weird but good...worth the visit for $5 or $3 ,.We paid 3 and sat in back row....worth a look mfor the culture and the music. show is only 45 min long...thank God as the seats had no leg room.

An entertaining hour. This proved to be an interesting evening diversion. It is worth reading the programme in advance, which is what I didn't do. The performance was made up of a number of individual and unrelated set pieces, performed to musical accompaniment. I had wrongly assumed they were linked and the performance was an arc of storytelling. I therefore spent time trying to unsuccessively create some kind of linkage and storyline where it didn't exist. I should have simply sat back and enjoyed what I saw at face value. that said, sitting back wasn't really an option. The Vietnamese are generally much shorter (and slimmer in girth) than us Europeans. The Theatre seating reflected this. Thankfully the show is only an hour and therefore damage to knees and back was minimal.

Music + puppets. I actually enjoyed the music more than the puppets. Especially the singers, both male and female, were really great.No need to be afraid of the front rows. We were in row three and did not experience any splashing.
Good fun. Intersting and fun show. Musicians very good. Book early at the theatre for best seats. Bargain at 100,000 VD.

Thang Long Water Pupper Theater. This show is something that is recommended that tourists in Hanoi must see. The puppets themselves are beautiful in colour and attractive to look at. For the most par,t the various stories and legends of Vietnam were told through the actions of the puppeteers in a solid way, but not all puppets were synchronized at times when they should have. The women singers talked to each during the performance. While they may have been giving instructions to each other, it was rather distracting. Additionally, Individuals arriving late meant that entire rows of people had to stand up blocking the view of other patrons and once again distracting viewers from enjoying the performance. The information on the pamphlets provided to viewers would benefit from more in-depth information about each song and section of the entire show. Overall, despite the small distractions, this is still a show that you should see at least once if you are in Hanoi. Enjoy.
To turisty... To long a show, that wasn´t that amazing. After a couple of "songs" it kind of just repeated it selv.And the theater is build for the Vietnamese, so not a lot of leg room... ;-)

Slippimg. This serious cultural attraction is being turned into a tourist trap. Performances are brilliant but totally marred by audience flash photography which disrespects the performers and audience, All photography should be banned as it is in any self respecting theatre. Very sad to see this wonderful cultural heritage so abused by ignorant tourists.

Did not see what the big deal was. Liked - Puppets were set in a large pool of water on stage. Live music played by an orchestra and choir.Disliked - The show was not really exciting enough to hold my interest. Kind of boring, especially if you cannot understand Kinh.
Fun but 30 minutes would be enough. Great parts to the show that amazed but also parts were boring. If you go do not even think about using the toilets or you'll die!

Best way to end the day.... A traditional water puppet show is an ideal way to end a day in Hanoi. Although not in English, it is easy to understand the simple tales played out by the puppeteers using bamboo rods swishing through the water. An orchestra provides lovely music (on some unusual instruments) to accompany the short stories. Great fun for all the family!

For tourists but worth the visit.. This was an unexpected pleasure. We enjoyed the music, the puppets were in the water and the story was lovely. Highly recommend to any one visiting Hanoi for a one time experience.

Folksy. I can imagine Vietnamese kids having a blast when this form of theater was presented in original setting of flooded fields out in the countryside. The show now is more touristy and caters to foreign tourists who seem to either love it or fall asleep in the theater. The puppets are themselves colorful and I have not seen a puppet show in past where they move in three dimensions. The stories themselves are simple ones about rural life. The dialogues are lost unless you understand vietnamese and the accompanying live orchestra while likely authentic gets a bit screechy once the novelty value is lost.The place seems to always run to full houses as I had trouble getting tickets the day of the show and ended up buying advance tickets for the next day.

Fantastic!. The water puppet show was brilliantly entertaining and set to an eight piece Vietnamese orchestra that played wonderful music. It was a charming, unusual, and very clever performance that kept the whole audience amused. When a family with four young children sat behind us, I braced for fussy fidgety children. Instead, all I heard was laughter and applause.We soon figured out that the puppets were attached to the ends of bamboo poles under the water, but we are still puzzled over how the puppeteers got the dragons to spit water, the farmers to do the back stroke, the birds to preen for each other.If you have children, this show is an absolute must. If you don’t have children, go anyway. It’s a blast and an interesting window into the folk art of traditional Vietnam.

Just about worth the time... Not overwhelmed.. Very cramped, looks dated and old. I think I fell asleep until my wife nudged me. Annoying that even on the fourth row very hard to see the show with someone sat in front of you, pleased when the show ended. I'd only go if you've exhausted everything else in Hanoi.
Puppet Theater. An hour of your time , watching a vietnamese tradition. We did it. Enjoyed it. Got some good photos.

Surprisingly good. Having slept through performances in many theaters around the world, I was not expecting a lot from the water puppet show. However it was an entertaining show and with a duration of 45 minutes was probably perfectly timed. I won't pretend to have understood every one of the stories told but I did understand some of them and found the stories about the fisherman and the Coconut collector to be funny and entertaining. Given the amount of movement above and below the water and the number of characters crossing paths on the watery stage at any given time, the puppeteers appear to be very skilled.The theater appears to hold about 350 people but with the tiered seating, even sitting in the second row from the back we had no difficulty seeing the performance. The acoustics are also excellent. However the seats are quite small and any normal sized or above man will find it a tight squeeze.
Front row. Well worth the experience, however if you are not in the first two rows it is hard to see all the show. In saying that, it is very clever and amazing it was only discovered 30 years ago.
Great, Different. it was a nice experience and fascinating to see how they manipulate the Puppet.It is a 50 minute show and I would highly recommend
Underwhelmed. Hot and cramped theatre. Odd show but probably because we didn't really understand what was the meaning behind it.

Interesting... But Glad We Didn't Pay For 1st Class Seats. I enjoyed watching this traditional Vietnamese form of entertainment, originally performed by farmers to entertain themselves when the rice paddies flooded. The puppets were quite primitive and the movement on the water a skill to perform but nothing special to watch; for me it was more about being a part of a cultural experience enjoyed by the Vietnamese. The traditional musical instruments were interesting to watch, but as with other reviewers a lot of the singing was lost on me. I did find the small pamphlet next to the door as you went into the theater quite helpful for identifying the different performances, and was available in multiple languages. Finally, the theater itself and seating space is small - it was not built for westerners but worth putting up with for 30 mins or so. Tickets were 100,000 for 1st class (nearer the front) and 60,000 vnd (nearer the back) but I'm not sure where the split in the rows is made. We were sat on the back row and didn't feel it detracted from the performance at all.

Good to see this part of Vietnamese culture, but not particularly exciting. I have to be honest: I had expected more. The music was nice, the puppets were nice but I wasn't marveled by the technique. Also the theatre is quite small with very little leg room. Still, I found it valuable to experience this part of Vietnamese culture. I feel no need to go back though.
water puppets. we found the theatre enjoyable. Laughed through the show, the traditional music was amazing. It took us a little while to see how the puppets were manouvered but it was really clever.

Water puppet. Traditional Vietnamese Water Puppet Show performing arts. Quite surprised at the popular spot of people swarming out of the theater! Pretty cheap to buy tikets and go privately. I went in without a reservation, adminssion was able to smoothly.

It's one of those things you just have to do once while in Hanoi. Okay, I've seen it twice, and that's probably enough, but it is entertaining, and a great look at Vietnamese folklore and authentic culture. If you're tall, try for an aisle seat, or ask to be relocated to a chair on the side, as the seats are definitely not designed for Westerners.

Hanoi Waterpuppet theater. It was something you had to see, but I believe it was a bit of a disappointment. The chairs in the theater really need to be replace by new once. To have very clear view you need to have front row seats otherwise you view will be more or less blocked by the person(s) in front of you. The puppeteers are standing in the water up to their waist, which deserves some respect, but the show itself is not very impressive. If I would have missed it, I would not have worried.
Good Value. For the price 60,000-100,000VD it was a great hours entertainment. Really get to see another part of the Vietnamese culture. If you have a spare hour, a must!
Intereting. I think you have to go and see it because the puppeteers are up to their waist in water, but to be honest it is quite boring. The music and singing go on for too long.

CLEVER & ENTERTAINING. Do go if you get the chance, very clever and entertaining. The seat as exceptionally close so tall people have a problem but they are happy to relocate you to a chair to the side.

Not for tall people. I'm 6'2' i could not find a way to sit and watch the show. I resigned after half an hour to sit in the aile on the floor.Story, if there is one, is in vietnamese, no translation.I don't recommanded it. my girlfriend enjoyed it ok, but not that much.if you go. get the front row.

Sorry, but worth a yawn. We went to the WPT as part of a pre-arranged tour day. Had heard some not so flattering things about it, but wanted to check it out ourselves. One big mistake we made was taking 'premier' seats, which were in the middle of the theatre therefore we were unable to make a discrete exit. I am really sorrry but this one is for speakers of the language, and is lost on the balance of us. The performers looked like they were having a fun time but all the humour is lost. I still don't get the relevance of the whole show. Tip....Get a seat near the exit door...
Entertaining. Didn't have much expectation but turned it was quite entertaining. Although story was not difficult to understand, would be excellent if with subtitle.
Something Unique. This is certainly something different, that from a traditional and cultural aspect shuld be supported, even though the music is may not be made for our ears.

Unique Theater. My sisters and I really enjoyed the water puppet show. The music is excellent and featured Vietnamese native instruments. The puppeteers are incredibly adept and we were amazed at the way they manipulated the puppets that are in the water. The theater itself is lovely, seats are good and roomy and the show started on time. tickets are pretty cheap (around 3 US dollars). I would have paid a lot more for the experience.
OK Experience. Not top of the list of things to see in Vietnam but and interesting hour watching the water puppets. Music is traditional but seats are very cramped.

It is part of the culture. We went to the evening show and to be fair we were pretty tired from a long haul flight and two hectic days trying to see Hanoi. The show was fine, but not something i would do again.
worth a visit. the traditional instruments were absolutely fascinating and the singing was beautiful. We enjoyed the whole experience - and so cheap!

ok, but nothing really special. We had a funny evening here, but we didn't understand much, and the seats were hard. We had the expensive seats, but nevertheless we had a really bad location in the theater?! The show was so so, but the music and atmosphere was nice and special. I guess its ok before a dinner, but its most probably not the highlight of your Vietnam trip.
Fun evening for kids and adults.. Be sure to read about the story before watching the show. Great musicians, too.

Colourful, delightful. Hou can tell when a show is worth seeing when your cynical teenagers are enchanted from the outset and the performance seems to be over in minutes.Treat yourself to a seat towards the front.

Interesting. For a $5 entry fee this is worth a visit. A few people walked out from the half hour show and had it been longer we would have followed them. Best to go non tour so as to please yourself.

Great show. Our hotel Emotion Hanoi booked the puppet ticket for us. This was my first time seeing water puppet show. My children enjoyed it very much. We really enjoyed this historical entertainment which was accompanied by some beautiful traditional music. Enjoy it!

Ok way to spend an hour. Everyone on the internet and in guide books talks about seeing water puppet shows so we went to see one. We paid 100,000 dong, roughly $10USD, for the good seats. You have a choice between good and ok seats, 50,000d or 30,000d. We bought our tickets in the late morning the day of and they only had one show left for the day with only the good seats left. If you want your ideal price range and time, GO EARLY!It starts with the band playing 2 songs, which was fine, then the show started. There's 12 skits. Some range from one minute to a couple of minutes. A couple of skits were really cool with beautiful dances and a great stories, most were just ok (puppets splashing about with a vague story being told and a cheap laugh) and several were just plain boring. Twice puppets arms fell off during the performance.The seating is like movie theater stadium seating, so unless someone's tall in front of you, you'll probably get a good view of the show. The seats however have smaller space than airplane seats!! I'm only 5'7 and I was cramped. If you're over 6 foot tall, you'll be uncomfortable. The whole show is in Vietnamese, which makes it authentic, but if you don't speak it you'll be oblivious to the stories or what they're trying to explain.I was glad I went, it was a neat experience but on hindsight, if I missed the show, it'd be fine with that.
For people young and old.... this is a very interesting show even if you don't speak Vietnamese. My girls were enchanted, and so were we!

Interesting cultural visit. My family wasn't thrilled to go here, however we were all really surprised. The music and the puppets were great and we were thankful for the English brochure that told us what was going on. The seats are a shocker...very crammed for tall western people!

A really authentic Vietnamese experience. Great value. Tickets very cheap. We also visited the puppet theatre in Ho Chi Minh and thought the Hanoi show was better.For the price we paid, there were no complaints. A comparable show in Australia would cost five times the amount. Programs are distributed so you can easily follow the show. Negative: seating very tight for bigger people and ask for aisle seats if you are over 6 foot!!

Well worth seeing. we are well travelled and often do not go in for "Touristy" activities but we thouroghly enjoyed the water puppets - an excellent show - well done and the performers, performed as though it were their first and not their (supposedly) 1,000,000-th show
Fun!. A proper tourist trap but one definitely worth doing. It was completely random but a lovely way to spend an hour.

Cute and a good way to spend a 1/2 hour for the price.. After feeling that you are tricked into the 100000dong for the so called VIP tickets which go from the front to just about the back of this theatre, not certain if the 60000 tickets are only for the locals, I came out with an "ok" feeling about it.The performance although is interesting.Would I do it again or recommend to a friend. Only if there's nothing else to do!

All tourists, but still enjoyable. The water puppet show was very enjoyable. It featured traditional Vietnamese music and unique puppets that danced on a small pool at the front of the theater. The show is about 1 hour long and was filled 90% with tourists, but it's still worth checking out.
Fun and games. A nice way to see some traditional rural festivity while staying in the big city.Well performed and enjoyable.

A date with Vietnamese culture. If you get time do not miss the Water Puppet Theater - its a treat for tourist to get exposed to local fairy tale through music and folk-tales. Whats come more eminent is the strong Chinese influence on Vietnamese culture.

When in Rome!. The venue is like an old fashioned West End theatre - red velvet seats etc. The show was a hit with our three year old who loved the puppet that goes fishing and ends up getting caught by the fish. Some traditional music and singing, easy to follow plot and definitely worth it - the shows last about an hour and then you can head back out of the air conditioned luxury for an ice - cream downstairs!

Good experience. Enjoy the traditional songs.. This traditional show takes about an hour and is quite entertaining. The music has its up and downs and so have the screeching voices of the female singers. The solo of the lady with the traditional string instrument is beautiful and should not be missed.
Excellent entertainment. Very entertaining and clever. We were lucky enough to be in the front row and got great photos.

Good for kids. This is more a kids event. I would have been disapointed if it was expensive. Nothing special here
Hoa lo prison was far more interesting. We left in the middle of the show.

Excellent for children. My wife and our two small children went to see this show in July and it was the highlight of our trip in Hanoi, the show was well put together with beautiful music and kept both our 4 and 2 year old entertained through out.Don't fall for the buying of a ticket to take pictures and just have a camera in your bag, and if your are paying the 100 000 vnd ticket expect to be seated in any of the first 10 rows, almost not worth paying the extra unless you are in row A
Was interesting but.... ...its one of the local attractions, and good to see,but not at the expense of other activities.

Fun. As the show started we could barely suppress our giggles, an impolite affliction that will affect anyone who has seen the movie "Team America". Other than that, the show was fun and interesting. The musicians were fantastic and well worth drawing your attention away from the puppets for.

An experience well worth it. This is one of the things which were recommended to us on our visit to Hanoi. It did not disappoint. I didnt really have a clue what was going on given the dialogue is in Vietnamese however the show itself is worth a watch and the puppeteers and the band are highly skilled. Well worth a watch.
Go and see it. This was great. The show was great and humerous, and the instrumentation and singing was beautiful.
Excellent show. It's an excellent water puppet show. I loved the music and the colorful puppets. The story was easy to understand although they told it in Vietnamese. Don't miss the show.
Good time!. My kind of show, just under an hour and quite entertaining. But very loud.

Very Enjoyable Show. We aren't big theatre people, or puppet people for that matter, but we were in Hanoi in June 2012 & the show was recommended to us.It is a very cheap night out (i think we bought the good tickets & they cost us maybe $6) and we were pleasantly surprised by the quality of the whole show. It has a live band, some wonderful singers, and the puppets themselves were amazing. Even though we couldn't understand Vietnamese, it was easy to follow the story as they give you an explanation program in English upon arrival. The good thing we found were the stories were each quite quick, so I think children would be captivated by the whole thing without getting bored. We would recommend anyone visit the Water Puppets, its a show like nothing we've seen before.
good. good . amazing how they can control puppet in the water!
Cramped seats. I wouldn't normally go to something like this, but it was actually pretty interesting. But if you are taller than about 5 feet, you'll be eating your knees.

A wonderful cultural show!. My hotel provided us with tickets for wonderful seats for this show. We loved the Vietnamese music played on traditional instruments, the intricate puppets, the smoke, the atmosphere. The worst part was that it was a bit hot, but fans were given out upon entry. I wouldn't go to Hanoi without seeing this show!(Actually I was there before 2011, but Tripadvisor didn't have the date on the pull-down list.)
Wow. The music and the puppets are worth the visit, no matter if you don't understand the language.

enjoyable show. I did this as part of a city tour that I had arranged through my hotel. I enjoyed the show, puppets and traditional instrument playing. A cultural performance that is unique to Vietnam.

Fun show, unique. Fun show while in Hanoi. Don't set your expectations too high, and you will enjoy it. Admission is super cheap (don't remember exactly), but worth it to get the closer seats (there are only two sections to choose from).
Gorgeous!. It was a lovely experience and great value for money. i recommend it.
Puppets!. Great show, very talented - great to have had such a cultural experience!

Initial novelty wears off quickly.... Not that we were expecting a Vegas show or anything but we found this show to be very hap-hazard. The puppets would often bump into each other, be out of sync etc. Being honest, the Vietnamese music was a novelty at first, but by the end of it we were looking at the programme wating to see when the thing would end. It was pretty much completely designed for tourists. I suppose you have to see it when you're in Hanoi, I'm sure kids would absolutely love it.
Great evening's entertainment. I wasn't sure what to expect but this was a great experience, the show was entertaining and funny. Well worth a visit.
Very entertaining. make sure you read the little booklet first, before the lights go out, as it will not make sense otherwise. Very enjoyable and an important part of Vietnam tradition.
Well worth a visit. While many dismiss this as "touristy" - give a thought to the puppet operators and how it's done. Simple yet amazing. If you see it here of in Saigon - it's the same performance

Great end to our Hanoi tour. Definitely worth seeing.Best to get in early and get a seat closer to the front.The puppeteers are amazing, very clever and the singers and musicians are very talented.I went to the show as it was included in the tour package.Delightful and surprising hour we thoroughly enjoyed.

Unique. The water puppet theatre is a unique experience. The theatre is air conditioned which is a relief. We couldn't quite decide if we liked it or not but it is one of those unique experiences that you must do in Hanoi. Also it is very cheap. Get the good seats - at the price it is still a giveaway compared to Western prices.
Very entertaining. Entertaining and fun. Definitely unique and a good cultural experience while still being easy to watch and fun
Rubbish!. Boring pointless show of puppets moving in the water to the sound of some terrible live Vietnamese music. 45 minutes felt like 2 hours. seats were uncomfortable. Don't bother
Cute and human like puppets. Ask hotel front desk to book tickets before you arrive cost is US $6 several shows nightly worth to go and is packed full when we were there on the 27th June 8pm show

Good to see if you have a free evening. I was a bit afraid about the comments but we stayed 2 weeks in Hanoï, so we had plenty of time to try this.And we were not disappointed. It is true that the cheap ticket is really ok (60000 VND) and you don't need the 100000VND ones. The place is quite small so you can see the show from the up, it is ok. The music is vietnamese, so if you don't like, well! The different little stories are sometimes funny and always cute. It is a traditional show, so don't expect a big thing, and you will spend a good time (quite short, it lasts 45 minutes)

Get in early for best seats. I agree with some of the other comments that it was a bit long, especially with the cramped seating, but it is definitely worth seeing.Best to get in early and get a seat closer to the front.There are musicians playing traditional instruments which was very interesting, and at the end, the puppeteers come out, waist deep in water! It is very clever how it is done, especially puppets carrying candles!There is an extra fee for SLR cameras of a couple of dollars. Definitely worth taking a camera if you're sitting near the front.
Wow. We really enjoyed the skillfull mastery of the colourful puppets and the closeness of the musicians and performers.

Water magic. We went within hours of arriving in Hanoi, it was fresh and a different cultural experience. Sitting in the theatre with a melting pot of tourists and locals was unique. The performance nothing we had seen before. Worth the 1.00 camera fee per camera

Not worth the visit - we fell asleep!. Given the hype that this received in the guide books we went to the theatre with high expectations but were really disappointed. The puppets were charming but the performance was far too long - was one hour but 20 mins would have been enough. My husband and I would have left but were pinned in the middle of a row. Ended up actually falling asleep and feeling very ashamed of ourselves (though this may have been in part due to jet lag!)I think that families would find it a nice diversion for kids but would not recommend this as an attraction for adults.

Not for me!. Maybe having some greater cultural understanding and background information on the puppets might have been a benefit before attending this show. Unfortunately my husband and I felt tortured having to sit through the whole show; & even though it was clever, it just did not appeal to us. Several westerners left in the middle of the performance, which we felt was a little disrespectful, but we wanted to do the same. We have since spoken to others who have attended the show and they really enjoyed it, so it is just a matter of preference.

Interesting for the family. Definitely a tourist attraction but interesting nonetheless. Our 7 and 9 year olds enjoyed. Watch out for rigged taxi's outside. Musicians talented, some of the puppets need a bit of maintenance.

Very enjoyable. How quaint was this show! The puppeteers are amazing, very clever and the singers and musicians are very talented. Well worth the money. From memory it is $20 per person and from what I saw, everyone clapped and cheered and enjoyed themselves as much as we did.
Puppets in Water. First view of puppets in water. I could not see very well so best to try to get a seat up front. Unusual show.
A trip in the Vietnam culture. It was an unusual show. Never seen a show where the puppets move around in water.
Interesting. I went to the show as it was included in the tour package. Not my cup of tea but still quite interesting.

Entertaining excellent value. Air conditioned! Inexpensive, entertaining and skillful rendition of ancient Vietnamese folk tales told beautifully and seamlessly. Delightful and surprising hour we thoroughly enjoyed.
Interesting.. I haven't seen anything like this before, so it was quite interesting.

Great end to our Hanoi tour. We traveled with young children, ages 7,9 and 11. As part of our tour package, we had tickets to the puppet show. This was our first time seeing water puppet show. Our children enjoyed it very much even though they couldn't understand the stories and as for us parents, we really enjoyed it as well.

Ech!. If you actually like the art of puppetry you can definitely pass on this. The musicians look bored out of their heads, the puppets are just thrashed around side to side in a verrrry amateurish way. The puppeteers are standing in water that is waist high, and the puppets are held above the water.

Interesting. Coming from an Asian who doesn't think too much about cultural shows put on for tourists (our interest was piqued as we had long heard about this traditional Vietnamese art form), the show was pretty impressive especially taking into consideration everything was controlled by 6 puppet masters from behind the scene who must have spent years trying to master the puppetry. I can see why this was a popular entertainment back in olden days when there wasn't the tv or Internet. The one important tip I have is: Pick up a brochure before you enter the theatre. It lists each scene that is enacted by the water puppets so you don't get lost or bored because you don't understand what's going on. There is a story, and a meaningful story at that. Well worth the visit for us.

great experience. thoroughly enjoyed this lovely water puppet show... while trying to figure out how they were doing the act, the performances taught a lot about vietnam culture and life, with a wonderful backing orchestra and singers, ... it really takes you back in time to when this popular show was the MAJOR attraction in the area.. one can understand why even today... I wish them the best and hope they can continue this lovely tradition.

interesting and actually enjoyed the music. Did not regret going to this show. Did not know what to expect but it had a movie theatre-style venue and showed Vietnamese culture (farming, fishing, etc.) through water puppets instead of the usual cultural dances. I actually enjoyed the music, ancient Chinese-style music using old Chinese instruments (I mention this because I have Chinese ancestry and don't enjoy this type of music as played back home).

Water puppet show a must see. We had never heard of this, but wow what a find. Something unique to see for a reasonable price, puppets literally performing in water! We had to pick up the tickets on the morning of the performance but worth doing enroute to other things

Thoroughly enjoyable! Worth to see.. Although in a local language there's pamplets in English and other foreign languages giving details of the different stages of the play. It was quite entertaining and well performed - some of the action were quite funny even my 3 kids 11, 7 and 3 were laughing and clapping.

Not Impressed. It is difficult to say who this show is aimed at. I cannot think it is for the little children but neither did many of the adults seem very impressed. After a few tunes played by the small orchestra at the side of the stage some puppets appear in the water at the front of the stage .Various puppet scenes are enacted out with the puppets being controlled from behind the backcloth by wires under the water. I was quite relieved when the end came as I found it fairly tedious. (Possible because I didn't know the stories the were trying to portray)

Great experience!. Had a great fun during the show,Life, traditional music and colorful puppets.Show is in Vietnamese but fun and easily understandable.Ask for front rows because sits are small and close to each other and heads of people in front of You stay in line of sight
Interesting. Different from everything we have ever seen before. It is simple, but quite interesting. If you are in Hanoi, book a ticket. It`s only one hour of a different entertainment and culture.

Interesting show but not that exciting. Fairly old theatre. We paid on the day via the lady at the ticket booth and didn't have any problems getting an available seat. Cheap as chips to see the show but there's not much to it. Worth a visit if you've got time to spare otherwise I'd saying you're not missing out on anything spectacular :)

Worth visiting. The place is a little cramped and the air con don't work well. Most of the audience are tourists.
But this is one attraction that is uniquely Hanoi. I have not seen anything like this anywhere else in Europe, the Americas, Australasia or Asia. I have not been to Africa yet.
I was entertained and amazed.

Unusual and well worth a visit. Fun for the whole family. Maybe it is trite, but the price is reasonable and its a fun cultural event. Warning, however: the Vietnamese sense of leg room in the theatre doesn't necessarily fit the western frame (I'm 6'0"), but the show is only 45 minutes, so its not too bad.
Water Puppets. We loved this puppet show. Very well done. The vietnamese are very clever and talented. Had a great time.
Water Puppet theatre. Started off in english then switched to vietnamese so no idea what they were on about, but visually very good.

nice show, terrible public. An original / traditional puppet show in a not very authentic theatre, with an terrible public. Many tourist don't know how to behave themselves, just yelling to their friends on other rows. I had payed for a first class ticket, but I can not say I ve got a good place, I could not see the musicians, the distance to the water floor was too far to make pictures

worth a visit. it's local art, kinda simple, nothing fanciful. It's world class, probably because noone else is doing it. mainly tourists catching the performance.still worth a visit, just get it over and done with. been there, done that.current ticket price is 60k & 100k (bear in mind inflation there move pretty fast)

Well worth a visit.. Of course it is all in Vietnamese (why wouldn't it be!) and difficult to follow, but the experience of seeing something from a different culture is surely why we travel? Over half the audience were locals and loved the humour. Show is only 50 minutes long anyway. The singers & musicians, who obviously have seen the show a zillion times, laughed the loudest and genuinely seemed to be having a ball. Well worth a visit.

horrible experience. There were constant interruptions from people arriving late. This was not their fault – as they should have been told to wait for the next show but the company want to maximise bums on seat for every show even if its at the expense of people's enjoyment; we actually wanted to buy tickets for a later show but were told quite rudely that it was sold out and we had better go to the show just about to start. It’s not that much of an exaggeration to say that we were virtually dragged in. This together with the constant clicking of dozens of cameras and the large impersonal auditorium (in relation to the ‘stage’) made it a really fake, frustrating experience. There was nothing wrong with the actual show or the music but unless this is your only chance of seeing a puppet show don’t bother. There is an excellent puppet show in a museum in Ho Chi Minh. The experiences could have been more of a contrast.

Incredible Show. Be prepared to be entertained in true Vietnamese style and music. This world famous show is a must if visiting Hanoi. The music is great with explanations about the significance of the instruments, musicians and puppeteers as well as the stories behind the various acts.
A little touristy!. I was quite good - the sort of thing that lots of tourists are bussed into and bussed out of.....

Very authentic, amazing puppet show. This was the second water puppet show I have seen, the first one being in Ho Chi Minh, and despite having some common characters I was very amazed by this show. Firstly, it does not use recordings-all music and voices are produced live by a small orchestra of traditional vietnamese instruments. Secondly, it has more acts, and also acts that are more complex in terms of puppetry with dragons flying all over the stage. Also, enough information is presented in the programs to give non-Vietnamese speakers a good understanding of what was going on. Strongly recommend this to any visitor

Jim Henson on water - entertaining. You may have seen a similar show in Saigon but this is where it originated from. Having never seen a water puppet show before we were unsure as at what to expect. Knowing that the puppeteers use water as their medium will the show take place indoors or outdoors? You step into a a proper theatre with the set in front of you and sure enough there is the water pool. An orchestra sits to the side of the water stage in traditional costume and starts the overture as such. You are then entertained for an hour or so by a variety of puppets portraying a rural story. Dialogue is all in Vietnamese which makes it more entertaining as you don't understand a word but enjoy the intonation of the actors. A very different attraction which amuses all while enjoying the skills of the puppeteers.

Funny. I enjoyed this very much i mean just to see how you could entertain people without all the crazy special effects in movies now a day...could not understand a word as it was all in vietnamese..but i got the story a lil bit...the musicians were really good enjoyed it very much

So much better than I thought it would be!. We went here on our second last day in Hanoi, but only because it was a tick the box thing. I'd heard it would be really boring and wasn't expecting much. However we really enjoyed it. Goes for about an hour & is such a beautiful account of Vietnamese rural history.
Funny show. the show was funny and the price was reasonable, but if they could provide sub-title could help the audiance to better understand the content of the show

Humorous Culture. Vibrant funny, a must see, i went with my sister and her family the kids loved it, the big kids did too, most shows are packed, its not in English but very easy to understand the meaning behind the stories told, the puppets perform to traditional music, the musicians also doing the voices and amusing noises, would definitely go again

WORTH THE TIME. This is a great evening. We took our 9 month old grandson whose eyes were glued to the show from start to finish. We are in our 60s and enjoyed every moment so a show for all ages. Take it for what it is a bit of fun with good music and some great puppetry.
Traditionally pleasing. Nice and traditional, although i personally liked the water puppet shows in Ho Chi Minh, surprisingly even though the water puppet originated here.

CULTURAL MUST SEE. A real insight into the Vietnamese culture. The music,the unusual musical instruments, the exquisite puppetry pieces, the various stories that are played out, all of which is just awesome. People of all ages would just love it!!

Fun evening. This is a fun evening in an air-conditioned theater. The show is only 50 minutes long and is a great escape from the heat. It is a little silly, but good for a laugh. Excellent music. Five shows a day. Best seats in the theatre are only $5 U.S.
good value. beautiful music and shows you seens of life at a river.

ok if you have lots of time, but ultimately missable. I'm mildly glad I saw it, but definitely wouldn't go back, and it definitely isn't essential to see. It was kind of fun, just for something different to do, but if you are tight for time, this is completely missable. The show is a series of vignettes, some more visually interesting than others, and some having more dialogue, so less enjoyable if you don't speak Vietnamese. If you have kids who would enjoy a puppet show though, this is probably a worthwhile visit. Side note - we went to a seafood dinner nearby at a street vendor after the show, and after being used to prices of $2-5 for sidewalk meals, were shocked by our $50 USD bill...not sure if it was because it was seafood, or because the area is so touristy, but make sure to ask the price of things *before* you order.

Children would love it. Wished we could have sat a lot closer as it was difficult to get photos we quite enjoyed, we did this on our free day between Sapa and travelling onto Hue. It was light entertainment.

A most unusual experience, not to be missed. The Water Puppet show is something you probably have never seen before. After entering the building (close to Hoan Kiem lake) you mount stairs to enter a usual theatre. After you have found your seat(s), you observe that the stage is a big pool filled with water. On the left of the "stage" is a section (dry of course) where a Vietnamese orchestra of about nine men and women is installed. Then the performance starts with music from the orchestra and the water puppets, operated with long sticks by artists, standing in the water behind the backdrop, will appear in the water pool. (See picture). There is also music from the orchestra and dialog between the artists and members of the orchestra, supporting the story represented by the puppet show. The curious thing is, that of course most of the public is tourist and don't understand a word of Vietnamese. So the jokes made in the water puppet show leave the public cold while the musicians obviously are enjoying the jokes. But, while we do not understand much of the story, the performance and ambiance of the Water Puppet Theatre is not to be missed.

Fun to watch. Theater is directly across the road from Hoan Kiem Lake so it's very easy to find. The show is entertaining. Traditional music and instruments were used in the show which are very interesting and ear catching. The first class tickets and standard are not much different in term of price ($2) but it's a lot easier to see and enjoy the show with the first row so make sure you buy first class tickets. Check availability at least a day before as tickets sold out very quickly.

A surprisingly enjoyable show. We had overlooked this attraction before, at at the urging of our Hanoikid guide booked tickets and attended. We really enjoyed this historical entertainment which was accompanied by some beautiful traditional music. The venue was large, airconditioned and well organised. It is very inexpensive and I think a must see to have a rounded view of Vietnamese culture.
A fun afternoon.. This was another hightlight. It was funny and well put together. Do expect too much and you will enjoy every moment.
Fire Breathing Dragons. A must do cultural experience. The puppeteer's are masters and don't miss the dragons. My 7 year old son loved it and it gave him a great memory

Nightmare. The only redeeming quality of this atrocious spectacle is the laughs. Unfortunately, the comedy is unintentional. The show basically consists of creepy, broken cardboard dolls being blindly flailed across the surface of stagnant, dirty water for an hour. The "stories" are virtually incomprehensible - a series of nightmarish vignettes loosely choreographed to Vietnamese screeching. Even the performers look embarrassed to be associated with this disaster... behind their lifeless eyes you can almost hear them weighing the pros and cons of drowning themselves just to end the agony a little bit earlier. I considered this as well. As for the other reviews that actually recommend this experience, I'm at a complete loss for an explanation. Unless you're some kind of water puppet masochist, you're better off crossing the street to mingle with the locals and watch the sunset over Hoan Kiem Lake. Or drowning yourself.

Potentially a great cultural experience.. The Thang Long Water Puppet Theatre continues an ancient tradition that uses puppets to tell cultural tales of the lives of farmers and peasants who live along the water. The music was good, the stories were interesting, though like everything in Vietnam there is a strong pro-communist message built in. We went to the 9:20 show and I was a little disappointed. The music was great but the puppets were old, some broken, and most in need of some TLC and a paint job. What bohered me most is that this was supposed to be the International troupe who travelled the world performing in dozens of countries. What I saw was sloppy puppeteering, with puppets sometimes 3/4 submerged in water, moving out of time, or not moving when they were supposed to. It is possible it was just an off night but I suppose if you figure these guys put on six 45 minute shows a day, 7 days a week and we saw the last show of the night, I guess its to be expected.The Thang Long Water Puppet Theatre is worth a visit if you're in Hanoi and for $5 its worth it but I would think I would have been more entertained by a local water puppet show somewhere else in Vietnam.
Fun to watch but not amazing.. it was quite good, but very touristy. stories depict like in viet nam

puppet theatre. well worth a visit-All up it only takes an hour and probably seen once, you will never need to go again. Trying to ring and book tickets or even talk to someone is impossible so take pot luck and go to the ticket office in the morning and book and pay for your tickets. Good fun though-you will enjoy it.
Interesting. Family of 3 really enjoyed this but you must get seat close to the front.

How to end a hot day. If you're in Hanoi during the hot months, going to the water puppet theater is a wonderful way to cool down after a day of street shopping around the lake. Beautiful music produced by a traditional Vietnamese orchestra accompanies a colorful show that visualizes ancient Vietnamese culture and literature.

At least it is AIR-CONDITIONED!. After all the reviews and hype, I was disappointed with the Water Puppet show. I guess it's just "one of those things you have to do in Hanoi"! A lot of people were asleep in the cool, dark theatre. They have no rules regarding photography, so annoying flashes were going off all the time. The music is good - but no part of the show is in English, so if you take kids, be warned they will have a hard time following the skits.Cute and original - but for your own enjoyment, work very hard to get a seat as close to the front as possible for the best view.

So, So Puppet Show (sorry!). I admit that I'm not a great puppet fan but we went to see the show. Unfortunately it lived up to my expectations- the sets were very squashed so it was good that the show only lasted 50 minutes. The puppets were clever I suppose but very uninspiring and the feeble applause at the end by the audience summed up the general feeling of most people there.PS- don't be conned into paying for a 'take photo's' ticket- unless you have a really good camera or have a front row seat its virtually impossible!

fun way to spend an hour. myself and my wife enjoyed visiting the water puppets show in hanoi. the show was entertaining and at 40 minutes it is just the right amount of time. don't listen to negative reviews as it is a cheap and fun way to spend an hour in hanoi.

very interseting. This was the first time we saw an interesting show. The artists were skillful and everything would be magic and amazing by their hands. We enjoyed the whole show and wish to come back one day.

Read up on water puppetry before you go. Very interesting and entertaining but voice over is in Vietnamese so to understand what's going on read up beforehand on water puppetry and the stories/myths. Unless you speak Vietnamese of course. Brilliant performers .. what a skill .. and the highlight was unexpectedly the đàn bầu instrument musical solo.

Expected More... This was one of the things we were most looking forward to on our visit to Hanoi but have to say that the music was the best thing, the story fairly easy to follow but we enjoyed the music more. 5 people in our row were asleep!! It's about 40 mins long so should just about hold children's attention,having said that there were plenty of restless kids last night.Buy your tickets at the venue not from and agent......

Enjoyable show. For the price we paid, it was quiet an entertaining show. It was fun to watch and we didnt regret it. We really enjoyed and if you have kids, it's a complete must when you visit Hanoi. Choose the seats though, view could be limited depending on the height of people in front of you.
Great fun!. We really enjoyed this show with its clever puppetry and sense of humour. The accompanying traditional music orchestra and singing was an added bonus
wonderful. It was so good to see something that is almost a lost art and the shows are brilliant.
Interesting. Fun cultural experience. The history of the show is interesting, for an American, Asian audiences are a fascinating experience. I am not sure which I found more entertaining.
Fantastic. Very skillful artists, humorus, no need for interpreters

Easy show to fit into the schedule. The show at the puppet theater is entertaining and just long enough to maintain my interest. I think each show is 1/2 hour. For me, the đàn bầu was one of the highlights of the show. This is the musical instrument that is prominently featured throughout the show. Even considered buying a small one.

Worth attending a performance. Water puppet theatre is very Vietnamese (a thousand year old performance art). This 45-minute performance shares myths and legends and gives insights into daily life in Vietnam (ie. rice planting). Performance is accompanied by musicians and Vietnamese singers (who likely relate the stories acted out by the water puppets) but you don't need to understand the singers to understand what is transpiring or to appreciate the skill necessary to manipulate these substantial puppets on under water 10 to 13 foot bamboo rods. Theater is directly across the road from Hoan Kiem Lake in the Old Quarter so easy to find. We stayed at the Sofitel Metropole on Ngo Quyen and it was an easy 10 minute walk.

Unique cultural show. I lived in Hanoi for 10 months and it took me that long to actually get into this show. I checked every time I was in town and they were always sold out. I finally caught it a few nights before I left. The ticket saleswoman was rude practically every time I was there. The show itself however, was fairly entertaining. Not for thrillseekers, but those interested in culture will enjoy. The show is entirely in Vietnamese (with exception of the introduction), but an interesting cultural relic of Vietnamese culture. If you are visiting the museum of ethnology, they perform a water puppet show there as well which is included in your ticket price and doesn't require you to stay through the entire hour show. Right now the prices are 100,000 VND for 1st class (the front rows) and 60,000 for 2nd class (everywhere else). There is an additional charge to use video recorders. Maybe for cameras as well, I didn't have mine with me, so I didn't check. Sorry.

"Puppet sleep maker". We went after seeing the reviews on trip advisor and walked out wondering whether other reviewers had seen a different show.The puppets moved awkwardly, when they were supposed to be beating drums they just looked like they were waving their arms in the air with drumsticks. They were not in sync, with some puppets moving a second too late each time and you could see the arm of the performer behind the curtain and the storylines were lame. We sat in the second row and could see people in the front row nodding off because it was so boring. Since the puppets are so simplistic and unsophisticated, they could have made better use of special effects and lighting but didn't. I think primary school students could have done a better job. After seeing the show, their claim that they had performed internationally was unbelievable. The only saving grace of the show was a lady playing a unique one stringed instrument with amazing sounds. But... please don't waste your $5 seeing this show. You won't be missing out AT ALL.

Unique. This was a unique performance that has more visual appeal than anything else. This was the only place in all of Vietnam where air conditioning was on full blast; I was freezing through the entire performance.
Water puppets. Don't believe people when they say you have to see it. Terrible! It was boring and very hard to know what the dickens was going on!

Not to be missed (though...). This one hour show is the most popular attraction in town. Worth seing (as it's not too long) and do buy your tickets pn the spot and not throu a travel agency, as prices won't be the same... Just remember that they a quite a few shows a day and the 6 pm, most popular as people eat early, needs to be booked at least a day ahead of time

Great fun. This was my third visit to Hanoi and have attended the Water Puppet Theater each time --- it is great fun and over the course of time I have collected a variety of puppets used for these uniquely Vietnamese performances.

A great show... The Thang Long Water puppets are one of Hanoi's major tourist attractions and as a result the place is always crowded with groups coming and going.. the show is noisy but good and the skill of the puppeters is well well worth seeing and a great way to spend an hour.
MUST DO. it is nice but a little bit too long , almost 1.5 hrs, it is a long time

Enjoyed the performance itself.... This was interesting and a must see, if you can't get to the ethnology museum to view a more authentic version situated in a pond but only on weekends. i could not appreciate the music thought but I am not complaining as the tickets are inexpensive and provides a reprieve from the oppressive heat.

Lovely, vibrant and interesting. I had seen the Thang Long Water Puppet Theatre on TV shows but am happy we watched a performance. The show was lovely, vibrant and an interesting insight into Vietnamese culture. Yes, all speaking is in Vietnamese but we found where ever we travelled this was the case. I think this is a nice display of the pride Vietnamese people have. The performance programme is available in many languages and therefore easy to compare the show to the programme. We arrived a few minutes late but were very fortunate to receive 2 seats in the centre of the front row. In hindsight the late arrival may have been good as we missed all the bus loads being dropped off and organised. I found the performance delightful and appreciate we were able to take photos. Entry fee is minimal and you pay a little bit more to take photographs or film the show. Particularly great place to visit if travelling with children.
Good fun. Me thinks the Vietnamese have a quirky sense of humour and you would agree if you see the Water Puppet Theater. It is a must see.

Puppet Show. We enjoyed the performance but I was not entirely comfortable as the theatre seating is not really designed for tall people with long legs. I am 190cm tall & spent the entire performance seated with my legs spread very wide so as not to have my knees up beside the ears of the lady seated in front of me.

Included in tour. I went to the Water Puppets as it was included in our tour. I suppose it was good to experience it but quite honestly I nearly fell asleep. It was interesting for a while but did go on a bit and seeing as it's in Vietnamese it's difficult to understand what's going on. Seems like an important part of the culture but I think it was probably set up to entertain children and young children at that! If you're short on time there are far better things to do in Hanoi.

Traditional, brief. It was fun to learn more about the history of the water puppet theatre and how it fits into the national culture. Theatre was cramped, power went out once, and it's hard to follow along if you didn't read through the program first. You should go for the experience and history, but it's not *that* exciting.
Suprisingly short. This seemed very touristy - the show was fun but it only lasted 45 minutes which seemed very short.

memorable last night in Hanoi. Our last night in Hanoi couldn't have been better than this. Our guide had purchased for us the front row seats, making the show a lot more enjoyable. The simple yet fun dramatic stories were nice to watch. The duration is perfect (around 40 minutes) and the musicians do their job very well.

Don't miss this. Great entertainment. Best seats, and only seats for photography are the front row. If you can, ensure your travel agent insists upon fron row seats, even if your have to wait. It's really well done, great lounge out the front also.

Lame. Advertised as one of the must-see cultural highlights of a visit to Ha Noi - I found it to be way way too long, seats built for small pert Viet bottoms, and the condition of the stage wet-set and the water puppets was uhhh 'vintage' at best. Go if you must but we found it to be a rather painful exercise.

Very Entertaining. Bright, colorful, entertaining show with traditional music played by musicians on traditional instruments. It's a small, crowded theater, but there really are no bad seats. They charge $1 to take pictures. A must see in Vietnam.

Very impressive performance, shame we couldn't understand a word. The performance was technically excellent but the singing and narration was all in Vietnamese which detracted somewhat from the overall enjoyment.

Definitely add to your 'to do' list. Situated at the top end of the lake, I recommend booking our tickets early in the morning for an evening session. Venue is air conditioned and seats comfortable but you will struggle if over six feet tall - I am 6'5" and had no hope. There are fold down seats along the side they will let you use if this is the case. Performance is very entertaining, lasts for 45 min to an hour.

Short show--good fun.. We enjoyed the simple traditional Vietnamese stories as presented by the puppeteers. Lots of laughs and great puppeteer performance. How do they do that stuff with the dragons, the fish, the fisherman, and the phoenix.The performance of traditional Vietnamese music and singing was also excellent.All in all, a good time was had by all.
Water puppet show. Was cheap, entertaining and unusual but don't expect too much

Baffling - in a good way!. I loved this. It was short and sweet, at only an hour long. The music is excellent. I understood about half of the stories, although the ones I didn't get were probably more entertaining for it! It doesn't cost much to see this, and it's something that you won't find anywhere else!

Kids would love it, but we enjoyed it too. We went to the 3.30pm show which also got us out of the heat for an hour. Really fun, light entertainment. Kids would love it. We enjoyed it for the traditional music, costumes and the puppet show was well done.
Fun to watch but not amazing.. It was fun to watch but it wasnt amazing. if you are there for a few day then check it out. but if you are press for time and dont go you are not missing out on much.
Interesting. The music was terrific. The musicians play traditional instruments. The water puppet show is fun and unique to Hanoi. Don't expect too much and you won't be disappointed.

Highly entertaining. We thoroughly enjoyed watching this show. The dialogue was in Vietnamese but the introductions had English and French translations. The theater also provided small leaflets in English, French, Korean and Japanese, which you can grab right outside the hall. They were helpful in making sure you can follow along.The presentation started with some Vietnamese music played on traditional instruments. Then moved on to show Vietnamese life through the colorful dancing puppets, which were highly amusing.A tourist trap? Perhaps, but since it only costs $5 (for the first class tickets, cheaper for the normal one), it really doesn't matter. Just go see the show and get a taste of Vietnamese tradition and culture in an entertaining setting.
good. Went and watched the show. Was okay in parts but pleased we went as was good.

unique. I am not a fan of puppets, not even water puppets, but I enjoyed the show. I also think it is interesting to learn about this tradition. It is part of their history and something unique, so for the price and to do something different and more relaxing in the evening, it might be worth checking it out.

Delightful. I enjoyed this presentation. It lasts for 50 minutes, begins with a Vietnamese orchestra including some traditional instruments. A small pamphlet is available at the door which you should read before you watch the performance as it explains what aspect each of the short scenes depicts, although it isn't too difficult to guess. It is a colorful show, the puppets are delightful and the puppeteers, skilled. The ideas represent simple village life where water puppets were traditionally performed in rice fields. I have been surprised by some negative comments on this forum, it is only a puppet show! But a delightful one in my opinion.
Very entertaining. I was skeptical about this as I'm often not a fan of the obvious tourist attractions but it was really entertaining.

Traditional drama of Viet nam. Water puppet is one kind of Vietnam traditional art. I have a great passion for traditional art of Vietnam so I came to see this show first when I took my city tour in Hanoi with Minmax travel company. There were many tourists at the theater. The tickets for the show are often sold out so it is better that you buy in advance. It lasted 50 minutes and I found it very relaxing. The theater is located near Hoan Kiem Lake so after the show i walk around the lake for the fresh air/ Wonderful traditional art. Nice theater and I will be back for another show.

I do not understand Vietnamese. I almost fall sleep when watching the Water Puppet Show as they do not have any screen to show subtitle in other language, i do not understand Vietnamese and i feel extremely bore.

Suprised. I have never seen a kind of puppet show or something like that. It's quite interesting and attractive. Lovely portrayal of the water puppets and vietnamese history. The show included music and bunch of cute little puppets dancing and jumping around on water. You will be charged if you want to take pictures or video. See it if you want to get about this kind of puppet.
another art. it is a must to see it if you are in Hanoi. Music and the show are realy great.

People too enthusiastic about puppets. I may have enjoyed this show if it wasn't that as soon as it started, almost everyone in the theatre decided it'd be appropriate to lean forward and/or stand. I spent the entire performance moving this way and that to actually see what was going on.You are given seats to sit in. I don't understand why people thought it would be appropriate to obscure the view for those behind them when they had a fine view of the stage themselves. It was a poor experience all around.
A once only visit. Too long even at 45 mins, air conditioning was the only plus on a very hot evening

Little glimp of Vietname culture. It's definitly a tourist trap, but it sure does give you an impression of Vietnamese culture with live music and beautifull water puppets. Just don't expact a spectacular show and you'll have a wonderfull experience (of 50 minutes) which gives you an idea of a puppet show in the rice paddies. Note: if you want to make pictures or videos they charge you extra when entering the theater. Guards are present in the theater, but I did not see them checking the tickets...
Not a must. The performance itself was pretty good, but often not easy to follow. Also the seats really close together so if you're over 5ft 9 or so (and I'm 6ft 2) you'll be very uncomfortable!

Great for the kids and music. This was a great way to take a break from the hot summer sun, we booked in advance to avoid all the tourists and there was lots!Try get a front row seat its so much better.

Worth Seeing. We enjoyed this, though we're not sure the extra money we paid for better seats really got us anything. Shows run frequently each afternoon. We walked up a few minutes before the 3:00 show and bought three tickets. The music was too loud for me, but the puppets are wonderful, and it's a nice break if you've been walking around all day.

Water Puppet. The show started on time and there was english and french translation of the introduction. The show was all in local language but the puppet performance was easy to understand. The theater seats has small leg room and there is difficulty in seating.

A must for everyone who visits Hanoi. You cannot book online for this you have to front up to the theatre to get tickets. No one told us this so the day we wanted to go was booked out when we arrived, but no big deal we got tickets for the following day.
Some thing different. Considering I never saw any thing like it, it was worth while to see once, but I don't think I would go again.
Water Puppets are tops. This is a top show and you must see it when you visit Hanoi
Worth the money. Would have been better if there was a translator as everything was in Vietnamese and the info provided was too brief

Best Show is Town...!!. This is the best show in town...and for VND$100,000 (first class) or VND$60,000 (Second Class) tickets, the show is a real bargin. The show will delight, inspire, and allow you to appreciate Vietnam's cultural arts.

Choose your seat carefully. Great show, amazing music and singing. Suggest you sit either in the front row (if you wish to take photos) or near the back to avoid having cameras (and their flashes) interrupt your enjoyment.
Pretty fun. Although it's all in Vietnamese, we laughed with (and at) this performance. The show is only 45 minutes long and the ticket is cheap so give it a try!
Shouldn't Miss. A fun filled hour! The music is wonderful, the puppets are fun and the theater is interesting. Worth the time and entertaining!

For a puppet fan, probably a must - otherwise not quite, but still entertaining. We visited the water puppet theather on our holiday in Hanoi with my husband as this had been mentioned in various places to be "must see" attraction.I'm not specifically a puppet fan, so I cannot speak on their mouths, but for me this was a bit foolish and quite simple show. Stories were not really for children, but the performance otherwise maybe more on childish side. Some funny parts (jokes) that made it entertaining, but I would not say that you loose much if you don't go.On the other hand the tickets were 100 000 VND, so roughly 4 Euro so it was not a big investment either.

Something everyone should see, very clever. Very cleverly done, just long enough as you can't understand
anything, but worth a visit.

The only one's (I know of) in the world. Water puppets are still a feature of Vietnamese village life and there are special ponds in many villages especially for their performances. However, apart from occasional performances at the Museum of Ethnology, the only place you will see them in action in Hanoi is here.
A must for a visitor to Hanoi.

Worth Visiting But Only If You Have Time. A fun show with traditional music being played and sang live. The puppets are basic in their movements, but really make the story come to life. The show is only 11 scenes in length and about 1 hour in length. If you are limited in time for Hanoi then I wouldn't make this your first priority, however it's something fun to do to fill your extra time.

Better than it sounds. We were a little skeptical at first but it was really entertaining, and cleverly done. Not too long to become a drag we were really glad we went. If you are not sure I definately recommend giving it go!

Punch & Judy on water with horrendous sound. I know these things are often a matter of taste, so this might well prove that I don't have any, but ........I walked out, it was that good.A naff production of Punch & Judy on water to an accompaniment of extremely loud noise (cannot call it music, but some did), with overtones of 3rd rate moral stories.

Not a must see. Unless you are a puppet fanatic, you can skip this attraction. This is a very simple puppet show. We were a group of ten and only one person managed to not fall asleep. Could have done without.
A cultural experience. The water puppet show was excellent. It gives you a taste of the culture of vietnam. I am glad we had a chance to see it
A must see just for the local experience. the play is in the old theater, the puppet show is entertaining about an hour long, try to come a little early to sit closest to the stage for a better show.

Maybe Unique but Not Impressive. Water puppet theater may be unique to Vietnam, but at least what we got to see here was not impressive. Basically, you got wooden puppets, held on sticks from behind a curtain, flailing--more or less rhythmically--around in a pool. At least the show is mercifully short (45 minutes).Beware the taxi touts outside the theater!

A very entertaining 45 minutes. This show is a must see when visiting Hanoi. It is an amusing and clever insight into some aspects of this fascinating culture and the skills of the puppeteers are amazing.
Interesting Artform. Was memorised by the puppeteers work here. Definitely worth a viewing.

Beautiful and very funny theatre. This kind of theatre is for people from Europe or USA very exotic and a little bit amazing. The play is with live music (asian instruments, very special), the puppets move in the water and it looks very nice...there are 11 parts of play that describe the life in a village, fishing, buffalos, working in the rice fields... I didn't see anything like this... You have to see and listen, If you will be in Hanoi. The cheap ticket costs 3 dollars.
Mixed feelings on this one.. I admired the puppeteers' craft, but my husband found the music too discordant for his western tastes!

Stunning. A small and intimate theatre allows you to see a terrific show. The various 'stories' told by the puppets are easy to follow and the physical strength of the puppeteers is most impressive. A really engaging evening's entertainment.

A MUST - A See. I have seen this, I have witnessed the way all the wooden puppet got moved! It is all terrific and the excellent guide who can explain to us clearly all the actions and its meaning made me understand all the content better even it was played in Vietnamese!

no idea why it is a 'MUST'. After hearing that it is a 'must' and reading some of the reviews I was sure that I am going to see somthing like "Cirque du Soleil". Unfortunatly we got to watch a puppet show from the beginning of the previous century. I don't care about the fee but could have slept better in my hotel room.
A must see. Very clever and entertaining. Great value for money for a quick culture injection.
Puppet Theatre a must. This is a tradition in Hanoi and well worth seeing. It is a production easy to follow and we would recommend it

What started off well went down hill fast. The price was right but the length was way too long. I think it went for about 15 songs that went out of their way to put you to sleep and all sounded the same. It would have been better if it was only a couple of songs. The guy next to me even said his brother had been and said not to go but he did anyway, he wished he didn't. Maybe ok for very young children and go early in the day when you are more awake

I expected to be bored - far from it!. I was actually not too keen on this. Since this was largely in the Vietnamese Language I thought it is going to be a bit boring. We had some time to kill before we got on the night train to Sapa and this was an excellent. It was very different to any puppet show I had seen before. Very skillfully done. Attractive, colorful costumes. Well worth it. You need to purchase your tickets early. Our agent did for us. I think the hotel would also do it. Don’t bother with the restaurant downstairs - food is pricey and nothing to write home about.
Wow!. I was skeptical but right at the start of the show it is evident how/why this is a respected art form. It lives up to the hype. Good musicians too.
It's unique. Only in vietnam and this one is the largest. Well worth the entry fee this is good entertainment and great skill.
Entertaining. An entertaining show for about 45 minutes; a part of the Vietnamese Culture.

Cute!. It's a one hour long show for just $5 for front-row seats, $3 for middle seats, $1.50 for video, $1 for camera! Yeah, the ticket sales lady is rude and ignores you when you walk by. She also doesn't like it when foreigners buy the cheaper tickets (like we did) but they are really all great seats! The show included music and a bunch of cute little puppets dancing and jumping around on water. A few were funny and others were boring.
Okay if you get a good seat. Worth it but long and hard to see if you are not near the front.

A must - see when in Hanoi. This was a lively show and a great cultural experience. Very popular with tourists and locals alike. Always a long queue for tickets but the queue moves quickly and we had good seats. Extremely good value for a few US dollars only.
nice to see. it was nice to see and now that i have seen it it isn't a thing i would go back to again.

Beyond My Expectations. A professor from my university invited me to see this, and he even sent an article about it in advanced. I am never one for puppets, magicians, clowns, etc. so I had low expectations for what this would be like.In three words: It. Was. Fantastic.Seriously, the talent and coordination that goes into the puppetry and story telling was amazing. I was totally engaged and videoing it as much as possible. The stories were adorable and so well done. Any age could appreciate this special cultural feature.

This was so beautiful. The history of the fields explained with music and the wonderful wooden puppets. The live singing and instruments adds to the atmosphere. Very clever. Air conditioned theatre also.

Worth a visit. Worth a visit if you are in hanoi for a evening. There are 5 shows a day so it's easy to fit into any plans. The show is a number of 3-5 minute acts with different puppets, 50 minutes total. It's 100,000 dong per person, 20,000 dong to take photos. I don't know if it's worth paying to take photos since it is incredibly dark. The people in front of us were taking photos the entire time and it looked like they all came our blurry. A cute performance which entertained us for the less than 50 minute. Don't expect cirque du soliel quality but for the price, we felt it was worth our time and money.

Wonderful. What a gem the theatre is. As I looked around the faces in the crowd there were smiles everywhere, a lovely portrayal of the water puppets and vietnamese history. Don't forget to pick up the programme by the door as most the narration is done in Vietnamese.
very clever. get a seat in the front if you can. the thearter is very unique and worth the visit
historic and cultural. A glimpse of old Vietnamese cultural past. The show is in Vietnamese language but despite that a very pleasant experience.

Boring and uninspiring. The 1 string instrument was amazing and the music interesting. However, the actual puppet show was kinda boring and not very exciting. It was in Vietnamese so it was even harder to understand.
It was only S$5 so it was alright, I can't imagine paying anything more for it. Don't waste your time here.
Very enjoyable!. Very fascinating and thoroughly enjoyable. tickets are available days in advanced and sell out very quickly. Tickets for Sunday morning show are 40% cheaper for children.
water puppets. W hile it was quite "cute" it certainly went on a bit and was definitely not a must do.

Worth a Visit. The water puppet theatre was worth the visit, but all the dialogue was in Vietnames. There was however some beautiful Dan Bow playing by a lady member of the orchestra. It was also worth paying $3 for the top seats
Worth seeing. Very obviously aimed at tourists but well organised and fun to go to. Do be aware that there appears to be a charge for taking photos/videoing the show. Well worth seeing though.

Enjoyable experience. Nice show and music, worth to see if you are in Hanoi, and definitively worth the $5 you pay for the show. We were on the 5th row so quite close to the water with quite a good view and close to the musician on the left side of the stage. They apparently charge at the entrance if you want to take pictures or videos inside, I didn't pay nor took pictures, and I am not sure how they can control this once the show has started, as it seems almost everyone was taking pictures anyway. The only downside is that the seats are quite small and not much space for your legs, so if you are overweight or claustrophobic, this place is not for you... and don't come late, my wife and I thought it was a good idea to let people in before us, only to have our entire row have to stand up to let us go to our seats.

Beautiful but uncomfortable. The water puppet theater is really a must-see in Hanoi. The music was beautiful and the performance was quite interesting. I couldn't fully enjoy it though - my legs were too long (I'm about 5'10") and I literally could not move throughout the performance. Despite the discomfort, the experience was well worth it.
Dont bother. Not sure why so many tourists go this - not sure why we went either. Thought our 11 yr old would enjoy it - he was bored to tears too!!

I loved the dancing coconuts!. Few people appreciate the Water Puppet Theatre but it is a slice of life of the Vietnamese. It floods for 4 to 6 months in some parts of Vietnam and in rural Hanoi and the Puppet Theater was born from that condition. Watch it!
