The skillful puppetry can be seen but you know it is hard because the puppeteers are partially submerged in water. I particularly loved the dancing coconuts.
Music is Good. Kind of "cheesy" fun! The music is what I enjoyed the most! I was surprised that the theater was pretty large.
Must see experience.. Great show but be prepared for sore knees as there is very little room between the rows of seats. Try to get seats as close to the front as possible if you want to take photos.

A good fun. This is quite an interesting show, around one hour The scenes are quite funny, and the setting is original. Quite cheap, too.You do not have to reserve in advance, except if you want to sit close to the water (no risk getting wet). So this will not take too much of your time especially if you are around Hoam Kiem lake.The program can change from time to time.

Fun. We found this to be a fun experience. The local, live music and the puppets were entertaining. The show is made up of about a dzoen short skits. Each one not lasting long. The show lasts for about 50 minutes.We found there was not much leg room, and the people in front of us were leaning forward, partially obstructing our view, the distance between rows in minimal. And these were "first-class" tickets. Even five rows from the front there were times when we could not see the 'stage'.I was pleased that we went for the glimpse into Vietnamese culture.
More than just puppets. An enjoyable evening. The water puppets were very good, but the musical performance which accompanied the show were excellent. Highly recommended

Tourist trap. Water puppet show was interesting, but we were pretty ready to get out of there by the end. The show lasts about 50 minutes. We also got ripped off into buying "First Class" tickets, and once we were in the theatre we had no clue as to how our seats could have been "first class." They were right on the aisle in the middle section of the theatre, and the people next to us probably had the normal price tickets.

Didnt mean to go!. We had decided to give it a miss then finding ourselves outside with no plans for the evening purchased 2 first class tickets. The seats are designed for Vietnamese children and my wife and I had to contort ourselves to get into them and sit down (there are some ordinary chairs you can move to in the side aisles if you are quick enough).The programme was quite entertaining and overall we enjoyed this unique entertainment. Would I go again? Never!

really?. I know this is a traditional Vietnamese art form but it's really cheesey. At least for those of us in our mid-30's. Probably fun for kids. I did enjoy the live music. Might be worth the $3 entry if you have an afternoon to kill or it's raining out, otherwise skip it.

Fun experience!. Cute performance with wonderful music! Only about $5, so it is cheap entertainment. Theatre is right in the center of town and very easy to find. Go early in the day to get tickets as the shows seem to sell out fairly quick. Musicians are absolutely fantastic! The puppet part of the show is extremely well done. Highly reccomend this excellent look back at early Vietnamese culture!
Pretty amatureish. not too keen on this one. Was a bit amateurish. You could see the puppeteers behind the curtain .Just not our cup of tea.
if you have nothing else to do. not in english and very childish very repetetive and boring
Too loud. Seemed very entertaining but we were forced to walk out after 10 min because the it was so loud we needed to cover our ears

Total waste of time. On a recent trip to Hanoi, my husband and I were torn about whether to see this show but decided to give it a try, based on a few favourable reviews.We've since decided we should trust our instincts. The best part about the show is the fact it is only 45 minutes long and only costs $3. But, oh dear, I really can't see how anyone could find this tedious display of puppetry anything other than boring. I have to admit, I don't much care for puppets at the best of times. But this show seemed a little pathetic for a country which has so much to offer in other areas. Compared to some of the incredible cultural experiences we've seen in Thailand (Siam Niramit) and Cambodia (Children of Bassac apsara dancing), this was a total yawn.
Must See. Excellent traditional music & crafty traditional water puppet show.

It's different!. It's worth going to see this show, as it is an original art-form. Some of the scenes are quite entertaining, and it's not obvious how they manage to move the puppets. The show lasts about 45 minutes, which is enough. If you are tall sit in the front row, or get an aisle seat, as there is very little leg room.

The puppets are superb. The puppets themselves are superb and some of the stories are really well told. This wasn't everybody's cup of tea - but the show doesn't last long - so give it a go for an evenings entertainment!
Best water puppet show in Hanoi. Beautiful water puppets, good perfermance, good seating. Appropriate length of performance time.

About as much fun as you can have with water and puppets. Well you have to visit it, and it is a fun and pleasant albeit touristy, show. Fellow tourists videoing and flashing away with their cameras were an unwelcome element of the show. They should ban cameras altogether. Sit in the more expensive seats near the front.
Fantastic. As a first time, or even multiple timer, go see the Water Puppets. The show was fantastic.
Great show. Well worth watching. A fabulous colourful vision. Great old fahioned entertainment.

Entertaining. Loved it. It was recommended to me by friends earlier. It was 100,000dong a ticket. I had slipped into being a child and amazed by the show. Its very simple yet impressive. Totally worth it!

60k for a little entertainment. Not a bad price to get yourself a nice evening entertainment. I was told this is a VERY TOURISTY thing to do but I was bored and don't feel like being in the crazy traffic. I find it pretty amusing though, even though I do not really understand most of it.

Go, don't miss it. It's hard to follow the story but it's based upon VN folklore, however, the puppets are excellent and it's very clever how they operate them all, well worth a trip. HOWEVER, don't pay the VND100,000 (US$5) for a first class seat unless you're guaranteed a seat in the first 5 rows. Pay the VND60,000 for a 2nd class seat. You can still see and hear everything.

JUST BAD!!. BORING and LAME!!!!! It may be cheap but you are crowded in seats with no leg room and a bunch of puppets moving in water. The only redeeming thing was the musicians. Don't waste your time or money!

A real cultural treat. We didn't know if this would be up our street or not but we were really amazed by the puppeteers skills. The musicians are also clearly greatly talented. The show is about 45 minutes, it's a great spectacle and also quite funny - shame to miss it really.

Dreadful... and expensive!. As this show was sold out pretty much our entire stay, we decided to buy a ticket as it MUST be good.Oh dear... the ticket alone was 60,000VND for 2nd class and 100,000VND for 1st. The seating area is so small it really does not make any difference... pay the 60,000!The show was very un organised. Puppets were not in time, or were half out the water, some nearly drowning. It really is an eye opener to how far behind Vietnam is from parts of the world

Its compulsory, believe me. The water puppet theatre seats about 350 in a regular theatre environment - raked auditorium and what would be a conventional stage. The stage is a big water tank with a set which is a Confucian temple at back and above on an upper level. The band and singers are up in a wing, but in traditional dress and very much part of the show; the structure is like a chinese opera with lots of plucked instruments and percussion, flutes and a lot of wailing.The puppets enter in the water from the back and the sides, through slits in screens.The puppeteers are behind the screens up to their waists in the water so you can't see them, and they use long rods under the water to manipulate the puppets.There are men and women puppets, animals, small fish, big fish, water snakes and dragons.All in all its a first-class experience for less than $5

Good experience for the price. Our famiy of 5 with two teenagers enjoyed the cultural experience of the live music and seeing what a water puppet theater is since we had no idea. You can reserve your seats ahead of time although we lucked into the last 5 seats 10 minutes before the show.

Music and Theatre. A wonderful hour of music and puppet theatre. Book ahead if you want the popular time slot (late afternoon or evening). Read about the several different plays beforehand so you understand better what's going on.

A wonderful spectacle. This is one of the least expensive artistic performances I have ever attended, only $5, and boy is it worth seeing! A wonderful spectacle, the puppeteers are excellent and the live music a pleasure. Do not miss this one. Go early as tickets sell out FAST.

Fun experience. People were grumbling prior to the performance but it was lovely. The music and singing were a perfect accompaniment to the puppets in the water.
A must-see if you are in Hanoi.

Not sure what to make of it. It's clear that there's a lot of skill involved in the music and presentation of the puppets, but without an understanding of what the story or background is the show is merely puppets jumping around in the water with accompanying music. Maybe if there was a background talk for non-Vietnamese people before the show to explain the origins of the show and the scenes it would have been much better. But this is traditional Vietnamese theatre and I am a visitor, so it's their game and their rules, can't argue with that.
good for kids. It's a fine thing to take children to but I was a little underwhelmed
such fun. very clever, funny and just the right timing of one hour

A must see in Hanoi. This is a must-see attraction when you come to Hanoi.The theatre is quite small and it is arguable whether it is worth paying for the higher priced ticket (100,000vnd) or the cheaper one (possibly 60,000?). We paid for the higher priced ticket and were halfway back and I reckon the view in the back row may have been just as good.Although there was a brief English and French introduction, as the show progressed there was no explanation of each of the scenes, so it was left purely to our own imagination to interpret what was being acted out. It was worthwhile seeing the show.Tip: Head to the theatre at least one day ahead to book and pay for your ticket as the show times sell out well ahead of time. (We noticed that some show times had sold out three days prior!).

A must see. Traditional water puppetry is only seen in Vietnam and I have been several times over the last 6 years. Its a shame that the show doesn't change much, and it is better to see it in a village situation but the Hanoi show is cheap and a must see while you are there
Unique. Very interesting and different but the seats were sooo small, my husband's knees were in his chest the whole performance!
great show skillful, only 45mins a show and its busy. nice to see, must book in advance as it can be booked upto 4 or 5 days

Show is worth an experience but lack of passion. If you never been to a water puppet show, it's worth the experience. However, is the performance exceptional enough to blow your mind? Probably not. Still worth it if your curious for a must see...
Great afternoon/evening!. This was entertaining, with live music, singing and of course the water puppets! A great price and a good few hours for all!

Fun way to spend an hour. This is really authentic and a bit of fun. Really quaint theater and only $5 for a good ticket. The show portrays traditional ways of life in Vietnam and it's not like any puppet show I've seen - all the puppets are on water.
Well worth a visit.

Impressive and funny. We really liked the show. Even with no knowledge to Vietnamese culture and language it was quite fun. The artistry and technique is impressive, and the show is full of speed, colors and sounds.

What just happened?. This was undoubtledly very traditional and interesting to watch but my husband and I just kept looking at each other in a "whats going on" way throughout it. Some of the instruments were very well played but the theatre, I really just didn't get. Enjoyed looking at the puppets etc but after 10 mins I was ready to leave!

When in Rome. Although the show is in Vietnamese, the water puppets are amazing to watch. The music and the performers are very talented. Get the VIP seats, and purchase directly from the theater. You can get better availability that way!

Nothing to write home about but fun to watch. It's only 40 minutes long and a few people left disappointed but as long as you don't set your expectations too high then you'll enjoy it. It was the first thing we did in Hanoi and we are glad we did that first. Don't be concerned about tickets selling out fast (unless it's a Friday or Saturday night), we arrived at 7:00 and got tickets for the 9:15 show.
Poor show just tourist trap. Show lasts about 50 mins and was in my opinion a poor show and was disappointed with whole show. Place is a sell out for every show I just dont understand why

ok if you like tradition, but don't expect too much entertainment. if you value tradition then I guess you should see this show, however if you are looking for pure entertainment then you may want to look for it elsewhere.The show is ok, but I can't say I was thrilled. I viewed it as a cultural experience only.
Good for visit. I sure after you look show, you will feel happy and it is very funny . Thus, i can not understand everything but i like it so much
Not just for kids. You'll be surprised.... for the cost of a cup of coffee, why not have a look!

Short and sweet. Interesting but not fantastic. Nice little orchestra with unusual instruments.
Lasts about 45min and costs about $5. Would be boring if longer than that.

Interesting. Bought the VIP ticket at 100,000 dong which is well worth it for closer view. Show lasts for an hour and there's a coffee place downstairs if you would like to have a coffee before the show, expect the coffee to cost about 60,000 though. Bathroom on Level 1 is clean too, needs to climb a flight of stairs to reach the theatre on Level 2. Realised many actually moved to the empty VIP seats when the door is closed.

disappointing -- just for the tourists. This is all for the tourists. Not sure I would recommend it -- better to have a beer and some street grub. If you do go, get a seat near the front so that you can see everything. Book ahead -- it sells out as tourists are brought in by the bus-load.
Adult fun for the young at heart. I could not imagine what this would be like. It however turned into a mesmerizing show of skill and co-ordination. Don't miss it.
More for children. Have low expectations and the program might be amusing. Best part os the orchastra.
Great Fun!. Loved the water puppet theater, a must see! Buy tix early and get VIP so you can really see well!

Sweet Music. I was thrilled by the music ( though sounded exotic, could relate it to the Indian classic music influence in them) and also the methodic performance of the artists ( puppets are the real artists, though).. It was a short 50 minute show, and during holidays is an advance sell-out... We were lucky to have been denied a ticket, but the tentativeness helped, soon a group tickets got cancelled and was called out to buy... If not, we would have missed a nice opportunity..
Suggested. Very beautiful traditional show.You can book the show without passing through your hotel going on site, very easy.

Well worth the wait. We assumed you could just rock up and go in but alas, they were booked so got tickets for later that day, it was sooooooo funny, well worth checking out, some of the singing was amazing and the laughing we had being able to see the puppeteers behind the bamboo curtain smoking cigarettes and chatting was well worth it, pay extra and go front row for that!

Skilful puppetry. Although we were advised that the Water Puppets in Hanoi might be something we could miss, we decided to make up our own minds. And we were so pleased we went! It was a lovely performance and just the right length of time to keep our interest. Not at all boring and we were pleased that we didn't listen to others on this occasion! So don't miss it!

Beautiful!. Really atmospheric, great live music and lots of puppets. Most of audience are tourists, but apparently the theatre group take the show out to village festivals etc so not just a tourist attraction.

The Water Puppets. Frankly, I was pleased it was quite short; I did appreciate the stroy and the history but the seats were cramped and the German tourists with their video cameras going throughout the show were irritating. It would be a better experience if videos and flash photography was not allowed!

Entertaining Puppets at the Water Theatre. This is an experience that you can't miss if you are staying in the Old Quarter in Hanoi. For just a few dollars, you can spend about an hour watching the water puppets perform in air-conditioned comfort. You can also enjoy the music group that sings and performs during this time.
A must see. A unique form of entertainment that's delightful for all ages. You can't go to Hanoi and not see this special kind of theater. And very reasonable. Tickets were only $5.
A must!. I was not sold on the idea before going, but ended up loving it - a real treat. I highly recommend going! Also, make sure to buy tickets a day in advance, the shows do sell out.

Interesting and would recommend. This puppet show was interesting and had some very funny moments. Overall I feel positive about it. Music was good. The length of the show is just about perfect and all of the seats are stadium seating. However I had trouble seeing due to a tall man in front of me. Seats in front are preferable. You can take pictures if you pay an extra dollar which gave my husband something to do.

You will not regret. After exploring the city, standing extreme hits the streets, strong trading, it is a good opportunity to get acquainted with the culture, history, traditions, music of Vietnam and just to get rest. For us it was very interesting experience, first puppet theatre on the water. Also when you are going to any city there are some must see places, Water Puppet show is the one from a few in the capital.Book tickets in advance, Don’t save money on this and take first-class tickets (100000 dong).
Well worth the $5. Entertaining, well priced cultural experience... oops some arms fell off... but hey it was excellent

Been there - done that. Okay, being in Hanoi you need to go see the Water Puppet show. It was an okay experience, but it was rather dull and the orchestra did not seem like they enjoyed themselves. It really felt as something done solely for the amusement of the tourists. If you don't have time and need to chose between two things, I would probably chose to do something else.

A pleasant and very different experience.. We went to this for an afternoon show. The show was varied starting with traditional music and then the puppets made their entrance. The puppets were amusing and very clever. A pleasant and very different experience.

Unique form of entertainment. The show at the water puppet theatre was fairly enjoyable, and a unique form of entertainment, with colorful and humorous scenes acted out on the water by the wooden puppets. Unlike the puppeteers, who remained invisible until they came forward to get their applause from the audience, the musicians and singers in their traditional costumes could be seen all the time. The puppeteers are very skilled at maneuvering the underwater rods and strings attached to the heavy puppets, all the time standing in deep water behind the scenes, and must be admired for putting on a show like that for nearly an hour.The dialogue and singing is not in English, but it is fairly easy to follow the simple story-lines with the help of the printed hand-out. Children would probably enjoy the show, which includes a fire breathing dragon and some amusing chase scenes.On the evening that I went the audience was mainly tour groups, with a few Vietnamese, and was completely sold out. Apparently this is a popular theatre, so it is best to get tickets in advance.It is an inexpensive introduction to a very traditional aspect of Vietnamese culture. However, if you are over 6’ tall you will find the seating very uncomfortable as there is so little room between the rows and we were packed in like sardines. Also, the traditional music might not appeal to all Western ears if you have never been exposed to it.
Entertaining. It was a fun experience. I don't think you'll find it anywhere else in the world.
surreal. do you enjoy puppets? if you said yes, what's wrong with you? if you said no, like i did, go anyway. it's totally surreal. loved the band!
Fun to see. Seats in theater much too small for us but luckily show was only 45 minutes so I could survive the seating that long.
Maybe we had to much expectations.. Okay, it was al right to experience the Water Puppet Theater but maybe we had to high expectations. It is worth a visit if you visit Hanoi

Interesting to see ... Not Fantastic ... Smoke Smell. While we had heard mixed reviews on this attraction, it is such a classic Hanoi Vietnam icon that we wanted to give it a shot. Overall, it was interesting to watch the water puppets and experience the Vietnamese culture through this art form. However, there were a few aspects that definitely killed the enjoyment.1) They charge extra to photo or video the water puppet show. For those that paid to photograph or video, there was no control mechanism vs those who did not. This left the "honest" payers as feeling ripped off as this appeared to be nothing more than another money making scheme. 2) The seating venue is cramped and wreaked of smoke smell. This detracted from the ambiance and connection with the unique art form. 3) People file in late and again this was not well controlled. As the aisle in front of your seat and the next seat are very tight, everyone must get up to accommodate late comers.
beautiful. Beautiful Vietnamese folk music and incredible puppetry. Well worth a visit.

best bang for your buck in Hanoi. $3 ticket and just loved it. The music and the spectacle were stunning - so unlike alot of tourist 'specatacles'. Its less than an hour and you really want it to go on longer.
Enjoyable. Enjoyed a wonderful puppet show. We were spell bound watching the puppets on the water. Downside for me was that I left my camera behind and when I returned it wasn't there.
Lighthearted entertainment. An interesting & entertaining view of a traditional performance. The music & musical instruments were worth listening to.

Novelty. Great to see this old art form adn to understand how it became a national art, but there is not English translation, so its alla mystery unless you read about it!
Lovely traditional music and song and fun to see the puppets perform

Local culture, not high culture. If you go with the right spirit it's a great fun thing to do, especially with kids but without them too.It's very popular, so book in advance; not much difference between superior and ordinary seats. The show lasts an hour.Pick up the leaflet by the entrance to give yourself just a little insight into whats going on.Overview...it's puppets in water; it's fun and funny. What's not to like (unless, reading some of the other reviews, you happen to be twice the length of a normal local and don't fit into the seats!)
Water Puppet show. Something different from the usual puppet show. Worth a new experience. Recommended. The show with traditional Vietnamese live band music is about 45 minutes. USD5 per pax entry.
A Pleasant Surprise. A last minute decision to join a group to see this show and what a pleasant surprise. The music and singing were delightful and the puppets were great fun. Well worth seeing.

Appealing for all ages - Cute and unique. We have been to the puppet show a few times- and each time there has been something new and lovely. It is simply enchanting and so skillful. The musicians and puppeteers are so accomplished. You must go to (at least!) one show while you're in Hanoi- but book early.

A simple and unique show. As other reviewers have said, don't bother buying more expensive tickets, it is not a big theater. I sat 3 rows from the front and still had difficulties cause the guy sitting in front of me was quite tall. I guess the height between the rows is not high enough. Of course when you bring kids, you better sit at the front.The show was not in English, but it was easy to understand the content of the story. Kids will enjoy watching the puppets anyway.The beginning part when they play traditional music instruments can be boring for some people, especially for kids. Have an open mind and appreciate the skill it takes to play those instruments. It's a unique show, you should see it.

Beautiful culture. Get there early on get a ticket for the back row - the first two seats have no seats infront of them ! Music was bewitching ( although I wasn't too keen on the signing parts ! ) and the puppetry clever.
Loved this!. What a magical performance! The music and puppeteers are excellent. see this if you can!

A night with a diference. For cultural histriography this place is a must. The skill of the pupeteers is second to none and this is a chance to see it for yourself. Water puppetry was widespread in this region but is almost gone now. Each 'story' is supported with traditional music and the whole thing is magical. Support this traditional art and have a night with a difference. Book early as each performance is very popular and go to this one in Hanoi rather than the one in Ho CHi Minh.

One time only. I could not agree more with the reviewer below who said the music got annoying fast, but it is cheap and a required sight to see. Some of the puppets were actually pretty well done, but I was glad it was only an hour!

Uncomfortable experience. If you are above 180cm you will have trouble with the seating as they must be made for locals. The show is not in English which is to be expected in Vietnam and it is recomended some reseach be done to understand what it is about so the experience can be appreciated.

A colourful respite. A novel way to spend the afternoon and learn about Vietnamese culture. The theatre tells various folk tales through the use of puppets displayed in and over water. The logistics of this production are interesting in itself. The stories are told in Vietnamese, and there is a live band with traditional instruments, and singers off to the side offering musical accompaniment. The theatre is located near the central lake and is a colourful and cultural respite in otherwise a drab, noisy city.

It was good. Lighten up before you go in. This is a good little puppet show. Don't waste you $$ on the more expensive tickets all seat can see the same. its in Vietnamese so its hard to understand but you can work it out from the show. it kills 1-2 hours has great live music and worth the $4 i reckon.

More enjoyable than I thought. Not a great fan of puppets and singing (still mocked for leaving the puppets and opera in Vienna) but this was an entertaining hour of skillful puppetry in water. The musicians were talented, the puppeteers more so, they made the puppets move in such anyway that seemed almost sublime. Some very clever special effects also, none more than the final scene. Well worth seeing.
Very Different. Truly excellent and great value for money but be sure to book in advance.

Culture for tourist not very comfortable but worth seeing. I think this is one of the attractions where your own attitude will make much of a difference. On one hand:The rows are very tight so with 6´4 I had trouble seating, asian music is not love at the first hear for the western ear (and not in the 10th for most either) and there will be busloads of tourist coming in making the theater pretty crowded. On the other hand:If you have the time to relax at the cafe downstairs and then go up expecting to see something extremely strange full of colours, dancing and a good first step into this different culture and actually enjoy the professionalism of all being part of it then you can have a very nice hour. Basically it is up to you, I changed about half way through from one stage to the other so in all I ahd a good lively hour. Lot´s of opportunities for pictures as well.

Light Hearted Fun. A Nice way to spend an hour and laugh at the puppets antics. I particularly enjoyed the fighting water buffalo(?). Not a "must see" in Hanoi I don't think though, unless you have a particular interest in puppet shows, and as per other reviews you had better have short legs if you are going to fit into the seats!
Just what it says... water and puppets!. I thought it was quite amusing although I don't think it was supposed to be. Would be good to take children to this.

You have to go .. but I can't say I enjoyed it a lot.. The Eastern music gets irritating in a hurry, and the "plot" isn't easy to follow. But it's affordable to go, and you might as well see it while you're in town. I found myself looking at my watch a lot!
Wonderfu!!!!. You must see the Water Puppets and hear the beautiful singing and music that is a part if the presentation. Get a center seat..3 to 5 rows up!

Entertaining! (little improvements needed). We enjoyed the show although we hope there is a monitor for English translation just like some shows I've seen in other countries. I think it'll improve their business. ;-)Other reviews are correct that it is mostly for tourist that is why I hope they can also renovate the seats and give a little space as my 6-footer husband could barely fit his legs on his seats. :-) other than these I think it was a great show, music was awesome. And it's really good to entertain your kids.

Wow this was defintly worth the dongs!. Great and very funny performance. Almost 1 hour long. We were on the first row and gleefully did not get wet as mentioned in our guide.. You will get a little booklet showing the different parts played and somethimes i had to laugh out loud so funny!

Enjoyable, one-time experience. Depending on which seat you take, for $3 or $5 USD this is a nice activity to do while you're in Vietnam. I thought that the music was beautiful and that the puppeteers were very talented. And, despite the number of shows they perform back-to-back every day, I thought that they did an enthusiastic job. Like others have mentioned though, it could seem somewhat long for those who do not speak Vietnamese, so I wouldn't recommend going to multiple shows throughout the country. But, I think it is a decent, one-time experience while in Vietnam.

Short and sweet introduction to a unique art form.. My girlfriend and I enjoyed this attraction. The show only last one hour but we found that was about the right amount of time. The quality of the musicians and puppeteers in the show was good. The show is in Vietnamese so unless you speak the language you will not understand what they say. Luckily the puppeteers were good so we good most of the story by purely watching the show.It is a unique art form from the rice fields of north Vietnam and they theatre are doing a good job at keeping it alive.The only thing that is a bit annoying is that flash photography is allowed so at times we were overwhelmed by the flashing.

Not the "must do" experience I was lead to believe. I didn't know what water puppets were until I got to Vietnam - essentially, the controls for the puppets are under water, and the puppets emerge from the water without any visible signs of control. This is a centuries old tradition in Vietnam.The show which took a little over an hour has music played with traditional Vietnamese instruments. It's all very nice and entertaining. There is a "programme" which is free, and tells you a little about each act. However, given the international (certainly fewer Vietnamese people than non-Vietnamese), the story which is narrated is lost on most of the audience. My wife thought that the puppets were better suited to children than to the mature audience present. Cost was VND100,000 for "VIP tickets" which had me in the front row, and VND60,000 for non-VIP.

A bit boring. Let s just say Asian people have a different kind of humour then Western people, I suppose. The majority of the public were Western tourists, but I only heard the Asian laugh.I am glad I saw it, but it s not really professionally done in mine opinion. Good thing it only lasted for 50 minutes or so.Maybe a good idea when it rains.
it'smust if you are in Hanoi. Great show, will make your mood happy and you will forget all the stress of your work.
OK. It is a dying art so I guess you should see it while you can, just dont expect too much.

Must see in any Hanoi trip. Took the family to see the water puppets. We had a great night watching the different acts. Really very clever and you will probably never see anything like this anywhere else.

Still in the tenth century!. This show appears to be on every tour groups itinerary and perhaps some tourists, like us, find themselves in a theatre watching a show totally in Vietnamese scratching their heads as to why they are there. While I appreciate the cultural roots of this show it is definitely not a must see ..... The day to day life on the street is much more exciting!There is not much of a story line and like I said earlier it is all in Vietnamese yet the entire audience were westerners.If this show was being performed as free street theatre you would probably stop and admire for ten minutes before moving on...not worth the effort in my opinion.

A fun hour. It was good - a little bit lame - but interesting. Music and singing is excellent (in my limited knowledge of Vietnamese music and singing) and the puppetry is different to anything I've seen. Be sure to upgrade to the front rows. No need to pay the camera fee - they don't check/enforce.

A good show but cramped. Very enjoyable but the seating is not really suitable for larger Westerners. I am over 6ft with long legs and was fortunate that someone had taken our seats before we got there and I sat at the end of a row. What a blessing - I would never have fitted in and was able to put my legs out into the aisle.
Didn't do much for me. I know this is a "must see" for Hanoi trip but it didn't exactly turn my switch. It's a good show and I enjoyed the music and the performance, but it just wasn't my thing

Lighthearted fun absolutely worth the $5. I was interested to see what the water puppets were all about, despite some comments about it not being the most thrilling entertainment ever. I'm very happy that I did. Charming and absolutely worth the $5. Go into it with a sense of humor and enjoy it for what it is - a puppet show, albeit a very unique one! The traditional Vietnamese music accompanying the puppet show was very good; one of the women's voices extremely good.It will cost you $1 extra for a pass that allows you to take photos. Flashes can be mildly distracting during the performance, but it's all in good fun. Let folks capture their Kodak moments ;)

water puppets. Thought it was quite good, novel idea. The musicians were good too. Don't expect west end but remember it only costs about £3.60 so what have you got to lose. That was the better seats but they didn't seem any different to the cheaper seats. You have to pay for a ' camera permit ' but it's not exactly checked.

Loved it!!. We met people on our trip who said they hadn't enjoyed the water puppet show... you must be dead inside if this doesn't make you smile! The music is beautiful (quite soporific, we both nearly fell asleep at one point), and the puppets are really funny. Definitely get the front row seats, it's so cheap and you really want an uninterrupted view. This was definitely my Hanoi highlight. Go!

no vietnamese visitors at site. Interresting to see how they play the performance with puppets controlled through the water, but it felt like a 110% tourist show ( as we didn't see hardly any locals among the audiense)
Better than expecting. I was quite dubious about this before I went, but I really enjoyed it. The music is lovely and the puppet in water with special effects really works well,
Well..... If it's raining and you don't enjoy walking in Hanoi ( it's NOT Paris ) out in the rain - the this is for you!

Truly boring. I was always skeptical about going, I don't even like puppets, but with it being so famous I allowed my friends to drag me along. BIG MISTAKE. I was so incredibly bored I was literally angry at myself for being a fool and thinking I might actually enjoy it. That said, my three friends found it brilliant and funny! I think it depends on your tastes: I met a couple afterwards who also quite disliked puppets/musical theatre/that king of thing, but thought they might enjoy this, they too were mistaken. I would say if you don't really like 'that kind of thing' then definitely don't go, but if you are neutral or do like 'that kind of thing', then give it a try!

Puppet Theater. Not only were the water puppets magnificant, but the singers and musicians were first class. We loved it and it was so reasonably priced. Don't need to purchase the more expensive tickets and you all have the same excellent view wherever you sit.

A very unique experience - worth seeing. I am really glad we attended this show!The puppets, floating on water, were mesmerizing - it honestly brought out the child in me! The show was accompanied by live music, which sometimes got a bit too loud, but other than that, It was a lovely experience. At the end of the show they were selling puppets at the exit - I think that can make for a very interesting souvenir, full of nice memories.

Unique experience - muppets on water. I love the water puppets. There are unique to nothern vietnam and are utterly charming. The show lasts for about 45 minutes and the theatre is reasonably comfortable, (legroom can be a bit tight if over 183 cms). The traditional stories are well presented and, even though I have no Vietnamese language skills, easy to follow. The music is also a feature. Played by live musicians, who sometimews interact with the puppets, this is an unmissable attraction in Hanoi.
Traditional Drama. A traditional drama tells you some more about Vietnam
Culture. A good way to relax after dinner to enjoy the traditional music and the show on the water. totally worth it

Going for the so recomended show of Hanoi. Queing up for the tickets is frustrating because you are not going to get your tickets immediately unless you book it early we have to wait quite a while for cancelled booking which ended us with missing the first part of the show. Most of the audience are foreigners it will be wise to have a sort of some subtitles because i do not have a clue what the various pieces are about

You only need to do this once!. Water puppets were fun - but not something you'd ever do twice! It was interesting to see how they managed to hold these large puppets that must have been heavy. The story was traditional and not exactly taxing. I found that the orchestra had some really different instruments that I'd not seen before. The singing was in vietnamese - so there was a bit of guessing. At about $3 a ticket it will be an experience that wouldn't break the bank.
touristy. just ok. the girls singing and the group playing were good.
Peter M. Mostly tourists in the audience but the show was great.
A nice surprise!. I didn't know what to expect when we went in, but I was pleasantly surprised. It was very entertaining and a few laughs. Not for everyone but I liked it.

So creative. Music was eloquent and puppetry was light hearted and so creative. Great entertainment. Didn't like that they allowed people in late, disrupting the beginning of the show for others who made the effort to be seated on time.

Authentic experience giving a real flavour of Vietnam. The whole performance was very professional and it was easy to
follow the action from the accompanying leaflet.There were many locals in the audience and their enjoyment added to the experience.

included local wildlife. Loved the water puppet show! Easy to access in town although show at Museum of Ethnology out of town is performed by native villagers. Beware, we got to see a rat climbing the stage beams during the performance!

A uniquely Vietnamese experience but otherwise average. The Water Puppet Show is a unique experience and the accompanying music is very nice; gives one a chance to hear some of the typical Vietnamese instruments. That said, its very hard to follow whats going on if you dont understand the language and the seats arent the most comfortable or well put together. We had mid-level seats and even so it was tough to see the performance because of all the people sitting in front of us. Make the visit only if you're interested in crossing off a somewhat unique Vietnamese experience off your list.

Outstanding show!. I really enjoyed this show. The musicians and puppeteers were very talented. The only negative about the theatre is that there is very little space between rows so it is cramped, but the seats were comfortable.

Only watch if you're interested in music and culture. The puppets are very life-like but the songs sung along to it are in Vietnamese with no translation. The brochures given aren't very much help either.

An ordeal. If the puppet show had English subtitles it may have been more fun - we think it was a comedy but didn't really know. Asian opera style singing is a bit painful to listen to and the seats are definitely not made for western length legs. It would be been better if it only lasted for 10 - 15 minutes.

unique and fun.... Most will find this boring especially with the digital age. However when you are going for something called the puppet show you better go in with a different mindset. I wasn't expecting much from some of the reviews here but ended up loving every bit of it.Firstly the band plays lovely classical Vietnamese music. The audio system is very clear and the music so mesmerising. That itself is worth the price of admission.Next up would be the puppet show itself. While being in Vietnamese the complimentary guide (which comes in multiple languages) does brief us what the overall play is about (broken down by chapter). From there we can appreciate the overall show. It takes 45 minutes and the time just flew by.Would definately recommend this for folks visiting Hanoi. Not to be missed!

What a Show!. Accompanied by highly accomplished musicians and singers, it is fascinating to watch the puppets trashing through the water, trying to tell their story. Very well worth a visit for an hour long entertainment at reasonable cost
Ok. The puppets are a little tired and worn outd. The kids seem to like it for me as an adult!,,

Fun show. It was a fun show, and you can't beat the cost. We got the "cheap seats" last minute, in the back row. Be warned... there is NO leg room in this row! My husband ended up standing up for the last 10 minutes since his knees couldn't take it. However, the show itself was a lot of fun. I think kids would enjoy it a lot.

Great glimpse into the traditional Vietnamese culture. A great performance, suitable for everyone, even people who don't normally go to theatres, as the 17 pieces are really short (it lasts less than an hour all together), and very interesting, and the puppeteers exhibit great skill. The art of water puppets has developed in the delta regions of north Vietnam during the annual floods, as the fields were flooded and the farmers had time to indulge into art!

This is genuine - even the Vietnamese rate it. This was a lovely three quarters of an hour. The puppetry is an art form that goes back 1000 years and no tourist should miss it. The entertainment is alternatively funny, poignant and dignified. This is as close as the Vietnamese get to Broadway.

Superb Introduction to Vietnamese Culture. A short but very exceptional show which should be part of your itinerary. It helps understand the Vietnamese way of life especially in the rural areas. As an Indian, I could identify with a lot of similarities in the music and outlook to life
Water Puppet. Punch & Judy in the water... Great music and singing
Unique experience. A must to see as you will not see anything like this anywhere else
A different form of entertainment. Very enjoyable show. The crowd delighted in the entertainment.
Nice and Enjoyable. The puppet show was beautifully done and is a definite destination to go to if you have kids.

Colourful, traditional experience. This is, as far as I know, a unique Vietnamese entertainment. The puppets are activated by long poles under the surface of the water in a theatre. The themes are traditional with accompaniment of a traditional orchestra. Very colourful and clever, well worth a visit.

Mixed review. We were told to get the cheap seats, since the more expensive seats in the front are sometimes blocked by the heads of those sitting in front of you. Since there were no cheap seats left, I found myself behind a mother with a child on her lap, and I rarely saw a puppet. Fortunately for my adult daughter, there was no one sitting in front of her, so she loved the performance. Since Vietnamese entertainment is so different from American entertainment, I think it's a good thing to visit these kinds of events, so that you can get a feel for the culture of the country. The music and the puppets are traditional. This is probably a must see for someone visiting Hanoi, and if you buy your tickets a couple of days before, you should be able to get the better, cheaper seats. Be there on time, as those who came late had a hard time navigating in the dark.
Interesting, worth seeing. The water puppet show is a different kind of artistic experience. I found it fascinating.

Nothing like it before. It was good fun and a different experience. The show is in a homely theatre by the lake with regular shows of about 45 minutes. The musicians are very good and seats 60,000 vnd. If you have long legs then you will be a little cramped.

I've been 3 times, always fun!. I first went alone four years ago, then took my parents last May and most recently brought some friends visiting. It's one of the best things I've done in Hanoi. Live orchestra play traditional music, the show is like no other I've ever seen, and so cheap!
“Quaint” but well worth the visit. We decided on a visit at the last minute , to get out of the rain, and are very please we did.Excellent value for money and a real insight in older Vietnam

Entertaining, cheap and not too long. Myself and my girlfriend went to the Water Puppet show in Hanoi and thought it was pretty good. Although it is in Vietnamese you can still follow the stories with the program that comes with your ticket.The whole performance was around 45 minutes long and was entertaining. The puppetry wasnt spectacular but still fun to watch and the live traditional Vietnamese band were great to listen to.I would thoroughly recommend a visit. It doesnt take up much of your night and its cheap to get in.

Nice music accompaniment. If you have extra time to spare, do catch a water puppet show at the theater just to enjoy the mesmerizing note of the one stringed zither 'dan bau'. A piece of advice, there isn't much difference between the first class and second class seatings unless you can secure a seat in the first two rows.
Charming. This was a great show with beautiful music from traditional instruments. Not for kids only.

Insightful Adventure into Vietnamese Folk Art. For the past three times I have been in Ha Noi, Vietnam there has been one things I have said I must do. So guess the third time became the charm. Everyone seems to want to see the Ha Noi water puppet show which is highly advertised. I had mix feelings the previous two times but was encouraged to go this time and the hotel made it easy by getting me the ticket so I didn’t have to stand in line. The lights went down and the woman to my left and the man to my right pulled out their cameras and proceeded to accompany the beat of the music with their camera flash, only to be joined by a course of the other audience members and their flashes. I finally closed my eyes and enjoyed the music. Oh by the way, the music is wonderful and well worth all of the small entrance fee. For more information Google Ha Noi Water Puppet show. With all that said, it is traditional art form that tells folk tales of daily life in the rice fields. Do see it, you will enjoy it.

Best show in town. I was not loooking foreward to going to see this show but is was the highlight of Hanoi. Don't miss it. I am still not sure how they did everything. Bring you camers and use a movie setting if you have it.

It's Like Watching a Show on Weed. This will be the type of show that you'll really enjoy the first time, but you'll dread for the second time. The performances of the water puppets are artsy and pretty entertaining, but they should've had a translator that narrates the whole story in English, so we understand the songs and plot. But the kaleidoscope of neon colours, loud music, chanting of hyms i couldnt understand...kinda makes me feel like I smoked weed before coming in for the show.
Do see the Water puppet Show. The show was great. Get your tickets in advance if possible. It sells out
Too long (45mins), but still a must do. If not for the length (45-50min) and the fact that it's all in Vietnamese, we would have enjoyed it more. But still a must do in Hanoi.

Puppet Theater Worth A trip. The Puppet Theater was worth seeing. Its a delightful puppet presentation in water that gives a look into the traditional form of entertainment done originally in rural areas in the water filled rice paddies.
Good thing to see!. Try to get the front seat line, book a couple of days before

Must see in Hanoi. The combination of traditional lief Vietnamese music and the dancing and play of puppets is great to see. Don't miss this, if you are in Hanoi and make a reservation in advance or try your luck and just turn up for this excellent theater.

Unusual puppetry. Water puppetry is a very local art form, and it was fascinating to experience it. The quality of the puppeteers was rather uneven, with some clearly more talented than others. There was live accompanying music and song, which was good.

Not just for kids. If you go to Hanoi you have to go to the Water Puppet Theatre, located near the northern end of the central lake and very close to the old quarter of the city. There is also a similar theatre in Ho Chi Minh City but this is the original. Historically, water puppet theatres were in the open-air (entertainment by and for the rice padi workers) and it is amazing what they can achieve with what is basically a simple puppet on the end of a stick. As well as marvelling at the displays, it is also an opportunity to sample traditional Vietnamese music played on traditional instruments.

Traditional and quirky, tiny theatre ... The theatre and seats are tiny, the show at 45 mins to an hour is quite long ... however to see something so traditional and quirky for only a few dollars is really quite something ... the story telling is so exceptional that even though it is only conducted in vietnamese with traditional music .. I found it fairly easy to follow ..

Wonderful show and ultra cheap. We enjoyed this show, was one of the highlights of our trip to Hanoi. We purchased tickets around lunch time - we got the "first class" tickets, only about $7 each or something each or less. Headed in and took our seats and watched a wonderful show, English guides and audio is available in this theatre.Tip: You must buy your tickets earlier in the day as they are all sold out by the time the show is starting.

adorable and simple. This is a must see in Hanoi! I thought maybe an hour would be very long but it is just right - long enough to see the art and short enough so you appreciate it till the end. The lower price seat are perfect as the theatre is tiny, it does get quite warm so bring some water! Buy tickets early in the day as the shows sell out very fast. Worth a visit!

Colourful and fun. The water puppet show in Hanoi should not be missed. A brochure gives the outline of the stories, but even without that it is possible to follow the action. Very clever, and judging by the audience's mirth, very funny too. We spent an enjoyable hour.

Water Puppets - interesting for 2 minutes. While some people might find this interesting, I found this to be tedious after a few minutes. All the group tours take their clients here - why I have no idea.

Traditional entertainment.. It lasts for about 45 minutes. The ticket is 60.000 dong. you have to book a ticket one or two days before - especially on the weekends. The music is great and you get the chance to see traditional instruments. You have to pay extra if you want to use the camera - though we didn't. The seats are small and uncomfortable, but it's not big deal as the show lasts less than an hour. Of course it's touristic, but I liked it!!!!

Charming and delightful, old fashioned Asian entertainment. They do this historic show through out the day. It lasts about 45 minutes and seating in the front is only $5. Go early to reserve a seat, preferably in the first row. If you use a camera it costs another dollar. This is a cute, charming puppet show that should not be missed. It is primarily in Vietnamese but the language is no barrier to understanding the stories. This is an old theater and leg room is very tight. The theater is located at the northeast corner of the lake.

thoroughly entertaining. get tickets in advance, although they have lots of shows tickets can still run out 1-2 days prior. admittedly it looks a bit old, and the dolls need some touch up, but it is nonetheless entertaining, for it is one form of art that is true to vietnam culture
Tiny seats. The theatre needs to move into the 19th century. The premium chairs have no legroom at all.
Cute Story. Love from the beginning till the end! Love how they put life into the puppets! Love it! Totally worth the price!

Not worth it. We read and heard about the Water Puppet Theatre and how everyone should go and your trip to Vietnam is not complete without it, so we went. Dissapointment! It was fully targeted to tourists. The band members were talking to each other when not playing, story lines weren't interesting. The show was short, luckily. I don't recommend it.

Not what I expected. Worth a visit.. I had heard from others that is was disorganised and boring, but I found it to be pretty good. Even though the theater is in Vietnamese the introduction is on English. It is some humor, some drama and the puppets look lively. Worth a visit if you want to see something cultural about life in Vietnam and Hanoi

Not a must see. The water puppet theater was interesting to see, but don't be too upset if you miss it. Of course, it is all done in Vietnamese, so you really cannot understand what the story is about. The live orchestra is good. We had seats in row G, so unless you are seated either in the first 2 rows, or after row H, it is difficult to even see the puppets, as they are down in the water. After row H, the rows incline upward, so you are able to see over the heads of those in front. The show only lasts for 45 minutes.

Charming show. The musicians are wonderful, and I loved the banter between the lady singers and the puppets (even if I didn't understand it!). The puppet show was very enjoyable and even made me laugh in a few parts.
Clever Puppeteers. What a clever and amusing show. Also the musicians were very good. A great cultural thing that should not be missed.
A Fun Thing to do in Hanoi. Even though I do not usually like puppets, I enjoyed this,. The music is beautiful and the show is interesting and funny a times.

Interesting puppet show. Great cultural experience. But if you don't like loud music, maybe take some ear plugs to soften the noise. Musicians were great, puppets were amazing. Definitely something to be done once in your life!
Loved it!. Such an original experience, wonderful musicians and singers, but the puppets are the main attraction and it's a clever and amusing show.

Nice show with beautiful music. It was very nice and not to expensive. Only thing that was a little disappointing was that we paid 100.000 dong each for better seats and we were still in the middle of the theater.
Just Amazing. A very unique experience that gives a brief insight into some of the music and drama culture in Northern Vietnam.

Worth the visit. The water puppets were excellent entertainment, a very good price be sure to pay the little bit extra for seats close to the front for best views and also pay the extra $1.00 to take photos... Music is traditional Vietnamese with a live orchestra puppetry is very well done and quite amusing
fun but wouldn't feel sorry for myself if I missed it. kind of fun, gets you in touch with local culture, which is good. But it's not like it's a must see in Hanoi

Colourful and very entertaining. The music ( orchestra) the puppets and stories were all very entertaining and beautiful. About $5 US a ticket for a memorable evening out in Hanoi !!! We puchased the CD as the music was lovely.

MUST SEE. We came here on a whim one night, it was one of the best cultural things we'd seen in Vietnam.
Fun for the whole family, any age, any language!
Quirky. Appreciate the work that goes behind manipulating the puppets and the music is amazing but it wasn't my thing. It is only 45 minutes long...and worth the price of the ticket to see.

If you like puppets in water this is your thing. OK an acquired taste - seats are designed for Vietnamese height so if you have long legs wrap them around into the next space if possible at least it is only an hour.
ok. it was quite good, but very touristy. stories depict like in viet nam

gorgeous but boring. the puppets are gorgeous, the whole show is great except that i didnt understand the language, hence it became a shrilling "noise" instead of a cultural experience. that said, i was probably full from lunch and over-tired from all the activities... i fell asleep 5mins into the show and didnt wake up till the end >.<

Great Cultural Experience. A little pricy compared to other tourist attractions but more than worth it. Great educational and cultural experience - highly recommended.
Make sure you book your tickets a little in advance, maybe on the morning for an evening show as it is very popular.
Happy Travels!

GREAT FUN. All the guide books said that this was a 'must see' attraction & I totally agree.
I really enjoyed the show.
I recommend it to other travellers.
Cramp seats but a good show. Great seats, if you can get front seats for more leg room. The traditional music is great too. Also, buy tickets directly at the theatre before hand!
the puppet show was not so bad well only the music was ok. not worth the money no so exciting either very very old methods of drama if only interest those who likes music etc

only o.k.. this is the tourist mecca - they have 5 or 6 shows a day which are usually full - unlikely to be able to walk up and get tickets so if restricted time book in advance - 100000 VND a ticket. Music is great - puppets just so/so
water puppets?. My first thought was, Water Puppets, sounds touristy. But I found the show, especially the music, to be fun and enjoyable, and helped me understand the culture, Well worth our time.
Very touristy. Everyone says you should see a water puppet show in Vietnam.....but it is extremely touristy. Great if you have kids.
Loud. Cover your ears for the loud flute player. It's worth a one time visit. There are no locals here, only tourists.

A Hanoi must-do. A cheap and fun experience that can only be had in Vietnam, I couldn't be happier that I made this a part of my Hanoi adventure. While water puppets might sound like a kids-only pasttime, this is an ancient art developed by rice farmers hundreds of years ago and will delight anyone. The cheap seats are 60,000 VHD, the good seats 100,000, get there earlier in the day to purchase your seat as they sell from the front back, and don't cheap out, it's only a $2 difference. on the downside, the water smells a bit musty and the seats are a bit tight, but you quickly forget as the show begins. The Dan Bao solo is beautiful and the movement of the animal puppets is surprisingly realistic.Make it a night by taking in this show and then heading out for dinner at one of the Old Quarter restos.

Suprising and original. I'd never seen anything like this before and it made me laugh out loud. The one drawback were the stupid idiots in the audience who insisted on photographing the performance by holding up cameras and blocking our view. The management should ban photography altogether.
A must see. Great for adults and kids. Go for a unique experience. Worth the price

Cultural and Entertaining Performance! Beautiful!. I was amazed by how the artistes could make the puppets come to life the way they did. Even though the performance was delivered in Vietnamese and I did not understand a word of it, I was still enthralled by the puppets and the traditional music and songs. I was especially fascinated by the Dan Bau, a one-string instrument, played by one of the artiste. It was a performance that I had truly enjoyed. I would highly recommend this for anyone visiting Vietnam and who is into experiencing cultural events.Definitely not to be missed.

Umm...sorry found it boring. I feel like a philistine writing this but out of everthing I did in Vietnam this is what I would give a big miss. Thanks god the kids were not with me or there would have been a mutiny! For me it was very boring, too long and I spent the whole time wondering how much longer it would be until the end.Sorry!

A new cultural experience. Be warned that all of the speaking in the performance and song is in vietnamese and this does make it a bit harder to follow, but it maintains the authenticity of the experience. It is not the highlight of my vacation, but perhaps the highlight of my short stay in Hanoi.
Not for everybody. Probably my expectations were too high, it is nice but for me it was boring after 20 minutes.
Water Puppets a must for the kids. was a fun to do very clever very well done great for the kids gets very busy so book early

delightful for all ages. the hanoi ''water puppet'' theatre, located on the Hoam Kiem Lake, is a delightful, energizing display for the eyes and ears! no matter your age, this is a nice way to spend an hour--- enjoying a vietnamese cultural experience filled with the story of traditional vietnamese life as told through puppetry and music. an amazing display of talent and choreography, as the water puppets--men, women, fish, dragons (!), and waterbuffalo, etc-- dance, swirl, splash, dance, sing, fight, and recount a tale of vietnamese daily life. you will understand the story, regardless, and be absolutely delighted by the water puppet theatre in hanoi! certainly a nice, quite, relaxing break away from the madness of the hanoi traffic. i would go again in a heartbeat!
Delightful. This show delights in spite of its blatantly touristic nature. Go and enjoy yourself and don't worry too much about it. Beautifully presented. Appealing music. Comedy. Have fun.
The most famoust performent show in Hanoi.. the price is very difficult to buy, if you do not come early. normal site = 60.000d, Vip site 100.000d.

Folklore-by-numbers for the Touris. The singers/musicians looked ready to strangle the next potbellied Australian that grazed their noses with his telephoto lens, the plays themselves were actually very verbally based, meaning that the (few) Vietnamese people in the crowd were laughing heartily but we ignorant non-speakers were left a bit puzzled. Not to slag working artists but the whole thing had the feeling of a bedraggled song-and-dance trotted out for (relatively highly) paying tourists
Great show. with 3$ for this show, it really great and i have more knownlege about vietnamese people

Fun experience, especially with kids. Everyone told me this was a 'must see' in Hanoi. I don't know if I'd go that far, but it's a fun cultural experience that's inexpensive and less than an hour so it doesn't take up too much of your time.
very touristy. something to do if you wanna pass a little time but not really a cultural experience. enjoyable though

Crazy. Very entertaining and definitely worth the ticket price. It is an absolutely bizarre experience, confusing at times, but also very funny and very professionally done. The traditional music is worth the 100 000 dong on it's own.The show lasts about 45 minutes and is on several times each day (first showing 2.15pm, last showing 9.15pm). I would recommend buying tickets early in the day as they soon sell out. It's good to get seats as close to the front as possible as the puppets are quite low down. If you're unlucky enough to be sat behind someone tall, your view might be obstructed.
Folk art at its best. We took our young children (2 and 3) to the children's show on Sunday morning and they sat enthralled the entire time. Well worth the $13 we paid for front row seats.

Water puppets rule!. Back in Hanoi after four years and the water puppets were still as fantastic on our first visit. For a few dollars you get to see an amazing show lasting about an hour. The same performance at an arts festival in Australia a few years back cost around $50 or more! There's action and comedy and the skill of the puppeteers is phenomenal. Because of the demand for tickets,book a seat a day or two before you want to go, then go for a wander around Hoan Kiem Lake, grab an ice cream at Fanny and sit and watch life go by.

A cultural step back in time for a true Hanoi experience for all ages.... We managed to get seats on the day for the show at 5.15pm. It was just after Tet so may have been lucky as it was quieter but the theatre was 80% full. Let's just be clear what you can expect....as a few rather impatient or misinformed people left 15 mins into a 50 min show (perhaps running late for their next itinerary stop!). This is not Disneyland Hanoi with lots of modern gadgetry but a wonderful piece of traditional theatre that has been passed down from generation to generation and has a performing apprenticeship of 3 years. There is a combination of singing,music and obviously the water puppetry that kept our 3 and 18 mth old entertained with the youngest asking for "Moooorrrre" by the end. Whilst there was a brief introduction in English,French and ongoing dialogue and story telling was in Vietnamese but given this attraction is all visual then you don't feel you are missing out. Yes, the theatre is less than modern and the seats are more tight economy class than business class but for 45 mins of traditional entertainment that has a charming uniqueness and a peek back into a form of entertainment that has played out for hundreds of years in Vietnam then this is worth making the effort before you roll into the evening in the Old Quarter ,playing chicken with the motorbikes, restaurant bound for some local delicacies.

Worth a visit. For 100k Vietnamese dong, you get front sit to watch the show. Interesting to watch the show - they control the puppets with poles hidden by the pool of water. I like the last part of the show where a fish has transformed to a dragon - it flew on the stage.
Great show.. This is worth seeing as it reenacts a longtime part of Vietnamese culture. The show goes for about 45 minutes and the theatre is small so everyone gets a good view.
Good fun, good value. This is a pretty good show and doesn't go on for too long (45 mins). For the money you can't beat it and it's not something you will get at home.

Delightful fun for about an hour.... The ancient Vietnamese became bored during the rainy season, and carved puppets, and performed plays in the water. The show is about rural life--farmers and fisherman. The stories were cute, and the music was fun to listen to. Believe me, a play speaks a universal language. No Vietnamese required!I enjoyed it very much. About 1 hour, $3-$5.
Excellent show!. However not it is mainly for tourists, the show is really artistic, and shows a short introduction to vietnamese culture. I loved it!
puppets. it was an interesting water puppet show, nothing like what you would expect anywhere in the world. enjoyable.

thing to see. One of the main things to see is the water puppet show, there are many around the Thang Long theater is located near the old quarter & puts on many performances during the day & evening. Not expensive & worth the effort.
Fascinating and very different.. It was different and well worth a visit. Quite a spectacle

A great introduction to the Culture. The music was so good and very talented musicians playing their traditional instruments. I loved the puppets and the whole cultural story was great. We had 1st class seats (row G) and I would have preferred to wait for seats in Rows A or B if possible because it was hard to see over some of the heads in front. Ay approx. $5 not to be missed.

Entertaining. I'm a sucker for local/cultural performances despite the exorbitant prices you pay sometimes and though most say this is probably over-rated but I love it anyways. Considering this is a 45min performance for less than the cost of $10 in my local currency, it is well worth it. I just hope the performers are well paid for their efforts and that it doesn't all go to the "gar-men".

Excellent value. first class tickets 100,000 dong ($5)second class tickets 60,000 ($3)We had 2nd class tickets and found that it did not hinder our enjoyment at all - it is a small intimate theatre.This is an excellent opportunity to listen to some traditional music played live, and the puppets were entertaining. They had multi-lingual introductions, after which all the narration was in Vietnamese but this did not spoil our enjoyment.We were just strolling past and got tickets for later that evening, well worth the money.

Old fashioned but ok. It was more or less what we expected - sort of corny, but worth seeing because we wouldn't see it elsewhere. If you could see something similar in a village, it is our bet that it would be more culturally authentic.

Loved the music and puppets!. I was actually pleasantly surprised by this show after reading other reviews. Was enthralled by the skill of the puppeteers and enjoyed the orchestra and singers. Didn't find them at all loud as mentioned by other reviewers. Yes, the performance was totally in Vietnamese but as it is a very visual show , language was no barrier for us. Would recommend to children and adults alike for a great taste of Vietnamese culture at a reasonable price but get in early to buy tickets as they sell out fast!

Fun and unique. Enjoyed the show which was very different - make sure you grab a program to understand what is happening. Talented musicians accompany the puppets. We opted for first class tickets at 100,000 dong ($5) and had front row centre seats. Show is about 45 minutes long which is just right.Only annoyance is that flash photography and video is allowed if you pay an additional fee. The flashing of cameras during the show was distracting.Would recommend for a visit.
Delightful night. Fun show, very entertaining, lots of laughs and the musicians were outstanding.

Good for kids!. The performance was enjoyed by the majority of our group (8 adults and 7 children aged between 5 and 13). Most annoying were the other tourist who came in late or held video cameras up for the whole performance. Get a ticket for a seat near the front if possible.
Very disappointing. I know this is only $10 each but this was really disappointing. Maybe we had a bad show but not what I had expected
GREAT SHOW. had a amazing time only thing i like in the city i recommend it
Great experience!!. The water puppet show was awesome! I've never seen anything like that before, it's very lively.

A great way to spend an hour in Hanoi. I thought the show was excellent. We attended the 8pm showing and far from being tired, the performers were in really good spirits and thoroughly professional. You can buy tickets on the day from the little ticket window at the front of the theatre if you get there early enough or get your hotel to book you your ticket. The ticket window takes credit cards as well as dong and dollars. You get an allocated seat (we were in the second row from the front and the view was excellent). There are NO subtitles but this is an ancient and very obvious art form, it's very easy to work out what's going on in all the little stories, it's very visual humor.All in all, this is an inexpensive, different and entertaining show that I would recommend to anyone - especially with children!
Not that interesting. The music was wonderful, but too loud for the space, and the show was only moderately interesting.

Great fun, but tickets can be hard to get. We enjoyed the show, both adults and kids. It is worth going to see as it is something unique to Vietnam, both the puppets and the music. Tickets however seem to be hard to get by. We tried to buy some and were told they were sold out for the next four days. We happened to wander by the next day, and suddenly tickets were available again for that night!I can only guess there was a group cancellation, but like some things in Vietnam - a mystery that will never be figured out. Either way - worth seeing.

Average. I had high expectations before going, however I wasn´t impressed by the show. Obviously everything is in Vietnamese although you get a pamphlet with the name of the acts in English so you have to imagine what is actually going on. The music is good, though.
Disappointing!. The show was pretty average, too long and boring, probably more suited to children between 5-13 years of age.Wouldn't rush to go, several fellow travellers felt the same!!

Great value for money. Get First Class Tickets (first 15 rows) - they will cost the grand sum of $4 each ! Show lasts for 45 minutes and whilst not mesmirising it was very good none the less. Kids will love it - as will grown ups - well worth the money. If you want to take photos best bet is to be in the first five rows otherwise you will get some people heads in the shots so book a week or so in advance if you get the chance.
Very Different. I had never seen a water puppet show before so it is certainly worth seeing.
Cool puppets and effects. Didn't understand one word obviously, but loved the puppets and effects...but the music got annoying after a while!
A very professional performance. This performance is well worth visiting as part of your evenings entertainment. It is a visual pleasure and the music is charming.

Not the most exciting thing to do in Hanoi. Perhaps I was still experiencing jet lag or was just exhausted from a long day of touring, but I fell asleep during this show and we ended up walking out early. The music was extremely loud and, while there was definitely a story being told with the puppets, I didn't understand it since it was in Vietnamese. The puppets are very cool and there is no question that the people controlling the puppets backstage are really talented. I think I would have enjoyed an English-version of the show. I've never seen anything quite like this as the combination of puppets in water (yes, some even swim) is quite unique. If you have extra time on your hands and manage your expectations, it may be worth it, otherwise, skip it.
lovely entertainment. Definately worth a visit. Good theatre, and interesting and atmospheric entertainment. A well worthwhile evening out.

Worth visiting for the music. The theater is older and the smell of stale cigarettes seem to permeate everywhere, but visiting Asia this isn't uncommon. We were told we need to pay a one dollar to take video or photos, but this did not seem regulated and no one checked the ticket we bought to verify we could. The music that played before and during the performance, used some traditional instruments. This was excellent and very entertaining in itself. The scenes were not too long and it kept moving along. Since it is in vietnamese it was nice to have it keep moving to keep the kids attention. This is not an expensive outing and a part of the Vietnamese culture. It was a highlight of our trip to Hanoi. Book your tickets in advance for the show that you want, it sells out daily.

Cute, I suppose. This is an extremely popular tourist destination and hyped up advertising about it is to be found everywhere. If you have not seen water puppetry before then this is an opportunity to satisfy your curiosity. Entertainment quality for me was sorta okay.

Fill in time with 1hr theatre family entertainment. This is a 1hr Water Puppet theatre show that is available different times throughout the day. The show is opened 30mins before the show begins and it is recommended that you purchase a ticket earlier that day or previous day. The theatre is opposite to Hoan Kiem Lake (a main attraction in Hanoi). The tickets are 60,000VND ($US3) for 2nd class tickets or 100,000VND ($US5) for 1st class tickets. The difference being front row tickets. When you purchase your tickets, they are numbered ie: L1 (row L, number 1), so there is no need to arrive too early, however they do close the doors on time, so don't be late. There is a poster stating that you need to buy a ticket for photos/video $4 extra, nobody purchases these, and there is no policing of this. The show is in Vietnamese, so it is difficult to understand what is going on, you do receive a very basic brochure with little explanation. However I do recommend that you attend this show, it is an enjoyable 1hr, cheap entertainment. This show is also available in Saigon.

Best sleeping pill in town. For some this might be a thrilling cultural experience. Normally, I enjoy going to the theatre, but this was the weirdest thing I have ever seen. After 10 minutes of laughing at the whole thing, I was just plain bored. Again, for some this must be considered great, authentic entertainment (apparently as the theatre was sold out), we sort of hated it.

Go for the authentic music. Boring, touristy show...our group of five spent a good deal of the time nodding off. I saw the show 13 years ago and it is utterly unchanged. The musicians are very skilled and if you'd like to hear some wonderful Vietnamese music, the ticket is worthwhile for that alone...but don't go expecting something special beyond that.
Music very loud. I found it to be pretty ordinary. The music was very loud. My kids enjoyed it.Regards,Karen.

Very entertaining. When you buy a ticket, they tell you to pay a camera fee when you arrive at your showing. We didn't do this and no-one asked us for payment and judging by the amount of tourists taking constant flash photos (quite off-putting) they hadn't paid either. Show lasts about 45 minutes - very good.
Loved the show.. It was a worthwhile visit. We were fascinated by how the puppets moved and enjoyed the insights into the use of the land.

Very entertaining and cute! Highly recommend.. I highly enjoyed this performance. The music really helped to set the scene and tone of each act as the dialogue is all in Vietnamese.
