The musicians were very talented and it is worth the trip just to see them play. But ofcourse the water puppets were very entertaining, extremely cute and funny. The puppeteers are very talented and at times they had me gasping and giggling like a child. The theatre seemed fairly full so I would probably suggest buying tickets in advance which is what we did. I'd recommend this for all ages and I would attend it again. The cost was only 100,000VND ($5 US).

such a cool show!. Really a must-do if you're in Hanoi. It is amazing how the puppets can be manipulated by the puppeteers from so far away, and they really make the story come to life. The music played by the traditional musicians was also outstanding. I was extremely tired from jet lag, but I still managed to stay awake; the show was just that engaging!

traditional theatre. It was nice to see a traditional form of entertainment for villagers but my family felt it was pretty ordinary. After the initial interest of the water puppets wore off the stories were not that engaging and a few people in our group nodded off. For the current generation of youth it didn't impress. A front row might have made the experience more impressive.

I Wished There Was An English Version. In a word or two, water puppets were cute and funny at times. Dan Bau was an amazing instrument original to Vietnamese music. You've got to see it being played! One has to read the program prior to the show so you'd be able to guess perfectly what's it about. Yeah, I wished there was an English version. It probably will be extremely adorable if I understood it.
Boring!!!. sorry but I fell asleep. the music was ok but in general I would not go again.
Great entertainment. I'd highly recommend that this be on your list of things to do in Hanoi

Glad I went but would not go back. We saw the water puppet show, sitting at the front, in row B. The whole show was spoken in Vietnamese so we didn't understand what the dialogues were. They give you a little brochure stating what each act represents but that's about it. If you are going, the front row seats are worth it. Overall the show was interesting, at times funny but I found it boring personally after Act 3 or so. The puppets need maintenance and so does the stage area etc..

Different and could pass time on a rainy day. We visited the theater in September 2011.We didnt really know what to expect and as tickets were so cheap (around £2) we decided to give it a try.The show features a large orchestra as well as the puppets themselves. The show was interesting at first however we begin to find it a bit repetitive.Was worth going to see but wouldnt rush back!
marvellous show. their performance is superb unlike the hand held puppet this is on the water !!

Pick up tickets early. Spend the money and get seats in the front row. Dont worry - you are not going to get wet. You pay extra $1USD to use your camera during the show. The music was fascinating and the vignettes often highly amusing. Well worth the $5!

Traditional Puppet with modern touch. This theater is by far the most legendary performance-art in Vietnam. Beside the water puppet that were skillfully manuvered by the puppet master, bright colors of puppets and backgrounds, we will be entertained by stage-lighting, tradisional music and tradisional chants. They have brochures that tell the stories of the performance in many languages, so you can read it before the light is dimmed. Try to get the VIP seat at the middle. Forget the camera (you must pay to bring in the camera) sit back, enjoy...

Don't miss it when in Hanoi. The show is amazing! Not only the incredible puppet show but also the music. We had a "second class" ticket which was not a problem, as they place additional chairs next to the normal tiers.Try to get your ticket early, as the show is often fully booked. The theatre is located at the northern side of the Hoan Kiem Lake.

Average. This was our 2nd water puppet show and was not as good as the one in Ho Chi Minh City. A bit boring but should be done once during your time in Vietnam. Book ahead as some times were sold out.
Amazing Show. Never seen something like this earlier, though have seen a lot of puppet shows in India but was amazed by the way the entire show was done in water. Simply great.
Amazing. In the cold wheather, but the Vietnamese artist did a good job
Enjoy the craftsmanship. The show is done in VN however you can easily just sit through the hour long show and marvel at the craftsmanship of the musicians and puppeteers.

Cheap evening entertainment!. There are mixed reviews on here so we bought tickets with an open mind. Given tickets were only £3 we thought we had a fairly good idea of what this was going to be like. It was fairly simple, but lovely to see Vietnam share its history. Maybe a little cheesy at times but for the price it's certainly worth a visit!

Dingy theater, mediocre show. This seems to be the thing that every tourist in Ha Noi MUST do, and the company just churns out shows and bustles through the masses. There was moderate cultural interest generated by the show itself, but the theater is truly dingy and even seems like a potential fire trap, and the management will seat you anywhere they like, regardless of what your ticket says. Seats are so close together your knees are practically under your chin.

So awesome and unique!. I've never seen anything like it! They were amazing, still not sure how they do it... The seats are made for the Vietnamese people... ;) So get ready to get cozy with your neighbors!The music was just as awesome as the show. Loved it!

Fun and colorful. This show is a lot of fun; if you have time, you should attend. Besides being unique, it is quite well done, especially the musicians. Do not pay the person at the door for a ticket to use your camera; they are separate vendors, and it is a scam. But enjoy a good show.

Excellant, another must do. The show is unique as it takes place in water. It's amusing and just the right duration.
It's entertaining and worth the dollars. although, they could do a better job with the brochures and the theater ambience.
Tip : buy the ticket in advance

Unique and enjoyable. I've attended puppet theatres in Malaysia and Indonesia, but the Vietnamese show was certainly unique as it took place in the water. The show was conducted in Vietnamese with a live ensemble and singers. Although I didn't understand the language, the emotive power of the music and songs coupled with the puppets' actions allowed me to have an idea what the stories are about. On the whole, I enjoyed it very much.

Don't believe the guidebooks. As other reviewers have said, we were told this is a 'must see' in Vietnam. The theatre is musty, run down and we were packed in like sardines..no leg room at all.The puppets are in very bad repair and the show is incredibly boring..I actually fell asleep and I normally love going to live shows.The music is definitely the best part but I would not recommend this show.

worth going -good past time at night after dinner. The water puppet show is nice. But not too high expectation would be great. Clean and comfortable theatre. Entrance ticket is cheap, USD 2 i think?hardly remember.was there about a year plus ago,nov 2010. It lasted fpr about an hour or less.many tourist go for it too. Located in the centrler of old quarter,somewhere near to hoan kiem lake.i bought the tic earlier in the afternoon to avoid disruptions due to full house.

Entertaining and worth the price. The Thang Long Water Puppet Theater is right in the heart of the Old Quarter in Hanoi. The performances are are of water puppetry on a stage. The tradition of water puppetry comes from the rice fields when they were flooded. The Vietnamese started it for fun and now continues as part of their culture.The performance is 50minutes long. There are 5 times for the show, at 15:30 PM - 17:00 PM - 18:30 PM - 20:00 PM - 21:15 PM. We purchased our tickets on the day- we bought them directly from the theatre at about 10.30am, for the show at 3.30pm. You can choose between first class tickets $5, or second class tickets $3. We paid for first class and got the second row. You will be allocated a seat number. So there is no need to get to the show really early and line up. The performance is worth the price. There is a musical accompaniment to the puppetry. I agree with other reviewers that they do appear bored, and yes I did see some of the ladies filing their nails. I did not look to much at the musicians themselves as we had seen a couple of traditional music shows before, (in Hoi An and Hue). The best part was the puppet shows. The performances were very fun. The music and the puppets moved well together to tell traditional stories. Some were quite funny and the audience had many laughs. Others were more serene and beautiful. The water is murky and the puppets at not really smooth in movement, but nonetheless if you watch it for what it is and listen to the music rather than focusing on how the puppets move, you will enjoy it. The show went quite quickly, although 50minutes was enough. Although there is no direct translation into English, or other languages. You can pick up a show program when walking into the theatre (free) and it gives a brief, very brief explanation of each item. The programs are in many languages, Japanese, French, German etc.

Worth Going to, but keep expectations low. This is worth going to, as it's a short show, and gives a piece of culture you aren't going to find many other places. However, for this being the "best" water puppet theater, we thought they could have had better maintenance on their water puppets... the puppets were cracked and chipped in many places (we had front row seats) and looked quite "tired" and really, wouldn't take much effort to clean them up to make them look new again. Bottom line: worth doing, but don't have high expectations. Go for the cultural experience of it.

Mixed opinions but would not do again.. Our 10 yr old enjoyed the experience, but not the rest of the family. Most of the story was very difficult to follow as it was not translated. We ended up with back seat tickets and they were great. The theatre kicks up at the back and you get a clear view of the stage - better than most of the more expensive front section seats. You have to go, but thankfully it only lasted an hour!

Unforgettable Water Puppet Show. After a long day of walking around, touring and shopping, we decided to watch the water puppet show. Although we were not very keen to try in the beginning, we were glad that we actually did it. Our kids, 5 and 3 years olds had an amazing time, they were never bored and have watched the full show attentively (considering that we didn't understand anything that they said or sang). The threatre was packed but we managed to get seats at the back side (I was glad we got those seats since we have a full view of the stage). I recommend going to see the Water Puppet Show when you are visiting Hanoi.
Definitely worth a visit. Interesting show, which plays in the water. Accompanied by traditional music of Vietnam, a place where you can experience the real Vietnam
definitely worth the cultural experience. We loved this, worth seeing for the puppetry and the live music and singing, buy the first class seats.
Front row seats. One night we decided to check out seats at the booking office for the next day and we got front row seats for there 8:00pm show. Good fun and very cheap.

Good music, highly entertaining but not always for the right reasons. This short performance is well worth the price of admission, if only to see the most intensely bored set of performers I've ever seen on stage. That they nevertheless produce some highly enjoyable music is a tribute to their talent. I can't imagine what it must be like to perform the exact same show 5 or 6 times a day, 7 days a week, ad infinitum. But the two lead female singers looked like if you handed them nail files they'd spend the entire show using them. Although they're not capable of super-sophisticated movement, the puppet-cast-of-thousands is also pretty fun. But to me the best part is the music.A few practical points: the performance is miked, and therefore overwhelmingly loud in the small hall. (An advantage is that it's suitable for small children, who can talk out loud without much danger of disturbing anyone around them.) The seats provide very little leg room for persons of height -- I don't think I could've managed much more than the 45 minutes of entrapment the show required. Oh, and tickets do sell out for the popular 20.00/8 pm showing so plan to get them in advance.

Must-See Water Opera. Fabulous experience of the wonderful and ancient art of water puppetry. The whole colourful show is played out with life-size puppets supported by a company of musicians and singers who tell the story behind each scene played out on a large indoor pool.Seating is a little cramped but a truly worthwhile cultural adventure.

Water Puppet Theater. The show was okay. Place was fully booked and they wrote sitting places to the tikets bad so it was hard to understand wich was your place. (Like the letter were hard to understand)
Enjoyable afternoon. This was a fun show that was cultural and good value. Some of the puppets look a little dated, but overall the show was fun.
No Subtitle. No subtitle at all. Want to take picture and video? Pay more. A bit boring I think. But worth to try if you visit Hanoi.
Something unique. Should at least watch once, it is a unique cultural show.

Amazing!!. This is supposed to be the best water puppet show in Hanoi and I agree. It is absolutely fantastic, the starting music is surreal and enchanting.Ensure that your tour guide books the tickets early for good seating as they get booked out pretty quick and chairs are even place on the walkways to pack more tourists in.Try a great cocktail or beer at the bar at the entrance while you wait for the show.
Fun. Is fun to see and an excellent show. Getting a little tired and needs some energization !

Better than expected!. While this is not really our thing we had been told by friends not to miss it as its pretty unique. Positives - its short, not expensive and you get to experience Vietnamese culture. Negatives - well its a puppet show!
If in the lake area go

A totally different experience!. The water puppet theatre is a world apart, even from every day Viet Nam. The only negatives are that tourists insist on photographing with flash during the performance, and that the excellent live musicians providing the traditional music for the show appeared to be deeply bored. I can overlook that, but the flashes of cameras do interfere with one's ability to enjoy the performances. I highly recommend taking in a show and then visiting the sales desk for informative books about the tradition.

fun time. Brought the kids here for the first time and also the 1st time for me to see the show.The program is just enough with cool, fun water puppet acts and good traditional music. The place was packed with almost 95% foreigners or non-local. This is a good show for traditional culture of VN. Strongly recomend if you never seen this before. However, don't expect anything spectacular or wow factor here.

Excellent Cultural Experience. We bought our tickets early in the day and got front row. The musicians are brilliant and the story gives a good indication of early life in Vietnam. Our kids (9 & 7) loved the show as well. Amazing what you can do with a few puppets and a watery stage. Was good value.

fun. We went with no expectations and enjoyed it. The musicians seem not at all bored with all the repeat performances they do. The puppets were most interesting and used puppets were available to buy.
Disappointed. The idea of water puppets sounded interesting, but in reality not so much. The music quality is somewhat grating and the puppetry is not very sophisticated. We would not recommend.
Go!. Whilst I wouldn't be tempted to return, the VND100,000 seats provided a great view of the action, both in terms of the puppets and the orchestra. The latter was excellent as were the singers.
Fun and short. So interesting to see the entertainment before a world of internet and television.
A good cultural experience. The show is sung and told in Vietnamese, so I missed a lot of the back story. They should have translated it onto a written program for the tourists.
Must see. Real tradition, authentic and fun. A unique entertainment, all in Vietnamese, and just long enough to not get bored. we live here, and after twenty years, still enjoy it.

A unique cultural experience. A great experience, with live music and the water puppets portraying rural life and legends of Vietnam. It was really enjoyable, although the dialogues were in Vietnamese, program briefly described the script. It is really amazing what the artists behind the curtain can do with their puppets!
Average. Would not really recommend however it does provide a little bit of Vietnam culture.
nice show. in city centre and it is very typical for water rice culture
So much fun. Great Asian music (live) and funny water puppet show. Went as part of a group... and was great value for money :-)

An interesting novelty. Its not sophisticated, but as a little bit of culture wrapped up in a show its pretty good. My 6 year old daughter enjoyed it, as did I. Booking in advance is worthwhile - usually the day before. Show times seem to vary so don't always follow what you read here - check at the theatre when you arrive as it does seem to vary a lot. Always full so aim to go early in your trip. The box office opens before 2.30 - not sure exactly when. Cash only

ok for the price. it;s a must see i suppose. It costs $3-$5 for the 45min show. Not bad for the price & the puppets are very well made. They try & charge you another $1 to take photos. Don't pay it & take photo anyway. They will never know

Not my thing. This was a bit of let down, we were bored in 5 minutes, and so were the those participating. The singers (choir) were texting friends, and they were chatting and not engaging with us. Probably how you feel if thats all you been doing since the morning.

Really not worth it. This was really odd. We're a pretty cultured family but there is something pretty low rent going on here. It just all felt kind of sloppy and unpolished. Orchestra and singers were more interesting than the puppets. Maybe it's something that appeals to the musical theatre crowd, but it didn't work for us. Hanoi is an amazing city with far more interesting things to see.

Critical Review - just my 2 cents. The Water Puppet Theater is located near the lake (north-east) in a building which is not very hard to miss judging from the number of people queuing up for tickets daily.There are 6 show slots every day (only 5 on Sundays), and it runs 7-days a week. Tickets are priced at 100,000VND and 60,000VND. Plus 20,000VND (can be paid upon entering the show) if you want to use your camera. I was planning to see the renowned Water Puppet show in Hanoi as I read quite a number of great reviews about it. My friend and I had to stand in line for more than 15 minutes before we got our evening tickets (8pm show). However, the lady told us the 60,000VND tickets were sold out and gave us the 100,000VND ones instead. We got second row seats nevertheless.The show was pretty packed that night, though I saw quite a number of empty seats behind. I am not sure where they draw the line between the 100K and 60K seats though.Generally, it was an entertaining performance. Good musicians, great traditional music, it was definitely an experience not to be missed.On the contrary, being a performing artist myself, I tend to review performances in detail.Presentation/appearance wise - I don't understand the poor maintenance of puppets and props. Seeing they do 6 shows every day of the week, charging tourists approximately $3 and $5 and selling off most of their tickets, they should be able to keep the puppets and props in good shape. Some of the puppets are not even functioning well (eg. one arm moves, the other does not. some even have 2 faulty arms), where else they are a few that look so badly worn out (big obvious chunk of paint "peeled off" from face, and very dirty-looking dragon). A small part of the painted-Styrofoam even came off halfway through the show (well, because one of the puppeteers keep maneuvering the puppet against it).Performance-wise: As this has been an ongoing performance for many years, I never expected so many glitches from the start till the end. There were a few occasions where one or two of the puppets were not synchronized with the others during a dance. Not sure if the audience noticed that, but it was pretty obvious for us (my friends and I) seated in front. Some parts of the show were pretty sloppy too, making it seem like a chore for the performers - I know they have been doing the same thing too many times, but it really shows in their performance. I did forewarn a critical review, and am not some whiny tourist. Maybe Thang Long Water Puppet Theater can look into the 2 aspects, especially the appearance of the puppets.As said, it is a great performance overall. Get your tickets early to avoid disappointment as some show slots get 'sold out' really fast.
show was ok... it was ok to see , nothing really special unless you really like these kind of things.
So fanstatic. enjoy the show in the evening will bring you the relax time.

Great show marred by people smoking in the theater.. Brought my kids to see the show since I heard so much about it. It was interesting and an eye opener into a different culture. Up til now, I'm still trying to figure out how some of the actions were done! The pace was pretty good and we did not have much time to be bored, thankfully, and my kids enjoyed themselves.Unfortunately, there were people smoking in the theater and that made it a really unpleasent 45mins. Cigeratte smoke makes me nauseous so I felt pretty sick by the time the show ended.For the experience, go. But once you've done it, I don't think I'd return again.
interesting water puppet show. first time in my life to watch this water puppet show. interesting, must take a look ya! I would suggest in future they can provide us the translations.. thanks...

Must see traditional Vietnamese theatre. Go earlier in the day as they musicians can get tired, great theatre well organized inside, the tickets sales are a bit odd but stand and wait , The puppets I had seen in Adelaide when i was a kid and not sure what to expect, but it was fun and well performed , the water puppet stories are easier to follow,kids would love this show too

Anticipation. Well this one totally confused me i had no idea what it was about until the end! It was noisy and smokey and long and the flashing of the cameras (that people had to pay extra to use) was extremely annoying.Disappointed.
Must see. The water puppets were a surprise and you get an introduction into vietnamese music, for 5usd we were sitting on the 1 row.
Fantastic!. Loved it so much, I went twice!..Music is great, puppets were wonderful and very colorful.
a nice evening out...something different. full of tourists, but it is interesting. nice to see something cultural and different. it doesnt actually matter which tier of of ticket you get.
Worth seeing. Seeing the water puppets is definitely worth seeing. The puppeteers are very skilled. Having said that I would also say having seen it once I feel no need to return.
Dissapointed. We had no pre set expectations about this show, so we were not too dissapointed at what we saw. Problem was that after 15 minutes we both fell asleep! Say no more!
Well worth seeing!. Very intriguing form of puppetry, appealed to young and old. Definitely worth seeing.

loved it. first afternoon, very tired but loved it - only about an hour and well worth seeing and hearing - the musciians were great. don't miss if you're in hanoi - it's not like puppets i've seen anywhere else
Great Fun. What an entertaining way to spend an hour. We arrived just before the 8:15pm show and were able to get tickets. The puppets were super fun to watch. We thoroughly enjoyed the experience.
interesting to see. we where able to see a show of the water puppet theater. It was great to see a theater like this. It is different from the one you know from Europe, but very nice to see.

Water Puppet Laughs. Again a must do in Hanoi. It is very cheap to go and although quite tedious and perhaps boring to some the music was amazing and it only lasts an hour. On the busiest corner in Hanoi

I WANT MORE!. I l.o.v.e. my puppets!! Puppets just make me happy and words are needless! No seriously - this is a very well orchestrated performance which exhibits vietnamese tales in a creative and authentic way accompanied by great live music! There are several performance during the day and night but if you are wanting to catch one on a weekend night buy your tickets in the morning or a day earlier! Enjoy!
Worth a visit. We enjoyed the show. Not too long, not too short. The puppeteers are quite skilled at creating their illusions. The introductions are in Vietnamese, English and French.

Admit it, you've been had.. When I read all the "must see" reviews, I can only think of that Dostoevsky short story -- where the protagonist pays a Franc to see the bearded lady at a carnival side show, and is underwhelmed. When he leaves the tent the barker, who is trying to lure other suckers, says, "Monsieur, was that not the most AMAZING thing you've ever seen?" And the guy doesn't want to admit he's been had, so he replies, "Oui, monsieur, it was truly amazing!"That has to be what's going on with the water puppets; some of you guys don't want to admit you fell for the hype (or you went because your tour took you), and you can't bring yourself to admit you were bored to tears and got ripped off.I'll give them one thing: the band consists of traditional Vietnamese instruments (with a modern bass guitar incongruously thrown in), so if you're a music buff the music will be interesting for 5 minutes. Unfortunately the show lasts an hour -- and even the kids were yawning. It's a puppet show, after all -- and the only novelty is that the puppets are in a tank of water, being manipulated from behind via poles, instead of from above or below in the usual fashion. There isn't even that much skill involved, from what I could tell.I know it's only 5 bucks; but is that all an hour of your life is worth? Skip it. Go shopping.

Entertaining. I got a second class ticket in row Q and could see the stage area with no issues. The show is entertaining and something different to do in Hanoi. For the cost of the ticket I would recommend it.
Absolutely different. I would have never expected a puppet show surprising me so much any more as this one. Really deserve the visit.

Well worth 5 dollars. Live Vietnamese band with good music. Well done show and good interaction with the water. You will be asked to pay to take pictures, but no one paid and just took pictures anyway.

Fun and worth the prize. I was in the 8pm show short before christmas and it was nearly booked. The show is very funny and interessting. It is about 50min with live music, singing and of course the water puppets. The only drawback is the very small seats... but ok for the time.

Really pleasant..... but not for the uncultured/ignorant. I really liked it.Okay, I'm not absolutely amazed by the experience but I think it's well worth going in with an open mind and taking it for what it is - a very very old traditional art that has been kept alive for so many years (that can only be a positive right??)It's only an hour- so even those who bore easily can't complain too much....What did it for me was the music, amazing and so nice to hear traditional stuff. The musicians were really talentedI AGREE THAT THE WOMAN SELLING THE TICKETS IS USELESS. May aswell put a puppet in the ticket booth..... full of water.

Intriguing if not compelling. I have been here several times in the past decade and it seems to be getting a bit tired, possibly resting on its laurels as something the increasing hoards of foreign tourists just "must do". It's worthwhile for a couple of hours, and tickets are quite cheap, but I would not weep if I could not get tickets next time. Hanoi is full of things to do, so this is not unmissable.
Loved it!. Although the theater is kind of dirty, the show was really good and interesting. I thought it would be on the lake though, but it is across from it. Definitely a 'must see' when in Hanoi.

Very cute, nice music, short if you don't think so. This is a cool way to see something semi-authentic, and the music seemed pretty different than things I'd ever heard, and if you're not into puppet shows its cheap and short, so if your wife says go, just say OK.

Make the ticket booth your first stop in Hanoi. Absolutely put this show at the top of your list of things to see and do in Hanoi. It was the highlight of our stay - a completely unique hour long show with incredible puppetry and engaging music and singing. Honestly, I'm not sure how this isn't ranked the #1 attraction in the city! Especially if you're staying in the Old Quarter, as we did, it's a great location and easily walkable.We booked our tickets our first day in Hanoi and already the best seats were sold out for many of the shows over the next couple days. I suggest stopping by soon after your arrival in town to get one of the better seats if you are visiting in a peak tourist season. Also, there are so many people taking pictures that if you wind up in the back, you'll see a sea of LCD camera displays.

Might be the most overrated attraction in Hanoi. Like everyone else, we saw the obligatory water puppet show during our recent visit to Hanoi. For all you hear about the show ahead of time you come in with pretty big expectations. Unfortunately the show failed to live up to those expectations for us.The show takes place in the cozy Thang Long auditorium in Hanoi. The main stage area features the pool where the the puppets perform, and off to the left is an area for a small "orchestra" and some vocalists. The show opens with a couple of musical numbers, followed by 11 short puppet acts (which are described in the program). I should note that the show did start on time when we visited.The musicians were perfectly good and demonstrated some specialty instruments that you won't see in the West. However, the puppetry left us feeling disappointed. I went into the show imagining complex puppetry actions, but most of the 11 acts were a particular set of puppets doing little more than bobbing left and right across the pool to the music. It frankly struck me as something a group of middle school kids might put on. Mercifully, the show is surprisingly short, otherwise I would have been asleep when the lights came back on.For whatever reason this has become an obligatory stop for visitors to Hanoi, so I doubt I will sway you not to visit. If you're on the fence about going, don't bother. If you missed the show, you really didn't miss much.

Something different and mildly authentic. LOGISTICSThe Thang Long Water Puppet Theater is located opposite Hoan Kiem Lake on the Northern side. It's a large building and it impossible to miss due to the faces on the front. It's 50,000 dong for a basic set and 100,000 dong for a seat in one of the first 10 rows (not necessarily a front row seat). There are around 5 shows a day at various times.PROS- The show is wonderful and something just completely different. I have never seen anything like this before and I enjoyed the uniqueness and enthusiasm of the performers.- The singers were great and the instruments they played were fantastic to listen to.- I guess it's somewhat 'authentic' for vietnam but you will have a tough time trying to find anyone who is Vietnamese in the audience.CONS- The show is in vietnamese so it's hard to understand what is going on. However, this is manageable considering you just enjoy the puppetry.- They need to ban camera flashes in the theatre. Because the entire theatre is filled with Westerners all sporting big canon cameras they often don't know how to use the first 5 minutes of the show is nothing more than flashes. It's annoying. If you have a camera you should definitely take pictures but turn your flash off for heavens sake. It's not hard!CONCLUSIONDefinitely worth a visit. This was the most enjoyable thing we did in the city of Hanoi.CONCLUSION
One lost hour. We are all told this is a must see, Think we are all being had, One hour of my life I can't get back!
Cultural Show. Kids enjoyed the puppets and music of this show. Not to long & cheap entertainment

Good TRADITIONAL enterteiment!. Expecting the worse we went to the puppet show and were pleasantly suprised- it's amusing, not too long, the price is fine and we did wonder how are the doing it?
A great way to start an evening in hanoi.

Not Just For Kids. A trip here was included as a part of our tour. Wasn't exactly looking forward to it, but turned out to be ok. Only lasted about 45 - 50 minutes, so not too much of a struggle. Lots of short segments, so no one part drags on for too long. The small live orchestra is good and you have to admire the skill of the puppeteers. Seats are a bit on the small side and visibility will be impaired by people taking photos. The gradient of the seating could do with being a bit steeper to minimise the impact of being stuck behind a tall person.
lovely. this is a must see in Vietnam.. fun, great traditional music and a good show.. but be sure to get a seat on front, so no head of a person will disturb your sight!

Fell asleep. Perhaps it was jet lag and then my daughter read her journal where she said at first she was excited but than she was bored, still a good listen to cultural music and an ancient form of entertainment. Worth the money for front row seats

A worthwhile watch. The show was great & funny! I thoroughly enjoyed myself at the show. The water puppet "art" is family tradition, so it was really cool to see the whole entertaining show. It is amazing how alive the puppets become by the skillful manipulations of the artists behind the scene. We had front row seats, so it was even more exciting to see everything up front with the puppets, effects, and other stuff! it's definitely a must see in Vietnam and worth your time & money.

Needs more legroom. The show I went to was all in Vietnamese. I'm not sure if they do specific languages at certain times, might be something to look into. Still fun to watch, but 45 mins was more than enough for me.Being over 6 feet tall my legs were mashed awkwardly into the seats in front of me. The seats are clearly designed for the shorter variety, and when the shows are full it can be pretty uncomfortable after 10-15 mins. If you are tall try to get an aisle seat.

Far too smokey. The other reviewers are on the mark. It's averagely cute and a good way to kill $5 a ticket and an hour of time.. But my number one complaint was the incredibly strong cigarette smoke that hung in the air of the theater. I'm not sure if it was from the cafe downstairs or from some of the puppets that breath a little smoke during the performance, but it was quite overpowering and could be clearly seen through the stage lights. Thank goodness for cheap laundry services in Hanoi!

Dont bother. Although the show gives you a little insight into Vietnamese culture, the show is in the native language, so the humor is lost on you. You get a basic idea of what each scene is about, but thats about it. 1st Class tickets in the front are VND100,000 and 2nd Class tickets are VND60,000. Dont spend the extra money, its all the same, theater is not very big.
Great entertainment. Must see for the whole family. Good theatrical redition of traditional Vietnamese life

Entertaining - nice way to kill an hour. The show itself is not really much to rave about - puppetry by people standing in the water, don't expect anything artistically advanced (other nations had developed much more advanced performing arts in the same time period) or something that will blow your mind. Very touristy - I was sitting in the third row and all the time, someone was in my way taking pictures so I couldn't see properly. Everything explained nicely in English and French, not all Vietnamese like some reviewers said. The musicians are stellar!

Great experience for young children. I took my 3-year old daughter here for her first theatre visit. She absolutely loved it, the water, the fire, along with the simplicity of the play is perfect for kids. Lovely traditional performance for grown-ups too.

A Cultural Must See.. Thanks to Tom at Hanoi Moment Hotel we had good seats. Close to the front is the best. Usually sold out so book early. The orchestra performance was outstanding with Vietnamese instruments utilized. The orchestra performance alone is worth the very cheap admission price. The performance was something you really need to experience rather than have be tell you. Gil
spectacular!. wonderful experience! the artists were so talented! I definitely will come back
Not my thing.... Should've known better, but the water puppets were just a total tourist trap.
Something completely different. Theatre was very crowded with terrible legroom. Performance was enjoyable and completely unique.
Not to be missed. One of the highlights of our trip to Hanoi - spectacular performance in an original and authentic setting
Ok. While it is quite interesting, but for those who can't understand Vietnamese, it can get a little boring during the 40-min show.
Worth the hype. The Puppet show in Hanoi has great reviews and I can see why! Although it is very busy and the seating is compact, the show is fantastic and worth the visit.

A fun night out. Loved this show. Something quite uniquely Vietnam. All the seats are fine, so don't worry if you can't buy the good ones. Book a day or two in advance to avoid missing out, especially if you only have a short time in Hanoi.

Dedicated performers with a perspective on culture. We booked our tickets through Art Hotel Hanoi and got a 3.30pm show, front row tickets.Many reviews mentioned that it was a boring show but since I am of an South-East Asian background, I could relate to the stories being told. Of course the stories could have been better. The show is 45 minutes long and the theater is quite dark. Try not to use flash photography as it really is disturbing to the performers and audience. It starts off with festival drumming where if you look at the troupe, you would see some interesting instruments being played. The puppet show includes a chapter on horse racing, buffalo fighting, village guardian procession. All these are played out by puppeteers behind curtains manipulating the poles their puppets are on, in waist high water. If you find stories on village life boring, you may either skip this show or sit through it with an open mind.There was a scene listed in the playbill about Quan Ho singing and a few people around us remarked they don't know why the singer was caterwauling. Actually it is no different from listening to Chinese opera. The story in this segment are songs sung between men and women during a yearly festival. The puppets show a 2 processions, one with a male sitting in a palanquin and the other female. It reflects a period in history where men and women were segregated and it is not sightly to see a male being alone with a woman without chaperons. So during the festival, the male may sing a song to his heart's choice without being reprimanded. At the end of the song, both male and female return to their own palanquins and go on their way. Try get any show before 5pm because it will leave you with time to go to the lake and after the show take an early ice-cream snack at Fanny's. Tickets are at VND100,000. Pre-book your tickets through your hotel to avoid disappointment. It is a show that you would watch only once for the experience and value the dedicated performers.
Step back in time. Wonderful respite and restful treat after a crazy day dodging scooters!

Not super exciting, but worth the visit.. This show was something different to see. It is not expensive. Although it was not the highlight of my trip, I would recommend it to others. You will not see anything else like it anywhere.

Excellent Entertainment. We greatly enjoyed the show put on at the Water Puppet theatre. The audience at such shows are mostly tourists, so we were wondering if the show would turn out to be gimmicky and suchlike, but we were pleasantly surprised to see how the water puppet experience has been kept authentic. the puppets themselves don't look especially intricate (from row H), but we were certainly mesmerized by the fluid intricacy of the actions created by the puppeteers. We were (and still are!) trying to puzzle out how the puppets didn't get cross-tangled in each other. The musical group accompanying the puppet show should also be commended for adding to the atmospheric performance.

Entertainingly kitsch. The tickets cost around £2 and the show lasts 45mins so from this perspective, it is worth going just to experience it. The puppets were somewhat in need of some tender loving care and the routines were entertaining as they were quite bad (let's just say they weren't always quite synchronised as I suspect they were meant to be). However, the live band were fantastic with some great singing and traditional instrument-playing. Worth going for an entertaining evening.
Don't expect too much..... Just think for a moment that its one hundred years ago and see how people got entertained before there were 3D cinema's. Its fun to see especially for children.

interesting but later boring. it is interesting at first but it's not long before you can understand the same trick. You might get bored after 30 mins and fall asleep. But it's only inexpensive ticket so I would still encourage people to experience this show.

worth the experience. Definitely worth a go. You'll see nothing like this back at home. It's all in vietnamese, but you get a little booklet, so you know whats going on. Lasts about 45 mins, so its not too long. Seats are a bit cramped, but its worth the pain!!
Good experience. This was an interesting experience, not one I would repeat but for the cost and an hour's performance it was well worth visiting.

An interesting insight into vietnamese culture. Good to see the water puppets, a colourful show, accompanied by nice traditional music, an art that started in the rice fields of Vietnam to entertain villagers. Very busy, I think you have to book/purchase tickets prior to the performance time you want.

A great diversion for an hour, very cleverly performed. We got the "VIP" seats for 100,000 dong which meant we were a little closer to the action, but the theatre is quite small so the 60,000 dong seats are probably not that bad either. The puppet show is very well done, and is basically a collection of scenes accompanied by a 9 piece orchestra. They use fire and smoke with the puppets too - children will love it, and adults will marvel at the ingenuity of the rig. Definitely worth a visit.

Extremely engaging - one to see. I was a bit reluctant to see the water puppets despite it being one of the headline tourist attractions in Haoi - I am just not really a performing arts kind of guy. But I went after chatting with various other fellow travellers, and I am quite glad that I did.It is a little difficult to explain exactly what the show is. It is a blend of performing arts, comedy, history and music. It all comes together pretty well for an enjoyable 45 minutes or so. I suspect a longer show might well have felt like a drag, but they pitched it about right in terms of length.The main attraction is the water puppets themselves. As it sounds, these are puppets that are manipulated from rods below the water rather than strings from above. It is very cleverly done, and almost "acrobatic" if that makes sense. I didn't see many children in the theatre but I am sure kids would have been delighted. The music is suprisingly haunting, even if you don't like traditional Asian music.It is expensive by Vietnamese standards (100,000 Dong, or US$5.00), but still less than a cinema ticket in the West. Announcements are in English, French and Vietnamese, but the performance itself is only in Vietnamese. But, like the opera, even if you don't understand the words, it is pretty easy to follow what is going on - these are not sophisticated plotlines!Couple of tips: get your tickets early (or possibly even day before), as they do sell out quite fast. Also, most people prefer the evening showing, but I think it works better in the afternoon - makes a nice break in the cool of the theatre from the heat of Hanoi.

The puppet fun.. The first time I went to Vietnam, as well as my first water puppet show. I'm very interestingwith puppets made of wood is synchronized swimming. Although I do not understand the contents of the play but I like the excellent art as well as the puppets look like this.
Never seen anything like this. Our boys (9 yrs and 7 yrs) really enjoyed this unique puppet show. Also interesting for mum and dad!

Ok but music was wonderful. The water puppet display was a little ho hum but the small group of musicians beside the theater was fantastic, I would have paid just to see them play their traditional instruments.
A Must See. The whole show is fantastic, definitely worth a visit.

Great music - fun show.. This is one of the "must do" things for visitors to Hanoi but it proved quite difficult getting a first-class ticket. No matter when we asked or how far in advance we requested first-class tickets we were always told that none were available. One day we took our chances and turned up for the 15.30 show right at that time and got the last two tickets - right in the front row! So you have to be persistent - I think they keep the best seats for tour groups. Anyway, the show was fun and the music and singing really appealled to me - it was certainly worth the entry price as far as I was concerned (10,000Dh).

Folk entertainment with live musicians/singers. This is certainly one of the more popular shows in Hanoi with a series of shows running through out the day. Essentially it is a puppet show with a water feature where the puppeteers are hidden behind a bamboo chick screen.It starts off with a live traditional band and soon puppets are brought in to depict life in the countryside. Although in Vietnamese, you can easily understand the stories. It ends with a fantastic dragon dance. The entire show is less than an hour. Tickets are priced around USD3-5.The show is not for everyone, I see some members of the audience yawning away and being bored. However if you wish to see some local culture, this would be one of the shows to catch.

cultural but three of us fell asleep. it was interesting, very culturally enlighting but we all kept falling asleep. The girls liked it more than the guys... they fell asleep - not everyones cup of tea

Interesting. I had never before seen a Water Puppet show so I'm glad I went. It was a bit touristy and for me the music was too loud and seemed to overpower the puppets. Was it great ... No. But it was very interesting and was only USD $5. I would keep it on a "to do" list but it should not be at the top. They have many shows per day, so you can probably squeeze it in during some free time.

highly recommended - a must see in Hanoi.. There are five shows a day so you can book it at the door - the fixed price will be the same; Your hotel staff can buy the tickets in advance for you for the same price.

Entertaining!. We had to book tickets in advance as it was very busy and didn't want to miss this.
Amazing show and how the puppets are manouvered in water and colourful costumes.
Lovely live music with singers and large theatre!
Only complaint was alot of mosquitoes or bugs as got alot of bites on the legs!!
Still worth seeing the show!

A nice glimpse at a Vietnam tradition. Get there early to get your tickets. We ended up in the last row, and the leg room was very limited, but the show was great! It was a nice glimpse into vietnamese culture, and it was very reasonably priced.

Definitely a Must See in Ha Noi. The Water Puppet theatre is a must see attraction when visiting Ha Noi. Only about one hour session, it is popular so you must book ahead. Most hotels seem to offer the booking service, but it is beside the lake and easy to find to book yourself (for the next day).Photography is allowed and the theatre fills rapidly. Reserve a front seat if you can as back rows have limited (and distant) vision. The puppets are not small but from the back appear so. There is a significant amount of music involved. You spend a lot of time wondering how they actually do what they do. It is something you must do even on a restricted stay in the city. Certainly not expensive. Enjoy a real cultural experience.

very touristy. the theater is always very crowed, the seat rows are very small and you do not have a lot of place. The show itself was very touristy in our eyes. This was one of the attractions, that we could have skipped.
interesting, but.... Ihe performance is an hour which is enough. the women enjoyed it more than the men. It would be helpful if there was more information about the stories on the program.

Something different found nowhere else. Bored of the norm cinema...here's a good place for a different kind of show....see the local culture and interesting to watch them (the puppets) performing in the water.

Traditional Water Puppet Theatre was enjoyable. Traditional singers and musicians accompany the water puppets as they tell stories of ancient times. Not very loing, about an hour and al the seats are good enough and it only costs 60 VND. I paid as much for my coffee at the cafe next door. Easy to find right on the Lake.
different. worth a look at this ancient theatre craft; the musicians were wonderful and the puppetry fascinating.
Interesting Show. I found the storytelling a bit thin, but the performance was interesting due to the unique style of bringing the puppets to life via the water venue.
Very different. When in Hanoi you must see this, the show is very well done and was a great cultural thing to see. VIP seats get you near the front, probably worth the extra money.

Entertaining. This water puppet show, although clearly targeted on toursists, is very entertaining, the music is very nice and the pupetteers incredibly talented. It's mostly in Vietnamese. Tickets are $3 or $5, and there are lots of show times. Even the back row seats are pretty good.

Well worth 1st class seat. Book ahead as 1st class seats sell fast. We managed to get 1st class seats for an afternoon show the following day from the ticket office. Our men folk were not overly keen but now think it was one of the highlights of Hanoi. A short show of less than an hour with lots of variety of characters, surprises and amusing too.

Got tickets last minute and glad I went. I originally did not plan on going to the water puppet show but after getting to Hanoi, I decided I wanted to see it. Getting tickets was difficult as the shows fill up fast, but our hotel was able to get us tickets from someone who had cancelled. I'm glad I was able to see this. It was only 45 minutes long so I didn't get bored and was a cute way to spend an evening watching the puppets and listening to the music. Programs are provided in many languages so you are able to follow what is going on. Overall I'm glad I could do this but definitely recommend getting your tickets in advance!
My wife's - must do!. Great art form - with a great history (of it's origin). Don't miss this Hanoi icon.They have changed the stories this year, so return even if you've seen it before.
Interesting to see once. It's interesting for a first timer, just because the idea of water puppets is unique to me.
Amazing. Comfortable seats and an art form requiring great skill.

Great fun to watch! Love the authentic music. A step away from the hustle and bustle of the old quarter. An hour of lively entertainment in a purpose built theatre. Very efficient in and out ( there are loads of shows daily). Colourful , musical and very reasonable price. Very nice bar to the right of the entrance where you can watch the world go by !
So, so. A cultural show but did not understand the shows meaning or story.

Average. The water puppet show was included in our trip and so we watched the show but it was not fit to my idea of ''having a good time'' It's a part of the viatnemese culture so it's good to see it while you are there but if you have limited time you might like to spend it in somewhere else and you wouldn't miss much!

Something different. This one is on water.. Your first thought would be 'Gosh, are there divers underwater holding up those puppets?'This place is located next to Hoan Kiem lake, where you can walk around while waiting for your show. Be sure to pick up AND READ the little english leaflet otherwise you wont know whats going on at all. The whole show is in Vietnamese, but is still enjoyable. The fee was 60,000VND (~USD3) for standard seats and 100,000VND (~USD5) for first class (closer to stage). All seats are numbered.

Good fun. While it did feel a little strange watching a puppet show in Vietnamese in a room full of non-Vietnamese adults, it was a fun, light-hearted experience. Something to tick off from the list of things to do.
Entertaining. Enjoyable theatre - loved the music, enjoyed the puppets, missed some of the story lines but that did not detract from the experience.

unique experience. This was a really cool experience, very unique and unlike anything you'd see outside of Vietnam. They have a program that gives a short overview of each segment that they do which we found pretty helpful to understand what's going on. Also, it's worth buying the better seats, you end up sitting much closer, better for taking pictures and such, and the price is only a few dollars more. Fun way to spend an evening.

Unique. The theatre on the opposite side of the Hoan Kiem Lake(in line with the bridge to Thap Rua).Buy the cheaper tickets,view is always great.They are several performances a day,so it's not necessary to buy tickets in advance.Dress code: casual.It's a highlight for all and I think unique in the world and very exciting.

Something for women and children. My boyfriend did not like it. The man seating next to me also slept for 40 minutes. I had fun. Never saw something like this. It's worth an 1-time visit. I also liked the music very much. Especially one song and the story describing the history of this song.
Must see in Hanoi. Simply the must see thing. You cannot see it any where else. Here is also he place where you can see and understand the local life and belief. Also here is the home land of puppet.
Water Puppets are a treat for young and old !. Have been to the Water Puppet show twice now, heve enjoyed each performance, very talented puppeteers.

Excellent!. Beautiful music from a live orchestra and singers, fascinating and beautifully made puppets. Dont bother trying to photograph things with a normal camera - there isn't enough light - just enjoy it, Evenings book up quickly so book ahead or go to a morning show.
A must see for every visitor. Great and interesting performance of an ancient vietnamese custom.

Just to experience the Vietnamese culture. As part of experiencing Vietnamese culture, you shouldn't miss this show. Even though we didn't understand the language, still, it was a great experience wathing them perform and sing. Puppets' movements were quite lively, just wonder how they did it as the platform was water. As 1 of the tourist attractions, there were many tourists in the theatre, as expected. Just that their seats weren't that comfortable. It could be a disaster for those with longer lengs.Overall, still worth visiting.

Good show but repetitive. The puppets are enjoyable except it gets a little old after 30 minutes, so the last 30 are a bit "long". The music (live) on the other hand is enjoyable and the performers very good.

Hilarious - definitely worth doing.... It is important to remember that this show is super cheap by western standards. In terms of me understanding what was going on in the show I will be honest and most of it was lost on me. But I still enjoyed it. The skill involved and technique is very impressive and it is interesting to see how deep the water is - at the end the performers wade through it.I probably wouldn't do this again but I was glad that I did it. The 50 minutes or so went past quite quickly.Some will hate this show - I saw people walking out halfway through the performance and kids may get bored.In terms of rating I would give this maybe a 3.5/5. Good and worth doing but probably not a must-do.

Great Puppet Show. The Water Puppet Theater is situated above the Helios Coffee House. The show is a wonderful experience and the music is out of this world. My friends and I definitely enjoyed the show very much.

Fun! Not That Touristy. After reading so much about this being a touristy thing to do, we were pleasantly suprised. We attended on a local holiday so there were as many locals there as westerners and all seemed to enjoy themselves. The puppetry was good, but not as technical as I expected it to be. But the music and the singing were amazing and well worth the meagre price of admision.

Happy story. Nice and happy story. Interesting how they can play the puppet in the water. Very difficult to get the tickets. The hotel tried to get us the tickets but unsuccessful. In the end, we went there to try our luck, managed to get the more expensive ticket 100k VND, instead of the 60k VND ticket.

Colorful experience. The kids really liked this performance. And as adults it is also easy to get impressed by the skills of the performers. There is no dialogue in any of the scenes shown. But they did give us a sheet which listed what happened in the different scenes so there was no problem following what was happening.

Timeless. A great tradition in Hanoi. The theater is a bit old and musty, but then thats the charm of the place. The show is fun, the kids loved it and it was short enouigh so that the gimic didn't wear thin. Recomended if you have an hour to kill in Hanoi.
Surprising good. It is certainly a good experience on watching this show. Not to miss to see the culture of Vietnam at a glance and its performance

A must - interesting. An interesting place - and one of the best attractions for Hanoi. The theatre is average and the puppets are getting worn and aged. Staff are rude and obstinate and allow people to continually walk in and out of the theatre.
SUPERB!. Unique, wonderful puppetry and would have liked to revisit.
unique. lovely to see a unique show, something that you will remember for a long time
great fun. My 8 year old son loved it and I was amazed as well. Definitely a highlight of Hanoi for us.

Very clever. It was a little hard to understand the story and although we had first class seats I found it very hard to see. It was very clever it beautiful musical instruments. We would have been happy if the show was half the length. Worth seeing.
Fun and interesting. Don't be late, as you need time to read the program to understand the different scenes that are a part of the show. So enjoyable and so well presented.
Better than expected. I wasn't quite sure what to expect but this was charming
Great show!!!. For the extra money, take the 100,000 dong seats. These are the first two rows. Otherwise you may end up 20 rows back. The difference is 2 USD per seat !!!
Different. An unusual intertainment in a quirky little theatre. Great music and something unusual.

Lightehearted fun plus an insight into country life.. This show is really charming, full of life and simple humour. It concentrates on scenes from traditional farmers' lives, and gives you a window on their world. The music on traditional instruments is melodious and very different to traditional Chinese music.
glad it was only an hour long. Seen one you have seen them all. Seats were close and the show was okay, but unless I was taking kids I would pass.

Do not miss this age old entertainment - its glorious.. Be sure to go and book your tickets in advance so as not to miss this - we went a day in advance, its close ot the hotel so if you can go early in the morning to ensure a seat.

Different experience. Disliked the rude and disinterested ticket seller.
The puppet show was however worth the time and effort. A must-see ! Do buy tickets in advance if possible and get first class tickets if you wish to take pictures.
Boring!!. It was one of worse show I've even been. The water puppet is badly organise and the show was absolutely boring!!! We left 15 minutes later. There were a couple of people left before us too.

Cheapest puppet show in the world. The tour guide translated and summarized the story of the play for us so it was easy to catch up with what’s going on. The music sounds like Chinese but the puppet’s clothes were undeniable Vietnamese. More favourable, the ticket price is very cheap and same price for all seats so you’d better come early to take the good ones near the water stage.

tourist trap. Beware of this tourist trap, I'm sure this place is only busy as it seems to be on many people's "to do" list by default, and by the time you're walking out of there it's all too late, you've wasted and hour of your time, unless of course like me you used it as valuable nap time to recover from jetlag.

Interesting. I went to see this as I had always wanted to watch one when visiting Vietnam. I had seen these on tv before so kind of knew what to expect. It was about $3 USD for entry. The staff at the door tried to get people to pay extra for using cameras even though you don't need to. It went for about an hour. By half an hour I was itching to go. It was interesting but because the show is in Vietnamese, it was a bit of a drag to keep up with whats going on (unless you're really paying attention). They play traditional instruments which was cool.

Amazing. The guide book said this was something that must be done in Hanoi, and it was right. We had no idea what was in store for us. Watching the show was amazing. And affordable. Get your tickets early.

Worth Seeing. It's worth seeing. I was not blown away. I was really looking forward to it, so I may have been expecting too much, it is pretty amazing though if you are into puppetry. If you are really big or tall, be aware that the seats are very tight and you may be uncomfortable in the theater.

An excellent show for all ages. We attended the Thang Long theater during our stay in Hanoi. This was one attraction that I definitely wanted to see. We tried to go on our second day in Hanoi, but these shows sell out quickly, so we got shut out. The next day we got there around 10 AM and there already was a line, but we were able to get tickets for the performance. This puppet show is for all ages, children will like the puppets, and it's amazing what the puppet masters can do in the water. It was thoroughly enjoyable, and I would highly recommend it if you are staying in Hanoi.

tourist attraction , water puppets. was ok , english translation would have helped . didnt have a clue what was going on . Also only trourists there , lot of overhead camera clicking blocking the few for us behind them . Better if there was a sigh NO CAMERAS PLEASE

Enjoyable. Cute little theatre and a fun show to watch. Definitely worth a visit if you are in Hanoi. Our two young boys enjoyed it too. I would try and get seats in the first 1-3 rows though as it was quite hard to see further back.
Worth a laugh. return to your childhood for a bit and enjoy the talant of the puppetiers. Well done.
Must see. Its worth seeing, water puppet is something worth looking at, for fun, to understand a little bit of the life of Vietnamese sailors and their life.

Nice show, don't miss it. it was a nice show and worth the VND100,000. show is in Vietnamese but they have brochures in english etc. 45mins show with some local instruments and the puppet show. Just do not take the taxis waiting outside after the show,they will rip you off.walk a few steps away and take those taxis that are passing by

Interesting art form. Good music, interesting art form.
The play is in Vietnamese (naturally!), so a little hard to follow the action, but quite interesting nonetheless.
Unique experience. Definitely one of the must sees if it is your first time in vietnam...don't skimp on the seats...get one closer to the front

It's only in local language. You don't understand what's happening. It's only in local language. You don't understand what's happening. You can read the text in English, aldo is dark insight, so there is no possibility to read it during the play.
A bit disappointing. Maybe interesting if you go with kids otherwise it looks a bit boring although it is very cheap and takes less than one hour of your time
highly recommended~!. A very interesting show until I was shocked when the show ended, felt that 45 minutes is not enough for me.

Disappointing and dull. Guide books will tell you this is a must do. If you are short on time don't worry too much if you give it a miss. We booked tickets a day in advance but not really necessary. Local musicians accompany puppets operated by others using long poles under water. The first 5 minutes it's something different but the next 30, you want to be somewhere else having a beer! I guess this is a cultural thing for the locals...
Cultural fun. A cheap event and one of the significant cultural events in which you can participate. Amusing popular & simple but could use some explanation.

Different but not all that great!. Coming from America, we tend to make comparisons and with modern technology, there is nothing spectacular outside of the U.S. The water puppet show is okay and need to view just once but did not impress me in any way.

Cheesy, boring. We did not enjoy this. I'm pretty open minded to things like this, love theatre, the arts, etc. I had read about this and asked a couple how they liked it. They really enjoyed it and said it was funny. Guess we didn't get the humor too much. Appreciated the programs in various languages to describe what was going on. I was interested to see how the puppets worked but that was about it. Found in very unprofessional that the two of the puppeteers while taking their bow were talking to each other - seriously? You're on stage for 2 min, can't you table your conversation? We would not go back and would not recommend seeing this. Had we not been seated in the middle of the row we probably would have walked out. Also, because you are allowed to take pictures for an additional fee most of the performance felt like a strobe light with all the people taking flash pictures the entire time.
A Must See Experience. For the cutural experience it was completly enjoyable.
It was a novelty, but we consider it average. It's puppets in water, so they are small and difficult to see, but it's a novelty and good to experience once. Then you can say you saw it :-)
Cheesy and not worth the time. I'm glad we went and saw the water puppets. My feet needed a break from walking around, but if you're between the ages of 20-35 this probably isn't for you!

maybe just not my thing. Ive been to a number of local shows around asia and perhaps this is why my review rates this as mediocre but i must say that we were not too inspired by this show. Its not that the show is poor, its essentially a puppet show on water - its just theres not much too it... like i said, puppets on water. Also worth noting that the leg room is not designed for westerners so if you are above 6ft then prepared to be cramped

Water puppets. Wasn't sure if it would be great - looked online and saw some You Tube video - it looked terrific. It was 45 minutes long. The time flew by. The orchestra was great and the puppets very colourful and entertainiing.
very funny. it is show to worth see. it cost 5$ for first class and 2,5$ for seconde place, but I recommend you to by the first class . It is near by Hoan Kiem Lake. book it in advance for sure

unique show!. although it's only 45 minutes, we enjoy the show as we have never seen this before on other part of the world! Just that we don't really understand the conversation of it... otherwise it's worth seeing... Please book/buy the ticket early (preferblely 1 to 2 days before as it sold out fast)... and if possible choose the front row of seat if you want to take photos (USD1 extra for camera and USD4 extra for view cam)...
Water puppets. A must do because of the traditional aspect but I wouldn't go back again.
culture. This puppet theatre has improved since we visited 11yrs ago. Very clever and gives a nice I site to life in vietnam

Traditional Puppets - think in context!. We've lived in Vietnam for a year, and have heard about the puppet show. Hanoi's puppet theatre is reportedly the best in the country. Keep in in context, don't forget that you're witnessing a cultural practice from 1000 years ago. Read up on it first, as it will make for a more interesting show.
Excellent performance. Well worth a visit, this unique performance runs for 45 minutes and should be fitted in to your itinerary.

Good at the start, gets boring later on.. Has very high acclaimed, probably coz' it's the only thing to do in the Old Quarter aside from walking around and shopping. Also, guess it's coz it's deeply rooted in culture. Apparently all their shows run housefull on all days.There's a live band playing music and singing (a couple of really good voices) and a group of people behind the curtain who manipulate the puppets using long rods under water. It's fun at the start marvelling at the art form, but gets repetitive after a while. The songs are all in Vietnamese, so you can't really follow what's going on. The theatre itself, although clean and air conditioned, is very cramped. There's absolutely no leg room when seated. So much so that if anybody's trying to get past you, you have to stand up and fold back the seat.

Vietnamese Culture. The Vietnamese are said to be the pioneers this performance craft. We have three young children (ages 8, 7, 5.5) and while they were entertained they were more entertained by trying to figure out how the puppets worked.The performance we saw was in Vietnamese but the simple story lines made it easy to figure out. The unique music instruments and traditional song were a enjoyable exposure to Vietnamese culture.Book early because the seats fill up quickly.

Very charming ! Do not miss it. Quite unusual and very beautiful puppet theater. Movements of the wood dolls over the water are fascinating to follow, the stories are well presented (and understandable), and the live music entertaining. Do not miss this !

A must see. I was skeptical about a puppet show but this was amazing!! I really enjoyed the music and the puppets and am so glad I went. I think that this is a must stop for every visitor to Hanoi.My one recommendation is to ask for an isle seat or front row for taller people since the rows aren't that widely spaced

Quaint & interesting show, beautiful traditional music. The traditional music was a highlight. It was impressive to think about how they operate the puppets. Some of the performance pieces were briefer than I hoped, but it was still great. The poor puppets could do with a face-lift - some of them are well worn!
must see. very colourful and amusing performance. sit fairly close to the front as the undisciplined tourists keep taking flash pictures which i found very annoying.

An Amazing Experience. I was on a tour in Vietnam and was given the opportunity to break my days activities to go to the Water Puppets.
I was amazed and would reccommend anybody to see this magic show and will always remember it

Amazing!. It was an absolute pleasure taking in a show at teh theater. I didn't know what to expect, and it can't really be compared to anything else I've seen. The music was beautiful, and the experience unforgettable.
For young and old alike. Our kids loved it, and so did we. If you are in Hanoi on the weekend, make sure you book in advance, as the place does sell out.

Very Entertaining. The theater is old and musty and the exterior was dusty and not so well-kept BUT (and it's a huge BUT) the show was awesome. I have no idea of what the characters were saying, but the show gave me an insight to the cultural and historical background of Vietnam...The singers/actors have excellent voices and the musicians were equally talented.All in all, I loved it!
Well done show. Obviously aimed at tourist, but a good way to preserve an ancient art form. Worth the hour.
Worth watching. One of its kind, very interesting worth watching. The price is reasonable. Everybody should visit at less once.

Interesting. Ticket office opened at 1.15pm so don't rush to get there first thing in the morning. I've seen the water puppets in Saigon and rate the one in Hanoi much higher. The theatre is a proper theatre and the show had many more elements than the one in Saigon. I think the show lasted about an hour and there are several sessions in the afternoon and into the evening. Good fun.

A performance you will enjoy. If you visit Hanoi then you have to see this show. The ticket price is so good and they will amuse you with their performance. it is a 45 minute show so you will not be bored at all. I saw the show on my first day in Hanoi so I asked the hotel to book tickets for me. The show was so full as I expected.
Not worth the effort. Better to spend the evening enjoying a leisurely dinner.. The Water Puppet Theater is highly overrated. Maybe it would be fun for children, but we were happy when it was over.

I've never seen anything like it. This water puppet show what not exactly what I expected, but it was actually very good. The music was nice and the volume was pleasant. There was some fire works and some laughters. It's only about 50 min long, but the ticket price is 5 dollars, so it's still good value for money. Our 2-year old absolutely loved it and wanted to go back the next day.Make sure that you get tickets to the front rows. We were at the absolute front and you can't get too close since the stage is in a waterfilled pool in front of you.
Unique and Entertaning. We enjoy the show, it reflact the culture and historical of old Hanoi.

Much better than I expected - worth the money. This is a puppet show in an indoor theater. They have proper seats - with reserved seating tickets. We bought the 'first class' seats which are closer to the front (US$5 each). There is a live music ensemble that plays. The puppet show was very good - great puppets, lighting, music and singing. It goes for 50 mins. Apparently the Vietnamese farmers would make the puppets to entertain themselves during the wet season. Well worth the time and money - it's very entertaining.
A Must excellent entertainment. Our guide recommended that we see a show and we are so glad we took his advise, it was great.

Music was great.. Okay if this is your first time to veitnam then you definatly have to see it. It does not really matter where you sit. The musicians and their instruments were great. On our show they needed to Do some maintenance with the puppets as a number if them broke and we could here them talking behind. I have seen them in Saigon and they were much more professional and then stories more interesting.

Amazing culture show. You probably have never seen such type of theater before. The stage is a kind of a pond, the puppeteers are standing behind some bamboo curtain invisible for the people. They tell a story consisting of multiple acts, even involving some special effects.Music is played live by musicians next to the stage.You are allowed to take pictures or movies, but are requested to pay a small fee for it. If you book early you can select seats close to the stage.
Cute shows. We sit quick far away, please choose the seat infront. The show all in Vietnam language, but there is a leaflet in explanation in different languages. Good to watch.

book the front row. The puppet show is really worth seeing and the traditional music brilliant, but the seats are not well tiered at this venue so if possible book ahead and book seats in the front row.

45mins nice entertainment but they could skip the French announcement. This show is a kind of MUST for tourists and I think it was a nice 45mins entertainment for the 100k VND (ca. 4 EUR) entrance fee - they could charge more as it's always fully booked (we bought tickets 2 days in advance! at their own counter) - for locals this is expensive as equivalent to a complete meal for 2 at a simple Pho-restaurant...The Announcement in French could be skipped as most people in the world speak English in 2011 :-)Please note that if you are tall and big the seats are somewhat uncomfortable as you can't stretch your feet at all.... Otherwise GREAT - go for it!

Well Worth A Visit!!. This show is a must see whilst you are in Hanoi and shows the tradition of Vietnam. There is wonderful music played on traditional instruments to accompany the puppets. The introduction is spoken in Vietnamese, English and French. The rest is in Vietnamese but you can tell what is going by the puppets and also the leaflets that can be picked up as you enter the theatre. You can either buy type 1 tickets which are 60.000 VND (3USD) and those are the seats at the back part of the theatre or you can buy type 2 tickets which are 100.000VND (5USD) which are located at the front of the theatre. I recommend type 2 tickets as there is a better view. The time of the shows from Monday-Friday are 15:30 17:00 18:30 20:00 21:15. The show times for Sundays are: 9:30AM with 50% off for children. Each show is about 45 minutes long. I really enjoyed this show.
Traditional music and instrument a must for music lovers. Great show, time went very quick so you know it was entertaining. Traditional flavour enjoyed by our family.

Punch and Judy in water. Well I am not a huge puppet fan but thought we should see the local culture. It was OK but laster for 45 minutes and had to hang around for a while before it began. It is worth going to see just for the live music performance and it is nice but would not go out of your way to see it.

Give this a miss. Have you ever been to a high school play? well this is the level of the production. I expected complex puppet theatre and I got a very amature performace that acually made me laugh for all the wrong reasons.

A must see in Hanoi !. We went to the water puppet show because one of our travel guides (National Geographic) had two pages about it. We paid a little more for better tickets (still a cheap attraction) for the show at 20:00, and we were on the fourth row. I must say that we really enjoyed the whole show, even my teenager son. The music was beautiful and it made us enjoy the beauty of the water puppet show and the stories they related. Overall, the show is very funny and I think that people of any age would enjoy it.When I was there, about 10 people arrived after the beginning of the show and disturbed everybody, so please be on time at the show.
waste of time !!!. This show is a hyep and a real waste of time.Water theater show is a old and lost art in Vietnam, and for a good reason.
