Worth a watch, if you have the time. The show was entertaining, and the manner in which the show was delivered was fascinating for young couples like us who are more used to cinemas and LED TVs. Downside, the theatre was very very old, seats were narrow, and not being able to understand Vietnamese made it rather boring as we approached the later parts of the show. Worth a watch, if you have the time.

Amusing. This is an interesting show since you can not find such show in every country. It is nice to watch how skillful they played the puppet on the water although they used vietnam language. But you can still enjoy it. Anyway, the ticket price is quite cheap.It is better to book this show from tour guide to make sure you got the tickets

Worth the trip for $3. The show was fun to watch and the music was beautiful. It was quite short but we all decided that it was the perfect amount of time to see the historical art without it becoming a drag. A great site to check out before dinner to enjoy a few laughs.
Keeping the culture alive. We thoroughly enjoyed every minute of this excellant performance. The musicians are fantastic, the puppets were amazing. A show not to be missed - great value for money!

Not for everyone. We wnt to this show as we thought it would be entertaining for our 10 & 7 yr olds. After the first puppet act my 10 yr old stated she wAs bored as she couldn't understand the story line. We all enjoyed the orchestrA more then the puppets. We have spent over 4 weeks in vn over the last 1 yr and visited many museums, attractions and this is the first time my children have lost interest so quickly. There are more interesting things in Hanoi to see.

My kids love it. Maybe it is only me, but i felt asleep.I don't find it interesting nor exciting.I guess it is a age group thing.My 6 year old son practically gave it a standing ovation.He wanted to watch it again straight away.

interesting performance. A piece of Vietnamese culture that they are fiercely proud of. We were quite amazed at the dexterity of the puppeteers and actually enjoyed the show more than we thought we would. An essential part of a visit to Hanoi for sure! Do go to the theatre to get tickets early tho and get the first-class seats which are cheap by any standards.
A must see spectacle. One of the most authentic experiences in Vietnamese culture you will find.

Is good to remain some traditional show rather than extinct. The show start with a group of people playing Vietnamese traditional music instruments. The music is quite good. Actually I feel bored watching the show, cause the ladies who sing for the show when puppet dancing on water using Vietnamese language that I can't understand at all. I only can based on the puppet show to understand that this shows actually showing Vietnamese life as farmer, praying for rain then dragon brings rain, some dance for ceremony, couple meeting from boat. Its hard job to control the puppet using stick from behind the scene. This shows attracts people who like traditional show. Since this show inheritance for long time ago. Front seat is 100,000d and back seat is 60,000d.

Hilarious. The puppets were really old. The whole show was hilarious, my husband and I could not stop laughing the whole show. The music however made up for the puppets. It was beautifully played and sung. Overall had a good time because of the atmosphere and the music and being able to have a good laugh.

Funny show. Thang long water puppet theater was the great place after you had long trip outside Hanoi. The ticket was a bonus from minmax travel for our trip. the show was very impressive and creative with Vietnamese story. It coming up with all authentic life in Vietnam. amazing performance in a pool of water.

Very unique. I thought this show was really unique, entertaining and special. I just wish they banned viewers from using their cameras. Half of the audience was taking pictures, with flash, and it was really distracting from the entire performance.

A fun hour for $3. My girlfriend and I heard about water puppets. It was to purchase tickets- bought tickets for our show about an hour before it started. It was also assigned seats so no need to que up early. You can get closer seats for $5 but we got the cheaper seats for $3. We were in the last row but still saw everything. The show was all Vietnamese but cool live music and puppets of course were fun and cute. Not a must see but if you have an hour to spare it's worth it

Entertaining tourist attraction. Shows run at vartous times throughout the day and while attended entirely by tourists it reallyis entertaining, if a brief 45 minutes. Out guide satayed to watch expaining that though he has seen it many times the show varies and he li8kes the music,

Enjoyable!. I thought the water puppets were thoroughly entertaining, set against traditional Vietnamese music, there were different segments and different types of water puppets being used. From fighting dragons, to flying butterflies, jumping fish, to scenes of farming, fishing, rowing, it was a new experience and I enjoyed every minute of it!

Very clever and kids will love it. My sister and I went to see this and the place was full of kids who just loved it! We had no idea what was going on as the whole story is obviously in Vietnamese but you can get the jist by from the performance and program.The show goes for about an hour and there are 4 shows a night. My recommendation is pay the extra for a closer seat, it really isnt expensive and also as soon as you get to Hanoi go to the theatre during the day and get tickets as we had to book a few days in advance.
A must do in Hanoi. The water puppet theater in Hanoi is absolutely wonderful.

Technically impressive when you think about it, and funny also. We hadn't planned to go see the water puppetry, but as we walked past, we decided, why not. For $3, it's a cheap hour. Technically it is actually very impressive and creative, doing all the action you see on the water stage. They have rice planting, coconut picking, horse races, dragons and fireworks. I mean that is some pretty serious puppetry. And very well done.For some reason, the movie Team America comes to mind, but in a good kind of way. If you don't take it too seriously, we found it to be pretty funny.

Especially Kind there. We came late to the performance because I had an accident and had to go to the hospital for second degree burns. Not only did they let us in for the last few minutes (the show is very charming and delightful), but when we exited, the woman at the counter saw my bandaged fingers, asked if I wanted to see the show from the beginning, told us to wait on the benches nearby, and then let us in to the subsequent show for free. I thought it was terribly kind.

Worth visiting it!!!. The show is typical of the Vietnamese culture, so it's worth visiting the theater. You may be bored a little, but it's something traditional, so you must do it. The ticket for the show is not very expensive, so it would be better if you book the "expensive" one. You can take pictures during the performance, though you have to pay extra (60.000 D) .The music is really nice and you get the chance to see traditional instruments. Keep in mind that the tickets might be sold out, so decide early if you want to go.

Excellent! Creative! Very good!. The vietnamese are very creative for coming up with something so authentic! I give 6 stars to this performance. Every tourist MUST visit this place. Or it wouldn't be a complete one!
Something to do. For 5 bucks some A/C it's worth it. It should be 15'minutes not 45 but oh well. Like I said, it's something to do.

Uniquely Entertaining.. I really loved the Water Puppet Show. I had read mixed reports on TA so I wasn't expecting too much, but I was pleasantly surprised. It was wonderful. Something very different than anything I had seen before. The seats are elevated so everyone gets a good view and every seat in the theatre was taken. It lasted around 1 hour so it wasn't too long. The traditional music and clothes as well as the puppets made for great entertainment. Don't miss it.

There are better things to do in Hanoi. We were really looking forward to the water puppet theatre - recommended by both our travel guide and tripadvisor, it had to be good. However, it was quite dissapointing. It does not cost anything really so it's not like it's a loss of money. But you are in there for almost an hour of just the same thing all over. I guess it's fun to go to with kids, but I would not really recommend this to anyone except for families.
Really relax time in Hanoi. I got chance to see Water Puppet show after our Hanoi City tour finish,i only pay $5 for ticket and that is excellent show that visitors never forget.good for children
Boring. I went with my 6 and 8 yr old. the 6 yr. old and I were bored out of our minds, it was really bad is all I can say. For some reason the 8 yr. old loved it. It was a waste of time IMO.

Come Prepared With Your Sense of Humour. I would say that the majority of the crowd with us that night were not amused with the show at all. Can't blame them. The puppets are not well maintained, the scenes a bit too simple to appreciate and one has the feeling that the ticket is overpriced for the kind of entertainment provided.But my partner and I enjoyed the show immensely. The music was performed live, the musicians were great and the scenes gave us many opportunities to make up our own story lines (the whole show was in the local tongue). We were in stitches. Watch out for the fire scene, I laughed like no one's business.Point is: you're in Hanoi, you sample whatever that is offered and enjoy yourself. This is much better than using the money to buy something at the night market only to find out that you paid triple the actual price.

Good experience!. I’d rate it 5 just for the live music you get to hear all along the show; very impressive musical instruments. As for the puppets’ show itself, I found that a bit childish but it was a nice experience, kids in the room appreciated it more than we did! I think you have to do it once because it’s part of the culture.

Show a bit manic.Not exactly what I expected.A respite from the heat.. Bought 60k tickets which were fine.No need to splash out (no pun intended).O.k if you have nothing else to do & its cool inside. A bit like watching your 3 year old kid playing with dolls in the bath.I expected puppets to glide on the water but some were almost submerged.Fireworks a bit of a damp squib.( again no pun intended)Made me want to giggle at the thought of us actually being there:)If you want to see a historic "art form" don't expect much more.It did give us & fellow travelers that we met a great deal to laugh about in conversation :)Not wanting to run it down but to give advice as LP says it's a must see & I don't agree.

Seen it 4 times, still love it. Every time we are Hanoi, the water puppet theatre is on must list, it's one folk art with many hundred years history, show did not change much all these year, just one genuine art from far away time, still practice today.

Mmmmm........yes, well what can I say???. Most of the time we were watching battered puppets fighting with one another or just splashing around in the water. This we found amusing at times and had to laugh at how ridiculous it was. However, we did enjoy the music which had a haunting sound to it, though the muscains had as much expression as the puppets. I think even they, were wishing they were else where.

Great performance. The Water Puppet Show was a great and unusual experience for me. I loved the music which is very much different what we are used to, the small band seemed professional for me. The show was very colorful, eventful, but a little bit short. I felt a bit of rush, otherwise everything was ok.

Good for a little light entertainment. Not the greatest show on earth but for the money and spending 45 minutes worth a look and was quite entertaining.Tried to book ahead and it was all full but go to the box office about 10-15 mins before the performance you want and they should have some spare tickets.

Good bit of culture. worth a visit.. went to the show. tickets booked the day we arrived (today) by hotel. 100,000vnd each. shows book really quickly, so best to book in advance if want a daytime or early evening show. ours was at 8pm, was nice to walk around hanoi and hoan kiem lake at night to get there and back. show was quite loud and full. lasted for about 45 mins, with music, singing to support water puppets. would like to have had some leaflet to explain the story as all singing was in vietnamese, but this did not spoil the show as was interesting. well worth a visit. also try the bar beneath the puppet theatre and try mango shake, it was absolutely divine!

Quick show small audience. The show wasn't really what I was expecting (sticks Vs strings), but I still enjoyed the show nonetheless. As much as everyone talks about the water puppets you must go and experience for yourself best seat in the house was only 10 dollars.

I like it!. Despite what a personal friend and some reviews said, I find it entertaining. Music and singing were of good quality and puppets funny; something different, family friendly and entertaining. Remember to obtain tickets prior to your show, sometimes a day in advance

average experience. Definitely mix reviews. I didn't really like the water puppetry itself while my cousin did. I already went in with low expectations from ppl's reviews, the puppetry movements for me didn't impress me as much. Though it is an interesting concept water puppetry but I guess I expected it to be better executed. The best part I thought was the live band and singers even though I didn't understand a word of Viet. After the show don't head for the stairs. Make a left and there is an area filled with some of the puppets. good photo op. For the price it's ok to check it out. Also, it was hard to enjoy the show when lots of ppl in front of you are taking pics with there flash on.

One of Hanoi's highlights. Our guide used a bit of initiative and added this attraction to our tour. He charged us $8 a head and I see he must have made a $5 a head profit. No one in our party complained at the price and it was a most enjoyable 45 minutes show and quite unlike anything I had ever seen before.The seven piece live band were particularly good and complemented the excellent water puppetry.After the show there is quite a good shop where you can buy puppets at reasonable prices.

band was the highlight. My husband and I were quite pleased with the water puppetry show. We both really enjoyed the live band, and to see some unusual instruments native to Vietnam. The show is only $3 per ticket, and you really get a genuine experience of traditional culture. I would recommend anyone to see the water puppetry show.

$2USD ticket - good value, good fun... The $5USD ticket - ummm.. maybe!!!. Yes, this is a bit tacky and could be viewed as a tourist trap but when you are only spending 40,000 dong (US$2) or 60,000 dong (US$3) for a 45 minute performance, then its ok! This is the second time to have visited the Water Puppet Theater in Hanoi and it did seem better than 5 years ago, although I don't know why! Its very cheap for the afternoon shows that are 40,000 dong. But the price rises quickly and the evening shows are 100,000dong (US$5) per ticket. This is probably a bit expensive for this activity. The show is interesting, the chairs are too tightly packed, quite uncomfortable if you are taller than 6.0 (ft) but the show is just 45 minutes so you are able to get in/get out quite quickly. If you've some time in Hanoi, there isn't much else to do other than take your pick of restaurants and wait for your next trip to Halong Bay, Sapa or elsewhere so why not give this a try. I doubt we will go see it for a third time but I would recommend to first time viewers just because its cheap and gives you something to so/see around the old quarter.

Tacky tourist 'attraction'. The only people at this show were Western tourists. The seating is uncomfortable and the show is amateruish. The only explanation for the popularity of this show is the dearth of other entertainment in Hanoi.

Delightful. After reading previous reviews, I was expecting a shabby, run-down dump. But I was surprised to see a quality facility on par with any off-broadway theater. We must have gone after renovation. We did enjoy the performance, especially the live traditional musical accompaniment. We went to the box office on a Saturday afternoon and were unsuccessful in getting tickets for an evening performance that night or the next. We settled for a Sunday morning show.

Fantastic music and silly fun! Worth the $3 ticket!. After reading several negative reviews from other TripAdvisor members, my husband and I had low expectations for the Thang Long Water Puppet Show. After some debate, we decided to go ahead and see the historical show for ourselves. We knew it was unlikely to buy a ticket for a same day show, but got very lucky and had great seats. The music alone is worth the trip and the $3 ticket. I have never seen some of the musical instruments played at the show, and the musicians were incredibly talented. The old theatre and small seats added charm to the evening. Although the puppetry wasn't flawless, it was a great experience to see the water puppets in action. I laughed the entire show and thought it was perfectly silly and entertaining.In response to some of the negative reviews: the show is in Vietnam and should be in Vietnamese. I was unable to follow the plot, and it didn't take away from my experience in the least. The water was murky, but again, this is a small detail and did not distract me in the slightest. I really recommend this show to anyone who appreciates excellent music and a cultural experience.

It was ok. Puppet show was interesting for the culture aspect. It lasts about 45 minutes. Make sure you get there at 1pm to buy your tickets for the afternoon shows, because they sell out fast during peak tourism months. I wouldnt say its a must see, but im glad i saw it, but I wouldnt have been dissappointed if we missed it too. If you are taller then 5'5" then your knees will be shoved into the seat in front of you. They say you are not allowed to take picutres, but everyone was taking pics. If you got 1 hour to spare then spend it there.i think the tickets were 40000vnd per person.

Overrated Experience. We were excited to see this show, as my fiance is a performer and this was highly recommended by every guide book/website... Afterwards we were both like "whaaat?" and just relieved that we paid only a few dollars for tickets. The puppets don't have a wide range of movement, and most of the time they were half submerged in (dirty) water. The scenes are sloppily staged, if you do not read up on Vietnam history before the show, you will have absolutely no idea what is going on. The musicians, however, are terrific, and the puppets are preceded by a "dan bau" performance that we enjoyed. Only go if you have lots of free time in Hanoi!

Imaginative and very enjoyable.. This traditional performance was enjoyable,fun,colorful and very skillfully executed. The traditional music and singing which accompanied the water puppets was thoroughly enjoyable. Different

Disapointing.... “You have to go,” is what you will read in every guide book and hear from every travel agent. The truth is that you don’t. For being one of the city’s top attractions, we were greatly disappointed by the show. The theatre itself was decrepit and old. The atmosphere was musty. The lighting, sound systems, and seating were all sub-par. For being a major tourist attraction, you would think that the city would invest a little more time and money into the faciltity. The show itself may have been interesting if I understood the language, but I found nothing of value. It seemed very gimmicky and I actually fell asleep at some point only to be woken up by a poorly orchestrated fireworks show that was supposed to be erupting from a Dragon’s mouth. You can find something better to spend your hour doing, even if it is just sitting in a quiet café in a back alley.

Great cultural experience but if you're 5'10" or more like me get front row or aisle tickets. This would have been a worthwhile cultural experience - let's face it, it's $3 for the 'best' seats. The performance was charming and the faces of the musicians showed ecstacy as they played along.I must add though, the seats are not made with Western frames in mind. After 15 mins I was in agony with my knees jammed into the frame of the seats in front. If I'd been closer to the aisle I would have got up and sat on the steps. Maybe I'm too old as well as too tall but the pain was so intense I felt nauseous for half the performance.

Absolutely pathetically bad. I rarely ever make such a black and white statement about anything on Trip Advisor, but take my word for it, the whole Thanh Long Water Puppet Theater experience - in the big main old "theater" next to Hoan Kiem lake - is a joke. It reminded me of the movie "Team America: World Police", which was at least intending to be sarcastic and funny.The theater itself is falling apart. The entrance is a mixture of falling apart and mid-fix-up: anywhere else if the West and parts of Asia would have it covered up, or closed for renovation for safety reasons. Not here: it's a naked collapsing mess for the naked eye. The building itself it falling apart. Our tour guide in Hue told us that the Vietnamese often intentionally let things fall into disrepair until a world organization like UNESCO or a UN office or a foreign charity agrees to pay for fix-up: this must be one of those cases.The ticket seller - apparently the same one as a previous December 2010 poster had - is rude and useless, rarely looking up from her cell phone and tickets. No easily understood information is signed for availability: yes there are signs with times, but even the day before, most of that day's and the next days's tickets are sold out - in our case, there was a hand-written sign that said only "9:30" on it, which apparently meant only 9:30AM show tickets for the next day were still available. Because of the ticket seller's attitude and no other apparent desk or office in sight, it didn't seem like much use trying to find out more either.Tickets are cheap: $3 up front and $2 mid to back. Front is fine, but the seats are uncomfortable for people over 5 and half feet or so, they are made for the generally smaller Vietnamese frame I suppose. Still, for an hour or so you can make it.There are signs saying you can pay to take pictures in advance or after, but it seems to run on trust, and most tourists seemed to abuse that totally, with no one enforcing it. Despite the laughably poor quality of the show, they still ought to disallow cameras: it's a darkened room for much of the show, and whatever mood there is is totally ruined by constant flashes and camera sounds throughout. The show itself is the anti-Cirque-du-Soleil. There's a water pit in the front at seat level, with a background ancient VN-looking "building" behind it with faux grass curtains on the bottom floor hiding the puppeteers. To the left are the musicians and two singers. The show is about an hour. The announcer speaks in English with a heavy, easily misunderstood accent. The musicians are all right, and the two VN female singers were perhaps the only good thing about the show.The show is intended to be about life and culture in VN over the past couple hundred years. The puppets themselves are papier-mache or whatever, about a foot tall each, attached under the water by what looks like poles that you can't see, and the puppeteers move the puppets around seemingly over the water and between each other and back and forth over the water. Getting all the crossing poles right must take a lot of skill; however, that skill is not in sight at this theater (well, at least we didn't see poles getting banged up on each other).The puppets are well worn and well dated - at some point this has gone beyond nostalgia and antique into just junkiness. The puppeteers can't seem to get their puppets to move around and dance in sync. Some puppets have little wicks and fire effects (with little candles on them) but the puppeteers repeatedly unintentionally got them doused in the water by puppetting without care. The entire stage looks like it's falling apart, sometimes the lit puppets would bang up against the faux grass curtains as the puppets went back into the back and it looked like the fire would set the curtains ablaze (thankfully this did not happen). The water itself is so full of floating garbage that it's sometimes distracting and wholly unsavory looking.I can not overstate how bad this is. That is not to say the concept or location aren't fantastic: they need a LOT of work. The building needs fixing. The ticket attendant needs to be replaced. The staff overall needs training. The stage itself needs an overhaul, the sound system for the narrator needs replacing, the puppets themselves need replacing, and the puppeteers need more training.I would seriously suggest that the management contact Cirque du Soleil - quietly, privately - and spend some money to get them to consult on how to overhaul this thing. Until then, absolutely do not bother unless you like to see a trainwreck of a "performance".

a Culturistic performance. Firstly, I am not a theater person as I usually feel like dozing off into 10 minutes into the show. Secondly, I first knew about this water puppet show as NatGeo had an episode that covered it.The building was under going renovations on the first floor when I went, so I was instantly surprised when we got up to the second floor and led into the cosy theatre. The music accompanied the water puppet show perfectly and it just amazes me how the people controlling the water puppets behind the curtains can withstand the heavy weight of some puppets. There was some scenes where by the curtains was pulled aside to introduce new puppets and the audience could make out people using their hands to push the puppets forward. It was a slight turn off but it was inevitable I guess. Major annoyance was when inconsiderate tourists snap pictures with their flash on.I really appreciate the part whereby the show's ending and all of the cast members come out from backstage and gave a thank you bow to the audience. It was really sincere and you could assume that they are really determined into preserving this wonderful heritage, the Thang Long Water Puppet Theater.

A must must thing to do. We have tried in the Hochiminh city but in here, it was much better than what you saw in the south side. Everything was the same but the only different thing was the performance. It was a big different and much more skillfuler. A must must thing to do

Excellent water puppet Show but rude ticket seller. I enjoyed Thang Long water puppet Show. This program is excellent and very funny. All my family members are interested. One thing that makes me unhappy is the ticket seller. She worked very slowly and speaking mobile phone, people waiting is very frustrating.

Don't expect too much and you won't be disappointed. As long as you are not expecting too much from this puppet show, you won't be disappointed. A series of short skits designed for entertaining young children not accustomed to the way of the xbox. Performances are simple and the accompanying orchestra is good insight into traditional Vietnamese music. The skits depict aspects of life and myths from the rice paddies. They are not a single storyPerformances are a little degraded by the flashing of camera from audience members who do not realise that the puppetry is too far away to be lit by their feeble flashes, or have no idea how to turn the flash off on their camera. I think this would have been wonderful to see before the advent of cameras in the rice paddiesThe introduction of fire to the shows has increased the entertainment value - however, be sure to note where your nearest fire exit is and have your escape plan ready ;)TIP: get your tickets the day before or you may miss out on the show that you want to see

Hilarious for the wrong reasons. Worth a watch but don't expect high culture.. We went to the show on the back of a glowing recommendation from the Lonely Planet - I can only assume that the LP reviewer saw a different version. Although the music was particularly good, the overall impression was one of disorganisation and of lucklustre puppeteers. At some points the show was almost embarassing for the audience: the musicians talking and laughing when they were not performing and two puppeteers wading into the performance area to retrieve a puppet that had become caught on a fixed prop. It's hard not to come away with the impression that the producers know that they can wheel out the same mediocre performance night after night to an audience of tourists who will applause regardless.Having said the above, at $3 the show is worth a watch as it is a unique spectacle and is only an hour long. How it has such a good score from reviewers on this site is, however, a mystery to me.

A sweet experience worth seeing. I was a little worried that this would be an exploitive tourist trap, and yes, there were bus loads of tourists who I wish would learn to turn their flash off. I found it a nice escape from the bustle of Hanoi - and I especially liked the music which is live (the first two songs showcase the talents of the musicians - one of whom played a solo on a stringed instrument (I think it's called an Erhu) that for me was a highlight of the show. The cost is next to nothing (pay extra for the better seats - I think it's a buck more) and don't bother to do it as part of tour. We just showed up and got second row seats - well worth a late afternoon break from walking around Hoan Kiem Lake (shows are every 1.5 hours from around 3pm to 9pm).

Amusing, creative, and artisitic, if simple, fun.. I read reviews here before going, and was expecting it to be boring, but it was not at all. The music alone was worth the 2 dollars. I found it to be quite funny, and did not need to speak Vietnamese to enjoy it. It is so short, I cannot fathom how anyone would be bored - and it is a puppet show, so don't expect much more, and you'll have a great time. I've paid many times more and had much worse experiences in the theater.

Book early or go at showtime. The theater was "sold out" for the days we were there, but on the advice of our hotel we went and waited at the ticket office. The people in front of us were turned away, but tickets appeared when we got to the window. Once the program began the empty seats were counted and more people were ushered in. We could only purchase the $2 ticket, but when the show began I moved up to the front row ($3 seat) and was happy I did. It is a fun show.

water puppetry in Hanoi. We weren't sure quite what to expect but it was quite entertaining. Water pupperty originally started in the 11th century, performed on ponds and flooded rice paddies in the Red river delta in Northern Vietnam. The country folk believed (and many still do) that spirits controlled every aspect of their lives, from cooking to farming, so worshipped kitchen gods and rice gods etc, and invented water puppetry as a means of worshipping them. Nowadays the shows take place in a theatre, but the stage is still water. I spent the show trying to figure out where the strings were as I couldn't see them. It wasn't until the end when a bamboo screen was lifted to reveal the puppeteers standing waist deep in the pool that I realised the wooden marionettes are controlled using long bamboo rods from beneath rather than strings from above. An orchestra and singers play traditional music to accompany the several short stories acted out on the water. All the stories have a rural theme - fishing, farming, harvest, etc - based on Vietnamese folklore, and are in Vietnamese, so couldn't follow everything, but generally got the gist . Particularly enjoyed the one about the legend of the returned sword as we'd seen the tortoise that is supposedly the star of the story earlier on in the Ngoc Son temple.

Very special and traditional. We really enjoyed the show, it was a great performance and activities to represent the face of Hanoi including a historic, traditional side and modern side. The entry is not really expensive and its location is perfect - right in front the Hoan Kiem Lake, very easy to find out.

A delightful introduction to Vietnamese cultural traditions. My friend and I saw the Thang Long water puppets on our first night in Hanoi (August 27, 2010). In just 55 minutes we were introduced to the main features of Vietnamese agricultural life, the country's symbolic animals (dragon, turtle, phoenix and unicorn), and Hanoi's founding legend. The brightly-painted puppets were full of personality, there was some gentle humour, and the manipulation of the puppets on the water 'stage' was very skilful. The whole performance, including the accompaniment on traditional instruments, was delightful and not to be missed. Afterwards I bought an irresistibly cute turtle ($US7) as a souvenir. Jan (Auckland, New Zealand)
Interesting show. Its full of turists, ok, but I think it's an interesting show. Music and actors make you get inside the performance.
Funny show. I enjoyed the music and the funny puppets. However I have to say, the lady ticket seller was extremely rude, on the phone all the time and no eye contact.

Didnt get past rude ticket seller. We got as far as the ticket booth where the woman inside couldnt be bothered to even look up to see what we wanted . .until we started insisting that she pay a bit of attention to us and speaking up loudly. ( We were very polite in doing so I might add, trying not to be rude in return) We were the only ones in front of her booth at the time and she was busy chatting with a friend. No smile, no eye contact, no information given. With this kind of treatment of the paying public, it is a wonder anyone goes at all! We will not go back nor will we attend the show.

Must see show in Hanoi. Among all the tourist spots in town, I would say this is the must see cultural show in Hanoi, and it is so special which only available in Hanoi. The length of the show is just right. A great way to spend your night.
not to recommend. full of tourists.very long, horrible...Cheap touristic show.

Go so you can say you've seen it. I agree with Johann's review, it's not for everybody. The theatre holds about 400 and is packed every night. If you're over 175 cm (5 foot 6) you will find the seats too close together and the atmosphere very hot. I found it amusing for about 15 minutes, but by the end it was very repetitive. Some people DID leave early (most couldn't get out if they tried), while others found it so fascinating they stayed around after the show to take photos of the musicians. It only lasts an hour, but don't expect a fantastic night of entertainment. 'Charming' is a better description.
Fantastic. Come to enjoy yourself and have a smile as these water puppets preform a talented show. Best $3 USD spend in Hanoi, the actors and musicians are quite talented, had an enjoyable night.

Great & special show. I must say that Water Puppet show is really attractive traditional thing in Vietnam. The advice is that although there are many different show per day, you should come directly to Thang Long Water Puppet Theater to get your availability at least one day before. The theater is always busy. Only about 3USD you can have a fist class seat. And, opposite the Theater, you can do a walking tour to visit Hoan Kiem Lake & Ngoc Son Temple.

The good theater!. People must come to this place. Price were 60.000 VND. My kid (12 years) enjoyed the water puppet show very much. There are many things that's people can find and understand more about Vietnamese. Very funny and entertaining.
Best 3 dollars you'll spend in Hanoi. This is a lovely attraction. Very cheap and very charming, dripping with culture.

Coolest Puppet Show Around. This water puppet show was the highlight of my trip to Hanoi, They are incredibly skillful and they have been doing this type of show for a very long time, The cost was not expensive and I loved it, I was amazed at how the people behind the screen could control the puppets in front of the screen so well, A must see in Hanoi

so nice and wonderful. Thang Long water puppet theater just very near to Hoan Kiem lake. It gave me a very nice and wonderful experience. All the show were in a water, they show about vietnamese story, history ... The performance also had live music. Very interesting.

Bizarre but fun!. This is a definite must-see in Hanoi. Its a bit strange but very entertaining! The puppeteers are very skillful and the simple story lines are interesting and fun. A word of warning- the seats in the theatre are absolutely tiny! I am 5 ft 7 and I could just about fit my legs in. If you are much taller than me then you would be pretty uncomfortable, although the show does only last an hour.

Traditonal Vietnamese view. They show us a history of vietnam, all the show on water and the people need to stay under the water for all the show. They also have a live music and vietnamese musical instrument They under the water to monitor the show.this is the first time i watch this type of show, i fell very exciting and wonderful. I can have a new experience of this water show. So wonderful

Unique and Attractive. We bought tickets for first class seats because wanted to see clearly. It is 60,000VND/ticket. My sons (3 years and 8 years) enjoyed the water puppet show very much. The traditional music can make you fallen asleep especially if you are already in a sleeping mood. Overall the puppet show is quite attractive and unique as it is performing on the water surface. For peak season, you have to buy the ticket a day or a few days before because it considers a "must see" when you visit Hanoi.

A Nice Cultural Experience, but not for Everybody. This type of water puppetry dates back to the 11th century, about 1,000 years ago. It started as a way to rid rice plantations of evil spirits, and soon grew into entertainment for ancient villages, and is unique to Northern Vietnam (though it's now shown in Saigon as well). Now, watching puppet shows of any kind may sound really boring for you - and if that is what you are suspecting, then you are probably right. And yes, this is actually a puppet show, with all the dialogue in Vietnamese (no English translation). So, before spending an hour of your time on this, think to yourself if watching a puppet show where you don't even understand what people are saying can still be worth it for you, even at a cost of just $4.00, given that you'll be exposed to beautiful live traditional Vietnamese music, and expertly done puppetry, as well as a little cultural exposure to ancient Vietnam. If the answer is "that sounds really stupid" then this show is definitely not for you and you will have a much nicer time elsewhere in Hanoi.For me, it was a treat. Granted, I sat as a full grown adult watching a puppet show for an hour, but the traditional Vietnamese music was what did it for me. It is performed live, beautifully done, very nice to sit and listen to, and the puppetry is done to the beat of the music. The skills of the puppeteers were excellent, it was well choreographed, and the orchestra was in traditional costume. The water puppets themselves were interesting to see, as they are typical Vietnamese, and I've never seen anything quite like them before - handmade and colorful. It only lasts an hour, costs only $4.00 (well worth the extra $2.00 to upgrade to the VIP seats for a total of $6.00), and is a nice break in a day of sightseeing and hot sunshine.The downsides of the experience are that the seats are miniature, so at 6'2", I had to sit sideways down the aisle, and after the show started, I immediately moved to an aisle seat so I could remotely exist in the seats. There was no way I could extend my legs. There is one seat in the very back that is at the end of the aisle, so you have nobody in front of you - this was a godsend, as we booked too late and the front row seats were already sold out (the whole show was sold out actually). The narration and dialogue are entirely in Vietnamese, so you don't know what they're saying - you can follow the acts, because they're pretty basic, but it would be nice if they put a subtitle board up or something so everyone could enjoy the story, which might have been a nice one, I'll never know. Cameras are allowed, but they ask you to pay a dollar or so if you want to take photos, or $5.00 if you want to take videos. They're working on the honor system, though, trusting you to be honest about your intentions, so it's not enforced, it's just up to you to decide how you want to handle it. Basically, I was able to appreciate this for the cultural experience that it was, and also as a nice break in the day where I could listen to some new traditional music - some other people were sleeping, but at the end of the show some even gave a standing ovation, and nobody walked out early. Now, if I just focused on the puppet show in Vietnamese as pure entertainment, I would probably have been sleeping too. Definitely not for everyone, but I'm happy I took an hour out to see it, and it's right by the lake, so you can walk from there out and about or take a cyclo ride.

Loved the water puppets!. I loved the water puppets and was enthralled for almost the entire show. Technically it is amazing what they can do with the puppets, and the entire effect is beautiful. I am a nearly-thirty year old and felt like a little kid enjoying this show. My brother (also nearly-thirty) was slightly less amused but still glad to have seen it. Besides, at a few dollars for a ticket there's no reason not to go. Side note: my hotel, the Jasmine (recommended) bought my tickets for me so I didn't even have to stand in line.

very uncomfortable seating. I probably wasn't in the right state of mind to enjoy the show. The leg room was tiny, and it was very uncomfortable to have to sit there for about an hour. With the surface of the water as a stage, the show was interesting (at first), but not quite entertaining. Because it was entirely in Vietnamese, I couldn't get beyond just seeing puppets moving around. I'm sure that if you can follow the stories, it would have been much more entertaining. After 10-15 minutes, the novelty just worn off for me, making my seat feel even more discomfort.

Hysterically awful, a once in a lifetime experience. You have to go and see this for the fun of it and the 'cultural' experience. It is like something you have never seen before and will never see again! It does get a little boring after about 10 mins so don't expect extreme excitement, but if u can see the funny side of it, it's just so random!

Bia Hoi helped this experience!!. This was very culturally enlightening, and very entertaining. For those who found it boring, I would suggest beer... it helps. Air conditioning is lovely and cool, and the theater is pleasant. Watch out for the courting cockerils who produce an egg and then a chick. Overall, well worth 40,000 VND!!

Hugely overrated - My kids and i were bored. We paid for the cheap seats - which if truth be known are not actually that far from the stage since the theatre is small. After about 10 minutes i was waiting for the end, i found it boring, unimpressive - and at one point had to tell my daughter not to go to sleep. There is no doubt that those who control the puppets have a skill, but its not amazing. It is apparently hundreds of years old, well the fact that this place is one of the only place in the world that still tries to cling onto water puppets really goes to how how the rest of the world were not impressed and thus gave it up as a bad idea.I found the music basic at best, the musicians were sat laughing and joking when it was not their part and the puppets repetitive and boring. Not even worth the pittance i paid to get in. Was not impressed at all, still if you do go, when you get bored just know that when the dragons in the water start trying to get the ball there is only about 5 mins left.

Traditional but entertaining for all. Thoroughly enjoyed the experience of sitting in a comfortable, air conditioned auditorium for an hour of pure entertainment. The program was presented as a series of short vignettes and although all in Vietnamese, they were easily understandable. Each was so short that it was impossible to get bored and the whole thing represented great value for money. You could only wonder at the skills of the puppeteers and when they all present themselves at the end, it was fun to see them in their wet weather gear. Go see it!

kids will love it. This is a traditional show - you don't have to be a rocket scientist to understand the story and if you are visiting a foreign country don't be so arrogant to expect 'subtitles or translation' Just enjoy it for what it is and maybe read a bit about it before you go. Lasts just over an hour, sure not everyone will like it, I'm pretty cynical generally and I found it quite charming. Kids will love it.

A Nice traditional show. Thang Long water puppet is a show that becomes a tradition for thousand years in North Vietnam. Because the show performed on the surface of ponds and rice-fields thousand years ago, it is also performed on the same way in the theatre nowadays.The stage contains a small ponds with greenery water and bamboo curtains at the back to hide the figure of the player.Tickets are sold in 2 classes:1. First class, costs VND 60,000 (1 USD = VND 17,500)2. Second class, costs VND 40,000Performances take place all days of the week.Time15:30 PM - 17:00 PM - 18:30 PM - 20:00 PM - 21:15 PMSunday morning: 9:30 AM ( especially discount 50% ticket price for youngsters)In the brochure it is stated that you have to pay VND 15,000 for taking pictures with camera and VND 60,000 for capturing a movie/video. Inside the theatre, everybody ignore this note and just take pictures and movies freely.As I told you, you must be a tradition and culture lover if you want to see this show. Otherwise, it will be very boring for you and you will feel like wasting your precious and limited time in Hanoi/Vietnam.For little ones, I am pretty sure that they will love the show because it is interesting to see the puppets appear and dissapear from the water, dancing and perform on the surface of the water, and so on.The whole show takes about 45 minutes, covering 17 scenes, not related to each other:1. Raising the Festival Flag2. Chu Teu or the narrator3. Dragon Dance: Four Dragons dancing on the surface of water4. On a buffalo with a flute5. Agriculture (planting the rice field)6. Catching frogs7. Rearing ducks and catching a fox8. Fishing9. Harvest festival. Returning to the native land after college graduation. A triumphant return of a new graduate to his native village aim at expressing his gratitude to the anchestors.10.Lion dance11. Phoenix dance (ended with having a big white egg, interesting)12. Legend of the Restored Sword; King Le Loi after triumphing over Ming invaders, gave the magic sword back to a giant golden turtle who lived in the Lake. This legend is associated with Hoan Kiem Lake or Lake of the Restored Sword which is located in front of the Thang Long Theatre.13. Children playing in the water14. Boat racing15. Unicorns play with a ball16. Fairy dance17. Dance of four holy animalsTips from me:A. Buy the front row seats (A, B, C, D). At the back seats you will see nothing except people's heads in front of you.B. Be at the place at least half an hour to make your chance bigger in getting the front row seats. The best is to book it online or through someone you know in Hanoi previously like I did.C. Don't try to relate one scene to another because it does not have any relationship at all.Last but not least: enjoy the show!
Almost impossible to like. Very boring- dont waste a night. There is no understandable story for the majority of people. We walked out- bit rude but we only had 2 nights! Please don't bother!

A fun and illuminating cultural experience!. The water puppet show takes place in a small theater -- both first and second class tickets will buy you good seats. Be sure to purchase your tickets a few days in advance, as shows are often sold out due to bulk purchases by tour groups. The show is a quick 45 minutes or so, and it is a really fun experience. Musicians play traditional Vietnamese instruments and the puppeteers hide under a stage and behind some curtains as they maneuver the colorful wooden puppets to the music, portraying various aspects of traditional rural life. Yes, the show is in Vietnamese, but that's part of the cultural experience! As you enter the theater, you can pick up a free pamphlet in English, which briefly describes the art form and the series of "dances" you'll encounter. That is more than enough to give you the context you need to understand the show -- the rest is up to you, your imagination, and your sense of cultural appreciation! It was well worth the price ($3-4) and one of the most enjoyable parts of our trip to Hanoi!P.S. Some of the scenes can be a bit scary for young children due to loud drums and flashing lights. Suitable for preschool aged and up!

It's an Institution - Of course it's a must see. I'd start by saying that you either love it or hate it. It is in an enclosed air-conditioned (although it may may not be that cool tempreture wise) theater just opposite the Hoan Kiem lake.The three of us loved it. I had reservations about watching it initially because I am not a cultural performance buff. However, we are glad we did go. Yes, it was all in Vietnamese but then again, how can it be authentic if it was done in a foreign language? At 60,000 Dong (roughly USD3.60), you simply cannot miss it - and it is not about the money either.You are given a pamphlet with a title or a one line description of each of the 17 scenes lasting about an hour. Knowing what each scene is about, we found it fairly easy to understand what the puppeteers are trying to convey - which is basically of local beliefs and of everyday life. Figuring it out was half the fun. Think of how the puppeteers do it and you'd be more appreciative.Yes, there were some people in the audience who were sleeping (I would like to think that it was because of their hectic tour itinery more than anything else) but most were interested and attentive. Go see it and remember that this type of entertainment has long history as well - well before most entertainment must sees as we know today.

Boring.... The only reason we went to the water puppet show was because it was included in our package deal. There were a few scenes that were cute or made me chuckle, but overall it was pretty boring. It was all in Vietnamese with no read along about the story or lyrics to the songs.

Language is a barrier here. It starts off with a 10-min musical introduction prior to the show, and this one is with English translation. However, the actual puppet show is all in Vietnamese. The only translation you can count on is the Program Sheet which you can take outside the entrance of the theatre. This pamphlet comes in both English and French,but don't count on it too much, for it only states the title of the chapters and nothing else. I do not understand Vietnamese, and so could only admire the skillfull maneuvers of the puppeteers behind the curtains. Unfortunately, you will not be able to comprehen the story the puppets are trying to tell. I would say this place is not a must-go, but no harm visiting if you have some time off. Tickets are at 40,000 dong. Photography during the 50-min show is allowed at no charge although the tickets states otherwise.

Over-rated Puppet show. If you are from any parts of Asia where puppet show is a norm, this Hanoi's version is short of surprises.The novelty of a water-based show wears out fast after 20 minutes. The melody, the tricks and lighting become too reptitive for an hour long show.Worst, there's no translations or subtitles to go with the singing which is a real pity.Still, you should visit this once if you are in Hanoi because there's nothing better to do besides eating and walking around the Old French Quarter.If you are one of those who believed every show has a 'spirit' behind, this one may be it. It was originally staged to worship 'deities' and provide entertainment during a flood so there you have it...the original sin...hehe...

Strings attached. Before you visit the puppet theatre, consider what forces tug the strings of those darling, dancing puppets. After meeting the theatre director and requesting photographs for a Hanoi magazine article I am writing, I did not receive them. So I returned to the theatre, opened the door of the corridor leading to her office and took two steps. Through the open door of a smoke-filled conference room, I was greeted by a flurry of pointing and barked commands to leave. Then two men rose up from the table and physically escorted me to the door. In 20 years of journalism, writing for publications scattered around the globe, I have never received treatment like that from any individual or organisation. [My source list includes reformed terrorists and hardened criminals]. About the only theatre employee capable of civility and communication was the outside security guard who had a second language [French] and [shudder] interpersonal skills.

A MUST SEE in Hanoi!. I caught the water puppet show on the last night of my trip, after I had gone on all the tours, after I had learned all about the Vietnamese legends and the culture. The show wraps up everything in one musical and cultural delight!This form of entertainment is found only in Vietnam, having originated from the farmers who would stage the shows in rice paddies or in shallow ponds. Set to traditinal Vietnamese music, courtesy of a live band and vocalists, the puppet show depicts Vietnamese legends, religious/cultural beliefs and their typical way of life. All scenes are depicted with the use of puppets that actually swim, dance, battle, climb trees, catch fish etc quite well!Buy your tickets early or ask the front desk of your hotel to secure tickets for you while you tour -- the seats sell like hotcakes and a lining up a few minutes late could cause you to line up the following afternoon. (really helps to ask the hotel's front desk to do it for you)Also, make sure you get yourself a copy of the program that has both a Vietnamese and English translation of the different scenes that are being depicted. The poor folks seated beside me without a program were quite lost.I'm really glad I caught this show and I really recommend it to anyone looking for an entertaining and delightful way of capping off their visit to Hanoi.

A must see while in Hanoi. The show takes less than one hour - and it a MUST when visiting Hanoi. Try getting seats at row A, B or C - it's hard to see what's going on further back. We sat at row H - with children. They couldn't see a lot - and the staff is not as friendly as you would expect. But excellent show.

Surprisingly Entertaining. I went there with a cynical mind since I have never been a fan of puppet show. Also, coming from an Asian background, I was certain that I would not be particularly intrigued by it. However, I surprised myself by staying for the entire hour. The puppets were amazingly agile and I couldn't help wondering about the immense skills needed to control the puppets. For the price (40,000 dong for front row seats), I would say it is quite worth the experience. What I hated about the experience: The cramped theatre and the limited leg space. Also, the constant flash from the photography of the tourist was distracting.

Book asap!. Reading previous reviews had not prepared us for how booked out the water puppet theatre was. The booking clerk flipped through day after day of totally booked out performances, stretching at least weeks into the future. It looked to me as though there were large numbers of block booking, obviously agents etc. We were lucky to be able to get seats at all during our stay (which was not during the most busy period of the year either - April). But we did, and the experience was well worth it.

Vietnamese culture for a song. We were there last Friday night at 5:20 pm but the cheaper tickets for the first two shows were all sold out!The short skits offer a glimpse of the historical and cultural events, and rural life in Vietnam. Everything's in Vietnamese and it's a pity that there was no brochure to explain the performances. Still, we got to hear live singing and music played on traditional Vietnamese instruments, and watch highly skilled puppetry performed in a pool of water.. And some parts are just so humourous! Simply amazing.. We're glad we didn't miss it!Tips:- Ticket prices: 20,000 VND for Class 2 and 40,000 VND for Class 1 (USD1 = 16,000 VND). You can pay extra if you want a CD. And Class 1 seats are worth the extra dollar!- 3 shows a day: 5:15pm, 6:30pm and 8:00pm.

A must do in Hanoi - you'll love it!. Water Puppet (Mua Roi Nuoc) show at the Thang Long Water Puppet Theatre is a must do during your visit to Hanoi. There are two shows a night and even though it's all done in Vietnamese, it's very enjoyable. A traditional Vietnamese orchestra with singers provides background music for the show. There are several short puppet shows each lasting about 3-4 minutes. The entire show is performed by puppeteers standing in the water behind a screen as they maneouver the puppets. It's pretty inexpensive and very impressive and you can take photos.

Worth the money. My husband was sceptical to watch the Water Puppets at first but after the show, he was absolutely sold to it. He said the show was all worth it ! The show lasted for an hour and they have upgraded the seats. The seats are very tight from row to row but they are now all elevated so it doesn't matter if you sit on the 3rd row and beyond. Unfortunately, the story telling was all in Vietnamese but the water puppets are so amazing ! The front row seats only cost U$2.5 so very very cheap. You will never regret it ...

Magic!. We went to the 6.15 show, arrived at 6. There were plenty of seats at that stage but it filled quickly. We were in the front row having paid less than a dollar extra, it's worth it. You also get a CD of the music, ideal for editing your video when you get home. Both still and video cameras are allowed and contrary to what our guide book told us, we didn't have to pay extra to film.The show itself began with some Vietnamese singing and music, interesting. And then the magic began. The movement of these huge and multi-parted puppets was incredible, at times you couldn't believe what you were seeing. Firecrackers add to the illusion. Room is warm but pick up a free fan on the way in.Only tip I'd give is to walk a couple of minutes when you get out before taking a taxi. We got one directly outside and were totally ripped-off, our only negative taxi experience in Vietnam.
